DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 1, or the fourth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Mongkut, king of Siam, dies at the age of 64. In only 17 years he implemented sweeping political, economic and social changes with western help.
1916: National Peking University Professor Hu Shih's proposal that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style wins quick acceptance.
1918: T. E. Lawrence, the British officer known as "Lawrence of Arabia" and the Arab forces of Emir Faisal capture Damascus from the Turks.
1920: The Peking government cracks down on Russian settlements in China.
1921: The Chinese Communist Party sets up its branch in Hunan Province with Mao Tse-tung as its secretary.
1924: Jimmy Carter, an American peanut farmer who became the 39th president of the United States, is born. He was instrumental in getting Israel and Egypt to sign the Camp David agreement ending hostilities between the two countries.
1936: General Francisco Franco Bahamonde, 44, is proclaimed "Chief of the Spanish State" by the nationalist military junta trying to seize power in Spain.
1946: The International War Crimes Tribunal in Nuremberg sentences 12 Nazi leaders to death.
1947: The Japanese Ministry of Education abrogates the name of Kyoto Imperial University.
1949: The Chinese communists set up a regime in Beijing with Mao Tse-tung as party chairman. The regime was recognized by the Soviet Union the next day.
1956: The ROC government implements regulations governing distribution of land to retired servicemen.
1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, a U.S. government agency that conducts and coordinates research on flight within and beyond the earth's atmosphere, is formally set up as an independent agency headquartered in Washington, D.C.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Nigeria.
1964: Japan's "bullet train" makes its first journey from Tokyo to Osaka.
1965: A coup attempt by Indonesian communists is crushed by Suharto, an army officer who becomes president of Indonesia two years later.
1969: The sound barrier is broken by the Concorde 001 during a test flight in France.
1972: Louis Leakey, British archaeologist and anthropologist, dies in London at the age of 69. He discovered the 1,750,000-year-old Zinjanthropus fossil at Olduvai Gorge and the contemporaneous "Homo habilis" at Lake Natron in Tanzania between 1959 and 1964.
1974: The annual three-day meeting of the Sino-U.S. Cooperation Science Program is held in Taipei.
1975: Muhammad Ali beats Joe Frazier in a rematch in Manila. Ali had recaptured the world heavyweight title after defeating the fearsome George Foreman in a sensational upset in 1974. Frazier beat Ali in 1971.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Joseph A. Rice, president of the Irving Trust Company.
1976: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung leaves for Lesotho to attend a ceremony marking the kingdom's independence.
1982: Helmut Kohl is sworn in as West Germany's sixth chancellor, succeeding Helmut Schmidt.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification, and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1997: Gul Mohammed, the world's shortest man at 56 cm tall, dies.
1999: Taiwan announces the termination of flights to and from the Philippines after negotiators from the two sides failed in last-ditch efforts to address a stormy dispute over passenger quotas.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Every system of moral law must be based upon man's own consciousness. It must be verified by the common experience of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT VISITS MAYAN CULTURAL SITE
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu and Anita Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu visited a Mayan archaeological site in the northern tropical rain forests of Guatemala Saturday.
Lu visited the famous Tikal archaeological site accompanied by the wife and daughter of Guatemalan Vice President Juan Francisco Royes Lopez.

Lu climbed to the top of the steep second shrine in one stretch, and said that she was impressed by the grandeur of Mayan culture. She also said that she wishes to introduce Mayan culture to Taiwan people so that they will be able to appreciate its greatness.

Lu later attended a luncheon hosted by Guatemalan Vice Foreign Minister in her honor near Tikal, during which she spoke of her "journey of soft diplomacy" -- her ongoing four-state trip which also included El Salvador, Honduras and Belize.

Lu said that during her meetings with the leaders of the four states, she got a deeper understanding of their style and charisma. She noted that the president and vice president of El Salvador are both scholars-turn-politicians, and added that they have high expectations of economic development and the future of their country.

They are also young -- between 40 and 50 years of age -- and some emerged as national leaders from opposition parties, she said. Lu added that such experience and backgrounds make her and all those who have long fought for democracy and human rights in Taiwan feel close to them.

Lu noted that she couldn't see much during her whirlwind visit of the four countries. But she added that the aim of the trip was to cement diplomatic relations and to share the experience of Taiwan's democracy, human rights, technology and love with the allies, as well as to increase substantial cooperation with them.
Lu said that the warm hospitality she received during the trip was beyond her imagination, which showed the importance these countries attached to her visit. She added that she was deeply touched.

Lu also said that she had taken US$40,000 with her on the trip, and presented US$10,000 each to charity groups in each nation that she visited, in order to let people there feel Taiwan's love and caring.

After her return to Taiwan, she will also launch a drive to promote adopting underprivileged children in the four nations, with Taiwan communities donating money to the children by supporting them. She said that this would enable Taiwan people to have more exchanges with the people in those countries.

Lu stressed that her visit was planned as a complement of President Chen Shui-bian's recent tour, so she visited the four allies in Central America that Chen did not go to in August. She stressed that she is visiting the countries on behalf of the ROC, and not in her own personal capacity.

Lu will conclude her "journey of soft diplomacy" in Central America after a joint press conference in Guatemala and a dinner hosted by local overseas Chinese Sunday. She is scheduled to return to Taipei via San Francisco Wednesday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUKE PLANT RECOMMENDATION DRAWS MIXED COMMENTS

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi reiterated Sunday that he will respect Premier Tang Fei's final decision at the end of the month on the fate of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant.
However, Lin added in a television interview that he is more concerned about the nuclear waste being produced by Taiwan's three existing nuclear power plants.

With the addition of a fourth plant, which is approximately 30 percent complete, Taiwan will have to dispose of a total of 920,000 barrels of low-radiation waste material, as well as over 7,000 kilograms of high-radiation waste, he said.

Lin, who had presented a recommendation Saturday to Tang to halt the nuclear plant project completely, said that allowing private companies to build alternative sources of power in its place will only cost NT$75 billion (US$2.4 billion), while the completion of the nuclear plant will cost another NT$120 billion (US$3.8 billion) on top of the NT$90 billion (US$2.9 billion) already spent on its construction.
Taking the different costs and environmental concerns into account, Lin advocated scrapping the nuclear plant in favor of other energy sources that do not generate nuclear waste material.

However, former Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang of the opposition Kuomintang disagreed with Lin's proposal. He said that the construction of natural gas power plants will present more risks, such as having to use pipelines to send natural gas from southern Taiwan to the plants, which would be located in northern Taiwan.
He added that the issue of carbon dioxide emissions from the plants cannot be ignored, either. Therefore, he concluded that Lin's alternative energy proposal is "not very feasible."

Wang, who had promoted the fourth nuclear plant project during his tenure as economics minister, went on to say that the new nuclear plant will be able to generate approximately 2.7 megawatts of energy a year.

He noted that it would take 100 ships to deliver the amount of coal needed to generate the same amount of power if alternative plans call for using fossil fuels, while the island would need just one airplane to break through any possible blockade of Taiwan to deliver the necessary fuel for a nuclear plant.
Wang also pointed to the safety of the nuclear plant and the "direct blow" that scrapping it will deal to industrial firms that want to stay in Taiwan.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is a member of the KMT's Central Standing Committee, also voiced his support for the continued construction of the plant.

Ma said that despite differences in opinion within the Cabinet -- with the premier taking on the KMT's pro-nuclear stance and the economics minister recommending an anti-nuclear energy policy as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's principles dictate -- the final decision is ultimately up to the premier, under the rules of Taiwan's government system.
Ma pointed out that abandoning the nuclear plant project will have adverse effects not only on the downward-spiraling domestic stock market but also on the nation's credibility in the world.

However, Lai Shih-pao, convener of the opposition New Party's legislative caucus, said that the impact of halting the plant's construction on the economy and the stock market will only be short-lived. He urged Tang to make a decision on the issue as soon as possible instead of waiting until the end of the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN TO INTERVIEW NSB OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: A member of the Control Yuan special task force in charge of investigating a former National Security Bureau chief cashier's suspected involvement in embezzlement said that his team will interview several NSB officials during the next two weeks.
Kuo Shih-chi said that the Control Yuan -- the nation's highest supervisory body -- has already compiled financial records on Col. Liu Kuan-chun and other related NSB personnel.

Kuo went on to say that his team is in the process of collecting and verifying more evidence through interviews with NSB chief accountant Chao Chun-kuo, former NSB chief accountant Hsu Ping-chiang, and NSB cashiers.
He added that he will also ask NSB Director Ting Yu-chou to explain related case material to the Control Yuan in the future.

Kuo said that his task force is also looking into whether other NSB officials have helped cover up the alleged NT$90 million (US$2.9 million) embezzlement and whether Liu's disappearance may lead to a breach in national security due to the amount of sensitive information he may have come across in the past.
Kuo added that although Liu has never received intelligence personnel training, he nonetheless handled classified items while he was the NSB's chief cashier from 1998 to May 2000.

Two other members of Kuo's team said that they will double up with another Control Yuan task force that is investigating the case of former NSB Personnel Director Pan Hsi-hsien, who had traveled to mainland China immediately after his retirement earlier this year, a violation of NSB regulations. Pan is currently being detained by Beijing.

Liu had sought for and was granted a two-month leave starting July 16. He has since failed to answer subpoenas requesting him to explain suspicious transactions under his bank accounts, maintaining that the money belongs to his family and relatives.
On Sept. 15, he applied to extend his leave until the end of September. The special task force in charge of investigating his case has found no record of Liu leaving the country.
Prosecutors have issued a warrant for Liu and banned him from leaving the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Summit on Arts & Culture to be held in Ottawa

TEXT.P: The Canadian Council for the Arts is planning to host a World Summit on Arts and Culture, with some two thousand representatives of arts councils and funding bodies from more than 50 countries meeting in Ottawa this coming December.

Jean-Louis Roux, chair of the council, said the organization can't stand still in the face of globalization. "We can no longer afford to look at the arts in a purely national context. The wide world is on our doorstep and we are part of it."
The desire to build international alliances by arts groups has been driven by political issues, including fear of liberalized trade agreements and globalization.

But it goes further than that, according to Shirley Thomson, director of the council, who said that the market for art is no longer limited to Canada. "We can no longer ignore the fact that we are part of that international market, and it seems to me building a link of federations with other arts councils is one way of solidifying that infrastructure."
The new network is likely to be based in Australia and will meet every two years. The groundwork will be laid at the world summit in December.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE BACK CONSTRUCTION OF 4TH NUKE POWER PLANT: KMT POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of respondents to a recent poll said they support the construction of Taiwan's controversial fourth nuclear power plant, according to the results of a survey published Sunday by the main opposition Kuomintang.

The survey of 1,100 people was conducted by a private consulting company from Sept. 22-24 on the commission of the KMT. Its results show that 59.2 percent of those polled said they back the continued construction of the fourth nuclear plant, while 29 percent of them disagree.

The fourth nuclear power plant was initiated by the KMT while it held the reins of administrative power. After the Democratic Progressive Party came to power in May, the new administration began to mull whether or not to continue with construction of the nuclear power plant.
The poll also shows that 63.8 percent of the respondents said they agree that a referendum on the issue should be held, while 33.9 percent expressed disapproval of such a general vote.

Meanwhile, 62.3 percent of the respondents said they also support the idea of the government conducting referenda to decide other crucial national policies, while 34.3 percent of the surveyed said they did not back the idea.

The results of the poll show that 63.5 percent of the respondents thought the government is not well-prepared for any possible oil crisis. Less than 10 percent of the respondents expressed approval of government preparations, according to the survey's results.

DOC.HEADLINE: AT LEAST FOUR QUAKES MEASURING 4 ON RICHTER SCALE ROCK HUALIEN CITY

TEXT.P: A series of earthquakes including at least four that measured higher than 4 on the Richter scale rattled Hualien City on Sunday, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
No human casualties or property damages have been reported, the CWB added.
CWB officials said that an earthquake measuring 3.9 on the Richter Scale struck Hualien at about 1:21 p.m., while a separate temblor of a magnitude of 4 on the Richter scale hit at 1:22 p.m.
Taroko Gorge in Hualien County and Nanao in Ilan County registered magnitudes of 2 and l on the Richter scale, respectively.
Another temblor measuring 4.7 on the Richter scale had struck Hualien at 12:03 a.m., while an earthquake measuring 4 on the Richter scale rocked the same area at 11:44 a.m.
During the past 20 hours, nine quakes have hit Hualien, the CWB added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL STORM COULD ERUPT IF PREMIER TANG FEI STEPS DOWN

TEXT.P: A political storm could result if Premier Tang Fei steps down from office, a local political commentator said Sunday.

Wu Nai-jen, secretary general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, has repeatedly opened fire on Premier Tang Fei, causing internal DPP factional strife, he told the media, speaking on condition of anonymity.

He pointed out that members of the current administration under the joint control of President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Tang Fei face challenges from both the Legislative Yuan and the ruling DPP itself.

After the March presidential election, the Legislative Yuan, the nation's highest law-making body was still under the control of the opposition Kuomintang. Furthermore, the Legislative Yuan can block Executive Yuan decisions.

Few DPP members were chosen to take Cabinet posts. At present, only Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan, Minister of Transport and Communications Yeh Chu-nan, Vice Education Minister Fan Hsun-lu and the newly appointed deputy representative of the Republic of China in the Unites States are DPP members.
As a result, Tang can not easily implement the new government's policies, not to mention the DPP's policies, the expert said.
DPP factional strife has also been a key factor in making the new government inefficient in regards to policy implementation.
The DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan has been dominated by three main internal factions -- the New Tide, Mainstream and New Century groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE KUAN YEW 'LESS PESSIMISTIC' ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT TIES AFTER VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct.1 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew said he was "less pessimistic" about cross-strait ties than he had been before his recent visit to Taiwan.
The respected statesman, who visited Taiwan Sept. 23-26, made the comments in an interview with the Straits Times and its sister Chinese-language publication, Lianhe Zaobao.
Lee noted that President Chen Shui-bian has been told by the United States, Taiwan's principle backer, that "independence is out, and he knows it is not practical."

Lee also spoke about meeting with the leaders of the two major opposition parties, Chairman Lien Chan and Vice Chairman Vincent Siew of the Kuomintang, as well as Chairman James Soong of the People First Party. He said that the leaders had indicated that they support the resumption of cross-strait talks on the basis of the 1992 consensus.
Lee noted that President Chen in his inaugural speech did not reject the 1992 consensus, in which each side is allowed its own interpretation of "one China."
However, the president subsequently refereed to it as the 1992 "spirit," not "consensus." This was because of opposition from pro-independence fundamentalists in Taiwan, Lee said.

He also said that Chen spelled out his policy in detail in his inaugural speech, which sketched a well-balanced position that had helped defuse tensions. Since then, however, he has elaborated and modified his position, including his recent statement that reunification is not the only option.
In Lee's observation, Chen's policy is "still in the process of formulation and has not finally crystallized. He seems to be sounding out reactions in Taiwan."
Lee said that in the end, "President Chen will have to make up his mind about whether he represents pro-independence fundamentalists or the majority of the people of Taiwan."

He also said that Chen's adviser Lee Yuan-tseh told him that at least 70 percent of people in Taiwan do not want immediate reunification, nor do they want independence for Taiwan. Taiwan people want the status quo, the Singaporean senior statesman said.
He added that he had told Lee Yuan-tseh, a Nobel laureate, that maintaining the status quo is only possible if the island does not drift further away from the mainland.

The respected academic and Nobel laureate understands that, and believes the status quo can be maintained under the umbrella of a "one China" in terms of history, tradition, and blood ties -- but not yet politically, Lee Kuan Yew said.
The senior minister also said the stalemate between mainland China and Taiwan should not drag on. "It must be broken, the sooner the better," he said.

Lee said that should the cross-strait logjam drag on into next year, the next U.S. president should encourage Taiwan and Beijing to talk by going back to the 1992 consensus on "one China," with each sides stating its view of the meaning of that concept.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO CONVENE FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC SEMINAR SOON

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will soon convene a seminar on the nation's financial and economic issues at the Presidential Office.

Officials of the Presidential Office said President Chen has expressed great concern about the current financial and economic situation in Taiwan, especially with the domestic stock market having slumped badly recently.

The officials added that Prime Minister Tang Fei, related ministers and representatives from industrial sectors will participate in the seminar. They added that the agenda of the seminar will also include the controversial fourth nuclear power plant.

Chen last week met with Wang Yung-ching, chairman of Formosa Plastics Group, and Douglas Hsu, head of Far Eastern Group, the country's two industrial heavyweights, to exchange views on the current economic situation in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, a group of industrial heavyweights and trade and economic intellectuals on Sunday urged the government to implement measures to prop up the local stock market, which dropped heavily last week.

Tseng Fan-cheng, director general of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., said that Taiwan's industrial fundamentals are sound, and the drastic stock market collapse was caused by a lack of confidence in the government among domestic and foreign investors.

Kuan Chun-jung, professor of agricultural economy at National Taiwan University, said it is contradictory that the Chen Administration prefers not to construct the fourth nuclear plant on the one hand, but plans to stimulate Taiwan's traditional industries on the other hand. Halting construction of the fourth nuclear power plant will have the greatest impact on these same industries, he said.

Lei Li-fen, also a National Taiwan University professor, indicated that the heavy domestic stock market slump has not just affected investors, but has also reduced private consumption, resulted in a decrease in the nation's gross national product, and shut down enterprises -- thereby exacerbating the unemployment problem.
She urged the government to use the national stabilization fund to help the stock market in order to prevent a macroeconomic collapse.

DOC.HEADLINE: BID TO FLY LONGEST KITE FAILS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's attempt to gain a niche in the Guinness Book of Record for flying the longest kite in the sky failed on Sunday.

The kite, which was measured at 1,300 meters in a morning ceremony at the Police Academy stadium, was sent to Chuwei beach in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County in the afternoon to challenge the old record of 1,035 meters.

Many people were on the beach in the afternoon waiting to see the feat. Taoyuan County Stadium and Kueishan Township, sponsors of the activity, sent staff to check every part of the giant dragon kite meticulously, hoping that everything would go smoothly for the world record.
At 3:15 p.m. buoyed by the winds, the kite began its slow ascent into the sky. Spectators cheers excitedly whenever pieces of the kite surged into the air.

The winds seemed to help too. But after 10 minutes of the first part of the kite being in the air, a section was swept toward some nearby trees. Part of it then hit a tree branch, and the whole kite slumped to the ground. It is estimated that only about 996 meters of the kite actually got off the ground.
The sponsors said that they were disappointed about the failure, but added they would wait for more appropriate time and place to make a second bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG PRACTITIONERS PROTEST ON TIANANMEN SQUARE

TEXT.P: Nearly 1,000 members of the Falun Gong sect staged demonstrations on Tiananmen Square in Beijing on Sunday, mainland China's National Day, in protest against the Chinese government's suppression of the spiritual movement.

Witnesses said groups of Falun Gong members rushed in and out of the square soon after 8 a.m., holding up their yellow banners of Falundafa, but they were quickly dispersed and many of them were dragged into vans and buses by police and soldiers before 8:30 a.m. Small groups of Falun Gong members continued to protest in and around the square later in the morning.
The witnesses said that there were many uniformed and plainclothes police on the square, and that they did not know whether all of the protesters were from Beijing.

Meanwhile, a small group of Falun Gong members staged a peaceful demonstration outside the liaison office of Beijing in Hong Kong Sunday in protest against China's suppression of the spiritual movement.
In Macao, members of the spiritual movement distributed handbills on the same day to refute Beijing's propaganda against the Falun Gong sect in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 2, or the fifth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
322 BC: Aristotle, Greek Philosopher, dies of a stomach illness at the age of 62. A pupil of Plato, the tutor of Alexander the Great, and the author of works on logic, metaphysics, ethics, natural science, politics, and poetics, he profoundly influenced western thought.
1803: Samuel Adams, American statesman, dies at the age of 81. He was one of the signatories of the Declaration of Independence.
1835: Texan-Americans strike the first blow for an independent Texas by staging an armed uprising against the central government of Antonio de Santa Anna in the town of Gonzales, 108 km east of San Antonio.
1869: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Indian leader, is born. He used non-violent civil disobedience in his campaign for Indian independence.
1870: Rome becomes the capital of Italy.
1871: Cordell Hull: American statesman, diplomat, and the secretary of state under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, is born. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1945.
1909: A 220-km railway from Peking to Changchiakow (Kalgan) in Inner Mongolia, the first railroad built and owned by China, is opened to traffic.
1918: The world's first public health college is established at John Hopkins University in Baltimore.
1920: U.S. marines, sent by President Woodrow Wilson to Haiti to restore order, clash with rebel forces and kill their leaders.
1924: The League of Nations in Geneva adopts a protocol for the peaceful settlement of international disputes.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed commander-in-chief of the Northwestern Communist-Suppression Army and Chang Hsueh-ling deputy commander-in-chief, with their headquarters in Sian.
1935: Italian forces invade Abyssinia.
1942: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's special envoy, Wendel Willkie, arrives in Chungking to confer with Chinese leaders.
1945: George Smith Patten, Jr., American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany, is demoted by U.S. Army Chief-of-Staff Dwight D. Eisenhower.
1973: Siri Siriyodhin, Thai speaker of the House of Representatives and head of an 11-member parliamentary mission, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: A total of 319 model soldiers are cited to mark the ROC's 21st Armed Forces Day.
1985: The ROC government announces the liberalization of gold imports and transactions.
1985: Rock Hudson, Hollywood star, dies of AIDS at the age of 59.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the revision of tariffs, lowering the highest tariff rate to 58 percent.
1989: The ROC and Liberia re-establish diplomatic relations. Peking severs formal ties with Liberia in protest.
1990: A hijacked Chinese jet crashes into two parked planes at the Guangzhou airport, killing 127 people.
1996: A Peruvian plane slams into the Pacific Ocean, killing all 20 people on board.
1998: Sanjaasuregiin Zorig, a popular government minister and the leading figure in Mongolia's peaceful democratic revolution, is murdered.
1999: Overseas Chinese communities around the world donate NT$540 million (US$16.9 million) for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "During the examination of every system of moral laws with the teaching of acknowledged great and wise men of the past, there must be no divergence. Applying the examination to the operations and porches of nature in the physical universe, there must be no contradiction."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 161.07 POINTS
