Market turnover amounted to NT$67.5 billion (US$2.16 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC V.P. BLASTS BEIJING FOR INSINCERITY, BACKWARD MENTALITY
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Anita Chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu criticized Beijing Sunday for its lack of sincerity and "backward mentality" of insisting on its cherished "one China" principle as a precondition to negotiations with Taiwan.

Lu said at a press conference in Guatemala City, the last stop on her four-state Central American visit, that Taiwan's 23 million people cannot accept Beijing's claim that Taiwan is a part of mainland China.

She went on to say that the "one China, two systems" model Beijing used to incorporate Hong Kong into mainland China is not suitable for Taiwan. Furthermore, she added that the system has already received many complaints in Hong Kong.

Regarding the trend that Taiwan's Central American diplomatic allies have been increasing bilateral exchanges with mainland China while maintaining that their relations with Taiwan are strong and steady, Lu said that Taiwan cannot stop its allies from making other friends.

She pointed out that Taiwan should be confident and understanding about its allies' contacts with mainland China, adding that the heads of state of El Salvador, Honduras, Belize, and Guatemala all clearly expressed during her week-long visit their continued support for the ROC's bid to rejoin the United Nations.

She said that the presidents of El Salvador and Honduras as well as the prime minister of Belize will visit Taiwan in November and December, while the president of Guatemala will visit Taiwan in March.

She also pledged that the new ROC government will honor the former administration's promises of economic assistance, and she suggested that the Central American nations can send representatives to Taiwan to learn agricultural and food processing technology as well as high-tech skills.

After departing from Guatemala, Lu and her entourage stopped in Acapulco, Mexico, before arriving in San Francisco for a 30-hour stopover. She will return to Taipei Wednesday, ending her first overseas trip since becoming vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 161.07 points to 6,024.07.

The bourse opened at 6,165, but due to lack of confidence on the part of investors and heavy selling pressure, the index began to go down in the second half of the trading session. For the day, the bourse fluctuated between 6,248.12 and 6,014.87.

A total of 1.73 billion stocks worth NT$67.5 billion (US$2.16 billion) changed hands, compared with the previous trading session which saw 1.73 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$61.04 billion (US$1.96 billion).

Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with plastics and chemical stocks moving up the most at 0.7 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.1 percent, while foodstuff shares remained unchanged.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 3.5 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.6 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.4 percent, construction stocks at 2.3 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 1.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 413 to 125, with 75 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taipei stock index futures market were lower Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved down 101 points to close at 6,149, with 5,963 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for November decreased 130 points to finish at 6,150, with 92 contract transactions, while December futures plunged 152 points to close at 6,248, with 12 contracts changing hands.
March 2001 futures fell 82 points to finish at 6,370, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June 2001 futures.
Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Monday at 6,250 for October, 6,280 for November, 6,400 for December, 6,452 for next March, and 6,450 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
October TE futures moved down 14.5 points to close at 312, with 2,081 contract transactions, while November TE futures lost 8.95 points to finish at 320, with 29 contracts traded.
December TE futures plunged 23.7 points to close at 315.3, with 12 contract transactions, while March 2001 TE futures moved down 20.6 points to finish at 330, with one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for June 2001 TE futures.
October TF futures decreased 15 points to close at 728, with 360 contract transactions, while November TF futures fell 8 points to finish at 738, with two contract transactions.
December TF futures lost 15 points to close at 734, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLNESS OF TRAIN OPERATOR CAUSES DELAYS ON MRT LINE

TEXT.P: Trains on the Mass Rapid Transit System's Hsintien Line were delayed for 10 minutes beginning at 10:24 p.m. on Sunday at the Taipower Building Station.
An on duty train operator, surnamed Li, who was suffering from a serious flu, passed out while operating a train heading northbound on the Hsintien Line.
After the head of Taipower Building Station discovered the situation, he woke up Li and accompanied him to Chihshan Station where another train operator took over.

Mass Rapid Transit Corporation authorities decided to mete out punishment to Li after hearing about the incident. In order to avoid such situations in the future, they will implement stricter rules to prevent MRT train operators from going on duty when they are not feeling well, said an MRTC source.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA ACTIVELY INTEGRATING ITS WESTERN REGIONS

TEXT.P: Beijing is looking to secure its western regions through colonization and forcing ethnic minorities in both Tibet and Xinjiang to abandon their cultures and eventually their religions through various restrictions, reported the Australian on Monday.

The daily reported that the Communist Chinese government is pushing to consolidate its hold on the outer fringes of the country by encouraging the migration of Han and Hui people to Tibet and Xinjiang.

The Chinese government has encouraged Hui Muslims and Han Chinese to open businesses in these places in order to facilitate the further integration of both Tibet and Xinjiang into the Chinese fold, the daily reported.

The daily cited the town of Langmusi, which was once a predominantly Tibetan pilgrimage center, as an example illustrating the demographic shifts that are occurring as a result of government polices, noting that the white skull caps of the Hui Muslims are becoming a common sight among the brightly colored tunics of the Tibetans.

The daily quoted Robbie Barnet, an analyst and scholar of Tibetan studies at Columbia University in New York, as saying that the Hui have laid the foundation for the Chinese traders now flooding Tibet.

These developments seem to signal something that Tibetans have dreaded for decades -- a real Chinese determination to integrate Tibet into the Chinese economy, said Gabriel Lafitte, a Tibet policy analyst based at Melbourne University.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYDNEY AIRPORT BRACING FOR BUSIEST DAY EVER

TEXT.P: Sydney Airport is expecting to experience its busiest day ever on Monday as thousands of foreign athletes, spectators, and members of the media head home en masse following the end of the 2000 Olympic Games.
An airport spokesman said about 100,000 passengers, mostly outbound, are expected to come through the airport over the course of the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER DENIES DIPLOMATIC PROBLEMS WITH SOLOMON ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao on Monday denied reports that the Solomon Islands is considering switching its diplomatic ties away from the ROC to mainland China.
Tien said that the foreign minister of the Solomon Islands visited Taiwan before Tien departed for his recent European trip and that bilateral relations with the south Pacific nation remain stable.

Tien was responding to questions about a foreign media report that quoted Solomon Islands government sources as having said that the new government of Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare has been rethinking the issue.
According to the report, observers believe that the Solomon Islands may be using the issue to obtain more financial aid from Taiwan.

Tien said that the Solomon Islands urgently needs various kinds of funding to help regain its political stability, but no one country -- "certainly not Taiwan" -- can bear the entire weight of the financial support.

He added that the Solomon Islands government has already contacted the World Bank and countries such as Australia, New Zealand, and the United States to seek the emergency financial assistance that it needs. As a diplomatic ally, Tien said that the ROC will certainly provide assistance if it can.
Tien concluded that Taiwan "will not and has not agreed to take upon itself to provide for all the emergency needs" of the Solomon Islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS NUKE PLANT `LESSER EVIL'

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said Monday that he does not think that nuclear power is "absolutely safe" and the "only option", but he is choosing the "lesser evil" in meeting Taiwan's energy needs.
Tang, who has said he personally supports the completion of construction on Taiwan's controversial fourth nuclear power plant, made the remarks while fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan.

The Premier said that from the angle of safely, it is not logical to scrap the much safer fourth plant, while maintaining the less safe first and second nuclear power plants, which the Ministry of Economic Affairs does not plan to scrap until perhaps a decade later.
He added that he is not saying that the fourth plant will have no "problems," but one has to choose the "lesser evil" in sorting out the thorny problem of meeting Taiwan's energy needs.
Tang said the controversial project will involve many questions and challenges related to politics, society, and the economy.

He noted that the factors to be taken into consideration include nuclear safety, nuclear waste disposal, future sources of energy, air, water and nuclear pollution, and also the question of whether the alternative proposals can make up for the scrapping of the fourth nuclear power plant.

He also added that consideration will be given to the issues of Taiwan's international credibility, the implementation of government authority, the project's budget which had already been approved in the Legislative Yuan in 1996, whether there will be enough time to hold a referendum, and the impact on Taiwan's overall economic development.

The Premier earlier told members of the Economic Committee in the Legislative Yuan that the Executive Yuan will not rule out an announcement of its decision within one or two weeks on whether to continue construction on the plant in Kungliao, Taipei County, which is now 30 percent complete.

Tang said that the Executive Yuan had originally planned to announce its decision by the end of the month, but considering the fact that it could have a great impact on Taiwan's overall economic development, it has decided to make an announcement earlier.
In related developments, Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said that because of regional imbalances, only the northern part of Taiwan does not have enough electricity to meet its needs.

Lin said that Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, although located in the northern part of Taiwan, will rely on central Taiwan for its power supply and will not be affected by limited supplies in northern Taiwan.
Lin asked how can an industrial park attract foreign investors if there is not enough electricity.

Meanwhile, Chen Tze-nan, the acting secretary-general to President Chen Shui-bian, responding to reports that Premier Tang could step down because of his support for the continued construction of the fourth nuclear plant, said that although the president and the premier do not see eye to eye on the project, the Executive Yuan will have the final say on the fate of the plant.

Chen said that the premier, in the eyes of the president, is the "most ideal person" for the premiership and that both will have the "same stance" on the project in the end, adding that reports speculating on Tang's imminent departure from his post are "unfair" and "impolite."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'THREE MINI LINKS' TO BE OPENED BY MID-DECEMBER: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) confirmed Monday that direct trade, postal and transport links between the offshore outposts of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China will be implemented after mid-December.

The MAC said that the opening of the "three mini links" in a "gradual and partial way" is aimed at promoting economic prosperity in the offshore islands, taking care of the daily needs of their people, cutting the underground illicit small trade now rampant despite the ostensible bans, and promoting positive exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The Cabinet-level council in charge of the charting of the nation's mainland policy gave a briefing on the background of its report on the impact and assessment of "three mini links" across the Taiwan Strait.

It said that Kinmen and Matsu will be the priority in the implementation of the "three mini links," and that the premise will be "one region to one harbor" -- meaning Kinmen is to be linked to the opposite mainland city of Xiamen, while Matsu and its opposite city, Fuzhou, will maintain designated transport routes.
After the initial transport links are on track, the MAC will assess limited links of another offshore island -- Penghu -- with the mainland.

The MAC said that because of the concerns about the defense of the offshore islands and the added burden of security checks, the opening of links will be conducted in a "gradual way." It added that the scale and the volume of transport links and exchanges of personnel and cargoes across the Taiwan Strait will also be subject to reasonable regulation.

As for using Kinmen and Matsu as "mid-point" or berthing places, the MAC said that such an arrangement would be out of the question, considering Taiwan's current mainland policy, national security and long-term economic benefit.
The government will only give special consideration to requested connections on a case-by-case basis, such as religious pilgrimages, the report also said.

On linking water and electricity supplies between the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China, the MAC said that as the supply of water and electricity in the two outposts is now self-reliant, there is no need to consider the question now.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-DOMINICA RELATIONS TO REMAIN STABLE AFTER P.M.'S DEATH: TIEN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said Monday that Taiwan deeply regrets the death of Dominica Prime Minister Roosevelt Douglas, but that bilateral relations between the two nations will be unaffected by his passing.

Douglas, who took a friendly attitude toward Taiwan during his eight-month stint as prime minister, died at his home unexpectedly Sunday. Asked if his death will lead to adverse changes in ROC-Dominica relations, Tien predicted that Dominican internal politics should remain much the same for the next five years, because Douglas' governing coalition between the Dominica Labor Party and the Dominica Freedom Party still retains a majority in the parliament.

Douglas, who served concurrently as Dominica's foreign minister, last visited Taiwan in early August to attend the fourth annual meeting between the foreign ministers of the ROC and its four Caribbean allies.

Douglas had said during his stay in Taiwan that the voices of the 23 million people in Taiwan needed to be heard by international society, and that Dominica's determination to support the ROC's bid to join various international organizations would not be swayed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.002 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$31.314.
The local currency opened at NT$31.292 and was traded between NT$31.292 and NT$31.326.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$420 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SNAGS MAY DELAY BEIJING'S ENTRY INTO WTO UNTIL AFTER EASTER

TEXT.P: Beijing's entry into the World Trade Organization is likely to be delayed until next year, perhaps around Easter, the Hong Kong Mail reported today.

According to the report, the prediction comes as new snags have emerged in Beijing's negotiations with 100 other nations on the terms of its accession to the global trade group, forcing a near-breakdown of the latest talks in Geneva, after three weeks of intensive efforts.
In the wake of the stalemate, the United States has contacted Beijing for a new round of talks to solve the seemingly intractable issues, the White House confirmed.
Reports quoted a White House spokesman as saying that U.S. Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky "has contacted the mainland Chinese government, but no date has been set for a trip."
The U.S. trade representative "still feels it can be done by year end, but the time is getting short," the spokesman conceded.

Hong Kong Airport Authority Chairman Fung Kwok-king was less optimistic. With negotiations involving more than 100 parties, "you would expect that there would be some bumps along the road," it quoted Fung as saying in Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE TO HOLD FINANCIAL & ECONOMIC SYMPOSIUM

TEXT.P: A senior official confirmed on Monday that the Presidential Office will soon convene a financial and economic symposium to discuss how to rescue the nation's economic situation, which is worsening daily.

Chen Che-nan, acting secretary general of the Presidential Office, said that Premier Tang Fei, members of the Cabinet financial and economic panel, scholars, experts and representatives of civilian business and industrial groups will be invited to take part in the meeting.
Chen stressed that the Presidential Office-sponsored economic symposium will not interfere with the functioning of the Cabinet financial and economic panel.

The goal of the meeting will be to come up with ways to implement the 102 major construction projects proposed by the Executive Yuan, Chen said, stressing the meeting will not be convened by the National Security Council.

Details of the meeting will be announced next week, Chen said. He also noted that representatives of political parties will not be invited to the meeting, as only industrial experts will participate, Chen said.
He stressed that the meeting is to be held to address concerns of the populace in regard to domestic, national defense and foreign affairs issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST INDUSTRIAL PORT TO BE INAUGURATED LATE THIS YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin, southern Taiwan, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first port exclusively for industrial use will be inaugurated by the end of this year. The port is located in Mailiao, Yunlin, southern Taiwan.

Mailiao Harbor in southern Taiwan's Yunlin County has an area of 476 hectares, and is similar in size to Taichung Harbor, in central Taiwan. It will be the deepest of Taiwan's ports, and will be navigable to ships of up to 260,000 tons, according to the port administration.

The volume of goods that can be handled at the port will reach 60 million metric tons annually in the initial stage, after its official inauguration at the end of this year. That figure is greater than the volume capacities of Taichung and Keelung Harbors put together.

The volume of goods handled at Kaohsiung Harbor, the largest port in Taiwan, is 100 million metric tons. The Mailiao Harbor administration officials noted that their facility has tremendous future potential.
It is hoped that this government-owned and private enterprise-operated harbor will be a new model for Taiwan's port operations, and can stimulate the domestic economy.

Residents living near Mailiao, also home to a Formosa Plastics Group power plant, said they hope one day to see the new port upgraded to an industrial and commercial port that will bring prosperity to their county.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. FIRM TO SET UP R&D CENTER IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin, southern Taiwan, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA): U.S. firm Lam Research Co. has announced that it will invest NT$2 billion (about US$645.1 million) to set up a research and development center and production facility in Tainan Science based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan.

A ground-breaking ceremony was held on Monday, and was witnessed by officials including Lin Hsin-yi, ROC economics minister, Steven Dunn, director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Kaohsiung Office, and Merrit Cook, chief of the Economic Division at AIT's Taipei office.

Lam Research first entered into a strategic alliance with the Ministry of Economic Affairs in 1995. The firm then set up its Taiwan branch at Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in 1994. The company is a supplier of products needed by semiconductor makers in Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.

The new R&D center in Tainan will be the second such facility that Lam has set up outside of the United States, with the first one in Japan. Taiwan will give the firm excellent access to mainland China as well as Southeast Asian countries, a source with the company said.
Lin Hsin-yi said that Lam Research's increased investment in Taiwan meant that foreign investors still have confidence in Taiwan's economic climate and conditions.

According to MOEA statistics, a total of 937 foreign investment applications totaling US$5 billion were approved during the January-August period, an increase of US$2.82 billion, or 109.9 percent, over the previous year's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER NOT RULING OUT TAX HIKE TO COVER DEFICIT

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said Monday that he is not ruling out a possible tax hike to cover the imbalance between government revenues and expenditures.
Tang made this clear while answering questions raised by Legislators Lee Chuan-chiao and Chiu Ching-tsun at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session.

Opposition lawmakers asked Tang how the national budget will be balanced if the government fails to implement previously decided construction work while trying to maintain the projected 6.6-percent annual economic growth rate.

Lee also asked Tang to make his final decision on finishing or scrapping construction of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant as soon as possible. On Saturday, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi suggested to Tang that he discontinue work on the facility, thus sparking further debate.

Chiu pointed out that Tang told the legislature that the nation's economic growth rate will reach the government's projected figure of 6.6 percent for 2001, but the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development had thereafter immediately lowered its growth estimate. The KMT legislator said that this is an indication that the coordination between members of the Cabinet is poor.

Tang replied that it will be impossible to balance revenues and expenditures if government income is reduced while expenditures are increased. Raising taxes is one method of balancing the deficit that the government will consider, Tang said.

Meanwhile, Lin Chuan, director general of the Directorate General of Accounting, Budget and Statistics, said in a Legislative Yuan interpellation session that the government will be forced to hike health insurance premiums if the deficit continues to worsen.

DOC.HEADLINE: NGO COMMITTEE INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: Taiwan inaugurated a new committee on non-governmental organizations under its Ministry of Foreign Affairs Monday as part of the island's efforts to enhance non-official exchanges with the rest of the world.

Presiding over the ceremonial launching of the Non-Governmental Organization Committee, Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao said that NGOs, which number more than 24,000 and account for 8 percent of the world's 300,000 international organizations, will play an increasingly important role amid the ongoing trend of globalization.
He said that the NGOs have exercised far-reaching influence on many important international issues, as some 1,000 such groups are recognized by the United Nations as its consultative partners.

Turing to domestic NGOs, Tien said that many have won high praise from the international community for their contributions to international disaster relief and other humanitarian services, which Tien cited as examples of President Chen Shui-bian's idea of "Taiwan standing up and reaching out."

Tien said that his ministry is trying to establish a "partner relationship" with local NGOs while respecting their independence and operations as well as sharing with them its experience in international affairs, so as to enable Taiwan to make a greater contribution to the world.

The NGOC, which will offer "one stop" services to local NGOs to help nurture their ability to take part in international affairs, will for the foreseeable future run as a task force of the Foreign Ministry, a ministry official said. He added that it will be incorporated into an official department once the ministry's organization regulations have been revised.

With Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan serving as its concurrent chairman, the NGOC will consist of three divisions responsible for communications, education and evaluation, and international cooperation and development.
Members of the NGOC, which will number between 10 and 15, will be selected from among "outstanding figures" from various sectors of society, Lo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT CONCERNED ABOUT IMPACT OF 4TH NUCLEAR POWER PLANT

TEXT.P: As part of the government's efforts to avert a possible chain reaction stirred up by a proposal to halt the building of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi has launched a tour of large firms to help bolster local business investment confidence.

Although the proposal submitted over the weekend by the Ministry of Economic Affairs to the Executive Yuan represents only the point of view of the MOEA, it caused the local stock market to continue to plummet Monday and many firms voiced grave concern over the country's sluggish economic prospects.

At the same time, relevant government agencies are seriously concerned about subsequent developments, as any halt to the ongoing construction of the fourth nuclear power plant is expected to greatly shake the investment willingness of the local business community, dealing a heavy blow to the already deteriorating local economy.

In a bid to prevent local enterprises from moving out amid such bearish sentiments, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Taiwan's highest-level government economic planning authority, has instructed its subordinate agencies to extend assistance to large-scale domestic investment projects launched by local businesses.

Lin himself was first to kick off the confidence-building measure, taking part in a ground-breaking ceremony for the construction of a research and development center funded by the U.S.-based Lam Research Co. in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan. He is scheduled to visit other companies located in the park in the coming days.

According to a news release issued by the MOEA Sunday, Lin praised the U.S. firm's decision to invest in Taiwan and stressed that he has been seeking to improve Taiwan's water and electricity supply since assuming his post in May.

The press release also pointed out that the MOEA has worked out a comprehensive package of alternative options should construction of the controversial nuclear power plant really come to a halt. It said that "the measures will undoubtedly meet Taiwan's long-term demand for electricity," and asked both local and foreign companies to erase any worries in this regard.

According to MOEA statistics, foreign and overseas Chinese investment in Taiwan totaled US$5.023 billion in the first eight months of this year. The figure represents an increase of 109.9 percent over the level posted during same period of a year ago, but government officials have showed grave concern, as the majority of the investment money has gone to the finance sector.

A recent MOEA-commissioned poll also found that unclear government economic policy, as well as insufficient water and power supplies and labor protests, are usually the leading factors in the eroding business investment confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEXPLODED BOMB DREDGED FROM PENGHU FISHING GROUND

TEXT.P: A huge unexploded bomb suspected to be from the World War II era was dredged up by a fishing boat Monday from a fishing ground in the waters off one of the Penghu islands.

The fishing boat "Jui Hsing Li No. 16" found the 500-pound dud while operating in waters eight nautical miles north of Tungchi Isle and towed it to the Penghu county seat of Makung, where it was taken away by an army bomb disposal unit.
According to a military spokesman, the bomb, which lacked a detonator, was dropped during World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECONSTRUCTION FORCE FOR QUAKE-AFFECTED AREAS FORMED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Council of Labor Affairs Monday formed the first group of 500 people of a reconstruction force aimed at helping those who suffered in last year's devastating earthquake to revive their hometowns.

CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu urged unemployed people in areas affected by the Sept. 21 earthquake that claimed more than 2,400 lives to register with the CLA in order to get a job reconstructing their hometowns.
Chen said unemployed people between the ages of 15 and 65 living in affected areas, mostly in central Taiwan, are eligible to register for a job with a minimum monthly wage of NT$15,840 (US$510).

Lin Tsong-ming, director-general of the Employment and Vocational Training Administration under the CLA, said the accepted applicants will enjoy a five-day work-week and labor insurance. He added that people with higher educational levels will be given priority in a range of jobs from rebuilding houses to sweeping the streets.
The CLA will invest NT$2.8 billion annually to help approximately 20,000 people in affected regions to get jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: `MINI DIRECT LINKS' WITH MAINLAND CHINA TO OPEN IN DECEMBER

TEXT.P: Direct shipping and trade links between two of Taiwan's frontline islands and mainland China will begin in mid-December, according to an announcement Monday from the Mainland Affairs Council.

In a background briefing, the MAC said the measures are aimed at bolstering the prosperity of the islands of Kinmen and Matsu. However, the briefing said that an abrupt opening of trade links would endanger the security of the two islands, given Beijing's refusal to renounce the threat of force against Taiwan, which would in turn compromise Taiwan's safety.

In order to balance the needs of prosperity against the security risk, the MAC said it has been decided to ease the ban on direct shipping and trade between the two islands and the mainland gradually, adding that the move will be limited to specific harbors.
Under the plan, the links will start between Kinmen and the mainland port of Xiamen, and between Matsu and the mainland port of Fuzhou.

Initially, there will also be strict limits on the type of goods allowed to be imported from mainland China and the number of passengers allowed to travel on the routes, and trade centers on the two islands are being considered to ensure the limits are observed, said the MAC.

Taiwan ships will be prohibited from taking advantage of the direct links by sailing to mainland China via the two islands, and Taiwan exporters will not be allowed to ship their goods to the mainland through Kinmen or Matsu.
Voyages for religious purposes, such as carrying Taiwan pilgrims to mainland China, may be exempt from the restrictions on a case-by-case basis, according to the MAC briefing.
Once in place, the measures are expected to curtail the rampant smuggling between the two islands and mainland China, and might be expanded to Taiwan's offshore county of Penghu, said the MAC.
Given that Kinmen and Matsu are self-sufficient in water and electricity supplies, the MAC ruled out the possibility of importing water and electricity from mainland China to supply the two islands.
The MAC also stressed that mainland China's cooperation is vital for the pilot program's success and added that it will take Beijing's reactions into account and adjust the measures if necessary.
Meanwhile, the Kinmen county government has worked out a proposal to set up four sites for cross-strait trading, three of which will be on the main Kinmen island and one on Little Kinmen Island.
The proposal calls for a register to be maintained of mainland Chinese who want to conduct small-scale trade, together with limits on the ships they can use.
Once the sites are open, trade outside of them or after their business hours will be prohibited, according the county government.
Both the new Taiwan dollar and the renminbi would be accepted as currency, and mainland traders would be able to keep whatever revenues they earned.
The proposal is subject to the approval of the county council and the MAC.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG STUDENTS DEMAND AMENDMENT OF PUBLIC ORDINANCES

TEXT.P: Some 300 college students and their supporters Monday staged a protest march, saying that the public security ordinances of Hong Kong are violating their rights for free assembly.
The protest followed the arrest of five college students on Thursday for organizing a demonstration against tuition hikes without a police permit.

The ordinances stipulate that a police permit is required for any demonstration of more than 30 people. Organizers should apply for the permit seven days in advance, if more than 50 people take part in the demonstration.
The ordinances were adopted by the provisional legislative council just before Hong Kong's handover to Beijing in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF APPROVES JAPANESE REINSURANCE COMPANY'S LIAISON OFFICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance Monday approved the setting up in Taiwan of a liaison office for Japan's Toa Reinsurance Co. Ltd.

Founded in 1940, Toa Reinsurance Co. ranks the 17th on a list of the world's professional reinsurance companies. It has a 30 percent market share of the Japanese reinsurance market and has seven offices worldwide.

The company registered a turnover of 100 billion yen (US$926 million) in the period from April 1, 1997 to March 31, 2000. At present, its gross assets total 302.8 billion yen and its net assets stand at 40 billion yen, a show of its sound financial condition, according to statistics obtained by the MOF.

The MOF indicated that Toa was given an "AA-" (very strong) grade for its solvency ability by the world renowned credit grading co. Standard and Poor's on May 8, 2000, further proof that it has sound finances.

According to the MOF, Toa thinks the development of the Asian reinsurance market in the next five years is promising. Thanks to the speedy development of Taiwan's economy, the need for various types of insurance by all local industries are also expected to grow significantly, according to the company.
A Toa spokesman said the company attaches great importance to the establishment of the Taiwan liaison office.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO DEPUTY HEAD DISMISSES ACCUSATIONS OF CHECKBOOK DIPLOMACY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's aid to Macedonia was given to help the Macedonian people and consolidate bilateral ties rather than as a means of buying friendship, Government Information Office Deputy Director-General Frederic Chang said recently.

In an interview with Macedonia's Utrindke Vensik daily newspaper, Chang disputed the interviewer's accusation that the Republic of China practices "checkbook diplomacy," arguing that Taipei engages with other countries on the basis of "equality, mutualism and respect," which he said is a far cry from buying diplomatic recognition.

He also said the ROC's treaties with Macedonia will be kept intact, despite the recent change of government in Skopje, stressing that Taipei will honor its commitments of aid to Skopje, no matter who is in power.

Chang said that although the Macedonian government has not yet received the ROC ambassador's credentials, Skopje is processing the matter according to international protocol and the time-consuming diplomatic process will not affect the flow of aid from Taiwan.

He acknowledged that Taiwan's investment in the Balkan state has not grown as fast as had been expected and attributed this to "the geographic distance between the two countries." However, he held out hope that the distance problem will be overcome through the joint efforts of the two countries.

The interview, conducted between September 17-19 when Chang visited Skopje to open a photographic exhibition on Taiwan, was carried in the Sept. 28 edition of the paper, a copy of which reached Taipei on Monday.
Taipei forged diplomatic ties with Skopje in 1999, touting the Balkan state as its springboard to Europe. Macedonia is Taiwan's only ally in Europe other than the Vatican.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Premier Tang Fei reaffirms support for construction of 4th nuclear power plant.
The China Times:
Premier Tang reiterates continued construction of 4th nuclear power plant, otherwise he will offer to resign.
The United Daily News:
MAC unveils plans for opening direct cross-strait 'mini 3 links' late this year.
The Liberty Times:
The Cabinet will advance a final decision on the 4th nuclear power plant project to mid-October.
The China Post:
Premier Tang 'defies' President Chen, backs nuke plant.
The Taiwan News:
Premier Tang advances nuclear-plant decision; Vice Finance Minister Yen hints at stock market intervention.
The Taipei Times:
Tang is steadfast on nuclear power plant project.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 3, or the sixth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln officially designates the last day of November a national holiday, to be called Thanksgiving Day.
1867: Elias Howe, the U.S. inventor and manufacturer who designed early sewing machines, dies at the age of 48. He patented the sewing machine and made US$2 million from it and subsequently won patent-infringement suits against a number of manufacturers, including Isaac M. Singer.
1888: Carl von Ossietzky, the German journalist and pacifist who won the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, is born. He was imprisoned for exposing Germany's military buildup.
1929: Yugoslavia becomes the official name of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
1932: Iraq becomes independent after the British mandate ends.
1952: The first British atomic weapon is exploded off the Monte Bello Islands, west of Australia.
1963: President Ramon Villeda Morales of Honduras is overthrown in a military coup.
1966: Lesotho, which was formerly governed by Britain as the Protectorate of Basutoland, becomes independent.
1970: "Yu Chao," the first 100,000-ton oil tanker built in Taiwan, is launched. "Yu Chao" is the name of a legendary Chinese ruler who taught the people to build tree houses for protection against wild beasts.
1972: Armando Yoshida Vaca, new Bolivian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1972: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko sign a pact limiting the number of defensive missiles of their respective countries to 200.
1973: Gen. Robert E. Cushman, commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The sixth World Chinese Pharmacists Amity Conference opens in Taipei.
1975: The 10th World Chinese Traders Conference opens in Taipei with more than 900 overseas Chinese from 57 countries and areas attending.
1976: ROC Finance Minister Walter H. Fei leaves for Manila for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
1976: Jack Davis, president of Rotary International for 1977-78, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1977: Former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is arrested on corruption charges.
1989: Troops loyal to Panamanian strongman General Manuel Antonio Noriega crush a coup attempt by junior officers.
1990: Singapore and mainland China establish diplomatic relations.
1990: East and West Germany formally unite to become the single nation of Germany with Berlin as its capital and Helmut Kohl as provisional chancellor.
1995: Manuel Saturnino da Costa, prime minister of Guinea-Bissau, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1997: A powerful earthquake rocks central Italy, causing more damage to the frescoed interior of the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis in Assisi.
1997: Japan's magnetically levitated train breaks the world speed record for a manned train when it clocks 451 kph on an experimental track west of Tokyo.
1999: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs extends appreciation for the efforts of 25 countries that support membership in the United Nations for the ROC.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Confronted with the spiritual powers of the universe, a man must be able to maintain moral law without any doubt. He must be prepared to wait a hundred generations for the coming of a man of perfect divine nature to confirm moral law without any misgiving."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 119.37 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 119.37 points to close at 6,143.44.
Market turnover amounted to NT$87.91 billion (US$2.82 billion). (Bty Ben Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI OLYMPIC TEAM RETURNS

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei Olympic team returned to a warm welcome in Taiwan Tuesday morning following the completion of the Sydney Olympic Games on Sunday night.

Huang Ta-chou, leader of the team, said upon his arrival at CKS International Airport that the team received as many medals in Sydney as it did at the previous nine Olympic Games, tallying one silver and four bronze.

He noted that the team also placed fourth in shooting and eighth in archery and that it deserves the praise of the nation, but he added that as the goal of Olympic athletes is to always strive to be better, "we will not be content with what we have today."
Huang expressed the team's appreciation for the support given by fans to the Chinese Taipei athletes during the Games.

He also said that the work of the Sydney Organization Committee is a model to be emulated for future Olympics, noting that the committee turned a swamp into an athlete's village and mobilized 47,000 volunteers to help participating athletes during the duration of the Games from Sept. 15 to Oct.1.

The Chinese Taipei team sent 55 athletes to the Sydney Games to participate in 13 sports. They were able to win one silver and one bronze in weightlifting, one bronze in women's table tennis, and one bronze each in men's and women's taekwondo.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 119.37 points to close at 6,143.44.

Affected by another drop in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 6,165.44 and continued to go down, but after purchases made by government funds, share prices began to go up. The bourse fluctuated between 6,248.12 and 5,907.04 during trading.

A total of 2.29 billion stocks worth NT$87.91 billion (US$2.82 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.73 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$67.5 billion (US$2.16 billion).

All of the eight major categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 5.5 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 4 percent, textile issues at 3.5 percent, pulp and paper issues at 3.4 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 3.1 percent, constructions stocks at 2.6 percent, electrical shares at 1.2 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 389 to 171, with 61 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUKE PLANT CONSTRUCTION `A TEST OF POLITICAL WISDOM' SAYS ROC PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Tang Fei said Tuesday that continued construction of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant is a test of political wisdom as well as a choice between the lesser of two evils.

Tang told legislators at an interpellation session that the nuclear power plant issue involves far-reaching political and economic concerns. He added that Taiwan has no other sources of energy besides a limited hydroelectric capability, that fossil fuels will one day be depleted, and that a reliance on natural gas to meet future energy needs would present various difficulties in terms of feasibility and execution.

Later, at a Budget Committee interpellation, he told legislators that the decision on whether to continue or halt construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant will be based on national interests and not on political party preferences.
Tang, who is a member of the opposition Kuomintang, added that his personal stance after evaluating the issue is that the nuclear plant project should continue.

He pledged Monday that a final decision will be made within one or two weeks to minimize the adverse effects that the plant's uncertain fate has had on the local economy. However, he added Tuesday that the decision will not be whipped out so fast that it is made "in the blink of an eye," and that an upcoming Cabinet meeting on Wednesday is only for the Economics Ministry to make a report on the issue.

Tang, who is scheduled to meet President Chen Shui-bian later in the evening to discuss the issue, said that it is best to find a solution that is acceptable to the majority because he does not wish to see the issue lead to a huge political storm.

Meanwhile, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, who is also a member of the KMT but supports halting construction on the nuclear power plant, said in a radio interview that he did not take on his stance simply to endorse the president's position.
He added that he was not pressured by any American interest groups during the decision-making process that led him to recommend scrapping the plant, which uses General Electric technology.

Opposition KMT legislator Chang Fu-hsing called for Lin to step down because he said that Lin had made "unprofessional" comments by ignoring industry and commercial support for the nuclear power plant and instead taking on "an environmental protection administrator's line."

Lin's proposal of a natural gas power plant as an alternative to the nuclear power plant also came under fire from opposition People First Party legislator Hsieh Chang-chieh, who said that the installation of natural gas pipelines would cause just as much public resistance as the nuclear plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR SEEKS INTERPRETATION OF LAWS TO RESOLVE NUKE CONTROVERSY

TEXT.P: Opposition New Party legislator Feng Ting-kuo said Tuesday that he is passing around a petition to ask the grand justices to interpret related laws that may help resolve the controversy surrounding the fourth nuclear plant project.

Feng's petition, for which he hopes to obtain the signatures of at least one-third of the legislators within two days, seeks an interpretation of Budget Law Articles 71 and 88 as well as the legality of the various solutions that have been proposed to end the nuclear plant impasse.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators have insisted that the Cabinet can stop the plant's construction simply by withholding the allocated budget for the plant according to a provision in the Budget Law that allows for a reduction in cases of "special national circumstances."

Backed by the director-general of budget, accounting, and statistics, Premier Tang Fei had countered on numerous occasions that the Cabinet has no legal basis to halt the nuclear plant project even if it decides in favor of such a move because only the legislature can overturn an approved budget through another vote.

Tang said Tuesday that a grand justice interpretation may be too late to save the "urgent" situation because everyone can see the adverse impact that the controversy has already had on the local economy. Tang pledged Monday that he will make a final decision on the matter within one or two weeks.

Feng said that stopping the plant's construction midway would cost the public a total of NT$90 billion (US$2.9 billion) in compensation to various interests. Added to the NT$46.7 billion (US$1.5 billion) already spent on the project, he said that scrapping the project would cost almost as much as completing the project, which has an allocated budget of NT$160 billion (US$5.1 billion). He went on to ask, "Why not finish using this budget?"

He added that the new nuclear power plant -- which is already about 30 percent complete -- would be far safer than the first and second nuclear plants, which he noted could be retired earlier than previously planned, thereby increasing the overall safety level.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taipei stock index futures market were generally higher Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved up 113 points to close at 6,262, with 7,243 contracts traded.

TAIEX Index futures for November increased 145 points to finish at 6,295, with 109 contract transactions, while December futures surged 200 points to close at 6,448, with seven contracts changing hands.
However, June 2001 futures moved down 54 points to finish at 6,295, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for next March futures.
Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Tuesday at 6,149 for October, 6,150 for November, 6,248 for December, 6,370 for next March, and 6,349 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also generally higher.
October TE futures moved up 10.95 points to close at 322.95, with 2,332 contract transactions, while November TE futures gained 4.5 points to finish at 324.5, with 53 contracts traded.
December TE futures rose 10.95 points to close at 326.25, with four contract transactions, while June 2001 TE futures fell 25.7 points to finish at 341.8, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March 2001 TE futures.
October TF futures surged 40 points to close at 768, with 818 contract transactions, while November TF futures gained 29 points to finish at 767, with two contract transactions.
December TF futures rose 37 points to close at 771, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE GIRL TO SERVE ON PLANETARY SOCIETY'S TRAINING MISSION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Hsin-Liu Kao was among nine student scientists selected from over ten thousand entrants worldwide to serve on the Planetary Society's Red Rover Goes to Mars Training Mission.
Hsin-Liu Kao, 11, from Taipei, said she has a wide range of interests, including science, art, reading, traveling, mountain climbing, astronomy, and sailing. She is fluent in English and Chinese.
The winners, four girls and five boys ranging in age from 10 to 15, will select a possible landing site on Mars for some future sample return mission.

The other winners were Zsofia Bodo, 15, from Hungary; Kimberly DeRose, 13, from the USA; Bernadett Gaal, 14, from Hungary; Shaleen Harlalka, 15, from India; Iuri Jasper, 12, from Brazil; Tanmay Khirwadkar, 13, from India; Wojciech Lukasik, 10, from Poland; and Vikas Sarangadhara, 10, from India.
"This is the first time members of the public will command a spacecraft instrument on a planetary mission," said Linda Kelly, Education Manager of the Red Rover Goes to Mars project.
"Students will actually program a camera on a spacecraft in orbit around Mars to take pictures of the surface," she added.
The remarkable young people were chosen from a field of 80 semi-finalists from 16 different nations. Students from a total of 44 nations participated in the contest.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE ARCHEOLOGIST GIVEN KEYS TO UNLOCK PYRAMID SECRETS

TEXT.P: A leading Australian archeologist has received a permit from the Egyptian government over the control of excavations at Egypt's most famous site -- Giza -- the home of the Great Pyramid and the Sphinx.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday reported that Professor Naguib Kanawati, head of the Macquire University's Department of Ancient History and director of the Australian Center for Egyptology, will start work next month with a team of 10 Australians at the vast, closely guarded site at the invitation of Egypt's director-general of Antiquities -- Dr. Zahi Hawass.
Giza, located on the outskirts of Cairo, is important because it represents the Pyramid Age and is the cemetery of the 4th Dynasty (c.2613-2494 BC).
"The age of the great pyramids was the richest period for the kings and the bureaucracy. We are talking about thousands of tombs," Kanawati told the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG REPORTEDLY BECOMING REAL POLITICAL THREAT

TEXT.P: The defiant Falun Gong is becoming a real political threat to the Communist Chinese leaders and their rule over mainland China, as the number of its followers appears to be increasing instead of decreasing and as more of them are becoming less afraid of confronting Beijing, reported the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, the daily reported that two women with U.S. passports arriving at Beijing's airport were not allowed entry into the country and were escorted back on to the plane headed back to Hong Kong.

The two women, who were only identified as being mother and daughter, reportedly tried to join other Falun Gong members in staging a protest in Beijing's Tiananmen Square on October 1 -- the National Day of the People's Republic of China.

But other Falun Gong members in China successfully disrupted Sunday's elaborate National Day celebrations in Tiananmen Square. They were dispersed or arrested by Chinese police for embarrassing the Chinese leadership on such an important day, the daily reported.

On October 1, the daily reported more than 1,000 Falun Gong members, most of them middle-aged women, were arrested while marching in Tiananmen Square. The march was the Falun Gong's largest display of anti-government sentiment in the capital since Beijing outlawed the movement 14 months ago and called the sect "evil cult," reported the daily.
Wave after wave of protesters emerged from the crowds to unfurl yellow banners or adopt Falun Gong's meditation pose before being beaten up and dragged away by Beijing's undercover police.

The daily reported a large section of Tiananmen Square had to be closed off for more than half an hour, a major embarrassment to the Chinese government on National Day as police struggled with protesters and attempted to re-establish control.

DOC.HEADLINE: TERMINATION OF NUCLEAR PLANT CONTRACTS TO IMPAIR ROC CREDIBILITY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's credibility in the international market will be impaired if it finally decides to scrap its business contracts concerning a controversial nuclear power plant project, a U.S. business executive said Monday.
In contrast, the Clinton administration kept mum on the controversy surrounding Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant construction project.
Both the Department of Energy and the Department of Commerce would not make any comment on the possibility of Taiwan discontinuing construction of the controversial nuclear power plant.
The two departments said they are not in a position to comment on the issue because it is basically the Republic of China's domestic affair.

The office of the U.S. Trade Representative also said whether Taiwan will uphold or shelve the project has nothing to do with trade barrier issues and that no American firms have so far ever pressured the USTR to help them resolve the project-related trade deals.
A senior business executive, who once worked with the U.S. government, said it's no easy task for Taiwan to decide whether to continue or discontinue the nuclear power plant project.

He stressed what American business people care is not Taiwan's political wrangling but rather its general business climate, including the stability and continuity of its major industrial policies and availability of electricity and energy supply.

The executive, who demanded anonymity, said if Taiwan suspends its nuclear power plant, it must compensate General Electric Co. a large sum of money in accordance with an existing contract between them concerning the project.

Therefore, the executive said, GE is not expected to incur a great loss from termination of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant project. The real loser will be Taiwan itself as its international credibility will be at stake and foreign investors will become more cautious in launching any politically sensitive investment projects on the island, he noted.

The debate over the project has raged in Taiwan for 10 years. When the state-owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) held an open tender in 1996 to choose a supplier for nuclear reactors to be installed in the new plant, major U.S. companies, including GE, Westinghouse and ABB, had competed fiercely for the contract. At last, GE won the US$1.8 billion contract.

GE reportedly has completed more than half of the work for the nuclear reactor deal with Taipower. ROC Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi's suggestion last weekend that the government should replace the fourth nuclear power plant project with alternative power supply plans. Lin's statement has caused concern in the relevant U.S. business community.

Frank C. Carlucci, chairman of the U.S.-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, and Rupert Hammond-Chambers, acting president of the council, are currently on a visit in Taiwan. They are scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian and other senior ROC financial and economic officials to exchange views on the strengthening of U.S.-Taiwan trade and economic cooperation.
They will also convey American business people's common hope that Taiwan's investment climate will not be affected by political factors.
