The local currency opened at NT$31.291 and was traded between NT$31.291 and NT$31.326.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$288 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS SEARCH LOCAL NEWSPAPER OFFICE FOR CLUES INTO LEAK

TEXT.P: Taipei district prosecutors searched the editorial office of a local newspaper and the residences of two of its editors Tuesday in an apparent move to discover how the transcript of an interrogation had been leaked to the media.

Led by Senior Prosecutor Huang Chuan-lu, district prosecutors and local staff members of the Justice Ministry's Investigation Bureau sealed off the offices of the China Evening News and spent over an hour going through its desks and files. At the same time, another team searched the homes of the paper's news center director Sung Chao-tsin and society section editor Liao Hsiao-lung.

Huang did not comment on the purpose of the search or whether the prosecutors had found what they were seeking. Sung was brought back to the Investigation Bureau's Taipei branch office for further questioning.

Taipei District Prosecutor Office Prosecutor-General Huang Shi-ming said that the media leak is a matter of national security and must be thoroughly investigated. He added that he will explain the ins and outs of the investigation after it has ended.

Reportedly, investigators and prosecutors were looking into how the China Evening News had come across the information that led Sung to write a Sept. 30 article that included interrogation transcripts from an ongoing investigation into the alleged embezzlement and money-laundering case of Col. Liu Kuan-chun, a missing former chief cashier at the National Security Bureau.

The Association of Taiwan Journalists released a statement protesting what they said was the prosecutors' serious infringement on freedom of the press and basic human rights guaranteed by the Constitution. The group added that the case signified a huge step backwards for Taiwan's democratic reforms, as well as a huge irony in light of the recent handover of political power to a new administration.
China Evening News editors present during the search said that the newspaper respects the investigators, but that the media deserves more respect in terms of both action and attitude.

The newspaper later made an announcement to protest the "improper" sealing off of its editorial department during the search, which it said had affected its operations and infringed on its press freedoms.

The paper declared that it cannot shirk its duty to track the ongoing investigations into Liu's alleged embezzlement case, as the scandal involves the nation's highest intelligence agency and has far-reaching effects on national security.

It went on to state that the investigation agencies should focus on the source of the scandal instead of the reporters who unveiled the scandal, adding that Western nations would not rely on press reports as evidence for their investigations, much less investigating and interviewing the press.

Citing a U.S. Supreme Court decision that ruled the New York Times was not guilty of revealing secrets and endangering national security for exposing a Pentagon report on the Vietnam War, the newspaper also urged the legislature to amend current laws to strike a balance between freedom of the press and the necessary supervision involved in intelligence agency scandals.

Meanwhile, responding to claims that the transcripts were leaked out by NSB Deputy Director Han Kun, Han released a written announcement to assert his innocence. He pointed out that he was never involved in the interrogations because he was neither a military prosecutor nor a Justice Ministry investigator. Therefore, he had no access to any transcripts, he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION HEAD AIMS TO GIVE TAIWAN TOURISM A BOOST

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan said Tuesday that she plans to give a boost to Taiwan's tourism industry.

With the five-day workweek to be put into practice next year, and Taiwan's likely entry into the World Trade Organization having an impact on the island's economy, Yeh says that leisure activity will become a more important part of Taiwan life, which she said will help promote tourism.

She noted that the Executive Yuan now considers tourism to be one of the island's strategically important industries, and hopes to transform Taiwan from an industrial island to an attractive tourism destination.
In her report to the Legislative Yuan Wednesday, Yeh is expected to propose using tourism for diplomacy as well as making money.

Under Yeh's desired target for 2003, Taiwan will welcome 3.5 million overseas tourists and 100 million domestic tourists, with total tourism revenue accounting for 5 percent of the island's gross domestic product.
On domestic tourism, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has mapped out a development plan for Hengchun Peninsula in Pingtung County, hoping to turn it into the "Hawaii of Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR PROPOSES NEW KIND OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE MECHANISM

TEXT.P: A legislator Tuesday proposed another kind of link between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, saying that the top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should gather together to talk about the concept of "one China."

Legislator Lin Cheng-tse of the Kuomintang suggested in the Legislative Yuan that the ROC executive and legislative heads and their mainland China counterparts hold such a meeting to help solve cross-strait problems.

Lin noted that Taiwan's stock market had nearly crashed through the psychologically important 6,000-point threshold, which has dealt a serious blow to investors. He added that the government should help solve the problem.
Lin said that some people say that domestic economic development has reached a bottleneck and that Taiwan may have to give in to mainland China and open direct trade, postal and transport links.

But as cross-strait relations have been stalled over the "one China" question, he has therefore suggested that the top leaders between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait meet each other to communicate on the "one China" concept.
Premier Tang Fei, responding to Lin's proposal, said that such a meeting does not "hinge on us, but on mainland China."
The legislator then suggested that perhaps the use of a third party will help -- meaning that figures from Taiwan, mainland China and the United States would all meet to talk.

The premier said that of course an intervening third party would be helpful, but he noted that there is not even a national consensus on the question on the unification or independence of Taiwan. "How can we talk about anything with the other side of the strait?" Tang asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD BACKS CONDITIONAL OPENING OF CASINOS ON OFFSHORE ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development called an inter-ministerial meeting Tuesday to discuss the feasibility of allowing opening of casinos on offshore islands on an experimental basis.

CEPD Vice Chairman Chang Ching-sen, who chaired the meeting, said the council basically supports conditional opening of casinos on offshore islands since Taiwan has been unable to completely eradicate gambling games.

Quoting a CEPD study, Chang said Taiwan can follow measures adopted by advanced countries in legalizing casino business. For instance, he said, the government can hold an open tender for hopefuls to bid for the rights to operate casinos and impose a ceiling on the total number of casinos in each selected region.

The CEPD also suggested that the Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Ministry of the Interior work out accompanying measures to ensure orderly opening of casinos on an experimental basis and to minimize the possible adverse impact of the liberalization.

According to the CEPD report, prepared by the council's Sectoral Planning Department, 105 countries or regions around the world now have legally licensed casinos. Both Taiwan and Singapore have not legalized casino business.

The report said the government can consider allowing selected offshore islands or disaster zones hardest-hit by last year's devastating earthquake to operate casinos on an experimental basis to help boost economic development in those regions.

Nevertheless, the report said, local governments should hold a plebiscite first to explore the opinions of local residents about the proposal. Without the support of the majority of local residents, the report said, the ban on casino business should be maintained.

Chang said speakers of the county councils in less-developed offshore and eastern Taiwan counties, including Penghu and Taitung, suggested opening of casinos in their counties on an experimental basis during their meeting with President Chen Shui-bian on June 20. Cabinet Secretary-General Wea Chi-lin then asked the CEPD to assess the feasibility of the proposal.

In addition, tourist industry operators in the 921 earthquake-stricken zones have also urged the government to permit them to operate casinos to help revive the battered tourist industry in the regions.

Officials from the CEPD, the Ministry of the Interior, the Tourism Bureau, the National Police Administration and the Ministry of Justice as well as scores of scholars and experts attended the inter-ministerial meeting.

While CEPD and tourist officials gave a thumbs-up to the proposed conditional opening of casinos in selected areas, officials from other government agencies and most scholars strongly opposed the proposal.
The opponents said casino business will only have limited positive effects on local tourist industries, but will cause serious social and criminal problems. No consensus was reached at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING UNILATERALLY SETS UP FIRST ISLAND DEFENSE LINE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Beijing has unilaterally declared a "first island defense line" which includes waters surrounding the Tiaoyutai Islands, Spratly Islands, Taiwan and Singapore.

The Yomiuri Shimbun, a Japanese mass-circulated daily newspaper, quoted a source from the Japanese Self-Defense Force as saying that in order to ensure that the area's vast oceanic resources come under its control, Beijing intends to enforce its claims by 2020.
Yomiuri also quoted Kazuya Natsukawa, ex-chief of the General Staff of Japan's military, as reporting that Beijing has insisted that it can safeguard Asian stability with its own forces.

The paper also reported that a two-week submarine rescue training exercise initiated by the United States is currently being held in the South China Sea about 360 kms northeast of Singapore. A total of 11 countries in the region are to take part in the joint training course, which began Monday.

Japan, Singapore, and South Korea have all dispatched submarines or rescue vessels to take part in the training, in addition to the United States. The drill is focused on training military personnel how to conduct rescue operations for both nuclear-powered and conventional submarines that run aground or suffer accidents while operating more than 100 meters beneath the sea.
Mainland China, Great Britain, Australia, Indonesia, Chile, Canada and Russia have sent observers to the training.

The exercise is being held in waters that fall within the first island defense line unilaterally claimed by Beijing. The United States and Singapore have invited Beijing to take part in the rescue training, in order to avoid isolating mainland China in this region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI GERMAN SCHOOL MARKS 10TH ANNIVERSARY OF GERMAN REUNIFICATION

TEXT.P: Deutsche Schule Taipei held a special "knocking down the Berlin Wall" ceremony Tuesday to mark the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 and the 10th anniversary of German reunification.

The ceremony was co-chaired by Klaus Rupprecht, the new German representative to the Republic of China, Sabina Hagemann-Unlusoy, director of the German Cultural Center, and Michael Lagler, headmaster of the German school in Taipei.

During the ceremony held on the school campus in Yangmingshan, suburban Taipei, the participants jointly knocked down a wall modeled on the Berlin Wall to symbolize the falling of "mind walls" that separate individuals.

Speaking on the occasion, Lagler said the specially built Berlin Wall replica symbolized a wall between people and a barrier between countries. "We hope the special knocking-down ceremony will remind all mankind to get rid of their `mind walls' and forge friendship with each other," he added.

Hagemann-Unlusoy noted that what remains of the Berlin Wall can now be seen only in museums. Describing the Berlin Wall as a prison wall that prevented the people of the former communist East Germany from fleeing to the free world, she said it is a wonderful thing that the Berlin Wall no longer exists.

Rupprecht said young Germans may have little memory of the Berlin Wall, but added that although the Berlin Wall has already fallen, there are still "mind walls" in the hearts of West and East Germans. The de facto German ambassador to Taiwan encouraged all schoolchildren to remove their "mind walls."

In addition to German, French and British students on the Swire European Campus, representatives of German companies in Taiwan and student delegates from several local schools also attended the special celebration activity. Many students took home "debris" of the Berlin Wall replica as souvenirs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VEEP SADDENED BY FORCED CANCELLATION OF TOURS OF U.S. FIRMS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Anita Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Monday she was saddened by restrictions imposed by the U.S. government on her activities during her layover in the United States.

Lu arrived in San Francisco Sunday evening for an overnight transit stay on her way home after a four-state "journey of soft power diplomacy" aimed at shoring up the ROC's diplomatic relations with its allies in Central America.

Lu, who concurrently heads a Presidential Office science-technology advisory committee, said she originally planned to visit two U.S. high-tech companies in the Silicon Valley on Monday. However, Lu said she was forced to change her schedule after the U.S. government pressured the two firms -- Hewlett-Packard Co. and Cisco System Co.-- to reject her visits.
During a dinner hosted by Tseng Ching-yuan, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in San Francisco, Lu said she is by no means a troublemaker.
"I feel sad to face many restrictions on my activities in a democratic country like the United States," Lu said emotionally.
On Monday morning, Lu toured a science/technology museum in San Francisco and met with several scholars in her hotel room to exchange views on Taiwan's science/technology development.

Lu and her entourage left Taipei Sept. 22 for a four-state journey which took her to El Salvador, Honduras, Belize and Guatemala. She made transit stops in Los Angeles and Miami on her way to El Salvador. She is scheduled to leave San Francisco at 1:05 a.m. Tuesday and will return to Taipei Wednesday local time.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT IS PRIORITY OF ROC GOVERNMENT: CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Central Taiwan, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that he will make economic development the priority of all his policies after the political environment improves.
Chen made the remarks during a visit to Taichung County, also home of a major industrial park and many companies including the Wheel Giant, Inc., the manufacturer of Giant bicycles.

Chen indicated that after cross-Taiwan Strait ties, diplomatic concerns and security issues are all stable, he will give priority to economic development. He added that he will not forget any of the social welfare measures that he promised in his electoral campaign, and said that they will all be implemented in the future.

Chen said he feels that there are no "sunset industries," and people cannot define absolutely what is a traditional industry and what is a high-tech one. He urged industrial sectors to pursue reforms in order to reap the maximum financial benefit.

As an example, he cited Taichia township in Taichung County, which used to be famous for its straw mat industry, but now makes one of the most well-known bicycles in the world, and has also developed sophisticated biotechnology firms.

Although the bicycle industry has been called a traditional industry, Wheel Giant, Inc. has been pursuing renovation and its bicycles are a best seller in Taiwan, mainland China, Europe and the United States.
"That proves that if there is dream, there is hope," Chen said, adding that as long as people have confidence and do not abandon traditional industries, there is definitely a bright future for them.
Chen also cited his personal example, saying that he has done what was once considered impossible. He urged the public to have faith in the country.

Amid the recent chaotic financial and economic situation in Taiwan, Chen said there are some people who still cannot accept the results of the election held in May. Chen went on to say that he will focus on various reforms and make economic development the priority of his administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY ELITE TO MEET IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Representatives of the world's semiconductor industry will meet in Taipei in December to map a blueprint for the industry's technical development, sources from the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association (TSIA) said Tuesday.

The meeting, to be jointly sponsored by TSIA, the Semiconductor Industry of America (SIA), and flagship associations of the semiconductor industry from the European Union, Japan and South Korea -- the EECA, the EIAJ and the KSIA, respectively -- is aimed at working out guidelines for the technical development of the semiconductor industry for the next 15 years, according to a TSIA spokesman.
It will be the first time the world's semiconductor industry leaders will have met in Taiwan for an international meeting.

The SIA first convened the international semiconductor meeting in San Francisco in 1998. The second meeting was held in Japan in 1999 and this year's Taiwan meeting will be the third of its kind, the TSIA spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIRWAYS TO RESUME TAIPEI-MANILA CARGO SERVICE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's EVA Airways announced Tuesday that its cargo flight service between Taipei and Manila will be resumed on Wednesday.
This will be the first Taiwan flight to service the Taipei-Manila route since the two countries suspended their aviation links last March.
EVA will operate two weekly fights to Manila, using MD-11 and B747-400 all-cargo planes.

Last week, an EVA spokesman said the company would resume its passenger flights to Manila from Oct. 9. The spokesman said that passenger bookings are growing rapidly, with some flights having a 70 percent-80 percent reservation rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRENADIAN PRIME MINISTER KEITH MITCHELL TO VISIT SOON

TEXT.P: Grenadian Prime Minister Keith Mitchell and a three-member entourage will arrive in Taipei Wednesday for an eight-day visit to the Republic of China.

While in Taipei, Mitchell will take part in ROC National Day celebrations on Oct. 10 and will also call on President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Tang Fei, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and Chung Chen, director general of the Government Information Office.

Mitchell and his entourage will also visit Taipei World Trade Center, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, the National Palace Museum and other places of cultural and economic interest in Taiwan, before departing on Oct. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG MEMBERS STAGE DEMONSTRATION IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: More than 80 Falun Gong members Tuesday sat peacefully together in a vacant lot outside Beijing's liaison office in Hong Kong in protest against China's nation-wide suppression of the spiritual movement.
A spokesman for the demonstrators said they hoped that China would stop suppressing the spiritual movement and quickly release all Falun Gong members arrested Sunday on Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
Hundreds of Falun Gong members, who staged demonstrations on Tiananmen Square Sunday in protest against government crackdown on Falun Gong, have been detained by police.

The spokesman said some Beijing leaders, led by President Jiang Zeming, have abused their power in suppressing peaceful demonstrations. He expressed the hope that China would resolve the "Falun Gong problem" in a fair and peaceful way.
Falun Gong was outlawed in China as an "evil cult" last year, but members of the spiritual movement have kept resisting the suppression.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA CARD SET RECORD IN TRANSACTION NUMBER AND VOLUME

TEXT.P: Taiwan VISA card holders concluded 17.66 million transactions in August with a total volume of NT$47.74 billion (US$1.54 billion), both single-month record highs, the VISA International Service Association announced Tuesday.

The association said Taiwan VISA card owners made 116.3 million transactions with a total volume of NT$300 billion during the first eight months of the year, which made up the lion's share of credit card use by Taiwan consumers.

The VISA Association issued 336,000 new cards in August which brought its total issuance in Taiwan to more than 16.7 million cards and makes it the biggest card issuer in Taiwan, said the association.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER RESIGNS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Tang Fei submitted his resignation Tuesday, for what he described as "health reasons." His resignation was accepted by President Chen Shui-bian that evening.
At a press conference convened at around 8:30 p.m., Tang announced that his resignation would take effect immediately.

Tang expressed his gratitude to Chen for "fully understanding his intention to leave" and to the executive and legislative yuans for "their support" during his four-month period in office, the shortest premiership in ROC history.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DEFENSE CHIEF SEES OPENING IN CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen said Tuesday that he sees an opportunity for Taiwan and mainland China to improve relations after an "apparent change" in Beijing's attitude toward Taipei.

"Somehow there's a way to bridge that difference if people of goodwill and creativity take advantage of the opportunity," he said during a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a private research institute in Washington.
Cohen said that he saw "a change in both the tone and the content" of Beijing's message when he visited mainland China in July.
He noted that, a year ago or less, the Beijing leadership was talking about the possible use of military force against Taiwan and setting a deadline for cross-strait negotiations.
During his discussions with the same leaders in July, Cohen said, the message was that "they did not give up the right to use force but they had no intent to use force."
"I think there was quite a significant difference in both the tone and the content of that message," Cohen said, although he admitted that others may fail to see a change in Beijing's position.
Another reason for his optimism about cross-strait relations is his perception that the two sides are in fact not too far apart.
"The Chinese leadership would say it's `one China, two systems,'" he said. "And if you listen to the new Taiwanese president, he's said `one China, two interpretations.'"
Until both sides find a way to bridge their differences peacefully, he said, the U.S. will maintain its position.
The U.S. has a one-China policy, supports the three joint communiques with Beijing and also supports the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, he went on.

On relations between Washington and Beijing, Cohen said that mainland China "wants to get back on a solid track with the United States" after a year-long hiatus in the wake of the bombing of Beijing's embassy in Belgrade in May 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG'S RESIGNATION MAY HAVE MAJOR IMPACT ON TAIWAN POLITICS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Tang Fei submitted his resignation Tuesday, for what he described as "health reasons." His resignation was accepted by President Chen Shui-bian that evening.
Tang's resignation is expected by local political observers to have a major and profound impact on the political situation in Taiwan.
At a press conference convened at around 8:30 p.m., Tang announced that his resignation would take effect immediately.

Tang expressed his gratitude to Chen for "fully understanding his intention to leave" and to the Executive and Legislative Yuans for "their support" during his four-month period in office, the shortest premiership in ROC history.

Tang denied that his resignation was related to a disagreement between him and Chen as to whether or not construction of the fourth nuclear power plant should continue. Tang, a member of the opposition Kuomintang, supports the continued construction of the plant, while Chen and the DPP are resolutely opposed.

Presidential Office Acting Secretary-General Chen Che-nan confirmed Tang's resignation later in the evening, saying at a press conference that the president accepted Tang's resignation on the grounds that Tang indeed has health problems and has voiced his intention to resign several times over the past several months.

President Chen and the Presidential Office offered their sincerest gratitude to Tang for his devotion to the administration and expressed hope that he will return to the government team as soon as he has recovered, the acting presidential secretary-general said.
Tang, 68, was born in Jiangxu Province of mainland China. A graduate of the ROC Air Force Academy, Tang sought advanced military education at the Warfare College of the Armed Forces University.

An air force pilot-turned officer, Tang has been military attache to the ROC Embassy in South Africa, president of the ROC Air Force Academy and director of the Political Warfare Department under the Air Force General Headquarters.
Other prominent posts he has held before becoming premier include commander-in-chief of the Air Force, chief of the general staff and defense minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TO TRY TO STABILIZE INTEREST, EXCHANGE RATES

TEXT.P: Following the resignation of Premier Tang Fei Tuesday evening, a Central Bank of China official said the bank will make every effort to stabilize interest and foreign exchange rates so as to "minimize the political shock to the nation."
The CBC official said that despite Tang's resignation, the CBC will convene its third-quarter session of the joint meeting of its boards of directors and supervisors on Oct. 5 as scheduled.

Chou A-ding, director of the Foreign Exchange Bureau of the CBC, said that the foreign exchange market will be decided by supply and demand, although he added that the CBC will intervene if a seasonal, occasional or abnormal situation occurs.
Asked about the inflow and outflow of foreign capital, Chou said that the CBC has a mechanism to strictly monitor the situation in this regard.

At the same time, sources in local banking circles said that Tang's resignation will not only be a shock to the local financial and stock market but will also have a negative impact on the national budget now being deliberated in the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CRITICIZES PROPOSAL FOR SCRAPPING FOURTH NUCLEAR POWER PLANT

TEXT.P: The secretary-general of a Kuomintang think tank criticized Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi Tuesday for "lacking professionalism" by proposing to halt construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant.

P.K. Chiang said that although Lin presented alternatives to the fourth nuclear power plant while proposing to scrap the nuclear power project, there is no guarantee that his alternatives are feasible.

Lin's decision to propose a halt to the project "lacked professionalism and conscientiousness," said Chiang, a former economics minister and former Council for Economic Planning and Development chairman.

The controversial plant has been a political hot potato, with Premier Tang Fei, a KMT member, supporting continued construction, while President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party are opposed to the project.

Tang told legislators that he himself was not satisfied with the alternatives presented by Lin and resigned from the premiership Tuesday evening, although poor health was cited as his reason for quitting.
Chiang criticized Lin for allowing "political consideration" to influence his proposal and disregarding Taiwan's economic needs and national security.

Claiming that the fourth nuclear power plant will be "10 times as safe" as the existing first, second and third plants, and that the nuclear waste produced by the fourth plant will be only 25 percent of that produced by any of the existing ones, Chiang said that if the government wants to cease the on-going project, it should first scrap the more hazardous ones.
Regarding the alternatives submitted by Lin, Chiang said that there is no guarantee that they can be finished in the next few years.
He added that Lin also failed to mention the air pollution problems which arise when coal and natural gas are used as the fuel for thermal power plants.
The transportation of coal and natural gas from foreign countries for thermal power plants are also vulnerable to a blockade by mainland China, Chiang said.
The KMT's position, he said, is to continue construction of the fourth nuclear power plant, while also carrying out projects for alternatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES TO MAINTAIN NORMAL ALERT FOLLOWING PREMIER'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: The Armed Forces of the Republic of China will maintain normal alert and will not upgrade its combat preparedness in the wake of the resignation of Premier Tang Fei, a Ministry of National Defense spokesman said Tuesday.
Spokesman Huang Shui-sheng said that the armed forces will maintain its normal operations and training but will watch the cross-Taiwan Strait situation closely.

At the same time, a Financial Ministry official said that the National Stabilization Fund will intervene in the local bourse if there are any "abnormal" stock market developments in the wake of Tang's resignation.

Yen Ching-chang, vice finance minister and concurrently executive secretary of the NSF, announced that the fund control commission has authorized him to use the fund to intervene in the daily worsening stock market, and that after an intervention on Tuesday, the Taipei Stock Exchange Market rose 119 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD SEMICONDUCTOR COMMISSION POSTPONES BEIJING'S ENTRY

TEXT.P: The World Semiconductor Council has postponed its processing of Beijing's bid for membership of the body, an official of the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association said Tuesday.

Hu Cheng-ta, secretary-general of the association, said the Chinese Semiconductor Industry Association is considered by the council to be a state-governed organ rather than a private industry association.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEARCH OF NEWSPAPER OFFICE SPARKS CRITICISM

TEXT.P: The search of a major newspaper's head office Tuesday by Taipei District Prosecutors Office sparked criticism from local political parties.

Several prosecutors and investigators led by Prosecutor Huang Chuan-lu of the Taipei District Prosecutors Office went to the head office of China Times Express and the houses of two of its reporters to search for the transcript of an interrogation which had been leaked to the media and carried in last Saturday's China Times Express.

Opposition People First Party legislators described the district prosecutors office's action as "serious and gross" and urged President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Tang Fei, and Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan to extend their apologies to the public.

At a press conference, Lee Ching-an, PFP spokesperson in the Legislative Yuan, said the PFP respects the judicial system but added that the freedom of the press is very important and "can never be trampled on."

Legislator Shen Chih-hwei said now that Taiwan has entered the era of freedom of speech, such tactics should not be tolerated. She urged Tang and Minister of Justice Chen to express their apologies and called for the Control Yuan (Taiwan's highest government watchdog body) to investigate to see if the prosecutors' search infringed on human rights and the freedom of the press.

Legislator Lee Ching-hua said that President Chen had lauded the China Times a day earlier on its 50th founding anniversary for the newspaper's contributions to the promotion of democracy in Taiwan. However, the incident which occurred less that 24 hours later made Taiwan's democracy "a big joke in the international arena," Lee said.

Lin Feng-cheng, secretary-general of the opposition Kuomintang, also expressed his party's concern over the incident, saying the KMT respects the judiciary's handling of legal cases, but hopes that it will abide by procedure.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CEPD CHIEF URGES FORMATION OF COALITION GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Former Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang urged Tuesday the formation of a coalition government to stabilize the political situation following Premier Tang Fei's resignation.
He told the media that the best way to stabilize the political situation and win back the support of the people would be to form a coalition government.

After the March 18 presidential election, Chiang said, the Kuomintang, which still controls most seats in the Legislative Yuan, tried to persuade the Democratic Progressive Party government to let the KMT form the Cabinet, but failed.
Later, he went on, the KMT demanded the formation of a coalition government, but the proposal was also rejected by the DPP.

As the present situation is urgent, Chiang said, President Chen Shui-bian, who gained only 40 percent of the vote in the presidential election, should also listen to the views of the remaining 60 percent of Taiwan's voters.

For the sake of keeping industries from leaving the island, he said that all parties should sit down to discuss effective measures, and added that the KMT is willing to cooperate in this aspect. Chiang is now the secretary-general of a KMT think tank.
At the same time, DPP Legislator Trong Chai affirmed Tang's contributions to assisting the new government during his four-month stint as premier.

But Chai urged the president to select a new premier with great care, so as to avoid having another short-lived premier, as it is very important now to ensure sound operations in economic development, the stock market, and the political and military situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION: TAIWAN FACES POLITICAL TURMOIL WITH DEPARTURE OF PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan faces a fresh round of political turmoil with the sudden resignation of Premier Tang Fei, the opposition People First Party said Tuesday night.

PFP Chairman James Soong said the country is encountering a political upheaval and he urged all political parties to put the country's interests over party benefits and work together to pull the country out of the difficulty.
He called on President Chen Shui-bian to stage an all-party conference to draw up a common front on issues concerning the national interest.

PFP Legislator Chen Cheng-sheng warned after Tang's announcement of his resignation that the island is facing a period of political uncertainty, economic collapse, domestic industry exodus and international doubt as to its credibility.

In an interview with a local cable television station, Chen said it is a pity that Tang quit because he flew in the face of Chen by insisting on pressing ahead with the construction of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant.

He said it has turned out that Chen, who touted his administration as a "government for the whole people" rather than for any political party, has chosen to follow the Democratic Progressive Party's dictate in preference to what he claimed is "the majority public opinion" on the issue.

Opposition Kuomintang spokesman Jason Hu told a press conference that his party appreciates Tang's contributions during his four months in office and is disappointed at his departure, which he described as a loss to the government and the people.

He criticized Chen for over-stepping his constitutional mandate by disregarding the premier's authority, which he said led to Tang's resignation, although Tang himself cited ill-health as his reason for leaving his post.
He promised that the KMT will do its utmost to secure the welfare of the people while the country faces a possible political disturbance.
KMT leaders went into a huddle immediately after Tang's resignation, in a meeting expected to continue late into the night.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan was quoted as wondering why Tang would quit after Chen had promised to respect his decision on the nuclear plant.
The KMT whip at the Legislative Yuan, He Chih-hui, predicted a political storm is forming in light of the government budget, still pending approval at the Legislative Yuan.
He blamed Chen for deserting the premier after milking him for all he was worth.
Minority New Party leader Hau Lung-ping regretted Tang's departure, calling it an unfortunate loss for not only the DPP but also the people of Taiwan.
He said Tang's resignation is an indication that Chen's "government for the whole people" has collapsed and that the country is moving into uncharted territory.

The DPP remained tight-lipped on Tang's resignation Tuesday night. Secretary-General Wu Nei-jen, who has publicly criticized Tang as incompetent and has long been prodding him to resign, said his party would call a press conference the following morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF SPEAKS ON CABINET RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will not necessarily have to resign en masse following Premier Tang Fei's resignation Tuesday evening, a government spokesman said.

Chung Chin, director general of the Government Information Office said at a press briefing that Tang had only asked for his "personal leave" and he thinks that his move would not necessarily mean that the other members of his Cabinet would have to follow in his footsteps.
But Lee Juo-i, deputy director-general of the Central Personnel Administration pointed out that whether the Cabinet should quit en masse should be decided by the Presidential Office.

While meeting President Chen Shui-bian earlier in the evening, Tang again submitted his resignation, the fourth time he has done so since Sept. 19, Presidential Office Secretary-General Chen Che-nan said, adding that after taking into account Tang's health condition, the president approved his resignation.
Tang was hospitalized for removing his chest tumor even before his swearing-in, and was later readmitted when his surgical wound become infected.
Chung said that the outgoing premier will be present at the weekly Cabinet meeting, to be presided over by Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Wednesday, to bid farewell to his Cabinet.
Tang, who assumed his office on May 20, was the shortest-serving premier of the nation.

Meanwhile, a Legislative Yuan official responsible for meeting affairs said that the budget plan now being deliberated at the legislature has to be dropped and the incoming Cabinet will have to prepare a new one.

If the Legislative Yuan fails to complete screening and approval of the new budget plan, government agencies will be able to make temporary use of the budget amount set for last fiscal year for ordinary administrative affairs in accordance with the regulations set forth in Budget Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MOVES TO STABILIZE STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong announced Tuesday night that the maximum single-day drop of stock prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange will be halved to 3.5 percent over the coming six business days from Wednesday.
The maximum single-day rise will remain unchanged at 7 percent, he said.
Shea called a press conference to make the announcement, hoping to minimize the impact on the stock market by Premier Tang Fei's sudden resignation.
The minister also said that the National Stabilization Fund started making intervention on the stock market Tuesday, with Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang taking charge of the operations.
Owing to the intervention of the stabilization fund, the benchmark weighted price index gained 119.37 points Tuesday to close at 6,143.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER FAVORED TO TAKE OVER PREMIERSHIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is expected to name the new premier Wednesday, and Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung is the most favored choice, according to sources close to the Presidential Office.
The new premier will replace Tang Fei who resigned Tuesday evening, citing poor health.

Following Tang's resignation, Chen called a meeting with several influential Democratic Progressive Party leaders, including DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh, DPP Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen and former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung.
The sources said that Chen asked Lin about his intention of taking over the premiership, but Lin declined the offer. As a result, Vice Premier Chang became the most favored choice for the post.
Chang, 63, has served as legislator and presidential secretary-general.

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 4, or the seventh day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1669: Rembrandt van Rijn, Dutch painter whose works are unmatched in their portrayal of subtle human emotions, dies at the age of 63.
1777: U.S. forces led by George Washington attack the British at Germantown but are repulsed.
1822: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th President of the United State, is born. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by one electoral vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops in 1877, supported the welfare of minority groups, and reformed the civil service.
1824: Mexico becomes a republic.
1830: Belgium becomes an independent state after being part of the Netherlands since 1815.
1878: China opens its first embassy in the United States when Chen Lan-pin presents his credentials to President Rutherford B. Hayes.
1904: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, French sculptor and the creator of the Statue of Liberty, dies at the age of 70.
1905: Orville Wright, American aviator, is the first person to fly an aircraft for more than 33 minutes.
1910: Portugal is proclaimed a republic as King Manuel II flees to Britain.
1924: Charlton Heston, American actor, is born. He was best known for his appearances in such film epics as "El Cid" and "Ben Hur", for which he won an Oscar.
1947: The Russians successfully launch Sputnik I, the world's first artificial satellite.
1947: Max Planck, German physicist, dies in his home in Gottingen at the age of 89. He won a 1918 Nobel Prize for discoveries in connection with the quantum theory.
1949: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the USSR.
1949: The US State Department reaffirms its recognition of the Nationalist government as the only legal government of China.
1952: The pacemaker, an external device developed by Dr. Paul Zoll of Harvard Medical School, is for the first time fitted to a human, David Schwarts, to control his heartbeat.
1969: Anthony Grey, Reuters correspondent, is freed from house arrest after being held by the Chinese communists in Beijing for 20 months.
1974: The 75-member Peiping opera troupe leaves Taipei for the United States on a 72-day performance tour.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1978: The ROC Ministry of National Defense announces the successful development of the "Hsiung Feng" (male bee) missile.
1986: A 12-member political reform group of the Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT) decides to announce the lifting of the emergency decree at a proper time, and passed legislative principles for the National Security Law during the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: An Israeli cargo plane crashes into a residential area in Amsterdam, killing more than 200 people.
1993: Russian troops loyal to President Boris Yeltsin capture the parliament building in Moscow after two days of fighting in which more than 300 die. Vice President Alexander Rutskoi and other parliament leaders are herded into Lefortovo prison.
1994: An undersea earthquake rocks Russia's Kuril Islands, killing more than 16 people.
1999: Taiwan's U-Land Airlines forges a cooperation relationship with Vietnam's Pacific Airlines (PA) to operate flights between Taipei and Ho Chi Minh City.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is true of the really great moral man, that every act of his life becomes an example for generations, everything he does becomes a statute for generations, and every word he utters becomes a law for generations."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 145.52 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 145.52 points to close at 5,997.92.
Market turnover amounted to NT$25.27 billion (US$0.81 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY ON HIGH ALERT AFTER PREMIER'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's armed forces have been on high alert against any unusual movements on the opposite side of the Taiwan Strait following Premier Tang Fei's sudden resignation announcement Tuesday, said Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming on Wednesday.

Military surveillance has shown that everything has remained normal on the mainland Chinese side of the strait and that there have not been any unusual military movements since Tang's resignation was accepted by President Chen Shui-bian at around 8:40 p.m. Tuesday, the chief of the general staff said.

Reporting at the Legislative Yuan, Tang said President Chen instructed the military to heighten its vigilance so as to strengthen the nation and the people's security protection immediately after the premier resigned.
Tang, however, added that the armed forces have not upgraded their combat preparedness despite shifting to a higher level of alert.
The top brasshat stressed that the military is the nation's defense mainstay and consistently upholds the nation's security regardless of which party or individuals are in power.
Premier Tang Fei submitted his resignation Tuesday for what he described as "health reasons." His resignation was accepted by President Chen that evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG CHUN-HSIUNG TAKES OVER AS PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has appointed Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to take the place of Tang Fei as premier, it was announced Wednesday.
Chen Che-nan, acting secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said in a brief press conference that Yu Shyi-kun, the former vice premier, will serve as secretary-general to the President.
Chen also said that the Cabinet will immediately undergo a minor reshuffle and that the new Cabinet will strengthen its economic and financial team in order to meet the expectations of the public.
Chang, 62, a long-term legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), served as Chen's campaign manager during the presidential race and then as secretary-general to the President.

Yu, 52, a former two-term magistrate of Ilan County and spokesperson of the DPP presidential campaign, last served as the vice premier before resigning to take responsibility for a failed rescue operation in central Taiwan.

The acting secretary-general also said that President Chen reaffirmed his intention of inviting leaders of the major opposition political parties to a discussion on national affairs, adding that he hopes the opposition leaders will overcome their own differences with the DPP and attend the roundtable meeting.
He also said that President Chen is deeply sorry about Tang's departure and that he expressed his sincere praise and appreciation for Tang's role over the past four months.
Tang, citing that his poor health made him unfit for the premiership, tendered his resignation Tuesday night.

Observers had said that his departure was inevitable as the veteran Kuomintang member, invited by President Chen to form "a government of all people," had to step down as his position on the continued construction of the controversial fourth nuclear plant ran directly counter to that of the Presidential Office and the DPP.
Meanwhile, Chung Chin, a government spokesperson, said that the short-term Cabinet will resign en masse, but added that personnel changes in the Cabinet will be kept to a minimum.
Chung, director general of the Government Information Office, said that President Chen, out of consideration for national stability, wants to keep the Cabinet reshuffle to a minimum.

Chang spoke with Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong and Chung after presiding over his first Executive Yuan floor meeting as the premier. Both Shea and Chung would not elaborate on the contents of their discussion with Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 145.52 points to close at 5,997.92.

Affected by the news of Premier Tang Fei's resignation, the bourse opened at 5,989.45, but due to purchases by government funds, shares prices began to go higher. The bourse fluctuated between 5,997.92 and 5,946.95 during trading.

A total of 1.11 billion stocks worth NT$25.27 billion (US$0.81 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.29 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$87.91 billion (US$2.82 billion).
Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.5 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 3.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 2.7 percent, textile issues at 2.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.8 percent, construction stocks at 1.6 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 523 to 53, with 31 stocks remaining unchanged.
