DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taipei stock index futures market were lower Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved down 219 points to close at 6,043, with 839 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for November decreased 220 points to finish at 6,075, with 77 contract transactions, while December futures dropped 225 points to close at 6,223, with 43 contracts changing hands.
March 2001 futures plunged 226 points to finish at 6,257 with four contract transactions, while June 2001 futures lost 165 points to close at 6,130, with 20 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Wednesday at 6,262 for October, 6,295 for November, 6,448 for December, 6,483 for next March, and 6,295 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
October TE futures moved down 11.3 points to close at 311.65, with 269 contract transactions, while November TE futures lost 11.35 points to finish at 313.15, with 70 contracts changing hands.
December TE futures fell 11.3 points to close at 314.95, with 21 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures lost 24 points to close at 744, with 886 contract transactions, while November TF futures decreased 19 points to finish at 748, with 19 contracts traded.

December TF futures dropped 24 points to close at 747, with eight contract transactions, while March 2001 TF futures moved down 24 points to finish at 757.6, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June 2001 TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WON'T SIT IDLY BY POLITICAL TURMOIL: LIEN

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the major opposition Kuomintang, expressed the hope Wednesday that the political turmoil will soon be over one day after the resignation of Tang Fei as the premier.
Tang tendered his resignation Tuesday evening, citing his ill health as the reason. His deputy, Chang Chun-hsiung, has been appointed to take over the post.

Chairman Lien said that Tang's departure is not due to the ostensible health reasons, saying that the veteran KMT member had to step down because his ideals and policies differed sharply from that of the president.

Lien said that with cross-strait relations stalled, stock and currency markets slumping, economic development down, and government attitude wavering, the KMT, as the major opposition, cannot sit idly by the political turmoil and watch the nation's past glory and economic prosperity being trampled.

He expressed the hope that the government will place national stability and economic development as its priority, stressing that if the turmoil continues, then it is meaningless for this government to continue to rule the nation.
Meanwhile, James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP), said Wednesday that in the interests of the general public, political parties have to make national stability their responsibility.
Soong said that the PFP supports the president's idea of convening a roundtable meeting to discuss major national issues.

Sun Ta-chien, the PFP spokesperson, criticized the Presidential Office for its lack of sincerity in pushing for the proposed roundtable meeting, saying it was only using the idea as a facade to stabilize the political situation because of the problems it was facing as a minority government.

Sun said that both the KMT and PFP have been preparing for the meeting for a long time, and he urged the Presidential Office to be sincere in squarely facing the constitutional crisis confronting the nation.

Sun also said that this is a critical time when the political wisdom of the president, new premier and new Cabinet will be tested, and he called for the establishment of a communication mechanism between the ruling party and the Legislative Yuan, which is dominated by the opposition parties.
On the question on whether to overturn the Cabinet, another minor opposition New Party member said that the NP is against the idea.
Lai Shyh-bao, NP whip in the Legislative Yuan, said that from the point of view of national stability, the NP will not work toward toppling the Cabinet just because of Tang Fei's departure.
Lai said that toppling the Cabinet will mean a non-confidence vote, and as the NP still does not know how the new premier will perform, it is not advocating the action.
Lee Ching-an, spokesperson for the PFP, said reshuffling the Cabinet is one of the president's rightful powers and should not be used as a reason for toppling the Cabinet.
She said however that if the new Cabinet goes against the will of the people, then her party will propose following such a course of action.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN LAMBASTS DPP AS ALL TALK

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday that the KMT is as sorry as the Taiwan public about Premier Tang Fei's resignation the previous day, labeling it the result of a political struggle rather than due to Tang's "health problems."

Lien lambasted the ruling Democratic Progressive Party as being all talk and little useful action over the past four months, saying it had "constantly held the premier back and hindered him rather than helping his performance."

Lien said the new government has not only been disrespectful towards the majority in the legislature, but has disregarded the premier's authority that is mandated by the Republic of China Constitution.

He made the remarks during a meeting with Premier Tang Fei who submitted his resignation Tuesday for what he described as "health reasons." Tang's resignation was accepted by President Chen Shui-bian that evening.

Tang, who said Tuesday that his resignation took effect immediately, visited the KMT Central Committee the first thing in the morning. When he arrived, the KMT chairman gave Tang, a KMT member, a bear-hug welcoming him "home."
Tang told Lien that he chose to resign because he felt he could not implement his ideals that he believes are all in the interests of the nation and the people.

Meanwhile, Tang said he has done his utmost over the past four months as the premier, particularly on issues regarding domestic affairs and the development of cross-strait relations. "I have no regrets," he noted.
Lien invited Tang to be a senior adviser to the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN FACES MAJOR TEST AFTER TANG'S DEPARTURE: JAPANESE MEDIA

TEXT.P: Several national newspapers in Japan Wednesday gave prominent coverage to the news of Republic of China Premier Tang Fei's resignation, saying his departure means Chen's four-month-old government will now face some daunting challenges.

Asahi Shimbun, Yomiuri Shimbun, Mainichi Shimbun, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Sankei Shimbun, and Tokyo Shimbun all reported that because Tang's stance of supporting the continued construction of the controversial fourth nuclear plant pitted him against President Chen Shui-bian, he tendered his resignation Tuesday evening.

Asahi Shimbun said that the resignation of Tang has plunged the "government of all people" led by President Chen into crisis and that Chen will be forced to make major judgment calls on how to run his government now.
Mainland China will quietly eye political developments in Taiwan, and progress on the stalled cross-strait relations is expected to be more difficult, reported the daily.

The Yomiuri Shimbun said that Chen faces his biggest test as his "government of all people" has been shaken after only four months. It added that the Kuomintang, the largest opposition party and the dominant force in the Legislative Yuan, will now step up its offensive and the political situation will continue to be unstable.

Mainichi Shimbun said that President Chen faces the biggest crisis of his four-month old administration. It added that the weak basis of his political power has been revealed and that the opposition camp will now step up its pressure on the ruling party, making political turmoil inevitable.
Another widely circulated newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, echoed this view.

Sankei Shimbun said President Chen's credibility in running the government will face major challenges and he will have to review the idea of "the government of all people" or study the possibility of forming a "coalition government," adding that the political situation in Taiwan is turbulent.

Tokyo Shimbun said it is very obvious that the Cabinet members have different views on domestic and foreign issues and that the Cabinet will have to undergo a major reshuffle, adding that the government's foundations will probably not become solid in the short term.

President Chen will face a major test regarding his handling of the controversial fourth nuclear plant and also the daunting task of maintaining stability through the political turmoil, the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PREMIER VOWS TO MAINTAIN POLITICAL STABILITY

TEXT.P: New Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday he will do his utmost to maintain domestic political stability and ensure continued economic development.
The legislator-turned-premier made the vow at a press conference held after he was named premier by President Chen Shui-bian and chaired a Cabinet meeting.

"Political stability and economic growth will be our highest priority," Chang said, adding that he understands very well the needs of the public -- a safe political environment, continued economic growth and stable stock market.
Chang, mindful of likely clashes with a hostile parliament dominated by the main opposition Kuomintang, also called for a new political culture of cooperation instead of conflict.
Chang said he will attentively listen to the "voice of the people" and sincerely and modestly accept the supervision of opposition parties.

In the future, Chang said, his Cabinet will strengthen communications with the Legislative Yuan and all major political parties. "I earnestly hopes that both the ruling and opposition parties can understand general public expectations of political stability and continued economic growth and work together to realize these goals," he noted.

Chang's appointment to the premiership on Wednesday took control of the Cabinet away from a member of a rival political party. Chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party replaces KMT stalwart Tang Fei who resigned late Tuesday for health reasons.

Chang, 62, lauded Tang for his dedicated services during his four-month stint as premier. "Tang has brought peace, harmony and stability to our country following Taiwan's first-ever democratic transition of power between different political parties," Chang said, adding he is convinced that all local people will remember Tang's outstanding contribution to the country forever.

The Cabinet resigned en masse in a formality Wednesday following Tang's surprise resignation the day earlier. Chang said most of the Cabinet members would be retained and a "very small-scale reshuffle" will be made in the shortest period of time possible.
He further said the Cabinet will withdraw its draft budget plan for fiscal 2001 from the Legislative Yuan Thursday for certain necessary revisions.
Chang said the Cabinet would submit a revised budget plan to the legislature after taking into consideration the views of opposition lawmakers.

Meanwhile, Chang confirmed that Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen has agreed to remain on the post. However, Chang said, Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong has expressed his firm determination to step down from his current post.

Chang would not confirm reports that Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan will serve as vice premier and that Chiou I-jen, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, will be named Cabinet secretary-general. "I'm still mulling some personnel arrangements and no final decisions have been made yet," he added.

Chang cut short his sixth term in the legislature to become secretary-general to the President in May. In late July, he was appointed vice premier when his predecessor, Yu Shyi-kun, resigned to take political responsibility for a botched rescue of four workers killed by flash flood in the Pachang Creek after waiting in vain for help for hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER REFRAINS FROM SAYING WHETHER TO STAY ON

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Wednesday he had tendered his resignation, and would not comment on whether or not the resignation would be accepted.

Lin, in the eye of a political storm triggered by Tang Fei's resignation as premier the previous evening, said last week that his ministry would advise against the continued construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant, but he also said that should the premier decide to go ahead with construction, he would forego his "personal values and feelings" and implement the project.

Lin, faced with a barrage of criticism because of his opposition to the fourth nuclear plant, said that he was "very sorry" for becoming the "flash point" of the political storm and that he would resign.

He said that the fourth nuclear power plant has been the focus of controversy for several years and that it is a problem that will have to be faced by any economics minister, adding that the criticism directed at him is "not fair."

Meanwhile, former Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said that the fourth nuclear plant should not be halted now and that proposals for alternative energy sources put forward by the Ministry of Economic Affairs are not feasible.

Reporting on the Central Standing Committee meeting of the opposition Kuomintang, Wang said the only reason for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to halt the project is political considerations, and added that the DPP should not cause the national economy to collapse to further its owns selfish ends.

Wang claimed that in terms of power supplies, the northern part of Taiwan has faced long-term electricity shortages and that the system of more transferring power from southern Taiwan to the north is not based on a sound foundation. The early completion of the fourth nuclear power plant, he said, would enable Taiwan to "shrug off the nightmare of power rationing."

He said that the island's reserves of gas, the alternative proposed by the DPP, can be maintained for only two weeks. If mainland China were to impose a blockade on Taiwan, the supply of gas would immediately run into difficulties, bringing unprecedented disaster to the island.

Wang stressed that the government's attitude toward the scrapping of the project is based on the DPP's platform that stipulates its opposition to nuclear power and because President Chen Shui-bian committed himself to scrapping it during the presidential campaign. He added that the DPP has totally ignored the fact that a moratorium would have a disastrous impact on the diminishing domestic economy and the ailing stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MEMBERS NOT ALLOWED TO JOIN CABINET WITHOUT PARTY CONSENT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang Legislative Yuan caucus resolved Wednesday that no KMT member will be allowed to join the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-held Cabinet in his or her capacity as an individual without party endorsement.

Violators of the resolution will be dealt with by the party, the KMT legislative caucus decided during a meeting called less than one day after President Chen Shui-bian accepted Premier Tang Fei's resignation.
The KMT legislators took turns to lambaste Chen for "dumping" Tang after "using" him.

Legislator Chen Chieh-ju forecast that the next Cabinet to be headed by DPP's Chang Chun-hsiung, who was vice premier during Tang's four-month tenure, will last no longer than the Tang Cabinet, given that the DPP is still the minority in the legislature.

Legislator Chang Fu-hsing said there is no feasible option for the DPP to find a way out of a political turmoil which is looming ever-larger. The opposition KMT should step forward to offer to form a coalition government so as to provide hope for the current Taiwan political situation, he added.

Legislator Chen Hsieh-sheng suggested that unless consent is reached between the DPP and the KMT, no one from the KMT will be allowed to join the DPP-led Cabinet in his or her capacity as an individual. Chen's suggestion was passed unanimously.

Meanwhile, the KMT legislative caucus announced at a press conference that the DPP's "government for the whole people" has already collapsed and claimed that the new Chang Cabinet will be doomed to fare no better than the Tang Cabinet.
The KMT caucus stressed, however, that the time is not yet ripe for a no-confidence vote against the newly formed Cabinet.

Both the KMT and the opposition People First Party called Wednesday for the suspension of the general budget screening and the general interpellation at the Legislative Yuan until the new premier has been in office for "a certain period of time."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.009 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at NT$31.322.
The local currency opened at NT$31.290 and was traded between NT$31.290 and NT$31.326.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$566 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-U.S. SUB-CABINET MEETING TO BE HELD AS SCHEDULED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Despite the surprise resignation of Republic of China Premier Tang Fei, the fifth sub-Cabinet economic dialogue between Taiwan and the U.S. will be held in Washington, D.C. Thursday as originally scheduled.

Four ROC deputy financial and economic chiefs -- Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, Central Bank of China Deputy Governor Chen Shih-meng, Vice Finance Minister Sean C. Chen and Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development -- have already arrived in Washington in preparation for attending the sub-Cabinet meeting to be held at the U.S. Treasury Department.
The ROC representative office in the U.S. said the one-day sub-Cabinet meeting will not be affected by Taiwan's Cabinet reshuffle.

ROC and U.S. officials will exchange views on a broad range of issues, including the general economic situation, intellectual property rights protection, government procurement measures, transparency in financial institution operations, liberalization of Taiwan's undersea cable market and other related topics.

ROC Representative to the U.S. Chen Chien-jen and American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush will head the ROC and the American delegations, respectively, while Lin Yi-fu and Under Secretary of the Treasury Tim Geithner will serve as chief ROC and U.S. negotiators, respectively.

The agenda will not include Taiwan's controversial fourth nuclear power plant project because it has nothing to do with any trade barriers between the two countries, Clinton administration officials said. The project mainly involves trade deals between an individual U.S. firm -- General Electric -- and the ROC's state-owned Taiwan Power Co.

The four ROC deputy economic and financial chiefs paid visits to the office of the U.S. Trade Representative, the Treasury Department, the Department of Commerce and the Federal Reserve System Tuesday for preliminary talks with relevant U.S. officials.
The annual sub-Cabinet meeting is the highest-level ROC-U.S. dialogue mechanism in the absence of formal diplomatic relations. It takes place in Washington D.C. and Taipei alternately.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRUDEAU'S SON QUOTES ROBERT FROST TO SAY GOOD-BYE TO FATHER

TEXT.P: Pierre Elliott Trudeau's eldest son paraphrased poet Robert Frost to say good-bye to his father Tuesday, saying "the woods are lovely, dark, and deep. He has kept his promises and earned his sleep."

"Je t'aime, papa," Justin Trudeau said with tears in his eyes at the end of his eulogy at a state funeral in Montreal, triggering more tears among all those attending in person and watching the ceremony via a live broadcast.
Canada has mourned the death of celebrated former Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau for the past five days. It was Justin's poignant eulogy to his father that brought an entire nation to tears.

"Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the words convey so many things to so many people -- statesman, intellectual, professor, adversary, outdoors man, lawyer, journalist, author, prime minister, but more than anything, to me, he was dad. And what a dad. He loved us with the passion and the devotion that encompassed his life," he said.

The 28-year-old son forgot one word, lover. His father had been a real life lover at least to several famous women, including constitutional lawyer Deborah Coyne, who brought her daughter with Trudeau, nine-year-old Sarah, to the memorial service. Movie actress Margot Kidder, an ex-girlfriend of Trudeau's, also turned up at the funeral clutching a bouquet of white roses.

Absent was classical guitarist Liona Boyd, who had an eight-year relationship with Trudeau during the 70s and 80s. Boyd said she chose not to be there out of respect for Trudeau's former wife Margaret and his family.
Another former girl friend, singer-actress Barbara Streisand, has rarely been mentioned by the Canadian media over the past few days, although she had had a very open affair with Trudeau.
Cuban President Fidel Castro and former U.S. President Jimmy Carter were among 21 honorary pallbearers. Carter praised Trudeau as a symbol of democracy and human rights.
Castro declared three days of mourning in Cuba for his old friend Trudeau and ordered all flags lowered to half-mast.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DECLARES WAR ON CARP

TEXT.P: The Australian government Thursday declared war on the carp, a fish that has experienced a population explosion and has been dubbed by farmers as the rabbit of the water.

The Howard government has begun mapping out plans to control the freshwater fish that was introduced to Australia in 1859. The carp has become notorious for contributing to the degradation of rivers, according to the Department of Primary Industries.

DPI Minister Warren Truss told reporters Wednesday that the carp's population density has reached one fish per square meter of water surface in some areas. It has dominated Australian waterways for 30 years and now accounts for an estimated 90 percent of the fish biomass in Australian rivers.
He said the spread of the carp is causing chaos in the natural environment by increasing water turbidity, damaging aquatic plants, and making aquatic habitat less suitable for native fish.
The DPI on Tuesday put out four publications on carp research and management as part of its efforts at substantially reducing numbers and restoring environmental balance in major rivers.
DPI, helped by experts, came up with a national strategy for carp management, which includes genetic technology to control fish fertility and also the manipulation of the food chain.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER SHIFTS TO INTERNET FROM PC PRODUCTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's personal computer giant Acer Inc. has successfully transformed itself from a leading personal computer maker into an Internet organization and is progressively launching a new generation of products and services to meet changing global demand.
In an interview with the Australian Financial Review, Acer chairman Stan Shih said the strategy has been working since the company's transformation to an Internet appliance and services provider.

This is expected to lead to new relationships in the communications sector where Acer is likely to negotiate deals with regional giants, including the government-owned telecommunications firm Telstra Corp. of Australia, the daily reported.

Shih's move came as Acer's PC sales had been languishing. The company's business fortunes are expected to reverse in the long term with the growth in the Internet and new technological advances, reported the daily.

The daily quoted Shih as saying that "our PC business is not too good, but we believe this will turn around. A major original equipment manufacturer customer in the U.S. is recovering, and although the third quarter results were disappointing, we expect to see the first quarter of the next year looking stronger."

The daily reported that Acer has been investing in its long-term future, casting its net wide across key technologies, such as storage technology, chip sets, power modules, cable modems, software and communications technology, and whatever is needed to establish a strong service structure.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT `NEVER PUSHED FOR INDEPENDENCE'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui told U.S.-based Voice of America Monday that he disagreed with mainland China's idea of unification but "has never pushed for Taiwan independence."

In a simultaneous TV and radio Chinese-language broadcast aimed at a primarily mainland audience, Lee said that it is wrong to have "only one central government to which all local governments answer," adding that the Chinese people deserve more democracy and freedom.

Lee noted that issues such as lifestyles and promoting agriculture should be left up to local government. How a handful of people in Beijing can control 1.3 billion people "is truly, seriously difficult," he said.

Lee said that the Kuomintang government, which ruled Taiwan for the past five decades before being ousted on March 18 this year, should have established a local government with Taiwanese people at its core to help the local people rule themselves. Instead, he went on, the KMT ruled "with the ways of the dynasty era."

However, he continued, Taiwan at least "had some accomplishments" in its political system and has "continually strived to promote democracy and human rights." In fact, he said, Taiwan's history can serve as a model for mainland China because "all being Chinese, if Taiwan can, why can't mainland China?"
Lee said that the promotion of democracy and political reform in Taiwan should be of "immense help" to the 1.3 billion people in the mainland.

Regarding the harsh criticism from mainland China aimed at him, Lee said that both the National Unification Council and the National Unification Guidelines were established during his time in office, and that while the late ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo legalized visits to mainland China by veterans, "real exchanges between the people began in my term."

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER QUITS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong confirmed Wednesday that he had tendered his resignation and that it had been accepted.
The economist-turned-minister said he has no regrets about departing from the government and that he is looking forward to returning to academia.
Shea offered his resignation to take token responsibility for the plunging stock market, which has lost one-third of its value since the formation of new administration on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: `BUSINESS AS USUAL' IN ROC-U.S. RELATIONS: U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A U.S. State Department spokesman said Tuesday it is convinced that unofficial relations between the U.S. and the Republic of China will remain "business as usual" following ROC Premier Tang Fei's surprise resignation.
The spokesman said the U.S. government is aware that Tang has resigned for health reasons. "We are confident that our unofficial relations with Taiwan will continue smoothly," he added.
As for Tang's possible successor, the spokesman said the State Department has no comment on such a purely domestic issue.
Meanwhile, a Taiwan affairs expert said the only U.S. concern about the issue is whether Taiwan's military reform will be affected by Tang's departure.

Stephen Yates, a senior policy analyst with the Heritage Foundation, a right-wing think tank, said that if Tang's resignation leads to a slowdown or a complete halt to Taiwan's military reform, the scenario will certainly have an adverse impact on U.S. arms sales to the country.

Tang, a four-star-general-turned-politician, won U.S. recognition for his efforts to promote Taiwan's military modernization during his stints as air force commander-in-chief, chief of the General Staff and defense minister. With U.S. assistance, Taiwan has worked hard to upgrade its defense capabilities in recent years.
Yates said it would be a wise move if President Chen Shui-bian were to appoint Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to succeed Tang.

Yates, who is familiar with Taiwan's general political situation, said that since Chang served as the top aide to President Chen before assuming the post of vice premier, he will be able to work smoothly with Chen after taking over the premiership.

Yates also said he does not think the main opposition Kuomintang, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20, will initiate a no-confidence vote against the new premier following Tang's resignation because the KMT's support rating has remained low since its embarrassing defeat in the March 18 presidential election.

If the KMT broaches a no-confidence vote, the move will certainly lead to Chen's decision to disband the KMT-dominated Legislative Yuan. Should that be the case, Yates said, the opposition People First Party will be the top beneficiary and the KMT will very likely lose its majority in the legislature.

Except for military reform, Yates said, Tang's resignation is not an important event to the U.S. unless Tang's successor makes significant changes to Taiwan's policies toward mainland China and the U.S.

Asked whether Tang's departure will facilitate realization of any U.S. policy goals, Yates said the U.S. government has so far given a "neutral" or "slightly favorable" evaluation of the performance of Chen's administration.
However, some other U.S. observers said Tang's resignation reflects the cold reality that the Democratic Progressive Party-led ROC government has not yet gotten out of the starting blocks.

Robert A. Manning, head of the Asian Study of the New York-based think tank Council of Foreign Relations, said since this is the first time that the DPP has wielded power, the Taiwan people should give their new government a longer period of time to settle in.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ADVISES AGAINST TRAVELING TO ISRAEL

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Foreign Affairs official recommended Wednesday that people should avoid traveling to Israel for the time being, as the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is worsening daily.
The official added that the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Tel Aviv has been instructed to watch the situation closely, especially since the conflict has spread to Jerusalem.
If travel to the area is unavoidable, visitors should pay careful attention to their safety by avoiding entering the West Bank and Gaza Strip, the official added.

Travelers already in Israel who have encountered an emergency can get in touch with the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Tel-Aviv for assistance, he said, adding that the Republic of China representative office in Israel is located at the Azrieli Center l-Pound Building 21 Fl. 132 Impetach-Tikva Road, Tel Aviv. The telephone number is 972-3-695-4742 or cellular phone 972-15275204.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC CHAIRMAN ELECTED PRESIDENT OF WORLD STEEL ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: Wang Chung-yu, chairman of China Steel Corp. of Taiwan, was elected president of the International Iron and Steel Institute, the first Chinese president of the authoritative steel organization, IISI sources said Wednesday.
Wang was elected at the IISI's annual meeting held in Melbourne from Oct. 2-5. Wang had served as vice chairman of the organization for the last two years.

The IISI, a non-profit international organization, is composed of approximately 200 steel enterprises from more than 50 countries. The major steel plants in the U.S., the U.K., France and Japan are all IISI members.

None of mainland China's steel plants are IISI members and the sources said it is expected that attracting mainland Chinese steel companies to the organization will be one of Wang's major tasks, as the mainland will represent a tremendous steel market after its entry into the World Trade Organization.
Members of IISI churn out 750 million metric tons of steel each year, accounting for 70 percent of the world volume.

As one of the few Taiwan entrepreneurs occupying an important position in an organization with great economic influence, Wang is expected to help Taiwan increase its economic clout in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP VOWS TO ASSUME FULL RESPONSIBILITY OF GOVERNING

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh issued a three-point statement Wednesday, throwing his full support behind President Chen Shui-bian's decision to promote Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to the premiership.

Hsieh, also mayor of Kaohsiung City, issued the statement at a press conference aimed at defusing public jitters over the possible adverse impact on domestic political and economic stability of Premier Tang Fei's surprise resignation the previous day.

Former DPP chairmen Yao Chia-wen, Chang Chun-hung and Lin Yi-hsiung, as well as Peng Shao-chin, secretary-general of the DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, were also present at the news conference to throw their weight behind Chang's promotion.

Hsieh said President Chen, a DPP stalwart, has appointed Chang to succeed Tang, a member of the main opposition Kuomintang, mainly because Chang is a savvy politician used to the cut and thrust of domestic politics and parliamentary operations.
"The quick decision is also aimed at minimizing domestic political uncertainty caused by Tang's departure," Hsieh explained, adding that the DPP fully backs the president's decision.
Hsieh further said the DPP deeply appreciates Tang's consenting to serve as premier following Taiwan's unprecedented transition of power from the long-ruling KMT to the DPP in May.

"Tang's dedicated services over the past four months have contributed much to helping stabilize the domestic political situation. All DPP members are very grateful of Tang's contribution and we wish him an early recovery to good health," Hsieh added.
Noting that all the people of Taiwan share a common destiny, Hsieh said local people will suffer if the domestic political arena remains mired in political uncertainty and instability.
In view of the public expectations and trust, Hsieh said, the DPP will assume full responsibility for governing and satisfying the demands of the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PREMIER DIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China former Premier Yu Kuo-hwa died of respiratory failure at the age of 87 Wednesday at the Taipei Veterans General Hospital.
Yu was diagnosed in 1993 with lymphatic leukemia, a disease that normally gives patients a three-year survival period.
He was hospitalized on Sept. 25 and transferred to the intensive care unit after his condition deteriorated on Sept. 30.
Doctors said that in addition to the lymphatic leukemia, Yu also suffered from high blood pressure, heart disease, and other organ failures that resulted in his death.

Yu served as premier from 1984-1989. Before taking the premiership, he had served as minister of finance, governor of the Central Bank of China, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, senior adviser to the president, and vice chairman of Kuomintang.
Yu's wife died earlier this year. He is survived by two sons.

Hsu Li-teh, a former senior adviser to the president who had been Yu's colleague for many years lauded the former premier for his great contributions to the promotion of Taiwan's economy and the stabilization of Taiwan's finances during his terms as central bank governor, CEPD chairman and premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC SAYS ROC'S FUNDAMENTALS STILL GOOD

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan said that the nation's economic fundamentals are still good.
Perng made the remarks in his attempt to help calm the nation's jitters after the resignation of Tang Fei as premier on Tuesday evening unleashed a political storm for the four-month-old government.

Perng, who has been tipped as a possible vice premier candidate after President Chen Shui-bian announced that Vice Premier Chang Chung-hsiung would take the place of Tang and that the new Cabinet will strengthen its financial team, would not respond to questions regarding his possible promotion.

Although political uncertainty may have a "short-term" impact on the stock and currency markets, Perng said, investors should have confidence in the nation, adding that they should look at the fundamentals over the long term. In addition, he went on, the listed companies in the stock market have enjoyed good profits.

Perng, who was recently rated by Global Finance magazine as one of the best central bank governors in the world, also said that he has not seen any major flight of foreign capital from Taiwan recently.

Asked about whether the CBC will announce a cut in the deposit reserve ratio in a CBC board meeting Thursday, Perng said only that the CBC will not comment on issues concerning the currency policy of the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC V.P. RETURNS FROM CENTRAL AMERICA VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu returned Wednesday from her four-state "journey of soft power diplomacy" aimed at shoring up the ROC's diplomatic relations with its allies in Central America.

Lu and her entourage arrived after a 30-hour layover in San Francisco, where she toured a science and technology museum in San Francisco and met with several scholars in her hotel room to exchange views on Taiwan's science and technology development.

She had left Taipei Sept. 22 for her first post-inauguration overseas journey, which took her to El Salvador, Honduras, Belize, and Guatemala. She also made transit stops in Los Angeles and Miami on her way to El Salvador.

Before returning from Guatemala, the last stop on her trip, Lu said that the four heads of state had all told her that they will continue to lend support to the ROC's bid to rejoin the United Nations.

The presidents of El Salvador and Honduras as well as the prime minister of Belize will visit Taiwan in November and December, while the president of Guatemala will visit Taiwan next March, she added.

Upon arriving at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Lu brushed aside reports that she would take on former Premier Tang Fei's vacated post in addition to serving as vice president, a remark that was later substantiated when Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung was appointed the new premier.

She added that Tang's resignation has been "brewing for a long time," and that President Chen Shui-bian had only accepted it after "careful deliberation." Therefore, everyone should respect the president's decision, she said.

Lu also said that Tang's resignation marked a "metamorphosis and transfer" of political power which would allow Chen's administration to strengthen its grasp on power. Chen had acquired only "an approximate amount of power" on May 20, she said, adding that taking real control was a gradual process.
She added that Tang's resignation will not lead to a so-called "constitutional crisis."

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN MINISTERS EMPHASES INVESTMENT FROM TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Mai, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is one of the three major sources of foreign direct investment in Association of Southeast Asian Nations, said an joint statement issued Wednesday by an ASEAN ministers meeting.

The trade and industry ministers of 10 ASEAN member states, who gathered in Chiang Mai for an ASEAN Investment Area (AIA) Council of Ministers, said that southeast Asian is Taiwan investors' second favorite destination after central and southern America.

The statement quoted statistics compiled by Taipei authorities in 1999 as saying that Taiwan had pumped more than US$523.04 million into this region, which accounts for 16 percent of the island's total investment overseas in the year, comparing to US$477.92 million and 14.5 percent in 1998.

The figures make Taiwan a major source of foreign investment in southeast Asia other than the United States and European Union, said the communique, adding that ASEAN should pay Taiwan its due attention .
The AIA council opened its one-day meeting here Wednesday and will be followed by a gathering of ASEAN economics ministers on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TAIWAN-PORTUGAL TRADE SEMINAR TO KICK OFF IN LISBON

TEXT.P: The first trade seminar between Taiwan and Portugal will be held in Lisbon from Nov. 14-15, in an attempt to promote bilateral economic and trade exchanges.

The Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce and Euro-Asia Trade Organization will jointly send delegations to the seminar, which is sponsored by the Republic of China's representative office in Lisbon and the Board of Investment and Tourism of Portugal's Economic Ministry.

The attending officials will discuss issues such as industrial cooperation, and will try to hammer out measures to promote joint development of the Asian and European markets. The Taiwanese attendees will also tour Portugal in order to get more detailed information about the investment environment in the Southern European country.

Portugal joined the European Union in 1986. Local trade observers have suggested that Taiwan companies use Portugal as a springboard to the European market, considering its cheap but high-quality laborers and its stable political and economic situation.
Taiwan enterprises would also have greater access to certain African countries due to Portugal's special relations with its former colonies, the observers added.
According to Portuguese official statistics, Taiwan producers of telecommunications, information and environmental protection equipment have the greatest potential in Portugal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEN OFFICIALS IMPEACHED FOR LAST JULY'S PACHANG RIVER INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan impeached 10 officials and officers Wednesday, holding them responsible for last July's Pachang River tragedy in which four persons were killed.

Because of failure of government agencies to take timely and effective rescue operations, four workers were swept away by rising flood waters in Chiayi County on July 22 after struggling for life for more than two hours.

Several ranking government officials stepped down to take political responsibility for the incident, including then-Vice Premier You Shi-kun and National Police Administration Director-General Ting Yuan-chin.
The Control Yuan impeached the 10 officials and officers for violating the law and seriously harming the public interest and the government's image.
The 10 impeached officials and officers include Vice Interior Minister Li Yi-yang, former Fire Agency Director-General Chen Hung-yi and Air Force Major Generals Chung Shen-ning and Tsai Chu-yu.

Chiayi County Magistrate Li Ya-ching escaped from being impeached with a 6-5 vote by the Control Yuan members. But the Control Yuan may take up his case again after reviewing whether or not he should be held responsible.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT INSISTS HIS 'ALL PEOPLE GOVERNMENT' STILL FUNCTIONING

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian insisted on Wednesday that his "government of all people" is still functioning following the resignation of Premier Tang Fei.
Chen made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the Washington Post Wednesday afternoon.

The president stressed that his "government of all people" has not failed. So long as political party leaders put the interest of the nation and the people higher than that of their party or themselves, the spirit of the "government of all people" will live on, Chen said.
He added that the party affiliation of the next premier will have no effect on the idea.

Tang's resignation has shocked people in Taiwan and overseas. Local and international as well as mainland Chinese mass media have played up the event, putting Taiwan's short-term political situation in the worldwide spotlight.
Therefore, President Chen put aside all his afternoon business to give an exclusive interview to the Washington Post.

According to a presidential aide, the Post reporter asked Chen whether the resignation of Premier Tang Fei meant the failure of his advocated "government of all people." President Chen replied that it did not.

He went on to say that the "government of all people" is a conviction of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. The DPP-led administration has faced a lot of difficulties since assuming power on May 20, he noted, adding that competition between the political parties is normal in a democratic country like Taiwan. An administration that accepts the supervision of opposition party is also normal, he said.

Asked about an opposition proposal to set up a coalition government, Chen stressed that the true minority or majority parties are not decided by the number of seats in parliament, but whether the government policies win the people's support or not. He cited the Clinton Administration, which is not a minority government despite the fact that Republicans outnumber Democrats in both the Senate and House of Representatives.
Asked about the affect on mainland China of the internal change, Chen said that the partial reshuffling of the Cabinet has nothing to do with cross strait relations.

But Chen pointed out that Beijing has employed a "united front" against Taiwan, and has tried its best to divide business and industrial groups in Taiwan, overseas Chinese communities around the world, and Taiwan's diplomatic allies. "At this moment, we (the people of Taiwan) must stand united to cope with Beijing's united front," the aide quoted Chen as saying.
Regarding the economy, which is worsening daily, Chen said that the government will invite more economists and experts to join the Cabinet, so as to effectively deal with financial issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN BUSINESSMEN STILL OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Paul Cassingham, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, said Wednesday that foreign businessmen in Taiwan are still optimistic about the island's economy, despite the sudden resignation of Premier Tang Fei.
He told the media that foreign investors are in Taiwan because they are optimistic about its long-term economic development, and added that their views are not influenced by short-term incidents.
Cassingham went on to say that it is a normal thing to see government officials step down in democratic countries.
When then-U.S. President Richard Nixon resigned over the Watergate scandal some 20 years ago, he noted, the U.S. economy was not adversely affected.

At the same time, Ho Wei-ling, chairman of Compaq Computer Taiwan, said that after learning of Tang's resignation, she exchanged views with business friends and colleagues, all of whom agreed that Taiwan's economy will not be affected by the premier's resignation, as the island's economic fundamentals remain sound.
But Ho pointed out that political stability is important for foreign businessmen who have come to Taiwan for investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL MAGAZINE NAMES TAIWAN'S WEALTHIEST 100 TECHNOLOGY GURUS

TEXT.P: Local financial magazine Business Weekly announced Wednesday its annual list of Taiwan's wealthiest 100 technology industry leaders.

Despite the broad stock market plunge, Hon Hai Precision Industry Chairman Terry Kuo, who was last year's number-two wealthiest man in the local technology industry circle, nevertheless leaped into first place with a NT$31.1 billion (US$1 billion) boost in his total fortune, which worked out to be approximately NT$97.9 billion (US$3.1 billion) as of Sept. 8.

Kuo's net worth is equivalent to approximately half of what Amazon.com founder Jeffrey Bezos -- Forbes' No. 10 ranking techno-billionaire -- is worth, at US$6.1 billion. But Kuo's treasure pile is still a far-cry from the US$60 billion amassed by William H. Gates III, the world's wealthiest man.

Kuo ranks 212th on Forbes' list of billionaires from around the world, based on prevailing valuations on May 22 which put his net worth at US$2.8 billion. His company makes computer parts for Compaq, Apple, and other U.S. companies.
Taiwan's richest technology leader from last year, Quanta Computer's Lin Pai-li, lost NT$51 billion (US$1.6 billion) this year to end up second with a net worth of NT$66.9 billion (US$2.1 billion).
Via Technologies Chairwoman Cher Wang, the second daughter of Formosa Plastics Chairman Wang Yung-ching, was named the wealthiest woman in Taiwan with a net worth of NT$18.4 billion (US$588 million).
Wang ranked No. 6 in the Business Weekly top 100, while her father ranked No. 122 on the Forbes list of billionaires with a net worth of US$4.3 billion.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp.'s Morris Chang ranked No. 21.

According to the local survey, which calculated the worth of stocks owned by the chairmen, trustees, major stockholders, and presidents of all listed local technology companies, approximately one-third of last year's hi-tech elite were overtaken by other up-and-coming entrepreneurs.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRENADIAN PRIME MINISTER ARRIVES FOR EIGHT-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Grenadian Prime Minister Keith Mitchell, accompanied by a three-member entourage, arrived in Taipei Wednesday night for an eight-day visit to the Republic of China.
Mitchell told Vice Foreign Minister Lin Chi-cheng, who greeted him upon his arrival, that he feels like he is a citizen of the Republic of China, as this is his sixth visit to Taiwan.
While in Taipei, Mitchell will attend National Day celebrations on Oct. 10, and will also call on ranking government officials, including President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.
Mitchell is expected to call on the president Thursday afternoon and visit the new premier Saturday.
Mitchell is expected to depart for home on Oct. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT HEAD SAID TO BE WORRIED ABOUT NUCLEAR PLANT ISSUE

TEXT.P: Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, was quoted as saying that he is worried that the scrapping of Taiwan's fourth nuclear plant would dampen foreign investor's confidence in the island.

Chen Tan-sun, Tainan County magistrate, made the announcement upon returning from a visit to central America as a member of the entourage of Vice President Annette Lu. He said Bush expressed his worry when he greeted Lu in Los Angeles, where the vice president made a overnight stop on her way to El Salvador.
Chen also said that the resignation of Primer Tang Fei shows the failure of President Chen Shui-bian's "government of the whole people."
"Although Tang is an able person, an outsider can hardly lead a Cabinet made up mainly of members of President Chen's Democratic Progressive Party," said the magistrate.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG SUGGESTS THAT ADMINISTRATION FORM COMMUNICATION MECHANISM

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong on Wednesday urged the Presidential Office, the Cabinet and the ruling party to establish a communication mechanism to deal with current political instability and prop up the local stock market, which has been in the doldrums recently.
Tang Fei's resignation as premier Tuesday shocked Taipei political circles, resulting in Wednesday's stock market plunge beneath the psychologically-important 6,000-point level.

Despite Tang's claim that he was resigning for poor health, it is widely believed that the true reason for Tang's resignation was his pro-nuclear power stance, which flew in the face of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's anti-nuclear power platform.

The number of DPP seats in the legislature is less that of the opposition KMT, but Soong said that forming a coalition government is not the only way to solve the current political turmoil. If the DPP-led administration does not intend to face current political reality, it should resort to the people -- and dismiss the legislature to hold a legislative election.

He acknowledged that under their respective situations, the KMT and DPP will not necessarily support such a legislative election. Therefore, he suggested that a communication mechanism be established among the Presidential Office, the Cabinet and the ruling DPP.

With Chang Chun-hsiung replacing Tang Fei as premier, Soong said that the possibility of forming a coalition government is lower than before. But he urged opposition parties to engage in rational interpellation in the legislature, and called for the administration to acknowledge political reality and communicate with opposition parties on major legislation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWSPAPER EDITORS TAPPED FOR GOVERNMENT JOBS

TEXT.P: Chiou I-jen, Deputy Secretary-General of the National Security Council, was reportedly named the new secretary-general of the Cabinet Wednesday night, in a partial administrative shakeup triggered by the resignation of Premier Tang Fei, according to informed sources.
His post at the National Security Council is expected to be filled by Antonio Chiang, publisher and editor-in-chief of the English-language Taipei Times newspaper.
Chiang has written many historical documents for the Democratic Progressive Party.

Su Cheng-ping, another newspaper editor, will be tapped in the shakeup as new government spokesman, said the sources. The editor of the Taiwan Daily News will replace Chung Chin as the director-general of the Government Information Office.
Chung will be reassigned as a minister without portfolio.

Earlier in the day, Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang was reportedly designated by Premier-designate Chang Chun-hsiung as the new minister, after Shea Jai-dong stepped down to take responsibility for the plunging stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Chang Chun-hsiung, a DPP stalwart, named new premier; the Cabinet undergoes a minor reshuffle.
The China Times:
Chiou I-jen to be Cabinet secretary-general; Yen Ching-chang to head the Ministry of Finance.
The United Daily News:
The Cabinet will undergo a partial reshuffle.
The Liberty Times:

The China Post:
Chang Chun-hsiung named premier, vows to pursue economic stability.
The Taiwan News:
New government taking shape.
The Taipei Times:
Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung steps up to replace Tang as new premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 5, or the eighth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1830: Chester A. Arthur, the 21st president of the United States, is born. Arthur became president after the assassination of James A. Garfield.
1908: Bulgaria declares its independence from the Ottoman Empire with Ferdinand I assuming the title of czar of Bulgaria.
1922: Tsao Kun is elected president of the Peking government.
1930: The first Balkan Conference is held in Athens, with representatives from countries from the Balkan Peninsula and Turkey taking part.
1941: Chinese forces heavily defeat Japanese invaders near the Milo River in northern Nanan Province, killing or wounding nearly 80,000 Japanese troops.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek accepts General George C. Marshall's proposal for a 10-day cease-fire to pave the way for a resumption of peace talks. Marshall arrived in Chungking on Dec. 22, 1945 as U.S. President Harry Truman's special envoy.
1951: The ROC's Legislative Yuan passes regulations providing farmland to soldiers.
1958: The United States delivers a batch of "Hercules" ground-to-air missiles, known in Taiwan as the "Goddess of Victory" missiles, to help improve the ROC's national defense.
1970 Anwar Sadat becomes the president of Egypt following the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Togo.
1973: Taiwan's first case of coronary artery surgery is performed at National Taiwan University Hospital.
1974: The third World Chinese Christian Conference opens in Taipei.
1974: Maj. Gen. Carlos Alcoreja Melgarejo, commander-in-chief of the Bolivian Army, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1976: The fifth World Chinese Tourism Amity Conference opens in Taipei with E. T. Chu, chairman of the Taiwan Visitors' Association, presiding.
1978: More than 20,000 boy scouts and brownies from Taiwan and 10 foreign countries launch a series of eight-day camping activities in the 5th National Jamboree held in Kaohsiung.
1980: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi arrives in Taipei to take part in the 16th Conference of the Asian Parliamentarians Union.
1983: Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1988: Operation Yun Han is declared a success with the completion of the TPE-1042 engine for the indigenous defense fighter.
1989: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: Premier Lee Huan instructs the Executive Yuan to set up special task forces to study problems concerning law and order, communications, environmental pollution, public housing, and economic crimes.
1991: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev pledges to match the United States in scraping tactical nuclear weapons.
1991: Cheng Kung, the first guided missile frigate built in Taiwan, is launched.
1993: Communist China breaks its moratorium on nuclear testing.
1996: Some 50 countries adopt a declaration calling for the earliest possible agreement on a global ban on anti-personnel land mines.
1998: The Judiciary Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives votes to recommend an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton's action during the Monica Lewinsky case.
1999: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill in favor of Taiwan's participation in international organizations, especially the World Health Organization.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The fact that a man is able to confront the spiritual powers of the universe without any doubt, shows that he understands the will of God. The fact that he is prepared to wait a hundred generations after him for the man of perfect divine nature without any misgiving, shows that he understands the nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ANNOUNCES NAMES IN CABINET SHAKEUP

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, who took office Wednesday following Tang Fei's sudden resignation from the premiership, announced Thursday the names involved in the partial Cabinet shakeup being carried out.

Chang confirmed that independent Grand Justice Lai Ying-chao has been appointed vice premier to assist him and that Chiou I-jen, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, has been named the new secretary-general of the Cabinet.

Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang was promoted to finance minister, replacing Shea Jia-dong, who resigned Wednesday following Premier Tang Fei's resignation to take token responsibility for the plunging stock market, Chang said.

Su Cheng-ping, an editor at the Taiwan Daily News, was named the new government spokesman, or the director-general of the Government Information Office, replacing Chung Chin, who has been reassigned as a minister without portfolio, Chang added.
Chang also confirmed that President Chen Shui-bian formally named Tang as a senior presidential adviser Wednesday.
Outgoing Finance Minister Shea Chia-dong and Secretary-General of the Cabinet Wea Chi-lin will be reassigned to other posts soon, Chang noted.
The above personnel changes were carried out Thursday morning with the consent of President Chen, he added.
Chang stressed that with only a partial shakeup and a minimal shuffling in postings, the whole mechanism of the Cabinet will function even more effectively.
In a solemn but simple oath Wednesday, Chang vowed to do his utmost to maintain domestic political stability and ensure continued economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 31.73 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 31.73 points to close at 6,029.65.
Market turnover amounted to NT$78.2 billion (US$2.49 billion).
