DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 31.73 points to close at 6,029.65.
The bourse opened at 5,932.79 and began to go up after purchases made by government funds. The bourse fluctuated between 6,047.78 and 5,904.98 during trading.

A total of 2.23 billion stocks worth NT$78.2 billion (US$2.49 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.11 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$25.27 billion (US$0.81 billion).
Only one of the eight major categories posted losses, with bank and insurance shares moving down by 0.6 percent, while cement stocks remained unchanged.

The other major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 2 percent, followed by construction shares at 1.2 percent, electrical stocks at 0.8 percent, textile issues at 0.6 percent, foodstuff shares and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 310 to 236, with 72 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taipei stock index futures market were generally higher Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved up 62 points to close at 6,105, with 5,727 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for November increased 75 points to finish at 6,150, with 124 contract transactions, while December futures lost 53 points to close at 6,170, with 41 contracts changing hands.
June 2001 futures moved up 165 points to close at 6,295, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March 2001 futures.
Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Thursday at 6,043 for October, 6,075 for November, 6,223 for December, 6,264 for next March, and 6,130 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also generally higher.
October TE futures moved up 1.35 points to close at 313, with 1,740 contract transactions, while November TE futures gained 1.85 points to finish at 315, with 58 contracts changing hands.
December TE futures increased 1.35 points to close at 316.3, with one contract transaction, while June 2001 TE futures moved down 11.5 points to finish at 319, also with one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for March 2001 TE futures.
October TF futures gained 8.2 points to close at 752.2, with 911 contract transactions, while November TF futures increased 8.2 points to finish at 756.2, with four contracts traded.
December TF futures moved up 7 points to close at 754, with five contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSTY STARTS NORMAL FOR NEW GOV'TS: GIO HEAD-DESIGNATE

TEXT.P: It is normal that a new administration starts off rusty and requires time to begin functioning smoothly, particularly after a transfer of power from a rival party which has held the government reigns for several decades, said the newly designated government spokesman Thursday.

Su Cheng-ping, an economist-turned-editorial writer, who was appointed by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to replace Chung Chin as director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), said the new administration led by Chang absolutely has the potential to win back the people's confidence.

Su, who holds a master's degree in civil economy from Germany's Frankfurt University and has been a senior economics consultant with the German Trade Office in Taipei, said he is confident that the new administration will enjoy pleasant approval ratings from the Taiwan public before long.

Citing examples of similar slow starts by new administrations in the United States and Germany in the past, Su said it took President Bill Clinton time before his administration began running smoothly after he won the presidency from the Republicans who had held the White House for 12 consecutive years. He also said the same thing happened in Germany when the Social Democratic Party's Gerhard Schroeder became chancellor following 12 years of Christian Democrat rule.

Su noted that temporary low approval ratings for President Chen and his government are also understandable since voters had pegged high expectations on the new government taking over after five decades of rule by the Kuomintang.
Poor approval ratings for the new Democratic Progressive Party government should be reversed if the public gives the administration more time, he stressed.
Su, 50, a commentator and editorial writer with the Taiwan Daily News, is expected to be sworn in as the new government spokesman at a formal ceremony Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAVAGE PRICE WARS OCCURRING IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Savage price wars are now under way in mainland China on a number of products, including household appliances, personal computers, television sets, air conditioners, and vehicles.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, The Australian Financial Review on Thursday reported the price wars were not only between Chinese manufacturers, but also between Chinese producers and foreign manufacturers importing their products into the mainland.
The daily quoted Belle Chan, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, as saying that Chinese producers and foreign manufacturers were engaged in a tit-for-tat price cutting war.
"Of the consumer products with softening prices, the present round of the price wars is most visible on televisions, air conditioners, and private vehicles," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARALYMPIC TORCH RELAY KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: In a ceremony held outside the Parliament House in Canberra, Prime Minister John Howard on Thursday lit the Paralympic relay torch and handed it to tennis star David Hall to officially begin the 13-day torch relay from the nation's capital to Sydney, site of the Paralympic Games, which kick off on October 19.

More than 4,000 athletes from 125 countries will take part in the sporting event that will include 19 events, including football, judo, shooting, tennis, table tennis, volleyball, archery, basketball, cycling, and fencing.
The opening ceremony of the Paralympic Games will be held at the Stadium Australia on October 18 -- the same venue where the opening ceremony of the 2000 Olympic Games was held.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HOUSE EXPRESSES SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S INTERNATIONAL ROLE

TEXT.P: The U.S. House of Representatives has unanimously adopted a resolution supporting Taiwan's "appropriate, meaningful participation" in the United Nations and other international organizations.

The non-binding resolution, passed by a voice vote on Tuesday night, also calls on the administration to fulfill its commitment to more actively support Taiwan's membership in appropriate international organizations.
In the Taiwan Policy Review of September 1994, the Clinton administration pledged to support Taiwan's membership in organizations which do not require statehood.
The administration also said that it would help Taiwan's voice be heard where membership is not possible.
Mainland China claims that Taiwan is part of China and has successfully blocked the island's attempt to join international organizations.

House Concurrent Resolution 390, introduced by Rep. Bob Schaffer (R-Colo.) and co-sponsored by 87 other House members, points out that the 23 million people on Taiwan are not represented in the U.N. and that "their human rights as citizens of the world are therefore severely abridged".
It says that Taiwan has in recent years repeatedly expressed its strong desire to participate in the U.N. and has much to contribute to the work and funding of the world body.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA CHAIR OPENLY OPPOSES 4TH NUKE PLANT

TEXT.P: The founder of Taiwan's plastics giant Thursday openly expressed his opposition to the continued construction of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant, saying that nuclear power is not only costly but also unsafe.

At a press conference sponsored by himself, Wang Yung-ching, founder and chairman of the Formosa Plastics Group, said his stance is identical to that of the new Democratic Progressive Party-led government, which is resolutely opposed to resuming construction of the controversial power plant.

Wang reiterated that the drawbacks involving the fourth nuclear power plant, including high construction and maintenance costs, serious environmental protection problems, and the questionable safety of the power plant, have led him to say no to the mammoth project.
Wang told the nation's entrepreneurs not to worry about power shortages, saying that there are always alternatives when it comes to generating power.
As for the NT$90 billion (US$2.88 billion) that Taiwan has already spent on the project, Wang suggested that the cost be absorbed over five years, but he did not elaborate.

It is understood that Wang openly made the remarks mainly because the FPG controls Taiwan's second "powerhouse" -- the electricity generating plant located in Mailiao, Yunlin County -- which is poised to break Taiwan Power Company's monopoly as the sole supplier of power in Taiwan.
The FPG's two thermal-powered generator units in Mailiao have already become operational, without official permission, according to unconfirmed reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO U.S. PRESSURE OVER 4TH NUCLEAR POWER PLANT: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen said Wednesday that the U.S. government has never pressured Taiwan over the controversial fourth nuclear power plant issue.

Chen said neither American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush, the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, nor any Clinton administration official has ever pressured Taiwan either to uphold or scrap its fourth nuclear power plant project.
Chen made the remarks after the U.S. Department of State issued a statement expressing its stance on Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant project.

The State Department readout said: "Whether to continue the fourth nuclear power plant is a decision of the Taiwanese authority to make. The U.S. government's major concern is the contract provisions which mutually agreed upon in the past are fulfilled."
Chen said the readout just expresses the U.S. hope that Taiwan faithfully carries out the provisions of a contract it previously signed with the U.S. firm concerning the project.

"Nothing is unusual for the United States to show concern about whether Taiwan fulfills its obligations under its contract with an American company," Chen noted, adding that in the fourth nuclear power plant case, the main U.S. concern is that if Taiwan finally decides to scrap the project, it must compensate the U.S. contractor in accordance with contract provisions.
General Electric Co. of the United States has won the US$1.8 billion bid to supply Taiwan with nuclear reactors and other related equipment to be installed in its fourth nuclear power plant.

Although the ROC's former Kuomintang government already approved the budget for the new power plant, opposition to the project has never abated. The controversy raged again after the Ministry of Economic Affairs suggested an end to the project last weekend. The political storm triggered by the controversy already led to the resignation of Premier Tang Fei and a subsequent minor reshuffle of the Democratic Progressive Party-led government.
U.S. Secretary of Energy Bill Richardson would not make any comment on Taiwan's Cabinet shakeup over the controversial power plant project.

In his speech to the Foreign Press Club Wednesday, Richardson just stressed that nuclear energy is clean and safe. He said the real problem lies in the disposal of radioactive waste from nuclear power plants.

Richardson said most U.S. nuclear power plants have failed to take effective measures to help ordinary American people understand the safety of nuclear energy. He also admitted that the United States has not yet found a suitable place for permanent disposal of nuclear waste.

An official with the ROC Representative Office in the United States said the Clinton administration is now evaluating the feasibility of building a facility in Nebraska State's Yucca mountain region for permanent disposal of nuclear waste.

Nevertheless, the official said even if the U.S. government finally agrees to the proposal, it is unlikely to give a green light to the shipment of Taiwan's nuclear waste to Yucca for permanent disposal.

Meanwhile, a GE spokesman said Wednesday that GE has continued production of equipment for Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant because it has not received any notice from Taiwan demanding a halt to the project.
"We will fully respect Taiwan's final decision on the fate of the project," the spokesman said.
GE sources said the company will incur little financial loss even if Taiwan decides to scrap the project.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.002 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$31.320.
The local currency opened at NT$31.295 and was traded between NT$31.295 and NT$31.325.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$332 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PREMIER SEEKING LEGISLATIVE YUAN SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Newly-designated Premier Chang Chun-hsiung met Thursday with Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, to exchange views on how to deal with the national budget and how to improve relations between the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan.

After the one-hour meeting with Wang, acting Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said that the Executive Yuan will withdraw the national budget project presented by former Premier Tang Fei after Chang formally assumes the post of the nation's premier.
As to when he will deliver his administrative report to the Legislative Yuan, Chang said that the date will be decided after he is formally sworn in as premier on Friday.
Chang said that the Executive Yuan under his leadership will partially amend Tang's national budget bill.

Legislator Chou Po-lun (DPP-Taipei County), who accompanied Chang in the meeting, said later that Chang had sought the support and cooperation of Wang and the opposition Kuomintang during the hour-long talk.
President Chen Shui-bian will preside over Friday's inaugural ceremony of the new premier and vice-premier, as well as several new Cabinet-level officials.

The president nominated incumbent Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to fill the vacancy left by former premier Tang Fei, and Grand Judge Lai Ying-chao was appointed to the vice premiership. Meanwhile, Chiou Yi-jen was appointed secretary general of the Executive Yuan while Yu Shyi-kun has been tapped as secretary general to the president.

In other moves, Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang was promoted to minister of finance; and Su Cheng-ping was appointed director general of the Government Information Office to replace Chung Chen, who was given the new post of minister without portfolio.
Antonio Chiang, publisher of the Taipei Times, was appointed deputy chairman of the National Security Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG'S PREMIERSHIP NOT TO WORSEN CROSS-STRAIT TIES: DPP CHAIR

TEXT.P: The appointment of Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung as Taiwan's new premier will not strain cross-strait relations, Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh said Thursday.

Hsieh made the remarks in a radio interview after President Chen Shui-bian appointed Chang to take over the Premiership following Tang Fei's surprise resignation on Tuesday. Both Chen and Chang are DPP stalwarts.

Although Tang, a senior member of the main opposition Kuomintang, cited "health reasons" for his decision to quit, many observers feel that the main cause of Tang's departure was the DPP's insistence on calling a halt to the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project.

Against this backdrop, some observers said they are worried that Chang's promotion to the Premiership may further chill the already frigid cross-strait ties because of the DPP's pro-independence platform.

However, Hsieh said such worries are unfounded, stressing that the DPP's current stance on cross-strait relations is to maintain Taiwan's present status quo, not to pursue outright or de jure independence for Taiwan.
Hsieh, who concurrently serves as mayor of Kaohsiung, said he doesn't think that mainland China will intensify its hostility toward Taiwan simply because of Chang's appointment to the Premiership.

Hsieh also said that the DPP should adjust its established policy goals to cater to Taiwan's mainstream values, with a view to facilitating the DPP's transformation from a "minority opposition party" to a "majority ruling party."

With Tang's departure and Chang's promotion, Hsieh said, the DPP is now the Republic of China's real ruling party. Nevertheless, as the DPP controls only 68 seats in the 221-member Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said that the party should modestly and sincerely consult with other parties concerning major policy issues.

"The DPP should also revise or adjust its previous policy goals and proposals in order to live up to the public's expectations," Hsieh urged, adding that the DPP should refer to prevailing mainstream values in formulating its party platform and amending its party charter.

"Self-examination and self-adjustment are necessary in pursuit of progress and continued growth," Hsieh said, adding that all DPP members should forge an intraparty consensus and unity to fulfill the responsibility of governing.

Noting that the recent stock market slump has mainly resulted from the public's doubts about the government's capacity to manage various financial problems and ensure continued economic growth, Hsieh said the top priority of Chang's Cabinet will be to rebuild public confidence in the government.
In the future, Hsieh said, the DPP will play a role of "integration and coordination" to help ensure smooth government operations.

"We are hopeful that both the Presidential Office and the Cabinet will speak with the DPP headquarters before formulating any major policy. We will then coordinate the support of all major intraparty factions in the DPP legislative caucus," Hsieh said.
In addition, Hsieh said, the DPP will strengthen communications and consultations with major opposition parties, including the KMT, which controls more than half of all parliamentary seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE QUAKES ROCK HUALIEN COUNTY

TEXT.P: At least three earthquakes, the most serious of which measured 4.8 on the Richter scale, rocked Hualien County in eastern Taiwan Thursday, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

CWB officials said that an earthquake measuring 4.8 on the Richter scale hit Hualien County at 4:29 a.m., while another two earthquakes measuring 3.9 and 4.1 on the Richter scale struck the same county at 1:14 p.m. and 1:51 p.m. respectively.

The epicenter of the first quake was located at a depth of 23.4 kilometers some 8 kilometers northwest of Hsincheng in Hualien County; while the epicenters of the last two quakes were located at a depth of 11.9 and 10.9 kilometers, respectively, some 4 kilometers southwest of Hsincheng. No casualties have been reported so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICE INCREASE IN SEPTEMBER SET 19-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: Consumer prices increased by 1.75 percent in September, the highest such monthly figure in 19 months, the Directorate General of the Budget, Account and Statistics announced Thursday.

DGBAS officials attributed September's consumer price increase to Typhoon Bilis, which hit Taiwan at the end of August, sending the prices of fruits and vegetables skyrocketing. The price of food was estimated to have increased by 20 percent.
They also cited state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp.'s move to increase petroleum product prices, which hiked the price of transportation by 20 percent.
Increased tuition costs and miscellaneous school fees in September also forced parents to increase educational and other expenses by 30 percent during the month.

The officials said that consumer prices increased by 1.14 percent in the first nine months of the year. As the fourth quarter typhoon season has passed, and international oil prices are also expected to stabilize, they said that monthly consumer price increases are expected to remain within the 1.55 percent predicted by the DGBAS for the entire year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB HEAD MEETS REFORM-MINDED INVESTIGATORS

TEXT.P: Wang Kuang-yu, director of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau, met with representatives of the Investigators Reform Association Thursday to discuss MJIB structural reforms.

It was the first time that Wang had met IRA representatives since a group of reform-minded grassroots MJIB agents formed the association on Sept. 9 to push for a sweeping overhaul of the bureau's operations and functions.
Pai Po-wen, an IRA spokesman, said after the meeting that the IRA representatives reached a preliminary consensus with Wang on the MJIB's internal reforms.
Wang was quoted as having assured the IRA delegates that he is pleased to see the formation of the new association.
"Wang also agreed to assign a senior official to meet with IRA representatives once every three months to discuss various reform programs," Pai said.

According to Pai, the IRA presented a five-point reform program to Wang. One of the proposals is to transform the MJIB into a purely crime-fighting agency and to free it from five decades of political manipulation. The association has also come up with a draft bill on supervising intelligence-gathering operations and making them impartial.

Under current regulations, the MJIB is under the authority of the Ministry of Justice. But in fact, it has been instructed to conduct controversial "national security condition surveys" under the guidance of the National Security Bureau.

Pai said the association has asked Wang to push for revisions of current laws to free the bureau from being asked to conduct such surveys, which have long been lambasted by opposition political figures as government-sponsored "white terror" political persecution tactics.

In reply, Wang was quoted as having told the IRA representatives that the MJIB must operate strictly in accordance with the law. Before the current regulations are revised, Wang said, MJIB agents must still conduct "national security condition surveys." However, he agreed to gradually cut such kinds of surveys.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FINANCE MINISTER VOWS TO BUOY SAGGING STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Finance Minister-designate Yen Ching-chang said Thursday he will do his utmost to let local stock prices reasonably reflect Taiwan's current economic fundamentals after he assumes office.

Yen, an incumbent vice finance minister who will be sworn in as new finance minister Friday, told a news conference that current stock prices fail to reflect Taiwan's robust economic fundamentals and general business records of companies listed in the Taiwan Stock Exchange and the OTC (over-the-counter) market.
Noting that the bourse forms an integral part of a country's capital market, Yen said the recent fall in local stock prices is unreasonable.

As the Democratic Progressive Party-led government has failed to articulate its financial and economic policies, the local stock index has shed more than 2,000 points since May. Yen said he will strengthen communications and coordination with relevant government agencies to upgrade the administrative quality in order to regain the public's confidence in the government's capabilities to ensure continued economic growth.

Yen also reminded local stock investors that foreign capital only accounts for 5.5 percent of total stock market turnover. "Local investors need not be affected by foreign financial institutions' recent selling spree," he added.
Meanwhile, Yen voiced opposition to the proposal that the Ministry of Finance cut the stock transaction tax rate, which stands at 0.3 percent at the moment, to help lure back stock investors.

"As the tax rate was very low, I don't think a further cut will have any effect. Moreover, a cut in the transaction tax rate may fuel speculative money games and hinder healthy development of our stock market in the long run," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOPPLING CABINET IS ONLY PERSONAL OPINION OF LAWMAKERS: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said Thursday that a proposal to topple the new Cabinet represents only the "personal opinion" of the KMT legislators who brought up the idea and does not represent the stance of the party.
Lin added that time must be taken to contemplate such a proposal, while KMT Chairman Lien Chan would not comment on the idea. "It is inappropriate to speculate on the issue," the KMT head stressed.

If the Legislative Yuan were to vote to topple the Cabinet, President Chen Shui-bian would have the authority to dismiss the legislature, which would bring about an immediate legislative election. Otherwise, a regular election is already scheduled for December of next year.
Chao Shou-po, director-general of the KMT's Department of Organization Affairs, which handles mobilizing KMT members, said that the KMT has not considered the issue of holding such a re-election.

Responding to ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh's comment that the KMT may not benefit from toppling the Cabinet because both the DPP and the KMT's approval ratings are dropping, Chao only said that all levels of the KMT's local committees will be prepared to fight it out in next year's legislative, county magistrate, and mayoral elections.

At a press conference held by the KMT's legislative caucus, lawmakers urged newly appointed Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to decide the fate of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant without delay, and to allocate more expenditures for economic infrastructure in his revised national budget draft.

Legislator Her Jyh-huei said that he hopes the president will let Chang take charge of Cabinet affairs without interfering, so that Chang can be a "constitutional premier," meaning someone with real power to promote his policies.

Her added that the public's greatest worry is that the DPP's pro-independence and anti-nuclear platforms are having adverse effects on cross-strait relations and the economy. Therefore, he urged the DPP to abandon these two party platforms altogether.

Legislator Chen Chieh-ju said that vague economic policies have caused immense harm to the economy, adding that if Chang does not decide on whether to continue building the nuclear plant, he will tread on the same path as former Premier Tang Fei, who resigned over the same issue Tuesday.

Legislator Liao Fung-te urged Chang to make revisions to the national budget proposal according to the recommendations of the opposition parties. If Chang changes only "the name and the cover," the lawmakers will not accept such a budget plan, Liao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PHILIPPINES ECONOMIC MEETING POSTPONED
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A ministerial meeting on economic issues between the Republic of China and the Philippines was postponed because of Taipei's Cabinet reshuffling, according to a announcement by Taipei's representative office in Manila on Thursday.

The annual ROC-Philippines Joint Economic Conference, initially set for Oct. 12, was postponed to between January and March of next year, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in the Philippines said.

ROC Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, whose recommendation to scrap the country's fourth nuclear plant set off a political storm in Taipei and led to Tuesday's resignation of former Premier Tang Fei, had urgently informed the representative office that he would be unable to attend the meeting on the originally-scheduled date.
Manila has agreed to reschedule the annual meeting sometime next year, said the office.

However, a conference between the business leaders of Taiwan and the Philippines will go ahead as scheduled. The Joint Conference of the Chinese-Philippines Business Council and the Philippines-Chinese Business Council will be held on Oct. 13 and 14 in Manila.
A 34-member Taipei delegation, including Jeffrey Koo, chairman of Chinatrust Commercial Bank, will arrived in Manila on Oct. 11, said the Taipei representative office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PRODUCT PROMOTION HELD IN TOKYO

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council held a promotion exhibition in Tokyo Thursday, attracting more than 900 Japanese manufacturers looking for deals.

The promotion group, the largest in recent years, was comprised of 105 Taiwan manufacturers showing products for the elderly, creative DIY products, gardening tools, stationery, gifts and sports equipment.

Yang Shao-lin, leader of the promotion group, noted that Tokyo is the third Japanese stop of the group after Fukuoka and Osaka. He had particular praise for Fukuoka, describing it as a good foothold for Taiwan businessmen looking to make inroads into the Japanese market.

Yang also reminded Taiwan businessmen in Japan to look for profits over the long term and urged them to learn the habits and needs of the Japanese, saying that they will find Japan a place worthy of investment. (By K.M. Huang and Lilian Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP025 10-05-00 SEPTEMBER FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES RECORDED AT 8-MONTH LOW
Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves in September totaled US$11.16 billion, the lowest level in eight months, Central Bank of China officials said Thursday.

The officials said the figure represents a decrease of US$1.36 billion from the previous month, but preserved the country's standing as the holder of the third-largest foreign reserves in the world next to Japan and mainland China.
But the officials said that September's figure is a sharp increase of US$10.01 billion from the same month of last year, mainly because of the continuing influx of foreign capital to Taiwan.

Taipei foreign currency dealers said that the new Taiwan dollar faced heavy pressure of depreciation in September, and the CBC intervened actively by selling U.S. dollars to prop up the Taiwan dollar, resulting in the shrinking of foreign reserves for the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN TO VISIT BEIJING

TEXT.P: Wu Poh-hsiung, vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, said Thursday that he will visit mainland China in mid-November.
If the visit takes place, it will make Wu the highest-ranking KMT official to visit the mainland in recent years.
Wu said that his visit will allow him to participate in a convention of the World Hakka Association to be held in the mainland province of Fujian.

Wu, himself a Hakka, said he will also visit Beijing, but denied that the visit is to pave the way for an upcoming visit by KMT Chairman Lien Chan to the mainland, pointing out that Lien has no plans to visit Beijing.

Wu's visit to Beijing will follow that of other high-ranking KMT officials, including former secretary-general John Chang and P.K. Chiang, former chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.

It was reported that Chiang had visited mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, the semi-official organization authorized to handle cross-Strait ties in the absence of formal contacts between Taiwan and mainland China.

It is expected that Wu will meet some high-level mainland officials, as the Beijing authorities have expressed a desire to meet him. Wu indicated that while he will not take the initiative in meeting such officials, he will not rule out such meetings.
He also said that if any meetings take place, he will "honestly express the real thoughts of the Taiwan people."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN DONATES 60% OF LIVER TO FATHER IN LIFESAVING OPERATION

TEXT.P: A young man donated 60 percent of his liver to his father in a transplant operation that was the only way to save the older man's life, doctors from National Taiwan University Hospital said Thursday.
The 57-year-old father of Hung Chien-hsiung is a carrier of the hepatitis-B virus who in the past year had suffered from jaundice and liver failure that had taken him to the brink of death.

When the patient's three sons learned that their father needed a liver transplant, they all expressed willingness to donate their livers to save their father's life. After evaluation, doctors decided to use part of 27-year-old Hung's liver for the transplant.
The 14-hour transplant operation was conducted on Aug. 9, doctors said, adding that at present, Hung's new liver is functioning well and his jaundice index has been restored to a normal level.
The liver possesses a strong regeneration ability and the younger Hung's liver will grow to its original size within six months, the doctors said.

This is NTUH's first successful live adult-to-adult liver transplant among the nine liver transplants it has carried out. Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, the first Taiwan hospital to complete a live body liver transplant has successfully conducted 49 such cases, among which only seven were adult-to-adult transplants.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CONFIDENT HE CAN DEAL WITH POLITICAL SITUATION

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian has told the Washington Post that he is confident he will be able to deal with the "temporary doubts and concerns" caused by the current political instability.

In an article published Thursday in the Post and concurrently on the front page of the International Herald Tribune, Chen is quoted as saying in an interview conducted the previous day that his government is not facing a crisis despite the crashing stock market, the divided legislature and the sudden resignation of the premier, a member of the opposition Kuomintang.
He also warned that mainland China has been playing at divide-and-conquer with Taiwan's legislators, and he urged both ruling and opposition party members to be cautious of such tactics.
Mainland China has already invited about one-third of Taiwan's legislators to visit Beijing in a bid to isolate Chen.

"They are working very hard to sabotage the internal unity of Taiwan, so this is something that we must be worried about," Chen said. "We are concerned that some people and some groups here are receptive to China's wooing and can't distinguish between friend and foe."
He urged the establishment of "a sense of friend and foe, a sense of caution, and a sense of crisis."
According to the Post, analysts are split about Chen's prospects, and the KMT has been working to create the impression that political chaos reigns on the island.
However, the article went on to say that Legislator Parris Chang of Chen's ruling Democratic Progressive Party is optimistic about the change in premiership to someone with DPP roots.
"This will help ensure that we have not abandoned our principles," Chang said. "We should not abandon our roots."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT THANKS GRENADIAN P.M. FOR VOICING SUPPORT IN U.N.

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian thanked Grenadian Prime Minister Keith Mitchell Thursday for the Caribbean nation's support of the ROC's bid to join various international organizations such as the World Health Organization.

Chen also thanked Mitchell for Grenada's voicing of support for the ROC in the U.N., describing Mitchell as a leader with "one of the world's greatest senses of justice." Chen added that he is touched by such unwavering friendship.

He noted that the two countries have remained close since establishing diplomatic relations 11 years ago and that high-ranking government officials exchange frequent visits. This being Mitchell's fifth visit to Taiwan, Chen added that Mitchell should be able to notice Taiwan's progress and development.

Mitchell, who is in Taiwan to attend ROC National Day celebrations on Oct. 10, exchanged opinions with Chen on issues related to the Caribbean region and urged the ROC to strengthen cooperative relations with the region.

Chen assured Mitchell that all the cooperative projects and agreements between the two countries will not be affected under his new administration because Taiwan's policies have a sense of continuity, irrespective of any Cabinet reshuffles.
He added that he hopes to further improve bilateral trade and economic cooperative relations so as to bring about even closer mutual friendship.

Mitchell and a three-member entourage arrived in Taipei Wednesday and is scheduled to depart on Oct. 11. He is expected to call on ranking government officials, including Premier-designate Chang Chun-hsiung, during his visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGE OF PREMIER WILL AFFECT CROSS-STRAIT TIES: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang official in charge of the party's mainland China affairs claimed Thursday that the change of Taiwan's premier will affect the future development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
But Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT Mainland Affairs Department, said that the effect will be of a "hidden nature" and that there will be no immediate worsening of bilateral relations.
He made the remarks upon his return from a month-long visit to the U.S. at the invitation of the Culture Department under the American Institute in Taiwan.
Asked about the U.S. reaction to the change of premier, he said that when President Chen Shui-bian named Tang Fei as premier last May, it was lauded as a "wise move."
"Now that Tang has gone," he went on, "there will not be a good reaction."

The KMT's mainland policy planner said that Tang, a former defense minister under the KMT administration, had played a significant role in helping stabilize cross-strait relations and the military situation.
Claiming that new Premier Chang Chun-hsiung is unable to display these functions, he said that the government should "handle cross-strait relations with great care in the future."

Tang resigned from the premiership earlier this week, mainly because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party insists on its sticking to its policy of scrapping the on-going construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant, a policy with which Tang and his party disagrees.

Chang further claimed that this may cause new apprehension over whether the DPP will also insist on its pro-Taiwan independence party platform, although there has been no evidence to suggest that this will be that case.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S DIPLOMATIC OFFENSIVE IN AFRICA WORRIES TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Beijing's campaign to increase its diplomatic presence in Africa has set Taipei on edge, according to an analysis by the Mainland Affairs Council released Thursday.

Beijing's efforts, most recently represented by its call for a forum in Beijing with the African states from Oct. 10-12, betrays its ambitions to be the leader of the world's developing states and to undermine or destroy Taipei's diplomatic relations with its eight African allies, the analysis said.

Pitching for a new international order and closer cooperation between the People's Republic of China and the Dark Continent through the discussion, Beijing has invited Taipei's eight allies to attend the forum as observers, some of whom have agreed to participate.

Beijing's promises to beef up its consultation with African states on international issues on the basis of equality, mutual respect for sovereignty, and reciprocity, sound attractive to certain African states which are plagued by heavy foreign debts and low international status.

What most concerns Taiwan is the scenario that the forum, if successful, could be institutionalized and gradually developed into a full summit of African leaders which would boost Beijing's bid to be the leader of the third world and accordingly curb Taiwan's diplomatic activities in Africa, according to the MAC.

Beijing's long-standing claim of holding an anti-hegemony position and its claim of fiercely opposing power politics make it a hero among many developing states in Africa, who rally behind Beijing in the hope that it will speak out for their causes on the international stage, said the MAC analysis.
Along with the growth of its national strength, Beijing's hoped-for role as point-man for the developing states might be reinforced, warned the analysis.

Beijing has never passed up any chance to shut Taiwan out of the international community and its officials have always gone out their way to make a case for Beijing's claim that "there is only one China in the world and Taiwan is a part of it." It will certainly try to use its leverage with African states to drive Taiwan out of the continent, the analysis concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER: `I WON'T TALK ABOUT POLITICS ANY MORE'

TEXT.P: Former Premier Tang Fei, who resigned from his post earlier this week, said Thursday that he will no longer discuss politics.
New Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and other Cabinet ministers visited Tang at his residence earlier in the day to express their gratitude for Tang's leadership over the past four months.
After a half-hour of talks, Tang escorted his visitors to the door and shook hands with them one by one. Outgoing Government Information Office Director-General Chung Chin even embraced with him.

When asked by a reporter whether he will accept President Chen Shui-bian's invitation to serve as senior advisor to the president, Tang said: "Sorry, I will not talk about any political issues from now on."

The Cabinet ministers who visited Tang also included Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, Education Minister Ovid Tseng, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan, and outgoing Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MISERY INDEX LOWEST IN ASIA: CENTRAL BANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan said Thursday that the domestic misery index, measured by adding the country's unemployment rate and its consumer price inflation rate, ranks lowest among the major Asian countries.
As of the end of August, Taiwan's misery index reached only 4 percent, Perng said at the CBC's third-quarter board of directors meeting.

He added that this shows that Taiwan's overall economy is healthy and that consumer prices are stable. Taiwan's misery index is comparatively low even when measured against those of developed countries, he said.

Perng said at a press conference after the board meeting that maintaining the stability of consumer prices is the foremost responsibility of CBC. Other than doing its utmost to maintain consumer price and currency exchange rate stability, he said that the bank will also make efforts to promote economic growth.
Within these operational parameters, he added, the board of directors believes the best measure at the moment is for the bank to maintain the current interest rate.

Responding to whether the board of directors has recommended that the CBC depreciate the local currency once and for all to increase export competitiveness, Perng said that the foreign exchange market often overreacts and that the directors did not make such a demand.

In terms of consumer prices, Perng said that Taiwan's export growth has reached as high as 24 percent. With the future accession into the World Trade Organization and the future increased taxes on tobacco and liquor, the consumer price index is expected to go up by 0.6 percent per year, he said.

In addition, he went on, if the price of international crude oil remains at US$32 per barrel, then the domestic CPI should go up by another 0.6 percent a year, bringing the total to approximately 1 percent. Therefore, the central bank must do its utmost to maintain consumer price stability, he stressed.

According to Shih Tsun-hua, the CBC's deputy director of economic research, the first two quarters of this year marked strong expansions in Taiwan's foreign trade, driving domestic demand and allowing the economic growth rate to reach 6.68 percent.

He went on to point out that the stock market plunge since April has slowed down the domestic economy. However, he added that the continued flourishing export industry, the uncertain private sector investments, and the speeding up of post-quake reconstruction projects in central Taiwan should be able to prop up the third-quarter economic growth rate to 6.67 percent.

According to the Cabinet's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics, this year's economic growth rate should be approximately 6.57 percent, representing a "fairly good" domestic economic situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT: TAIWAN WILL NOT ACCEPT `ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS'
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said in an interview with French newspaper Le Figaro published Thursday that the people of Taiwan will not accept Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula.
The interview, conducted in Taipei at the end of last month, was prominently carried on the paper's international page.

Chen pointed out that Taiwan is a democratic and sovereign independent country whose residents espouse a variety of values. Therefore, he said, the government must respect the people's will, and he declined to define a conclusion on "China's future."
The president stressed that the Taiwan people will never accept the "one country, two systems" formula to become a second Hong Kong or Macao, or a part of the People's Republic of China.

As Taiwan and mainland China have reached no consensus on the "one China" issue, he said that the two sides should move to find a mutually-acceptable definition of "one China" through dialogue and on the basis of the 1992 negotiations.

In order to resolve the cross-Taiwan Strait problems at an early date, Chen stated that Beijing and Taipei should start engaging in negotiations now, otherwise the differences will not be overcome and mutual misunderstandings may widen.

On former President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition last year of the current cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship," Chen said that if Beijing renounces the threat of force against Taiwan, he will never write the "state-to-state theory" into the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN'S APPROVAL RATE PLUNGES IN POLLS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's approval rate plunged in various polls Thursday after former Premier Tang Fei resigned.
In a survey conducted by The China Times, more than 40 percent of those interviewed blamed Chen for the political chaos.
Chen's approval rate has dipped from 74 percent in April to 43 percent on Wednesday in a serious of surveys by the newspaper.

In the polls conducted among more than 700 adults, the people who disapproved with Chen's performance on the job outnumbered those who approved of him 45 percent to 43 percent -- for the first time since his swearing in May, said the China Times.
Ironically, the poll gave Tang an approval rating of 73 percent, similar to the rating at the end of August.
Similar findings were found in a poll Thursday by the United Daily News, which had Chen's approval rating at 42 percent against 45 percent before Tang resigned.
That figure is equivalent to that of former President Lee Teng-hui in 1999 when he was showing signs of political wear and tear after ten years in the presidency.

Tang's quitting has also taken its toll on Chen's Democratic Progressive Party, with those who said they trusted it's capability of ruling trimmed by 7 percent to 37 percent, while those who lacked trust surged from 45 percent to 48 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 6, or the ninth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1552: Mateo Ricci, Italian Jesuit missionary to China, is born. He spent the last 30 years of his life in China.
1807: English chemist Sir Humphrey Davy discovers a new metallic element and calls it potassium.
1860: A Franco-British force captures Beijing. China's Ching court is thus compelled to make further concessions in the 1860 Treaty of Beijing.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai forces the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander-in-chief of the Canton military government and begins to launch the second eastern expedition.
1927: The International Stock Exchange Center of the New York Stock Exchange is formally opened.
1937: The League of Nations condemns Japanese aggression against China.
1937: The State Department of the U.S. condemns Japan's invasion of China.
1939: Chinese troops win the first battle of Changsha in Hunan Province against invading Japanese forces.
1946: The Chinese communists turn down General George C. Marshall's cease-fire proposal.
1958: Seawolf, a U.S. nuclear submarine, surfaces off New England's coast after setting a world record by remaining submerged for two months.
1963: President Hubert Maga of Benin and his wife arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The ROC and Uruguay sign a treaty of amity in Taipei.
1973: Gwanda Chakuamba Phiri, Malawi minister of youth and culture, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: As Israelis are beginning Yom Kippur, one of the holiest days in the Jewish calendar, a joint Egyptian-Syrian invasion force is attacking their country on two fronts, triggering the fourth Middle East war.
1975: The 11th General Assembly of the Asian Parliamentarians Union opens in Taipei with more than 80 delegates and observers from nine countries taking part.
1976: Shiroshichi Kimura, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for a 16-day visit.
1980: The first World Congress of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacology sponsored by the National Union of the Chinese Medical Doctors' Association opens in Taipei.
1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated by Islamic extremists while reviewing a military parade in Cairo. He was succeeded by Vice President Hosni Mubarak on Oct. 13.
1986: The ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs decides to invest NT$1.2 billion in developing anti-pollution technology over the next three years.
1987: The National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center, comprising the National Theater and National Concert Hall, is inaugurated after six years of construction costing NT$7.5 billion.
1991: An Indonesian military plane crashes into a government building in Jakarta, killing 102 people and injuring more than 5,000 others.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin demands the resignation of his opponents in the provinces after putting down rebellious legislators.
1999: Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's most notorious criminal who raped and killed the 17-year-old daughter of TV celebrity Pai Ping-ping in April 1997, is executed after being sentenced to death for his crimes.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and understanding: qualities necessary for the exercise of command."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. GOV'T HAS NO POSITION ON 4TH NUCLEAR POWER PLANT PROJECT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government has never demanded that Taiwan complete the fourth nuclear power plant project nor that it scrap it, said Darryl Johnson, deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs Thursday.

He did add that the U.S. government does of course have normal concerns that the contract provisions concerning the project are fulfilled because it is the government's responsibility to safeguard the interests of U.S. businesses.

The manner in which the contract provisions should be addressed, however, is a matter for the parties concerned to work out, he said during a cocktail party after the ROC-U.S. sub-Cabinet meeting wrapped up.

Johnson categorically denied rumors that certain U.S. companies have tried to exert pressure on Taiwan through the U.S. government and have even threatened that Taiwan may risk losing weapons acquisitions from the United States if the project is discontinued.

On Wednesday, the U.S. State Department issued a statement expressing its stance on Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant project. The readout said: "Whether to continue the fourth nuclear power plant is a decision for the Taiwanese authorities to make. The U.S. government's major concern is that the contract provisions which were mutually agreed upon in the past are fulfilled."

Meanwhile, ROC Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, chief Taiwan negotiator to the fifth ROC-U.S. sub-Cabinet economic dialogue, said matters concerning the fourth nuclear power plant project were not discussed during the one-day meeting.

Lin mentioned, however, that officials from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) did visit the Ministry of Economic Affairs and expressed their concerns about the fulfillment of contracts signed between U.S. companies and Taiwan.
But AIT officials said that the U.S. government will not intervene whether the nuclear power plant project is continued or scrapped, according to Lin.

ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen, who headed the Taiwan delegation to the meeting, reiterated that neither AIT Chairman Richard Bush nor the U.S. government has formally expressed concerns to him about the possible discontinuing of the project.

The bourse opened at 6,037.54, and due to a strong rebound in electrical shares and other stocks, share prices continued to go up. The bourse fluctuated between 6,367.39 and 6,037.54 during trading.
