DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN SCIENTISTS PRAISE TAIWAN'S SEISMIC SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Two Canadian scientists who visited Taiwan soon after last year's Sept. 21 earthquake and have been following the island's recovery efforts said Thursday that Taiwan now has one of the world's best seismic research systems.

Dr. Guy Felio and Dr. David Lau also praised Taiwan's government and research community for making all earthquake data available to the world and for being willing to help other countries benefit from the knowledge they acquired from the earthquake, which killed 2,320 people and injured about 8,000 others.

One of the direct beneficiaries is British Columbia, Canada's most earthquake-prone province. Felio said that Vancouver's municipal government and the B.C. provincial government have adopted his team's recommendations on seismic risk evaluation on public buildings based on the data collected from Taiwan.

Ching-cheng Kuan, information director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada, said that in the aftermath of the 1999 earthquake, Taiwan established an emergency response team "that stands ready to assist others in time of need."

The three were speaking at the "Update on Taiwan Earthquake: One Year Later" seminar sponsored by the TECO's information division. Kuan used the opportunity to thank Canada for providing timely cash, medical, and technical assistance to help in Taiwan's relief work.
Carleton University Civil Engineering Professor David Lau, a mission member, said the Chi-Chi earthquake produced 400 records that are very useful for seismic and construction studies.

With more than 600 monitoring stations around the island as well as rich resources and top-notch facilities, Taiwan's National Earthquake Center has made a significant impact on reducing the hazards in future quakes, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUGOSLAV LEADER MILOSEVIC URGED TO STEP DOWN

TEXT.P: Australia's Prime Minister John Howard and Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Friday joined U.S. President Bill Clinton and U.K. Prime Minister Tony Blair in demanding that Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic accept election results and step down.
Howard told reporters that "in the interest of avoiding bloodshed and inevitable death and destruction it's time for Milosevic to go and accept the democratic expression of the Yugoslav people."
In the September 24 election, Milosevic was defeated by his opponent.

In a statement faxed to the CNA on Friday, Downer said that "what we are seeing in Belgrade at the moment is the inevitable result of Slobodan Milosevic's refusal to accept the democratically expressed will of the Yugoslav people."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC TRUMPETS OLYMPIC ACCOMPLISHMENT IN BID FOR 2008 GAMES

TEXT.P: Mainland China's ruling Communist Party is launching a campaign to bring the Olympic Games to Beijing in 2008 with the state-controlled China Daily trumpeting the country's third place overall finish in the medal standings in Sydney as proof of its Olympic worthiness, reported the Australian on Friday.

The daily reported that mainland China entered the 2000 Olympic Games with the ambition of bettering its overall medal tally at the 1996 Atlanta Games. It accomplished its goal by grabbing 59 medals, including 28 golds, 16 silvers and 15 bronzes, and moving up one notch in the overall standings.

The national team's performance handed the Chinese government a propaganda victory and allowed it to avoid retreating into a period of self-examination after the withdrawal of 27 athletes prior to the start of the Olympics due to the use of performance enhancing drugs, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PREMIER TANG FEI SAYS GOODBYE TO CABINET

TEXT.P: Ex-premier Tang Fei, who resigned Wednesday for health reasons and whose resignation was accepted the same day by President Chen Shui-bian, said goodbye to the Cabinet Friday at a farewell and changeover ceremony.

Composed and peaceful, Tang delivered a short speech thanking President Chen for allowing him the opportunity to work at the Executive Yuan. Tang also expressed his appreciation to the people of Taiwan for their support and tolerance, and to the Cabinet members and other colleagues for their devotion to the job and to working together.

Tang, an air force pilot-turned official who served in the military for more than five decades before becoming defense minister, said his departure will allow him to be a regular civilian for the first time since the age of 12 when he entered a junior air force college.
"Now I will have time to read, which was a luxury before, and I will also be able to spend more time with my family," Tang said in his speech.

Senior presidential adviser, Peng Ming-min, who officiated at the changeover ceremony, expressed his appreciation to Tang by saying that "it's been a tough time for you, Premier Tang. We sincerely thank you."
Chang Chun-hsiung, vice premier during Tang's four-month tenure who was appointed by President Chen to succeed Tang, demonstrated his respect for Tang by giving him a deep bow.
It was learned that Tang has accepted Chen's offer to become a senior adviser to the president, on the one condition that he not be paid for the position.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRESIDES OVER SWEARING-IN CEREMONY OF NEW CABINET

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over the swearing-in ceremony of new Cabinet members and other top government officials, including Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Secretary-General to the President Yu Shyi-kun, at the Presidential Office Friday.
The Cabinet underwent a partial reshuffle after the resignation of Tang Fei as premier Tuesday evening.
The new and old government agency heads faced the national flag and a portrait of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the founder of modern China, to give their oath of dedication to serving the nation and the people.

The swearing-in ceremony was witnessed by Vice President Annette Lu, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng, Examination Minister Hsu Shui-teh, Control Yuan President Frederick Chien, National Security Council Secretary General Chuang Ming-yao, as well as two deputy secretary-generals to President Chen Tze-nan and Eugene Chien.
Following the ceremony, the new premier and the outgoing premier held another changeover ceremony at the Executive Yuan.

Chang said that he accepted the new mandate with a guarded attitude and expressed the hope that the opposition parties could forego their past rivalries to work together for the benefit of the nation, adding that political stability and economic development will be the top priorities of the new Cabinet.
Another two changeover ceremonies were held at the Government Information Office and the Ministry of Finance.

Su Cheng-ping, editor of the Taiwan Daily News, replaced Chung Chin, who was reassigned as a minister without portfolio, as the government spokesman. Su said that the international media is very concerned with Taiwan's democratic development and that he vows to step up the publicity campaign internationally so that foreign countries are more aware of Taiwan's achievements.
Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang took over as new Finance Minister in a ceremony held at the Finance Ministry.

Shea Jia-dong bowed out by wishing his successor good luck and saying he hopes that the new head can lead the ministry like the surging stock market Friday, which rallied 5.4 percent after days of slump.
Yen said that the focus of his future work will be on pursuing a sound capital market for Taiwan and on a more rigorous management of national assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PREMIER PITCHES FOR NORMAL, PEACEFUL CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: New Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday he earnestly hopes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can forge a normal, peaceful relationship.

Chang made the call in a speech delivered at the inaugural ceremony for an inter-party parliamentarian association aimed at protecting the legitimate rights and interests of Taiwanese investors in mainland China.

Chang, the Republic of China's first premier from the young Democratic Progressive Party, said he is very pleased to see the formation of the new non-partisan group to help promote benefits of Taiwanese investors on the mainland.

"This is a good omen of inter-party reconciliation and cooperation as legislators from across the political spectrum have now found a common cause regarding the sensitive cross-strait policy -- protecting the rights of our investors," Chang said.
Chang, himself a six-term legislator before joining President Chen Shui-bian's administration, added that he looks forward to seeing the new group succeed in realizing its goals.

Chang, now Taiwan's third most powerful leader, further said he hopes Beijing can resume dialogue with Taiwan as early as possible to facilitate the development of a normal, peaceful cross-strait relationship.
Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, said the latest partial Cabinet reshuffle will have little impact on cross-strait relations.

"The basic tone and axis of our policy on cross-strait relations, outlined in President Chen's May 20 inaugural speech, will remain intact in the wake of the minor Cabinet shakeup," said MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin.

Noting that the top goal of the DPP government's mainland policy is to maintain stability in the Taiwan Strait, Lin said the Cabinet's personnel adjustment will not change this fundamental policy goal.

"Since the axis of our cross-strait policy remains the same, we don't think mainland China will change its basic attitude toward cross-strait relations simply because of our Cabinet reshuffle," Lin explained.

Lin also renewed his call on mainland china to resume interaction and consultations between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait with a view to resolving problems through dialogue.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN ARRANGES FOR NEW CABINET TO GIVE REPORT OCT. 17

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has arranged for the new Cabinet to give an administrative report on Oct. 17, said Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng on Friday.
Chang Chun-hsiung on Friday formally took over the premiership from Tang Fei, who resigned Tuesday evening.

Because Chang has temporarily withdrawn the government's budget for 2001 and because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has asked that a subsidy for the elderly be included in the new budget, the new Cabinet has returned to square one on the budget issue.

With only a limited amount of time left to pass a government budget in this legislative session, Wang said that the Legislative Yuan has arranged for the new Premier to give an administrative report on Oct. 17, after which the budget proposal will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for review.
Chang said that he will hold extra meetings Friday afternoon to discuss issues related to the government's budget next year.

On the issue of inclusion of a subsidy for the elderly in the budget, Interior Minister Chang Po-ya had a reserved attitude, saying that inclusion of such a subsidy will depend on the overall financial situation. "If there is enough money, then it will be included," she pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINESE FISHING BOATS NABBED FOR CONDUCTING ILLEGAL TRADE

TEXT.P: Six mainland Chinese fishing boats and 15 people aboard were nabbed Friday for conducting illegal "small scale" transactions with Kinmen locals, the Kinmen Coastal Patrol Squad reported.

The Kinmen coastal patrol forces, which have stepped up patrols in recent months due to the increasingly rampant illegal trade in waters near Kinmen, discovered a cluster of mainland Chinese fishing boats lingering around Chiunglin Bay in northern Kinmen and managed to nab six of them before they dispersed.
The boats, remodeled from oyster collecting boats, were found full of agricultural products and bamboo handicraft originating from the mainland.

The Kinmen coastal patrol forces even found that several of the 15 mainland Chinese people were "faces familiar" to them, indicating that some had already made illegal cross-strait trade their regular way of making a living.

Hsu Chin-lung, an official with the Kinmen Red Cross Society, who rushed to the coastal patrol squad headquarters to learn more about the latest development, urged the mainland Chinese people to refrain from conducting illegal trade since the so-called "mini direct links" -- direct trade, transport, and communications links between the ROC's outlying posts of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China -- have not been officially approved yet.
After being interrogated and receiving a punishment notice, the 15 mainland Chinese citizens were ordered to take their vessels and leave Kinmen waters.

According to the Kinmen coastal patrol authority, mainland Chinese citizens have become increasingly daring and active in recent months, sailing to Kinmen to conduct illegal "small scale" trade with the Kinmen locals.

This "small scale" trade activity is so easy and widespread that some Kinmen-based travel agencies have even incorporated it into their tourist itineraries for visitors from Taiwan. If a tourist is interested in taking a look at the illegal trade, the travel agency simply makes a phone call, and within half an hour, mainland fishing boats arrive at a predetermined spot where the tourists are not only entertained by watching the transactions, but can also make purchases of their own.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.024 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 31.296.
The local currency opened Friday at 31.292 and was traded between 31.292 and 31.319.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$421 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. RESPECTS ROC DECISION ON 4TH N-POWER PLANT: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs Friday ruled out the possibility of the U.S. government interfering with Taiwan's decision on the fate of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said as the project is purely the Republic of China's domestic affair, the U.S. executive branch is unlikely to interfere with Taiwan's decision-making procedure regarding the issue.

"The U.S. government will fully respect our decision on the project," Chen stressed, adding that if Taiwan finally decides to scrap the project, it will faithfully fulfill its obligations to compensate the U.S. supplier of the nuclear power generation equipment in line with the contract provisions mutually agreed upon in the past.

Chen's remarks echoed a U.S. State Department readout issued on Wednesday, which said: "Whether to continue the fourth nuclear power plant project is a decision for the Taiwanese authorities to make. The U.S. government's major concern is that the contract provisions which were agreed upon in the past are fulfilled."

Darryl Johnson, U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, also said at a cocktail party held in Washington, D.C. after a one-day U.S.-ROC sub-Cabinet meeting that the Clinton administration has no position on Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant project.

But Johnson stressed that the U.S. government does have normal concerns that the contract provisions concerning the project are fulfilled because it is the government's responsibility to safeguard the interests of U.S. businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS `STONE' METAPHOR REFERRED TO DPP ITSELF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian took the initiative to explain that the "stone" in his comment that "the stone has been removed from the path" of his four-month-old government actually referred to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) itself and not to any specific person.
The president's "stone" metaphor on Thursday immediately drew widespread speculation as to what he was actually referring to.

The opposition Kuomintang said the president was referring to outgoing Premier Tang Fei, who as a former defense minister and a veteran member of the Kuomintang was invited to head the Cabinet in May. Many believe Tang did not resign due to "health reasons" as stated, but was in fact forced to resign over his support for the continued construction of the fourth nuclear power plant.
The DPP, trying to assuage public misgivings about the president's remarks, said that the metaphor actually referred to the shedding of an old system and old burdens of the past.
The president therefore said the "stone" actually referred to the party itself, adding that the DPP as a ruling party has to take more responsibility now.
The president's "stone" remark was hotly debated in the Legislative Yuan Friday, with the KMT legislators lamenting the fate of Tang turning from a "gem to a stone."

Legislators from the People First Party said sarcastically that the president himself is the biggest stone on the road and that if the political situation turns from bad to worse, then the 22 million people on Taiwan may decide one day to remove Chen from the political scene.
KMT spokesman Jason Hu said that the KMT would not take the opportunity to speak ill of Chen during his present difficulties, but added that more gaffes from the president will backfire someday.

On the KMT's assessment of the new Cabinet, Hu said that it has taken the political situation into consideration even less than the previous Cabinet did, adding that the personnel changes occurred without consultations with the legislature or even with the DPP itself and was a "worrisome" development.
Chang Chun-hsiung, a long-term veteran of the DPP, formally took over as premier Friday, thereby signifying a step away from President Chen's professed goal of setting up a broad-based government.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO MAP OUT MEASURES TO ACTIVATE ECONOMY: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, who is also in charge of the Cabinet economic and financial panel, said Friday that his group will work out measures to help activate the nation's economy, which is worsening daily.

Sworn into office Friday morning, Lai said that the measures will include how to improve the domestic investment climate as well as how to promote public confidence in the nation's economic development.
Lai made the remarks at a press conference held at the Government Information Office with other new Cabinet members.
Lai said he hopes that experts, scholars and business and industrial leaders will offer suggestions on economic development.
He also said that the government should implement its social welfare policy in a manner that takes into account its limited resources.
Asked about the controversial fourth nuclear power plant, Lai said the government agencies concerned should submit all accompanying measures before a decision is made.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, U.S. CALL FOR TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY BY YEAR'S END
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the United States expressed their common hope Thursday that Taiwan can become a member of the World Trade Organization by the end of 2000.
The appeal for Taiwan's early WTO accession was outlined in a joint press statement issued at the conclusion of the Fifth Subcabinet-Level Economic Dialogue between the two countries.

Representatives of the two sides met at the U.S. Department of the Treasury to exchange views and consider future areas of cooperation on a broad range of bilateral and regional issues affecting the economic, financial, trade and investment relations between Taiwan and the United States.

As the two countries do not maintain formal diplomatic ties, the one-day meeting was held under the auspices of the American Institute in Taiwan and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO) in the United States.
Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu and Timothy F. Geithner, under secretary of the treasury for international affairs, served as chief ROC and U.S. negotiators, respectively.

During the morning session, Lin and Geithner delivered reports on trends and developments in the U.S. and Taiwan economies as well as the outlook for Asia. In the afternoon session, the participants were divided into three groups for discussion on three subjects -- banking and finance, trade, and law enforcement.

In the financial panel discussion, Taiwan's efforts to modernize its financial system and to become a regional financial center were recognized. The two sides also discussed the merits of allowing market forces to play a greater role in the determination of the exchange rate and stock prices in Taiwan, the importance of adequate regulation and supervision, prospects for greater participation by foreign-owned financial service firms in Taiwan, particularly in asset management.

In the trade sector discussion, the United States asked Taiwan to make an unequivocal commitment that it will indeed abide by its WTO commitment to liberalize fully its telecommunication market as of July1, 2001.

Meanwhile, the United States recognized Taiwan's ongoing efforts to strengthen its protection of intellectual property rights, but noted the need for the adoption, implementation, and enforcement of an effective optical media law that controls copyright piracy at the manufacturing source by strictly regulating optical disc manufacturers.

Taiwan raised several sanitary and phytosanitary issues affecting Taiwan's agricultural exports to the United States. Both sides agreed to further discuss relevant trade issues at the next bilateral meeting to be held under the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement.

During the subcabinet-level meeting, the two sides also explored the potential for greater cooperation and coordination on combating international financial crimes and curbing Internet crimes. Such cooperation and coordination will include possible mutual visits and training programs.

In addition to Lin Yi-fu, members of the ROC delegation also included Vice Finance Minister Sean C. Chen, Central Bank of China Deputy Governor Chen Shih-meng and Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairwoman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

The annual subcabinet economic meeting is the highest-level official dialogue mechanism between Taiwan and the United States in the absence of formal diplomatic ties. It takes place alternately in Taipei and Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC V.P. PLEASED WITH BETTER U.S. TREATMENT DURING RECENT TRANSITS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that she was pleased to have achieved several breakthroughs during the U.S. stopovers on her recent "journey of soft power diplomacy" to four of the ROC's allies in Central America.

Lu, who returned Wednesday from her first overseas trip since becoming vice president, said at a press conference that her stops in the United States were marked by numerous "major breakthroughs," especially compared to ROC President Chen Shui-bian's transit in August.

She cited the facts that she was allowed to stop in three cities instead of just one and was treated like a head of state, with a new limousine to welcome her at the airport. She added that overseas Chinese leaders, U.S. Congressional representatives and academics were all allowed to meet with her.

She went on to criticize the U.S. government's "rudeness" during Chen's Aug. 13 stopover in Los Angeles on his way to the Dominican Republic. She said that it was this treatment of Chen that made her particularly concerned about her own transit, which led to the improved treatment.
Chen's short hop from Los Angeles International Airport to his nearby hotel was delayed by 25 minutes because of engine problems of his limousine arranged by the United States.

Furthermore, Chen was not allowed to meet with U.S. Congress members or any U.S. officials other than American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush. Nevertheless, Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Cal) called on Chen in defiance of a publicly announced U.S. State Department objection to any such meetings with Chen during his 16-hour transit stop.
Lu said that every successful U.S. transit would lay the foundation for the next one, adding that Taipei cannot show too much weakness, for fear that others will "dig deeply into the soft soil."

She also noted that U.S. treatment of the ROC president also triggered the concern of many U.S. congressmen. She said that she hopes they will urge the next U.S. administration, to be sworn into office in January, to improve Washington's treatment of senior ROC officials during transits on U.S. soil.

Lu also thanked the four countries she had visited -- El Salvador, Honduras, Belize, and Guatemala -- for continuing to voice their support for the ROC in the United Nations. She added that the only reason Taiwan still cannot rejoin the world-governing body is mainland China's obstruction.

Lu also praised former Premier Tang Fei, a retired air force general, as being "a learned military man," adding that it was a shame he belonged to a different political party and was in poor health. Tang was succeeded by incumbent Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung in a formal inauguration ceremony Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC EMPLOYEES TO HAVE EIGHT-DAY SPRING FESTIVAL HOLIDAY: CPA

TEXT.P: Public functionaries will have an eight-day Spring Festival holiday next year, an official of the Cabinet-level Central Personnel Administration confirmed Friday.
The agency convened a meeting with representatives of related government agencies as well as business and industrial circles Friday to discuss how many public holidays to declare during 2001.
It was decided at the meeting that public functionaries around the nation will have a total of 113 days off next year.

Official holidays will include the nation's founding anniversary on Jan. 1, the Spring Festival Holiday during Jan. 23-26, Tomb Sweeping Day on April 5, the Dragon-boat Festival on June 25, the Autumn Festival on Oct. 1, and National Day on Oct. 10.

Next year's Spring Festival will begin on Jan. 23, a Tuesday, and continue to the end of the week. The preceding Monday will also be a day off for public employees, so they will have the entire week off.
Meanwhile, both public and private sector employees will enjoy a mandated two-day holiday every week beginning Jan. 1 of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN IMPEACHES FORMER SECURITY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The watchdog Control Yuan passed a resolution Friday to impeach Pan Hsi-hsien, a former personnel department chief of the National Security Bureau, for his impairment to national security.
The impeachment proposal was broached by Control Yuan members Huang Wu-tse and Kang Ning-hsiang and passed by a vote of 12-1.
The resolution accused Pan of lacking consciousness of mainland China's hostility toward Taiwan and having acted recklessly to hurt Taiwan's national security.
It pointed out that Pan filed an application for mainland China's "Taiwan compatriot certificate" when he was still working with the NSB.
Noting that the move was part of Pan's preparations for visiting mainland China, the resolution said Pan left for the mainland shortly after his retirement from the NSB.
According to current Republic of China regulations, a retired civil servant must apply for a government approval of his or her mainland travel plan if he or she has not yet retired for three years.

The resolution said it is very regrettable that Pan, a high-ranking security official in charge of mainland China-related intelligence affairs, has failed to abide by such travel rules aimed at protecting national security.
The resolution suggested that the Committee on the Discipline of Public Functionaries mete out the maximum harsh penalty on Pan in accordance with current law.
Pan has been taken into custody by mainland Chinese security authorities since local media reported his travel activities on the mainland.
Following Pan's detention on the mainland, the NSB reportedly has changed its communication codes with its agents stationed abroad in a remedy measure.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 7, or the 10th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: A "holy league" of naval forces from Spain, Venice, and the Vatican explodes the myth of Turkish military invincibility by annihilating their fleet at the Battle of Lepanto in the eastern Mediterranean.
1900: Heinrich Himmler, German head of the Gestapo, and from 1929, Adolf Hitler's second-in-command, is born.
1913: Henry Ford, the leading manufacturer of U.S. automobiles in the early 1900's, creates the world's first assembly line to build Model T cars.
1919: KLM, national airline of the Netherlands and the world's first airline, is established, and flights are scheduled for 1920.
1937: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution pledging moral support for China in the wake of Japanese aggression in that country.
1949: East Germany, or the German Democratic Republic, is proclaimed with Wilhelm Pieck as president and Otto Grotewohl as prime minister.
1950: Chinese communist troops enter Tibet.
1953: Microfilm, a kind of photographic film on which reduced images of printed and other materials are recorded, is first shown at an office machinery trade exhibition held in Paris.
1958: Chinese communists begin to launch a mass movement in Tientsin to make iron and steel, in which about 100 million people participated. The movement, which proved to be a waste of both human and material resources, resulted in a loss of 100 billion yuan in industrial production.
1959: Pictures of the far side of the moon are relayed back to Earth for the first time by Lunik III, the Soviet spacecraft.
1959: Mario Lanza, US tenor and film actor, dies at the age of 38. His films included "The Great Caruso."
1961: Two defecting Chinese communist pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, arrive in Taipei from Seoul.
1965: The International Olympic Committee decides that starting from the 1968 Olympic Games to be held in Mexico City, East and West Germany may send separate teams to the international athletic competition.
1974: A 90-member Japanese calligraphic mission led by Akira Koyama arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Wu Cho-liu, a noted writer in Taiwan, dies at the age of 77.
1976: U.S. President Gerald Ford, already under fire for pardoning the disgraced Richard Nixon, tells the public on prime-time television that "there is no Soviet domination of eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration."
1977: The Soviet Union adopts a new constitution, replacing the one introduced in 1936.
1981: Dr. Hassan Hamza Hajra, mayor of Taif, Saudi Arabia, arrives in Hualien and meets with Wu Shui-yun, magistrate of Hualien County, to discuss sister city ties.
1982: Jimmy Wei, national policy advisor to President Chiang Ching-kuo and former president of the Central News Agency, dies of a heart attack at the age of 77.
1985: The Achille Lauro, an Italian cruise liner, is seized by Palestinian terrorists, endangering the lives of more than 400 passengers on board. The passengers were freed on Oct. 9 when the hijackers surrendered.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo tells Katherine Graham, head of the board of the Washington Post and Newsweek, in an interview that the ROC government would soon propose lifting martial law to actively promote democracy, but added that new political parties should abide by the ROC Constitution and anti-Communist policy. He also emphasizes that the ROC will never negotiate with the Chinese communists.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1998: Thousands of Russians take to the streets to protest against unpaid wages and to call on President Boris Yeltsin to resign.
1999: Sweden donates NT$50 million (US$11.57 million) worth of relief goods to help earthquake-affected people in the Republic of China on Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of magnanimity, generosity, benignity, and gentleness: qualities necessary for the exercise of patience."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 1.64 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Saturday, with the benchmark weighted price index edging down 1.64 points to close at 6,352.03.
Market turnover amounted to NT$92.44 billion (US$2.95 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, edging down 1.64 points to close at 6,352.03.
The bourse opened at 6,385.39, and fluctuated between 6,425.69 and 6,289.52 during trading.

A total of 2.43 billion stocks worth NT$92.44 billion (US$2.95 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.69 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$97.44 billion (US$3.11 billion).
Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by electronics shares at 0.5 percent.

The other major categories all lost ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by textile issues and cement stocks, both at 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.1 percent, construction stocks at 0.8 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 337 to 228, with 62 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. INTENDS TO TRANSFER NUKE WASTE MANAGEMENT TECH TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of Energy has shown that it intends to transfer nuclear waste processing and storage technology to Taiwan, as it sent a special aid to Taiwan recently to learn about related developments here.

C.K. Chou, a special assistant at the U.S. Department of Energy and director of the Fission Energy & Systems Safety Program under the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, visited Taiwan over the past several days meeting officials from the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council as well as Taiwan Power Co., owner of the temporarily-suspended fourth nuclear power plant.

Although the U.S. government has continuously insisted that it will not interfere in Taiwan's decision to uphold or scrap the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project and is only concerned that "private" contracts previously signed are fulfilled, Chou's low-profile visit to Taiwan calls Washington's neutrality on the issue into question.

Chou, in Taiwan to assist in U.S. and Japanese nuclear waste management technology transfers, said he was shocked to learn that Taiwan's natural gas reserves are only sufficient to provide the island with power for 14 days, while 36 percent of the island's electricity is already natural gas-generated, and the Ministry of Economic Affairs has proposed to increase that ratio.

Chou, who departed for the United States Friday after spending the previous days exchanging opinions with Taiwan, Korean and Japanese nuclear experts, noted that the three countries have very similar environments, with a marked lack of natural resources.

However, he noted that Japan already has 53 nuclear reactors with four being constructed, and that South Korea has 16 nuclear reactors with four being built and another eight planned for operations by 2015.
In comparison, he noted, Taiwan currently has three working nuclear power plants, while the fourth is approximately 30 percent complete.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party has been garnering support to scrap the fourth plant midway into its construction, while opposition parties have been largely opposed to the idea. The plant is designed to run two U.S. General Electric reactors.

Chou said before his departure that the main object of his Taiwan trip was to promote U.S. and Japanese nuclear waste management technology transfers in the hope that an international nuclear waste disposal research center can be established, so as to allow nuclear power consuming countries like Taiwan to run their own "geologic repositories."

The U.S. government is reportedly not only concerned about whether the GE contract is fulfilled, but is also worried that Taiwan's anti-nuclear power sentiment will become an issue that requires a plebiscite to decide. This is seen as likely to trigger new tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

Washington political observers believe that the last thing Beijing would like to see is Taiwan holding plebiscites to decide on major national issues. A plebiscite on the fourth nuclear power plant project is seen as the possible precursor to another plebiscite to decide the Taiwan independence issue.
