DOC.HEADLINE: WHERE THERE IS BREATH, THERE IS FUTURE: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that life is full of hope and opportunities. "Where there is breath, there is future," he said.
Chen said as long as a person persists and never gives up, a better tomorrow is guaranteed.
He continued that one can always find ways and means to succeed if one wants to; and similarly, one can always find excuses and reasons to fail.
Chen made the remarks during an audience with Sue Thonell, executive secretary-general of Life Line International, at the Presidential Office. Thonell is currently on a business tour in Taiwan.
The president stressed that on the road to becoming a society of modern citizens, Taiwan needs at least three vital factors in its social fabric -- humanity, knowledge and volunteer work.

"We were all left with vivid impressions of the voluntary work that was driven by simple compassion in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake last year. I hope that people in Taiwan will continue to volunteer to help others, based on the spirit demonstrated by workers with Life Line organizations worldwide," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKERS VISIT ROC VETERANS IN NORTHERN THAILAND
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Rai, northern Thailand, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Eleven legislators from the Republic of China on Friday expressed the hope that the government of Thailand will continue to offer equal treatment to former ROC soldiers and their families residing in the mountainous areas of northern Thailand.
A batch of ROC soldiers entered northern Thailand in the early 1950s, after the Kuomintang government was defeated in the civil war with the Chinese Communists and retreated to Taiwan in 1949.
Most of the ROC soldiers settled in the mountains of northern Thailand at the time, and have since become naturalized Thai citizens.

Speaking on behalf of the legislative delegation at a dinner with Chiang Rai Provincial Governor Samrerng Poonyopakorn, Legislator Hsiao Chin-lan thanked the Thai government for its treatment of the former ROC soldiers and their families, and said he hopes that the legislators' visit will further promote understanding and cooperation between the Thai and Chinese peoples.

In turn, Gov. Samrerng said that there are many minority ethnic groups in Chiang Rai province, and they are all offered equal treatment by the Thai government. The ROC veterans and their families have been especially well-treated, and most of them have been naturalized as citizens of Thailand, he noted.
Former Gen. Chen Mao-hsiu, a representative of the ROC veterans in Thailand, thanked the 11 ROC legislators for their visit, and praised Samrerng for his achievements as head of Chiang Rai province.

The 11 ROC legislators are traveling from Chiang Rai province to Mae Haun Saun province to visit former ROC soldiers and their families. They are scheduled to fly to Bangkok on Oct. 9, where they will attend a reception organized by the ROC representative office in Thailand to celebrate the ROC's National Day on Oct. 10.
They are scheduled to depart for Taipei on Oct. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S TIME SEEN RUNNING OUT AFTER MILOSEVIC'S DOWNFALL

TEXT.P: The downfall of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic this week is being closely watched by his supporters in Beijing, as Europe's last dictator was swept away by a democratic election, indicating that the clock is ticking for politically inflexible regimes that are reliant on nationalism.

In an analytical article, The Australian Financial Review noted that when a NATO missile hit the Chinese embassy in Belgrade during the war against Serbia last year, a propaganda campaign was unleashed in China portraying Milosevic as the champion of his people against cruel Western imperialists.

With Milosevic cowering in a bunker and Serbian cities crammed with people celebrating his downfall, Zhongnanhai must be aware that it has backed another loser, as it did with other "people's heroes" such as Pol Pot and Ceausescu, the daily said.

The daily noted President Jiang Zemin's determination to rebuild his party's popularity through nationalism, and to carve his own name in history as the Great Unifier of China. "Taiwan -- the jewel in the crown following the Pearl River pearls, Hong Kong and Macau, flies in the face of today's pluralistic trends," the paper said.

Chinese people, like the Yugoslavs, experienced too much in the 20th century to keep trusting cadres, mandarins or tsars to do their talking or their decision making for them for ever, the daily said.
They want a say in their future, they are well acquainted with what happens when others decide for them, it added.
The daily noted the Soviet Union survived for 70 years before imploding. "Can the People's Republic of China outlast it?" the paper asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: TICKET SALES FOR PARALYMPICS BOOMING

TEXT.P: Ticket sales for the 2000 Paralympic Games are booming, and only about 2000 tickets remain unsold for the opening ceremony on October 18, according to the games organizers.

The 2000 tickets to the opening ceremony have trickled back to the organizers as returns from sponsors. Most of them are expected to be A-category seats, and about 87,000 seats are available to the public, they said.
The tickets for the finals of the men's and women's wheelchair basketball matches have already been sold out, and tickets for all swimming events have also sold out, they said.

The organizers originally expected to sell a total of 650,000 tickets and to sell out both the opening and closing ceremonies to reach their US$10 million sales target, they said. But they discovered that demand was better than expected, and they have already raised US$9.7 million from ticket sales, with most of the sales going to schools and concession holders, they noted.
More than 4000 athletes from 125 countries will compete in the Paralympic Games from October 19 to 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: S&P AFFIRMS TAIWAN'S AA+/A-1+ RATINGS

TEXT.P: Standard & Poor's affirmed its AA+ long-term and A-1+ short-term issuer credit ratings for Taiwan in a report from Singapore Friday and announced that the outlook on Taiwan's long-term ratings remains stable.
The ratings apply to both foreign and local currency obligations.

S&P cited progressive democratization as a force heralding a "revolutionary transformation" of the island's political and institutional makeup. The report went on to say that the changes could reduce some of the "murky links" between government and businesses.

However, S&P also warned that the new government is faced with fewer political and economic resources. With the ruling Democratic Progressive Party still a minority in the legislature, S&P predicted that there may be short-term turmoil during the transition period.

The international ratings agency added that failure to control the national deficit, overcome policy and legislative paralyses -- including the passing of the next budget -- and address contingent risks could impair economic growth prospects, the fiscal balance sheet, and subsequently, Taiwan's creditworthiness.
According to S&P, Taiwan's ratings are bolstered by factors such as a strong external balance sheet, ample international liquidity, and an "innovative" and "robust" export-oriented economy.

The ratings agency report stated that Taiwan's "negligible" external public-sector debt and high external net asset position, estimated to be at least 70 percent of its exports in 2000, both surpass the medians for both AA and AAA rated countries.

In terms of international liquidity, S&P said Taiwan's huge foreign exchange reserves -- surpassed only by Japan and mainland China -- was also a factor in support of the agency's ratings. Taiwan's reserves are expected to reach US$115 billion by the end of the year, exceeding short-term external debt by more than 400 percent.

Taiwan's manufacturing flexibility, especially in the electronics and information technology sectors, as well as an abundance of "nimble" small- and medium-sized firms, also help sustain economic and employment growth, according to S&P.
Negative factors cited by the agency as constraining Taiwan's ratings were political and economic "vulnerabilities" posed by Taiwan's relations with mainland China.

S&P predicted that cross-strait relations are likely to remain uncertain in the face of mainland China's demands for reunification. This may result in increased tensions, S&P added, "but the risk of armed conflict remains low."

Taiwan's stable outlook balances Taiwan's good growth prospects, external flexibility, and prospects for improved government transparency and accountability against potential weaknesses in fiscal strength, S&P indicated in its report.

Continuous fiscal deficits, which have averaged 4.4 percent in the past decade and may persist for the next few years, are causing a deterioration in the government's net creditor position, S&P added.

"Fiscal flexibility is hamstrung by an antiquated tax system and political pledges against tax hikes on the revenue side, and high spending pressures, especially social and economic, on the expenditure," stated the credit agency.

"Fiscal pressures could also increase from contingent liability resulting from the high private-sector leverage, and the government's propensity to support financial institutions and the asset markets," S&P added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PLAN FOR ASEAN-AUSTRALIA-N.Z. FREE TRADE ZONE SCUTTLED

TEXT.P: Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines have raised their opposition to an Australian plan to merge the Association of Southeast Asian Nations Free Trade Area and the Australia New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement, resulting in an abrupt end to the wider free trade alliance.

In a dispatch from Chiang Mai, Thailand, The Australian Financial Review on Saturday reported that the opposition by the three ASEAN members was a blow to Australian hopes of making progress on an ambitious plan to merge the 10 ASEAN countries and Australia and New Zealand into a single market of 530 million people, with an annual gross domestic product of about US$1.1 trillion.
In a statement faxed to CNA, Australian Trade Minister Mark Vaile nevertheless said that Australia has taken an important step towards closer economic integration with Southeast Asia.
"Ministers agreed to work towards a Closer Economic Partnership linking the 10 ASEAN countries, Australia and New Zealand," Vaile said.

But the Review reported that Australia's ambitious plan was scuttled on Friday at a meeting of ASEAN economic ministers in Chiang Mai, which adopted a Malaysian initiative to weaken the Australian proposal.
The watered-down proposal is concerned with "technical assistance and capacity building measures," and is not as broad as the one proposed by Australia, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE STAYING AT HOME DESPITE LONGER VACATION TIME

TEXT.P: Mainland China's ambitious effort to bolster economic growth by boosting domestic consumption with "holiday economics" are not working out, mainly due to the lack of support from Chinese consumers.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, The Australian Financial Review quoted Chinese media as revealing that about 50 million people used the break to travel in early October, but figures from the past few days indicate that their holiday destinations have been fairly close to home.

Meanwhile, the Review quoted the China Daily as revealing that only 23,000 people had visited the Great Wall at Badaling, near Beijing, on Sunday. This was less than half the site's daily tourism capacity.

China has been trying to boost consumption levels over the past year by extending its three main holidays in the belief that the greater amount of leisure time would stimulate spending. But foreign analysts have given mixed reviews about the success of Beijing's experiment, the Australian daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA LIFTING TRADE SANCTIONS AGAINST YUGOSLAVIA

TEXT.P: Canada will lift economic and trade sanctions against Yugoslavia and work to help the country get back on its feet, Canada's Prime Minister Jean Chretien announced Friday.
Chretien made the statement after learning that former Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic had conceded defeat and that president-elect Vojislav Kostunica will take power.

"First I would like to say that I have just sent a letter to the new president of Yugoslavia -- President Kostunica -- and I offered my congratulations to him and offered my best wishes," Chretien said during a brief visit to Edmonton, Alberta.

Milosevic started and lost four wars in the Balkans during his 13 years in power, and sanctions imposed by the United Nations, Canada, the United States and Europe have left much of Yugoslavia impoverished and isolated.

Some of those controls were eased after Milosevic signed the 1995 agreement to end the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina. However, other sanctions were imposed again in 1998 after Milosevic launched a brutal crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG'S DEPARTURE INDICATES BEIJING'S IMPOTENCE REGARDING TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The recent resignation of Tang Fei from the Republic of China's premiership highlights Beijing's impotence in dealing with Taiwan-related affairs, according to The Economist magazine.

The London-based weekly said although Tang's departure from Taiwan's political scene may bring Beijing some anxiety, the event is not expected to have an immediate impact on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Nevertheless, the weekly said, Tang's surprise resignation earlier this week seems to have made mainland Chinese leaders better understand their impotence concerning Taiwan-related affairs.

According to The Economist, mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin said at a Beidaihe policy review meeting in August that he felt frustrated with the ineffectiveness of mainland China's policy strategy toward Taiwan over the past decade.

The weekly further said Beijing leaders seem to have come to terms with the cold reality that mainland China's military muscle will not be strong enough to swallow Taiwan in the next few years and that during this period mainland China can only endeavor to deepen trade and economic relations with Taiwan to prevent the island from drifting further away.

Tang, a four-star general-turned-politician and a senior member of the long-ruling Kuomintang, had helped stabilize Taiwan's domestic political situation and cross-strait relations following the island's first-ever transition of administrative power from the KMT to the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party in May.

The Economist said Tang's resignation indicates that President Chen Shui-bian's drive to run "a government of all people" has failed. As the ROC constitution has not clearly defined the powers of the president, the premier and the parliament, the British weekly predicted that Tang's abrupt departure will bring Taiwan a period of "political uncertainty."
The weekly also said the KMT will very likely try to block the DPP government's economic reforms and even boycott its budgetary plan to undermine President Chen's credibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOREIGN TRADE CONTINUES TO BOOM: MOF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's booming two-way trade showed no signs of slowing down in September, thanks to continued economic growth in the United States and Europe, the Asian recovery, and strong domestic demand, sources from the Ministry of Finance said Saturday.

Taiwan exported US$12.95 billion worth of products in September, up 22 percent over the same month of the previous year, and the third-largest single month export figure in Taiwan's history, the MOF officials said.
In the same month, Taiwan imported US$11.78 billion worth of commodities, an increase of 28 percent over the year-earlier level, they added.
September's monthly trade surplus of US$1.17 billion exceeded the US$1 billion mark, the first time since last December that this has been achieved, the MOF officials noted.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's total foreign trade exceeded the US$100 billion mark during the first three quarters of this year, an indication of the island's strong competitiveness in world trade, the officials said.

If two-way trade remains brisk in the last three months of 2000 -- usually the high season for exports -- and monthly foreign trade figures average US$13.60 billion during the last quarter, this year's annual growth of imports and exports will reach 30.8 percent and 24 percent, respectively, the officials said.

Nevertheless, they stressed that there are several negative factors that could adversely impact the country's foreign trade, including recent economic and political instability -- which is poised to rattle investor confidence and consumer spending -- coupled with increasingly higher international oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS UPPER HOUSE SPEAKER TO ARRIVE FOR FIVE-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Kotak Loeak, speaker of the Republic of Marshall Islands' Upper House, will arrive in Taipei on Oct. 9 at the head of a delegation making a five-day visit to the Republic of China.

While in the ROC, Loeak and his entourage will attend various activities for the celebration of the ROC National Day on Oct. 10 and will call on Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao and other ROC government officials.
They will also visit various ROC cultural and economic establishments, before returning to the Marshall Islands on Oct. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS VOICE SUPPORT FOR REPORTER ACCUSED BY MILITARY

TEXT.P: Lawmakers across the political spectrum on Saturday voiced their support for a local newspaper reporter who has been accused by the Defense Ministry Friday of revealing military secrets.
At a press conference, the legislators criticized the military for being "absurd" in denying the content of the reporter's article while using the same report to prosecute him.
Hung Che-cheng, a Power Daily reporter, was accused by military prosecutors of attempting to pry into national secrets, an offense that carries a maximum sentence of five years imprisonment.

Hung was investigated for writing a story on the eve of President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration that three Beijing warships were spotted within 30 nautical miles of Suao Harbor in northeastern Taiwan.

He was spared a court martial because he is a civilian, and was instead sent to Taiwan High Court prosecutors for indictment on the criminal charges. He was also subpoenaed by the military court to serve as a witness.

Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that the military's accusation may be difficult for the public to accept, because digging up news and "reporting the truth" is a duty that the media cannot shirk. He urged the military to reconsider whether the reports in question are serious enough to be prosecuted.

Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the majority opposition Kuomintang noted that the recent series of searches and indictments is "not a coincidence," adding that the new government may be using the opportunity to intimidate the local media, which has traditionally been aggressive.
Hung's indictment was the second high-profile case within a week in which the press has run afoul of the judiciary for its coverage of military scandals.

On Tuesday, the office of the mass-circulated China Times Express was searched by prosecutors for publishing transcripts of a deposition given by two military officers on the corruption of an army colonel at the National Security Bureau. Also searched were the homes of two of the paper's journalists.

The prosecutors, leading a group of police, swooped in on the China Times Express office Tuesday morning in a vain attempt to seize a copy of the deposition, which they billed as "secret," claiming that its leakage would put the pursuit of the scandal in peril.

Regarding the more recent case, Legislator Lee Ching-an of the opposition People First Party questioned whether the military was attempting to cover up the truth when it made its accusations based on a report whose accuracy it had denied.

Speaking for the military at the press conference, military judge Hsiao Fu-ming said that "nobody said Hung was guilty," but only that he "was suspected of a crime." Hsiao added that only the judicial system will be able to determine whether Hung is guilty.

Deputy director Liu Chih-chien of the military spokesman's office reasserted that the military had not discovered any mainland Chinese warship activity outside of Suao Harbor prior to President Chen's May 20 inauguration.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's National Press Council urged the executive and legislative branches of the government to define the reasonable limits of "national security" and "divulging secrets" in order to allow the media to enjoy its press freedom under the principle of self-regulation.
The NPC also questioned how Hung could be indicted over "prying into national secrets" if his report had been false, as the military had immediately moved to deny its accuracy.

Because the ethics of journalism demand that sources remain protected, the NPC added it would be against the professional code of journalists for Hung to respond to the military court's subpoena and come forward as a witness.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T SHOULD IMPROVE EFFICIENCY IN POST-DISASTER RECONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: Experts and academics at a Saturday symposium on post-quake reconstruction urged the central and local governments to improve their coordination and efficiency in delivering disaster relief and settlement assistance, as well as pursuing reconstruction work.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh noted that although some observers have said that clearing away the current chaos is "something that only God can do," the minute he walked into a region hit hard by last year's devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, he "discovered that God has already done a lot, and the rest is what we have to do."

Lee, a Nobel laureate who serves concurrently as the convener of the National Public Sector Post-Disaster Reconstruction Alliance, went on to say that everyone should do their best to remove the metaphorical "stones," adding that the thing to be feared the most would be to discover that "we ourselves are the big stones" that block progress.

Chu Hai-yuen, vice convener of the alliance, said that the function of the Cabinet's own post-quake reconstruction committee is unclear. He added that minority peoples living in the disaster region have not been sufficiently cared for, the legal system is inadequate for the task, and the participation of the public in the establishment of reconstruction policies has also been insufficient.

Chu questioned the efficiency of all levels of government, adding that the local government's performance particularly was "not quite ideal" in all areas, including disaster relief, assistance for people who need new dwellings after their homes were destroyed, and ongoing reconstruction work.
He noted that local governments have also had problems with embezzlement, referring to a case where relief items were discovered in the home of a local official.

Chu went on to say that the different levels of government also have a "serious problem" with communicating and cooperating with each other, and have therefore come up with very few objective and constructive suggestions.
He urged a simplification of the administrative process and the establishment of a supervision system to ensure that waste and overlapping of budgets for the reconstruction do not occur.

At the same symposium, members of reconstruction teams from the disaster regions did not entirely agree with the "Taipei viewpoints" and the "professional perspectives," insisting that the voice of the people living in those regions should be heeded.

The team members pointed out that although planning is important, people in the disaster regions face the immediate issues of shelter, food, unemployment, and transportation. They added that the people do not want short-term work, but rather want long-term jobs.

The people don't want beautiful and expensive houses that require long-term mortgages, they said. Rather, durable and reasonably priced houses that can be lived in immediately are called for, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HALVING MAXIMUM SINGLE-DAY FALL OF STOCK PRICES REMAINS

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang announced Saturday that the special measure cutting the maximum single-day fall of equity prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange to 3.5 percent will be continued until Oct. 11, as originally scheduled.

Former Premier Tang Fei's sudden resignation Tuesday shocked the island, and in order to minimize its impact on the stock market, former Finance Minister Shea Jia-dong announced a temporary change in stock market regulations. Normally, the maximum amount a stock's price is allowed to fall in a single day is 7 percent, but the ministry decided to halve that figure to 3.5 percent for six business days, starting on Wednesday.

Despite an overnight plunge on the New York Stock Exchange, the TAIEX benchmark weighted index rallied a hefty 324 points Friday, thanks to intervention by the government's national stabilization fund and the temporary change in maximum single-day falls. The index was stable Saturday, closing just 1.64 points lower.

Yen originally considered ending the temporary measure on Monday, ahead of schedule. But some investors thought such a move would have an adverse effect on the stock market, and Yen finally decided to allow the measure to remain until Oct. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB TO END 'POLITICAL SURVEILLANCE' WORK

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau will formally phase out its controversial "political surveillance" work soon, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan confirmed Saturday.

Chen was responding to a China Times front-page report that the MJIB had directed its agents Friday to immediately stop "political surveillance" operations in a move to show the bureau's support for "neutrality in intelligence gathering".

Chen said at a press conference that the National Security Bureau under the Presidential Office has reached a consensus with the Executive Yuan that the MJIB will focus on criminal investigations and national security affairs, and will no longer conduct any politically-motivated reconnaissance of the activities of specific political parties or individual politicians.

According to the MJIB's current organizational statute, "political surveillance," also known as "national condition surveys," ranks among the bureau's nine major categories of responsibilities, and is performed under the guidance and supervision of the National Security Bureau.

The China Times report said MJIB Director Wang Kuang-yu decided to order an immediate halt to the controversial "political surveillance" work after meeting with a grassroots group of reform-minded MJIB investigators Thursday.

Commenting on the report, Chen said although the MJIB is required to complete certain legal procedures before adjusting its functions, the bureau should suspend its "political surveillance" work first as an expedient measure.

Chen said since he took office in May, the Justice Ministry has on many occasions asked the MJIB to stop the previous Kuomintang government-initiated practice of "political surveillance", more commonly known as "white terror" political persecution of political dissidents and opposition parties.
The formation in September of the Investigators Reform Association, a group of MJIB agents, helped accelerate the scrapping of the decades-old practice.

With the support of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and under strong pressure from other major political parties, the NSB has agreed to free the MJIB from the controversial "political surveillance" work.

NSB sources said the bureau has formed a special task force to study how to adjust NSB and MJIB duties. "The task force is scheduled to finalize a report within one month," said an NSB official, adding that the bureau plans to complete necessary legal procedures to adjust the MJIB's role by the end of October.

Meanwhile, opposition New Party Legislator Elmer Feng said NSB Director Ting Yu-chou has promised him that the MJIB will scrap "political surveillance" and conduct only "national security surveys" in the future.

According to Feng, the "national security surveys" will focus on investigating mainland Chinese infiltration or other subversive activities, foreign nationals' anti-ROC government activities, terrorist activities, financial crimes, general public opinion and social trends.
"All these are positive changes in line with the principle of maintaining neutrality in intelligence and law enforcement operations," Feng said.
New Party parliamentary whip Lai Shih-pao said he will initiate a proposal to add an anti-political surveillance provision to the current National Security Law.

The provision would ban the government from wire-tapping and monitoring any individuals, except for those who are suspected of being involved in activities strongly detrimental to national security and social stability, Lai explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CABINET'S APPROVAL RATING STANDS AT 63.2%: POLL

TEXT.P: The approval rating of the newly reshuffled Cabinet stands at 63.2 percent, according to the results of a recent public opinion poll released on Saturday.

The telephone poll of 1,040 randomly selected adult residents, conducted by Eastern Multimedia Group (EMG) Friday, found that 63.2 percent of the respondents are satisfied with the partial Cabinet shakeup following Tang Fei's surprise resignation from the premiership on Tuesday.

Nevertheless, 34.2 percent of those interviewed said they are dissatisfied with the small-scale Cabinet reshuffle, which saw the promotion of Chang Chun-hsiung from the post of vice premier to the premiership and changes of chiefs of a few government agencies.
Survey results also show that 62.8 percent said they feel Chang is suitable for the premiership, while 35.3 percent said they think otherwise.

A cross analysis of the poll results further found that the approval ratings of both Premier Chang and the new Cabinet are similar among different groups of the respondents divided in terms of gender, age and party affiliation. This indicates that the new Cabinet personnel arrangement is acceptable to the majority of local people.

However, a series of EMG polls found that President Chen Shui-bian's approval ratings have been on a declining streak. According to the latest poll, Chen's approval rating stood at 48.3 percent, the lowest level since he assumed office in May.

The EMG survey center said Chen enjoyed an approval rating of higher than 80 percent after delivering his inaugural speech on May 20, and that his popularity rate still stood at 77.2 percent on the eve of his first month in office. His approval rating plunged to 49 percent following the Pachang Creek tragedy in July, which claimed four lives and led to the resignation of then-Vice Premier Yu Shyi-kun to take the blame. Chen's approval rating has since never exceeded 60 percent, according to EMG surveys.

Although the new Cabinet has pledged to give the top priority to ensuring continued economic growth, the latest poll found that 54 percent of those interviewed have no confidence in the government's ability to realize this goal. Confidence of the supporters of the main opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party was especially low.

More noteworthy was that 66.1 percent said they have no confidence in the new pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party-dominated Cabinet's ability to stabilize relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, 48.4 percent said they believe that relations between the new Cabinet and the KMT-controlled Legislative Yuan will become increasingly better, but 31.5 percent said they don't think that the Cabinet-parliament relations will improve, while 20 percent said they cannot forecast the future development of Cabinet-parliament ties.
The poll further found that 77.4 percent do not support the proposal of an early re-election of the legislators, while 22.3 percent gave a thumbs-up to the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM FORESEES NO BIG CHANGES IN U.S. POLICY TOWARD ROC

TEXT.P: There will be no dramatic changes in the U.S. policy toward the Republic of China no matter who wins the upcoming U.S. presidential election, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao predicted Saturday.
Tien made the forecast in a radio talk show on the development of Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations.

Noting that the two major U.S. parties' policies on relations across the Taiwan Strait have shown a trend of continuity, Tien said he doesn't foresee an about-face in the U.S. policy toward Taiwan following its November presidential election.

"Either the Democratic Party or the Republican Party wins the presidency, the U.S. policy on cross-Taiwan Strait relations will be based on its three joint communiques with mainland China and its Taiwan Relations Act, a U.S. law that regulates Washington-Taipei exchanges in the absence of formal diplomatic ties," Tien explained.

Of course, Tien said, the new U.S. president will make an overall review of the U.S. policies toward Taiwan and mainland China. "But basically there will be no U-turn in its policies toward both sides of the Taiwan Strait," he added.

Nevertheless, Tien said if Republican candidate George W. Bush wins the presidency, his administration will certainly re-evaluate the U.S. policy toward mainland China as one of Bush's senior campaign aides has said that the Republican Party will treat mainland China as a "competitor," not a strategic partner as the current Clinton administration does.

The international affairs expert-turned-minister further said he thinks the ROC government should pay close attention to the possible shakeup of mainland China's policy-making political bureau as some members are getting old.
"We should carefully monitor how the mainland political bureau will be reshuffled as well as whether Beijing will adjust its strategy or policy toward Taiwan," Tien noted.

Tien further said he doesn't think that Taiwan needs to care about Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew's forecast that the United States will regard mainland China as the key negotiating target for cross-strait relations and that Taiwan's role in the process will be overlooked.

"We need not worry about that. Although Taiwan is the smallest in the triangular relations, the United States has on many occasions stressed that cross-strait issues must be resolved by peaceful means and that any settlement proposals must have the consent of the people of Taiwan," Tien said.

Turning to relations with the Solomon Islands, Tien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is still checking why the Solomon Island foreign minister didn't arrive in Taipei Friday as originally scheduled.

The Solomon Island minister's abrupt cancellation of his arrival to attend the ROC's Double Ten National Day celebrations has caused speculation about the prospects of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

Tien said the political situation in the South Pacific island nation has not yet fully stabilized. According to Tien, the Solomon Islands has asked Taiwan to offer financial aid. But as the amount exceeds Taiwan's financial ability, Tien said, the government is still mulling the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT HONORS VISITING FORMER MONGOLIAN PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian gave a luncheon Saturday in honor of a 13-member delegation headed by former Mongolian Prime Minister Janlaviin Narantsatsralt.
As the ROC's Double Ten National Day is at the corner, Chen expressed his hope that both the ROC and Mongolia will go prosperous.

Chen got acquainted with Narantsatsralt three years ago when he visited Ulan Bator to sign a sister-city agreement with Ulan Bator in his capacity as Taipei mayor. Narantsatsralt was the mayor of Ulan Bator at that time.

The former Mongolian prime minister now heads the Mongolian-Taiwan Association. He told Chen that he hopes Mongolia and Taiwan will strengthen cooperation in the cultural, educational and economic areas.

Chen expressed the hope that the Mongolian-Taiwan Association and its Taiwan counterpart, the Taiwan-Mongolian Association (headed by Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chang Chun-hung) will establish liaison offices to promote exchanges.
The Mongolian delegation arrive in Taipei on Oct. 3 to promote substantive relations between the two countries which have no diplomatic relations.
Besides meeting with Taipei political leaders, the delegation toured several local cultural and economic establishments.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO RESUME KAOHSIUNG-MANILA PASSENGER SERVICE

TEXT.P: China Airlines will resume its Kaohsiung-Manila passenger service Sunday morning, with over 100 passengers going to board the first flight.
CAL's passenger service between Kaohsiung and Manila has been suspended for nearly one year because of the termination of the aviation agreement between the Republic of China and the Philippines.
The two countries signed an agreement to restore their air link recently.

A spokesman for CAL's Kaohsiung office said that a Boeing 737-800, which is capable of carrying 158 passengers, will be used on the first flight to Manila Sunday morning, and added that more than 100 passengers have booked for that flight.
During the initial period, CAL will operate one flight between Kaohsiung and Manila daily. The one-way flying time is one hour and 40 minutes.

The CAL spokesman said that he is optimistic about the business on the resumed service between Kaohsiung and Manila, because it can save Manila-bound passengers about four hours in time and NT$5,000 in fare. In the past, they had to change planes in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 8, or the 11th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: John Hay, U.S. statesman and diplomat, is born. As secretary of state from 1898 to 1905, he promoted the "open door" policy with China.
1858: The "Arrow Incident" occurs, in which a Hong Kong-registered ship, the Arrow, is searched in Kwantung by Ching soldiers and 12 of its sailors are arrested. The incident led to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking and the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1869: Franklin Pierce, 14th president of the United States, dies at the age of 65. He was unable to reconcile the issue of slavery that divided his country.
1895: Queen Min of Korea, who had tried to stem the tide of Japanese domination, is assassinated in her palace at the instigation of the Japanese.
1897: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., a New York news agency, comes up with the novel idea of charting general trends in the trading of stocks and bonds on Wall Street. The agency computes a daily industrials average by using a list of 12 stocks and dividing their total price by 12.
1912: Montenegro declares war on Turkey, starting the first Balkan War.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the National government of the Republic of China.
1954: Communist Vietnamese forces occupy Hanoi.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of the "Free China" monthly magazine, is sentenced to 10 years in prison for involvement in an insurrection.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Senegal.
1965: The Asian Christian Anti-Communist Conference is opened in Taipei.
1967: Clement Attlee, British politician, dies at the age of 84. As Labour prime minister from 1945 to 1951, he established the National Health Service, expanded public ownership of industry, and granted independence to India and Burma.
1970: Russian novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.
1973: Thai Air Force Marshal Boon Choo Chandrubekas arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Economic Minister Y.S. Sun leaves for the United States to attend the China Week Celebration at Expo 74 in Spokane.
1974: Eisaku Sato, Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1964 to 1972, is awarded the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts toward nuclear disarmament.
1974: Gen. Lai Ming-tang, chief of the general staff, returns to Taipei from a two-week visit to Central America.
1981: A team of 10 divers recovers 431 gold bars worth US$83 million from the wreckage of the "Edinburgh," a British cruiser sunk by German destroyers and a U-boat in the Barents Sea in 1942.
1981: Costa Rican President Rodrigo Carazo Odio, Madame Carazo, and their 12-member entourage arrive in Taipei for a five-day official visit.
1984: Beijing announces a plan to make primary school education compulsory by 1990 and to eradicate adult illiteracy by 1995.
1992: A chartered plane carrying tourists from Taiwan, Europe, and China crashes in northeast China, killing 13 people and injuring four others.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks Sumatra, Indonesia, killing more than 100.
1997: Tung Chee-hwa becomes the first Chinese leader to address Hong Kong's legislature, 100 days after Britain ceded the territory to Communist China.
1998: The U.S. House of Representatives approves launching a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, only the third such investigation in U.S. history.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei says the ROC is determined to proceed with a plan to develop its own anti-missile defense even with no outside aid in the face of Beijing's growing missile threat.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of originality, energy, strength of character and determination: qualities necessary for the exercise of endurance."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
A think tank of the opposition Kuomintang urges the return to the National Unification Guidelines to stabilize relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The China Times:
The United States is trying to lobby for the continued construction of the fourth nuclear power plant.
The United Daily News:
The U. S. is very concerned with possible scrapping of the nuclear power construction project.
The Liberty Times:
President Chen Shui-bian addresses Janlaviin Narantsatsralt as the former prime minister of the People's Republic of Mongolia.
The China Post:
Economics Minister denies electricity shortage looming.
The Taiwan News:
New era dawns in war-torn Yugoslavia.
The Taipei Times:
Surveillance may be on the way out.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REITERATES OFF-HANDS POLICY ON TAIWAN NUCLEAR PLANT

TEXT.P: A U.S. official dismissed Saturday as "irrelevant" reports from Taipei that Washington was lobbying Taiwan to continue the construction of the nation's fourth nuclear plant, which involves U.S. firms.
Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, told CNA that the U.S. State Department has already issued a statement on this issue, and its off-hands policy still stands.
The United States announced on Sept. 4 that it is Taipei's decision whether to proceed with the plant, and the U.S. government is only concerned that all contract provisions are fulfilled.

In first-page stories on Sunday, two mass-circulated newspapers in Taipei quoted unidentified government officials as saying that Washington is expected to pressure Taipei to continue the construction of its fourth nuclear plant, which would use a reactor manufactured by U.S. firm General Electric Co.

The United Daily News quoted an official of Taiwan's Atomic Energy Council as saying that AIT officials, displeased with President Chen Shui-bian's public statement that even the United States is unable to properly dispose of nuclear waste, have lodged a complaint with the Taiwan nuclear regulatory agency.

Both the United Daily News and the China Times reported that AIT officials are working on a position statement to be addressed to President Chen, with the aim of dissuading Taiwan from abandoning nuclear power.

Chen, who campaigned for president on an anti-nuclear platform, has made moves to scrap the island's fourth nuclear plant. The plant is already 33 percent finished, and some NT$48 billion (US$1.54 billion) has already been spent on it.
Chen's administration has estimated that scrapping the plant will cost the country NT$75 billion (US$2.41 billion) to NT$90 billion (US$2.9 billion) in compensation for contractors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-MANILA DIRECT AIR LINK RESUMES

TEXT.P: Suspended air links between Taipei and Manila were resumed Sunday after a protracted dispute over air rights.

Lee Yun-ning, chairman of China Airlines, and Rodolfo Reyes, director of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office, jointly presided over a ceremony commemorating the resumption of direct flights to Manila at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Sunday morning.

Reyes said that the Taipei-Manila air link is unlikely to be scrapped again, as the new aviation agreement between the two sides was signed in consideration of the mutual interest of the Republic of China and the Philippine Islands.

Reyes pointed out that many Filipino laborers now working in Taiwan will again be able to fly directly between Taiwan and Manila without a stopover in a third country, which will save them a lot of time and money.
He added that the resumed air link will make his country more attractive to Taiwan investors.
Lee pointed out that the Taipei-Manila air link began in 1967, and has greatly contributed to mutual understanding and friendship between the two countries.

He expressed his belief that the resumption of the direct air link will help strengthen economic and cultural interchanges between Taiwan and the Philippines. He also promised that China Airlines will offer its best services for passengers flying the route.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIVESTOCK OWNERS URGED TO BE ON GUARD AGAINST FMD

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) on Sunday urged livestock farmers to be on guard against outbreaks of foot and mouth disease and rigorously follow vaccination measures against the disease.

Lee Chin-lung, director of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said that Taiwan is still affected by FMD, as the virus is still latent in the environment. He added that sporadic FMD cases could erupt at any time.
Lee said that farmers should be especially cautious at this time of the year, because animals lose their resistance to the virus as cold weather approaches.
He noted that Taiwan has not seen any FMD cases in hogs in nearly 18 months, and no such cases in cattle in nine months. The latest FMD cases among goats were reported in February.

But he stressed that the lack of new FMD reports does not mean that the disease has been eradicated in Taiwan. He added that officials from his bureau will work with their local counterparts to ensure that all livestock farmers rigorously follow livestock vaccination procedures.

FMD is an acute, contagious, febrile disease that occurs in cattle, hogs, sheep, and other hoofed animals. It is caused by an array of various rhinoviruses and is characterized by vesicular eruptions in the mouth and about the hoofs and udders.
Taiwan first reported an outbreak of FMD three years ago, resulting in the large-scale slaughter of the nation's hogs, which dealt a serious blow to the nation's pork exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEADER URGES IMPROVEMENTS IN DOMESTIC INDUSTRIES
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan on Sunday urged the government, industrial and commercial sectors to upgrade Taiwan's domestic industries and increase their competitiveness.
Lien made the remark at a ribbon-cutting ceremony of Prokia Technology's new high-tech manufacturing facility in southern Taiwan's Tainan Science-based Industrial Park.
Lien said that faced with a slumping economy, the government and industrial sectors should work together to push the development of high-tech industries.
He added that Taiwan industries need to upgrade and change their structure so that they can increase their competitiveness and survive.
With high-tech manufacturing accounting for 60 percent of Taiwan's total production, Lien said that high-tech industries should get more attention from the government and industrial sectors.

Lien said he was happy to see that the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park, a product of the KMT-led government, has continued to develop since he attended the ground-breaking ceremony of a Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. plant there three years ago.

Wung Cheng-yi, chairman of Cabinet-level National Science Council, promised that the government will supply companies in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park with sufficient electricity and water, so that they can step up production as quickly as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SURVEY: 63 PERCENT OF VOTERS WORRIED ABOUT NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: A recent public opinion survey by the Kuomintang Policy Coordination Committee indicates that 63 percent of the island's eligible voters are worried about the country's future development following the resignation of former Premier Tang Fei.
The telephone survey was conducted among 1,138 voters between Oct. 4-5. The results were made public Sunday.

When asked which party they would support following Tang's resignation, 23.81 percent named the People First Party, followed by the KMT with 23.11 percent, and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party with 21.44 percent.
Forty-seven percent said that Tang's resignation was not good for the country's political and economic stability, while 28 percent said it was beneficial.

Tang's greatest contribution to the country during his four-month stint as premier were named as military and national defense (25 per cent), mainland policy and cross-Taiwan Strait relations (16 percent), and social security and moves against "black-gold" forces (12 percent).
Fifty-five percent said they no longer have confidence in President Chen Shui-bian's "government of all people" following Tang's resignation, while 36 percent said they have confidence.
Fifty-one percent said they have no confidence in new Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, while 32 percent said they have.
Sixty-three percent said they were worried about the country's future direction, and a similar 63 percent said they were dissatisfied with the general performance of the ruling DPP.

Regarding the best way to improve the political and economic situation, 35 percent pointed to the formation of a coalition government, followed by the formation of a DPP Cabinet (18 percent), and the formation of a Cabinet by the largest party in the Legislative Yuan (13 percent).
Presently, only 32 percent said they hope to see President Chen recalled, while 52 percent are against recalling the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. PLANS TO HELP TAIWAN, SOUTH KOREA HANDLE NUCLEAR WASTE

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of Energy is willing to help Taiwan and South Korea handle highly radioactive nuclear waste, and will do so in two stages, a trade source said on Sunday.

According to the U.S. Department of Energy, the first stage will implement the transfer of technology while the second stage will transport solidified radioactive waste to a foreign country for deep burial. At the present time, the U.S. plans to bury the nuclear waste in Siberia.
The plan will be implemented once the Russian Parliament approves the project, the source said.
The U.S. Department of Energy announced in September that it is willing to share its nuclear waste disposal technology and experience with countries around the world.

C.K. Chou, a special assistant at the U.S. Department of Energy, said that the U.S. is now conducting a study on handling highly radioactive nuclear waste in such a facility, the results of which are to be submitted to the U.S. president and the Congress for approval next year. If approved, the department will formally apply for a license to build a nuclear waste dump.
Expert sources said that only 3 percent of an amount of nuclear waste must be solidified and sealed before permanent burial, while the other 97 percent can be recycled for further use.
South Korea is said to have originally planned to send the waste from its nuclear power plants to Europe for handling, but suspended the plan after objections from the United States.
The United States and Russia are now planning to build a nuclear waste dump site in Siberia, but the plan is subject to the approval of the Russian Parliament.
Taiwan's state-run Taiwan Power Co. has also reportedly contacted Russian government agencies on the issue of dumping its nuclear waste there.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER THROWS WEIGHT BEHIND NUCLEAR PLANT

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen threw his weight behind the island's controversial fourth nuclear power plant Sunday despite the fact that the cabinet seems determined to stop its construction.
Responding to questions from reporters in Kaohsiung, Wu said that nuclear power would serve the nation's security interests better than any other form of energy.

Although both nuclear and fossil fuels have to be imported to the island, a single Boeing 747 can deliver enough nuclear fuel to supply a nuclear plant with a capacity of 2.7 million kilowatts for one year, compared to 100 ship-loads of coal to supply a thermal electricity power plant with a similar capacity for the same amount of time, Wu said.

Wu noted that Taiwan's shipping routes are vulnerable to a blockade, adding that nuclear power generation would not be hindered by such a situation, while coal-burning power plants would be paralyzed.

He said he doesn't think that the island's nuclear plants would become a target of military attacks by Beijing, because the radioactive fallout from the destruction of the plants would be a huge risk to the mainland itself.

Meanwhile, Democratic Progressive Party legislator Lee Ying-yuan, who has been designated as Taiwan's deputy representative to Washington, said Saturday that the DPP will not alter its anti-nuclear stance, regardless of Washington's concerns about Taiwan's decision to halt the construction of its fourth nuclear plant, which would be equipped with U.S.-made reactors.
Characterizing it as a private-sector issue, Lee said he believes that Washington will respect Taiwan's decision, as long as it is not detrimental to U.S. contractors.

He was asked to comment on Sunday's reports that Washington was lobbying Taiwan to continue the construction of the plant. A U.S. State Department official in Washington denied the report earlier in the day, and reiterated Washington's hands-off policy on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE HOPE GOVERNMENT WILL RESOLVE ECONOMIC PROBLEMS FIRST

TEXT.P: The latest public opinion survey shows that most people in Taiwan hope the new government will give priority to resolving the island's pressing economic problems.
The survey was conducted by the National Tendency Public Opinion Research Center among 1,073 people between Oct. 6-7. The results were made public Sunday morning.

Sixty-two percent of respondents said the government should focus its energy on resolving Taiwan's economic problems, followed by social security issues (7.3 percent), black-gold corruption (4.6 percent), and cross-Taiwan Strait relations (2.6 percent).
Forty-two percent of those polled attributed the sharp drop in President Chen Shui-bian's approval rating to the government's failure to resolve Taiwan's economic problems.

The survey indicates that 63 percent of respondents support the appointment of Chang Chun-hsiung to replace Tang Fei as new premier, and 46.7 percent said they have confidence in Premier Chang and new Vice Premier Lai Ying-chao.

Thirty-eight percent said they would consider giving the ruling Democratic Progressive Party more seats in the Legislative Yuan in next year's elections, while 39 percent said they have no such consideration.

A great majority of those polled said they would give the new administration more time to display its efficiency, because four months is not enough time to make a fair judgment on the government's performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$ 25 BIL. IN BONDS OK'D FOR LOCAL SALE BY FOREIGN INSTITUTIONS

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China has so far this year approved an accumulated NT$25 billion in New Taiwan dollar denominated bonds issued by international financial institutions in Taiwan.

A CBC official said that the central bank had approved the application of the Interamerican Development Bank to issue NT$7 billion bonds in Taiwan in May, and also approved the European Investment Bank's application to issue NT$12 billion in bonds here in August.
On Sept. 15, the CBC approved the application of the European Council Development Bank to issue NT$6 billion bonds in Taiwan, he further pointed out.

Meanwhile, in order to promote both inbound and outbound capital flows, the CBC accepted a recommendation from the Ministry of Finance on Jan. 4 to help local investment promoters collect NT$60 billion to invest in foreign stock and securities markets, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:

KMT Chairman Lien Chan urges the government to present measures to help farmers cope with possible challenges following Taiwan's WTO entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 9, or the 12th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1192: King Richard the Lion-hearted abandons the Holy Land after an unsuccessful Crusade, leaving Jerusalem in Muslim hands.
1701: Yale University is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
1944: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrives in Russia to talk with Joseph Stalin in the Third Moscow Conference.
1944: The United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China promulgate a draft for the Charter of the United Nations.
1958: Pope Pius XII, originally Eugenio Pacelli, dies at the age of 82. He headed the Roman Catholic Church during World War II.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Congo (Leopoldville) Republic.
1962: Uganda gains formal independence after nearly 70 years of British rule.
1965: ROC Ambassador to the United States and Representative to the United Nations Tsiang Ting-fu dies of liver cancer in New York at the age of 71.
1967: Ernesto "Che" Guevara, the Argentine-born revolutionary who helped Fidel Castro win power in Cuba, is shot dead after being captured by Bolivian Army troops. He was 39.
1967: Indonesia severs diplomatic relations with communist China.
1970: Dissident Soviet writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize for Literature, turns down an invitation to Stockholm to attend the award ceremony in December.
1970: Cambodia declares itself the Khmer Republic.
1972: Prime Minister Tupua Tamasese Lealofi IV of Western Samoa arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: General Hernado Currea Cubides, Colombian defense minister, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1973: Mayor Chang Feng-shu of Taipei leaves for Honolulu to attend a council meeting of the Asian and Pacific Area Conference of Mayors.
1974: A two-day post-congress symposium of the first conference of the World Nuclear Medicine Federation opens in Taipei.
1975: Soviet dissident and human rights activist Andrei Sakharov is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Alberto Nogues Perez, foreign minister of Paraguay.
1976: A 34-member delegation leaves Taipei for the United States to take part in the second Worldwide Conference of People-to-People International at Kansas City, Mo.
1983: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan escapes unharmed when 17 members of his entourage, including Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk, are killed in a bomb blast in Rangoon.
1984: A famous Cantonese opera performer from mainland China, Hung Hung, 40, announces her defection in a press conference held at the Free China Relief Association in Taipei.
1986: The Executive Yuan passes the Program for Taroko National Park, in which NT$4 billion is to be invested in developing the park over six years.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Task Force approves the first draft of the Temporary Provisions Governing Relations between the People of the Mainland Region and Taiwan Region.
1998: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government resigns after losing its 31st vote of confidence.
1999: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urges mainland China to promote relations with Taiwan based on a "special state-to-state relationship."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of dignity, noble seriousness, order and regularity: qualities necessary for the exercise of self-respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 142.61 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 142.61 points to close at 6,209.42.
Market turnover amounted to NT$59.48 billion (US$1.9 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO HELP FIGHT AIDS IN AFRICA

TEXT.P: Taiwan is planning to ship several million condoms to Africa as part of the World Health Organization's efforts at fighting AIDS on that continent, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.

Invited by the WHO delegation in Liberia, the MOFA agreed to donate 5 million to 6 million condoms to Liberia, which maintains formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, said Andrew Hsia, director of the MOFA's Department of International Organizations.
It was learned that the U.S. government has also promised to contribute 1 million condoms to the same WHO project, Hsia said.

He added that the MOFA plans to send the condoms early next year when members of Taiwan's private, voluntary medical group, Luchuhuei (the Roadside Bamboo Society), embark on a voluntary medical mission to Liberia.

Meanwhile, according to Hsia, the MOFA is also planning to cooperate with the WHO, the World Bank, and other non-government international organizations in jointly sponsoring another AIDS program to be launched in Chad, another ROC diplomatic ally in Africa.

M. Lesvegues, chairman of CareFrance, which is an affiliate of Care International, visited Hsia more than one month ago and invited Taiwan to be one of the donors to a US$2.3 million program helping Chad control and prevent the spread of AIDS, noted Hsia.
He said the MOFA has promised in principle to offer US$500,000 to the program and is willing to contribute the cash aid over three years.

AIDS is threatening to bring widespread death and suffering to the continent of Africa as about half of all people under the age of 50 living in sub-Saharan Africa are reported to be HIV-carriers, Hsia said.
