DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 142.61 points to close at 6,209.42.

Affected by a downward streak in electronics stocks in the United States, the bourse opened at 6,336.3, and due to profit-taking selling pressure, the index continued to move lower. The bourse fluctuated between 6,338.5 and 6,203.47 during trading.

A total of 1.76 billion stocks worth NT$59.48 billion (US$1.9 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.43 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$92.44 billion (US$2.95 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 2.9 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.8 percent, textile issues at 2.5 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.6 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.4 percent, construction stocks at 0.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.6 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 456 to 107, with 57 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taipei stock index futures were lower Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization weighted index futures for October moved down 225 points to close at 6,205, with 5,777 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for November decreased 226 points to finish at 6,239, with 185 contract transactions, while December futures lost 224 points to close at 6,281, with 10 contracts changing hands.
March 2001 futures fell 130 points to finish at 6,315, with two contract transactions, while June 2001 futures moved down 222 points to close at 6,430, with three contracts traded.
Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Monday at 6,430 for October, 6,465 for November, 6,505 for December, 6,445 for next March, and 6,652 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
October TE futures moved down 11.7 points to close at 322.8, with 1,530 contract transactions, while November TE futures decreased 11.25 points to finish at 321, with 67 contracts changing hands.
December TE futures fell 9.8 points to close at 328, with 16 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.
October TF futures lost 22 points to close at 739, with 729 contract transactions, while November TF futures decreased 27.2 points to finish at 751.4, with 24 contracts traded.
December TF futures fell 19 points to close at 753, with 16 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WELCOMES HAITIAN PRESIDENT WITH 21-GUN SALUTE

TEXT.P: Haitian President Rene Preval and his wife, leading an official delegation, arrived in Taipei Monday to attend celebration activities marking the Republic of China's Double-Ten National Day.

Preval and his delegation were accorded a 21-gun military salute during an official welcoming ceremony presided over by President Chen Shui-bian in the plaza of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei.
Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, the presidents of the five Yuans, and ministers of the Cabinet were also on hand to welcome the guests from Haiti.
This trip represents President Preval's second visit to the ROC on Taiwan during his tenure. He last visited Taipei in April 1998.

The occasion marked the second time President Chen has hosted a ceremony honoring a foreign head of state with a military salute since he assumed the ROC presidency in May this year. The first occasion was on July 1 when Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso Rodriguez visited Taiwan.

During his stay, President Preval is expected to meet with President Chen and Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao to exchange views on the international situation and on matters of mutual concern, said officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Preval, an agronomist-turned-president who studied agriculture at Belgium's UC Louvain, is also scheduled to meet with Chen Hsi-huang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, for discussions on agricultural cooperation between the two countries.
The Haitian president is also scheduled to visit several agricultural and aquacultural establishments around Taiwan during his stay, MOFA officials said.
The ROC has maintained close and cordial relations with Haiti over the past four decades since the two countries forged formal ties in 1956, MOFA officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN INVEST OVER US$ 24.5 B. IN MAINLAND: CBC

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen have invested more than US$24.5 billion in mainland China, said Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Pai-nan on Monday while fielding questions in the Finance Committee of the Legislative Yuan.

Legislator Lin Wen-lang of the Democratic Progressive Party said that the nation's trade surplus has shown negative growth and that its foreign currency reserves in September were down by more than US$1.3 billion, showing a serious capital flight from the nation, which he said is related to Taiwan businessmen's investments in the mainland.

Perng said Taiwan's trade surplus in the first nine months of this year totaled US$4.6 billion, down from last year's figure, mainly because of rising oil prices. In addition, citizens of Taiwan spent US$7 billion annually on overseas tourism.

Perng said official statistics from the mainland show that Taiwan businessmen have invested US$24.5 billion, but he noted that many businessmen, trying to evade taxes, invested indirectly via the Virgin Islands, so he estimated the actual amount is higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA MOVING TO LIFT SANCTIONS AGAINST YUGOSLAVIA

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Monday declared that Australia will lift sanctions against Yugoslavia, while demanding that former President Slobodan Milosevic quit politics and appear before the International War Crimes Tribunal to face war crimes charges.

In a statement faxed to the CNA on Monday morning, Downer said "I warmly welcome the fact that Slobodan Milosevic has publicly acknowledged the victory of Dr. Vojislav Kostunica in the Yugoslav presidential elections held on September 24. Dr. Kostunica and the people of Yugoslavia are to be congratulated for their courage and determination in returning their country to democracy."

"Australia looks forward to building closer ties with Yugoslavia, particularly bearing in mind the significant Yugoslav community in Australia. Australia will be moving to lift sanctions against Yugoslavia, consistent with steps taken by the European Union and the United States," he said.

"President Milosevic must not play any further role in Yugoslav political life and must appear before the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague to answer the charges of war crimes against him," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATHENS SHOWS LITTLE INTEREST IN HOSTING 2004 PARALYMPICS

TEXT.P: The International Paralympic Committee (IPC) is making a last-ditch effort to persuade Athens to host the 2004 Paralympic Games despite the minimal interest shown by Greek organizers.
Robert Steadward, the IPC of Canada president, told The Australian on Sunday that the Greek organizers still have not signed any contract with the committee to host the Paralympic Games in 2004.
He said the IPC was having serious concerns about Athens hosting the Paralympic Games immediately after the conclusion of the 2004 Olympic Games.
Steadward said he already expressed these concerns to the Greek sports minister who promised to raise the issue this week with Prime Minister Konstantinos Simitis.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HAS NO ROLE IN ROC'S NUCLEAR POWER PLANT DECISION: AIT

TEXT.P: The U.S. representative office in the Republic of China issued a press statement Monday to clarify its view on the current debate in Taiwan over whether to continue or cease construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant.
The Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan first stressed that whether or not to continue construction of the Lungmen nuclear power plant is a decision for the Taiwan authorities to make.

The AIT went on to say that the major U.S. concern is that contract provisions that have been agreed upon are fulfilled in either case, whether the construction of the power plant is continued or is halted.

Noting that there have been regular exchanges and visits between U.S. and Taiwan experts on nuclear energy for many years, including on issues related to handling and disposing of nuclear wastes, the AIT press release said there is no linkage between the recent visit of a U.S. nuclear waste expert and the construction of the controversial Lungmen nuclear power plant.
The statement also said the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission has certified the design of the type of reactor being incorporated into the Lungmen plant as safe for construction in the United States.

The controversy surrounding the fourth nuclear power plant has recently led to the resignation of Tang Fei from the premiership, and there has been speculation that the Clinton administration is pressuring the ROC's Democratic Progressive Party-led government to uphold the project.

The latest AIT statement was aimed at clarifying the speculation. Meanwhile, Ou-Yang Min-sheng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council, also denied reports that the U.S. government is either pressuring or lobbying the ROC government to continue construction of the Lungmen nuclear power plant.

Ou-Yang further said the main purpose of the recent visit to Taipei of a U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission delegation was to promote cooperation in nuclear energy technology and safety and had nothing to do with the fate of the fourth nuclear power plant project.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY INTELLIGENCE BUREAU DENIES POLITICAL SURVEILLANCE AT HOME

TEXT.P: The Military Intelligence Bureau on Monday categorically denied that it has conducted political surveillance domestically, saying that the MIB has only done intelligence work directed at mainland China.
MIB officials made the denial after the bureau was accused by People First Party Legislator Chin Huei-chu of conducting political surveillance in Taiwan in the name of safeguarding national security.

The officials stressed that it is not the MIB's job or responsibility to conduct political surveillance within Taiwan, noting that there has of course been no reason to wiretap any Taiwan individual or organization's phones.

They said that in the bureau's early days when the international and cross-strait situations were different and the burea's special missions were different from today's, all the bureau's internal phones were equipped with recording devices. But the practice was scrapped in recent years, they stressed.

MIB Director Hsu Chu-sheng, in an interview with CNA reporters the other day, also made it clear that the MIB has not and will not conduct political surveillance in Taiwan and will only conduct intelligence work aimed at mainland China.
At Monday's press conference, Legislator Chin urged the National Security Bureau not to only declare the suspension of political surveillance by the Ministry of Justice Bureau of Investigation.

She said if the government is indeed to suspend all political surveillance in Taiwan once and for all, all related agencies, including the Military Intelligence Bureau, the Military Police Headquarters, the Maritime Police Administration, and the National Police Administration, should all be ordered to stop with the secret surveillance business.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRONICS 2000 INT'L ELECTRONICS SHOW OPENS MONDAY

TEXT.P: The TAITRONICS 2000 Components & Equipment Taipei International Electronics Show opened Monday at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) Exhibition Hall.

The event, organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, will continue until Oct. 13 at the main TWTC Exhibition Hall and the Exhibition Hall II.

The show is featuring 944 exhibitors with 2,091 booths divided into sections on Meters & Instruments, Electronic Parts and Components, Foreign Products, Media, Electronics Manufacturing Equipment, Inspection Equipment, and Wires and Cables.
TAITRONICS 2000, the 25th event of its kind, enjoys international fame and attracts many foreign companies from the U.S., Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong, and South Korea to participate in the big event.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar fell NT$0.008 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 31.301.
The local currency opened Monday at 31.283 and was traded between 31.283 and 31.305.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$297 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER STATES OPTIONS DEALING WITH POSSIBLE SCRAPPING OF NUKE PLANT

TEXT.P: The state-owned Taiwan Power Company said Monday that losses resulting from the scrapping of the fourth nuclear power plant could hit NT$90 billion (US$2.87 billion).

In the wake of the Ministry of Economic Affairs suggestion that the controversial project be scrapped, Taipower has begun an assessment of the projected losses from the halting of the project and also of the options for dealing with such a decision.

Taipower said that General Electric Company of the United States won the bid to build the reactors for the proposed power plant in Kungliao, Taipei County, in 1995. The reactors are scheduled to be shipped to Taiwan next year.
GE has said that after it receives official notification of the project's termination, it will begin to draw up a compensation list regarding Taipower's breach of contract.
Taipower has estimated that construction on the nuclear power plant is already one third complete and that the money already spent on the project has reached US$48.5 billion.

Taipower, which will shoulder all losses resulting from a termination of the power plant project, said that options it is considering include raising electricity fees or drawing a part of its targeted annual surplus every year to make up for the losses.

Taipower stressed that the people will suffer under the implementation of either option, pointing out that this year's targeted surplus is NT$54 billion (US$1.72 billion), and if NT$10 billion is drawn, then this will mean that the national coffers will be short NT$10 billion. It added that if electricity fees are hiked, this will certainly have a direct impact on the general public.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER BACKS REFERENDUM ON NUCLEAR POWER PLANT PROJECT

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Chang Po-ya Monday threw her support behind the proposal that a plebiscite be held to decide the fate of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant.
Chang gave a thumbs-up to the proposal in response to an interpellation by ruling Democratic Progress Party Legislator Lee Chun-yi at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting.
Lee asked Chang whether she backs continued construction of the fourth nuclear power plant and whether she supports the holding of a plebiscite to resolve the controversy surrounding the project.
In reply, Chang said the time is still not right for her to express her personal view on the issue because the Cabinet has not yet formally discussed the project.

As for the "plebiscite" proposal, Chang said she feels that the measure may be able to provide a solution to this thorny issue. "As the government and major opposition parties have been unable to come to terms on whether to continue or scrap the project, a plebiscite can probably help free the government from its current plight," the minister noted.

Meanwhile, Chang said the Ministry of the Interior is drafting a referendum bill. "The ministry is still mulling which issues can be decided by a referendum and how a referendum vote will be held," she explained.
In view of the urgency of the issue, Chang suggested that the government immediately form a "serious dispute commission" to handle the contentious fourth nuclear power plant project.
Chang said the proposed commission can be authorized to host a series of public hearings to help the general public fully understand the pros and cons of the project before a referendum vote is held.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA SIGNS NEWS EXCHANGE AGREEMENT WITH MACEDONIAN INFO AGENCY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Central News Agency signed an agreement with the Macedonian Information Agency Monday to exchange news and other services.
CNA President Bill Wang and MIA President Zivko Georgievski signed the agreement on behalf of the two organizations at CNA's head office in Taipei.

Under the agreement, the two news agencies will supply English-language news items as well as photographs for distribution to each other's subscribers. The two wire services will also engage in journalistic exchanges, including co-sponsoring activities to promote professionalism.

Speaking at the signing ceremony, Wang noted that the two news organizations had actually started cooperating last year. In June 1999, when the Macedonian prime minister came to Taipei, CNA supplied MIA with news pictures about his visit. When ROC officials later visited Macedonia, MIA returned the favor by assisting CNA reporters with their coverage of the visit.
Wang promised that CNA will do its best to provide whatever services its Macedonian partner needs.

Georgievski said that his agency, established by parliamentary edict in 1992, is very happy and proud to cooperate with CNA because of its long history. "We can show to the rest of the world and our neighbors how we can work together," he said.

Ms. Vera Modanu, minister of the Macedonian Embassy who was invited as a special guest to witness the ceremony, expressed confidence that the agreement will enhance understanding and friendship between the two nations.

P.N. Chang, deputy director-general of the ROC Government Information Office, was also present at the ceremony. He pointed out that the ROC has initiated a number of projects to help Macedonia improve its economy, but added that the projects have not been publicized very well and are not widely understood.
Chang said he believes the news exchange agreement will improve mutual understanding between the two countries.
The Central News Agency was founded in 1924. It now has over 400 employees with correspondents stationed in some 30 major cities around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER CHAIRS CABINET FINANCIAL MEETING

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lai In-jaw said Monday local stock investment trust and consulting firms as well as banks which have been authorized to operate trust business will be allowed to engage in stock investment activities on behalf of clients.

Lai made the announcement after chairing a meeting of the Cabinet's special financial and economic task force, which was formed Aug. 25 to streamline government management of financial and economic affairs.

If all goes smoothly, Lai said, the Ministry of Finance will begin to accept applications by stock investment trust and consulting firms and banks on Oct. 11 for operating stock investment deals on behalf on their clients.
Lai said as individual investors form the bulk of Taiwan's stock investors, the new measure will help change the domestic stock market structure and thus increase market stability.

Moreover, Lai said, the task force has directed the finance ministry to push for an early passage of a bill aimed at allowing financial institutions to merge among themselves to facilitate Taiwan's financial globalization and upgrading of local banks' competitiveness in the world financial service market.

Lai said the finance ministry will also propose revisions to the current income tax law to allow merged banks to write off debts under certain conditions in order to encourage merger among local banks.

The task force was originally headed by the premier. From now on, the panel will be headed by Vice Premier Lai. Meanwhile, the task force will have two new members -- Minister-without-Portfolio Chung Chin and Lin Chia-cheng, chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.

Other members of the panel include Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan, Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and Lin Chuan, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics. (BY Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WARNS OF PARTY DISCIPLINE IF ECON. MINISTER GOES ANTI-NUCLEAR

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang will take party disciplinary action on Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, a KMT member, if he insists on suspending construction of the fourth nuclear power plant, KMT Secretary General Lin Feng-cheng said Monday.

Lin Feng-cheng said at a press conference that KMT policy is consistent in its support of resuming construction of the fourth nuclear power plant. He added that as a KMT member, the economics minister must support the KMT's pro-nuclear policy or else face party discipline.
Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, also a KMT member, stressed his support for completing the fourth nuclear power plant Sunday, citing national security concerns.

Lin Feng-cheng indicated that completing the fourth nuclear power plant would be very beneficial to the people of Taiwan and the island's economic development. As this is the KMT's policy, he warned that any KMT member in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-led Cabinet who fails to support the party's platform will be subject to party discipline.

However, he said that since construction of the fourth nuclear power plant has not yet been canceled, the KMT will closely watch the economics minister's actions on the issue before deciding whether to impose party discipline on the minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7,000-PLUS OVERSEAS CHINESE RETURN FOR NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: An estimated 7,000 overseas Chinese have returned for the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations this year, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission said Monday.
The number marks a nearly 50 percent decrease from the number of returnees three years ago, according to official tallies.

Following the island's first-ever transition of the Presidency from the long-ruling Kuomintang to the relatively youthful Democratic Progressive Party in May, different faces can be seen among the returning overseas Chinese.
OCAC officials said a number of Taiwanese expatriate organizations have organized delegations to return to Taiwan to celebrate National Day for the first time this year.
According to OCAC officials, the number of returning Taiwan-born expatriates is roughly the same as that of elderly overseas Chinese, most of whom moved abroad directly from mainland China.
OCAC officials attributed the decline in the number of returning expatriates in part to the fact that many overseas Chinese already attended the May 20 inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian.

The number of overseas Chinese returning for the Double Ten celebrations once reached a high of more than 20,000, but the figure has been in a steady decline in recent years, partly because of mainland China's intensified efforts to woo older-generation overseas Chinese by returning confiscated real estate and other assets to them, OCAC officials said.

Another reason is the change in Taiwan's domestic political situation, OCAC officials said. Because of the government's budget problems, the OCAC has earmarked only NT$5 million (US$161,290) for receiving overseas Chinese this year, compared to the nearly NT$100 million that mainland China spent for the same purpose during its Oct. 1 National Day celebrations.

Overseas Chinese sources said Taiwan's domestic political uncertainty under the DPP administration and the devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999 have also discouraged overseas Chinese from returning for National Day celebrations.

Meanwhile, the sources said, an increasing number of elderly overseas Chinese are now willing to attend celebrations of both the ROC and PRC National Days in their resident countries. In the past, most elderly overseas Chinese would only take part in celebrations marking the ROC's Oct. 10 National Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG CATHOLIC GROUPS PROHIBITED FROM GOING TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Priests and other members of the clergy in Catholic churches in Hong Kong have been prohibited from teaching or conducting religious activities in mainland China.

Joseph Zen Zekiun, a Catholic church bishop, said in an interview published Monday in the Sing Tao Daily News of Hong Kong that the ban followed the Vatican canonization of 120 missionary martyrs on Oct. 1. China permitted Hong Kong's Catholic groups to preach and teach in certain places in China before the canonization, which antagonized Beijing.

He believed that the Chinese authorities do not want Catholic churches in Hong Kong to have any kind of contact with their counterparts in China before the dispute over canonization is settled, and that the ban is only temporary.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT PRAISES OVERSEAS CHINESE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Monday expressed his gratitude to overseas Chinese for their long-term support of the ROC, and urged them to continue contributing to Taiwan.
Chen made the remarks to an assembled group of overseas Chinese in Taiwan to celebrate the ROC's National Day, which falls on Oct. 10.
Chen pointed out that this will be the first National Day celebration since the peaceful transfer of executive power in May.

The president said that despite Taiwan's lack of natural resources, the island is rich in passion and courage. He added that overseas Chinese can help Taiwan by transmitting a good image of the nation to the world community.

Chen noted that despite the current difficult diplomatic situation facing Taiwan, the island's people have not been discouraged from pursuing their dreams. He added that overseas Chinese have always supported Taiwan with real actions, and are a powerful source of strength in difficult times.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA SIGNS AGREEMENT WITH PORTUGAL NEWS AGENCY

TEXT.P: Taipei's Central News Agency recently signed an agreement with the Portugal News Agency to promote news exchanges and mutual understanding among the peoples of both countries.
The agreement was signed by Bill Wang, president of CNA, and Manuel Pedroso Marques, his counterpart at the Portugal News Agency.

Under the agreement, the two agencies will exchange news reports and photographs through the Internet. Both agencies also agreed to extend their cooperation by sharing reports from locations where one service has a correspondent but the other does not.

Pedroso said that the signing of the agreement will not only increase mutual sources of information, but will also help to promote cultural exchanges and economic and trade cooperation between the two countries.

The Portugal News Agency's news network extends throughout the European Union, as well as Brazil, five African countries, Macao and East Timor. It is the largest news agency in the Portuguese-speaking world.
The Central News Agency was founded in 1924. It now has over 400 employees with correspondents stationed in some 30 major cities around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT HOLDS TALKS WITH HAITIAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian held talks with his Haitian counterpart Rene Preval Monday. The ROC president stressed in the meeting that the new administration will honor all the agreements reached between Haiti and the former Kuomintang-led government.
Preval and his wife are in Taipei as the leaders of a Haitian delegation to the ROC's Double-Ten National Day celebrations.
Chen extended his heartfelt welcome to Preval, thanking him for coming so far for the National Day celebrations.

He also expressed his appreciation to the Haitian government and people for their long-standing support of the ROC, especially in its bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.

Chen said that he believes the peoples of the two countries share a common aspiration for freedom and peace, noting that he and Vice President Annette Lu have both been political prisoners, while Preval lived in exile in the United States for 10 years.

He told Preval that his new government will honor all agreements and cooperation projects pledged by the ROC government in the past, and added that Preval's Taiwan visit will certainly strengthen bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
In response, Preval voiced his gratitude for the warm hospitality accorded him by the ROC government, and expressed his appreciation for Taipei's assistance to his country in the past.
He said that Haiti will learn from Taiwan's experience in development, and went on to affirm his nation's continuing support of the ROC in the international community.
Chen's wife and several ranking ROC government officials were also present at the meeting, including Vice President Lu, Presidential Secretary-General You Shi-kun and Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG PRACTITIONERS ARRESTED FOR SUING BEIJING LEADERS

TEXT.P: Two practitioners of Falun Gong have been arrested after they took an unprecedented legal action against mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and two other Beijing officials in August for giving orders to crack down on the spiritual movement.

A spokesman for the Falun Gong organization in Hong Kong said Monday at a press conference that the two plaintiffs, Chu Keming and Wang Jie, were arrested on Sept. 7, after they filed a law suit with the Supreme People's Procuratorate in Beijing against the three Beijing leaders. Chu is a Hong Kong resident, while Wang is a mainland Chinese.
The spokesman expressed the hope that leaders of Hong Kong and foreign countries will do something to help secure an early release of the two Falun Gong practitioners.
China outlawed the Falun Gong sect as an "evil cult" and began to crack down on it last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ROC ALLIES MAY ATTEND BEIJING-SPONSORED FORUM

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said Monday that two ROC allies in Africa -- Malawi and Liberia -- may attend the forthcoming "Chinese-African Cooperation Forum" sponsored by Beijing.
Tien told the media that Beijing has sent invitations to the event to all eight ROC allies in Africa, with the apparent intention of luring them away from the ROC.
He said that most have taken Taipei's advice and declined the invitation, but a few still intend to attend the meeting.

Tien disclosed that Malawi will dispatch a delegation to the forum. He added that due to Taipei's urging, Malawi will not send a minister to the forum, as originally scheduled. Instead, the nation will send only a department chief, Tien said.
He added that Liberia may also send a delegation to the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA PLANS TO VISIT TAIWAN NEXT MONTH, SAYS ROC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A ranking Republic of China government official said Monday that Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama will visit Taipei in late November or early December.

Hsu Cheng-kuang, chairman of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, told reporters that the Dalai Lama's exact itinerary is as yet unfixed because of pressure from Beijing and other international factors, but his visit is almost a certainty.
He said that this time, the Dalai Lama will visit Taiwan as a noted international religious leader at the invitation of a local civilian organization.
But he went on to say that the Dalai Lama has said that he would like to meet with former President Lee Teng-hui, and is also likely to hold talks with President Chen Shui-bian.

When asked whether the new government will continue to implement the Kuomintang government's policy on Tibetan affairs, Hsu said that his commission will concentrate on cultural, economic and academic exchanges, rather than on political affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN GUESTS ARRIVE IN TAIPEI TO ATTEND NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: Some 500 distinguished guests and nearly 100 foreign news correspondents have converged on Taipei to celebrate the Republic of China's National Day, which falls on Tuesday.

According the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the distinguished guests include Haitian President Rene Preval, Grenadian Premier Keith Mitchell, Macedonian Minister of Justice Dzevdet Nasufi, Malawi Minister of Information Clement Stambuli, and Liberian Minister of Education Evelyn S. Kandakai.

The ministry added that Nicholas Sikkadza Matsebula, speaker of the House of Assembly of Swaziland, and Kathyna Argueta Membreno, Honduran deputy representative in the American States Organization, are also among the visitors.

Additionally, the United States, Switzerland, Colombia, Chile, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, the United Kingdom, Ireland and Turkey have also send delegations to Taipei to attend celebrations of the ROC's National Day, the first since the peaceful transfer of executive power in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMNESTY INT'L CONDEMNS S. KOREA'S DENIAL OF ENTRY VISA FOR WANG DAN
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chiang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The South Korean chapter of Amnesty International condemned the South Korean government Monday for its denial of an entry visa for Wang Dan, a leader of China's democracy movement.

The local chapter of the worldwide human rights group said in a statement that the South Korean government's action was akin to abandoning human rights and South Korea's own national sovereignty in order to flatter a great power. The statement urged the South Korean authorities to change its policy and unconditionally allow Wang Dan to enter the country.
The statement pointed out that Wang Dan is not only a world-renowned symbol of China's democracy movement, but also a representative of the world human rights movement.

Amnesty International added that its members will exhort world leaders at the third Asian-European Summit to pay more than just lip service to issue of democracy in China. The Third Asian-European Summit is scheduled to be held in Seoul on Oct. 20-21, and the group decided to invite Wang Dan to attend a series of activities accompanying the meeting of the leaders of Asia and Europe.

The statement stressed that by yielding to political pressure from Beijing, the South Korean government has not only denied an entry visa for Wang Dan, but has also run roughshod over the will of the citizens of South Korea.
Mainland China Premier Zhu Rongji will arrive in Korea on Oct. 17 to attend the summit meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES DECORATION FROM HAITIAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and his wife hosted a state banquet in honor of Haitian President Rene Preval and his wife at Taipei's Grand Hotel Monday evening.
Preval and his wife are in Taipei as the leaders of a Haitian delegation to the ROC's Double-Ten National Day celebrations.
Chen expressed his welcome to Preval for coming to Taipei for National Day celebrations, and received a Haitian golden decoration from Preval.

Earlier in the day, Chen held official talks with his Haitian counterpart, during which he expressed his appreciation to the Haitian government and people for their long-standing support of the ROC, especially in its bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.

Chen said that he believes the peoples of the two countries share a common aspiration for freedom and peace, noting that he and Vice President Annette Lu have both been political prisoners, while Preval lived in exile in the United States for 10 years.

He told Preval that his new government will honor all agreements and cooperation projects pledged by the ROC government in the past, and added that Preval's Taiwan visit will certainly strengthen bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
In response, Preval voiced his gratitude for the warm hospitality accorded him by the ROC government, and expressed his appreciation for Taipei's assistance to his country in the past.
He said that Haiti will learn from Taiwan's experience in development, and went on to affirm his nation's continuing support of the ROC in the international community.

Chen's wife and several ranking ROC government officials were also present at the earlier meeting, including Vice President Lu, Presidential Secretary-General You Shi-kun and Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WATCHING TO DETERMINE SOLOMON FOREIGN MINISTER'S WHEREABOUTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday that it is watching closely to determine the whereabouts of Solomon Islands Foreign Minister Denny Philip, who had been due to arrive in Taipei last Friday to attend the Republic of China's National Day on Oct. 10.

Commenting on Philip's absence at a ministry reception to welcome foreign journalists, ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said that he was indeed surprised by Philip's failure to appear on the eve of ROC National Day, adding that his ministry has maintained close contact with Solomon authorities.
Tien quoted a foreign news wire service as saying the Solomon Islands government announced Monday that its foreign minister postponed a trip to Taipei because of political uncertainty in Taiwan.

Former ROC Premier Tang Fei suddenly offered his resignation last Tuesday, which sent shock waves through the island's political circles. Although Tang cited poor health conditions as a reason for his resignation, it is widely thought that the true reason was that his pro-nuclear power stance conflicted with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's anti-nuclear platform. Tang is a member of the opposition Kuomintang.

Since June this year, conflict among ethnic groups has flared in the Solomon Islands. Although talks are being held at an Australian military base in northeastern Australia, the South Pacific nation's political situation is still very tense.

Asked whether the current political situation in the Solomons will provide mainland China with an opportunity to persuade authorities there to shift the island nation's diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, Tien was reluctant to make a reply. He said only that all ROC embassies and representative offices abroad are actively collecting information on the issue.

Foreign news media also reported that Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare said the Solomon government is awaiting political developments in Taipei before dispatching Philip to open the country's embassy.

The announcement appeared aimed at dispelling rumors that Beijing is offering Solomon Islands financial aid in return for withdrawing its diplomatic recognition from Taipei, according to the foreign news wire reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER CALMS DISPUTE OVER CHINESE ROMANIZATION SYSTEMS

TEXT.P: Education Minister Ovid Tseng promised Monday to present a Mandarin Chinese romanization system used in mainland China along with a system developed by a local scholar to the Cabinet to make a final choice.
The scholar-turned minister made the comment in an attempt to calm the dispute currently pitting Taipei City Government against an expert commission under the ministry.

Tseng said that as head of the Education Ministry, he has to respect the conclusion of the National Language Promotion Commission, which recommended the use of the Tongyong system, which was developed locally. But he added that as a linguist himself, he prefers Beijing's Hanyu system, now used by Taipei City on its street signs.

The problem stems from the previous government's demand in the late 1990s for a modern, standardized Romanization system to help foreigners pronounce Chinese words as one step in transforming the island into a worldwide business hub.

As a result, the National Language Promotion Commission under the Education Ministry recommended in August 1999 that Taiwan adapt Beijing's Hanyu Pinyin system, on the grounds that it is widely used around the world and is recognized by the United Nations.

Although adopting Beijing's system would be politically difficult for the island in light of its painstaking efforts to distinguish itself as a sovereign entity separate from mainland China, the Cabinet under former Premier Vincent Siew agreed to endorse the plan, but demanded supplementary measures to facilitate its implementation.

Siew and his administration stepped down before the system was officially adopted by the government, and a new panel under the Education Ministry canceled the decision. The panel members argued in favor of the Tongyong System, which was developed by a local scholar from the new National Language Promotion Commission.
They recommended the Tongyong System on the grounds that it accounts for various existing systems used to teach local dialects, whereas the Hanyu system does not.
The panel's decision has caused an outcry from Taipei City Hall, which has already begun changing the capital's road signs according to the Hanyu romanization system.

Lin Chen-hsiou, director of the city's Civil Affairs Bureau, criticized the panel for its "flip-flop" on the issue because of what he called its paranoid fear of being "unified by Beijing" simply by using the same romanization system.

"The romanization system is aimed at helping foreigners to recognize Chinese characters, rather than as an instrument for promoting local dialects." said Lin. "A system unique to Taiwan will only further isolate the island, rather than help it integrate into the world."

While Education Minister Ovid Tseng's promise might ease the dispute to some extent, no conclusion is likely in the near future, since Premier Chang Chun-hsiung made it clear Monday that there is no urgency to decide on the issue. Chang said he would refer whatever recommendation Tseng gives him to an ad hoc commission for in-depth study.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EMPHASIZES 'TAIWAN SPIRIT' IN NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday urged his fellow citizens to strive fearlessly forward on the path of freedom, democracy and human rights.

In his National Day message that was given to the media the day prior to ROC National Day, which falls on Tuesday, Chen said that the role of the Republic of China in the 21st Century should not only be that of a truly democratic nation, but also that of "a protector of peace in the Asia Pacific region" and "an active participant in the international community."

"The political and economic achievements of the 23 million people of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu did not suddenly fall from the sky, but result from the accumulation of the relentless efforts made generation after generation," President said.

"For the past fifty-odd years, we have, on this island of the Pacific Rim, followed in the footprints of our forefathers to create step by step an economic miracle and set the course for our democracy. These demonstrated inherent strengths of Taiwan and its people have thus repeatedly and inevitably attracted attention of the world."

"Beginning from the time when our ancestors sailed from across the sea to Taiwan hundreds of years ago, and running through the blood of all, from the indigenous people to the frontierless e-generation, the Taiwan Spirit is shared by all of our 23 million compatriots."

"The Taiwan Spirit originates from the interaction and mutual influence of Han culture and Austronesian islands cultures. It was successfully forged through all of our hardships and dreams. From the shores of the Pacific Ocean to the top of Mount Jade, all the people living on this land spare no effort, wisdom, confidence and hope in order to see the best understanding of this Taiwan Spirit recorded," Chen said.

He said that although people here came from different places and different clans -- including the indigenous peoples and more recently arrived residents -- they are now all merged in the Taiwan Spirit, sharing both their fortunes and mishaps. "No matter if we are called 'Taiwanese', 'Chinese' or 'global citizens', we will not confine our vision of the future nor forget where we stand," the president said.

"'The Taiwan Spirit' will continue to guide and lead us. With this unparalleled confidence, mutual trust and eternal faith, we will create the most spectacular and beautiful Formosa in the 21st Century," the President concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT CHEN SHUI-BIAN'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (I)

TEXT.P: Following is the full text of the Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's National Day message:
Today marks the 89th National Day of the Republic of China. I would like to thank all the distinguished guests and overseas Chinese who have come from afar to share with us this solemn moment of joy.

During the almost one hundred years of the history of the Republic of China, from establishing the nation to modernization and democratization, none of the achievements it made came about without our having to overcome many obstacles and difficulties. Success through each stage did not depend on the strength of any single individual or group, but rather came as a result of the awakening of the whole society and the resolve of the entire people.

Likewise, the political and economic achievements of the 23 million people of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu today did not suddenly fall from the sky, but result from the accumulation of the relentless efforts made generation after generation. For the past fifty-odd years, we have, on this island of the Pacific Rim, followed in the footprints of our forefathers to create step by step an economic miracle and set the course for our democracy. These demonstrated inherent strengths of Taiwan and its people have thus repeatedly and inevitably attracted the attention of the world.

We have successfully gone through the stages of hard-won economic development and difficult democratic reform. The Taiwan Experience of the past half century should gave us much confidence. Beginning from the time when our ancestors sailed from across the sea to Taiwan hundreds of years ago, and running through the blood of all, from the indigenous peoples to the frontierless e-generation, the Taiwan Spirit is shared by all of our 23 million compatriots.

The Taiwan Spirit originates from the interaction and mutual influence of Han culture and Austronesian islands cultures. It was successfully forged through all of our hardships and dreams. From the shores of the Pacific Ocean to the top of Mount Jade, all the people living on this land spare no effort, wisdom, confidence and hope in order to see the best understanding of this Taiwan Spirit recorded. Although we came from different places, and although there were once differences between the Hoklos, the Hakkas, the indigenous peoples and more recently arrived residents, we are now all merged in the Taiwan Spirit, sharing both our fortunes and mishaps. No matter if we are called "Taiwanese", "Chinese" or "global citizens", we will not confine our vision of the future nor forget where we stand.

Me dear fellow countrymen, in the last year of the 20th century, the people of Taiwan completed the first alternation of political parties in power of our history. We are confident that the future will prove that peaceful transition of political power does not simply mean win or loss for any individual or political party. Rather, it is a victory for all people and a victory of democracy. Building on this glorious foundation, we cannot but have more confidence in ourselves in facing the new century. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT CHEN SHUI-BIAN'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (II)

TEXT.P: As we constitute a new paradigm of democracy for all Chinese societies, we should fearlessly strive to move forward on the path of freedom, democracy and human rights. Yet the role of the Republic of China in the 21st Century should not only be that of "the realizer of democracy", but also that of "a protector of peace in the Asia Pacific" and "an active participant in the international community".

In facing the new political scene after the first alteration of political parties in power, we are a bit like the patient after surgery, in need of growing new bone tissue and blood, while at the same time we face both internal and external challenges.

Since May 20 in order to seek the greatest welfare of the people, yet in a very short time, we cautiously but vigorously worked on stabilizing the situation across the Taiwan Strait, preserving our national security, expanding our international space, and weeding out corruption while at the same time promoting good virtues. As a newly established government, we are keenly aware that there are still many things to be improved. I myself, the national leader, as well as all members of the new administration should exercise some self-examination and remain alert all the time. Meanwhile, we would like to once again sincerely plead with all political parties, both ruling and opposition, that they jointly uphold the common ideals of "national interest first, people's welfare first".

The Amis indigenous people of eastern Taiwan hold the belief that the oceans, the rivers, the land, the fruit trees and mothers are the "breeders" of all that is in the universe. They are supreme and cannot be profaned. Pondering carefully and feeling with our hearts the significance of this belief, we can see that it contains the idea of creation, nourishment and tolerance. It is a warm and touching symbolism, which contains no sense of antagonism or hatred. If all things in the universe can thus be created, then why can it not be so for our national future? Reflecting upon the spirit of our ancestors when they crossed the Taiwan Strait from Tangshan, apart from learning from their adventurous courage and creativity, we should always remember the virtues of self-confidence, trust in fellow countrymen, and faith in the land. These are the most solid foundations upon which to build our home.

My dear fellow countrymen, as we celebrate together the founding day of the Republic of China both at home and abroad, we should ponder solemnly upon the common destiny of the 23 million people in Taiwan. Although Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu are only tiny islands in the Pacific, our morale has never been daunted and our vision has never been blocked. "The Taiwan Spirit" will continue to guide and lead us. With this unparalleled confidence, mutual trust and eternal faith, we will create the most spectacular and beautiful Formosa in the 21st Century!
I wish prosperity to the Republic of China and good health and happiness to all of citizens and all of the distinguished guest. Thank you!
