DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 10, or the 13th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1911: A revolt against the Manchu (Ching) dynasty erupts in Wuchang and is followed by revolutionary activities throughout China. The government of the Republic of China formally announces on Sept. 28 that October 10 is henceforth to be observed as ROC National Day in commemoration of the Wuchang Uprising, which led to the establishment of the ROC on Jan. 1, 1912.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, who forced the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China on Oct. 6, formally assumes the Presidency.
1919: The Chung-hua ke-ming tang (Chinese Revolutionary Party) is reorganized by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as the Chung-kuo kuo-min tang (the KMT, also known as the Nationalist Party).
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes the writing of "Plans for Industrial Development."
1925: The National Palace Museum is inaugurated in Peiping (now Beijing).
1928: Chiang Kai-shek assumes the chairmanship of the National Government in Nanking.
1934: The main forces of the Chinese communist troops flee northwest from their bases in Kiangsi, starting their so-called "Long March."
1942: The U.S. and U.K. governments announce their intention to relinquish extraterritoriality and related rights in China.
1943: Chiang Kai-shek is sworn in as chairman of the National Government.
1954: Ho Chi Minh returns to Hanoi as the French evacuate.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down five mainland MiG-17 fighters and damages two more off the mainland coast, losing one Saber jet in the battle.
1962: Taiwan Television Enterprise, Ltd., the first commercial television station in the Republic of China, goes into operation.
1970: Fiji, a British colony in the southern Pacific sine 1874, becomes an independent member of the Commonwealth.
1973: Spiro Agnew, 54, twice chosen by President Richard Nixon to be his vice president, resigns before appearing in a federal district court in Baltimore to face charges of income tax evasion.
1974: A mass rally of 250,000 celebrate the 63rd anniversary of the Republic of China.
1975: A military parade of 35,000 members of the Armed Forces and reserves highlight the observance of the 64th National Day of the Republic of China, with more than 13,000 overseas Chinese and foreign dignitaries join in the celebration.
1976: A quarter of a million people assemble in the Presidential Square for National Day ceremonies with more than 15,000 overseas Chinese from over 50 countries and areas taking part in events marking the 65th anniverary of the Republic of China.
1978: More than 12,000 members of the Chinese armed forces brave driving rains to stage the largest military parade in many years during National Day celebrations.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo accepts the people's gift of 18 F5E jet fighters with a pledge to recover the mainland at a huge rally attended by 250,000 people to mark the Double Ten National Day.
1980: A strong earthquake rocks Algeria, killing more than 12,500 people.
1986: An estimated 250 thousand people gather before the Presidential Building to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Republic of China. President Chiang Ching-kuo addresses the nation in person, promising that the ROC will accomplish his ultimate objective of reunifying China.
1993: An overloaded ferry capsizes off the coast of Pusan, in southern South Korea, killing 292.
1997: The International Campaign to Ban Landmines and American Campaign coordinator Jodie Williams win the Nobel Peace Prize.
1999: On behalf of the government and people of the Republic of China, Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese community leaders from around the world for their patriotic deeds and generous donations after the Sept. 21 earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND TO EASE IMMIGRATION RULES

TEXT.P: New Zealand's government has indicated that it will ease immigration rules in a bid to counter the effects of the increasing exodus of Kiwis out of the country, reported the Australian on Tuesday.

The daily quoted Immigration Minister Lianane Dalziel as signaling plans to lower the NZ$1 million (US$450,000) investment threshold by NZ$250,000 (US$112,500) to lure more wealthy immigrants to the country as more and more New Zealanders move abroad, mainly to Australia, as a result of weakening economic growth.
In the year to August, more than 72,000 New Zealanders left their country, with over half of that number moving to Australia, the daily reported.

The government of New Zealand will also increase its annual immigration quota from 38,000 to 42,000 in the current year while at the same time making it easier for foreigners to gain permanent residency, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FM SAYS SOLOMON ISLANDS ON BRINK OF DISINTIGRATION

TEXT.P: Australia's Foreign Minister Alexander Downer told Parliament on Monday that the Solomon Islands lies on the brink of social and economic disintegration.

He stressed the importance of the peace talks that are scheduled to begin on Tuesday in Townsville, Queensland. A total of 130 delegates from the South Pacific country have come to Australia to take part in the talks.

Moore told Parliament that arson attacks, intimidation, assault and death threats have been constantly occurring in the nation's capital Honiara in the three months since an armed takeover of the government by the Malaita Eagle Force and elements of the nation's police force on June 5.
Downer stressed that the success of the peace talks lies entirely in the hands of the Solomon Islands' own people.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY POLICE DENIES ROLE IN POLITICAL SURVEILLANCE

TEXT.P: The Military Police Headquarters solemnly clarified its role in the national security/intelligence operation system Tuesday, saying it has never been authorized to conduct political surveillance.

The headquarters issued the statement after opposition People First Party Legislator Chin Huei-chu claimed on Monday that the MPH is among a list of government agencies responsible for politically motivated surveillance of activities of opposition parties and their leading figures.

Noting that the MPH forms an integral part of the Republic of China's national security/intelligence operation system, the headquarters said it has focused on special service security survey and military security survey.

The MPH further said it has been performing its duties under the guidance and coordination of the General Staff Headquarters under the Ministry of National Defense and the National Security Bureau under the Presidential Office.

"In our overall national security/intelligence operation system, the MPH has not been charged with the mission of political situation survey," an MPH spokesman said, adding that military police have never gotten involved in the so-called political surveillance work.

The spokesman went on to say that the MPH will continue to carry out its official duties in line with the principles of "military nationalization, administrative neutrality and rule of law" in the future.

At a Monday press conference, Legislator Chin pushed the National Security Bureau not to only free the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) from the controversial political surveillance job, also known as "white terror" political persecution tactics initiated by the previous Kuomintang government.

Chin said if the new Democratic Progressive Party-led government is indeed to phase out the decades-old "white terror" tactics against opposition politicians once and for all, all other related agencies, including the Military Intelligence Bureau, the Military Police Headquarters, the Maritime Police Administration, and the National Police Administration, should also be allowed to halt the secret political surveillance operations.

Under heavy pressure from opposition parties and protest of reform-minded MJIB agents, the National Security Bureau and the Ministry of Justice have recently reached a consensus on freeing the MJIB from the controversial political surveillance work.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE DEFENSE MINISTER PROPOSES DEFENSE SPENDING INCREASE

TEXT.P: Australia's Defence Minister John Moore has proposed a significant increase in defense spending in order to upgrade the country's military.

Moore wants to use the increased funds to buy new destroyers, upgrade the air force's F/A-18 Hornet fighter jets and the air defense systems on eight frigates, and replace combat systems in six Collins class submarines.
He told reporters Tuesday that defense spending would be increased by 3 percent in 2001, the first increase of its kind in about two decades for Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CELEBRATES 89TH NATIONAL DAY AMID FANFARE

TEXT.P: Thousands of cheerleaders, honor guards, dragon dancers, and performers from different walks of life joined tens of thousands of onlookers in front of the presidential office Tuesday to celebrate the Republic of China's 89th National Day.

Amidst hails of "long live freedom and democracy," "long live the people of Taiwan," and "long live the Republic of China" following President Chen Shui-bian's lead, the festivities kicked into high gear, beginning with the crowd's all-time favorites -- the rifle drill performances by the tri-service military and Taipei Municipal First Girls' Senior High School honor guards.

This year's "Double Ten" celebration was the first for the new Democratic Progressive Party government, which came into power May 20 after over five decades of rule by the Kuomintang. Last year's National Day celebration was canceled while the government concentrated its resources on post-disaster relief efforts after the killer earthquake that struck Taiwan on Sept. 21.

In a gesture to illustrate the new administration's affirmation of a pluralistic society, this year's event organizers balanced such traditional numbers as dragon dances and rifle drills with crowd-pleasers like an aboriginal dance performed to the beat of uplifting percussion and a parade of cross-country racing motorcycles, touring sedans, and all-terrain dune rovers.

President Chen said in his address that the 23 million people of Taiwan have spared no effort, wisdom, confidence, and hope in attaining the "Taiwan spirit." He added that this spirit will continue to lead the people of Taiwan to create a better Formosa in the 21st century.

Four selected college students recited an ode to the ROC's National Day using the four primary dialects of the people of Taiwan -- Mandarin Chinese, Fukienese, Hakka, and an aboriginal tongue -- instead of the manifesto that had traditionally been recited by a single youth representative in one language.
The mostly foreign imported music used during previous National Day festivities was replaced by local music, which made up about 75 percent of this year's musical numbers and background music.

An official tally put the total number of performers at this year's hour-long celebration at 3,074, while the number of local spectators, returning overseas Chinese, and foreign guests reached the 26,000 mark.

Similar festivities took place in towns and cities around the island as people celebrated the 89th year of the Republic of China, which was founded in 1912. Fireworks are expected to grace Taiwan's skies in the evening, with the largest pyrotechnic display scheduled to be held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Later in the afternoon, ROC Vice President Annette Lu is expected to join the crowd at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to watch Peking operas, lion dances, and other cooperative performances that seek to integrate the cultures of Taiwan's different ethnic groups.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is scheduled to host a National Day banquet at the Taipei Guest House in the evening to entertain foreign dignitaries, while a gala for the public will be held in the meantime at Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, a landmark that was built to honor the memory of the founder of the Republic of China and the father of the nation, Dr. Sun Yat-sen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGES RESTART OF CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE IN NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday again urged leaders on the other side of the Taiwan Strait to set aside differences and resume dialogue with Taiwan so as to break the current deadlock and achieve a "win-win" situation.

The president made the remarks while addressing more than 400 central and local government officials, elected representatives, and overseas Chinese representatives at the Presidential Office to mark the Republic of China's National Day.

President Chen said the government is sincere in seeking "goodwill reconciliation, active cooperation, and long-lasting peace," and he called on the leaders of mainland China to join us in returning to the spirit of 1992," putting aside disputes and resuming dialogue and exchanges as soon as possible."
But the president also reiterated the position that "the resolution of cross-strait issues and the future of Taiwan must respect the will of the 23 million people of Taiwan."

Now that the emotional heat generated by the election campaign has subsided, he said the nation faces not "only the serious ills and corrupt practices left by the past authoritarian regime, but also the verbal attacks and military threat from the Chinese mainland, which serve to put the wisdom of the new government to a serious test."

President Chen said that maintaining a stable, peaceful, and secure environment has become the top priority of the new government, adding that "if we cannot immediately ease cross-strait tensions, strengthen our diplomatic front, and boost the morale of our armed forces, it will be impossible for us to implement various domestic reforms."
He also said that the new government "based on the solid foundation that has been laid, has committed itself to a series of reforms that will instill the nation with uplifting energy."

The president then received 264 foreign dignitaries, including Haitian President Rene Preval, foreign diplomatic corps, and foreign media heads who had come to attend the "Double Ten Day" festivities.
Chen later addressed a rally of more than 26,000 people in front of the Presidential Office. The theme of his speech revolved around the notion of the "Taiwan spirit."

He said that although the people of Taiwan have come from different places and although there were once differences between the Hoklos, the Hakkas, the indigenous peoples, and the more recent arrivals to the island, the 23 million people of Taiwan "are now all merged in the Taiwan spirit, sharing both fortunes and mishaps."

Saying that Taiwan completed the first successful transfer of political power from one party to another in its history, Chen said that "we are confident that the future will prove that peaceful transition of political power does not simply mean victory or loss for any individual party," but instead victory for all the people and for democracy.

He also said that the role of the ROC in the 21th century should not only be that of the achiever of democracy, but also that of "a protector of peace in the Asia-Pacific region and of an active participant in the international community."
At the end of his National Day message, the president led the crowd in shouting "long live democracy," "long live the people of Taiwan," and "long live the Republic of China."

DOC.HEADLINE: MULTIPARTY TASK FORCE ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES TO MEET AGAIN OCT. 14

TEXT.P: The Multiparty Task Force on relations across the Taiwan Strait will meet again Saturday to work out strategy for helping the government break the current cross-strait stalemate.
This will be the task force's second meeting since its formation in August. The 25-member group, headed by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, met for the first time on Sept. 2.

Sources said task force members have proposed more than 80 topics concerning the development of cross-strait relations. The upcoming meeting is expected to map out a list of priorities for discussion.

Among the proposed topics, the issue regarding the so-called "1992 consensus" between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait will be given the priority. SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges.

In addition to discussing principles and directions for the future development of cross-strait ties, sources said, the Multiparty Task Force is also expected to come up with some concrete proposals for forging cross-strait rapprochement.

As the people of Taiwan remain divided over future cross-strait ties, President Chen Shui-bian has appointed Lee, a Nobel laureate, to organize the Multiparty Task Force to help forge a national consensus on the thorny issue.

The task force, composed of representatives from across the political and social spectrum, will serve as President Chen's advisory board in formulating Taiwan's policy and strategy toward mainland China.

As the task force has yet to work out detailed procedural rules, sources said, it still takes a certain period of time before the panel can present concrete recommendations on substantive cross-strait issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT CHEN'S NATIONAL DAY ADDRESS (I)

TEXT.P: Following is the full text of Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's address delivered Tuesday at a Presidential Office ceremony marking the Dorble Ten Naitonal Day: DISTINGUISHED GUESTS, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN
Today is the 89th National Day of the Republic of China. We are solemnly celebrating our country's birthday with thanks, as this year's national day has particular historical significance.

At the end of the 20th century, the 23 million people on Taiwan achieved, with love and courage, the first peaceful transfer of power through a change of ruling parties in the history of the Republic of China or any other Chinese society for that matter. After many years of living under emergency-decree and authoritarian rule in Taiwan, we finally used ballots to proudly announce to the world: "The people in Taiwan now stand up. Taiwan is now part of the worldwide trend of democracy and freedom."

From the very moment of my inauguration as President on May 20, I have felt not a sense of gratification or elation, but a deep sense of responsibility. Now that the emotional heat generated by the election campaign has subsided, we face not only the serious ills and corrupt practices left by the past authoritarian regime, but also the verbal attacks and military threats from the Chinese mainland, which serve to put the wisdom of the new government to a serious test.

Thus, maintaining a stable, peaceful, and secure environment has become the top priority of the new government. If we cannot immediately ease cross-strait tensions, strengthen our diplomatic front, and boost the morale of the armed forces, it will be impossible for us to implement various domestic reforms, because nothing can be achieved without the guarantees of national security and a secure international status.

We fully understand that all our fellow countrymen have high expectations of the new government. The international community is also waiting to see how the new government will ensure peace in the Taiwan Strait. However, no reform can be achieved in no time. Nor can the backlog of encumbrances that has been accumulated for decades be completely cleared in just a few months. Normalizing cross-strait relations also takes greater wisdom and patience.

Over the past five months or so, the new government has been subjected to severe oversight and criticism from citizens and the opposition. We modestly accept advice and make improvements. After the recent adjustments, the new government, with more experience, is leaving the meandering and rugged mountain path behind and moving onto a smooth highway. The government is now ready to launch at full throttle into its very full agenda. We are confident that the new administration will implement various reforms on a planned basis and efficiently.

In light of the international trends and the domestic demand, we must expedite national development projects and meet the expectations of the people. The following reforms and initiatives will be carried out:

Firstly, we must crack down on money politics and corruption, raise government efficiency, improve law and order, speed up judicial reform, implement educational reforms, and establish a partnership between the government and private enterprises. These actions will strengthen our basis for national development as we face an increasingly competitive world. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT CHEN'S NATIONAL DAY ADDRESS (II)

TEXT.P: With regard to economic development, we will keep abreast of the international trend of developing the knowledge-based economy, and use Taiwan's high-tech comparative advantage to realize our goal of turning Taiwan into a "Green Silicon Island." As we are entering the World Trade Organization, we have to help traditional industries initiate necessary changes and upgrading and remove obstacles to foreign investment. They will then be better able to cope with a more liberalized world.

As to social security, we will strengthen our preparations and defenses against natural disasters. We will also eliminate the narrow-minded and self-centered mentality and the habit of passing the buck. We must instead forge a community sense of lending a hand to those who suffer. Lastly, we will guarantee social justice, ensure the rule of law, and safeguard the welfare of the disadvantaged groups so as to establish a safe, stable, and secure society.

In the field of national security, we will upgrade essential military equipment, strengthen civil defense and psywar preparedness, and continue to carry out the military downsizing and enhancement program. Furthermore, as a contributor to regional peace, we support security in the Asia-Pacific region and world peace.

In cross-strait relations, we are sincere and patient in seeking "goodwill reconciliation, active cooperation, and long-lasting peace." We call on the leaders of the other side to join us in returning to the "spirit of 1992", put aside disputes, and resume dialogue and exchange as soon as possible. Thus, we can break the deadlock and achieve a "win-win" situation. Meanwhile, we reiterate our position that the resolution of cross-strait issues and the future of Taiwan must respect the will of the 23 million people in the Taiwan area.

Ladies and gentlemen, during its 89-year history the ROC has experienced an initial period of trials and tribulations, received assistance from foreign nations and become self-reliant, undergone colonial and authoritarian rule, and won worldwide acclamation with an economic miracle. Finally, before the end of the century, Taiwan has accomplished a democratic change of political parties in power, a "political miracle" that gives impetus to our entry into the new century.

Despite a difficult survival amid internal worries and foreign threats, the ROC still stands on its feet and strides forward. This demonstrates the unyielding and unswerving spirit of the people on Taiwan. We can proudly stride forward on the world stage because of our economic and democratic record.

On the threshold of a new era, our new government, based on the solid foundation that has been laid, commits itself to a series of reforms, which will instill uplifting energy into the ROC. At the turn of the century, I sincerely urge all our citizens to place the interests of the nation and our people above those of any political party or individual. Together, we take upon ourselves the lofty duty of enhancing the welfare of our descendants.

On this glorious day, I invite my 23 million compatriots to join me in wishing the Republic of China the best of everything. May the Republic of China enjoy a long and prosperous future and all my compatriots peace and happiness.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE TO VISIT QUAKE-AFFECTED AREAS IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Chang Fu-mei, minister of the Republic of China Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, said Tuesday that she was moved by overseas Chinese who have taken their precious time to return to Taiwan to witness post-earthquake reconstruction efforts in central Taiwan.
Chang made the remarks while hosting a luncheon for representatives of the overseas Chinese community in Taipei.

Chang noted that more than 6,600 overseas Chinese have come to Taiwan this year for National Day festivities, and many are scheduled to visit Nantou County, which bore the brunt of the 7.3-magnitude earthquake that hit Taiwan Sept. 21 last year.

Chang said the commission, in arranging for the visits of overseas Chinese this year, carefully planned their tours to include Nantou County. She added and that she was deeply moved to hear that some of the visiting overseas Chinese had returned especially after learning that they were scheduled to visit the area.

The representatives of overseas Chinese pledged their love and support for the new government. They added that 2000 is a significant year for the Republic of China, because it has seen the first transfer of political power in five decades.

They went on to say that the transition shows the success of Taiwan's long-term democratization. Taiwan has chosen a new administration with new thinking to face the challenges of the new century, they said.

They also stressed that this year saw the first anniversary of the Sept. 21 temblor, and noted that overseas Chinese shared the trauma of residents of the quake-affected areas. They went on to express the hope that reconstruction work can be completed as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY TALKS ABOUT FRIENDLY RELATIONS WITH AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Timothy Yang, director general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Australia, Tuesday talked about the friendly relations between Taiwan and Australia on the occasion of the Republic of China's "Double Tenth" National Day.

Speaking at National Day celebrations in Canberra on Tuesday, Yang said Taiwan looks forward to continuing support from Australians and people from other countries in its endeavors to help maintain peace and security in the Asia-Pacific region.
He said both Australia and Taiwan have a lot in common, including democracy, respect for human rights, and concerns for peace and security in the region.
"We in Taiwan believe in much the same things as do our friends in Australia," he said.
Yang took the opportunity to tell the Australian guests that bilateral trade between Australia and Taiwan has continued to grow and that Taiwan is now the fifth largest export market for Australia.
"The expansion of this burgeoning bilateral trade can only be good for both our countries and is sure to open the way for an improvement in relations in other areas as well," he said.
The economy of Taiwan and Australia are complimentary by their very nature, he pointed out.

"I can tell you of the high reputation for quality that Australian beef, dairy products, and fruit enjoy in my country," he said, adding that Australian consumers are aware of the good quality of Taiwan products.

The "Double Tenth" National Day was celebrated Tuesday not only in Canberra, but also in Sydney and Melbourne as the Taipei Economic and Cultural Offices in both cities entertained Australian and overseas Chinese guests.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DOES NOT RULE OUT UNIFICATION: HSIEH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party does not rule out "unification with mainland China" as an option for Taiwan's future, DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh said in a recent interview with the Voice of America, which was broadcast Friday.
Hsieh also said if mainland China adjusts its policy and strategy and shows brotherly love for Taiwan, the number of pro-unification Taiwan residents will certainly increase.

Hsieh further warned in the interview with the VOA Chinese-language program "China Forum" that if military force is used in resolving the disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the future generations of the people on both sides will surely suffer from its after-effects no matter whether the result is unification or Taiwan independence.

Hsieh, who concurrently serves as mayor of Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second largest city, said the DPP's ultimate mission is to protect Taiwan people's freedom and legitimate rights to choose their own lifestyle.

Therefore, Hsieh said, the DPP's basic stance lies in its insistence that any change to Taiwan's present status quo -- either unification with the mainland or the establishment of a Republic of Taiwan -- must be decided by its people through a plebiscite.
As for how the people of Taiwan will decide, Hsieh said the DPP, now the Republic of China's ruling party, does not rule out any option and will fully respect the people's choice.

Noting that the main reason behind Taiwan people's opposition to unification at the moment lies in the fact that the People's Republic of China lacks appeals. "Few of our people agree with the PRC's repressive rule," he explained.
Hsieh went on to say that if the PRC shows more goodwill toward Taiwan -- such as renouncing its attempt to use force against Taiwan -- more Taiwan residents may lean toward unification.

"I'm convinced that if mainland China displays its brotherly love for Taiwan and stops blocking Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations, the number of Taiwanese people supporting unification will increase steadily," Hsieh added.

The lawyer-turned-politician stressed that the current cross-strait problems does not lie in the DPP's opposition to unification nor have anything to do with the party's pro-independence platform. "The reality is that the people of Taiwan do not want unification," he noted.
For the DPP, Hsieh said, unification is not the sole option for Taiwan's future, but is indeed one of the options.

Hsieh further said mainland China should make self-reflection on Taiwan people's opposition to unification. "The PRC has hurt Taiwan people's dignity by intimidating and coercing them to accept the Beijing-proposed unification terms," he said, adding that none of residents in democratic Taiwan would buy Beijing's intimidation.
According to Hsieh, the DPP has not dictated any option for Taiwan's future. "What we have set is a process for changing Taiwan's present status quo -- holding a plebiscite," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONAL DAY FIREWORKS TO LIGHT UP SOUTHERN TAIWAN SKIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest fireworks display is scheduled to light up the skies of the southern city of Kaohsiung Tuesday evening in celebration of the Republic of China' 89th National Day.

In honor of President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promise to place equal emphasis on southern and northern Taiwan, this year marks the first time that the auspicious pyrotechnics display will be held for a southern audience. Traditionally, National Day fireworks have been held in the north.

The Combined Services Force General Headquarters, the military's logistics command, is in charge of preparing the 7,540 pyrotechnics to be fired off in the performance. Some 3,430 pieces are 300-meter high-altitude pyrotechnics, 1,250 are designed to explode at 200 meters, 420 shoot straight for the sky, while another 2,440 are placed inside the others and are designed to go off at low and middle altitudes.

The entire display will last about an hour and cost the CSF over NT$20 million (US$640,000). Kaohsiung City government, mindful of the over 100,000 people expected to come to the fireworks extravaganza, has issued an announcement urging them to utilize public transportation.
Some flights have been canceled or delayed for safety reasons, and a number of ships in Kaohsiung Harbor have been temporarily moved from their old berths to news ones, also for safety reasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS SOLID TIES WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Lilongwe, Malawi, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Yang Hui-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi reiterated Monday that relations between the Republic of China and his country remain firm and solid.
Muluzi made the reaffirmation during a 90-minute meeting with ROC Ambassador to Malawi Chen Hsi-tsan.
On the eve of the ROC's Oct. 10 National Day, Muluzi invited Ambassador Chen to his official residence for talks on matters of mutual interest.
During their meeting, Muluzi expressed his gratitude for the ROC's assistance to Malawi in its economic and agricultural development over past years.
Muluzi further said as the ROC and Malawi share common ideals in upholding democracy and human rights, relations between the two countries will continue to flourish.

Muluzi also denied a report that Malawi will send a deputy minister-level official to attend a mainland China-sponsored forum in Beijing to promote relations between the People's Republic of China and African countries.
Muluzi told Ambassador Chen that he will deliver a congratulatory message Tuesday in celebration of the ROC's Double Ten National Day. The message will be broadcast by Malawi Radio Station.
Foreign wire service reports said a Malawi Foreign Ministry division chief-level official is accompanying a Malawi business delegation to attend the ongoing PRC-Africa forum in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILL NOT BE 'BLACKMAILED' BY SOLOMONS, SAYS MOFA

TEXT.P: In the face of uncertainty over diplomatic relations with the Solomon Islands, the Republic of China has measured the situation and is prepared for the worst, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

The unexpected absence of Solomon Islands Foreign Minister Denny Philip from the celebrations of ROC National Day Tuesday has triggered speculation that bilateral ties between the two countries may be hanging in the balance.

Philip was scheduled to arrive in Taipei last Friday for a six-day visit, but he never showed up. In addition to joining celebrations of Taiwan's National Day, he was scheduled to officially open the Solomon Islands embassy in Taipei.
Unconfirmed sources said Philip has left the Solomon Islands and is on his way to Beijing. The MOFA officials said they could not confirm that report.
But one thing is sure, MOFA officials said -- the ROC will not be "blackmailed" by the Solomon Islands if Beijing lures the Pacific nation into its fold with dollar diplomacy.
Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao noted that it is still too early to speculate on relations between the Solomons and Taiwan.

On financial assistance to the Solomon Islands, Tien said continued cash aid is likely, but it should not exceed what Taiwan can afford. He added that as a foreign minister, he is also responsible for watching over the government's purse.

Meanwhile, mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao claimed that Beijing has no idea about Philip's whereabouts, but added that the PRC is willing to foster formal relations with all nations -- as long as they recognize that there is only one China in the world.

Sources from the Solomon Islands reported that the political situation there is very much on the brink, with political tensions among rival factions that have simmered over the last two years now coming to a boil.

Under the brokerage of Australia and New Zealand, warring Solomon Islands factions began talks Tuesday in Sydney. The negotiations are widely seen as the last chance to bring about peace in that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER WELCOMES RESUMPTION OF AIR LINK WITH PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan on Tuesday welcomed the resumption of Taiwan's direct air link with the Philippines, and urged both sides to treasure their bilateral relations.

Speaking in Manila, Yeh said that the resumption of the direct air link between Taiwan and the Philippines also represents the reopening of all kinds of exchanges between the two countries. She urged both sides to work hard for their mutual benefit, and to ensure that the air link is permanent.

The ROC's first female transportation is in Manila at the invitation of the Philippines' General Chamber of Industry and Commerce. She made the remarks in a speech at the organization's annual meeting.
Yeh noted that Taiwan is promoting the liberalization of its telecommunications industry in order to satisfy public demand for telecommunications services.
She added that Taiwan is also working to step up its Internet know-how in an attempt to be a part of what she called the frontierless global economy.

Referring to tourism, Yeh indicated that the Philippines, which is rich in tourist attractions and friendly people, is a favorite destination for Taiwan travelers. However, the number of Taiwan tourists visiting the Philippines fell significantly during the dispute over air rights, she added.

Yeh said the resumption of the direct air link between Taipei and Manila is likely to bring about more frequent exchanges between the two countries in the economic, commercial, tourist and cultural areas.

Air links between the ROC and Philippines had been suspended for nearly one year because of the termination of the aviation agreement between the two countries and the failure to agree on a new one. Taipei and Manila finally signed an agreement to restore their air link in late September.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS GROUP TO MEET WITH ECONOMICS MINISTER AGAIN

TEXT.P: The Chinese National Federation of Industries will meet with Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi again this week to discuss issues related to domestic industries.

The new government has put forward a series of new policies since taking power on May 20, such as shortening of the work week, reducing the number of foreign laborers, and implementing a five-day workweek on an all-out basis. The moves have sent shock waves throughout the island's industrial circles.

The most controversial issue of all -- the fight over whether to continue the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant -- resulted in the resignation of former Premier Tang Fei last Tuesday, aggravating bearishness sentiment in the local stock market and causing further public anxiety about the island's economic outlook.
Tang, a member of the opposition Kuomintang, supports going ahead with the construction of the nuclear power plant, which contradicts the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's anti-nuclear platform.
CNFI officials said that although the Cabinet has completed a minor reshuffle, the issues that concern domestic industries have still not been resolved.

The officials have met with Lin twice in the past few days to discuss the fourth nuclear power plant and other issues. They plan to meet with Lin again Friday for further discussions, with topics to include cross-strait trade and the current economic situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE SEMINAR INVOLVING 3 CHINESE AREAS TO KICK OFF IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: The sixth economic and trade seminar of mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong will be held from Oct. 17-20 in Beijing, with some 120 industrial and commercial leaders from the three areas expected to participate.

Hsui Sheng-fa, chairman of the Republic of China Federation of Industry and Commerce, will lead the ROC delegation to the seminar, which is to be organized by mainland China's All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce.

According to the China News Service, a mainland Chinese media agency, discussions at the seminar will focus on the effects the entry of mainland China into the World Trade Organization will have on economic and trade cooperation between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
The first economic and trade seminar of mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong was held in 1994. The meeting is held annually, with its venue alternating among Hong Kong, Beijing and Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: "DOUBLE TENTH" NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATED IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: The "Double Tenth" National Day of the Republic of China was celebrated Tuesday in Hong Kong with at least 1,000 entrepreneurs, celebrities, journalists, and leaders of various overseas Chinese organizations participating.
During the celebration, the participants adopted a proclamation, expressing their hope that the relations between China and Taiwan will "develop positively."

In the proclamation, they also expressed the hope that Beijing will recognize the reality that China and Taiwan are ruled by separate political entities, and will take steps to reopen dialogues with Taipei.
The "Double Tenth" National Day is jubilantly celebrated each year by people of Hong Kong, which reverted to communist Chinese rule in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINESE FISHING BOATS NABBED FOR POACHING IN ROC WATERS

TEXT.P: Two mainland Chinese fishing boats and 16 people aboard were nabbed Tuesday for poaching in territorial waters of the Republic of China.

In a routine patrol along the coast off Penghu, a patrol boat of the Coast Guard Administration Penghu Squad spotted two mainland Chinese fishing boats -- the Minlungyu 0234 and the Minshihyu 0250 -- fishing in an area only 8 nautical miles off the coast of Penghu's Hsiyu, or Western Isle.
The two boats -- both roller bottom trawlers -- were caught red handed operating in ROC waters, the maritime police said.
One of the seized boats, the Minlungyu 0234, was actually found to be the same vessel that was caught by the Penghu coastal patrol forces and released on Sept. 3.

The two trawlers were dragged to Makung Harbor for investigation. They were released after the seizure of their catches and environmentally destructive fishing gear. The seized equipment is of a design that not only catches small fish, but also unnecessarily kills other ocean lives.

Mainland Chinese fishing boats have become increasingly daring and active in recent months, brazenly cruising ROC waters to poach or conduct illegal trade in the belief that the Taiwan authorities can not effectively deal with them, the Penghu maritime police sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO INVITE SPECIALISTS TO ATTEND ECONOMIC FORUM

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party will invite local specialists to an economic forum on Oct. 13 to work out proposals for resolving Taiwan's economic problems.
PFP Chairman James Soong and Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih will deliver special reports to the forum, which is jointly sponsored by the PFP and a local business magazine.
The main purpose of the forum is to diagnose the island's economic maladies and come up with effective counter-measures for the problems, said a PFP official.

Major subjects will include the prospects for high-technology industries, the impact of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, the country's financial and economic difficulties, the national deficit, as well as the structural problems of Taiwan's financial system.
Noted specialists to be invited to the forum will include former Economics Minister Chao Yao-tung and former Executive Yuan Secretary-General Wang Chou-ming.
Former Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang and former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang are also expected to attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN OFFICIATES AT NAT'L FLAG RAISING CEREMONY IN NANTOU
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Central Taiwan, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan attended a national flag raising ceremony Tuesday to mark the Republic of China National Day at Nantou County's Chichi Township, ground zero of last year's disastrous Sept. 21 earthquake.
Also present at the ceremony were more than 100 local victims of the quake now living in prefabricated houses.
Lien criticized the Democratic Progressive Party-led administration as failing to speed up earthquake reconstruction work, now languishing far behind schedule.
As a result, over 60 percent of quake victims are awaiting jobs that have been promised to them, while an additional 30 percent are jobless and have no prospects for employment, Lien said.

Lien also told the participants that the KMT has carried out all 10 promises it made after a series of meetings he held with people from all walks of life in earthquake-stricken areas. He stressed that KMT lawmakers in the Legislative Yuan had enacted relevant legislation toward alleviating the problems faced by the victims.

Lien was accompanied on the trip by a group of KMT senior officials including P.K. Chiang, executive secretary of a KMT think tank, KMT Secretary General Lin Feng-cheng, KMT Cultural Affairs Chief Jason Hu and KMT Organization Chief Chao Shou-po.
Lien presented each participant with a pair of flour longevity peaches -- a traditional Chinese gift -- to mark the occasion.
Later in the day, Lien and his entourage called on a group of tea harvesters who were wounded in a car accident and are now hospitalized at the Christian Hospital in Puli.

Lien also presented 400 pairs of longevity peaches to the hospital. In return, Huang Wei, head of Puli Christian Hospital, presented a citation to Lien Chan in recognition of his assistance to the hospital during earthquake rescue operations last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-RUSSIA AIR LINK STILL FACING LONG ROAD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By S.F. Wong & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Talk of establishing air links between Taiwan and Russia seemed to have sparked up again following a visit by a group of Russian parliamentarians to Minister of Transport and Communications Yeh Chu-lan, with China Airlines and Russia's Transaero resuming talks on cooperation.
However, an official of the Civil Aeronautics Administration under the MOTC said that Taiwan and Russia have a long road ahead before a direct air link between the two countries can be established.

Actually, the Taipei -Moscow Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission's office in Moscow and its counterpart's office in Taipei inked the protocol for an aviation pact between Taipei and Moscow in 1993.
However, the Russian side canceled the agreement shortly after it was signed.

Talks resumed again in 1997, and a breakthrough seemed imminent when China Airlines and Transaero were chosen to fly the Taipei-Moscow route. CAL planned to inaugurate air services between Taipei and Moscow in September 1997, but Russia denied the aviation agreement again, on the grounds that the protocol was incomplete.
In the beginning of 1998, Russia again sent a delegation to three days of talks with Taiwan agencies concerned. But the agreement died again in the wake of the Russian government's reshuffling.

Despite the repeated setbacks, periodic contacts have continued over the past two years. The Russian side has insisted that in addition to signing the aviation agreement, the two parties must sign a commercial agreement. CAL is now carefully studying the contents of the proposed commercial agreement.

A CAL staffer said that the Taipei-Moscow line would not be particularly beneficial from a business standpoint, so CAL is negotiating with the Russians to obtain third-country air rights. This would allow a link to Frankfort, Germany, which would make the Taipei-Moscow line profitable. But he added that CAL has balked at the high price Russia has demanded for the rights.
The CAL official said that the two parties have already managed to reach some consensus, but there are still some differences that need to be addressed.

According to an official who took part the negotiations for an aviation agreement between Taipei and Moscow, Russia intends to sign a commercial agreement to replace the aviation agreement. Taiwan is reluctant to accept Russian proposal because it would not only downgrade Taiwan's status but also cause many harmful aftereffects, he said.
A CAA official said judging from past negotiations with the Russians, an aviation agreement that would uphold both sides' dignity is not likely to be signed anytime soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER PLAYS HOST AT NATIONAL DAY RECEPTION

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tien Hong-mao and his wife hosted a National Day reception at the Taipei Guest House Tuesday, with more 4,000 than Chinese and foreign dignitaries participating.
President Chen Shui-bian and the first lady as well as Vice President Annette Lu were among the guests invited to the party.
Foreign dignitaries present at the event included Haitian President Rene Preval, Grenadian Prime Minister Keith C. Mitchell, Speaker of the Lower House of Swaziland Nicholas Sikkadza.
Delegations from the Solomon Islands, Liberia, Honduras, Chile, Japan, Korea, the Philippines, Great Britain and Switzerland also took part in the reception.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAVEL AGENTS GEAR UP FOR 5-DAY WORKWEEK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's travel agents have been busy planning new travel packages for local tourists, as they look forward to next year's implementation of a five-day workweek for public servants.

According to surveys conducted by tourist agencies, travel packages that offer a two- or three-day itinerary are currently most popular among local customers. Some tourism entrepreneurs, including managers of entertainment parks and hot spring hotels, have already begun intensifying efforts to lure local tourists.

However, the implementation of a five-day workweek is not the only reason that travel agencies are stepping up efforts to lure customers. The other reason is simple survival, as tourism is expected to take a blow from the slumping stock market. The past four months have seen a bear market that has so far resulted in the loss of nearly NT$3,000 billion (US$96.8 billion) in equity capital.
According to official statistics, the decrease in the value of all the stocks on the local bourse represents an average loss of NT$200,000 (US$6,450) for every ROC citizen.
When personal wealth decreases, consumers generally first cut their expenses in traveling, and then stop spending on cars, jewelry, and clothes.

Travel agents said that since the stock market slump began, inexpensive travel packages have become more popular than before. Meanwhile, some agents have made their prices for expensive packages negotiable.
Despite a weak stock market, travel agencies are not giving up hope, and instead are urging people to take more vacations so as to take advantage of the current cheap prices for travel packages.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLOMONS ENVOY SAYS MINISTER'S BEIJING VISIT WAS UNOFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Solomon Islands' formal and cordial relations with the Republic of China have not changed, and its stance in support of the ROC in the international community also remains unchanged, the Solomons envoy in the ROC stressed on Tuesday.

Ambassador Seth Gukuna said that any visit to Beijing by his country's foreign minister, Denny Philip, should be viewed as a "personal" act that will have no impact on bilateral relations between the ROC and the Solomon Islands.
Gukuna said his government will issue a statement Wednesday to officially announce that formal and cordial ROC-Solomons relations remain unchanged.

Gukuna was obviously in an awkward situation Tuesday evening, when he attended a state banquet hosted by the ROC government on the occasion of Taiwan's Double-Ten National Day. The Solomons envoy was hotly pursued by Taipei reporters, who demanded an explanation of Philip's unexpected visit to Beijing.

The Solomons foreign minister was scheduled to arrive in Taipei last Friday for a six-day visit, but he never showed up. In addition to joining the celebrations of ROC National Day, he was scheduled to officially open the Solomon Islands embassy in Taipei.

Officials from the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs have been scrambling to ascertain Philip's whereabouts for the last five days amid rumors that he had shifted his destination from Taipei to Beijing.
Gukuna also rebuked foreign wire service reports that the Solomons government had instructed Philip to delay his visit to Taipei because of Taiwan's recent political problems as "groundless."

Meanwhile, Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao said earlier in the day that Philip was "probably in Beijing," but added that it is still too early to speculate on relations between the Solomons and Taiwan.

Tien noted that Taiwan is likely to continue its financial assistance, but he stressed that the aid should not exceed what Taiwan can afford. He added that as a foreign minister, he is also responsible for watching over the government's purse.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP. OFFICE IN SOUTH AFRICA CELEBRATES ROC NATIONAL DAY
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, South Africa, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Liaison Offices in the South African cities of Pretoria and Johannesburg jointly held a reception Monday night to celebrate the Republic of China's National Day.

Some 800 dignitaries from the local overseas Chinese community, officials of the South African government, foreign diplomats in South Africa and press representatives took part in the reception. Additionally, members of South Africa's political, military, police, cultural and business circles also attended.

Du Leng, representative of the Taipei Liaison Office in Pretoria, Taipei's quasi-embassy in South Africa in the absence of diplomatic ties with that nation, briefed the dignitaries on political and economic developments in the ROC, as well as cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Overseas Chinese in South Africa also held an athletic meet Monday in Johannesburg to celebrate ROC National Day.

Two major Chinese-language newspapers carried Tuesday's speech by ROC President Chen Shui-bian, as well as those by the presidents of the ROC's five government branches, the chairman of the ROC's Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, and overseas Chinese representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE TO HOLD ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL FORUM ON SATURDAY

TEXT.P: An economic and financial forum will be held at the Presidential Office on Saturday, a Presidential Office's official said Tuesday.

Kuo Yao-chi, director general of the Department of Public Affairs at the Presidential Office, said that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, expert scholars, and business and industrial leaders will all be invited to take part in the one-day forum.

The meeting's agenda will focus on how to prop up the slumping stock market, save Taiwan's traditional industries, deal with the controversial fourth nuclear power plant issue, and keep local enterprises from moving to mainland China, according to Kuo.
Kuo noted that this type of economic and financial symposium will be held periodically in the future, with themes and invitation lists to be decided by the Executive Yuan.
Vice Premier Lai In-jaw is in charge of drafting the theme of the future symposium, as well as deciding exactly whom to invite, Kuo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT WITNESSES NATIONAL DAY FIREWORKS DISPLAY IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian witnessed the massive National Day fireworks display in the southern harbor city of Kaohsiung Tuesday evening.
This was the first time that the nation's main National Day fireworks display was held in southern Taiwan since the event was first introduced 33 years ago.
Some 100,000 spectators enjoyed the spectacular display. Chen flew to Kaohsiung from Taipei for the event, accompanied by Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Chen Che-nan.
He told the spectators that his visit to Kaohsiung was an indication that his new government is giving equal treatment to northern and southern Taiwan, as promised during his presidential campaign.

Chen urged people in southern Taiwan to support his government, and added that the annual Lantern Festival, traditionally held in Taipei, will also be held in Kaohsiung during next year's Chinese New Year celebrations.
Meanwhile, Vice President Annette Lu attended the Second Taipei Fireworks Festival in suburban Taipei Tuesday evening.
She said that the new government attaches equal importance to the development of northern and southern Taiwan, and cited her presence in Taipei, while President Chen went to Kaohsiung.
Lu called for the cooperation of all people on the island, regardless of their ethnic origins, so as to create a new Taiwan filled with peace and love.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT, PREMIER SPEAK AT NATIONAL DAY EVENING PARTY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung attended a National Day party at Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall Tuesday evening.

Addressing the assembled party guests, Lu noted that the people of Taiwan chose a new helmsman in last March's presidential election, and added that so long as the 23 million people on the island consolidate their unity, the ROC will be able to march into the new century with confidence.
She expressed the hope that the people will display the country's power through human rights, democracy, peace and love -- not to mention a healthy dose of high technology.
Chang also spoke on the occasion, urging all of Taiwan's political parties to give up their confrontational style and instead prioritize the interests of the nation.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-pyng also spoke briefly at the party. The evening event featured a variety of entertaining performances, including songs by Chinese-Japanese singer Judy Ongg.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOUBLE-TEN NATIONAL DAY PARTY IN TOKYO ATTRACTS 1,500 PEOPLE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative office in Japan held a Double-Ten National Day party at the Okura Hotel in Tokyo Tuesday evening, attracting some 1,500 Japanese and overseas Chinese residents.

Lo Fu-chuan, ROC representative to Japan, noted that this year's Double-Ten celebrations carried a special significance, as they were the first National Day event since the transfer of administrative power.
He told the guests that the new government under President Chen Shui-bian will faithfully fulfill its international duties and will strive to improve the nation's dignity.

On the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Lo expressed the hope that mainland China will exert good will to create an environment suitable for cooperation, so as to resolve the "one China" issue.
He also called for strengthened cooperation between Taiwan and Japan to help improve regional security and peace.

Japanese dignitaries invited to the party included Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, Lower House Speaker Tamisuke Watanuki, former Foreign Minister Kabun Muto, and representatives from the Democratic Party and the Komei Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP. OFFICE IN PHILIPPINES CELEBRATES ROC NATIONAL DAY
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative office in the Philippines held a reception Tuesday night to celebrate ROC National Day.
More than 3,000 dignitaries from the Philippines, including former Philippine President Fidel Ramos, as well as representatives of the local overseas Chinese community attended the reception.

Speaking in front of the assembled guests, Philippine Senator Ramon Magsaysay stressed that the relations between the ROC and the Philippines are close. Taiwan is the Philippines' third largest trade partner and fifth largest investment destination, Magsaysay said, adding that he hopes bilateral ties will further be strengthened.

In turn, Chan Hsien-ching, ROC representative in the Philippines, said at the reception that the ROC, guided by Dr. Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People, has created a political and economic miracle.

Chan noted that the ROC's economy is the 19th largest in the world, with a per capita GNP exceeding US$14,000. He also noted that its foreign exchange reserves have reached US$100.05 billion, the third largest in the world.

He also lauded the ROC's democratization, pointing out that it has reached a mature level, as shown by the peaceful transfer of power after Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party won the March 18 presidential election.

Chan said that the ties between the Philippines and the ROC have long been friendly, adding that both sides have established sound relations in the fields of trade, investment, tourism and labor. He said he believes that the friendly relations will be further strengthened in the future.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 11, or the 14th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1727: George II, King of Great Britain and Ireland and elector of Hanover, is crowned in London. His 1743 victory at the Battle of Dettingen was the last time that a British monarch led troops in the field.
1821: Sir George Williams, English social reformer who founded the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA), one of the largest nonprofit voluntary organizations in the world, is born.
1834: Sir William Napier, Britain's Chief Superintendent of Trade in China, dies in Macao at the age of 48. He had recently returned from Canton after a disastrous attempt to persuade the imperial government of China to trade directly with Britain rather than through the Hong Kong merchants.
1896: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is enticed into and placed in confinement at the Ching embassy in London. He was later rescued by his British friends.
1900: Winston Churchill, British politician and writer, is elected a member of the House of Commons to begin his long political career. As prime minister, he led Great Britain in World War II. He published several works, including "The Second World War," and won the 1953 Nobel Prize for Literature.
1939: U.S. scientists, including Albert Einstein, outline to President Franklin D. Roosevelt the possibility of developing an atomic bomb.
1945: A joint declaration announces that an agreement between the government and the Chinese communists has been reached after six weeks of negotiations and that unsolved problems are to be settled by a political consultative conference.
1946: ROC government troops capture Kalgan (Changchiakow) in Inner Mongolia from the Chinese communists.
1957: The world's largest steerable radio-telescope goes into operation at the Jodrell Observatory of the British University of Manchester. The instrument has an 81-meter diameter parabolic bowl mounted on a trunnion 58 meters above ground level.
1968: Apollo 7, carrying U.S. astronauts Walter Schirra, Don Eiselle, and Walter Cunningham, is launched.
1972: West Germany establishes diplomatic ties with Communist China.
1975: A two-day national conference on "Building a New Asia Through Moral Rearmaments" opens in Taipei.
1976: Qiang Qing, the third wife and widow of Mao Tse-tung, is arrested with three associates. The so-called "Gang of Four" are charged with plotting a coup after Mao's death.
1976: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung returns from visits to Lesotho, Swaziland, and South Africa.
1978: The 1978 World Women's Football Invitational Tournament opens at the Taipei Municipal Stadium with 13 teams from Asia, Australia, Europe, the Americas, and the Pacific competing.
1980: Soviet cosmonauts return to Earth after a record 185 days in space in the Salyut 6 spacecraft.
1986: A National Development Exhibition in celebration of the centennial of late President Chiang Kai-shek's birthday is opened at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
1986: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev hold a summit meeting in Reykjavik, Iceland.
1986: A display of ROC military power in the "Kuo-kuang Maneuvers" is held at the Hukou Army Base in Hsinchu.
1990: The Ministry of the Interior reiterates that the Tiaoyutai island group belongs to the Republic of China. The chain of eight uninhabited islets, located in the East China Sea, is also claimed by Japan and Communist China.
1991: Direct air service between Australia and the Republic of China begins.
1992: President Lee Teng-hui and Panamanian President Guillermo Endara sign a joint communique on expanding bilateral cooperation.
1997: Leaders of some 40 nations end a rare Council of Europe summit with pledges regarding human rights and human cloning.
1999: Some 7,000 people gather at a stadium in Linkou on the outskirts of Taipei to mourn the 2,321 people who died in the devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he in this world who is possessed of absolute truth that can order and adjust the great relations of human society, fix the fundamental principles of morality, and understand the laws of creation of the Universe."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 168.87 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 168.87 points to close at 6,040.55.
Market turnover amounted to NT$24.78 billion (US$0.79 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 168.87 points to close at 6,040.55.

Affected by a plunge in U.S. hi-tech and semi-conductor stock prices, the bourse opened at 6,070.43 and continued to go down despite purchases made by government funds. The bourse fluctuated between 6,070.43 and 6,013.53 during trading.

A total of 0.92 billion stocks worth NT$24.78 billion (US$0.79 billion) changed hands, a record low since Sept. 27, 1999 and a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.76 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$59.48 billion (US$1.9 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical shares and textile issues moving down the most, both at 2.9 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 2.7 percent, cement stocks at 2.6 percent, construction shares and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 2 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 550 to 32, with 30 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taiwan stock index futures were lower Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization weighted index futures for October moved down 217 points to close at 5,988, with 1,488 contracts traded.

TAIEX Index futures for November decreased 218 points to finish at 6,021, with 180 contract transactions, while December futures lost 209 points to close at 6,072, with three contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Wednesday at 6,205 for October, 6,239 for November, 6,281 for December, 6,315 for next March, and 6,430 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
October TE futures moved down 11.25 points to close at 311.55, with 468 contract transactions, while November TE futures decreased 11.2 points to finish at 309.8, with 39 contracts changing hands.
March 2001 TE futures fell 7.8 points to close at 316.1, with five contracts traded. No transactions were reported for March 2001 TE futures.
October TF futures lost 25.8 points to close at 713.2, with 649 contract transactions, while November TF futures decreased 26.2 points to finish at 725.2, with 12 contracts traded.
December TF futures plunged 26.2 points to close at 726.8, with 103 contract transactions, while March 2001 TF futures dropped 21.22 points to finish at 731.4, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June 2001 TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: LANGUAGE POLICY SHOULD BE DECIDED BY HIGHER-LEVEL SAYS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Education Minister Ovid Tzeng insisted Wednesday that the government's Romanization spelling system, which is of vital importance to the nation's language policy, should be decided on by a level of government higher than the Ministry of Education (MOE).

Tzeng said the MOE is working to present two Romanization systems -- mainland China's Hanyu Pinyin scheme and the locally-developed Tongyong spelling system -- to the Cabinet for final decision on which to make standard in the Republic of China.
Answering a question raised by People First Party Legislator Lee Ching-an at the Legislative Yuan, Tzeng admitted that he personally prefers the Hanyu Pinyin system.

Tzeng, himself a linguist, stressed that while most Mandarin-speaking people in the rest of the world use the Hanyu Pinyin system, "we cannot ask them not to use it," adding that it's important for the people in Taiwan to "cope with world trends."

The scholar-turned-minister said he believes that he will not be forced to step down because he holds a different opinion from those in the MOE or other related government agencies. "Language policy should be made after rational considerations," he noted.

Tzeng's remarks came three days after Vice Education Minister Fan Shuan-lu announced that the ministry, in accordance with the conclusion made by a group of linguistic experts, had decided to adopt the Tongyong system.
During a news conference jointly held by Tzeng and Fan on Monday, Fan called on the different groups concerned to view the issue in a more open-minded way.
Fan said the gap between the two systems is not as wide as many people imagine. Around 85 percent of the two systems are the same, she added.

"It's a thorny issue for the new government -- although the former administration decided earlier to adopt the Hanyu Pinyin system, it failed to put it into practice due to too much discord -- but no antagonism should be produced because of it," she noted.

Tzeng said that as head of the education ministry, he has to respect the conclusion arrived at by the National Language Promotion Commission. But he added that as a linguist, he prefers Beijing's Hanyu Pinyin system, now used by Taipei City for road signs and place names.

The controversy over the issue stems from the previous government's demand in the late 1990s for a modern, standardized Romanization system to help foreigners pronounce Chinese words as an important step in transforming the island into a worldwide business hub.

As a result, the National Language Promotion Commission under the MOE recommended in August 1999 that Taiwan adopt Beijing's Hanyu Pinyin system on the grounds that it is widely used around the world and is recognized by the United Nations.

Although adopting the Hanyu Pinyin system would be politically difficult for Taiwan in light of its painstaking efforts to distinguish itself as a sovereign entity separate from mainland China, the Cabinet under former Premier Vincent Siew agreed to endorse the plan, but demanded supplementary measures to facilitate its implementation.

Siew and his administration stepped down before the system was officially adopted by the government, and a new panel under the education ministry canceled the decision. The new panel members argued in favor of the Tongyong system, which was developed by a local scholar from the new National Language Promotion Commission.
They recommended the Tongyong system on the grounds that it accounts for various existing systems used to teach local dialects, whereas the Hanyu Pinyin system does not.
The panel's decision has caused an outcry from Taipei City Hall, which has already begun changing the capital's road signs according to the Hanyu Pinyin Romanization system.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT AIRLINKS WITH EUROPE TO BE EXPANDED

TEXT.P: Three European countries have agreed to exchange "temporary aviation rights" with the Republic of China to facilitate bilateral visits, the Civil Aeronautics Administration said Wednesday.
CAA Director-General Chang Yu-hern confirmed a newspaper report that Spain, Denmark and the Czech Republic have promised to offer third and fourth freedoms to Taiwan carriers.
With the third and fourth freedoms, Taiwan carriers will be able to transport passengers and freight directly from Taiwan to the three European countries.
Chang said the three countries have expressed welcome to the opening of direct flight services by Taiwan's China Airlines and EVA Airways to their major cities.

Meanwhile, Chang said, the Netherlands has agreed to allow Taiwan carriers to increase two weekly cargo flights from Oct. 29. Chang said Taiwan's flagship China Airlines (CAL) will be granted the right to operate the additional cargo flights to Amsterdam.
According to Chang, the CAA sent an official delegation to visit the four European countries in late September to explore the possibility of expanding the ROC's airlinks with Europe.

The delegation consistently kept low profile during its 12-day visit to avoid mainland China's boycott as the four European countries all recognize Beijing and only maintain unofficial ties with the ROC.
The ROC has long maintained a formal aviation agreement with the Netherlands, allowing carriers from both countries to operate direct passenger and cargo flight services between Taipei and Amsterdam.

Against this backdrop, Chang said, the CAA delegation easily reached a consensus with the Dutch civil aviation authority on the revision of the existing bilateral aviation accord to allow CAL to add two weekly cargo flights to its service schedule.
In contrast, Chang said, the CAA delegation only scored "symbolic" results in its aviation rights negotiations with Spain, Denmark and the Czech Republic.

The ROC has never signed any formal aviation pact with the three European countries. For fears of offending mainland China, the three countries are reluctant to seal any formal accords with the ROC. They would only sign "temporary aviation pacts" with Taiwan on a reciprocal basis.

"As the civil aviation policies of the three European countries remain very conservative, the ROC must seek a major diplomatic breakthrough before it can convince them to sign formal aviation accords to pave the way for permanent direct airlinks," Chang noted.

Noting that none of the three countries would offer the critical fifth freedom -- the right to extending flights to third destinations -- to Taiwan carriers, Chang said their offer to exchange "temporary aviation rights" has only symbolic meaning and has little substantive effect.

"Without the fifth freedom, Taiwan carriers will have little interest in opening direct flight services to the three European countries due to gloomy profit prospects," Chang said, adding that the third and fourth freedoms will only enable local carriers to transport cargoes and passengers directly to the three countries.
Moreover, Chang said, the proposed temporary aviation agreements can be suspended at any time and provide little guarantees to Taiwan carriers' rights and interests.

Against this background, Chang said, the CAA hopes that local carriers will not open direct passenger flights to the three European countries until after the ROC manages to sign formal aviation pacts with them.

As it is easier for carriers to cope with the aftermath of abrupt suspension of cargo flights, Chang said the CAA will not oppose plans by any local carrier to open such services to the three European countries.

In addition to the Netherlands, Taiwan has also signed formal aviation agreements with three other European countries -- Italy, France and Britain, allowing its carriers to operate direct flights to Rome, Paris and London.
