DOC.HEADLINE: NSC NOT WORRIED ABOUT OUTFLOW OF LOCAL TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) is dedicated to solving problems for domestic technology industries and does not worry about their outbound investment, said NSC Chairman Weng Cheng-i on Tuesday.
Weng made the remarks while fielding questions about the trend of domestic technology industries shifting abroad and the attitude of the NSC toward the problem.
Weng noted that only about 300 computer peripheral companies in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park are investing in the mainland, saying there is no reason to worry.

He said that the NSC has been dedicated to solving the problems of high-technology industries and that statistics have demonstrated a net influx of technology talent so far, so there is no need to worry about the outflow of technology industries and a talent drain.

He also said that the NSC is now working with the Ministry of Economic Affairs to revise the regulations concerning high-tech mainland Chinese talent working in Taiwan. He expressed the hope these skilled workers will be allowed to stay in Taiwan for up to three years at a time so as to help develop domestic industries.
Meanwhile, Weng also said that even if the fourth nuclear power plant is scrapped, there will not be any power shortage problems for science-based industrial parks.

He said that Tainan Science-based Industrial Park needs about 1,000 megawatts of electricity over the long term, adding that it can rely on the thermoelectric-power plant as well as the second and third nuclear power plants in southern Taiwan for its power supply.

As for Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, Weng said that it is estimated that the park will reach its peak electricity consumption rate in 2004, at which time it will have 900 megawatts of its own electric power, so meeting the park's power needs won't pose a problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. MUST GUARD AGAINST MILITARY TECHNOLOGY TRANSFERS TO PRC: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Now that the issue of permanent normal trade relations between the United States and Communist China has been settled, the Clinton administration must take appropriate precautions to keep the People's Liberation Army from acquiring sensitive dual-use U.S. technology to improve its weapon-making capabilities, warned a renowned China expert Tuesday.

Larry M. Wortzel, director of the Asian Studies Center at The Heritage Foundation, wrote in a background analysis that to help ensure that the transfer of sensitive technology does not occur, Congress enacted legislation in 1998 requiring the Clinton administration to publish a list of Chinese companies in the United States that do business with the PLA. But to date, the administration has failed to comply with that law, he pointed out.
The debate in Washington over export controls to prevent the sale of such technology to China was temporarily set aside during the debate over PNTR, he noted.

"Congress should take up this matter now by demanding that the administration comply with the law and publish the required list so appropriate action can be taken to ensure that sensitive dual-use American technology is not being acquired by the PLA," wrote the former U.S. Army attache in Beijing.

Wortzel emphasized that despite President Bill Clinton's assertions about China during his summits with Jiang Zemin in both Washington in 1997 and Shanghai in 1998, "China is in fact not a `strategic partner' of the United States. Its aggressive behavior continues to threaten peace and stability in Asia."

Beijing's military modernization program relies heavily on foreign technology that it acquires through direct purchases or reverse engineering. "If appropriate precautions are not taken by the administration to restrict the sale of dual-use technology, a higher volume of trade with China could increase the chances that such sensitive technology will get into the PLA's hands," he said.

Moreover, Wortzel wrote, China's acquisition of dual-use technology and diversion of this technology to military use has serious implications for U.S. national security. Beijing has threatened to use force against the democratic Republic of China on Taiwan, and it bitterly resents that the United States sent two aircraft carrier battle groups to the Taiwan Straits when the PLA conducted live-firings of missiles there in 1996.

Beijing also vowed recently to respond militarily to any attempt by U.S. armed forces to assist Taiwan in the event of an aggressive act by China. If Beijing does attempt to solve the Taiwan issue by force, the U.S. military will be drawn into the conflict.

"The risk that U.S. technology could make the PLA more effective against the United States in such a confrontation means that the United States must carefully monitor high-technology sales to China. Negligence on the part of the administration could lead to an unacceptable scenario in which U.S. technology is used against American soldiers," said Wortzel.

He added that publishing a list of Communist Chinese companies that do business with the PLA "will reduce both the risk to U.S. military forces stationed around the world and the chances that sale of American technology to a Chinese military-related company operating in the United States could be approved by mistake."

"Compiling the list might not be easy, but failing to compile it could cost American lives. The Clinton administration owes it to the American people to uphold the law and identify these companies," concluded the China expert.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L INVESTORS SHOWING STRONG INTEREST IN ASIA: SURVEY

TEXT.P: International hotel investors are showing strong interest in buying hotel and resort properties in most Asian markets, particularly in Southeast Asia and Australasia, reported the Australian Financial Review on Wednesday.

The daily, quoting a survey of the 800 biggest investors and owners of hotel and resort properties carried out by the Jones Lang LaSalle Hotels' Hotel Investment Sentiment, said it is believed the region's economy has begun changing for the better since the 1997 financial crisis.

"The Asian recovery is well under way, although some short-term pain is expected in Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Auckland and, to a lesser extent, the Gold Coast (in Queensland)," said Jones Lang managing director David Gibson.

He added that the highest rates of return were being demanded from the less transparent markets of Bali, Jakarta, Beijing, Mumbai and Seoul, while the lowest initial yield expectations were in the tightly held or highly sought after markets, including Hong Kong, Tokyo, Singapore and Seoul, the daily reported.
From a buyer's perspective, the survey found that the most popular market in Asia is Bali, followed by Bangkok, reported the daily.
Meanwhile, Munich is the most popular market in Europe with potential buyers, followed by Paris, Rome, Madrid, Milan and Berlin, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE GOV'T AIMS TO INCREASE LNG EXPORTS TO ASIA

TEXT.P: The Australian government has set an ambitious target of winning a 30 percent share of the rapidly growing markets in Taiwan and other Asian countries for the country's liquefied natural gas within 20 years.

Resources Minister Nick Minchin on Wednesday announced that Australia's LNG industry would receive new tax relief through the removal of tariffs on equipment used in LNG plants not available in Australia.
He said the government would still decide policy on tax arrangements that would make new investment in the LNG industry more competitive with international suppliers.
He told reporters that the government recognizes the need to implement strategies to remove impediments to business and to increase international competitiveness.

In an interview with the CNA on Wednesday, Karyn Freeman of Shell Australia said the tax incentives would have a significant impact on the LNG industry, giving producers and exporters a more competitive edge to sell their products to Japan, South Korea, and particularly new markets such as Taiwan.
"We believe our government now recognizes the importance of the competitiveness of our LNG industry and wants to increase Australia's LNG exports to Taiwan and other markets as well," Freeman said.
She said Australia can compete with other LNG producing countries, including Indonesia and Malaysia, in terms of price and quality, and above all, political stability and reliability of supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER OPPOSES LOWERING TAXES TO PROP UP STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang on Wednesday expressed his opposition to suggestions that the government lower the business tax imposed on financial institutions and the stock transaction tax in order to help prop up the slumping stock market.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Yen said the business tax revenue generated from financial institutions cannot be cut as it is one of the major sources of the government's revenue, adding that 40 percent of this income is regularly allocated to local governments around the island.

Yen, a Kuomintang member, was appointed on Oct. 5 to replace Shea Jia-dong, who offered his resignation on Oct. 4 to take token responsibility for the plunging stock market, which has lost one-third of its value since the inauguration of the new administration on May 20.
Yen also said "no" to another legislator's suggestion that the government lower the stock transaction tax or stop imposing the stock transaction tax for one or two months so as to stimulate trading.

He stressed that lowering the stock transaction tax would be an act harmful to the healthy long-term development of the stock market and would only benefit short-lived bargain hunting which is not a desirable method for stabilizing the market.

Meanwhile, Yen, answering a question on whether the finance ministry will keep in place the temporary measure halving the regular 7 percent cap on the maximum allowable single-day fall in stock prices, said the six-day mercy scheme implemented for the period Oct. 4-11 will end Thursday as scheduled and the 7 percent two-way variation caps will resume simultaneously.

The Ministry of Finance had made an emergency announcement on Oct. 3 that the maximum single-day fall in stock prices would be halved beginning Oct. 4 in an attempt to minimize the impact on the local bourse of ex-Premier Tang Fei's announcement of his resignation, which sent shockwaves through Taiwan's political, economic, and social arenas.

On the movement of the National Stabilization Fund, which has been used regularly by the government to prop up the market when stock prices plummet, Yen said the fund was not instructed to buy Wednesday.

New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao ridiculed Yen as having "heightened" his own image and popularity by "scheming" to have the TAIEX weighted index jump on the first day of his resuming the post of finance minister. The finance minister is the only person eligible to authorize the movement of the National Stabilization Fund.

Lai added that the National Stabilization Fund, which has already spent some NT$100 billion on the stock market over the past four months, has suffered a loss of at least NT$30 billion so far, while the Four Major Fund, another fire-fighting arm of the government's finance sector, has lost some NT$50 billion after investing NT$500 billion in the stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.003 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at NT$31.298.
The local currency opened at NT$31.282 and was traded between NT$31.282 and NT$31.304.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$422 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGED TO GET IN CLOSER TOUCH WITH GRASS-ROOTS

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, should visit the countryside more often to get in closer touch with the people, said Hsu Shu-po, a KMT legislator Wednesday.
Hsu said that if Lien stays in Taipei most of the time, then people living in other places may not feel what the KMT is doing.
Hsu, who is also a member of the KMT Central Standing Committee, made the remarks at a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday morning.
He said that he has concerns about the outcome of next year's crucial legislative elections, saying that polls have shown that support for the KMT has continued to slump.

He noted that although the public is disappointed with the performance of the new administration over its first four months in power, public support for the KMT has not increased correspondingly, adding that even with the ongoing drive to bring former KMT supporters back into the party's fold, there has only been a less than 10 percent re-registration rate.

He said that many KMT veterans were so disappointed after the KMT's crashing defeat in the March presidential election, they cannot see why they would want to return. The KMT, although boasting the largest number of members of any party at 2 million, still finished third in the election with only 23.1 percent of the vote and is therefore holding its re-registration campaign until the end of the year.

Hsu said that as the KMT lost the presidency, and more recently the premiership, if the party loses its dominance in the Legislative Yuan after next year's elections, it will be left with nothing no matter what it says or does.

He said that the grass-roots KMT members should be made to feel the party reforms and that the future course of the party will be best demonstrated by what the party chairman has done. He therefore suggested that Lien visit the countryside more often to get in real touch with the party's grass-roots following, saying that this is absolutely the right course to follow.

He noted that the KMT cannot expect to gain greater popularity for any single thing and that the party can only achieve this goal through its long-term efforts, adding that the party chairman has a crucial role in winning over the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PITCHES FOR INTERNATIONAL SUPPORT FOR ROC'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday urged the international community to assist in the Republic of China's bid to join the World Health Organization.
Chen made the appeal while meeting with delegates to the 2000 Congress of the International Health Evaluation Association, which is being held in Taipei.
Chen said Taiwan has not only made enviable headway in economic development and political democratization but also have scored brilliant achievements in public health and medical services.
"Our progress in contagious diseases prevention and control, family planning and enforcement of a national health insurance program has won world recognition," Chen said.
However, Chen said, the ROC has been shut out of the WHO for more than two decades simply because of political reasons -- Beijing's recalcitrant opposition.

Noting that the ROC is more than willing to share its experience and achievements in various medical fields with the international community, Chen said, its lack of representation in the WHO has hindered such a drive.
"The ROC's absence is not only a setback for Taiwan but also a great loss for the WHO and the entire world society," Chen noted.
The president further said polio has been eradicated in Taiwan since 1982, while mainland China just rid itself of the infectious disease four years ago.

However, Chen said, the WHO has declined to recognize Taiwan's achievement in polio eradication. The WHO's West Pacific branch didn't mention Taiwan in its regional polio report to the WHO headquarters, even though the branch has listed Taiwan as a polio-free area.
In contrast, the WHO is scheduled to grant a polio-free certificate to mainland China at the end of October and formally declare the entire West Pacific as a polio-free region.

"We feel deep regret over the WHO's discrimination against Taiwan," Chen said, adding that political force has prompted the WHO to ignore Taiwan's efforts in polio prevention and eradication. "The WHO's handling of the issue is extremely unfair to the 23 million people of Taiwan," he added.

Chen further said despite Taiwan's economic strength -- the world's third largest foreign exchange reserves holder and the 15th largest trading power -- it has been shut out of the United Nations, the WHO and many other major international organizations.
Chen said the ROC will never be daunted by the unfavorable international conditions it faces and is firmly determined to "stand up and walk out" into the world arena.

"In addition to pursuing sustainable economic growth and continued democratic reforms, we will seek fair representation in world organizations and let the world hear the 'voice of Taiwan,'" Chen pledged.
He urged representatives of the International Health Evaluation Association to assist Taiwan in realizing its bid to join the WHO, a U.N. affiliate.
No matter how the world treat Taiwan, Chen said, Taiwan will not cease its efforts to take part in international activities and organizations.
The ROC, a U.N. founding member, was expelled from the United Nations in 1971 when mainland China claimed the China seat in the world body.

The IHEA delegates, including its founder, Morris Collen, and current IHEA President James B. McCormick, were accompanied by Lee Ming-liang, head of the Department of Health, during their meeting with President Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL SECTOR PROTESTS WHO INJUSTICE

TEXT.P: Medical workers in Taiwan raised an outcry Wednesday over what they see as the World Health Organization's injustice in handling a polio eradication certificate.

While Taiwan wiped out polio as early as 1982 and the ROC government has been petitioning the WHO for certification of the eradication for the past three years, the WHO decided recently to award the certificate to mainland China instead, sources from Taiwan's Department of Health said.

DOH officials said the WHO has earmarked 2000 as the year of polio eradication in the West Pacific, and the WHO's West Pacific Headquarters has also decided to include Taiwan within the West Pacific Polio Free Area this year.

Nevertheless, they pointed out, the report presented to the WHO Headquarters contains not a reference to Taiwan. When the WHO releases the latest results of its worldwide fight against polio at the end of October, it is expected to simultaneously award a certificate to mainland China for effectively eradicating polio from the Chinese community.

The development is undoubtedly a blow to Taiwan's medical community, which has made strenuous efforts to improve the island's public health, said Hsu Kuo-hsiung, deputy director of the DOH's Disease Control Bureau.
Despite medical workers' tireless efforts to eradicate the infantile paralysis-inducing disease, the WHO had effectively negated their success for political reasons, Hsu noted.

Only Taiwan has not been granted a polio eradication certificate, Hsu said. He added that over the last three years, the DOH actively submitted materials to argue for a WHO certification, including reports on polio vaccination rates, case reports and laboratory results.

According to Lin Shih-chia, director of the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan, the DOH even acted as a sponsor of a Rotary Club International campaign to recognize world governments' efforts to eradicate polio.
The campaign had compiled a fair and just report on the issue, using international standards. But in the end, the WHO decided to let mainland China enjoy a free lunch, Lin lamented.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-SOLOMON RELATIONS REMAIN NORMAL: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's diplomatic relations with the Solomon Islands remain normal, despite the Solomon foreign minister's failure to show up as scheduled at the ROC National Day celebrations, the ROC foreign minister said Wednesday.

After an opposition party legislator said that Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao believes the two countries are facing a "yellow light" in terms of their diplomatic relations, Tien told the press that Taiwan's attitude is to plan for the worst but hope the worst will not happen.

According to New Party legislator Lai Shyh-bao, Tien had admitted in a closed-door budget committee meeting earlier in the day that the Solomon Islands have indeed requested over US$20 million in emergency financial support, but that Taiwan is still considering the request because the ROC government does not think it is viable.
According to Lai, Tien went on to say that Taiwan already allocates over US$10 million for the Solomon Islands every year.

Denny Philip, the Solomon foreign minister, had been scheduled to arrive in Taipei last Friday for a six-day visit, but he never showed up. In addition to joining the celebrations of ROC National Day Tuesday, he was also scheduled to officially open the Solomon Islands embassy in Taipei.
Lai said that Tien has confirmed that Philip is now in Beijing.
Tien told the media that the Solomon Islands government has already pointed out that Philip's unfriendly conduct was a "personal act" that will have no impact on bilateral relations.

Tien added that Taiwan is not going to abandon its Solomon ally, which is currently facing financial difficulties due to domestic political unrest, but that the exact amount of financial assistance will require negotiations.

He went on to say that the ROC will take any opportunity to hold talks and secure diplomatic ties with other countries. However, responding to a legislator's claim that the ROC has recently approached five to 10 countries on establishing relations, he added that Taiwan has no specific country in mind at the moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE REAFFIRMS STANCE ON CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Herman Pan, Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: White House spokesman Jake Siewart said Tuesday that the U.S. policy of encouraging the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to conduct constructive dialogue and resolve disputes by peaceful means has remained unchanged.

Siewart was commenting on Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's National Day address in which Chen again pitched for a return to the "spirit of 1992" and an early resumption of institutionalized cross-strait dialogue and exchanges to break the current impasse.

Siewart said the U.S. policy on cross-strait relations has never changed, stressing that the United States has consistently encouraged Taiwan and mainland China to engage in constructive dialogue, reduce tension and seek peaceful solutions to their disputes.
Siewart also reaffirmed the U.S. stance that it will not act as a go-between or mediator in cross-strait negotiations.

Meanwhile, American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush also said Tuesday that the United States has long looked forward to seeing Taipei and Beijing resume talks. "We fully agree with President Chen's call for an early resumption of cross-strait dialogue," he noted.

Bush, the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, made the remarks while attending a cocktail reception hosted by the ROC's representative office in Washington, D.C. in celebration of the ROC's Double Ten National Day.

Commenting on Chen's call for a return to the "spirit of 1992" as a basis for cross-strait dialogue, Bush said the United States is not in a position to dictate the basis for Taiwan-mainland China talks. "We only hope that the two sides can find the best way for dialogue in the pursuit of mutual benefits."
Touching on Taipei-Washington relations, Bush said the United States and the ROC have long enjoyed a good and strong relationship, adding that he expects this good tie to continue in the future.

Stressing continuity in the U.S. government policy, Bush said the outcome of the U.S. congressional and presidential elections will not lead to dramatic changes in the U.S. policy toward Taiwan and that ROC-U.S. friendship will further deepen after the elections.

Bush also reaffirmed no U.S. role in Taiwan's debate on whether to continue or scrap the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project. "It's up to Taiwan authority to decide on the fate of the project," he stressed.
Bush reiterated what the U.S. government is concerned is whether contract provisions which Taiwan and the American contractor -- General Electric Co. -- previously agreed upon are fulfilled.

Bush said he thinks that Taiwan will fulfill its obligations to compensate GE if it finally decides to scrap the nuclear power plant project. As for how the scrapping of the project will affect the U.S. industry's confidence in Taiwan, Bush said it remains to be seen.

More than 1,000 dignitaries, including Panamanian Vice President Dominador Bazan, who is currently on a visit in Washington, and many influential U.S. congressional members, attended the reception to express their best wishes for the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CRITICIZES DPP MINORITY GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Several leading Kuomintang Standing Committee members criticized the Democratic Progressive Party administration Wednesday for what they called its failure to carry out effective operations.
Speaking at a meeting of the committee, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said that the so-called "government of all people" formed by President Chen Shui-bian on May 20 has virtually collapsed.

He went on to say that the DPP's "minority government," established after Premier Tang Fei's resignation last week, goes against the principles of responsible politics and is unable to operate effectively.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-pyng, a KMT vice chairman, said that new Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's call for "replacing confrontation with cooperation," is actually a manifestation of the DPP "pursuing its own interests."
Wang said that the KMT, which controls the most seats in the Legislative Yuan, must take the lead in directing national affairs and must take positive steps to solicit greater public support.
Chou Yu-jen, a National Policy Research Foundation fellow, was invited to make a special report on the prospects for the DPP minority administration.

Chou proposed that when a party controls the administration but does not enjoy a majority in the Legislative Yuan, the president should name the chairman of the party which controls a majority of seats as premier.
If no party controls a majority of seats, he said, a coalition government should be formed through negotiations among the political parties.
After listening to the report, Lien said that as an opposition party, the KMT should continue to participate in state affairs and play its proper role as the largest party in the Legislative Yuan.
Other KMT Standing Committee members, including Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Legislator Hsu Shu-po, also directed criticism against Chen's administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT MEETS WITH HAITIAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui met with Haitian President Rene Preval at Lee's office in suburban Taipei Wednesday.

During the one-and-a-half-hour discussion, they exchanged views on a broad range of issues, including agricultural development, information technology, political development, non-governmental organizations and biochemical technology.

Preval was in Taipei for the Double-Ten National Day celebrations at the invitation of the ROC government. This was his second trip to Taiwan, with the first visit taking place when Lee was president.
Lee told his visitor that after quitting the presidency last May, he has devoted himself to improving the livelihood of the nation's aboriginal residents through educational and religious channels.

He added that he has also begun to study biochemical technology, push for non-governmental assistance to developing countries, and study the possible impact that Taiwan'd entry into the World Trade Organization will have on domestic agriculture.
Preval expressed his appreciation for the ROC government's aid during Lee's tenure as president, citing programs to deliver hot meals to Haitian students and provide them with health care.
The two expressed their agreement that today's youngsters pay much more attention to political affairs than to agricultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S AVERAGE UNEMPLOYMENT PERIOD REACHES 22.5 WEEKS

TEXT.P: Blaming the lingering effects of the Asian financial crisis as well as last year's devastating earthquake, a Republic of China labor official reported that the average period of unemployment for jobless Taiwan laborers has reached 22.5 weeks this year.

Kuo Chi-jen, vice chairman of Taiwan's Council of Labor Affairs, said Wednesday in a report to the Legislative Yuan that Taiwan's unemployment rate usually fluctuated between 1 and 2 percent in the past. However, unemployment began to climb in 1994, reaching 3.6 percent in July of this year, he added.
He also noted that the average unemployment period in 1990 was only 14.8 weeks.
Kuo attributed the increase in unemployment to lingering effects of the Asian financial crisis and the temblor that struck Taiwan last year, which have made finding a job more difficult.
Meanwhile, with unemployed workers mostly middle-aged and elderly people, CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu told the legislature that public agencies should be the first to offer job opportunities to them.

She added that her council has commissioned some foundations to train the unemployed to do jobs such as child care, teaching, and housekeeping. She said some 14,000 people will be trained to do these jobs over the next year.
Chen added that the CLA will revise the nation's pension system and possibly stimulate the creation of part-time jobs, which might help middle-aged and elderly people re-enter the labor market.

She also indicated that in view of the imminent privatization of some state-run enterprises, the CLA will train laid-off workers with new skills, or create incentives for the employers themselves to offer such training courses, at the agency's expense.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO DISCUSS DISCIPLINARY MEASURES AGAINST KMT MINISTERS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's Evaluation and Discipline Committee is scheduled to meet Oct. 19 to discuss possible disciplinary measures against Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang, and Legislator Jao Yung-ching, all of whom are KMT members.

Committee director-general Chien Wei-chang said Wednesday that the KMT is displeased with Lin's decision to go against the party's pro-nuclear platform. The economics minister declared in a Sept. 30 recommendation to the Cabinet that he is against continuing the construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant.

Chien went on to say that his committee will also discuss whether Jao should be disciplined for his longtime anti-nuclear stance in the Legislature as well as for joining the so-called "supra-party cross-strait task force" despite the KMT's disapproval.

Chien added that because the new Cabinet has already become a "minority government" and essentially a "Democratic Progressive Party government" following the resignation of Tang Fei, a KMT stalwart, as the premier on Oct. 3, Yen should have reported to the KMT Central Standing Committee before accepting his new position in the Cabinet.
He added that his committee will also discuss whether other KMT ministers who remain in their Cabinet posts following last week's Cabinet reshuffle should report to the party again.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIRTUAL BANKS EMERGING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Virtual banks have increasingly become popular in Taiwan in the present e-commerce era, according to a local newspaper report by the Liberty Times.

The emergence of the so-called "virtual banks" indicates that the physical banks are becoming less important, as just a telephone call or logging on the Internet will provide customers with access to banks' services ranging from depositing and lending money, as well as offering investment, financial consultations and even firing complaints. Foreign banks, such as the ABN ARMO Bank, the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp. Ltd. and Citibank, N.A., which noticeably lag in numbers of branches as compared to domestic banks, are most active to seek scope in this area by planning to increase financial services on telephone on websites.

Taking Citibank for example, about 70 percent of the bank's total daily transactions are done at its financial services center. An average of 50,000 calls are made to the center per day, making the center one of the bank's most important units, the report said.
According to the report, Citibank spends around NT$500 million each over the past three years to explore business opportunities in this domain.

Cost assessments made by foreign banks themselves indicated that it costs about NT$140 for a bank to serve a client who personally visits its counter, while the expense to provide similar services through telephones, auto telling machines or online websites is only around NT$100.

Although "virtual banks" seem to be the dominant trend in the future, if judged from the prospective of a busy executive or investor, the report said, the new situation, however, represents a profound change for the vast majority of customers who are not used to dealing with just a strange voice on the other side of the telephone line.

A Citibank executive said customers will feel ill-at-ease if their calls are transferred several times or their e-mails get no answers from the banks, easily pushing them back to their old habits of visiting banks personally, he noted.
In efforts to tackle such problems, the key issue for those banking institutions interested in building a network of "virtual banks" is to win customers' trust, the Citibank executive pointed out.

According to the Citibank official, the bank requires that 80 percent of all the telephone calls reaching its financial services center must be answered within 15 seconds. Currently, only an average of two in each 100 calls are hanged up, while 92 percent of the customers' demands are met with just one call, he elaborated.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO INCREASE DIRECT TAIPEI-PENANG FLIGHTS
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Chen Yu-ping and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines will increase the number of direct flights it operates between Taipei and the Malaysian city of Penang from Oct. 26, a CAL source said Wednesday.

Lo Ting-hua, manager of CAL's branch office in Penang, said beginning Oct. 26, CAL will ply the Taipei-Penang route every Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday. On each of these weekdays, a CAL jetliner will take off from Taipei at 8 a.m. for a direct fly to Penang, leaving the Malaysian city at 4:50 p.m. to fly directly on its return to Taipei.

Eva Airways, another Taiwan airline, currently operates five direct Taipei-Penang flights per week. The increased CAL service will bring the number of weekly direct flights between Taipei and Penang to 10.

Lo noted that CAL began operating direct Taipei-Penang cargo service in 1996, and decided to operate direct passenger flights on the same route because of increasing demand from business travelers and tourists in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAITI HOPES TO LEARN FROM TAIWAN'S AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Haitian President Rene Preval visited the Republic of China Council of Agriculture Wednesday and obtained the council chairman's promise of aid for agricultural development in his country.

Chen Hsi-huang, chairman of the COA, told Preval, who arrived in Taipei Monday to attend celebrations of the ROC's National Day, that American economists in 1950 said that it would be very difficult to develop the economy of Taiwan, which had a per capita income reaching only US$160 and poor educational institutions at the time.
However, Chen added, the ROC has created an economic miracle thanks to its government's efforts to develop agriculture on a full-scale basis as the foundation of its industrial development.

Chen cited three steps which he said can serve as examples for Haiti in its economic development -- introducing foreign manufacturing technology, finding products suitable for processing and exporting, and improving manufacturing technology to expand export market.

Preval said Haiti and Taiwan share similar development conditions, as they are both island countries with mountainous topography. He added that therefore, Taiwan's experience in economic development serves as a good example for Haiti.

With most of the members of Haitian delegation having agricultural backgrounds, and some of them actually agricultural engineers, the eagerness of Haiti's government to learn something from Taiwan's agricultural development is apparent, Preval added.
Chen said that COA officials will accompany the Haitian delegation to visit various places around Taiwan so that they can better understand the country's agricultural biotechnology development.
The Haitian delegation is scheduled to depart from Taipei on Oct. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FINANCE MINISTRY WORKS TO DEFEND LOCAL STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Republic of China Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang held an emergency meeting Wednesday to discuss measures to stabilize the stock market, after which he announced the steps that his ministry will take.

Ahead of a defense of the psychologically-important 6,000-point level expected for Thursday in the face of bearish sentiment on the local bourse, the ministry declared that the Taiwan Stock Exchange will gather officials from 25 of the market's most heavily capitalized companies Thursday to exchange opinions on how to reverse the downward trend in stock prices.

The ministry also announced that it will promote the benefits of establishing a stock buyback system to 20 top companies next week, and added that the Securities and Futures Commission will coordinate with related government agencies to crack down on rumor-mongering aimed at manipulating stock prices.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange continued its downward streak Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 168.87 points to close at 6,040.55.

Selling pressure is expected to be immense Thursday, when the temporary measure that halved the regular 7 percent cap on the maximum allowable single-day fall in stock prices will no longer be in place. Stock market pessimism is being further fueled by the fact that the National Stabilization Fund has been ordered to prop up the market only until the end of the week.

The ministry noted that in the period from June 30 to Oct. 1, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.73 percent, the NASDAQ composite index lost 18 percent, the Nikkei stock average dropped 10.9 percent, and the Hang Seng index lost 6.37 percent; while the TAIEX dropped a whopping 26.92 percent despite strong exports, continually increasing foreign exchange reserves, and continued growth for listed companies.

The ministry went on to say that it will invite the heads of 25 of the island's largest publicly-traded companies, including China Steel, Acer, and Winbond Electronics, to exchange opinions on the local bourse's downward spiral.

It also plans to promote the idea of buying back outstanding stocks to the heads of 20 well-run companies that it says are oversold, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., United Microelectronics, China Petrochemical, Acer, China Airlines, President Enterprises, Taiwan Cement, Formosa Plastic, and Asustek Computer Inc.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO ENTRY FOR TAIPEI, BEIJING LIKELY TO BE POSTPONED TO EARLY 2001

TEXT.P: The entry of Taiwan and mainland China into the World Trade Organization is likely to be postponed until early next year, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said Wednesday.
Lin flew to Washington in early October to attend the fifth United States-Republic of China vice ministerial-level meeting on economic issues. He returned to Taipei on Wednesday.

While in Washington, Lin had exchanged views with U.S. Deputy Trade Representative Richard Fisher on the world economic situation, intellectual property rights, Taiwan's undersea cable market, government procurement and financial transparency.
Lin said the U.S. side did not formally express any concern to him over Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant, the construction of which the ruling Democratic Progressive Party intends to suspend.

The U.S. government considers the nuclear power project to be Taiwan's internal matter, and says that it is up to Taiwan alone to determine whether to continue the construction of the power plant, Lin said. He added that the U.S. side does expect Taiwan to fulfill the terms of the contracts it has signed with U.S. manufacturers.

U.S. firm General Electric Co. won the bid to build the two reactors for the controversial nuclear power plant in Kungliao, Taipei County, in 1995. The reactors had been scheduled to be shipped to Taiwan next year.
GE has said that after it receives official notification of the project's termination, it will begin to seek compensation from Taiwan Power Company.

As for the issue of Taipei's and Beijing's WTO entry, Lin quoted Fisher as saying that Beijing has not made sufficient progress toward meeting the terms for entry into WTO, so the entry of Taipei and Beijing into the world trade regulatory body will probably be postponed to early 2001, especially if there is no further progress in Beijing.
Beijing consistently insists that it must enter the WTO prior to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI OFFICIAL: TIES WITH TAIWAN TO REMAIN UNCHANGED
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Liu Cheng-ching and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Malawi official said in Beijing Wednesday that relations between his country and Taiwan will not be affected by his presence at the China-African Cooperation Forum currently being held in the mainland capital.

The director of the Malawi Foreign Ministry's Political Affairs Department, whose surname is Phiri, confirmed that Taiwan has made a great contribution to his country in terms of its economic development, but added that Taiwan alone cannot satisfy all of Malawi's needs for national development.

He added that Malawi is a developing country, and has to explore every possible resource to prop up its national development. He cited this as the reason for his presence at the forum, which he said is merely an attempt to establish cooperative ties with Beijing.

Phiri said that although the Beijing officials that greeted him at the airport proposed that official ties between mainland China and his country be established, he told the officials that he would not touch on the issue as his trip is mainly to discuss Malawi's exports of farm products to mainland China, as well as to solicit investment for his country.

He pointed out that almost all the members of the Southern African Development Community sent delegates to the forum; and his country, as a member of the community, is participating in the hopes of obtaining assistance from mainland China in the fields of medical care, education and infrastructure construction.
Phiri admitted that Beijing had communicated with Malawi through the two nations' embassies in the United Nations and Zimbabwe.
Taiwan is concerned about the fact that Malawi and Liberia, two of its diplomatic allies in Africa, are attending Beijing's forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WATCHING DIPLOMATIC MOVES OF MALAWI, LIBERIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government was closely watching the diplomatic moves of its two African allies -- Malawi and Liberia -- following media reports that the two countries might switch their diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, a Foreign Ministry official said Wednesday.
According to press reports, a Malawi official claimed in Beijing that Malawi and mainland China have been discussing the establishment of diplomatic relations.

The Malawi official, in Beijing for the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, further said that when he arrived at Beijing airport, a Beijing official had told him that Beijing had completed preparations for forging diplomatic relations.
The Taipei official noted that the credibility of the Malawi official's remarks remains unclear.
As an official from Liberia was also in Beijing attending the same forum, the Taipei official said that the ROC government was watching the situation closely.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Opposition KMT Chairman Lien Chan accuses the DPP minority government of violating the principle of political accountability.
The China Times:
Senior leaders meet at the Presidential Office to discuss stock market-boosting measures.
The United Daily News:
The Ministry of Finance unveils 3 new measures to prop up the sagging bourse as the daily slumping cap resumes 7 percent.
The Liberty Times:
The Ministry of Finance announces additional measures to bolster the bearish stock market.
The China Post:
TAIEX falls 2.7 percent as investors dump stocks.
The Taiwan News:
New efforts in the works to boost stocks.
The Taipei Times:
China agrees to forgive US$1 billion in African debt.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 235.54 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 235.54 points to close at 5,805.01.
Market turnover amounted to NT$57.29 billion (US$1.83 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER TO SELL REACTORS IF 4TH NUCLEAR POWER PLANT PROJECT SCRAPPED

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) will seek buyers for the reactors meant to be installed in the fourth nuclear power plant if the construction project is indeed scrapped, said Taipower President Kuo Chun-huei on Thursday.
Kuo said Taipower will seek buyers to help offset the unavoidable losses that the state-run company is going to incur if the project is brought to a halt.

Answering questions by lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan, Kuo noted that Taipower will also negotiate a settlement with U.S. General Electric Company, a major builder of nuclear reactors, regarding related facilities.
Kuo disclosed that Taipower has plans to contact several potential buyers abroad as a number of countries are beginning construction on their own nuclear power plants.
Kuo pointed out, however, that it is still too early to actually make the contacts abroad as the fate of the controversial project is still not clear.

Ex-Premier Tang Fei resigned on Oct. 3 due to stated health reasons, but it has been widely speculated that he actually stepped down because his support for the completion of the nuclear power plant put him in direct conflict with President Chen and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

The plant is already 33 percent finished, and some NT$48 billion (US$1.54 billion) has already been spent on it. Kuo said scrapping the plant will cost the country another NT$75 billion (US$2.41 billion) in compensation payments to contractors.

Meanwhile, DPP legislators asked Atomic Energy Council (AEC) Chairman Hsia Teh-yu, who was also present at the Legislative Yuan interpellation session, about new revelations that the fourth nuclear power plant is located near a fault, posing major safety threats in the event of an earthquake.

Hsia answered that the AEC has dutifully received safety assessment reports compiled by Taipower on concerns about the possible impact of earthquakes, typhoons, or tsunamis on the plant and that the reports found the nuclear power plant would be safe under all natural disaster scenarios.

Hsia however stressed that the AEC is willing to invite experts and scholars for further discussions on the plant's safety if the lawmakers have further misgivings about the plant's proximity to a fault line.
The AEC head meanwhile asked the lawmakers to help accelerate the passage of a legislation on radioactive waste management and related issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 235.54 points to close at 5,805.01.

Affected by a plunge in hi-tech stock prices in the United States, the bourse opened at 5,850.26, and due to lack of confidence on the part of investors, the index continued to go down. The bourse fluctuated between 5,981.67 and 5,763.81 during trading.

A total of 1.74 billion stocks worth NT$57.29 billion (US$1.83 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 0.92 billion stocks traded for a market turnover of NT$24.78 billion (US$0.79 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks moving down the most at 5.3 percent, followed by construction shares at 3.9 percent, textile issues at 2.9 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.3 percent, cement stocks at 1.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.7 percent, and pulp and paper issues and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 476 to 88, with 50 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 12, or the 15th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: After a month of experiencing mirages of land, explorer Christopher Columbus and his three ships sight "terra firma" at dawn.
1822: Brazil gains its independence from Portugal.
1901: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, renames the Executive Mansion "The White House." He won the 1908 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War.
1920: Bertrand A. W. Russell, British philosopher, mathematician, social critic, and writer who won the 1950 Nobel Prize for Literature, arrives in Shanghai as a visiting professor. He had a profound influence on the development of symbolic logic, logical positivism, and the set theory of mathematics.
1949: The Republic of China government moves its seat from Canton to Chungking.
1959: The United Nations General Assembly votes for a full-scale debate on Chinese Communist bloodshed in Tibet.
1960: Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev, angered during a debate on colonialism at the United Nations General Assembly, takes off his shoe and ponds his desk with it several times.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a friendship treaty in Taipei.
1968: The 19th Olympic Games opens in Mexico City, capital of Mexico.
1971: Dean Acheson, U.S. politician and secretary of state from 1949 to 1953, dies at the age of 78. He promoted the Marshall Plan and helped established NATO.
1974: Paul M. Popple, newly appointed deputy chief of the U.S. mission in the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: Juan Pao-shan, a Chinese student from Taiwan, is stabbed and killed in Los Angeles by leftists at a party in celebration of the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China.
1976: Communist China's Prime Minister Hua Guofeng becomes chairman of the Chinese Communist Party.
1977: The Civil Aeronautics Administration of the Communications Ministry inaugurates radar control in Taiwan air-space.
1979: Fidel Castro, head of the Cuban government, delivers a speech at the United Nations General Assembly, requesting more UN aid for third world countries.
1983: A Tokyo district court sentences former Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka to four years' imprisonment for his part in the Lockheed bribery scandal.
1984: In a move to further expand bilateral trade and economic relations, the ROC-Australia Trade Association and the Chinese-New Zealand Business Council are formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1986: During a display of ROC military power in the "Kuokuang Maneuvers," a combat skills exercise is held at a southern naval base.
1987: South Korea adopts a new constitution allowing direct election of the president by the people rather than by the electoral college.
1989: The Republic of China and Belize announce the establishment of diplomatic relations.
1989: Direct telephone links between Taiwan and the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu are completed.
1989: King Mswati III of Swaziland arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1992: A strong earthquake rocks Cairo, killing 552 people and injuring nearly 10,000 others.
1992: Premier Hau Pei-tsun receives Austrian Minister for Economic Affairs Wolfgang Schussel.
1999: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics estimates that property losses in Taiwan resulting from the Sept. 21 earthquake total US$9.2 billion.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is unobtrusive and yet it grows more and more in significance; whereas the life of the vulgar person is ostentatious, but it losses more and more in significance until it becomes nothingness."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taiwan stock index futures were lower Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization weighted index futures for October moved down 273 points to close at 5,715, with 9,062 contracts traded.

TAIEX Index futures for November decreased 291 points to finish at 5,730, with 645 contract transactions, while December futures plunged 355 points to close at 5,709, with 15 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Thursday at 5,988 for October, 6,021 for November, 6,064 for December, 6,098 for next March, and 6,213 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

October TE futures moved down 21.8 points to close at 289.75, with 1,975 contract transactions, while November TE futures decreased 21.65 points to finish at 288.15, with 192 contracts changing hands.
December TE futures fell 21.8 points to close at 294.95, with three contract transactions, while June 2001 TE futures lost 21.1 points to finish at 95, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March 2001 TE futures.
October TF futures moved down 11.2 points to close at 702, with 956 contract transactions, while November TF futures fell 19.2 points to finish at 706, with 47 contracts traded.
December TF futures fell 10.8 points to close at 716, with 46 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.
