DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REMAINS CAUTIOUS ON FINANCIAL AID TO SOLOMONS

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Wu Tzu-dan said Thursday that allegations that the Solomon Islands has demanded US$150 million in cash aid from Taiwan for maintaining diplomatic ties were based on sheer rumors.

Wu, who was reporting at the Legislative Yuan on the nation's latest diplomatic efforts and developments, said Taiwan is not going to abandon its Solomons ally, which is currently facing financial difficulties due to domestic political unrest.

He added, however, that additional financial assistance to the Solomon Islands will require negotiations and that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will be deliberate and cautious when making new decisions on this issue.
Wu stressed that Taipei will not make any new promises on financial aid before the government of the Solomons Islands presents a complete reconstruction plan.
Taiwan already allocates over US$10 million for the Solomon Islands every year, according to MOFA sources.

The unexpected absence of Solomon Islands' Foreign Minister Denny Philip from the Republic of China's National Day celebrations Tuesday triggered speculation that bilateral ties between the two countries may be hanging in the balance.

Despite the fact that the Solomon Islands' new Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare has said that Philip's visit to Beijing Wednesday was a "personal act" and that bilateral ties between the Solomon Islands and the ROC remain unchanged, Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao said Taiwan's attitude is to plan for the worst but hope the worst does not happen.

Tien admitted to New Party legislator Lai Shyh-bao that the Solomon Islands has indeed requested over US$20 million from Taiwan in emergency financial support, but added that Taipei is still considering the request because the ROC government does not think it is viable.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI OFFICIAL REAFFIRMS DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Malawi has no plans to forge official ties with mainland China as it still maintains normal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, a Malawi official said here Thursday.

Bywell Phiri, political affairs department chief at the Malawi Ministry of Foreign Affairs, made the remarks in response to an inquiry from Taiwan reporters about the reasons behind Malawi's decision to send him to attend the Beijing-sponsored forum on relations between mainland China and African countries.
Phiri said the just-concluded PRC-African forum was an international meeting with the joint participation of African countries.

"The main purpose of my attendance at the forum is to explore how Beijing conducts trade and economic exchanges with other African countries," Phiri explained, adding that Malawi is trying to develop trade and economic ties with mainland China through attending the forum.

Nevertheless, Phiri stressed that the primary mission of his Beijing visit was confined to discussing economic issues with mainland China and other African countries as well as to seeking possible trade and economic cooperation opportunities with other countries.

"Malawi has sent a delegation to take part in the Beijing forum simply because it wants to learn from the experience of other African countries in forging economic cooperation programs with as many countries as possible," Phiri reiterated.

Commenting on press reports that Malawi may switch diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing, Phiri said the reports are unfounded, adding that information about the establishment of diplomatic relations should be released by formal diplomatic channels, not the media.
Malawi was one of the two ROC diplomatic allies that have sent delegates to attend the PRC-African forum. The other ally was Liberia.
Malawi President Bakili Muluzi assured ROC Ambassador Chen Hsi-tsan earlier this week that Malawi has no intention of changing its longstanding cordial relations with the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar fell NT$0.002 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 31.300.
The local currency opened Thursday at 31.279 and was traded between 31.265 and 31.303.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$500.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIFICATION WITH TAIWAN BEIJING'S TOP SECURITY CONCERN: US REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing has in recent years viewed the goal of unification with Taiwan as its "top security concern" and has sped up its military modernization as a way of helping achieve that goal, according to a new U.S. congressional report released Tuesday.
Confirming a widely-held belief, the report prepared by the Congressional Research Service indicates a shift in the debate on mainland China's security concerns.

"Over the last two decades, the discussion of China's interests and challenges to regional stability has shifted from its role in the Cold War to domestic repression and instability to claims over the South China Sea to tensions over Taiwan," says the report.
"Especially since the mid-1990's, China has viewed its top security problem as preventing Taiwan's permanent separation and as securing unification as one China," it says.
"This focus has catalyzed the modernization of the People's Liberation Army, including the procurement of advanced foreign military equipment", it continues.

In the longer term, according to the report, experts believe that Beijing also aims to, among other things, preclude Japan's rise as the strongest power in Asia, support Beijing's territorial claims in the East and South China Seas, and counter American might in the region.

The 72-page report, entitled "China's Foreign Conventional Arms Acquisitions: Background and Analysis," is described as "one of the most comprehensive, unclassified assessments" on Beijing's conventional arms acquisitions.
It was prepared by the research arm of Congress upon the request of Sen. Daniel Akaka (D-Hawaii), ranking minority member of the Senate Governmental Affairs Subcommittee on International Security.

The report concludes that the operational significance of the PLA's qualitative upgrades through foreign arms acquisitions remains to be seen and will depend in part on its ability to achieve effective joint military operations through training.
Commenting on the report, Akaka said that "the Chinese are, for the first time in modern history, developing a capability to project air and naval forces beyond their coastal areas".
"The United States needs to seek ways to address any threat to American interests as a result of that capability," he said.

The congressional report examines the major foreign conventional weapon systems that Beijing has acquired or has committed to purchase since 1990, with particular attention to implications for U.S. security concerns.

Experts who prepared the report say the report does not assume that the PLA will engage in conflict with other forces in Asia, but they point out that since the mid-1990's, "there has been increasing concern about China's assertiveness in Asia and greater threats against Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATOR URGES AMERICA TO FACE THREAT POSED BY BEIJING

TEXT.P: In the wake of U.S. President Bill Clinton signing into law the bill that grants Communist China permanent normal trade relations, Sen. Jon Kyl (R-Ariz.) urged America to face the threat posed by Beijing to U.S. national security interests.

In a speech Tuesday on the Senate floor, Kyl explained that he voted for the PNTR bill because he recognizes the economic benefits it will have for many American workers, businesses, and customers, but added that "it is of utmost importance that we not lose sight of the fact that trade alone does not define our relationship with China. The actions and heated rhetoric of China's Communist leaders should be of great concern."

Chinese officials and state-sponsored media have time and time again made bellicose and threatening statements aimed at the United States and its long-standing, democratic ally -- Taiwan. They have even gone so far as to issue implied threats of using nuclear weapons against the United States, he noted.
"The question is, will we take them at their word on these defense matters as we did when they made trade commitments?" asked Kyl.

Moreover, he pointed out, the rhetoric from Beijing has also been accompanied by troubling actions. China has long-range nuclear-tipped missiles targeted at American cities and is greatly increasing the number of short-range missiles aimed at Taiwan. Moreover, it has taken steps to improve its ability to invade or blockade Taiwan and has proliferated missiles and weapons of mass destruction around the world.

Kyl noted that these are but a few of the many compelling reasons why the United States needs a national missile defense system to protect the country and to guarantee its freedom of action. It is also important for the United States to use the full range of economic and diplomatic tools available to halt China's proliferation of technology for missiles and weapons of mass destruction.

He said he believes the Senate missed an opportunity when it failed to pass an amendment offered by Sen. Fred Thompson (R-Tenn.) to combat this problem, but he added that hopes this legislation will be considered and passed next year.

In addition, the senator emphasized, "we need to ensure that strong export controls on U.S.-made products are in place so we don't inadvertently help China modernize its military. It remains to be seen whether the rhetoric from Beijing will become reality, but in light of China's troubling actions, prudence demands that we take steps to address China's behavior."

DOC.HEADLINE: TICKETS FOR PARALYMPIC GAMES SELLING LIKE HOT CAKES

TEXT.P: Tickets for the Paralympic Games have been selling like hot cakes six days ahead of the sports event termed as the world's largest in terms of the number of participating countries, according to the Sydney Paralympic Organizing Committee.
A SPOC spokesman told reporters on Wednesday night that nearly 750,000 tickets have been sold, including more than 70,000 out of the 87,000 available for the closing ceremony on October 29.
Tickets for all major sports competitions, including wheelchair basketball, power lifting, and the swimming finals, have been sold out, he said.
The Paralympic Games will begin on October 18 with the opening ceremonies, while actual competition will run from October 19 to 28.
Altogether, about 4,000 athletes from 125 countries will compete in 18 different events.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PITCHES FOR DIRECT AIRLINKS WITH RUSSIA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he hopes direct flight services between the Republic of China and Russia can be inaugurated as soon as possible.

Chen made the appeal while meeting with Oleg Ivanovich Lobov, chairman of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission (MTECCC), which is authorized by Russian authorities to handle exchanges with the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Chen said seven years have passed since Taiwan and Russia began to discuss establishment of direct airlinks. "I hope the two sides can accelerate negotiations and work together to overcome difficulties so that direct flight services can kick off soon to facilitate bilateral commercial, cultural, technological and academic exchanges," he urged.

The president also expressed his concern about Russia's arms sales to mainland China, saying such deals would pose potential threat to security and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region.
Therefore, Chen said the ROC looks forward to seeing Russia restrict quality and quantity of its weaponry sales to mainland China.
In addition, Chen said the ROC is interested in strengthening military, scientific and technological cooperation with Russia.
Meanwhile, Chen lauded Lobov for his achievements during his stints as Russian economics minister and first prime minister as well as for his efforts to promote substantive ROC-Russian ties.

Chen recalled that he had happy talks with current Russian President Vladimir Putin when he visited Moscow five years ago in his capacity as mayor of Taipei. At that time Putin was deputy mayor of Moscow.
Nowadays, Chen and Putin are the top leaders of their respective countries. Chen said he hopes their previous encounter can help boost the upgrading of substantive Taiwan-Russian relations.

Chen said the ROC hopes to invite former Russian President Boris Yeltsin to visit Taiwan, and that he himself also looks forward to visiting Moscow again in the not-too-distant future to pitch for closer cooperative ties.
For his part, Lobov expressed Russia's gratitude for the assistance and spiritual support extended by the ROC when the Russian nuclear-powered submarine Kursk sank in the Barents Sea in August.

As for the direct airlinks, Lobov said Russian airline Transaero has sent representatives to accompany him on his current Taipei visit. Lobov told Chen that Transaero representatives have reached a preliminary agreement with Taiwan's China Airlines on the opening of direct flight services between Taipei and Moscow. After the two companies work out some technical details, Lobov said, direct Taipei-Moscow flights can be inaugurated in the near future.
Lobov, heading a delegation of MTECCC officials and senior Russian business executives, arrived in Taipei earlier this week to attend the ROC's Oct. 10 National Day celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS MOST PEOPLE FEEL DOMESTIC ECONOMY WORSENING

TEXT.P: The majority of respondents to a recent public opinion poll feel that the domestic economy is deteriorating quickly, the opposition People First Party reported Thursday.
The PFP commissioned TVBS, a local cable TV channel, to conduct a telephone poll Wednesday with a view to exploring local people's confidence in Taiwan's business and economic prospects.

The poll of 803 adult residents randomly selected from around the island found that 81 percent of those interviewed said they feel Taiwan's present business climate is worse than last year's; 5.4 percent said they feel that the business climate remains almost the same; and 7.7 percent said they feel the general economic environment is better than a year ago.
Moreover, more than 50 percent said they think Taiwan's economic situation will deteriorate further next year, and only 25 percent gave an optimistic forecast.

Survey results also show that nearly 60 percent think the domestic inflationary pressure will become increasingly serious over the next year, and that 45 percent said they are worrying about the possibility of losing their current jobs.

As for the stock market prospects, 47.1 percent said they think local share prices will continue falling. Meanwhile, 39 percent said they think that the government should not intervene to prop up local share prices, while 40 percent said they prefer to see government intervention to prevent the bourse from plunging too drastically.
While 48 percent said they believe that the government's pump-priming measures can help buoy the sagging stock market, 32 percent said they think such government efforts will be of no avail.

The poll further found that 47.1 percent of those interviewed said they remain confident of the government's ability to address a host of financial and economic problems facing Taiwan, but about 40 percent said they have no confidence in the government's capability to resolve all those issues.

Noting that the poll results were like a no-confidence vote against the current Democratic Progressive Party-dominant minority government, National Chengchi University Yin Nai-ping said the government should craft out effective measures to resolve current economic plights in order to rekindle public confidence in the domestic economic prospects.

PFP spokesman Sun Ta-chien said the deterioration of Taiwan economy mainly results from chaos in the domestic political arena. As all residents on the island share the same destiny, Sun said, major opposition parties should refrain from making irrational or empty criticism of the government's policies and the ruling DPP should also honestly face the problems and take immediate measures to settle the issues for the benefits of all local residents.
Meanwhile, Sun said the DPP will call a meeting Friday to discuss strategy and concrete measures for addressing Taiwan's current economic and financial problems.

Sun said a number of former economic and financial officials and advisers to the previous government will attend the seminar to present their views and recommendations. Among the participants will be former Premier Hau Pai-tsun, Economics Minister Chao Yao-tung and Wang Chao-ming, a former vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER THANKS OVERSEAS CHINESE FOR SUPPORT OF DISASTER REGION
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, central Taiwan, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday in earthquake-ravaged Nantou County that the donations of overseas Chinese and their visit to the region offer "immeasurable encouragement" to the local people.

Over 6,000 overseas Chinese were in the central Taiwan county to attend a folk culture festival organized by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission as a part of events following ROC National Day celebrations on Tuesday.

Speaking at the festival, Chang pointed out that in the wake of last year's devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, which killed over 2,400 people, overseas Chinese have donated more than NT$1.9 billion (US$60.7 million) to disaster relief and reconstruction funds, while their domestic compatriots have given their time, money, and efforts for the same cause.
He added that the concern of the overseas Chinese can be deeply felt, and is proof that "blood is thicker than water."
Commission Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei urged the guests to help publicize the disaster region after they return to their foreign homes so that more people will visit the area.
County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien noted that many local hotels were fully booked during the visit by thousands of overseas Chinese, a substantial help for the region's floundering tourist industry.

A day earlier, the same group witnessed an aerial display by the ROC Air Force's second-generation fighter jets at an air force base in central Taiwan. An F-16 fighter, a Mirage 2000-5, a locally-designed Indigenous Defense Fighter, an Rf-5E reconnaissance plane and a E-2T AWACS flew in formation, followed by stunt flying by the "Thunder Tiger" squadron.
The overseas Chinese are scheduled to visit four different quake-ravaged areas in the coming two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 MORE RETIRED NAVAL OFFICERS QUESTIONED IN GRAFT CASE

TEXT.P: The panel in charge of probing arms procurement graft summoned two retired naval officers Thursday, to further clarify certain points in the case surrounding the death of Naval Captain Yin Ching-feng.

The panel summoned Rear Admiral Shen Feng-ping, former director of the Planning Department of the General Headquarters of the Navy, and Captain Chang Jui-fan, a former section chief under the Operations Department of the General Headquarters of the Navy. Both Shen and Chang were members of the six-member arms procurement panel in charge of purchasing French-made Lafayette frigates.
A spokesman for the panel said that the investigators want to probe the procedures used in the purchase, and whether other high ranking officers were also involved in the case.
The six-member procurement assessment panel visited France and Saudi Arabia before the decision to purchase the six "stealth" frigates was made.

Additionally, the panel has detained three other ranking military officers since President Chen Shui-bian's July order to probe the arms procurement graft case surrounding the death of Naval Captain Yin Ching-feng.

In related news, Lu Jen-fa, state public prosecutor general, who also heads the panel probing the arms procurement graft case, admitted in a Legislative Yuan interpellation session that the panel has not yet summoned any active ranking military officers.
But Lu told members of the Judicial Committee of the Legislative Yuan that the panel will summon active ranking military if such action is needed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PHILIPPINE ECONOMIC ASSOCIATIONS TO HOLD JOINT MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The 15th Joint Meeting of the ROC-Philippine Economic Association and the Philippine-ROC Economic Association will be held in Manila on Friday.

Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the ROC-Philippine Economic Association and Tung Shan-chen, chairman of the Philippine-ROC Economic Association, will jointly preside over the opening ceremony of the one-day event.
Philippine Minister of Commerce and Industry A. Rojas and Chan Hsian-ching, ROC representative in Manila, will be invited to address the opening ceremony.
A 32-member Taipei delegation led by Koo traveled to Manila Thursday to attend the meeting.
Discussions will be centered on how to strengthen bilateral economic cooperation in the process of globalization.
More than 100 Chinese and Philippine business leaders will take part in the discussions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOUD GATE DANCE THEATRE PERFORMS IN BERLIN
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre performed a dance titled "Portrait of the Families" to an enthusiastic response from the audience at a dance festival in Berlin Thursday.

The Cloud Gate dancers had greatly impressed the European art community during last year's Berlin Festival, when they performed a dance titled "Moon Water." The festival organizers therefore invited Cloud Gate back for this year's festival, along with other world famous troupes such as the Frankfurt Ballet.

Charles King, Taipei's representative in Germany, held a party at the Schiller Theatre to introduce the Cloud Gate performers to the Berlin Festival audience. It was an opportunity for Lin Hwai-min, Cloud Gate founder and artistic director, to meet many German art and literary figures.

The troupe gave the first of its three scheduled performances in the Schiller Theatre to a packed audience Wednesday night. About 20 dancers performed in "Portrait of the Families," a 100-minute examination of the last 100 tumultuous years of Taiwanese history from the point of view of the family. The performance is said to incorporate abstract dance, modern slide projection, and recordings of Taiwanese telling their life stories in a variety of regional dialects.
When Lin and the dancers made curtain-calls at the end of the performance, the thunderous ovation from the audience lasted for more than 10 minutes.
Many overseas Chinese residing in Germany came to the performance. Some were moved to tears by the depiction of the tumultuous years in the development of Taiwan.

A critic from the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (Frankfurt General News), commenting on "Portrait of the Families," said that Cloud Gate had proved once more that it is a world class troupe, on par with the best dance performers in Europe and the Americas.

Before coming to Berlin, Cloud Gate had given 10 performances at the Lyon Biannual Dance Festival. After its three performances in Berlin, Cloud Gate will begin a U.S. tour that will take the troupe to Kansas, New Jersey and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUNDBREAKING HELD FOR TAIWAN'S 1ST PRIVATE HYDROPOWER PLANT
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan County, southern Taiwan, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The groundbreaking for construction of Taiwan's first privately run hydraulic power plant was held Thursday at Wushantou Reservoir in Tainan County.

Co-funded by the Chiayi-Tainan Farmland Water Conservation Association and Formosa Chemical and Fiber Corp., the hydroelectric power plant is scheduled to be completed in December 2001, with an estimated annual electricity production of 42.16 million kilowatts.
The hydropower plant will be built next to the reservoir's outflow point, and its total cost has been estimated at NT$340 million.

At present, there are 39 hydraulic power plants around the island, all of which were constructed by the state-run Taiwan Power Co. Together, they account for 17 percent of the island's total electricity-generation capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRAY ARMY SHELL HITS RICE PADDY, NONE INJURED
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin County, southern Taiwan, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A stray shell from a live ammunition military exercise flew four kilometers off target into a neighboring county in southwestern Taiwan Thursday and exploded in a rice paddy, but fortunately no one was injured.

According to the police, farmers in a Yunlin County village heard a blast at around noon and followed the source of the explosion to find a three-meter long, two-meter wide, and one-meter deep hole in a rice paddy approximately 100 meters from the village.

The farmers, finding shrapnel around the crater, immediately reported the incident to the police, who confirmed with the military that an artillery unit of the Republic of China's southern Eighth Field Army, ten kilometers away, was conducting live firing exercises in neighboring Changhua County at around the same time.

The military then dispatched a team to the village and confirmed that the exploded shell indeed belonged to the artillery unit, which had been aiming for a creek bed approximately four kilometers from the village.

Army officers at the scene said that an overload of gunpowder may have caused the accident, adding that the military is very sorry to have frightened the farmers and will compensate them as appropriate.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOMB HOAX DELAYS MANDARIN AIRLINES PASSENGERS

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines passengers suffered a delay Thursday when the airline received telephone calls saying that explosives were planted on one of its planes.

The plane used for Mandarin Airlines Flight No. 762, a Fokker-50, took off from Taichung at 4:35 p.m., with 56 passengers and four crew heading for Taipei. Right after the plane's takeoff, the airline's Taichung branch office received calls saying that explosives were on the plane.
Taking the calls seriously, Mandarin Airlines immediately notified the airport's control tower and police.

After the plane landed safety at Sungshan Airport in Taipei, its passengers were told that there would be a delay before they could leave the plane. In an effort to soothe the passengers, the airline gave each of them a red envelope with NT$200 (US$6.4) -- a token Chinese gift symbolizing good luck.
At 6 p.m. all passengers and luggage were ferried by shuttle bus to the terminal, where airport police authorities searched all of the passengers and their luggage for any possible explosives.
As no explosives were found, the airline said later that the hoax must have been the result of some mischievous person.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAITIAN PRESIDENT VISITS CENTRAL TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL ESTABLISHMENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Visiting Haitian President Rene Preval visited a rice mill and a rice seedling center in Nantou County's Tsaotun Township Thursday.

In addition to his wife, Preval was accompanied on the trip by Chiou Jong-nan, Republic of China ambassador to Haiti, Lee Chien-chuan, deputy chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, and Lai Ying-feng, Nantou County deputy magistrate.

The Haitian head of state observed the rice mill technology with interest, and noted that Haiti's climate and human affairs are very similar to Taiwan. He added that he is happy to have the chance to observe Taiwan's agricultural development during his stay here.

Lee noted that the COA has arranged a schedule for President Preval to learn about Taiwan's irrigation systems, agricultural research and development programs, marketing system and farmers' associations.
Earlier in the day, Preval and his entourage visited a persimmon production and marketing zone at Tantze Township in Taichung County.
During that tour, Taichung County Deputy Magistrate Liu Shih-feng welcomed Preval on behalf of the people and government of his central Taiwan county.

Preval responded by saying that he was deeply impressed by Taiwan's advanced agricultural technology. He added that he hopes he will have the chance to further study Taiwan's agricultural development and successful marketing experience.
Later in the day, Preval and his entourage also visited a pineapple and mushroom farm at Hsinshe Township, also in Taichung County.
Preval arrived in Taipei on Oct. 9 for an official eight-day visit to the Republic of China. He also attended celebrations of the ROC's Double Tenth National Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TRANSPORTATION MINISTER CALLS ON PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Yeh Chu-lan, Republic of China Minister of Transportation and Communications, called on Philippine President Joseph Estrada Thursday to exchange views on matters related to the two countries.
Yeh, who arrived here Monday, described the meeting as cordial, and noted that it lasted for more than half an hour.

Yeh is the first ROC minister to visit the Philippines since the recent resumption of direct air links between the ROC and the Philippines after a hiatus of 10 months. Manila has reportedly attached great importance to her visit.

During her stay here, she called on the Philippine ministers of finance, trade and industry, tourism, and labor and employment. As Transportation and Communications Minister Vincente Rivera is currently overseas, she called on his deputy.
Yeh noted that she is keeping a "low profile" during this visit, and added that she came here to "make friends, and to convey friendship."
She said that her visit had opened the gate for all kinds of exchanges between the two countries, including those in trade, culture, and tourism.
Yeh also extended an invitation to the Philippine tourism minister to visit Taiwan November 3, to attend a Taipei meeting on tourism.

On the issue of Filipino laborers in Taiwan, Yeh suggested that the two governments establish better communications between each other to cut down on exploitation by labor brokers and benefit Filipino workers.
Yeh is scheduled to return to Taiwan Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER FRENCH INSTITUTE IN TAIWAN OFFICER DEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Thierry Imbot, a former officer at the French Institute in Taiwan who helped seal the deal to sell six French-made Lafayette frigates to Taiwan -- now at the center of major scandals in both countries -- died Tuesday after apparently falling from a fifth floor window.

According to a Thursday report in the mass circulation newspaper La Liberation, police have cordoned off the yard surrounding Imbot's apartment and have begun investigating his death. They have not dismissed the possibility that it may have been more than a simple case of accidental death, citing his "unusual" background.

Imbot, 48, had also worked in the French embassy in Beijing, and founded a consultant company in the United States to promote arms sales to various African nations. His father, Gen. Rene Imbot, was the head of the French intelligence agency from 1985 to 1987, and had recruited the younger Imbot to serve in the foreign arm of France's intelligence system.
According to the French Foreign Ministry, Imbot also held a U.N. position at the time of his death.

Police said that there was no sign of a break-in and that Imbot's bathroom window above the yard was open. Preliminary investigations suggest that he may have been trying to close the window when he fell to his death. No signs of physical struggle was found on his body.
Police added that several boxes in Imbot's apartment were still unopened, suggesting that he had moved in only recently.

Imbot's name appeared under many successful contracts to buy French arms, including the Lafayette sale, which allegedly led to the death of a Republic of China Navy captain in 1993, after which Imbot left Taiwan.

Earlier in the year, reports from Paris that huge kickbacks were paid to Taiwan officials for the purchase of the frigates fueled speculation that the naval captain's death was just the tip of the iceberg, and that an attempt was being made to cover up massive corruption involving senior military officers and government officials in both Taiwan and France.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERDUE LONAS OF 7 STATE-RUN BANKS HITS NEW RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: The total overdue loans of Taiwan's seven state-run banks set a record high of NT$354.19 billion as of the end of September, according to statistics compiled by a banking institute.
The same statistics also showed that the ratio of overdue loans averaged 5.26 percent, also a new record high.

According to the figures, overdue loans for the Bank of Taiwan totaled NT$35.58 billion as of the end of September, an increase of NT$2.36 billion over the previous month's level. The bank's overdue loans ratio was 2.63 percent, up 0.15 percentage points from that of August.

Taiwan Cooperative Bank's reported overdue loans as of the end of September totaled NT$66.19 billion, a decrease of NT$740 million over the previous month. Its overdue loan ratio was 5.81 percent, a decrease of 0.04 percentage points compared with the previous month.

The Land Bank of Taiwan's bad loans as of the end of September amounted to NT$60.23 billion, a monthly increase of NT$490 million. The ratio was 5.99 percent, 0.11 percentage points higher than at the end of August.

The Medium Business Bank of Taiwan registered overdue loans of NT$39.7 billion in the same period, increasing NT$490 million from August's level. The bank's bad loan ratio was 5.99 percent, up 0.11 percentage points.

Overdue loans held by Hua Nan Commercial Bank reached NT$48.34 billion, an increase of NT$430 million over the previous month's level. The ratio was 6.05 percent, a decrease of 0.03 percentage points as compared with that of August.
Meanwhile, First Commercial Bank's bad loans stood at NT$49.39 billion, a monthly decrease of NT$160 million. Its bad loan ratio was 5.8 percent, down 0.04 percentage points from August.

Finally, overdue loans held by Chang Hwa Commercial Bank reached NT$54.88 billion, an increase of NT$1.28 billion compared with August. The bank's bad loan ratio was 6.84 percent, an increase of 0.15 percentage points over August.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT VOWS TO ENHANCE TIES AMERICAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and the first lady attended a "Night of the Americas" banquet Thursday at the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel in Taipei.

The event was jointly sponsored by the 18 countries in the region that maintain embassies or representative offices in Taiwan. The party was held to mark this year's Columbus Day -- the 508th anniversary of the first cross-Atlantic voyage of Christopher Columbus.
ROC Premier Chang Chun-hsiung also attended the banquet.

In an address to the assembled guests, Chen praised the progress of regional integration on the American continents. The ROC president said he hopes that Taiwan and its allies in the Americas will strengthen their friendship and bilateral relations, work out measures to handle common concerns, and step up their participation in global affairs.
"Only non-stop communications and interchange can reduce each nation's mental barriers so as to jointly build a global symbiosis," the ROC head of state said.
He exhorted both Taiwan and the American nations to strengthen cultural interchange and mutual friendship so as to build a peaceful, prosperous and harmonious family.

Cross-Pacific interchange and cooperation are daily helping to develop both sides, and the multilateral Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation Forum represents the model for a globe without barriers, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL AND SOUTH AMERICA GOOD MARKETS FOR TAIWAN PRODUCTS: CETRA
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council on Thursday urged Taiwan businesses to tap the Central and South American markets.
CETRA officials made the call at a symposium to introduce trade developments in the Central and South American markets.

CETRA said the abandonment of political arguments in favor of economic development through competition has become a global trend, adding that the Southern Common Market, or MERCOSUR, has gradually integrated and strengthened the economies of its members -- Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay.
CETRA indicated that Central and South America are not only a diplomatic stronghold for the Republic of China, but also a major regional market for the ROC's exports.

Noting that MERCOSUR plans to incorporate all South American nations into a single free trade area in the future, CETRA said that increased competitiveness will result, a matter that cannot be ignored.

MERCOSUR occupies an area of 11.9 million square kilometers, accounting for 70 percent of that of Latin America; and has a population of 208 million, accounting for 64 percent of the total population of Latin America.

The common market's trade volume last year came to US$160.01 billion. MERCOSUR's most popular products include processed agricultural goods, livestock, forestry products, telecommunications, computer peripheral equipment, medicines and steel.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC WRITERS ELATED OVER CHINESE WINNING NOBEL LITERATURE AWARD

TEXT.P: Local writers were elated Thursday to hear that Gao Xingjian, a Chinese dissident playwright and author, had won the first Nobel prize for literature ever given to a Chinese in the award's 100-year history.
The Swedish Academy in its citation praised Gao "for an oeuvre of universal validity, bitter insights and linguistic ingenuity, which has opened new paths for the Chinese novel and drama."
Gao, born in 1940, was encouraged to write, paint and play the violin from an early age. He later studied French and literature at the Beijing Foreign Language Institute.
Considered the leading contemporary Chinese dramatist, Gao introduced the avant-garde ideas of European theater to Chinese audiences.
Gao left mainland China in 1987 and moved to France, opting for permanent residence there after the Tiananmen Square massacre of June 1989.
Wang Chi-lung, chairman of the Chinese Art and Literature Association, said that although the recognition is belated, it nevertheless has brought joy to all Chinese people.

Wang said that he feels that the central feature of Gao's work is his humanitarian spirit. The philosophy of life in his literature is very distinctive, which has helped his works and Chinese literature in general to win recognition in world literary circles, Wang said.
Gao's play "The Other Shore" was performed in Taiwan about a decade ago, Wang added.

The writer and historian Kuo Yi-tung, whose pen name is Po Yang, said he never got the chance to know Gao. But as Chinese have won Nobel prizes in physics and chemistry, he said he is excited to see a Chinese finally took the literary award, adding that it will encourage future Chinese writers to have a wider scope in their writing.

Writer Lucy Chen recounted that she met Gao in Beijing during the mid-1980s, and she felt at the time that Gao was a passionate man. She said that he was dancing at the time in celebration of the performance of his play -- and his divorce.

Noting that Chinese literature is rich and beautiful, both Wang and Po expressed the hope that more Chinese works can be translated into English and other languages, so that more people can appreciate the beauty of Chinese literature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 13, or the 16th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
A.D. 54: Claudius I, 64, Roman emperor and historian, dies after supposedly consuming poisoned mushrooms dished up by his fourth wife, his niece Agrippina. Shortly before his death, Claudius had agreed to acknowledge Nero, Agrippina's son by a former marriage, as his heir instead of his natural son, Britannicus.
1792: U.S. President George Washington lays the foundation stone of the White House.
1812: British forces under Sir Isaac Brock defeat the Americans at the battle of Queenston Heights, helping to put an end to the U.S. attempt to invade Canada.
1884: Greenwich, England, is adopted as the universal meridian from which standard times throughout the world are calculated.
1913: Representatives from China, Britain, and Tibet attend a meeting held in Simla, India to discuss various problems concerning Tibet.
1923: Ankara becomes the capital of Turkey.
1925: Margaret Thatcher, British Conservative politician and prime minister from 1979 to 1990, is born. Her administration was marked by anti-inflationary measures, a brief war in the Falkland Islands (1982), and the passage of a poll tax.
1939: Adolf Hitler tries without success to persuade U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt to mediate peace between Germany, France, and Britain.
1943: Italy declares war on Germany, its former Axis partner.
1949: ROC government troops evacuate Canton.
1960: The Institute of History and Philology of the Academia Sinica begins excavations at dwellings of the Yin people in Anyang County, Hunan Province, once the capital of the dynasty before 1200 BC.
1964: Three Soviet cosmonauts operating Voshkod, the world's first multi-seat spacecraft, land safely after a 24-hour journey.
1968: Liu Shao-chi, state chairman of Communist China, is purged at the 12th Plenum of the 8th Chinese Communist Party Central Committee held in Beijing.
1970: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severance of diplomatic relations with Canada.
1974: U.S. Senator Hiram Leong Fong of Hawaii arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1980: President Pieter W. Botha of South Africa is presented with the Key to the City of Taipei by Mayor Lee Teng-hui upon arrival for a state visit.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui presents a Key to Taipei to Mayor Leon Amon of the Ivory Coast's Dimbokro City.
1988: The Shroud of Turin, for centuries regarded as the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, is shown by carbon-dating tests to date from between 1260 and 1390 in the Middle Ages, a period rife with forgeries.
1993: The United Nations Security Council decides to resume an oil-and-arms embargo against Haiti after Haitian military leaders fail to follow an agreement to allow President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to return to office and restore a democratic government.
1995: Joseph Rotblat, the nuclear physicist who devoted his life to trying to ban the bomb he helped create, wins the 1995 Nobel Peace Prize.
1995: France rejects appeals to abandon nuclear tests in the South Pacific.
1997: Adil Carcani, who served as the last Communist prime minister of Albania under the late Stalinist dictator Enver Hoxha and his successor Ramiz Alia, dies at the age of 75.
1998: Daniel Chee Tsui, professor at Princeton University and a member of Academia Sinica, becomes one of the three co-winners of the 1998 Nobel Prize for Physics.
1999: A Jordanian Royal Air Force transport plane airlifts 14,600 kilograms of relief goods to Taipei to help surviving victims of the devastating earthquake that rocked Taiwan on Sept. 21.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is plain, and yet not unattractive; it is simple, and yet full of grace; it is easy, and yet methodical."

DOC.HEADLINE: CATHAY PACIFIC PLANE MAKES UNEXPECTED LANDING

TEXT.P: A Cathay Pacific airplane made an unexpected landing at CKS International Airport Friday morning for safety reasons.

The flight No. CS-410 plane took off from Hong Kong for Seoul, but the pilot requested permission to land at Taiwan's main airport after he noticed what seemed to be the smell of burning wires in the cabin. The Airbus 340 plane landed safely at 11:20 a.m.
Fire fighting and emergency vehicles were on hand when the plane landed to deal with any problems. They were sent away after the pilot said there was no need for their services.

The 99 passengers onboard were asked to exit the plane and wait in the airport so that airport authorities could carry out a thorough security check of the plane. The passengers were provided with lunch while they waited.
Flight aviation safety personnel inspecting the plane found one damaged part and a broken fuse.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER TO REPRESENT PRESIDENT CHEN AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has designated Vice Premier Lai In-jaw to attend the eighth informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum on his behalf, the Presidential Office said Friday.
The Presidential Office made the announcement after President Chen met with Brunei's APEC envoy Pengiran Hajyusof.
According to the Presidential Office, Chen informed Hajyusof during their meeting that he has decided to appoint Lai to represent him at the annual APEC summit to be held in Brunei in mid-November.
In response, Hajyusof was quoted as having told Chen that Brunei accepts and welcomes Lai's attendance at the APEC summit meeting on Chen's behalf.

During their talks, Chen also told the Brunei envoy that Lai is an economic and financial expert and that the Republic of China is more than willing to share its economic development experience with other APEC members.
Chen further expressed Taiwan's desire to expand substantive relations and cooperation with other APEC member economies.

APEC is one of the few government-to-government international organizations that simultaneously accepts Taiwan and mainland China as its full members. Because of Beijing's recalcitrant opposition, the ROC president has been barred from attending the annual APEC informal leadership meeting personally and must instead appoint a proxy to take part in the conference.

Vincent Siew, a former premier, twice represented former President Lee Teng-hui at the APEC summit during his stint at chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Another former CEPD chief, P. K. Chiang, and Koo Chen-fu, a senior presidential adviser and Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, also had attended the APEC leadership meetings on Lee's behalf.
Lai, a former grand justice who now also heads a Cabinet financial and economic task force, will be the highest-ranking government official to represent the ROC president at the annual APEC summit.
APEC, a 21-member regional forum, is dedicated to promoting free trade and investment to boost regional economic integration and cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. LAWMAKERS CONGRATULATE ROC ON ITS NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: Congratulating the people of Taiwan as they celebrated the 89th Republic of China National Day, U.S. Sen. Jim Bunning (R-Ky.) told the Senate Tuesday that with strong and continued American support, Taiwan will thrive and prosper far into the future.

Bunning added that the success of Taiwan must continue to "serve as an example -- as well as a challenge -- to the people and government on the Chinese mainland. The free, prosperous, democratic society that Taiwan has become is a glimpse of what can come to be on the mainland if the dictatorship in Beijing would get out of the way."

Over the last few days, seven members of the U.S. House of Representatives also congratulated the ROC for its many remarkable achievements during the past decades, with Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) declaring that he strongly supports Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization even before Communist China is admitted.

Taiwan has become "a beacon of democracy in the Asia-Pacific region, and the government of Communist China should never forget the importance of the freedom of Taiwan to the people of the United States," Rohrabacher stated on the House floor last Friday.
Rep. Jennifer Dunn (R-Wash.) praised Taiwan as "truly a model of success for many countries in the world," saying that "Taiwan deserves our congratulations and our support."

On the occasion of the ROC's National Day, Rep. Rick Hill (R-Mont.) pointed out that "it is important to remember that Taiwan has a strong relationship with the United States and we hope that this relationship will continue to flourish in the years to come."

Other congressmen who congratulated Taiwan and voiced their support for its bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations were Rep. Roscoe Bartlett (R-Md.), Rep. Phil English (R-Pa.), Rep. Tom Lantos (D-Calif.), and Rep. John Larson (D-Conn.).

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC NOT CONSIDERING OPENING TAIWAN'S LABOR MARKET TO MAINLANDERS

TEXT.P: The government is not at the present time considering liberalizing regulations to allow mainland Chinese laborers to work in Taiwan, said an official in charge of mainland China policy Friday.

Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks while attending a public hearing on the three direct links across the Taiwan Strait and on the rights of laborers.
The public hearing held at the Legislative Yuan was sponsored by Legislator Wang Tuo of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Chen said that if direct trade, postal, and transport links are established between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, then cross-strait trade will replace Taiwan's large-scale investment in the mainland and job opportunities for local laborers will hinge on the development of Taiwan's economy.
If the economy continues to grow, then local laborers' job opportunities will not decrease and their rights will be ensured.
He said that as the impact of opening Taiwan's labor market to mainlanders would be too large, the MAC's policy is to not do so even if the current ban on the three direct links is lifted.

On the government's plan to recruit more high-technology talent from mainland China, Chen said Taiwan is still short tens of thousands of such workers and so there is a need to introduce more such talent, which he said will have a positive effect on economic growth and will have no direct impact on the rights of Taiwan's laborers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 71.1 points to close at 5,876.11.

The bourse opened at 5,577.86, but due to a rebound in both financial and electronics stock prices, the index began to go up. The bourse fluctuated between 5,876.11 and 5,482.98 during the day's trading.

A total of 2.39 billion stocks worth NT$75.62 billion (US$2.42 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.74 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$57.29 billion (US$1.83 billion).
Three of the eight major categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 0.3 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.2 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 5.1 percent, followed by cement stocks at 3 percent, construction shares at 1.9 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.3 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 346 to 192, with 85 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: `COMMONWEALTH OF GREATER CHINA' SAID BEST CROSS-STRAIT SOLUTION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The formation of a `Commonwealth of Greater China' would be the best solution to the cross-Taiwan Strait impasse, said a Washington-based China expert on Thursday.

Jay Taylor, author of the book titled The Generalissimo's Son: Chiang Ching-kuo and the Revolution in China and Taiwan, said the Taiwan development experience during the Chiang Ching-kuo era is sufficient for mainland China to emulate and the formation of a commonwealth is the most viable option for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to break their deadlock.

During a seminar held at the Congress Library, Taylor, a fellow with Harvard University's Fairbank Center for East Asian Research, said if President Chiang Ching-kuo had lived a few years longer, the current situation across the Taiwan Strait would have been starkly different and Deng Xiaoping, known for being strongly in favor of peaceful unification of mainland China and Taiwan, also would not have ordered the bloody suppression of the democracy movement in Tiananmen Square in 1989.

Taylor, who has been serving at both the U.S. liaison office in Taiwan and the U.S. embassy in Beijing, said if Chiang were still alive today, he would definitely suggest that President Chen Shui-bian support the "one China" policy.

Ralph Clough, a China hand with the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University, seconded Taylor's comments, saying that if President Chiang Ching-kuo were still around, he would suggest that Chen forsake the notion of Taiwan independence.

If mainland China and Taiwan formed a so-called Commonwealth of Greater China, the Chinese Communists would be freed from worries of losing Taiwan as part of China's sovereign territory, noted Taylor, adding that Beijing would then be able to allow Taiwan to participate in international organizations in the island's capacity as a member of the Commonwealth of Greater China, fulfilling Taiwan's long held desire to widen its international horizons.
Taylor, who also has worked at the White House National Security Council, said that under this scenario, Chen might even become the first popularly elected president of the commonwealth.

In 1976, the year Mao Zedong died, President Chiang Ching-kuo accurately forcast Deng Xiaoping's reemergence on the political stage, thus prompting him to accelerate democratization in Taiwan, Taylor noted.

Clough, who also served in the U.S. Embassy in Taipei, said when President Chiang Ching-kuo appointed Lee Teng-hui as his vice president, Chiang believed that Lee would continue to promote Taiwan's democratization.

Despite the fact that wide gaps still exist across the Taiwan Strait in many areas, the situation in mainland China, particularly the government's efforts at strangling opposition parties and seeking further economic development, is pretty much the same as that in Taiwan 20 years ago, said Taylor.
"Mainland China is now also on its way towards democratization, only the process is much slower," he added.
"Democracy is a modern phenomenon, not a Western system, and it means the people choose what they want, regardless of religion, economy, or politics," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE LAUNDRY EXHIBIT BECOMES PERMANENT AT CANADIAN MUSEUM

TEXT.P: The exhibit titled "Enduring Hardship: Chinese Hand Laundry" was unveiled Thursday as part of a permanent display in the popular Canada Hall of the Canadian Museum of Civilization.
The new exhibit features a re-created Chinese hand laundry, based in part on the Central Laundry in Winnipeg, Manitoba, which was operated for many years by the late Ho King.

The exhibit recreates the ambiance of the Chinese laundries found in large numbers across Canada between 1900 and the 1950s. Artifacts from Ho's and other laundries, as well as documentary footage featuring interviews and individual recollections, give visitors an intimate and compelling look at the difficult lives led by many of Canada's early Chinese immigrants.

Guests and journalists were treated to a visit first to a counter area and then a kitchen area. At the laundry working area, one can get a feel for how difficult the tasks of washing and boiling were. It's easy to learn of the hard physical work carried out by the laundry men in a cramped and steamy environment.

Laundry was an essential means of livelihood for Chinese Canadians during the first half of the 20th century. To many of the laundry men's descendants, the hand laundry is a symbol not only of hardship, but of survival, endurance, patience, and sacrifice for the future.

Large numbers of Chinese laborers were brought to Canada between 1858 and 1885 to build railways and dig mines. They then went to different places along the Canadian Pacific Railway to set up laundry businesses as few other jobs were available to them.

Museum documents show that, at that time, Chinese immigrants were discouraged from entering other occupations and were subjected to legal restrictions and socio-economic discrimination. Running a laundry, which required little capital but long hours of hard work, thus became a common business for Chinese immigrants who spoke little English or French. In 1921, for example, Montreal had a Chinese population of 1,735 and 368 laundries run by Chinese people.
The hand laundry trade petered out in the 1960s with the aging of the early Chinese immigrants, but it remains an unforgettable part of Chinese Canadian history.

The exhibit was launched along with another titled "Canadian heritage: Alberta Oil Rig of the 1920s." The museum's President and CEO Victor Rabinovitch said these two new modules are "part of ongoing efforts to tell a full and accurate version of Canadian history."

Ranking officials from both Taipei and Beijing, including mainland Chinese Ambassador Mei Ping and James Tien, public affairs director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office, were invited to attend the unveiling ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO MEMBERS URGED TO GET SERIOUS ON FARM TRADE REFORM

TEXT.P: Ministers attending the meeting of the Cairns Group in Banff, Canada, have called on members of the World Trade Organization to get serious about agricultural trade reforms.

In a statement faxed to the CNA on Friday morning, Australia's Trade Minister Mark Vaile, who serves as chairman of the Cairns Group, said the group was "united and resolved to ensure that the current agricultural negotiations conclude successfully as soon as possible."

"We have reached a critical stage in the agricultural negotiations and it's now time for all WTO members to put their reform proposals on the table. The time has come to make good on the commitment made during the Uruguay Round to deliver a fair and market-based agricultural trading system," Vaile said.

"Government support to agriculture in the OECD in 1999 was over US$360 billion, as high as it was during the subsidy wars of the 1980s. The Cairns Group is committed to rectifying the unfair penalty that this huge level of support imposes on efficient, productive, competitive exporters," he added.
The Cairns Group has 18 member countries with Australia becoming its leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar fell NT$0.62 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 31.920.
The local currency opened Friday at 31.273 and was traded between 31.273 and 32.300.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$547 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CBS DIRECTOR LEAVES TAIWAN AFTER EMBEZZLEMENT CHARGES

TEXT.P: Former director of the Republic of China's Central Broadcasting System, Chu Wan-ching (Gloria Chu), was discovered Friday to have fled the country only hours after she was released on bail after being charged with embezzlement.
Chu was summoned to be questioned at the Taipei District Prosecutors Office Friday for having allegedly embezzled some NT$10 million (US$322,580) from the CBS Trust Fund.

She was released Thursday night with travel restrictions on NT$500,000 (US$16,130) bail, on the grounds that she insisted on her innocence and said she was willing to cooperate with judicial authorities in their investigation, said presiding prosecutor Wang Wen-teh.

To everybody's surprise, however, Chu, who became head of the former military broadcasting station during the era of Kuomintang rule, was already aboard an EVA Airways flight bound for Los Angeles at around 12 p.m. Thursday.

Local political observers said they believe Chu was able to successfully flee the country because she arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport before the notice of the prosecutors' order of travel restrictions reached the Bureau of Entry & Exit.
Chu, whose children are all living in the United States, left for Los Angeles holding a U.S. passport, said unconfirmed sources.
Prosecutor Wang said he hopes the U.S. government will help assist in returning Chu to Taiwan to face the charges against her.

Earlier on Friday, Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, said the CAA has the right to order an ROC civil aircraft to return to Taiwan after it has landed at a location abroad without opening its gates.

This right, however, has never been utilized by the CAA because it would involve too many complications in too many areas, including compensation to the hundreds of innocent passengers aboard the aircraft, Chang noted, adding that this power was also not used against the plane Chu was aboard.
Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs have kept mum on this case, only saying that it is improper for the MOFA to make any comments.

Meanwhile, Chu's husband, Ho Ching-hsien, chairman of a Chinese-language institute in Taipei, clarified in an interview with a local TV channel Friday morning that Chu did not leave the country to "escape" the charges brought against her.

Ho said his wife had made arrangements one week earlier to leave for Los Angeles on Thursday night in order to meet their son and accompany him to Pennsylvania where he will attend a military academy.

Kuomintang spokesman Jason Hu said Chu's leaving the country has nothing to do with the opposition party nor KMT Chairman Lien Chan. Hu said he fully trusts that the ROC judiciary authorities will handle the case justly and properly.
Chu, 50, is known to have maintained very close connections with Lien's wife over the past decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT ATTENDS RESTAURANT RIBBON-CUTTING CEREMONY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The Evergarden Restaurant, owned by Taiwan's Evergreen Group, was formally inaugurated Thursday with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso and First Vice President Arturo Vallerino in attendance.

Evergreen Group President Chang Yung-fa, Republic of China Ambassador to Panama Lan Chih-min, and General Manager of Evergreen International Corp. Chang Kuo-cheng jointly cut the ribbon at the opening ceremony.
More than 100 Chinese and Panamanian dignitaries witnessed the ceremony.
Panamanian President Moscoso held a private meeting with Taiwan business tycoon Chang before the inauguration of his new restaurant.
During the meeting, Chang reportedly talked to the Panamanian head of state about the new restaurant's operation and how to upgrade the quality of Chinese cuisine.
The Evergarden Restaurant has a capacity of 300 seats, and will provide Chinese food and Guangdong-style refreshments.
In addition to the eatery, Evergreen Group has invested in construction of an administrative building and a container terminal in the special industrial zone of Colon, near the Panama Canal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LODGES PROTEST OVER SOLOMON ISLANDS FOREIGN MINISTER'S MOVE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has lodged a protest with the Solomon Islands over the recent diplomatic snub by Solomon Islands Foreign Minister Denny Philip, said a Foreign Ministry official Friday.
Philip was originally scheduled to come to Taipei for the ROC's Double-Ten National Day celebrations. But he canceled his Taiwan trip without notifying Taipei, reportedly flying to Beijing instead.
Shih Ting, director of the ROC Foreign Ministry's Asia-Pacific Affairs Department, told the media that the Foreign Ministry had lodged a serious protest over Philip's move.

He also stressed that the ROC government would never accept any improper demands. Philip reportedly changed his Taipei visit plan after Taipei refused to comply with his demand for US$20 million in aid.
Shih said that the Solomon Islands prime minister attended a National Day party presided over by Teng Pei-yin, ROC ambassador to the Solomon Islands.
The prime minister described Philip's act as "a personal move," and reiterated that his government "treasures close relations between the Solomon Islands and the ROC."
Shih noted that Taipei considers the statement by the Solomon Islands prime minister as significant, and will do it utmost to maintain diplomatic relations between the two countries.

According to the Foreign Ministry official, rival factions and government representatives of the South Pacific nation traveled to Australia on Oct. 9 for a three-day peace conference presided over by the Australian foreign secretary.
He said that Taipei is confident that the rival factions will be able to reach a peace agreement, which will avert a political crisis in the Solomon Islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE LOWER HOUSE MEMBER VISITS TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Japanese Lower House member Kunio Hatoyama left Tokyo for Taipei Friday for a three-day visit, accompanied by his family and a group of aides.
Hatoyama has been elected to the Japanese Parliament eight times, and has served as education minister and labor minister. This is his first visit to Taipei since becoming a parliamentarian.

Hatoyama comes from an influential family in Japan. His grandfather, Ichiro, was a prime minister, and his father, Iichiro, was once foreign minister. Meanwhile, his elder brother, Yukio, is chief of the largest opposition party -- the Democratic Party.
During his stay in Taipei, Hatoyama will call on former President Lee Teng-hui and incumbent President Chen Shui-bian, and will visit some cultural establishments.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH'S ADVISER RECOGNIZES ROC EFFORTS TO LOWER CROSS-STRAIT TENSION
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Jennifer J. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior foreign policy adviser to Republican presidential candidate George W. Bush Thursday recognized Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's efforts to reduce tension in the Taiwan Strait since his May 20 inauguration.
In an interview with CNA, the adviser, who preferred anonymity, also said mainland China's security threat to the United States is worrisome and deserves concern.

She pointed out that if Bush wins the presidential election in November, his administration will continue to implement the longstanding "one China" policy which requires mainland China not to use military force to unify Taiwan and demands Taiwan not to change its present status quo.

The adviser accused mainland China of having caused many security problems to the United States. For one thing, she said, Beijing opposes the U.S. military presence in Asia. Moreover, it continues selling nuclear weapons to Pakistan, upgrading its own combat readiness and obstructing the U.S. implementation of a balanced "one China" policy.

Asked what role the United States can play in pushing for resumption of the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue, the noted foreign relations scholar said what the United States can do is to help cultivate a stable environment to facilitate cross-strait engagement and dialogue.

As for the timing for resuming cross-strait talks, the adviser said it's up to Taiwan and mainland China to jointly decide. It's not suitable for the U.S. government to dictate a timetable, she said, adding that the United States should also not act as a go-between in cross-strait engagement.

The adviser further said as President Chen's administration has handled cross-strait relations in a responsible manner and endeavored to lower cross-strait tension, she is optimistic about the future of Taiwan-mainland China relations and does not think that an immediate confrontation would erupt in the Taiwan Strait.

Asked whether the U.S. troops in Asia should be posted in the Taiwan Strait, the adviser said so long as the circumstances need, the U.S. naval forces can be posted at any place. The key point lies in whether mainland China poses military threats to Taiwan, she noted.

In her public speech delivered at the Council of Foreign Relations, the senior adviser said she believes that if mainland China continues its open-door trade policy and economic liberalization reform, all such measures will eventually have an impact on its political reform.

Generally speaking, the adviser said the bilateral Washington-Beijing relations are very complex and that the United States should seek to expand their relationship in a positive, constructive direction.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO PRESENT 'FEASIBLE' ECONOMIC MEASURES

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said Friday that the KMT, which relinquished executive power to the Democratic Progressive Party after losing last March's presidential election, will next week present feasible measures to alleviate the island's financial and economic problems.

According to KMT spokesman Jason Hu, Lien met with members of the party's task force on economic issues for one and a half hours to exchange views on the way the KMT should help resolve Taiwan's economic problems.

Members of the task force included former Premier Vincent Siew, former Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang, former Finance Minister Paul Chiu and former Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang.
During the past two weeks, Hu said that the KMT had invited scholars and experts to study problems concerning infrastructure development, cross-Taiwan Strait relations and industrial policy.
Lien reportedly instructed the KMT task force to convene a seminar on Oct. 27 to work out feasible countermeasures for financial and economic problems.
Former finance and economics ministers under the KMT government as well as noted scholars and experts will be invited to attend the seminar to present their opinions.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PREMIER BARES HIS POSITION ON FOURTH NUCLEAR POWER PLANT

TEXT.P: New Premier Chang Chun-hsiung says in his prepared administrative report to the Legislative Yuan that the Executive Yuan will handle the issue of the fourth nuclear power plant with care.

He also states that the government will step up Taiwan's development of energy technology, including studying the use of new and clean energy sources, promoting conservation of energy and improving efficiency of energy consumption.

Former Premier Tang Fei resigned from the Premiership early this month because of his support for continued construction of the nuclear power plant, which conflicted with the position of President Chen Shui-bian and that of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
As this issue has developed into a major political dispute that has affected the stock market, the new premier's position has attracted the attention of the public.
But judging from the prepared administrative report, Chang maintains a reserved position on this thorny issue.
In the economic development section of the report, Chang notes that his Cabinet will deal with the issue in a sound manner.

Regarding the development of science and technology, he asserts that the Executive Yuan will enforce strict controls on the operation of the three existing nuclear power plants to ensure their safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE NEWSPAPER INDUSTRY DELEGATION VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A delegation of mainland Chinese newspaper industry professionals met with their Taiwan counterparts at the Central News Agency headquarters Friday to exchange views on current industry trends as well as future cooperative possibilities.

CNA editor-in-chief Lee Wan-lai told the visitors that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have both common ground and differences in the wake of their longtime separation, but that they should nonetheless strive toward the grand objective of promoting exchanges.
Lee added that although the current Internet fever may have had an intense impact on Taiwan's newspaper industry, he is confident that newspapers will never disappear.
He went on to say that cross-strait exchanges should begin with the media, because positive reporting can lead to increased mutual understanding and decreased conflict and hostility.

Leading the mainland Chinese delegation, All-China Journalists' Association Director Huang Yenkuang said that his ten-member delegation was in Taiwan to learn from the island's successful newspaper experience and to share their own experience in turn.
The delegation will visit tourist attractions such as Taiwan's Sun Moon Lake and call on various media companies during their stay, scheduled to end on Oct. 21.

Republic of China National Press Council member Lin Sen-hung said that Taiwan's newspaper industry flourished and became very competitive after martial law-era restrictions on newspaper licensing and publishing were eased in 1988.
He went on to say that subsequent mergers and acquisitions have shown that capital, talent, marketing, and management are all essential elements for an enduring newspaper.

Chiang An-kuo, professor of journalism at Taiwan's Ming Chuan University, pointed out that Taiwan's newspaper industry has already entered a stage of steady development after experiencing saturation. He added that the traditional newspaper industry is working on an answer to the impact of real-time news services offered by online newspapers.
Chiang also suggested that cross-strait news media cooperation should begin with CNA and mainland China's Xinhua News Agency engaging in full-scale and proactive interactions and exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HAILS FIRST CHINESE NOBEL LITERATURE LAUREATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Friday hailed the decision to grant the 2000 Nobel Prize in Literature to self-exiled Chinese writer Gao Xingjian, saying that the honor marks Gao's greatest achievement.
Chen further said Gao's Nobel award marks a perfect end to the 20th century and a beautiful start for the 21st.

"The laurel is the pride of Chinese the world over and an encouragement to all Chinese writers," Chen said during an inspection tour of construction of a freeway tunnel project linking Taipei and Ilan Counties.
Although official mainland Chinese media has been silent about Gao's Nobel prize, the news made the front pages of leading dailies in democratic Taiwan Friday.
"Pride of Chinese the World Over," a China Times headline said about the mainland China-born author, playwright and brush painter, who now lives in exile in France.

The United Daily News said Gao, 60, has maintained close contacts with local writers and noted that the versatile novelist publicly vowed in 1991 that he would not return to repressive mainland China.

In an interview with a CNA correspondent in Paris, Gao said he appreciates the support of Taiwan publishers for artistic freedom, going on to thank his readers on the island for supporting his literary work and painting over the past decade.
Gao said he has been consistently moved by hospitality and friendship shown by Taiwan publishers, writers and readers every time he has visited the island.

Before winning the Nobel prize, Gao said, he accepted a Taipei City Hall invitation to make a three-month visit to the city late this year, as the largest Taiwan city's first "resident artist" -- a program aimed at helping promote local cultural development. Gao said he may have to postpone the visit to a future date, due to what he expects will be a tight schedule following his Nobel award.

Lung Ying-tai, director of the Bureau of Cultural Affairs of Taipei City Hall, said she is very happy to see Gao win the Nobel laurel, as he has a broad view of life. "But I also feel deep regret that mainland Chinese authorities are not generous and tolerant enough to keep Gao on China's soil," she added.

Gao, born in the central Chinese province of Jiangxi in 1940, fled his homeland in 1987 after one of his plays was banned and he was put under police surveillance. After the 1989 blood bath at Tiananmen Square in Beijing, he wrote "Fugitives," set against the background of the slayings. Beijing declared him "persona non grata" and banned his works.

Gao became the first-ever Chinese-language writer to win the Nobel award for his modernist and humanist contemporary Chinese works. He has lived in exile since 1988 in France, where he sought political asylum before taking French citizenship.
The Swedish Academy cited Gao for his "bitter insights and linguistic ingenuity."

"In the writing of Gao Xingjian literature is born anew from the struggle of the individual to survive the history of the masses," the academy said in its citation. "He is a perspicacious skeptic who makes no claim to be able to explain the world. He asserts that he has found freedom only in writing."

The writer and playwright went on a 10-month walking tour in the central Sichuan province to avoid harassment after his play "The Other Shore" was banned in 1986 and left mainland China the next year.

His novel "Soul Mountain" reflected that journey with several narratives by different protaganists. "With his unrestrained use of personal pronouns Gao creates lightning shifts of perspective and compels the reader to question all confidences," the academy said of the novel.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS TOP PRIORITY: MAC

TEXT.P: The resumption of systematic cross-strait consultations is still the government's main priority, an official in charge of mainland policy said Friday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, noted that the Straits Exchange Foundation is still the only channel commissioned by the government to conduct cross-strait consultations.

Cross-strait communication has been stalled since former President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait relations as "special state-to-state relationship" in July last year. Though the new administration has extended conciliatory gestures to the other side of the Taiwan strait since its inauguration in May, the prospect of resuming a cross-strait dialogue remains unclear.

Lin said that the government does not rule out the possibility of a second or third track mechanism for cross-strait talks, so long as both sides of the Taiwan Strait increase their dialogue through alternative channels such as foreign think tanks and scholars.
Lin also said that the official designated to serve as Taiwan's representative in Hong Kong remains unchanged, and expressed the government's hope that Hong Kong will approve his appointment soon.

Lin said that he hopes Chang Liang-jen, director of the MAC's Hong Kong Affairs Bureau under the previous Kuomintang-led government, will be able to assume his post in Hong Kong as early as possible, so as to help promote exchanges with Hong Kong.

The two governments have not yet reach an agreement on Chang's application for a work visa in Hong Kong, and the two sides are still discussing the matter, Lin said. He would not comment on reports that the new government may want to replace Chang with another official.

The main hurdle for Chang's application is said to be Hong Kong's imposition of more stringent conditions for Chang's post, including promises that he will do nothing to violate the "one China" principle, and that he will make no direct or indirect comments that might give the impression that he represents the Taiwan government.
Lin also said that Taiwan would like to discuss the disposal of nuclear waste with mainland China under the principle of equality.
Lin was responding to questions about whether nuclear waste in Taiwan could be sent to mainland China for disposal.
