Lin said that the state-owned Taiwan Power Co. is considering many sources for the disposal of its nuclear waste, and would not limit itself to any single place.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT PROMISES AIR LINKS ARE PERMANENT: ROC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada promised that the resumption of air links between his nation and the Republic of China are permanent and will not be interrupted again, ROC Transportation Minister Yeh Chu-lan said Friday.

Yeh, upon returning from a low-profile five-day trip to the Philippines to speak at the annual meeting of that nation's General Chamber of Industry and Commerce, noted that she called on Estrada Thursday.

Yeh said that Estrada had told her he was under immense pressure on the issue of air links with Taiwan, which had been suspended for 10 months because of the termination of the aviation agreement between the two countries and the failure to agree on a new one until late September.

Yeh said she had told Estrada that the resumption of air links will be mutually beneficial, and that it will save both time and money for the many Filipino workers who are employed in Taiwan. She added that history will prove the decision was correct.
Yeh pointed out that she had traveled to Manila on the first direct EVA Airways flight from Taipei to the Philippine capital since the resumption of bilateral air links.

During her stay in Manila, she also called on the Philippine ministers of finance, trade and industry, tourism, and labor and employment. As Transportation and Communications Minister Vincente Rivera was overseas, she called on his deputy.

Yeh said that she also met with Taiwan businessmen in the Philippines, who told her that the resumption of air links was a "relief for the needy and distressed." They noted the difficulties that they had encountered in quickly replacing Taiwan-sourced spare parts for their factory machinery since direct air links broke off last year.
With the re-established links, if they find that they are lacking certain spare parts in the morning, they can have the equipment shipped on the same day's afternoon plane, she quoted them as saying.

Yeh added that she has extended an invitation to the Philippine tourism minister to visit Taiwan on Nov. 3 to attend an international conference on tourism. The Philippine minister will have a chance to formally brief Taiwan investors on a plan to develop Clark Air Base, a former U.S. Air Force base, into a tourist attraction.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI MINISTER REAFFIRMS TIES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Malawi Information Minister and Government Spokesman Clement Stambuli Friday reaffirmed the solid bilateral relations between his country and the Republic of China.

Citing the proverb "a friend in need is a friend indeed," Stambuli said that Taiwan is a real friend of Malawi and his country values its ties with Taiwan very much. He added that Malawi will never transfer diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing just for economic benefit.

The Malawi government spokesman made the statement at a ceremony in which he and Central News Agency President Bill Wang signed an agreement to renew a news exchange pact between CNA and its Malawi counterpart, the Malawi News Agency. The two agencies first entered into cooperative relations in June, 1998.

Stambuli said that Taiwan has always come to the relief of Malawi whenever the African country suffered from famine or contagious diseases, adding that Taiwan's agricultural and medical groups stationed in his contry have been a great help to the Malawi people.

Stambuli made the clarification amid news reports that a six-member Malawi delegation, headed by the political department director of that country's Presidential Office, was in Beijing for the recent China-Africa forum.

Stambuli said that members of the group attending the forum are either private sector representatives or low-level government officials, who traveled to Beijing merely to seek trade opportunities. He stressed that their presence at the Beijing-sponsored meeting had nothing to do with diplomatic relations.
Under the terms of the agreement, CNA and MANA will exchange their English news services, and CNA will provide computers for MANA to facilitate the free flow of information through the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT TO ATTEND FORUM 2000 IN CZECH REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui is scheduled to depart for the Czech Republic Saturday at the invitation of Czech President Vaclav Havel.

Lee, a Presbyterian, will speak on religion and spirituality at this year's Forum 2000 conference, a gathering of noted personalities and former heads of state from around the world who have met annually since 1997 to discuss world issues.

The Dalai Lama will also be at the three-day conference, which begins Sunday, and is scheduled to host a seminar on Oct. 17. It is widely expected that Lee will openly meet the Tibetan spiritual leader-in-exile at the seminar. The Dalai Lama is also scheduled to visit Taiwan in November.

Lee will be accompanied by his wife and staff members on the trip. His itinerary, arranged by the ROC Foreign Ministry, includes golf and sightseeing after the conference. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Oct. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG ARGUES FOR CONSTRUCTION OF NEW INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Residents of Metropolitan Taichung on Friday expressed their hope that the government would soon start building an international airport in the greater Taichung area.

Legislator Lu Shiow-yen of the opposition Kuomintang held a public hearing Friday morning at Taichung City Council on the construction of an international airport in central Taiwan. Officials from Taichung County Hall and Taichung City Hall, parliamentarians, and officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications were also present at the hearing.
Lu said President Chen Shui-bian had promised during the presidential campaign that he would push for the construction of Taichung International Airport if elected.

She added that President Chen had also reiterated at one of his press conferences the government's determination to build the airport. Claiming that there has been no action to follow up on those words, Lu urged Chen to make good on his campaign promise and push for the construction of the island's third international airport.

Lin Chin-chuan, head of the Navigation and Aviation Department of the MOTC, said the ministry had in fact received instructions from the Executive Yuan to earmark NT$10 million in the 2001 fiscal year budget to hire a consulting company to evaluate the feasibility of building an international airport in central Taiwan.

Lin said the feasibility report will be provided to the MOTC for its reference when it makes its decision on the issue. The possibility of the construction of the international airport in central Taiwan is said to be very high.
Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai cited five advantages of constructing an international airport in central Taiwan. He said that the completed project would:
-- Promote the development of the greater Taichung area's industry and commerce;
-- Act as a link to the mainland once the government approves direct cross-strait air links;
-- Promote the greater Taichung area's tourism industry by increasing the number of tourist arrivals in the area;
-- Shorten the time it takes to travel abroad from central Taiwan; and
-- Eliminate a general impression that the government is biased toward northern and southern Taiwan at the expense of the central region.
Meanwhile, Liao urged the government to take measures in advance to solve problems common to international airports, such as noise and air pollution, traffic congestion, and other related issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP LOOKS FORWARD TO CONTINUED EXCHANGES BETWEEN TAIWAN, HAITI

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu told visiting Haitian First Lady Geri Benoit-Preval Friday that the ROC looks forward to the continued strengthening of bilateral political and economic exchanges between the two nations.

Lu said that although the two countries may be far apart geographically, the ROC treasures the friendship of its Haitian ally, adding that the personal visit of Benoit-Preval and her husband Haitian President Rene Preval will undoubtedly give them an even deeper understanding of Taiwan's current state of development.

She went on to note that Taiwan was very poor in its early days, but that the achievements of modern times came about through the common efforts of the government and the people. She added that Taiwan is very willing to share its successful experience with its allies.

Benoit-Preval responded that she came to realize after her visit that Taiwan's economic miracle didn't simply drop from the sky, but rather was the result of the industrious work of the island's people.

She went on to say that she is vigorously working to improve the status of women in Haiti, and at the same time hopes to learn from Taiwan's handicraft industry experience in order to promote and develop Haiti's own arts and crafts industry.

Lu noted that Taiwan would be very happy to cooperate with Haiti on handicraft technical training and marketing, adding that she has brought up in the past the idea of a "Latin Plaza" in Taiwan, where products and cultural relics of the ROC's Central American and Caribbean allies can be displayed, as a means for cultural and economic exchanges.
Preval and Benoit-Preval arrived in Taiwan Oct. 9 for an official eight-day visit, during which they attended the ROC's Oct. 10 National Day celebrations as guests of honor.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CONGRATULATES KIM ON WINNING NOBEL PEACE PRIZE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Friday congratulated his South Korean counterpart, President Kim Dae-jung, for winning this year's Nobel Peace Prize.

"I would like to extend my sincerest congratulations to you for the contribution you have made to reducing tension and promoting reconciliation in the Korean Peninsula, as well as to maintaining regional stability in the Asian-Pacific area and the world," said President Chen in a message delivered by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Chen and Kim had met several times before they were both elected to the presidency of their respective nations, according to a presidential news release.
He said that the coveted Nobel Peace Prize is a great honor, which Kim fully deserves. "(Kim Dae-jung) has written a wonderful page" in the history of Korean reconciliation, Chen added.

Chen said that the award serves to confirm Kim's efforts and achievements in leading the Korean peninsula toward reconciliation and peace for the 21st century, and also serves as a lesson for Taiwan and mainland China. "We can also do that, if we want to," Chen said, referring to cross-strait reconciliation.

Ever since the media reports of the two Korean leaders creating history by shaking hands on June 13, Seoul and Pyongyang have marched in the right direction -- toward reconciliation and peace, President Chen pointed out.

Despite the great ideological differences resulting from over 50 years of confrontation between South and North Korea, Chen said he believes both sides should be able to accomplish their "impossible mission" as long as they have wisdom and creativity.

Chen went on to say that he was so moved by the two Korean leaders' "historical step" that he hung a picture of Kim Dae-jung shaking hands with Kim Jong Il, paramount leader of North Korea, on a wall of his study.
The president said it is his firm belief that the leaders of both Taiwan and the mainland could jointly rewrite history someday by shaking hands like the two Kims.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PHILIPPINE ECONOMIC MEETING HELD MANILA
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The 15th joint meeting between the ROC-Philippine Economic Association and the Philippine-ROC Economic Association was held on Friday in Manila to discuss how to strengthen economic ties between the Republic of China and the Philippine Islands.

Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the ROC-Philippine Economic Association, and Tung Shang-chen, chairman of the Philippine-ROC Economic Association, jointly presided over the opening ceremony. More than 100 Chinese and Philippine entrepreneurs took part in the one-day meeting.
In his address, Koo took up the question of why Taiwan investors put less capital in the Philippines than its neighboring countries.

Koo cited statistics as saying that Taiwan investors had poured some US$43.7 billion into Southeast Asian countries as of June of this year, with Indonesia taking the lion's share of US$17 billion, followed by Thailand at US$10.2 billion, and Malaysia at US$8.8 billion.

He added that Vietnam ranked fourth at US$4.9 billion, and Singapore was fifth at US$1.7 billion. Meanwhile, the Philippines attracted less than US$1 billion capital investment from Taiwan, Koo noted.
Koo called on the participants to consider this question carefully, since the Philippines possesses abundant resources, a highly skilled labor force, and good investment climate.
Philippine Minister of Commerce and Industry A. Rojas said that Taiwan was the largest trade partner for the Philippines last year.

He said that during the period between 1995 and 1999, Taiwan was the Philippines' third largest export market, fifth largest source of imports, and eighth largest source of foreign investment. In 1999 alone, Philippine exports to Taiwan increased by 70 percent, while imports from Taiwan increased by 14 percent, Rojas said.
Rojas also stressed that the Philippine government has been implementing economic reform, economic liberalization and privatization.

Rojas also expressed his regret that ROC Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi was unable to attend the current meeting, and said he hopes that the ministerial-level economic cooperation meeting between the two sides can be held as soon as possible.
Following the opening ceremony, the meeting focused on panel discussions and business consultation. It closed Friday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP URGES TAIWAN PUBLIC TO ADOPT CENTRAL-AMERICAN CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that she plans to initiate a drive to raise NT$100 million (US$3.1 million) to promote the practice of adopting children in Taiwan's Central American allies.

While receiving members of the Chinese Women Enterprise Launching Association who will be departing for Washington, D.C., Saturday to attend a world women leadership summit, Lu said that getting 10,000 people to donate NT$10,000 (US$313) each will make the ROC's Central American allies feel "love from Taiwan" and help bolster mutual friendship at the grassroots level.

Lu, a women rights activist-turned-politician, went on to encourage the women delegates to the summit to speak out for Taiwan at international meetings so that more people in the international community will become aware of the nation's plight.
She also invited the representatives to join her soon-to-be-established National Women League, and work together toward equality and cooperation between the sexes.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PASSES OCEAN POLLUTION PREVENTION LAW

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a new law to fight ocean pollution Friday, with provisions for a maximum punishment of up to 10-years in jail and a fine of NT$100 million for violators.
Major points of the law include:

-- The government agencies concerned should map out a standard operating procedure for protecting the oceanic environment, and should periodically publicize the results of their surveillance on ocean pollution prevention. If needed, they can make restrictions on ships operating in endangered waters;
-- Ship owners must install pollution-prevention equipment, and port management authorities can ban a ship from operating if it is deemed to be a possible pollution hazard; and
-- Dumping anything that seriously pollutes oceanic waters is subject to punishment of one to 10 years in jail and a possible fine of NT$20 million to NT$100 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES READJUSTED BUDGET PROPOSAL FOR FY 2001

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved a readjusted national budget proposal for fiscal year 2001 Friday, and plans to submit the proposal to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation next week.

Following the resignation of Premier Tang Fei early this month, the Executive Yuan withdrew the original budget proposal from the parliament for readjustment to reflect the intentions of new Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.

Total revenues and expenditures remain unchanged at NT$1,458.5 billion and NT$1,608.2 billion, respectively, but the budget for social welfare has been cut by NT$4 billion, a sum that will be spent on other programs.
Trimmed expenditures also include NT$9 million in pay cuts for the president and the vice president, and NT$4 billion in government subsidies to the national health insurance program.
Most of the budget increases go to transportation construction projects and the agricultural development fund.

Lin Chuan, director general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said that the readjusted budget proposal gives priority to economic development and improving care for off-shore island residents, aborigines and farmers.
He added that the changes would have no detrimental effect on the welfare of the public or any minority groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
South Korean President Kim Dae-Jung wins the 2000 Nobel Peace Prize.
The China Times:
Kim Dae-Jung is the 2000 Nobel Peace Prize winner.
The United Daily News:
South Korea's Kim wins Nobel Peace Prize.
The Liberty Times:
Ex-head of state radio Gloria Chu skips bail and flies to the United States.
The China Post:
South Korea's Kim wins Peace Prize.
The Taiwan News:
Central Bank drops dollar intervention; Taiwan currency allowed to weaken -- a boost for exports and capital inflow.
The Taipei Times:
Vice Premier Lai In-jaw set to attend APEC summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 14, or the 17th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1066: Duke William of Normandy becomes the new ruler of England after defeating the English under King Harold in a hard-fought battle near Hastings.
1890: Dwight D. Eisenhower, U.S. military commander in Europe during World War II and two-term president of the United States after the war, is born.
1909: The Ching court sets up government counselor bureaus in each of its 22 provinces except Sinkiang, marking the beginning of a parliament in China.
1912: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, is shot in an attempted assassination prior to his assuming the presidency. He won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War.
1913: An explosion at Universal Colliery in South Wales kills 439 miners in Britain's worst mining disaster.
1915: The Interior Ministry of the National government orders a halt to the practice of binding the feet of women.
1920: Oxford University, the oldest university in Britain and one of the world's most famous institutions of higher learning, grants degrees to women for the first time.
1933: Nazi Germany walks out of the Geneva Disarmament Conference and withdraws from the League of Nations.
1939: The British Royal Navy battleship HMS Royal Osk is torpedoed and sunk in Scapa Flow, killing 810 people on board.
1944: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, summons 100,000 young intellectuals to join the army and organizes them into an expeditionary force of 10 divisions.
1944: Field Marshall Erwin Rommel, one of Nazi Germany's finest military leaders, known as "Desert Fox," dies at the age of 53. He commanded the Afrika Korps with distinction during the North African campaign from 1941 to 1943.
1947: The Bell X-1 becomes the first aircraft to fly faster than sound when the rocket-powered plane, piloted by U.S. Air Force Major Charles Yeager, is taken to a height of 9,700 meters under a B-29 Superfortress mother-plane. The test begins at 22,700 meters, and the maximum speed achieved is Mach 1.05, which is held for several seconds.
1958: Madagascar, known as the Malagasy Republic under the French, becomes a self-governing state in the French Community. It gained independence in 1960.
1964: Martin Luther King Jr., American cleric who formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. He was assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee four years later.
1973: Thanom Kittikachorn is forced to resign as prime minister of Thailand after violent clashes between troops and student protesters. He is succeeded by Sanya Thammasak.
1974: Mario Adolfo Martinez Gutierrez, dean of Guatemala's Institute of Science and Agricultural Technology, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives outgoing Jordanian Ambassador Fathi Yasin at the Presidential Office.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1977: The much-loved entertainer Bing Crosby collapses and dies after completing a round of golf near Madrid. He was 73. One of his most successful films was "High Society," with Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra.
1979: Dr. James Robinson, president of the University of West Florida, gives a reception at the Grand Hotel to mark the presentation of an honorary doctorate of law to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1991: Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese pro-democracy leader held under house arrest for more than two years by Burmese military rulers, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1992: Shin Kanemaru, Japanese political leader, resigns from Japan's parliament following criticism for his role in a scandal tying the Liberal Democratic Party to organized crime.
1993: The United Nations General Assembly ends a two-week general debate during which a total of 23 nations express their support for ROC membership in the world body.
1999: A delegation from the Republic of China takes part in the 26th International Small Business Congress held in Toronto, Canada.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man knows that the accomplishment of great things consists in doing little things well. He knows that great effects are produced by small causes. He knows the evidence and reality of what cannot be perceived by the senses. Thus he is enabled to enter into the world of ideas and morals."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP. IN U.S. TALKS ON CHEN ADMINISTRATION'S CROSS-STRAITS STANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative in the United States said Thursday that ROC President Chen-Shui-bian's administration has shown temperance toward the issue of cross-strait ties and is trying its best to keep contacts with Beijing.
Chen Chien-jen made the remarks during an interview with the Washington Times.

Chen told the Washington Times that President Chen is willing to view the notion of "one China" as a "topic for discussion" with Beijing, rather than as a "principle" which Beijing claims Taipei must accept before resuming dialogue on cross-strait issues.

Friday's edition of the Washington Times said it is very important to make this distinction, because according to mainland China, Taiwan's acceptance of the "one China" principle would mean Taiwan's acceptance of mainland Chinese rule.

On the issue of national defense, Chen said that although mainland China maintains an advantage in terms of weapons' quantity, Taiwan is presently superior in terms of weapons' quality. He added, however, that unless the United States continues to offer defensive weapons to Taiwan, mainland China will probably also gain superiority in weapons' quality within five years.
He said the ROC's new government still enjoys a nearly 60 percent public support rating, although this level is lower than the 80 percent support rating in April.

The Washington Times said that Chen Shui-bian, who won the presidential election on March 18 to become the ROC's 10th president, has a style that appropriately combines toughness and gentleness, allowing him to maintain a high reputation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MAINLAND AFFAIRS COUNCIL TO INSPECT TAIWAN SCHOOL IN PRC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council and the Education Ministry are planning to send a delegation to the southern mainland Chinese city of Dongguan in November or December to inspect a school for the children of Taiwan businessmen.

The council, which is in charge of mapping out Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, cited the need to study the school's facilities, teaching environment, and administrative operations to serve as the basis for future policy considerations when other Taiwan businessmen wish to follow in the school's example.
The delegation of council and ministry officials will also meet with Dongguan teachers, students, and the parents of students for informal discussions.

After five years of planning, over 700 students began their first semester at the school in September. The school is the first to be officially sanctioned by both Taipei and Beijing. Taiwan businessmen in other mainland cities such as Shenzhen and Shanghai have reportedly been preparing to apply for the establishment of similar schools elsewhere.
The council did not send any delegations to Dongguan during the application approval process, and only one mid-level official has inspected the school since it was officially inaugurated.

The Dongguan school is run by a Taiwan principal, hires Taiwan teachers, and uses Taiwan textbooks. Presently, it consists of a kindergarten and a junior high school, while planning for a senior high school is underway. Local businessmen have urged for continued support from Taiwan to help establish the school.

Many of the 35 teachers hired from Taiwan hold masters degrees or doctorates. The Taiwan teachers, whose average age is only 35, account for approximately 70 percent of the teaching faculty, with the rest being hired locally.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REPS PEN LETTERS URGING SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S U.N. BID

TEXT.P: Eleven members of the U.S. House of Representatives Friday sent letters to both Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Jesse Helms (R-N.C.) and Sen. Craig Thomas (R-Wyo.), chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs, urging the Senate to support Taiwan's participation in the United Nations.

"Taiwan's quest for self-determination is something the United States of America has traditionally and consistently supported. With President Chen Shui-bian's free and fair election, Taiwan continues to refine its democracy by improving safeguards for human rights and contributing to the international community," wrote the congressmen from both parties.

Unfortunately, the letters pointed out, "Taiwan's efforts to participate in international organizations have often been thwarted for political reasons beyond Taiwan's control. It is unreasonable for the people of Taiwan to be excluded from full participation in international institutions due to threats from mainland China. Denying Taiwan membership in the United Nations and other international organizations, obstructs its access to important international resources."

The House on Oct. 3 passed House Concurrent Resolution 390 relating to Taiwan's participation in the United Nations. "We believe this important legislation will once again restate our support and commitment to the progress of Taiwan's democracy," stressed the congressmen.

They requested the senators to place the House Concurrent Resolution on the Senate agenda "in order to insure timely passage of this widely supported resolution," adding that "the people of Taiwan have proved that freedom and democracy are not just American ideals; they are universal principles that apply to every individual, to every community, and to every nation."

"China's continuing harassment and intimidation in the Taiwan Straits underlines the urgency and necessity of Taiwan's participation in the United Nations," noted Wen-yen Chen, president of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs.

He added that "today, the U.S. is solely responsible for Taiwan's safety and security as laid down in the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act. When Taiwan joins the U.N., the responsibility for Taiwan's safety and security will be shifted to the international community."

DOC.HEADLINE: GAO'S NOBEL PRIZE MAY SERVE AS MORAL SALVATION FOR CHINA

TEXT.P: A major Canadian newspaper expressed the hope Friday that awarding this year's Nobel Prize in literature to Gao Xingjiang will serve as a kind of moral salvation for his native Communist China.

An editorial in the National Post said Gao's award-winning novel "Soul Mountain" describes an individual's search for his roots, inner peace, and personal liberty, themes that are "anathema to every one of the prescriptive literary rules laid down in 1942 by Mao Tse-tung."

For Mao, literature's primary function was to be political, while aesthetic values were to be suppressed. Also, the writer's audience was to consist of workers, soldiers, and peasants alone, noted the editorial.
"By contrast, Mr. Gao -- who was sent to a re-education camp during the Cultural Revolution from 1966 to 1976 -- wrote for a universal audience and often invoked existential themes," it noted.
Ironically, the Nobel committee's announcement came in the same week that Beijing branded the banned Falun Gong a "political rival" to the Communist Party and an "enemy of the nation," it said.
One effective way to fight this kind of repression, as Gao has shown, is to expose the violence inherent within the system, pointed out the editorial.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA AND U.S. AGREE TO LIMIT SMOG-CAUSING POLLUTANTS

TEXT.P: Canada and the United States reached a deal Friday to limit smog-causing pollutants that drift across the border and are believed to be responsible for the deaths of thousands of people in the two countries each year.

The pact, officially known as the ozone annex to the Canada-U.S. Air Quality Agreement, requires a 50 percent reduction in nitrogen oxide emissions from fossil-fuel power plants in southern Ontario. Their U.S. counterparts will reduce emissions by as much as 70 percent during the summer, when the effects of smog are the most damaging.

Canada's Environment Minister David Anderson said this is good news for the state of eastern Canada's air quality. He has indicated that he is prepared to force emission reductions on the province of Ontario if necessary.
Ground-level ozone, formed when volatile organic compounds and nitrogen oxide combine in sunlight, damages the lungs and is blamed for thousands of premature deaths every year.
The draft agreement puts an annual cap of 39 kilotons on nitrogen dioxide emissions from fossil fuel plants in Ontario and a five kiloton cap on emissions from Quebec.
The draft commits both countries to seeking further emissions reductions through energy efficiency, renewable energy, the use of cleaner fuel, and alternative technologies.
The deal will primarily benefit Ontario and Quebec and adjoining states in the northern United States. A final agreement is expected to be signed by the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSLATOR'S LABOR OF LOVE PAYS OFF WITH NOBEL PRIZE

TEXT.P: Mabel Lee's labor of love in translating Chinese dissident writer Gao Xingjian's novel "Soul Mountain" into English for an international audience payed off when the author received the Noble Prize for literature.

Lee, a 60-year-old retired Asian studies academic at the University of Sydney, told the Sydney Morning Herald on Friday that she could not believe Gao won the prize until her husband checked on the Internet and the BBC phoned 15 minutes later.
She told the daily that it took her eight years of full-time work to translate the novel of more than 500 pages by a writer virtually unknown in Australia.
The daily quoted Lee as saying that "I did this because I wanted to, and I didn't approach anyone until after I was fairly satisfied with it."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OFFERS '5 GUARANTEES' TO REVIVE PUBLIC CONFIDENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday his administration will not raise tax rates during his four-year tenure and will review the existing taxation system with an aim to boost economic development and increase government tax revenues.
This was one of the "five guarantees" offered by President Chen in his speech delivered at an expanded meeting of the Cabinet's financial and economic task force, headed by Vice Premier Lai In-jaw.

In his speech, Chen also promised to provide a stable investment environment for local industries. "To ensure continued industrial development and sustain economic prosperity, the new government will do its utmost to create a profitable business climate with adequate capital, manpower, water, electricity and land supplies," he explained.
Meanwhile, Chen said the government will streamline law enforcement to wipe out irrational protests and ensure smooth proceeding of legally approved investment and factory construction projects.

The president further pledged to upgrade administrative efficiency to meet the demand of the industrial sector. Chen said he has directed the Executive Yuan or the Cabinet to unveil a package of measures within one month for establishing one-stop service counters for new corporate registration, application for setting up plants in industrial parks and environmental impact evaluation.

Chen also pitched for an end to inter-party rivalry, saying that a war of attrition among major domestic political parties would only undermine Taiwan's capability to cope with severe challenges in the increasingly competitive global market.

"If the long feuding North and South Korea can move toward reconciliation, I see no reason for continued squabbles among our domestic parties," Chen said, adding that if all major local parties can move toward reconciliation and cooperation, its value will be no less than what a Nobel Peace Prize can offer to the people of Taiwan.

In his speech, Chen cited official tallies to prove that Taiwan's economic fundamentals remain healthy and robust. For instance, Chen said, Taiwan's exports registered a remarkable 24 percent growth in the first eight months as compared with the year-earlier level and industrial production also grew 9 percent during the same period.

Noting that Taiwan's current economic boom shows no signs of slowdown, Chen said he feels regret that there is a wide gap between the island's economic fundamentals and the performance of its financial sector.
Chen said he and his new government team will work hard to resolve present financial and economic problems and revive the business sector and general public's confidence in his administration.

Touching on the controversies surrounding the fourth nuclear power plant and Meinung dam projects, Chen said the government will work out long-term plans to ensure adequate water and electricity supplies over the decades to come. "I hope local people will have full confidence in the government's determination to realize this goal."

The half-day economic and financial meeting was chaired by Vice Premier Lai In-jaw. This was the first time that the Cabinet financial task force has met at the Presidential Office. In addition to the nine members of the task force, heads of the island's four largest trade and industry associations also attended the meeting to present their views on resolving current domestic economic and financial problems, including ways to prop up the sagging stock market.
President Chen, Vice President Annette Lu, Secretary-General to the President Yu Shyi-kun, and National Security Council Secretary-General Chuang Ming-yao were also present at the meeting.
Chen said he hopes the expanded Cabinet financial task force meeting can provide a forum for the industry sector to strengthen communication with his new administrative team.

The task force was founded by former Premier Tang Fei to beef up the government's handling of financial and economic affairs in the face of a growing crisis of confidence over the new administration's failure to articulate its financial and economic policies.

In addition to Lai, the panel has eight other members -- Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Lin Chuan, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Minister-without-Portfolio Chung Chin, Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER HEAD OF STATE RADIO DENIES KNOWLEDGE OF TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Former director of Taiwan's Central Broadcasting System, Chu Wan-ching, said in Los Angeles Friday that she did not know she was restricted from leaving Taiwan after prosecutors had brought embezzlement charges against her Thursday.

In a surprise move, Chu left the country only hours after she was released on NT$500,000 (US$15,700) bail Thursday evening. Upon arriving in Los Angeles, she was held for questioning at the U.S. Immigration Office's airport detention facility because Taipei prosecutors indicated through Interpol that she was the subject of a criminal investigation.
However, she was subsequently released Friday afternoon because she did not violate any immigration regulations, a U.S. Immigration Office public relations officer said.

At a press conference held after her release, Chu said that she was indignant at being suspected by prosecutors of having skipped bail and being on the run. She added that her "so-called case" had not yet been brought before the court and that she had not been indicted, so she expected fair treatment from the justice system.

She stressed that she left Taipei legally and arrived in the United States with an unexpired immigration visa and that she had only left for the United States in order to accompany her son to a military boarding school in Pennsylvania whose reported registration deadline is Oct. 14.

She went on to say that U.S. immigration visa regulations dictate that she accompany her 15-year-old son to enter the country. Therefore, she concluded that she had no choice but to place her son's education ahead of other considerations.

Chu pointed out that her passport has already been confiscated by the U.S. Immigration Office, which will speak with her again on Oct. 27 in what is reportedly a hearing on whether to grant her a green card. Therefore, she added that she will ask her lawyer to file a request for leave during this period on her behalf at the Taipei District Prosecutors Office.
She said that if the prosecutors decide to promulgate an order for her arrest and treat her unfairly, she is undecided on whether she will return to Taiwan.
Prosecutors said Saturday that they are considering subpoenaing Chu and that if she does not answer the summon, they will consider an order for her arrest.
Chu was suspected of having embezzled some NT$10 million (US$313,300) from the CBS Trust Fund.

Meanwhile, opposition New Party legislator Lai Shyh-bao criticized the government for its "inefficiency" and added that the prosecutors should have immediately telephoned the Bureau of Immigration after setting down travel restrictions on Chu.

Lai added that if a "suspect" can remain outside the law's reach through holes in the justice system, the crisis that the nation would face in times of major troubles would be "unimaginable." He called the fact that Chu was able to leave Taiwan despite travel restrictions "a state of anarchy."

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER URGES KINMEN POLICE TO PREPARE FOR THREE MINI DIRECT LINKS

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya Saturday urged Kinmen police to prepare well in order to be able to effectively battle the increase in crime that is likely to occur after the government implements the "three mini direct links" with mainland China.
Chang made the call while visiting Kinmen County Police Headquarters during a trip to Kinmen to preside over celebration activities for the fifth anniversary of the opening of National Kinmen Park.
Chang was accompanied by Deputy Kinmen County Magistrate Yen Ta-jen from the airport to the police headquarters to hear a briefing on Kinmen's public security situation.

Chang Tsang-po, head of Kinmen County Police Headquarters, said that at present, there are only 212 police officers in the whole Kinmen area, making it difficult to cope with the increase in crime since the government terminated the military-led civil administration system in Kinmen many years ago.
Once the government implements the "three mini direct links," it will be even more difficult to effectively crack down on rampant crime, he added.

In reply, Chang promised to strengthen the Kinmen police force in the near future. In addition to his pledge to beef up the police force, Chang also asked Kinmen police to install more surveillance equipment and strengthen civil defense in social communities in preparation for fighting crime after the implementation of the "three mini direct links."

The government plans to first implement the "three mini direct links" between Kinmen and mainland China's Xiamen by the end of this year, before eventually achieving the ultimate goal of practicing the "three direct links" with mainland China on an all-out basis.
The "three links" refer to trade, postal service, and transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S CURRENT SHOWS OF FORCE NOT AIMED AT TAIWAN: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China's ongoing massive-scale military training exercises are designed to signify its status as a world military power, not directed at Taiwan, a senior mainland affairs official with the main opposition Kuomintang said Saturday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Department, said the People's Liberation Army is currently conducting combined services drills in Beijing suburbs, Inner Mongol, northeastern China and Bohai -- also mainland China's biggest military displays in 36 years.

"As the exercises highlight such missions as attacking stealth aircraft and cruise missiles, the drills are apparently designed to beef up the PLA's capability to fight against world-class military powers," Chang said, adding that such large-scale military exercises are not suitable for staging in coastal areas.

In view of the adverse impact of mainland China's previous military intimidation against Taiwan, Chang said, Beijing has ordered coastal mainland provinces opposite Taiwan to avoid fanning bellicose sentiments or atmosphere after Taiwan's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party won the presidential election in March.

Nevertheless, Chang cautioned that mainland China's current massive-scale shows of force would deepen U.S. worry about the grave consequences of a military confrontation in the Taiwan Strait and thus step up its push for an early resumption of cross-strait dialogue.
Should that be the case, Chang warned that mainland China will take advantage of the scenario to reinforce its "one China" principle to secure political interests.

Chang pointed out that as mainland China has never renounced its attempt to use force against Taiwan and has ordered its coastal provinces to continue combat preparations, the DPP government should work out effective strategy to cope with mainland China's double-handed tricks.
Foreign wire service reports said mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin attended a training display near Beijing Friday, one of four such shows around the country and the biggest since 1964.

Jiang reportedly urged the mainland armed forces to put high-technology to work in their training. Photographs of troops and helicopters in action were splashed across the front pages of mainland China's state-run newspapers Saturday.
Beijing's China Daily quoted Jiang as telling troops to remember their "historic mission" and to "incorporate hi-tech achievements into their training".

Mainland media reports gave no details of the arms used in the displays, but a U.S. Congressional report said Tuesday mainland China had "significantly" upgraded its conventional arms by buying equipment from Russia and other countries in recent years.
They include top-of-the-line SU-27 fighters from Russia, which are thought to be comparable to the best warplanes in other Asian and U.S. arsenals.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER REAFFIRMS FEASIBILITY OF NUKE PLANT ALTERNATIVES

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi reiterated Saturday that his ministry's alternative plan to build natural gas power plants in place of completing construction on Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant is feasible and not an "impossible mission."

Lin was responding to critical remarks by opposition People First Party legislator Hsieh Chang-chieh who earlier in the day questioned how Lin expected enough privately-held plants to be constructed in time to meet the nation's energy needs when only one out of the 11 proposed plants that sought and received government permission five years ago is now operational.

With six private plants having abandoned their respective projects and four seriously stalled due to a lack of capital and problems with land acquisition, Hsieh wondered aloud whether Lin was lying or simply "unaware of what was going on."

Lin responded that it takes only three years to build a natural gas power plant and that he has even allotted another extra two or three years in case the projects face any sort of opposition, which he said that the government would help mitigate through the clear establishment of compensation standards next year and through the use of official authority.

Lin also said that he agrees with a suggestion to run a 161 kilovolt high voltage power line along the Taiwan High Speed Railway to be constructed in order to resolve the problem of sending power from southern Taiwan to power-hungry northern Taiwan.

According to Hsieh, if Taiwan's electricity needs increase by 5.5 percent each year, then the island will need an extra 9 megawatts by 2005. The government was originally planning to meet this need with the fourth nuclear plant's 2.7 megawatt capacity, another Taiwan Power Company plant's 4 megawatt capacity, as well as 2.57 megawatts from private-owned power plants.

With the government considering putting a stop to the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant -- a decision Lin said would be made by the end of the year -- Hsieh asked who would be held accountable for the energy gap when it happens.

Hsieh called for Lin to shoulder the political responsibility because Lin had stated he would step down if his ministry's suggestions were found to be "absolutely wrong." Hsieh added that he will continue to announce related "errors" and inside stories.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE PREMIER TALKS ABOUT TAIWAN ISSUE IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji said in Tokyo Saturday that Beijing will take a cautious attitude to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully, but he added that this issue should not be prolonged indefinitely.
Zhu made the remarks while meeting with Yukio Hatoyama, chief of the Democratic Party, the largest opposition party in Japan.
The premier stressed to Hatoyama that "so long as Taiwan accepts the `one China' principle, all other issues will be negotiable."
During the talks, Zhu said that some members of the Democratic Party seem to be advocating positive exchanges with Taiwan.
In response, Hatoyama said that he is against Taiwan independence but also opposes the use of military force by mainland China against Taiwan.
He expressed the hope that both mainland China and Taiwan will be able improve their mutual trust to resolve their disputes peacefully.

Zhu arrived in Tokyo on Oct. 12 for a six-day official visit. On Saturday, he also met with Komu Nonaka, secretary-general of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, and Takenori Kanzaki, chief of the Komei party.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM UNVEILS 8 MEASURES TO RESOLVE ECON. CRISIS OF CONFIDENCE (I)

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced eight new measures Saturday as part of the government's efforts to resolve the economic and political crisis of confidence Taiwan now faces.

Chang made the announcement after the Cabinet's financial and economic task force held an expanded meeting at the Presidential Office to discuss measures for resuming public confidence in the government's ability to run the domestic economy after the local bourse lost more than 3,000 points over the past four months.
Chang told a post-meeting press conference that the government will not raise tax rates during President Chen Shui-bian's four-year tenure.

"No tax hike is not an empty slogan, but a carefully-evaluated and feasible promise," Chang said, adding that the Cabinet will accelerate "finding new financial sources and cutting expenditures" in addition to promoting financial reforms to back up its "no tax hike" pledge.
For finding new financial sources, Chang said, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) will form a national property management task force to upgrade the use of state-owned land lots.

On the other hand, Chang said, the government will encourage private investment in public construction projects to help reduce government expenditure and expand private participation in public affairs. According to Chang, the government will offer incentives to encourage private industries to operate such public services as hospital and school management. Various government agencies will also be required to implement a zero-based budgetary policy and cut unnecessary spending.
Other measures worked out at the meeting included:
-- Cutting the business tax rate for the banking industry to "zero" from current 2 percent;
Chang said the tax-exempt measure is aimed at rationalizing the country's business taxation system and offering traditional industries easier access to securing working capital.

Chang said the MOF will draft a revision bill to the current business tax law to exempt banks from the controversial business tax. The revision bill will require local banks to use funds generated from the business tax exemption to write off their bad loans.
Meanwhile, local banks will be required to offer a six-month grace period for companies in traditional industries with normal business operations to repay their soon-to-be-matured loans.

Chang said the tax exemption will cost the national coffers an estimated NT$30 billion. "The MOF will raise funds from other sources to offset this shortfall in order not to affect the central government's financial grants to local-level governments," the premier said.

-- Coordinating local banks to pool a NT$450 billion fund for offering low-interest (6.5 percent to percent) loans to blue-chip traditional industry companies, with a maximum maturity period of seven years;

"The new liberalization measure is expected to help local banks handle bad debts by using foreign expertise and capital as well as to help increase domestic job opportunities and facilitate manpower training," Chang explained.
-- Ensuring no water and electricity shortages;

Chang said the government will assist private investors of power plants now under construction to overcome current investment barriers and revise the existing regulations governing private investment in the power generation industry to encourage private investment in smaller-scale power plants and development of recyclable energy resources.

Moreover, Chang said, a number of new reservoirs and water supply systems will be built in various parts of the island and many old dams will be renovated or expanded to ensure adequate water supplies for corporations and private homes. (By Sofia Wu) (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: PM UNVEILS 8 MEASURES TO RESOLVE ECON. CRISIS OF CONFIDENCE (II)

TEXT.P: Meanwhile, Chang said, the Cabinet has directed the Council for Economic Planning and Development to set aside NT$10 billion as the industrial parks development fund to facilitate leasing of land lots in local industrial parks so that investors can more easily acquire pieces of land for factory construction. If necessary, Chang said, the fund will be increased to NT$30 billion. Moreover, single-stop service counters will be established at major industrial parks to improve services for prospective investors.
-- Assisting traditional industries and small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in upgrading and transforming their operations;

Chang said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will use its 10 existing industry assisting systems and its NT$15 billion science-technology development fund to help SMEs upgrade production, marketing and management.

In addition, the MOEA will join forces with other relevant government agencies in forming a service group to help local industries cut production costs, strengthen research and development, and upgrade competitiveness.
-- Accelerating upgrading of the quality of local labor force and providing a proper quantity of foreign laborers;

Chang said the Council of Labor Affairs will consult with employers, employees and legislators in drafting a revision bill to the current Labor Standard Law for adopting an eight-week flexible work hours system in preparation for the government's plan to implement a five-day work week system next year.

The labor council will also revise current laws to ensure gender equality at workplace, remove employment barriers for female and increase job opportunities for local women to resolve labor shortage problems, Chang said.

This was the first time that the Cabinet financial task force held a meeting at the Presidential Office. President Chen Shui-bian delivered a speech at the opening of the meeting, pledging no tax hike during his tenure.

Vice President Annette Lu and several other Presidential Office officials as well as all the nine members of the Cabinet task force and heads of the island's four largest commerce and industry associations attended the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN, CHINA AIRLINES TO ADD MORE CHARTERED FLIGHTS TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines and China Airlines are meeting the surge in the number of Taiwan tour groups to Japan by increasing the number of chartered flights to northeastern Japan, notably Hokkaido.

According to Mandarin Airlines, which received approval for 100 charted flights, it plans to begin servicing mostly southern Taiwan customers by flying out of Kaohsiung to six different locations in northeastern Japan by the end of the year.
China Airlines, which already operates chartered flights to Hokkaido, also plans to expand its routes to cover more locations.

EVA Airways also operates chartered flights to Hokkaido. Travel packages usually run along the line of NT$35,000 (US$1,100) for five days and four nights in picturesque Hokkaido, which is known for the beauty of its four distinct seasons. According to EVA Airways, its 40 remaining flights this year are already mostly booked.

Local tour industry estimates show that Hokkaido is the vacation spot garnering the greatest growth in the number of Taiwan tourists in recent years, with the number expected to exceed 100,000 visitors this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-MAC CHIEF CLAIMS 'SPIRIT OF 1992' IS INVENTED BY FOREIGNER

TEXT.P: Former Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi alleged Saturday that the term "spirit of 1992" used in President Chen Shui-bian's olive branch to Beijing was invented by a foreign national, not Chen himself.

Su, the Republic of China's mainland policy planner during the former Kuomintang-government era, made the remarks during a seminar on cultivating a peaceful climate in the Taiwan Strait, sponsored by the KMT's national security division.
Su said President Chen has pitched for a return to the "spirit of 1992" for resuming dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"This may not be a wise strategy because, logically, without a consensus there can't be a spirit," Su said, adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait really had a consensus in 1992 on the "one China, separate interpretation" principle.

Based on this consensus, Su said, a historic cross-strait summit, known as the Koo-Wang meeting, became possible in 1993. "And the Koo-Wang meeting further led to a series of cross-strait talks on certain practical, technical issues between 1993 and 1995," Su explained.

He claimed that President Chen, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, intends to use the term of "spirit of 1992" to replace the "1992 consensus" to cover up his reluctance to accept the phrase that "Taiwan is part of China."
Su said the KMT's stance is that both Taiwan and the mainland are parts of China.

"In the past, Beijing was unwilling to say 'both Taiwan and the mainland are parts of China,'" Su said. After the DPP came to power in May, Beijing has adjusted its wording and declared publicly that both Taiwan and the mainland are parts of China.

Su said the DPP government should recognize Beijing's goodwill in making such a statement and begins to take measures to test Beijing's sincerity, including whether Beijing would truly treat Taiwan on an equal footing.
"The DPP should government should not continue ignoring Beijing's goodwill gesture, otherwise, the long-stalled cross-strait relations can't make headway," Su said.
He further reminded President Chen that the vague term "spirit of 1992" would only make the already confused cross-strait relations even more turbulent and disordered.

Moreover, Su said since the phrase "spirit of 1992" was invented by an English-speaking foreigner, it remains to be seen whether the "involvement of this foreign factor" will have a positive or negative impact on the future development of cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BUSINESS LEADERS SATISFIED WITH OUTCOME OF ECONOMIC MEETING

TEXT.P: The leaders of Taiwan's four major economic and industrial organizations said Saturday that they were satisfied with the outcome of the expanded meeting of the Executive Yuan's financial and economic task force.
The meeting, held at the Presidential Office, was designed to find ways to stabilize Taiwan's financial and economic situation, especially the stock market.
Eight measures were adopted at the meeting to help resolve the pressing financial and economic problems, including no tax increase during President Chen Shui-bian's four-year tenure.

Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, said that his suggestions have been included in the conclusions of the meeting and that he believes the new government is determined to engage in renovation.
He said that he will throw his full support behind the implementation of the conclusions reached at the meeting.

Wang You-theng, chairman of the Republic of China's General Chamber of Commerce, voiced his appreciation on behalf of the financial institutions for the decision to cancel the 2 percent business tax levied on financial institutions.

Regarding the steps to be taken to stabilize the stock market, Wang said that he hopes the Finance Ministry will exchange views with representatives from the insurance industry and from the financial, commerce, and industrial circles.
Lin Kun-chung, chairman of the National Federation of Industries, said the measures adopted at the meeting will provide enormous help to Taiwan's traditional industries.
He also expressed the hope that the national stabilization fund will invest capital in Taiwan's traditional industries and help them in management.

Tai Sheng-tung, president of the Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises' Association, said that those attending the meeting decided to provide greater government guarantees for enterprises applying for loans.
As a result, he estimated, an additional NT$100 billion in bank loans will become available for Taiwan's small and medium-sized enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL GROUP URGES BEIJING TO RESUME TALKS ON 1992-93 SPIRIT

TEXT.P: The president's advisory group on cross-Taiwan Strait relations Saturday urged Beijing to resume bilateral negotiations based on the spirit of 1992-93, which paved the way for constructive exchanges between the two sides.

Michael Hsiao, spokesman for the group, told the media after the group's second meeting that participants of the meeting also called on the leaders of the island's major political parties to get together to work out the foundation for talks with mainland China.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen and Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow were invited to make reports at the meeting, which was presided over by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, head of the group.

After hearing the reports, members of the group expressed the hope that cross-strait dialogue will be able to resume in line with the 1992-93 spirit, under which SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait Chairman Wang Daohan, held their first meeting in Singapore in April 1993.

Cross-strait exchanges were interrupted by then-President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June 1995, and have been suspended since Lee redefined cross-strait relations as a special state-to-state relationship in July last year.
As the president's advisory group is only a consultative body, Hsiao told reporters that the suggestions worked out by the group will not replace the official guidelines for national unification.
He said the group plans to present a report to the president on the principle for dealing with cross-strait affairs by the end of this year.
Regarding the "one China" issue, Hsiao said that more clarification from both sides is required, and added that this issue was raised at the day's meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR PRAGUE

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and his wife left Taipei for Prague Saturday night to attend the "2000 Forum," which will be chaired by Czech President Vaclav Havel.

Lee and his wife were accompanied on the trip by former National Security Council Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih and his wife. They were seen off at the airport by Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng.
During his stay in Prague, Lee said that he will meet with exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, who is also among the foreign dignitaries invited to the forum.
This was Lee's second overseas trip after he quitted the presidency last May, with the first trip taking him to Britain a few months ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 15, or the 17th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
70 B.C.: Virgil, Roman epic, didactic, and pastoral poet, is born. His greatest work was the epic poem "Aeneid," which tells of the wanderings of Aeneas after the sack of Troy.
1821: The Central American Federation wins independence from Spain.
1925: During the warlord era in China, Sun Chuan-fang, superintendent of Chekiang Province, appoints himself as the commander-in-chief of a military alliance force of five provinces in central China to launch an expedition against Chang Tso-lin's army in Manchuria.
1928: The airship "Graf Zeppelin" lands in New Jersey after making its first transatlantic crossing from Germany.
1945: Pierre Laval, the French politician who led the Vichy government which collaborated with Nazi Germany during World War II, is executed.
1946: Nazi war criminal Hermann Goering commits suicide by poisoning himself one day before his scheduled execution.
1950: The first popular elections of magistrates in Taiwan Province are held in Hualien and Taitung. There is a poor voter turnout and re-elections are scheduled for Oct. 22.
1955: A single ROC Air Force Saber jet, piloted by Captain Sun Szu-wen, shoots down one MiG-17 in a dogfight with 12 Communist Chinese MiG-17s north of Matsu.
1962: The coffin of Dr. Hu Shih, the late president of Academia Sinica, is buried at a cemetery in Nankang.
1964: Nikita Khrushchev is replaced by Leonid Brezhnev as First Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party with Alexei Kosygin becoming prime minister.
1969: The biggest antiwar demonstration in U.S. history is staged as millions of Americans take part in organized rallies and marches to voice their disapproval over their country's continuing involvement in the Vietnam War.
1973: The Sino-Paraguayan Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973: U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and Vietnamese political leader Le Duc Tho share the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the U.S.-North Vietnam cease-fire. But Le refuses it on the grounds that peace is not yet established in South Vietnam.
1973: Y. T. Wong, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, leaves for Los Angeles to attend a seminar on Sino-American trade.
1974: A 15-member national team leaves Taipei for Seoul to take part in the First Asian Taekwondo Championships.
1975: A martial arts contest is held in Tainan with 400 people from 11 countries attending.
1980: Lt. Gen. Armando Reyes Villa, defense minister of Bolivia, visits the headquarters of the ROC Army and also the ROC Navy.
1986: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang, presided over by Chairman of the KMT Chiang Ching-kuo, unanimously passes a resolution of political reform to institute the National Security Law during the period of Communist Rebellion and allow the formation of new political parties and organizations.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh, a member of the Academia Sinica, wins the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry. President Chiang Ching-kuo sends a letter of congratulations to Lee on Oct. 17.
1987: The ROC Executive Yuan passes regulations governing the applications of local residents wishing to visit relatives in mainland China.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: South African President F. W. de Klerk and African National Conress leader Nelson Mandela share the Nobel Peace Prize for their work toward ending apartheid and laying the foundations for a democartic South Africa.
1997: Steven Chu, a member of Academia Sinica and a professor at Stanford University, becomes one of the two co-winners of the Nobel Prize in physics.
1999: A Mirage 2000-5 fighter jet of the Republic of China crashes while on a routine training mission off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man must examine his own heart and see that he has no cause for self-reproach, that he has no evil thought in his mind. Wherein the moral man is superior to other men consists even in that which is not seen by men."
