DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING HAITIAN PRESIDENT BIDS FAREWELL TO ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Sunday that the ROC would like to strengthen exchanges and cooperation with Haiti in every aspect.

Chen also expressed the hope that Haitian President Rene Preval gained a better understanding of the ROC during his visit and will work toward increasing bilateral relations based on the solid foundation of the two countries' relationship.
The Haitian president and his wife, leading an official delegation, arrived in Taipei Oct. 9 to attend celebration activities marking the ROC's Double Ten National Day.
President Preval, accompanied by Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee, called on President Chen at the Presidential Office to bid him farewell before departing later in the day.

President Chen noted that this was President Preval's second visit to Taiwan and that he is the only Haitian head of state to visit the ROC twice, showing that Preval attaches great importance to the ROC-Haiti friendship.
The President said that he hopes to visit the Caribbean country soon to reciprocate the long-term support of the ROC by the Haitian government and people.

Chen also lauded Preval as a true friend of Taiwan, saying that although the Haitian president cannot seek re-election after completing his five-year term as stated in the Haitian constitution, "we welcome him to visit again as an expert in agriculture so as to promote further exchanges and cooperation between the two sides."
Chen also expressed the hope that the year-end presidential election in Haiti will be go smoothly.
He took the chance to say happy birthday to the daughter of President Preval to the delight of the visiting guests.
President Preval said he appreciated the warm hospitality extended to him and his delegation during the visit, adding that he is impressed by the political and economic development of the ROC.

He said that his first visit to Taiwan in 1998 was a journey of discovery of the ROC and that he learned a lot more during this trip, adding that this visit was aimed at increasing bilateral cooperation between the two countries.

He noted that Taiwan and Haiti are similar in many ways, adding that his country needs to learn a lot from Taiwan's political and economic development. He also vowed to continue promoting the bilateral friendship even after he steps down as president next February, saying he will work with the new government of Haiti to this end.
President Preval also again extended an invitation to President Chen and his wife to visit his country soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP URGES SPONSORING OF IMPOVERISHED LATIN AMERICA CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu Sunday urged the people of Taiwan to take substantial action by sponsoring impoverished children in Latin America to help cement ties with the ROC's allies in the region.

Lu made the remarks while speaking about her recent visit to four Central American countries at the Kiwanis International ROC district 27th Summit Convention in central Taiwan's Shalu township, Taichung County.

Lu said that during her visit to El Salvador, Honduras, Belize, and Guatemala, the media in those countries had reported prominently of her visit, showing the importance those countries attached to her visit.

She said that these diplomatic allies of Taiwan, under international pressure, have demonstrated steady support for the ROC over the years, adding that such steady support has made her realize that the ROC does not need countries that are "too greedy," but countries that "really support us."

Lu stressed that in order to help cement the ROC's relations with its Central American allies, she is ready to introduce the music and dance of Mayan culture to Taiwan, adding that she was quite impressed by Mayan culture during her recent visit.

She pointed out that she will also launch a campaign for the sponsoring of 10,000 impoverished children in Latin America, saying she believes love is inexhaustible. She expressed the hope that members of Kiwanis International could pool their resources to help the nation gain more diplomatic allies during the four-year term of the administration under President Chen Shui-bian.

She also said that Taiwan's annual per capita income surge from US$100 to US$14,000 over the past five decades could be attributed to five factors: human rights on the island, total democratization, peace, love, and the island's development of technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT'S ECONOMY-BOOSTING PACKAGE GREETED WITH DOUBTS

TEXT.P: The measures introduced Saturday by President Chen Shui-bian's administration aimed at boosting Taiwan's sagging economy were greeted with doubts by economists and the opposition Sunday.

Lee Kao-chao, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said President Chen's promise of no tax-hikes during his four-year term may be welcome by tax-payers, but could backfire by harming the country's long-term financial health.

The well-known economist said the administration can probably afford to keep tax rates at current levels for the next year, but its ability to initiate major programs in the final three years of its term will be heavily constrained unless it can pull in extra income.

Noting that the government's budget for fiscal year 2001 is already extremely tight despite the fact that the government has raised loans to the legal capacity, Lee said the administration will have difficulty in governing with the current amount of revenues, not to mention if it implements any tax cuts.

Under the economy-boosting package unveiled by President Chen, the two percent transaction tax levied on the finance industry will be lifted at an estimated cost of NT$30 billion (US$0.96 billion) per year to the government.
"How can a government without financial resources promote the public's confidence in the economy?" Lee asked.

Further more, Lee said, revenues from the transaction tax have already been factored into the 2001 budget, so the loss of the NT$30 billion in revenues will force the government to sell some of the state's assets, likely at loss, to fill the gap. Lee added that such a move doesn't serve the public's interest.

Sun Ta-chiang, spokesman for the People First Party, dismissed the package as "a radical shot in the arm" meant to have an immediate effect rather than provide a long-term cure for the country's ailing economy, despite the good intentions of its authors.

Pointing to the government's promise of loans to refugees of the Sept. 21 earthquake, Sun said the move benefits only a small minority of citizens because of the strict requirements, adding that the offering of NT$450 billion (US$14.28 billion) in potential loans to small- and medium-sized enterprises will also have only a limited effect for the same reason.
P. K. Chiang, former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development and head of a Kuomintang think tank, criticized the government for what he called "beating around the bush".

The leading architect of Taiwan's prosperous economy under the rule of the KMT pointed out that the pursuit of an independent and nuclear-free Taiwan by Presdient Chen and his Democratic Progressive Party are the main causes for Taiwan's economic woes.
"Any measures not addressing these causes will miss the point and are doomed to fail," Chiang said.

He suggested that Chen and his party drop the advocacy of Taiwan independence from the DPP party charter, saying this has blocked the government's contacts with Beijing and thereby hampered the establishment of direct shipping links between Taiwan and mainland China.

Direct shipping links, Chiang argued, would provide a lifeline for Taiwan's faltering manufacturing industry by creating a situation where mainland China could be used as a manufacturing base for its low-end products while maintaining Taiwan as a base for its factories producing high-tech goods.
Taiwan's manufacturing industry is teetering on the edge of extinction because of the high labor costs on the island and the fierce competition from mainland China.
The KMT think tank head also urged the government to continue the construction of the island's fourth nuclear plant, which Chen's administration is moving to scrap on environmental grounds.
Chiang said the abolishment of the plant will cast doubts on the government's commitment to boosting the economy.
He also expressed doubts about the wisdom of having the president personally involved in the task of rescuing the economy.

Calling the president the government's last resort in rallying public confidence, Chiang said he is worried that Chen may come to the end of his tether if the economy-boosting measures fail and his credibility suffers as a result.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPERT FORESEES NO IMMEDIATE CONFLICT ACROSS THE TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C. Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A U.S. expert on Chinese affairs said in Washington Saturday that although no conflict across the Taiwan Strait is expected to happen in the foreseeable future, relations between the two sides are still unstable and a crisis could potentially develop.

David Brown, deputy director of the Asian Research Department of the John Hopkins International Research Institute, said that although Beijing Vice Premier Qian Qichen has proposed certain new ideas on the issue of cross-strait relations, Beijing has been concentrating on using Taiwan's internal disputes to push the government of Chen Shui-bian into accepting Beijing's "one China" principle.
Brown, in his article recently published in a periodical on Far East Asia's bilateral relations, said President Chen has decided not to yield to pressure from Beijing.

The Chen administration' failure to reach a compromise with the opposition Kuomintang, which holds a majority in the Legislative Yuan, has been the main factor paralyzing the administration's ability to carry out its policies, he said.

The KMT's ability to employ procedural moves to delay deliberations on the national budget bill and on whether or not to continue construction on Taiwan's controversial fourth nuclear power plant has caused the serious dispute between the Executive branch and the Legislative Yuan, he said.

Although Taiwan's economic performance has been good, the continuing plunge in Taipei's stock market has shown the public's lack of confidence in the administration. Despite the government's best efforts at halting the plunge in the stock market, stock prices have dropped over 25 percent since President Chen was inaugurated on May 20.

Brown, a career diplomat who has served in U.S. diplomatic missions in Beijing, Taipei and Hong Kong, said that the tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has relaxed and that both sides have expressed the hope of resuming dialogue.
However, he added, the manner or style of dialogue has not yet been agreed upon and the prospects of dialogue resuming anytime soon are limited.

The Clinton administration has told the Beijing government that President Chen Shui-bian's pragmatic approach to cross-strait relations will open new opportunities for dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, noted Brown.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF PEOPLE CONSIDER GOVERNMENT'S ECONOMIC PACKAGE HELPFUL

TEXT.P: About 70 percent of the people of Taiwan said they think the economic promotion package passed Saturday by an enlarged conference of government financial and economic leaders will be helpful, according to a survey released Sunday.

In the poll conducted by the Trendgo Survey Research Center, 60 percent of those interviewed said the eight-point package will at least boost the faltering stock market, although 65 percent of the respondents listed political turmoil and investors' lack of confidence as the main causes for the stock market's nose-dive.

The other reasons stated by interviewees for the stock market's plummet in order were capital flight, including local investment in mainland China, the depletion of domestic capital, the worsening of the international economic situation, and the deterioration of the domestic economy.
The total capitalization of Taiwan's public-listed stocks has decreased by about one third since the new government was sworn in on May 20.
More than 60 percent of the respondents said their families owned stocks and were therefore feeling the pinch.

Meanwhile, 62.8 percent of the people interviewed said the government's economic promotion package will boost non-technology based industries, which bore the brunt of the stock price plummet, and 75.4 percent of them said they support the package.
The poll also found, 51.9 percent of the public is satisfied with the government's efficiency in addressing Taiwan's economic woes, while 37.1 percent said they were unsatisfied.
The survey was carried out by phone among 1,020 adults in Taiwan between 5:20 p.m. to 10 p.m. Friday. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS SAY TAIWAN ENJOYS SOLID ECONOMIC FUNDAMENTALS

TEXT.P: Several local economic experts cited statistics Sunday to illustrate that Taiwan's economic fundamentals are actually quite good, despite the general lack of confidence in the government's ability to handle economic and financial issues.

Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said that Taiwan's exports registered a 25 percent annual growth rate in the period from January to September 2000, the best performance for that period over the last 12 years. He added that this reflects the high competitiveness of Taiwan in the world market.

Wu cited the statistics after the Cabinet's economic and financial task force held an expanded meeting to find out ways to recover the public's confidence in the government's capability to handle economic and financial issues, especially as the local bourse has dropped more than 3,000 points over the last four months.

He indicated that the logic that the lack of public confidence in the stock market could also affect the economic situation is wrong, adding that the notion that the government was forced to hold an emergency economic meeting because of the slumping stock market is also arguable. However, he said he personally supports the eight measures to prop up the domestic economy that the task force came up with in Saturday's meeting.

He Mei-yueh, vice chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said the relocation of some industries abroad is quite normal, adding that there are also some foreign enterprises shifting to Taiwan. She also noted that this situation is beneficial to the changing structure of Taiwan's industries.

He indicated that local industries must experiment with change and accept the new circumstances, saying that they can no longer count on a large supply of cheap labor, like in mainland China, to remain competitive.

He said that in a recent vice ministerial economic meeting between Taiwan and United States, the U.S. delegates shared the view that Taiwan's economic development is very stable, pointing to Taiwan's 6.5 percent economic growth rate, its 9 percent industrial growth rate, and its low commodity price fluctuations and low unemployment rate.

The U.S. delegation also saw no presence of political instability in Taiwan, and on the contrary, stated that the existence of different opinions between diverse political parties is quite natural and healthy, he added.

He pointed out that President Chen Shui-bian has said people are free to criticize the government, but the best way to resolve the nation's problems is to sit down together and discuss solutions, adding that he agrees with his opinion that only cooperation can contribute to economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTER CHENG YEN RECEIVES NOEL FOUNDATION'S LIFE AWARD

TEXT.P: The Noel Foundation of the United States on Saturday gave the life award to Dharma Master Cheng Yen of Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Association for her "love without borders" activities.
Two of Master Cheng Yen's followers received the award in the name of Cheng Yen, who has been dubbed the "Mother Teresa of Asia".
At the award presentation ceremony, the organizers showed a film introducing Cheng Yen's charitable activities over the last 35 years.
Noel Irwin Hentschel, founder of the Noel Foundation, said he admires Master Cheng Yen for promoting the spirit of "helping the poor and educating the rich."
Cheng Yen is the first Chinese citizen to receive the Noel Foundation's life award.
Inspired by Mother Teresa, Noel Irwin Hentschel established the foundation in 1989 to create and fund projects to "help those most in need to help themselves".
Former life award honorees include Mother Teresa, Margaret Thatcher of Great Britain, and former Philippine President Corazon Aquino.
The foundation's life award for 2000 was also given to Sherry Lansing, chairwoman and CEO of the Motion Picture Group of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGES GOV'T TO PAY ATTENTION TO ECONOMIC PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, Sunday urged the government to pay more attention to the nation's economic problems.
Lien made the remarks at the launching of a cultural and educational foundation headed by Chao Shou-po, director-general of the KMT's Department of Central Organization.

Lien said he was worried about Taiwan's unemployment rate, which recently hit its highest level in years at 3.6 percent. The average waiting period for finding new employment also increased to six months.

Lien recalled that when Chao was the chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, he began to introduce foreign laborers into Taiwan. But judging from the current economic situation, Lien expressed worries that if the economy continues to worsen, Taiwan will turn from a foreign labor importer to exporter.

Lien also reminded the government to pay more attention to the downsizing of the Taiwan provincial government, saying that the next stage in the downsizing process will soon begin and measures need to be taken to accommodate the thousands of government employees who will be affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 16, or the 18th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1758: Noah Webster, American lexicographer responsible for the first American dictionary, is born.
1793: The execution of Marie-Antoinette, 38, queen-consort of the late King Louis XVI, and the prospect of further deaths by guillotine of both counter-revolutionaries and revolutionaries suggest that France is slipping even deeper into anarchy.
1846: American dentist William T. G. Morton successfully uses an anesthetic (diethyl ether) for the first time and removes a tumor from a young man's jaw at Massachusetts General Hospital.
1886: David Ben-Gurion, first prime minister of Israel, is born in Poland. He was a leading force in the creation of the state.
1906: British New Guinea becomes part of Australia.
1933: The ROC government troops launch a fifth all-out offensive against communist rebels by adopting a fort-blockade policy to move carefully and steadily, step by step.
1946: Ten leading Nazis found guilty a fortnight ago of crimes against humanity by the International War Crimes Tribunal are hanged in the gymnasium of Nuremberg Prison.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek presents the Chinese communists with eight conditions for a nationwide cease-fire.
1949: The Kuomintang establishes the Revolutionary Practice Institute with party leader Chiang Kai-shek as its president.
1951: Liaquat Ali Khan, prime minister of Pakistan, is shot dead while addressing a public meeting in Rawalpindi.
1959: George C. Marshall, American soldier, diplomat, and politician, dies at the age of 78. As US secretary of state, he organized the European Recovery Program often called the Marshall Plan, for which he received the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize.
1963: Ludwig Erhard succeeds Konrad Adenauer as chancellor of West Germany.
1964: Communist China explodes its first atom bomb at the Lop Nor test site in Sinkiang.
1972: President Dawda Kairbr Jawara of Gambia arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1975: Gen. Lai Ming-tang, chief of the general staff, leaves for a visit to Jordan and Saudi Arabia.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives a 30-member delegation of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. The group is headed by Eastern Washington State College President Emerson C. Shuck.
1978: Polish Cardinal Karol Wojtyla is elected pope, the first non-Italian pope since 1542 and the youngest this century.
1979: Wei Jingsheng, noted human rights activist in mainland China, is sentenced to 15 years imprisonment by a "people's court" in Beijing for "anti-revolutionary" activities.
1981: Moshe Dayan, Israeli politician and minister of defense, dies of a heart attack at the age of 66. He directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old mainland Chinese air force pilot, flies his MiG-19 to a US military base outside Seoul in South Korea.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, 1970 Nobel Literature Prize winner, arrives in Taiwan from Tokyo at the invitation of the Wu San-lien Literary Foundation of the Republic of China.
1984: Chiang Nan, pen name of Chinese writer Liu Yi-liang, is shot and killed by an assassin at his home in San Francisco.
1987: A Force-11 storm, the worst to hit Britain in 300 years, lashes southern Britain, demolishing buildings, blackening London and killing 18 people.
1989: A committee of the Convention in International Trade in Endangered Species, meeting in Lausane, Switzerland, votes 76-11 in favor of a ban on international trade in ivory.
1999: The ROC Navy destroyer "Kunyang" is formally decommissioned after serving in the navy for 31 years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, even when he is not doing anything, is serious; and, even when he does not speak, is truthful."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 245.16 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 245.16 points to close at 5,630.95.
Market turnover amounted to NT$94.68 billion (US$2.97 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESSURE OF SURGING WORLD OIL PRICES TEMPORARILY EASES: CPC

TEXT.P: Pressure on Chinese Petroleum Corp. to hike its oil prices has temporarily eased as international oil prices stabilized over the weekend in light of the peace summit in the Middle East scheduled for Monday, CPC sources said.
The average international oil price declined to about US$33 a barrel over the weekend.

A CPC spokesman said a price hike in the near future is unlikely if the summit meeting helps lead to a peaceful resolution to the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians. He added however that a price surge would be inevitable should the peace summit fail and the international price of oil increase to US$37 a barrel.

Citing last Friday's West Texas Intermediate benchmark price, which decreased US$1.19 from the previous trading day to settle at US$33.8 a barrel, the CPC official said world oil prices have stabilized after reaching a 10-year high on Thursday.
CPC Vice President Tsai San-lang told reporters Monday that chances are good that the CPC will raise oil prices if world prices surge to US$37 a barrel.
Monday's peace summit, being participated in by the leaders of Israel, Palestine, the United States, and several Middle Eastern nations, is not expected to have more than modest results.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 245.16 points to close at 5,630.95.

Encouraged by the eight economy-boosting measures announced by the Cabinet over the weekend, the bourse opened at 6,060.44, but due to profit-taking selling pressure and a lack of confidence on the part of investors, the index began to slide down in the second half of the session. The bourse fluctuated between 6,161.16 and 5,602.72 during trading.

A total of 3 billion stocks worth NT$94.68 billion (US$2.97 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.39 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$75.62 billion (US$2.42 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 5.3 percent, followed by textile issues at 4.4 percent, cement stocks at 3.8 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 3.7 percent, foodstuff stocks at 3.5 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.5 percent, and construction stocks at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 394 to 150, with 80 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taiwan stock index futures were lower Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization weighted index futures for October moved down 412 points to close at 5,486, with 4,687 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for November plunged 413 points to finish at 5,487, with 4,541 contract transactions, while December futures lost 414 points to close at 5,501, with 19 contracts changing hands.
March 2001 futures fell 100 points to finish at 5,650, with two contract transactions, while June 2001 futures decreased 298 points to close at 5,601, with three contracts traded.
Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Monday at 5,898 for October, 5,900 for November, 5,915 for December, 5,750 for next March, and 5,899 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
October TE futures moved down 20.45 points to close at 272.15, with 1,471 contract transactions, while November TE futures lost 20.3 points to finish at 269.7, with 1,079 contract transactions.
December TE futures decreased 19.95 points to close at 265.05 with 13 contract transactions, while March 2001 TE futures fell 20 points to finish at 266.25, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June 2001 TE futures.
October TF futures moved down 42 points to close at 703, with 1,024 contract transactions, while November TF futures lost 44.4 points to finish at 711, with 711 contracts changing hands.
December TF futures decreased 29.8 points to close at 725.4, with 45 contract transactions, while March 2001 TF futures moved up 15 points to finish at 735, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYDNEY 2000 PARALYMPIC GAMES SET TO KICK OFF

TEXT.P: The 2000 Paralympic Games, with almost 4,000 participating athletes from 128 different countries, is set to kick off October 18.

In an interview with the CNA, Carmen McCrone, chief of the Sydney Paralympic Organizing Committee's media relations, said the "Paralympic Games is the world's biggest sporting event in terms of the number of athletes and countries taking part in the 11-day event."

She said that, in addition, about 2,600 journalists, 2,000 team officials, 1,000 technicians, and about 10,000 volunteers will participate in what she described as "the largest contingent ever for a single international sports event."

Tim Fischer, formerly deputy prime minister of Australia and now the Paralympic mayor, told a news conference on Monday that the "2000 Paralympic Games will be a great success because of the unceasing efforts being made by all the organizers and the tremendous support from the Australian people."

Chinese Taipei, which will have 25 athletes taking part in six different events, will be trying to improve on its performance at the 1996 Atlanta Paralympic Games at which it won one gold and two bronze medals.
The events Chinese Taipei athletes will compete in are track and field, judo, power lifting, swimming, table tennis, and tennis.

"Our athletes are better prepared this time, so we hope they can perform better and win even more medals this year," said Chang Chao-shen, deputy chief of the Chinese Taipei team, in an interview with the CNA on Monday.

All 87,000 tickets for the opening ceremony on October 18 and the closing ceremony on October 29 have been sold out, as have the tickets to all the major events, including basketball, swimming, and track and field.

The SPOC has spent almost A$180 million (US$113 million) on hosting the Paralympic Games, much less than the US$3.75 billion poured into the just-concluded Olympic Games. Part of the reason for the lower price tag is the fact that the Paralympics will make use of facilities built for the Olympics that are already in place, an SPOC spokesman told the CNA.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA RECRUITING MILLIONS TO CARRY OUT CENSUS

TEXT.P: Mainland China is recruiting millions of officials to conduct the world's largest census, reported the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday.

Beijing will utilize 6 million census officials to collect the details of the world's most populous country. Five million of them will knock on the doors of 350 million households to conduct interviews and 1 million advisers will check their work, reported the daily.

In the previous census taken ten years ago, officials discovered 8 million more people than they expected. The daily reported mainland China put the country's population at about 1,259,090,000, or 22 percent of the world's population.

The daily however questioned the accuracy and efficiency of the census because many Chinese families do not report second or third children to census takers because they are afraid of being punished for violating the country's strict one-child policy.
The daily reported that in a society where people are deeply suspicious of officialdom, many balk at giving intimate details about their daily lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO HOLD TELECONFERENCE WITH U.S. THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will hold a teleconference with a noted think tank of the United States Monday night, officials of the Presidential Office confirmed Monday.
The officials said that the president will speak on cross-Taiwan Strait relations in his teleconference with the New York-based Council of Foreign Relations.
President Chen will also speak on Taiwan's bid to enter the World Trade Organization, the partial reshuffle of his Cabinet, and his views on Taiwan's financial and economic problems, they said.

They said that this will be the first teleconference since President Chen's inauguration in May. The president had a similar conference with the Heritage Foundation, another U.S. think tank, in April.

They said that the president, in addressing U.S. concerns about Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, will urge Beijing to shelf disputes and return to the "spirit of 92" to resume cross-strait dialogue and exchanges.
The officials said that the theme of the teleconference will be Taiwan's political and economic situation and cross-strait relations five months into the new administration's term.
The president will also speak on the substantial measures taken to deal with financial and economic problems by the Cabinet since a partial reshuffle recently.
The officials said that participants on the U.S. side will include about 70 scholars, business leaders, and media representatives.
The teleconference is scheduled to begin at about 8:30 p.m. Taipei time.
The officials said that such teleconferences may continue to take place in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER HEAD OF STATE RADIO SAYS WILL RETURN UPON RETRIEVING PASSPORT

TEXT.P: Former director of Taiwan's Central Broadcasting System, Chu Wan-ching (Gloria Chu), said Monday that she will return to Taiwan to face justice as soon as she has her passport retrieved from the U.S. Immigration Office.
In a long-distance telephone interview with Taipei's UFO Radio, Chu, who is currently in the United States, denied having been aware that she was restricted from leaving Taiwan.

Chu, however, offered her apologies to Taiwan prosecutors and admitted that she was wrong to have said that she will not return to Taiwan "if the prosecutors decide to promulgate an order for her arrest and treat her unfairly."

Chu, 50, was discovered early last Friday morning to have left the country only a couple hours after she was released on NT$500,00 (US$15,700) bail Thursday night after being charged with embezzlement.

Upon arriving in Los Angeles, she was held for questioning at the U.S. Immigration Office's airport detention facility after Taipei prosecutors indicated through Interpol that she was the subject of a criminal investigation.

However, she was subsequently released Friday afternoon (U.S. West Coast time) because she was found not to have violated any immigration regulations, said a U.S. Immigration Office public relations officer.

At a press conference held after her release in Los Angeles, Chu said that she was indignant at being suspected by prosecutors of having skipped bail and being on the run. She added that her "so-called case" had not yet been brought before the court and that she had not been indicted, so she expected fair treatment from the justice system.

She stressed that she left Taipei legally and arrived in the United States with an unexpired immigration visa and that she had only left for the United States in order to accompany her son to Valley Forge, a military boarding school in Pennsylvania whose reported registration deadline is Oct. 14.

Chu noted that her passport has already been confiscated by the U.S. Immigration Office, which will speak with her again on Oct. 27 in an interview on whether to grant her a green card. Therefore, she added that she will ask her lawyers to file a request for leave during the period on her behalf at the Taipei District Prosecutors Office.

On Monday, TDPO Assistant Chief Prosecutor Chang Wen-cheng stressed that the investigation of Chu's embezzlement case will continue and will definitely not be interrupted by Chu's staying in the United States.

Chang noted however that it is still too early to speculate on whether the TDPO will promulgate an order for Chu's arrest. He said that if she were to fail to appear in court after being subpoenaed three times, an order for her arrest would be issued, but he added that "the subpoena process has not even begun yet."

Also on Monday, Prosecutor Shen Ming-lun visited Chu's Taipei residence on Chingcheng Street to inspect the luxurious interior decorations which were allegedly payed for using money from the Central Broadcast System Trust Fund.
Chu, who is said to have maintained close connections with Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his wife, is suspected of having embezzled some NT$16 million (US$516,130) from the CBS Trust Fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER WILL CONSIDER ESTABLISHING LAS VEGAS MODEL CASINO ON PENGHU

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-Lan stated Monday that she will take into consideration the establishment of a casino on Penghu only if it is based on the Las Vegas model instead of on the Macau model.

Yeh explained in her response to a question put forth by Legislator Lin Pin-kuan at an interpellation session that she may consider setting up a casino on Penghu if it makes up only a small part of Penghu's recreation facilities which are mainly intended for family use.
Lin also said that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has spent most of its tourism budget on the development of Hengchun Peninsula.
Yeh stressed that although the ministry is making efforts toward turning Hengchun Peninsula into the Hawaii of Taiwan, the project currently is still at the planning stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN FORMULA MAY NOT SUITABLE FOR ROC'S U.N. BID: FM

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said Monday that the formula used by North and South Korea to join the United Nations may not necessarily suitable for the Republic of China to adopt in promoting its U.N. bid.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Tien said it took the two Koreas 28 years to realize their goal of joining the United Nations simultaneously under the formula of a divided country.
As the separation of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait differs from the division of North and South Korea, Tien said, the Korean formula may not necessarily be useful for Taiwan's U.N. bid.
Tien said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has consistently promoted the ROC's U.N. bid based on the fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are separately ruled.
"We are hopeful that mainland China can face up to this reality and accept it," Tien said.
The minister admitted that the ROC faces many hurdles in pursuing U.N. representation and that there is no panacea to cope with all those obstacles.

Nevertheless, Tien said, the MOFA will not be daunted by any setbacks nor will it cease its promotional efforts because seeking a U.N. seat provides an important opportunity for the ROC to assert its sovereign status and defend its position and legitimate rights in the international community.
Tien said he feels regret that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait still fail to resume dialogue.

Noting that the MOFA is not in a position to decide when cross-strait dialogue can be resumed, Tien said even if Taiwan and mainland China resume dialogue, its effect on the ROC's U.N bid remains to be seen.
The ROC, a U.N. founding member, has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971 when the U.N. General Assembly gave the China seat to Beijing.

Since 1993, ROC allies have annually pushed the U.N. authority to set up a special committee to work on measures to resolve Taiwan's representation issue. The proposal, however, has been unable to make the U.N. General Assembly agenda over the past eight years.

In the future, Tien said, the MOFA will convince as many diplomatic allies as possible to endorse the proposal urging the U.N. authority to form a special committee to study the ROC's representation issue. Meanwhile, he said, the MOFA will also persuade as many countries with diplomatic ties with Beijing as possible to adopt a neutral, impartial attitude toward the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.070 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$31.990.
The local currency opened at NT$32.200 and was traded between NT$31.760 and NT$32.205.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$505 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR CONFIDENCE IN GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday called for the Taiwan public as well as Chinese patriots abroad to have confidence in his government's ability to revitalize the sagging economy.

Addressing a Presidential Office tea party for representatives of the overseas Chinese community who returned to Taiwan to attend the National Day celebrations, Chen said the administration is only now able to begin tackling domestic issues, now that it has dealt with handling cross-strait relations, stabilizing foreign relations, and boosting the morale of the military.

Chen said that since he took office, cross-strait relations, the nation's diplomatic policies, and stability in the military -- all highly challenging issues for him -- have been resolved to at least satisfactory levels, thanks to the efforts of the administration.
The government has the time and energy to tackle domestic affairs and related issues only now that those other major concerns have been at least temporarily settled, Chen said.
He added, however, that it will take a great deal of time and patience to deal with domestic affairs and related reforms.

Currently, the government is making extraordinary efforts on revitalizing the sagging economy, initiating administrative reforms, working on post-disaster rehabilitation, wiping out "black gold" politics, and enacting judiciary and educational reforms, Chen noted.

Meanwhile, Chen saluted ethnic Chinese residing abroad as a special group, which he called "the mother of the Chinese revolution" and "the father of reforms." He called for the overseas Chinese community to continue to support the new government of Taiwan.

In related news, Presidential Office sources said Monday that Chen is planning to meet personally with the heads of the other three major opposition parties in the near future to exchange views on major national issues.

After failing to host a roundtable meeting with Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong, which he called soon after his inauguration, Chen changed tracks recently and planned to meet with Lien, Soong and New Party head Hao Lung-ping, in a "face-to-face" manner.

To realize that goal, Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun will first meet with the secretaries general of the three opposition parties to pave the way for the "one-to-one" meetings, to be presided over by Chen himself, the sources said.
Yu reportedly first met with PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi Monday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOV'T PROMOTES CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taipei City Government's China affairs team held a meeting Monday to discuss exchanges between the capital city and cities on the mainland and Hong Kong.
In the meeting, the group decided to focus exchange plans on Shanghai and Hong Kong after the city's Bureau of Civil Affairs proposed exchanges among districts within Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Taipei.
Meanwhile, the Bureau of Education brought up a planned project to exhibit a panda from mainland China at the Taipei Zoo. However, due to the complexities involved, no progress was made on the idea.

Shanghai City Deputy Mayor Feng Guoqin is expected to visit Taipei before the lunar New Year holidays, which falls in January 2001. A group of Hong Kong legislators is also scheduled to visit the island this December.
If everything goes well, Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will visit Shanghai next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL PRESIDENT TO VISIT ROC ON OCT. 27

TEXT.P: Dr. Craig R. Barett, president of Intel Co., will arrive in Taipei on Oct. 27 for a business trip to the Republic of China.

While in Taipei, Barett and local entrepreneurs will discuss today's e-commerce business strategies. The Intel head is expected to brief local technology leaders on the unlimited business opportunities, challenges and choices facing entrepreneurs now.

A spokesman for Intel (Taiwan) Co. said that discussions will center on how to speed up the development of the Internet and e-commerce, as well as how to break down business barriers by means of cooperation.

Establishing a basic foundation for e-commerce will offer clients a valuable service and help transform old-style business partnerships, with transactions and interchanges between distributors and clients being handled online, he said.

The Intel e-commerce forum will pool the experience of many economic forecasters, technology leaders, suppliers, systems analysts and internet operators so as to upgrade e-commerce competitiveness and information, he said.
The trip will also bring Barette to Beijing, Shanghai and Seoul, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD QUESTIONS GOV'T FOR MAKING DECISIONS BASED ON 'MERE IDEOLOGY'

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said Monday that the government's refusal to build a power plant when northern Taiwan lacks electricity and a reservoir when the south lacks water is blind worship of ideology without regard for reason.

He went on to say that the financial crisis facing Taiwan today as reflected in the stock market is merely the tip of the iceberg. Economics problems, political issues, and cross-strait relations are all being closely watched by the public because investors look three to five years ahead, he said.

Receiving representatives of an advisory industry organization, Lien added that people have much to complain about, with nobody certain of cross-strait stability after the new government's statement that unification with mainland China is not the only option.

Brushing aside criticism that opposition parties oppose the government simply because they are unwilling to accept their election defeat, Lien -- who was the KMT's presidential candidate in the March 18 election -- said that his party has experienced and talented members in its ranks, and therefore has the responsibility to point out its views on certain issues.

Democratic politics is about competition where good policies, ideologies, and ideas receive the people's recognition, he said. He added that when certain policies or ideologies don't work out, then it is time for the ruling party to be replaced by other parties.

Lien stressed that the KMT's fundamental position is to place Taiwan's stability, prosperity, and democracy as the first and foremost of its considerations. Under this principle, he said that Taipei and Beijing should co-exist under a peaceful and reciprocal manner.

Other than economic and cross-strait issues, Lien pointed out the importance of the stability of the constitutional system. He went on to say that the ruling party must respect the rules set down by the constitution and must especially respect the legislative majority party -- the KMT -- so that the nation's affairs can run smoothly.

He added that this is not a matter of being unable to accept election defeat, but rather conventional practice in a democracy. He also urged the new government to clearly establish its policies instead of constantly changing them, which he said has left the people at a loss as to what to do.

Lien went on to say that the amount of bad debts in the nation's financial system is so high that he does not dare to predict whether a local financial storm will erupt. He urged the government to be courageous and wise in pointing out its views instead of "fumbling about in a dark room."

The KMT is scheduled to hold a meeting of former economic officials Tuesday to discuss the financial issues now facing the nation and make recommendations to supplement the eight major economic policies declared by the government Saturday.

Also on Tuesday, the KMT legislative caucus is scheduled to discuss whether to push for a no-confidence motion against the minority administration and force a special parliamentary election to try to break the deadlock in the current political landscape.

However, Tseng Yung-chuan, director-general of the KMT's Department of Party-Government Coordination in the legislature, stressed that if the timing of the no-confidence vote is detrimental to the entire people and to political stability, he is certain the KMT will not follow through with it.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-ROC PRESIDENT ATTENDS `FORUM 2000' IN PRAGUE

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui chatted Sunday with Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel at a cocktail reception in honor of the participants in the ongoing fourth Forum 2000 conference.
Havel thanked Lee for the hospitality extended by the ROC government to his wife during a visit she made to Taiwan a few years ago when Lee was still in office.
The poet-turned-politician was also quoted as having told Lee that he himself will consider making a trip to Taiwan in the future.

On his way to Prague, Lee described Havel as a good friend, even though the two had never met. Lee further said he was very happy to have been invited to attend the Forum 2000 conference and to have the opportunity to meet with Havel in person.

Complimented by conference organizers for his contribution to Taiwan's democratization, Lee was among the 50-plus retired heads of state, religious leaders, influential politicians, writers and artists from around the world invited to attend the Oct. 15-18 forum.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Havel said globalization was one of major themes to be discussed in the conference, and added that he is still not sure whether globalization will have a positive or negative impact on the well-being of mankind.

"But one thing is certain -- that education will be even more important in the 21st century," Havel said, adding that education is not only aimed at increasing people's knowledge but also at the promotion of their well-being.

Forum 2000 is a think tank jointly founded by Havel and a Japanese foundation in 1997 to explore the values of culture and civilization to human development. The 2000 conference will focus on the values of education, culture and religion in what was described as the "year of globalization."

Lee and his wife were seated in the first row, together with former South African President Frederik de Klerk, a co-winner of the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize. Lee and de Klerk had met in both Taipei and the South African capital of Pretoria when they were still at the helms of their respective countries.

Lee, a devout Christian, was scheduled to deliver a keynote speech on globalization-related religious issues Tuesday, at a session chaired by the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader. Lee had extensive talks with the Dalai Lama when he made his first visit to Taiwan in 1997. It was not clear whether they will hold closed-door talks during their stay in Prague. The Dalai Lama was scheduled to arrive Monday.
Also attending the four-day meeting are former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres and former Polish Prime Minister Hanna Suchocka.

Lee will tour noted Czech cultural sites and tourist attractions after the forum ends. He and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei Oct. 22. Members of his entourage include former National Security Council Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih and several of his close aides.
Mainland China last month condemned Lee's trip to Prague, saying he should not be given a forum for activities aimed at separating Taiwan from the mainland.
A mainland Foreign Ministry spokesman accused Lee of having always engaged in activities aimed at Taiwan independence during his 12-year stint as ROC president.
The Czech Republic recognizes mainland China, but maintains friendly substantive ties with Taiwan.
Beijing lodged protests with London when Lee made his first overseas visit to Britain in June following his retirement on May 20.

The 78-year-old former ROC president is an outspoken critic of mainland China's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan and infuriated Beijing last year by declaring that Beijing-Taipei relations should be on "a special state-to-state" basis.

DOC.TEXT:

Collapse of investor confidence leads to stock market tumble in volatile trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 17, or the 19th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Charles II, King of England, sells Dunkirk to the French.
1849: Frederic Chopin, Polish-born French composer and virtuoso pianist of the romantic era, dies of tuberculosis in Paris at the age of 39. His music, written chiefly for the piano, is noted for its expressiveness.
1855: Englishman Henry Bessemer patents his process for making steel.
1912: The first Balkan War breaks out when Bulgaria, Serbia, and Greece declare war on Turkey.
1919: Zhao Ziyang, former Chinese Communist Party chief, is born. As prime minister in the 1980s, he pioneered bold economic reforms. He was swept from power in the political crisis sparked by the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations centered in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
1920: Hsieh Wen-ta, Taiwan's first aviator, flies his aircraft over Taichung in central Taiwan.
1945: The first batch of ROC government troops aboard some 40 U.S. Navy ships arrives at Keelung in Taiwan, which reverts back to Chinese rule after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1956: Calder Hall, Britain's first nuclear power station, is opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
1963: The Hong Kong government sets up the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
1964: Construction of a cross-harbor bridge in Penghu (Pescadores) is started.
1966: Lesotho and Botswana are admitted into the United Nations.
1967: Henry Puyi, formerly Hsuan Tung, the last Ching ruler, dies in Beijing at the age of 61.
1972: President Park Chung Hee declares martial law in South Korea.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center is dedicated at Shanhua in southern Taiwan.
1973: The ten Arab members of OPEC announce an enormous 70 percent hike in oil prices and a cutback in production in response to America's support for Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
1974: Adm. John Sidney McCain, former U.S. commander in the Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: The Asian Christian Federation opens its first conference on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei with 200 delegates from 15 Asian countries attending.
1977: Akira Nishiyama, former Japanese ambassador to South Korea, arrives in Taiwan to assume his duties as director of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei office.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for caring for the world's "unwanted and unloved."
1981: A group of more than 100 former officers of the U.S. Air Force's 14th squadron, better known as the Flying Tigers, arrives in Taipei to visit Chinese friends.
1989: An earthquake rocks northern California, killing more than 60 people.
1994: Israel and Jordan initial a historic peace treaty, ending their 46-year state of war.
1995: The Republic of China and Macau establish a five-year renewable air pact allowing Eva Airways, TransAsia Airways, and Air Macau to fly routes between Taiwan and Macau.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks security chief Alexander Lebed one day after Lebed is accused of building his own army in an attempt to seize power.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan calls on Cardinal Paul Shan to express gratitude for the 921 earthquake relief assistance provided by the Catholic community in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, without the inducement of rewards, is able to make the people good; and without a show of anger, to awe them into fear more than if he had used the most dreadful instruments of punishment."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 71.41 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 71.41 points to close at 5,702.36.
Market turnover amounted to NT$72.17 billion (US$2.26 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP PRESIDENTIAL AIDE TO CALL ON OPPOSITION PARTY SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun is scheduled to call on opposition Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng Thursday to pave the way for a possible meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and KMT Chairman Lien Chan.

After a long-proposed roundtable meeting with Lien and People First Party Chairman James Soong failed to materialize, Chen -- a Democratic Progressive Party stalwart -- switched tracks and is aiming to call on the two major opposition heads on a "one-to-one" basis to exchange views on national issues.
Yu and Lin came to an agreement Tuesday to meet in Lin's office to work out the feasibility of such a meeting between Chen and Lien.
However, Lin said that meeting with Yu does not necessarily imply that Lien is inclined to meet Chen.

Lin stressed that anything beneficial to the country and the people will be treated seriously by the KMT, but that the most important matter at the moment is to regain the entire public's confidence and not party politics. Therefore, he added that the ruling party should "bury itself in hard work" to try and re-establish that confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 71.41 points to close at 5,702.36.
The bourse opened at 5,512 and fluctuated between 5,742.68 and 5,512 during trading.

A total of 2.18 billion stocks worth NT$72.17 billion (US$2.26 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 3 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$94.68 billion (US$2.97 billion).

All the eight major categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 3.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 3.1 percent, foodstuff shares at 2.5 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 2.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares and textile issues, both at 1.5 percent, construction stocks at 1.1 percent, and electrical shares at 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 360 to 178, with 84 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taiwan stock index futures were higher Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization weighted index futures for October moved up 242 points to close at 5,728, with 3,094 contracts traded.

TAIEX Index futures for November gained 273 points to finish at 5,760, with 8,026 contract transactions, while December futures increased 280 points to close at 5,781, with 13 contracts changing hands.
March 2001 futures rose 73 points to finish at 5,723, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June 2001 futures.
Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Tuesday at 5,486 for October, 5,487 for November, 5,501 for December, 5,650 for next March and 5,601 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
October TE futures moved up 8.95 points to close at 281.1, with 1,170 contract transactions, while November TE futures gained 10.25 points to finish at 279.95, with 2,531 contract transactions.
December TE futures rose 18.55 points to close at 293.6, with 17 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures moved up 37 points to close at 740, with 503 contract transactions, while November TF futures increased 40.8 points to finish at 751.8, with 668 contracts changing hands.
December TF futures gained 37 points to close at 762.4, with eight contract transactions, while March 2001 TF futures surged 47 points to finish at 782, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June 2001 TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER URGES TAIPEI-BEIJING RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that the time for Taipei-Beijing reconciliation has come, adding that the government will evaluate and plan for direct trade, postal, and transport links with mainland China in stages.

Reporting at a legislative interpellation session, Chang said that when even the leaders of North and South Korea can step out of their ideological frames to break their long-standing impasse, Beijing and Taipei must do the same and replace criticisms and diatribes with rational dialogue.

He added that conflict must be replaced with negotiations and hostility with good will so that room for "broadband communication" between the two sides can be created, thereby establishing a new normalized, institutionalized, and transparent interactive framework.

As a gesture of good will, Chang said that Taipei will not have any predetermined stance going into negotiations with Beijing, which he said can take any form, take place under any occasion, and dwell on any subject as long as both put aside their disagreements and reach out to the future under the principles of acceptance, equality, and reciprocity.
Chang also pointed out that evaluations and planning have been completed on the "mini-three links" between mainland China's Fujian Province and Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands.

He went on to say that the initial stage will be based on the principle of "one port per area," with links to be established between set points and regular runs to occur at periodic intervals on fixed routes.

Meanwhile, National Police Administration Director-General Wang Ching-wang was in Kinmen Tuesday to look into local law enforcement needs. He pointed out that Kinmen's police force will be beefed up to help prepare for the mini-three links scheduled to commence in December.

The number of tourists from Taiwan to Kinmen is expected to increase with the implementation of the mini-three links. At the same time, up to 700 mainland Chinese citizens will be allowed to enter Kinmen per day and approximately 2,800 will be in Kinmen at any one time, Wang said. Because of this sudden influx, Wang noted that public security measures must be taken to thoroughly investigate all smuggling channels for illegal drugs, firearms, and fugitives.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT EXPRESSES VIEWS ON RELATIONS WITH CHINA (1)

TEXT.P: The following is an English translation of the text of an interview with Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian by Juergen Kremb and Andreas Lorenz of Der Spiegel, a leading German news weekly.

The text was provided by the U.S. Foreign Broadcast Information Service, which collects and translates articles on political, economic, technological and military topics published daily by news media around the world for the reference of U.S. government officials and contract workers. [FBIS Translated Text]
[Der Spiegel] Mr. President, are you Chinese or Taiwanese?

[Chen] I was born Taiwanese and a citizen of the Republic of China. At the same time, I am proud of my identity as a(n) (ethnic) Chinese. The people on both sides of the Straits of Taiwan are distinguished by a common culture, a common language, and a common history. We are an important part of the Chinese community.

[Der Spiegel] Even though there have been milder tones recently, Beijing still threatens to bring about reunification by force if you declare the island's independence. How great is the danger of war?

[Chen] I do not see any immediate danger. As long as the PRC does not take violent action against Taiwan, I will not declare independence. Nor will I change the name of our state from the Republic of China to the Republic of Taiwan. I will not schedule a referendum, which would change the current status, and I will not propagate the two-states theory. However, the will of 23 million Taiwanese on shaping their future must be respected on both sides of the Taiwan Straits.

[Der Spiegel] The leadership in Beijing is putting pressure of time on you: if Taiwan were to delay negotiations on reunification for too long, this would also be a reason for attack, they say. Do you still have any leeway at all?

[Chen] We know that we have to master a lot of difficulties. However, Taiwan's strength lies in its strategic location in the Pacific area. The constant threat of force by the Chinese leadership cannot rattle us. The latest elections proved this. Threatening gestures just take the mainland and Taiwan farther apart.
[Der Spiegel] Would the People's Liberation Army actually be able to conquer Taiwan?

[Chen] Currently, the greatest threat is posed by the more than 400 short-, intermediate-, and long-range missiles that have been stationed on the mainland. With its air force and its shore units, the PRC can, however, not engage in a successful invasion.
[Der Spiegel] But Beijing is aggressively rearming.

[Chen] We can still defend ourselves. If the Communists were to try to occupy Taiwan, we would launch counterattacks. We would mobilize the entire population. Studies by the U.S. Pentagon assume, however, that the strategic balance in the Straits of Taiwan might change after 2005.
[Der Spiegel] Do you expect help from other countries?

[Chen] Taiwan's security is inseparably linked with the stability of the entire region. It is in the interests of all Pacific states, in particular, however, of Japan and the United States, to guarantee our security.
[Der Spiegel] Washington seems to be rather unwilling at the moment to equip your military with new warships and antimissile systems.

[Chen] Victory or defeat in a conflict depends on the will to fight, on the kind of war, the quality of weapons and soldiers, and, above all, on the solidarity of the people. With regard to the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, the United States committed itself to equipping us with the necessary weapons. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT EXPRESSES VIEWS ON RELATIONS WITH CHINA (2)

TEXT.P: [Der Spiegel] This law can be interpreted differently.

[Chen] The point is not whether we get this weapons system or that one; the point is Washington's security guarantee in the Asian area. The fact that the Americans stand by this was proved most recently in 1996, when the Communist leaders held maneuvers and the United States sent aircraft carriers to the Taiwan Strait.
[Der Spiegel] Do you really believe that the United States would risk a war with Beijing to guarantee Taiwan's future. China is an emerging economic power, with whom nobody likes to butt heads.
[Chen] It is not just Taiwan that is involved in this matter, but also the strategic interests of the United States. China's missiles are also aimed at the United States.

[Der Spiegel] So far, Beijing has not reacted to your offer to meet President Jiang Zemin. The government there insists that you recognize the "One-China Principle," according to which Taiwan is only a Chinese province. You reject this. Where do you see possibilities for a compromise?

[Chen] So far, we have demonstrated great flexibility. We hope that the Chinese authorities will give up their preconditions and initiate a new era of relations together with us. I am willing to work out with the other side a definition of the expression "One China." However, all talks must preserve the principles of equality and democracy.
[Der Spiegel] Your predecessor Li Teng-hui characterized the relationship with the mainland as a "special state-to-state relationship," thus outraging the Communist Chinese. Do you stick to that?
[Chen] I am Chen Shui-bian and not Li Teng-hui. We use new tones.
[Der Spiegel] Parts of your Democratic Progress Party continue to strive for Taiwan's independence. How do you want to satisfy them?

[Chen] The Constitution obligates me to preserve our national security, sovereignty, and dignity. I stress that national interests go before party interests. I did not become president to give Taiwan for free to mainland China. The 23 million people of Taiwan would not permit this, either.
[Der Spiegel] Recently, you spoke of "two, three, and even innumerable possibilities" for future relations with the mainland. What were you thinking of specifically?
[Chen] At the moment no side is subordinate to the other. We have formed a working group that will soon submit specific proposals on the issue of reunification.

[Der Spiegel] So far, your government has even banned direct trade, transport, and postal links with the mainland. All goods must be shipped via Hong Kong, Macao, or other countries. When will this change?

[Chen] We are willing to discuss this with Beijing. We want to normalize economic relations with the mainland on the basis of reciprocity and respect of market principles. We will soon establish direct trade relations between the mainland and the Taiwanese islands of Quemoy and Matsu. However, our security must be ensured. At the moment, the problem is not us but the Chinese leadership, who do not want to talk with us. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT EXPRESSES VIEWS ON RELATIONS WITH CHINA (3)

TEXT.P: [Der Spiegel] Taiwan will soon join the WTO -- but this presupposes free trade among the members. This means, you have to take action.

[Chen] We hope that, after joining the WTO, the leadership in Beijing will become more open to the world, more liberal, and that democratization will make progress. This will promote the expansion of direct trade relations. However, WTO membership does not automatically mean for us that we must permit direct contacts.

[Der Spiegel] You have struggled for a democratic Taiwan for a long time and you have also made personal sacrifices. However, most countries, including Germany, do not recognize your country. Does this hurt you?

[Chen] No. It is more important to check our own position than to accuse other countries of being unfair. Perhaps, however, in the future we will have to struggle with greater toughness for recognition by the international community.
[Der Spiegel] How can you free yourself from the isolation?

[Chen] We want to expand our international activities. Among other things, we will work more for human rights at the international level, participate more intensively in nongovernmental organizations, and grant development and economic aid to Third World countries more frequently.
[Der Spiegel] In Parliament you do not have a majority, and the business leaders do not seem to trust you. Since you assumed office in May, stock exchange prices have plummeted by more than 30 %.
[Chen] NASDAQ, the US technology index, has also gone down. I am confident about Taiwan's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTRIES SPLIT OVER ROLE OF PARALYMPIC GAMES

TEXT.P: A split into two camps has occurred among the nations participating in the Paralympics over the role of the international sporting event, according to the Australian Paralympic Committee.

The United States, Australia, Britain, and a handful of other countries approach the Paralympics as an elite sporting event with a focus on winning medals, while the rest of the countries with participating athletes view it as a kind of rehabilitation project for disabled individuals, said APC chief executive Brendan Flynn.
The different attitudes to the sporting event may create problems for the future of the Paralympic Games if some countries are left behind on the playing field, he said.
Flynn noted that Australia would make moves towards greater integration of disabled and able-bodied sports to bring all sports under a stronger and more centralized administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REAFFIRMS STANCE ON PEACEFUL SOLUTION TO TAIWAN ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States, in an initial response to a mainland Chinese "white paper" on defense, said Monday it rejects the use of force or the threat of the use of force to resolve the Taiwan Strait issue.

"As we have told the (mainland) Chinese at senior levels, comments that focus on possible use of force (against Taiwan) are counterproductive to the peaceful resolution of differences," said a U.S. State Department official, who asked not to be named.
The mainland China's defense white paper, released Monday, offers a gloomy assessment of ties with Taiwan and justifies a stronger military by pointing in part to growing U.S. might.
The Beijing document also repeated a threat to use "drastic force" to prevent Taiwan breaking away, or if the island stalled indefinitely on reunification talks.

The U.S. State Department official, repeating longstanding U.S. positions on Taiwan, said the United States would continue its "one China" policy and urge both sides to refrain from actions or statements that increase tension or complicate dialogue.

"We will continue to adhere to our one-China policy. We urge the PRC as well as Taiwan to refrain from actions or statements that increase tensions or make dialogue more difficult to achieve. We urge them to take steps that foster dialogue, reduce tensions and promote mutual understanding," the spokesman said.

He added: "We welcome greater transparency with respect to China's military development, doctrine, spending and policies and will be reviewing the document in detail to see how this new edition of the white paper on defense contributes to that goal."
Meanwhile, the Department of Defense said its initial review shows nothing that jumped out as a major concern.
"We have started to review the white paper. Our initial review does not show anything that's jumped out as a major concern," said a Pentagon spokesman.
The United States does not recognize Taiwan diplomatically, but it does provide the island with the weapons it needs to defend itself against mainland Chinese attempt at reunification by force.

Ideally Washington would like to maintain the status quo and avoid conflict until reform inside mainland China makes reunification more attractive to the Taiwanese or until mainland China decides to tolerate an independent Taiwan.
