The local currency opened at NT$32.001 and was traded between NT$32.001 and NT$32.275.
The Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$747.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA SIGNS CHINESE ONLINE NEWS AGREEMENT WITH AFP

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Central News Agency entered an agreement with France's Agence France-Press Tuesday at a ceremony that ROC Vice President Annette Lu said signified Taiwan's future leadership role in global Chinese news networks.

Under the agreement, CNA will produce the Chinese version of the AFP Journal, a news website updated 24 hours a day. The Chinese content of AFP Journal will include top stories on international news, business, sports, high technology, and health, with pictures accompanying each story.
CNA President Bill Wang and Pierre Lesourd, president of AFP Asia-Pacific, inked the agreement on behalf of their respective agencies.
In her keynote address, Lu said that the 21st century is a century of information technology and that network news media has shortened the distance between people and between nations.

She went on to say that the distinguishing characteristic of the 20th century has been that major powers have always worried others for their demonstration of "hard national power" -- economic and military might.

In the 21st century, however, people will begin to welcome human rights, democracy, human kindness, peace, and high technology -- which constitutes the "soft national power" that Taiwan can share with the world.
Lu said that she was happy to see the two agencies go one step further in strengthening their cooperation.
In addition to Chinese-language news, AFP Journal already carries news in French, English, and German.
AFP is one of the three largest news agencies in the world, while CNA is the largest and longest-running news agency in the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFIDENCE CRISIS IS CAUSE OF CURRENT FINANCIAL PROBLEMS: KMT

TEXT.P: Most economic and financial experts attending a seminar Tuesday agreed that Taiwan's current financial and economic problems have been caused by a crisis of confidence.
Kuomintang Vice Chairman Vincent Siew presided over the seminar on current financial and economic problems sponsored by the National Policy Foundation, a KMT think tank.

Participants also included former Vice Premiers Liu Chao-shiuan and Hsu Li-teh, former Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang, and former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development P. K. Chiang.

Hwang Jenn-tai, convenor of the foundation's Technology and Economic Division and former chairman of the National Science Council, said that the solution to current economic problems lies in reviving public confidence.

Hwang noted that though Taiwan's economic fundamentals remain sound, the people of Taiwan have lost their confidence in the nation's economic development. He added that this lack of confidence has been reflected in the plunge in the Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index, which has fallen over 30 percent since the inauguration of the new administration.

He said that the economy currently faces four problems -- government indecision on infrastructure construction, stalled cross-strait relations, the continued worsening of the financial environment, and rising unemployment.

He stressed that the new administration's wavering attitude toward the construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant and a reservoir in southern Taiwan has led the public to harbor misgivings about the future course of the nation.

Hsu said that stalled cross-strait relations and the fourth nuclear power plant are the biggest factors affecting public confidence, adding that if the government could accept the principle of national unification over the long term, both sides could start talks and relations with mainland China would improve.

On the plan to suspend the construction of the fourth nuclear plant, he said that the new administration wants to scrap the plant only because of the Democratic Progressive Party's anti-nuclear platform.

Meanwhile, Liu urged the government to base its energy policy on the conclusions reached in a national energy conference in 1998 and continue to construct the plant, which was already 30 percent complete before the suspension of its construction.
Liu also said that mainland China and Taiwan should return to the agreement reached in 1992 -- that there is "one China," but both sides can have different interpretations of what that means.

The seminar was held in the wake of a special economic and financial conference held over the weekend by the government, during which a package of economic measures were adopted to stimulate the slumping economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PROUD OF IDENTITY AS ETHNIC CHINESE

TEXT.P: Presidential Office officials said Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian is proud of his identity as an ethnic Chinese, not a Chinese.

The Presidential Office made the clarification after foreign wire service reports said Chen had said in an interview with the German news weekly Der Spiegel that he is proud of his identity as a Chinese.

The Presidential Office said the reports were not correct. "What the president has said is that he takes pride in his identity as an ethnic Chinese (Huajen in Mandarin), not a Chinese (Chungkuojen)," a Presidential Office official explained.

Commenting on reports that Chen had told Der Spiegel that the President's Advisory Group on Cross-Strait Relations will provide him with clear suggestions concerning the Taiwan-mainland China reunification issue in the near future, the official denied that Chen had made any such remarks.

"What President Chen said was he hopes the advisory group, headed by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, can help forge a national consensus on the development of cross-strait relations," the official said.

The official added that the group has not yet reached a consensus on cross-strait issues, and that the conclusions presented by the group will be important reference materials in formulating Taiwan's future policy toward cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BEHIND ON QUANTITY OF SEX, CONTRACEPTIVE USE

TEXT.P: Taiwanese make love 78 times a year on average -- or once every 4.7 days -- but alarmingly, 14 percent do not use contraceptives, according to the results of an international survey released Tuesday.

The 2000 Durex Global Sex Survey, conducted on men and women between the ages of 16 and 55 in 27 countries, revealed that Taiwanese get their first taste of the forbidden fruit at an average of 21.4 years of age. That makes them relatively late bloomers compared to the global average of 18.1 and Hong Kong's 19, but puts them ahead of mainland China's average of 21.9 years of age.

According to the survey, respondents around the world make love 96 times per year on average, with U.S. citizens taking the lead at 132 times per year, or once every 2.8 days. Japanese lag behind other Asians, having sex just 37 times a year, once every 9.9 days. The reportedly romantic French came in third, at 121 times a year.

But Taiwanese ranked lowest among surveyed Asian countries in terms of contraceptive use, with 14 percent of Taiwan respondents not using any form of contraceptive at all, compared to mainland China's 7 percent and Hong Kong's 3 percent.

Some 52 percent of Taiwan respondents said that they have had only one sexual partner in their lifetime. But the other 48 percent are somewhat less faithful, as the average number of sexual partners of all Taiwan respondents is 4.3, according to the results. This figure is still less than the global average of 8.2.
Exactly one third of young Taiwanese lovers said that they not only thought their first experience between the sheets wasn't anything to shout about, but were actually disappointed.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMNESTY CHIDES CHINA FOR HUMAN RIGHTS ABUSE
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Y.C. Jiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Korean chapter of Amnesty International issued a statement Tuesday urging the Beijing authorities to "actively improve" human rights protection for the 1.2 billion people in mainland China.

Issued on the day upon the arrival in Seoul by Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji for a formal visit, the statement by the Korean chapter of the international human rights organization said that thousands of Chinese people have been tortured or detained without fair trials for participating in peaceful religious gatherings.
In 1999 alone, thousands of people were sentenced to death by mainland Chinese judiciary system, with some 1,800 being executed, the Korean Amnesty group noted.
In addition, dissident activists in Tibet and Xinjiang have also been targets of Beijing's suppression, it added.

Asserting that human rights is by no means an internal issue of any single nation, the group stated that protection for democracy and human rights in mainland China is an extension of peace and human rights in Asia as well as the whole world.
The group urged the Chinese authorities to immediately release thousands of political prisoners jailed for peacefully supporting Tibetan independence or seeking religious and political freedom.

It also urged the Korean government to single out the fact of mainland China's human rights abuses during the third Asia-Europe Meeting slated for Oct. 20-21 in Seoul, and to see to it that an entrance permit be granted to Chinese dissident leader Wang Dan.

The Amnesty International Korean Chapter planned to invite Wang Dan to come to Seoul for a human rights meeting between Oct. 12-15, but the Korean authorities turned down the group's request and refused to give Wang an entry permit.
Undaunted, the group plans to make another request of the Korean government to allow Wang to visit South Korea in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPE SENDS CONGRATULATIONS ON ROC NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: Pope John Paul II Monday sent a congratulatory message to President Chen Shui-bian on the occasion of the Republic of China's national day.
The pope said in the message that he and all mighty God have blessed the people and president of the Republic of China, and that they may enjoy everlasting peace, prosperity, and affluence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 5TH IN WORLD IN PURCHASES OF VISA TRAVELER'S CHECKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan consumers bought a total of US$301.5 million worth of Visa traveler's checks between the third quarter of last year and the second quarter of this year, making the island fifth in the world in terms of purchases of Visa traveler's checks, Visa International announced Tuesday.

The top five countries for sales of Visa traveler's checks during the period were the United States, at US$1 billion; Japan, at US$821.79 million; the United Kingdom, at US$730.93 million; South Korea, at US$337.59 million; and Taiwan, at US$301.50 million, the company's statistics show.

Worldwide sales of Visa traveler's checks reached a total of US$5.2 billion during the same period, which the company touted as an indication that its traveler's checks have become more and more popular among global consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLAR RECOGNIZES ROC PRESIDENT'S PERFORMANCE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Jerome Cohen, a noted U.S. China hand, said Monday he was impressed by Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's views and efforts concerning improvement of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Cohen made the remarks after Chen addressed about 100 members of the Council on Foreign Relations (CFR), a noted New York-based think tank, via teleconference on the delicate and complicated cross-strait issues.
It was the first time that President Chen has delivered a speech to the council on his views and stances on the development of cross-strait relations.
Cohen said he shares Chen's views that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should return to the "1992 spirit" to facilitate resumption of cross-strait dialogue.
"It is a good proposal. Back in 1992, both sides shelved their disputes and sat down to talks. What Taiwan and mainland China lack at the moment are dialogue and communication channels," Cohen noted.
After listening to Chen's speech, Cohen said, many CFR members have come to believe that Chen has the capability to properly handle thorny cross-strait issues and pursue permanent cross-strait peace.

Cohen, who organized the teleconference with Chen, said Taiwan and mainland China should increase contacts and cooperation. He suggested that Taiwan further ease restrictions on visits to mainland China by ROC officials. For instance, Cohen said, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who concurrently serves as chairman of the ROC's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou should be allowed to visit the mainland.
On the other hand, Cohen urged mainland China to cease any hostile moves toward Taiwan. "The more the cross-strait exchanges, the likelier Taiwan is attracted to unify with the mainland," he said.

Noting that the vast mainland market is very important to Taiwan, Cohen said if mainland China intends to unify Taiwan, it should place more emphasis on practical issues. Cohen said he hopes the next generation of mainland leaders will become even more pragmatic in dealing with cross-strait affairs.
As mainland China has recently softened its tone on Taiwan-related affairs, Cohen said he is optimistic about the prospects for cross-strait ties.
Cohen further said that in short term, mainland China is not expected to attack Taiwan at the risk of paralyzing its own economic development.

As for the possible impact of the outcome of the upcoming U.S. presidential election, Cohen said if Republican candidate George W. Bush wins the election, Taiwan may have greater access to more U.S.-made defensive weapons. Except for this, Cohen said, the electoral result is not expected to have significant impact on other aspects of the U.S. policy toward Taiwan.

For fears of offending mainland China, the U.S. State Department bans visits by the ROC president and vice president. When he visited Taiwan in May, Cohen suggested that Chen speak on his policy toward mainland China through teleconference to help CFR members better understand his cross-strait stance. Chen accepted his proposal. Cohen visited Taipei again in mid-September to work out details about the teleconference. In view of enthusiastic response from CFR members, Cohen said he plans to organize another teleconference for Chen next year.

In his Monday speech, Chen renewed his call on mainland China to resume cross-strait dialogue based on the "1992 spirit" in order to break the current stalemate and create a "win-win" situation for both sides.

Chen also stressed that Taiwan's political democratization can serve as beacon for mainland people. "I believe that so long as the two sides shelve their disputes and resume dialogue and exchanges, the much-anticipated opening of direct cross-strait trade, mail and transportation links, commonly known as 'three links,' will be able to become a reality soon," he added.

Stressing that Taiwan is always ready to open talks with the mainland, Chen said the ball is in Beijing's court to break the current cross-strait impasse. "Beijing should not impose any precondition for resuming talks," he added.
As for Taiwan's future, Chen said any solution to cross-strait issues must respect the choice of the 23 million Taiwan people out of their free will.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-SWAZILAND ECONOMIC CONFERENCE KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: An economic cooperation conference between the Republic of China and Swaziland opened Tuesday in Taipei with the aim of further reinforcing bilateral economic ties.

The conference was presided over by ROC Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi and his Swazi counterpart, Majozi Sithole, with an agenda that included measures on how to assist Swaziland map out long-term plans for economic and tourist development, promotion of bilateral economic and trade relations and soliciting the African nation's support for Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization.

Lin said at the opening ceremony that the ROC and Swaziland have implemented various cooperation programs that the two countries came up with during a previous economic cooperation conference, such as an investment guarantee agreement and an accord to prevent double taxation.

He also cited some examples to illustrate the increasing economic and trade exchanges between the two countries, pointing out that Taiwan's Nien Hsing Textile Co. plans to invest US$85 million to establish two clothing factories and one textile plant in Swaziland that could provide some 4,500 jobs, while an affiliate of Taiwan's Tuntex Group has initiated the third stage of an expansion program in Swaziland.

Bilateral trade between the ROC and Swaziland totaled US$2.82 million in 1999, representing 7.3 percent growth over the previous year. Economics officials said with Swaziland's improved investment environment, the country can serve as a base for Taiwan entrepreneurs wishing to enter "European and southern African markets."

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER PROMOTES WORLD'S 1ST WIRELESS SUPER-THIN NOTEBOOK PC

TEXT.P: Acer Inc., Taiwan's largest computer manufacturer, unveiled Tuesday its second-generation super-thin notebook PC, which the company boasts to be a definite boost to the so-called "e-life."

Acer TravelMate 350, publicized simultaneously around the world, is the world's first super-thin notebook PC to use built-in SmartCard, wireless regional Internet transmission technique and cutting-edge Bluetooth telecommunication technology, according to a company spokesman.

The latest innovation, weighing only 1.8 kg with a thickness of 2.1 cm, comes with a 13.3-inch liquid crystal display and a lightweight aluminum-magnesium alloy shell. Its battery, which can be used continuously for 2.5 hours, is also a technology breakthrough as it can be recharged to 80 percent of its power in only an hour, said Acer Inc. President Lin Hsien-ming.
Acer TravelMate 350 allows users to enjoy long-distance wireless communication, fully satisfying the "immense need" among e-age users to surf the web and communicate via the Internet, said Lin.
It also allows users to connect with cellular phones, palm digital aids and other consumer electronic gears, he added.
Lin estimated that single-machine sales of Acer TravelMate 350 could easily reach 600,000 annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER WILL STICK TO CORE BUSINESS WHILE SEEKING TRANSFORMATION (I)

TEXT.P: Despite widespread suspicion about the outlook for the global PC industry, Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih has reaffirmed that his group will continue sticking to its core business of computer manufacturing while seeking to expand into other fields.

Although Acer Computer -- Acer Group's mother company and Taiwan's largest computer firm -- has diversified into other fields more quickly than other computer companies, Shih stressed that overall transformation takes time and made it clear that Acer Computer will not cease its computer production operations, despite the fact that global demand for personal computers (PCs) is falling.
Shih made the remarks in a recent interview with CNA, the full text of which follows:
Q: What do you think of the future of the local computer industry? And how will Acer Computer tackle the painful phase of its transformation?

A: It is a fact that the global demand for PCs is declining and it is also true that all electronics manufacturers will have to undergo transformation as a result of the changing times. I know perfectly well that outside hopes are high that Acer will hasten its transformation, but that takes time.

And I don't think that Acer is experiencing a painful transition, because its transformation project already started two or three years ago. The group's current eight affiliated companies, which are all listed in the local stock market, are clear proof of the transformation's fruitful result.

The transformation which Acer Group is undergoing at the present stage is aimed at Acer Computer -- which is determined to maintain its core business of computer manufacture for foreign brands while aggressively seeking to create a new lease of life for the concern.

Judging from the performances of Acer Computer's eight affiliated firms, I can assure you that Acer Computer has not had a painful transition and that the transformation project has been carried out as scheduled. All this should be viewed as Acer Computer's long-term performance, and as its largest shareholder, I am not at all worried about the firm's EPS (earnings per share) for the years to come.
Q: However, institutional investors seem to hold a different view of Acer Computer's share performances, which have posted continued drops for a while. What is your opinion in this regard?
A: It is I who will suffer the heaviest loss if Acer Computer's share prices continue to fall, but transformation takes time and I hope that time will eventually prove that our direction is correct.
Q: In addition to the ongoing transformation strategy, what measures will Acer Computer take to improve its core manufacturing business and revenues?

A: In contrast to what is widely assumed, producing computers for Acer's own brands has been more profitable than manufacturing for foreign companies. But Acer will not abandon its computer manufacture business and will try to increase the percentage of such operations out of consideration of reducing business risk based on a global management revenue model. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER SEEKING TRANSFORMATION (II)

TEXT.P: In the future, Acer Computer will maintain the proportion of its manufacturing business and operations of own brand names at a rate between 70 percent and 30 percent, or 50 percent and 50 percent. The ideal percentage is 65 percent and 35 percent. Acer Computer will not allow the manufacturing unit to exceed 70 percent of its overall business, while the unit of own brand names will not surpass 50 percent of the total.
In essence, Acer will shift the strategy to focus production on its competitive lines while slowing down its pace in less competitive products.

Q: In light of the arrival of the "knowledge-based new economic era," will Acer Group's "Flying Dragon Project," which aims to chalk up a profit of NT$10 billion for the group by 2005, be the key element of the group's next stage of transformation?

A: The "Flying Dragon Project" is only a segment of the entire group's transformation campaign. In addition to forming a software sub-group, Acer Group will also set up a telecommunications sub-group to pave the way for it to edge into the vast overseas markets.

I originally thought that we would have to wait until 2010 for the "Flying Dragon Project" to reach the profit target of NT$10 billion, but internal assessments show that the goal can be achieved in 2005.

Although suspicion is running high about investing in Taiwan's software and Internet sectors after dot-com companies have shut down one after another in the United States over the past year, I do believe that someone has to embrace the task.

The scale of the "Flying Dragon Project" is relatively small compared to that of Acer Group's other investment projects, but Acer Computer is planning to cooperate in the project by pouring in the group's resources.
Q: What are Acer Group's competitive edges?

A: An excellent talent pool, a comprehensive distribution network and sound financial system are Acer Group's most competitive edges. Management of the group is therefore more difficult due to its large and complex structure.

To achieve the group's transformation goal, the vital issue is to implement a persistent internal restructuring in order to tackle dramatic changes from the outside world by exercising its competitiveness to the fullest extent.

Acer Group has also made several breakthroughs during its transformation process. For instance, it has sold out Acer Semiconductor Manufacturing Inc. to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and has changed the name of Acer Peripherals Corp. to Acer Communications and Multimedia Inc., marking a noticeable departure from traditional Chinese business philosophy, which views splits as unusual.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA TO VISIT ROC NEXT MONTH FOR RELIGIOUS PURPOSES
DOC.DATELINE: Prague, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, confirmed here Tuesday that he will visit the Republic of China on Taiwan in November for purely religious purposes.

This was the first time that the Dalai Lama personally confirmed his upcoming Taiwan travel plan. Previous press reports said the Dalai Lama is scheduled to visit Taiwan again in late November. The Tibetan spiritual leader made his first trip to Taiwan in 1997.
The Dalai Lama, winner of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize, arrived in Prague Monday to attend the fourth Forum 2000 conference, which opened Sunday.
He chaired Tuesday's session on the religious role in this era of globalization. Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui delivered a 10-minute speech on religious themes at the session.

During a coffee break, the Dalai Lama said he looks forward to visiting Taiwan in November, but he stressed that his visit is mainly aimed at understanding the development of Tibetan Buddhism in Taiwan.
The Dalai Lama said his Taiwan visit does not carry any political purposes. He admitted that there really exists pressure from mainland China against his Taiwan travel plan.
Asked whether he will meet with incumbent ROC President Chen Shui-bian during his Taipei visit, the Dalai Lama said he will meet with anyone whom he wants to meet during his stay in Taiwan.
The Dalai Lama recalled that during his 1997 Taiwan visit, he had extensive talks with then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
Before the morning session began, Lee and the Dalai Lama exchanged greetings in an amicable atmosphere. Lee said he welcomes the Dalai Lama's upcoming Taiwan visit.
Lee further said the Dalai Lama is his good spiritual friend. "We are not political friends," Lee added smilingly.

Lee's remarks were seen as a gesture to soften the sensitivity of his meeting with the Dalai Lama as mainland China has recalcitrantly opposed contacts between Taiwan and Tibet for fears of their possible collaboration to promote independence.
Lee and the Dalai Lama reportedly held closed-door talks Tuesday noon, but neither of them would confirm the report.
During Monday's session, which focused on the roles of education and science in globalization, Lee touted the successful Taiwan experience in economic development.

In his view, Lee said, the wealth gap between rich and poor countries resulting from globalization cannot be settled easily. Nevertheless, he said, the "Taiwan experience" is worth of reference and emulation by developing countries.
Lee, an agricultural economist-turned-politician, said Taiwan is more than willing to share its developmental experience with other countries.

Lee, an outspoken critic of Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan and an active promoter of Taiwan's distinctive identity, infuriated Beijing last year when he said Taiwan-mainland China relations should be on a "special state-to-state basis."
This was Lee's second overseas trip since he ended his 12-year stint as the ROC president on May 20. Beijing lodged protests with London when Lee visited Britain in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIPEI TAXI FARES EXPECTED TO BE IMPLEMENTED NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government formally approved Tuesday a hike in taxi fares, allowing taxi drivers in Taiwan's largest city to charge an average increase of 12.5 percent.

Under the new taxi fare plan, which is expected to take effect at the end of November, the flagfall will be formally increased to NT$70, with the flagfall travel distance shortened from the current 1.65 km to 1.5 km.

The plan, devised by the City Government Committee Supervising Rates of Public Utilities and Transportation, will also see the distance traveled for each additional NT$5 shortened to 300 meters from the current 350 meters, according to a Taipei City Hall spokesman.
Charges for nighttime taxis and daytime waiting will also be increased to NT$5 for each two minutes from the current NT$5 for each three minutes, according to the new plan.
On average, each taxi ride will be NT$15 more expensive than before.
Taipei County and the adjacent Keelung City will also follow suit and implement the same plan.
It will take about six months for cabbies in Taipei City, Taipei County and Keeling City, totaling about 70,000, to have new meters inspected and installed, said Taipei City government officials.
Until all the new meters have been installed, a contingent price list authorized by the local governments will be used, the officials noted.

According to a survey conducted by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications last month, Taiwan taxi drivers made a gross average of NT$42,000 (US$1,350) per month in 1999, for a net income of around NT$28,000 after expenses.
The net income was a decline of 12.3 percent compared with the results of a similar survey conducted in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-ROC PRESIDENT SPEAKS ON PEACEFUL TRANSITION OF POWER IN PRAGUE
DOC.DATELINE: Prague, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said here Tuesday that Taiwan is one of the 30-plus countries which have managed to successfully transformed from authoritarian rule to a democracy over the past 25 years.
Lee made the remarks in a speech delivered in English at a session of the fourth Forum 2000 conference, which opened in Prague Sunday.

Over the past quarter of century, Lee said, more than 30 countries in Europe, Asia and Latin America have evolved from authoritarian rule to democracies. "We are pleased to see Taiwan join the ranks," he added.

The agricultural economist-turned-politician said regular elections, freedom of speech, robust opposition parties and peaceful transition of power between different political parties are common norms of democratic countries. These features have also become mainstream values in today's world, Lee explained.

Noting that globalization is an irresistible trend, Lee said the influence of the Global Village on each country will grow increasingly in tandem with progress in information technology, free trade as well as international exchanges and interdependence.

Against this background, Lee said he is convinced that religion and culture will be problems that human beings have to face everyday. Lee, a devout Christian, said all people should face different religions and cultures with tolerance and broad-mindedness so that special features of various cultures and religions can continue to grow and complement each other.

Lee further said the greatest appeal of religion is to arouse goodness in human nature. In this rapidly changing information society, Lee said, all people should work together to let this common appeal become an effective disciplinary force and lead the world toward an even more harmonious and beautiful horizon.
Lee said he hopes religious freedom can expand to every corner of the world as early as possible. He also wished every resident of the Global Village can enjoy peace of mind and world peace.

Tuesday's session, which focuses on the impact of globalization on religions, was chaired by the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, who is scheduled to make his second visit to Taiwan in November.
Lee and the Dalai Lama are among the 50-plus retired heads of state, religious leaders, influential politicians, writers and artists from around the world invited to attend the Oct. 15-18 forum.

Forum 2000 is a think tank jointly founded by Czech President Vaclav Havel and a Japanese foundation in 1997 to explore the values of culture and civilization to human development. The 2000 conference focuses on the values of education, culture and religion in what was described as the "year of globalization."

Lee also delivered a speech at Monday's session, which focused discussion on the roles of education and science in globalization. Lee touted the successful Taiwan experience in economic development during the session.

In his view, Lee said, the wealth gap between rich and poor countries resulting from globalization cannot be settled easily. Nevertheless, he said, the "Taiwan experience" is worth of reference and emulation by developing countries.
Lee further said Taiwan is more than willing to share its developmental experience with other countries.
Also attending the four-day meeting are former South African President F.W. de Klerk, Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres and former Polish Prime Minister Hanna Suchocka.

Lee will tour noted Czech cultural sites and tourist attractions after the forum ends. He and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei Oct. 22. Members of his entourage include former National Security Council Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih and several of his close aides.
Mainland China last month condemned Lee's trip to Prague, saying he should not be given a forum for activities aimed at separating Taiwan from the mainland.
A mainland Foreign Ministry spokesman accused Lee of having always engaged in activities aimed at Taiwan independence during his 12-year stint as ROC president.
The Czech Republic recognizes mainland China, but maintains friendly substantive ties with Taiwan.
Beijing lodged protests with London when Lee made his first overseas visit to Britain in June following his retirement on May 20.

The 78-year-old former ROC president is an outspoken critic of mainland China's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan and infuriated Beijing last year by declaring that Beijing-Taipei relations should be on "a special state-to-state" basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABAC TO FILE SUGGESTIONS TO APEC'S SUMMIT MEETING

TEXT.P: An advisory committee of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum will file suggestions at the APEC summit meeting scheduled to be held in Brunei on Nov. 15, according to a Tuesday press release from the committee.
The APEC Advisory Committee (ABAC) consists of 63 business representatives of APEC member economies, with three representatives from each economy.

The three Republic of China representatives are Jeffrey Koo, board chairman of Chinatrust Commercial Bank; Chang An-ping, general manager of Chia Hsin Cement Corp.; and Kao Chih-shang, vice board chairman of I-Mei Foods Co., Ltd.

The subject of this year's ABAC suggestions to the APEC summit will be "facing globalization in APEC way," according to the press release from the ROC committee members. ABAC representatives will file their suggestions on aspects such as finance, the streamlining of commerce, sci-tech, and action guidelines.

Kao said ABAC is pushing for the implementation of the "APEC Business Travel Card (ABTC)" program, adding that the ROC will join the program in November, becoming the 11th member of the program. This, he said, is part of the streamlining of commerce.

Kao said that member economies who join the ABTC program must set up a special "APEC Line" at airport immigration halls, allowing businessmen who hold an ABTC to enjoy visa-free travel and speedy customs processing while entering and departing member economies.
The ABTC program was initiated by Australia and six member economies have joined the program -- the Philippines, South Korea, Hong Kong, Chile, New Zealand and Australia.
Thailand, Peru and Brunei are also expected to join the program this year. So far, 3,000 people are ABTC holders.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, PFP CHAIRMAN TO MEET

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said in Kaohsiung Tuesday that he is pleased to have been invited to meet President Chen Shui-bian later this week.

Soong told the press that he would like to meet with Chen to discuss cross-Taiwan Strait ties, finance and economics. However, he added that he would not respond to Chen until the following day, after he had held a consultation with PFP cadres.

He also expressed regret that Chen's intention to hold a roundtable meeting between the leaders of Taiwan's political parties has never been realized because of the drastic changes in the domestic political situation.
He said he would like to make some recommendations to Chen if they would benefit the whole people of Taiwan.

Soong also expressed his hope that the current minority government will offer its services to all the people of Taiwan rather than serving only minority people and ideological groups. He said the behavior of the Chen administration has made the majority of the people in Taiwan aware of the instability of the nation's future and will eventually bring the danger of war to the people of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD `WILL NOT QUIT' CROSS-STRAIT ADVISORY GROUP

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh denied Tuesday a newspaper report which claimed that he was considering quitting as head of the president's advisory group on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
The China Times Express had reported that Lee was displeased with President Chen Shui-bian because Chen did not respect him.
Lee was reported to have complained privately that "although former President Lee Teng-hui was detestable, he respected me for two years, while Chen respected me for less than two days."

The paper noted that despite Lee's opposition, Chen insisted on establishing a consultative group under the Presidential Office, prompting Lee to consider resigning as head of the president's advisory group.

"I have never considered quitting as convenor of the president's advisory group on cross-strait relations," Lee said, adding that he will do his utmost to promote peace and constructive development across the Taiwan Strait.
Lee stressed that he has been maintaining good interaction with the president, and will continue to provide various suggestions to him.
He also said that he had never criticized either former President Lee or Chen, as had also been reported by the China Times Express.
He expressed his deep regret over the failure of the paper to conduct some simple fact-checking before publishing their allegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DEMAND LABELING OF GMO PRODUCTS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) will implement a system requiring all products made from or containing genetically modified organisms (GMO) to be labeled starting from next year, a DOH official said Tuesday.

Chen Shu-kong, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said the agency will adopt a combined system of compulsory and voluntary labeling, and will first require the compulsory labeling on soybean and corn products.
Chen explained that products not included on the compulsory GMO labeling list will be subject to voluntary labeling.
He said the DOH is studying measures to examine products made from GMO material and will then decide how much of such material will be permitted in a product before it has to be labeled.
Chen pointed out that the European Union requires that products containing more than 1 percent of GMO must be labeled, while in Japan, the percentage is 5 percent.
A survey commissioned recently by the DOH shows that 74 percent of the 1,083 respondents hope the government will adopt compulsory labeling on GMO foods.
While about 70 percent of the interviewees said they had heard of GMO foods, only 11 percent of them said they would never buy such products.
Of the respondents, 21 percent said they believe genetically modified food is not good for the health, while 40 percent said they think that gene modification technology violates the laws of nature.
Nevertheless, 73 percent of the respondents said they would accept genetically modified foods.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER: FUTURE OF NUCLEAR PLANT TO BE DECIDED BY DECEMBER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that the Executive Yuan will decide by December whether to stop construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant.
He made the remarks while answering questions raised by two legislators from the opposition People First Party.
Chang added that the issue has been handed to the secretariat of the Executive Yuan for further study.

Former Premier Tang Fei resigned from the premiership early this month because he supported continued construction of the power plant, a stance that conflicts with the stance of President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

The Economics Ministry has submitted a proposal to suspend the nuclear power project, but the opposition Kuomintang and some industrial sectors advocate continuing the project so as to ensure sufficient power supplies for the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADERS FROM GREATER CHINA TO MEET IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: A trade seminar to be attended by business leaders from Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China will open Wednesday in Beijing to tackle issues arising from the imminent entry of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Wu Wen-ya, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), and Tsai Hui-yen, deputy director-general of the Intellectual Property Office of the MOEA, arrived in Beijing Tuesday along with a 27-member Taiwan delegation headed by Hsu Sheng-fa, chairman of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (TCCI). Wu will deliver a keynote speech at the annual two-day seminar which is held alternately in Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China.

Last year's meeting, which should have taken place in Taipei, was canceled because of Beijing's irritation over former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship."

Hsu expressed hope that the seminar will discover good competition across the Taiwan Strait on a complementary basis so as to create a win-win-win situation for Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China in the face of imminent WTO entry.
Jing Suping, chairman of Beijing's All-China Federation of Idustry and Commerce hosted a dinner party in honor of the Taiwan delegation Tuesday night.

According to Hsu, the main topics at the agenda will center on how to tackle issues that might arise from WTO entry for Taiwan and mainland China and how to develop competition and cooperation among Taiwan, Hong Kong and the mainland so as to seek benefits for all three.

Hsu also expressed the hope that the Beijing authorities will offer financial services to Taiwan investors in the mainland. Issues related to monetary services, law, Taiwan investors' interests and Beijing's development project in its western regions will also be included in the discussions, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU MAYOR TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Hsinchu Mayor Tsai Jen-chien is scheduled to leave for the city of Nanjing Wednesday, making him the first local government head in Taiwan to ever visit the mainland in an official capacity.
A Hsinchu City government spokesman said that Tsai is to attend the Second World Technology Conference at the invitation of the meeting's host, Nanjing Mayor Wang Hungmin.

Tsai's trip has been approved by the Republic of China government agencies, including the Interior Ministry and the Council of Mainland Affairs, as the conference will focus on technological development and has nothing to do with politics or ideology, according to an Interior Ministry official.
The Cabinet has recently turned down separate applications by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh to visit the mainland on political grounds.
Hsinchu City, location of the island's first science-based industrial park, is home to hundreds of leading information technology manufacturers.
Tsai is expected to return to Taiwan Oct. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 18, or the 20th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1405: Pope Pius II, originally named Enea Silivio Piccolomini, is born. He was noted for his unsuccessful attempt to lead a crusade against the Turks.
1860: Invading British troops burn the Yuanmingyuan, the imperial summer palace in Beijing, to the ground.
1867: The United States purchases Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
1873: Delegates from Columbia, Princeton, Rutgers, and Yale universities meet and formulate the rules of American football.
1898: The United States takes possession of Puerto Rico from Spain.
1907: The first plans are announced for an International Court of Justice to be set up in The Hague.
1922: Tsai Yuan-pei, a scholar and the president of Peking University, resigns in the wake of student protests against an extra levy on professor's handouts.
1926: The will of Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian founder of the Bolshevik party, leader of the Russian Revolution and first head of the USSR, is made public to the world in the New York Times.
1931: Thomas Alva Edison, America's most prolific inventor, dies at the age of 84. His inventions include the phonograph, the microphone, and the Kinetoscope. He also designed a complete electrical distribution system for lightning and power.
1941: General Hideki Tojo becomes prime minister of Japan and begins planning for war against the United States.
1944: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt cables Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government and supreme commander of the China theater of war, regarding his decision to appoint General Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China theater of war, succeeding General Joseph Stilwell.
1946: The Chinese Communists reject the government's latest peace offer presented by Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 16.
1967: Venera 4, a Soviet spacecraft, enters the atmosphere of Venus and transmits data back to earth.
1970: Vice President-Premier Yen Chia-kan leaves Taipei for New York to attend the 25th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.
1974: Acting for President Chiang Kai-shek, Vice President Yen Chia-kan accepts the credentials of Maj. Gen. Ismael D. Lapus as Philippines ambassador to the ROC.
1974: The ROC national taekwondo team returns from Seoul after taking second place in the First Asian Taekwondo championships.
1976: Chinese-American scientist Samuel Chao Chung Ting and his colleague Burton Richter share the 1976 Nobel Prize for physics for their discovery of an elementary nuclear particle called the "psi," or "J particle."
1976: K.T.J. Rakheth, minister of industry and commerce of the Kingdom of Lesotho, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1987: The United States attacks an Iranian oil rig in revenge for strikes against its shipping operations by gunboats.
1989: Erich Honecker, 77, East Germany's hardline ruler who failed to respond to the desire among East Germans for change, is ousted from the post he held for the previous 18 years.
1989: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer match in Guatemala. Eighty-three people are killed and nearly 200 others are injured.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Council is established under the Executive Yuan to formulate and implement mainland policy, with Vice Premier Shih Chi-yang serving as its chairman.
1998: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC's Straits Exchange Foundation, crowns a six-day visit to mainland China by meeting with President Jiang Zemin, marking the highest-level contact between the two sides since 1949.
1999: Two more Knox-class frigates leased from the United States are commissioned in order to help beef up the Republic of China's naval defense capabilities.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, by living a life of simple truth and earnestness, alone can help to bring peace and order in the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 270.13 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 270.13 points to close at 5,432.23.
Market turnover amounted to NT$56.31 billion (US$1.75 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 270.13 points to close at 5,432.23.

Affected by a drop in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,606.53, and due to a continued drop in electronics shares, the index continued to go down. The bourse fluctuated between 5,626.74 and 5,427.46 during trading.

A total of 1.89 billion stocks worth NT$56.31 billion (US$1.75 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.18 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$72.17 billion (US$2.26 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 6.1 percent, followed by textile issues at 5.5 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 4 percent, construction stocks at 2.7 percent, pulp and paper issues at 2.5 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.4 percent, foodstuff stocks at 2.2 percent, and cement shares at 1.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 527 to 39, with 50 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on the Taiwan stock index futures were lower Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization weighted index futures for October moved down 400 points to close at 5,328, with 1,633 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 403 points to finish at 5,357, with 8,626 contract transactions, while December futures plunged 404 points to close at 5,374, with 39 contracts changing hands.
March 2001 futures fell 222 points to finish at 5,501, with one contract traded, while June 2001 futures decreased 142 points to close at 5,701, with six contracts changing hands.

Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Wednesday at 5,728 for October, 5,760 for November, 5,778 for December, 5,723 for next March, and 5,843 for next June.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
October TE futures moved down 19.65 points to close at 261.45, with 406 contract transactions, while November TE futures lost 19.55 points to finish at 260.4, with 1,763 contract transactions.
December TE futures fell 19.85 points to close at 263.75, with eight contract transactions, while March 2001 TE futures decreased 9.9 points to finish at 265.3, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June 2001 TE futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW NOBEL PRIZEWINNER IN LITERATURE TO VISIT TAIWAN IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be the first stop on an overseas trip by mainland Chinese dissident novelist-playwright Gao Xingjian after he was awarded the 2000 Nobel Prize in literature on Oct. 12, sources from the Taipei city government said Wednesday.

Gao, the first Chinese to win the Nobel Prize in literature in its 100-year history, is scheduled to come to Taipei, where he has visited twice before, sometime in January, said Lung Ying-tai, director of the Bureau of Cultural Affairs.

At the invitation of the bureau, the 60-year-old writer-painter who has lived in self-exile in France over the past 12 years, will stay in Taipei for more than one month in his capacity as an artist in residence -- a program aimed at helping promote local cultural development, Lung noted.

Lung praised Gao as a true intellectual and artist who has kept his promise to visit Taiwan despite the difficult circumstances. Kao, an old personal acquaintance of Lung, was previously scheduled to visit Taipei as an artist in residence for three months beginning at the end of October.

In his long-distance telephone conversation with Lung Tuesday, Gao said he will have to postpone his visit until January and may not be able to stay for three months at one time because "it seems many things have come up" since he was awarded the Nobel prize. "Please let me pay this debt in several installments," he told Lung.

Gao, who was once forced to burn his writings to save himself from radical Chinese Communists and was driven abroad by Chinese censors, was cited by the Swedish Academy for his "bitter insights and linguistic ingenuity."

"In the writing of Gao Xingjian literature is born anew from the struggle of the individual to survive the history of the masses," the academy said in its citation. "He is a perspicacious skeptic who makes no claim to be able to explain the world. He asserts that he has found freedom only in writing."

Gao, born in the central Chinese province of Jiangxi in 1940, fled his homeland in 1987 after one of his plays was banned and he was put under police surveillance. After the 1989 bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in Beijing, he wrote "Fugitives," set against the background of the massacre. As a result, Beijing declared him "persona non grata" and banned his works.

In an interview with a CNA correspondent in Paris on Oct. 13, Gao said he appreciates Taiwan's publishers for their support of artistic freedom, going on to thank his readers on the island for supporting his literary works and paintings over the past decade.
He said he has been moved by the hospitality and friendship shown by Taiwan publishers, writers, and readers each time he has visited the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD URGES RETURN TO `ONE CHINA, SEPARATE INTERPRETATIONS' BASIS

TEXT.P: The chairman of the opposition Kuomintang on Wednesday dismissed President Chen Shui-bian's statement calling for a return to "the spirit of 1992" across the Taiwan Strait as "slogan politics" that ignores the welfare of the public.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party should cast away its ideology and return to the 1992 agreement on "one China, separate interpretations" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as the basis for a resumption in cross-strait talks.

Lien made the remarks after listening to a report by Kao Koong-lian, who was vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council in 1992, on cross-strait relations at a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday.

Kao, who had taken part in cross-strait dialogue policy in 1992, stressed that both sides of the Taiwan Strait did reach an agreement on "one China, separate interpretations" in 1992 and that the "spirit of 1992" was a term coined by President Chen, adding that the president had used his "imagination and creativity" to fictionalize the term "spirit" as meaning "dialogue, exchanges, and the shelving of disputes."

In fact, Kao said cross-strait dialogue began earlier in 1990 when both sides reached the Kinmen agreement on the repatriation of illegal immigrants. Also, cross-strait exchanges began in 1987 and the shelving of disputes between the two sides started earlier than 1992, he added.
Kao said that President Chen was trying to avoid the fact that a concrete agreement was reached in 1992 by using the vague term "spirit of the 1992."

Chairman Lien stressed that "one China, separate interpretations" should be the basis of cross-strait talks, adding that for years the KMT has pursued a pragmatic policy, which on one hand had increased cross-strait exchanges to maintain stability in the Taiwan Strait, and on the other hand had built a national consensus to help positive cross-strait exchanges.
Lien said that in May he had advocated exchanges between political parties across the Taiwan Strait, which he said was for the purpose of upholding the national sovereignty of the Republic of China.

Lien urged the ruling government to put aside its ideology and adopt a pragmatic approach like the previous government's in seeking to ease the cross-strait atmosphere in order to achieve a breakthrough in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU MAYOR LEAVES FOR MAINLAND VISIT

TEXT.P: Mayor Tsai Jen-chien of Hsinchu City in northern Taiwan left for Nanjing Wednesday, making him the first local government chief to be allowed to visit mainland China since the inauguration of the new Republic of China government in May.

Tsai will attend a conference of chief administrators of major science-technology cities around the world. Hsinchu, which hosts Taiwan's first science-based industrial park, is home to thousands of high-technology companies.

Prior to his departure, Tsai said he has received more than 20 groups of visitors from mainland China during his two-year mayoral stint and that the visitors included 10-plus mayors and county chiefs.

In the past, Tsai said, only mainland local government chiefs were allowed to visit Taiwan, a one-way exchange. "I'm hopeful that my mainland visit will mark the start of two-way exchange of visits by local-level government chiefs," he added.
Tsai, a stalwart of the ROC's new ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said he also hopes his mainland visit will contribute to the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Tsai was invited by Nanjing Mayor Wang Hungmin to attend the second world technology cities meeting, and the ROC government formally approved his visit. "Therefore, I'm not a cross-strait emissary," Tsai noted.

Earlier this year, the ROC government turned down separate applications by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, one of the brightest stars of the main opposition Kuomintang, and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who concurrently serves as DPP chairman, to visit the mainland for complex considerations.
In addition to attending the Nanjing meeting, Tsai will also visit Shanghai and Xiamen, which lies very close to the ROC's frontline island of Kinmen.
Tsai said cross-strait exchanges should be handled in a pragmatic manner, adding that there should be ample room for cross-strait cooperation in cultural and technological fields.
Tsai said he will look into administrative, production and operational mechanisms of major mainland high-tech parks during his Oct. 18-22 visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAY RIGHTS ACTIVIST REQUESTS CONSTITUTIONAL INTERPRETATION

TEXT.P: Gay rights activist Chi Chia-wei on Wednesday again made known his appeal requesting that the ROC Council of Grand Justice interpret why people of the same sex cannot legally marry in Taiwan.

Chi, who has also been devoted to AIDS prevention in Taiwan over the past 17 years, said his request for a public notarization of his marriage to his lifetime partner, a Mr. Lin, was turned down by the Taipei District Court in May.
Chi then filed a complaint with the Taiwan High Court against the Taipei District Court for refusing to authorize his marriage to Lin at the court's Notarization Office.

His complaint, however, was also rejected, prompting him to file a request to the Council of Grand Justice on Sept. 21 for an constitutional interpretation of the legal basis for the Taipei District Court and the Taiwan High Court's decision to reject his marriage notarization request.
Chi said the ROC Civil Codes do not contain a single line saying that people of the same sex are prohibited from marrying.

Noting that what he is fighting is an ideological battle, Chi asked why a modern society like Taiwan's, where gays and lesbians are increasingly accepted, cannot accept the notion of marriage between people of the same sex.
Chi said the Taipei District Court rejected his marriage notarization request on the basis that allowing a marriage between two men would "impair social morals and tarnish traditional ethics."

Homosexuality is one of the normal traits of human beings and gays and lesbians are as normal as heterosexual people, Chi stressed. Since they are normal and supposed to be accepted by all societies, why are they deprived of the right to marry that is enjoyed by heterosexuals, he asked.

He said more than 20 nations around the world now officially recognize marriage between people of same sex, adding that even in ideologically-restricted mainland China, two men were allowed to marry in 1990, and two women did the same in 1992.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF STRAY DOGS IN TAIPEI DECLINES NOTICEABLY

TEXT.P: The number of stray dogs in Taipei, Taiwan's largest city, has declined noticeably over the past year, down a whopping 30,000 animals over a period of a year, municipal government sources said Wednesday.

As of July, there were about 18,000 stray dogs in Taipei, down by a remarkable 37,000 from the approximately 55,000 recorded in the same month a year ago, officials from the Bureau of Environmental Protection (BEP) quoted a recent survey as indicating.

According to the survey conducted by Prof. Fei Chang-yung and his team at National Taiwan University's Veterinary Medicine Department, there was a total of about 229,000 canines in Taipei as of the end of July, 211,000 of which were dogs kept as pets, about 1,000 higher than the number tallied a year earlier.

The number of stray dogs, however, declined noticeably over the past year, apparently as a result of a series of measures taken by the city government to tackle the issue that have caused concern among international animal protection groups due to the brutality of some of the measures.

BEP officials attributed the decline in the number of strays mainly to the more severe penalties meted out to owners who are found to have abandoned their dogs, and also to the city government's policy of killing abandoned, old and sickly dogs.

They noted that over the past year, the BEP has made what they described as particularly "humanitarian" efforts to catch, take in and handle stray dogs in the hope that even unwanted animals can be treated properly.
At the same time, the officials said, a higher rate of stray dog adoptions by institutions and individuals has also contributed to a decline in the number of strays wandering the streets.
According to Fei's survey, the number of adoptions has increased 2.7 times over the past year, a number that is equivalent to one in every 141.6 Taipei citizens adopting a dog.

The survey also asked Taipei residents' opinion of the city government's "dog policy" over the past year, and found that 59 percent of the respondents approved of the measures taken by the government.

Non-dog owning residents were also asked why they do not have a dog -- the number one pet in Taipei according to a 1997 survey. Among the reasons stated by the survey respondents were a lack of space, fear of contagious diseases, and too much trouble, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES SWAZILAND DELEGATION

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian received the head of a Swaziland economic delegation Wednesday and told his guest he hopes to visit Swaziland in the near future.

During the meeting, Chen also told Majozi V. Sithole, minister of economic planning and development, that the ROC appreciates Swaziland's long-term support and assistance to Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations and other international organizations.

Sithole for his part said that his country is willing to speak for the ROC in its bid to join international organizations, firm in its belief that ROC entry will benefit other nations and that the ROC will contribute more to the international community.
The president noted that he twice visited South Africa during his terms as legislator and Taipei City mayor, but had yet to visit Swaziland.

Accompanying Sithole at the meeting were Roy Fanourakis, minister of agriculture and cooperatives; Prince Gaduza, minister of public works and transport, and Swaziland Ambassador to the ROC Moses M. Dlamini.
The Swaziland delegation arrived in Taipei Sunday to attend an economic and technology cooperation meeting that will last until Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO REVISE LAW TO FACILITATE EXCHANGES WITH MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government will revise current regulations to facilitate exchanges with Mongolia, a senior ROC official said Wednesday.
Hsu Cheng-kuang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, made the statement during a Legislative Yuan committee meeting.

Noting that more than 130 countries around the world, including mainland China, have recognized Mongolia as an independent sovereign state, Hsu said the independence of Mongolia has apparently become a historical fact.

The ROC recognized Mongolia's independence in 1946, but annulled the recognition after moving its seat to Taiwan in 1949. Current ROC regulations still regard Mongolia as part of the communist-controlled Chinese mainland.
Hsu said the ROC has forged closer substantive relations with Mongolia since Mongolia cut ties with the now-defunct Soviet bloc and began sweeping political and economic reforms.
However, he went on, controversy surrounding the ROC's stance on Mongolia's status has hindered further development of Taiwan-Mongolia relations.

"Legally, we regard Mongolia as part of the Chinese mainland," Hsu explained, adding that the policy has made it difficult for the two sides to exchange representative offices to facilitate bilateral exchanges.

The ROC government currently does not grant formal visas to Mongolian visitors. Instead, the ROC issues Mongolians with travel permits similar to those issued to mainland Chinese people in accordance with the Statute Governing Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
Hsu suggested that the Executive Yuan, or Cabinet, hold an inter-ministerial meeting to seek a solution to the thorny Mongolian status issue on a case-by-case basis.

With a view to removing barriers to bilateral exchanges, Hsu said, relevant government agencies should revise the existing statute governing relations across the Taiwan Strait to exclude Mongolia from the coverage of the statute.

By so doing, Hsu said, commercial, technological and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Mongolia will be able to make significant headway. "Moreover, it will also become easier for the two sides to exchange representative offices," he added.

Commenting on Hsu's proposal, an official with the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said the proposed exclusion of Mongolia from the coverage of the statute governing cross-strait relations will need further discussion because it "may cause problems" related to the ROC Constitution and even international law. However, the official, who preferred anonymity, declined to identify what these "problems" might be.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. PAGODA SYMBOLIZING ROC-U.S. FRIENDSHIP RENOVATED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A renovated marine observation tower symbolizing the friendship between the Republic of China and the United States was formally inaugurated Sunday in Virginia, while a new adjacent oriental garden opened to the public for the first time.

Overlooking the Hampton Roads Harbor in Norfolk, Virginia, the waterfront pagoda was built in 1989 to commemorate a 1983 visit by former ROC President Lee Teng-hui -- who at that time was Taiwan provincial governor. It is supposed to symbolize "the spirit of friendship and cooperation between Taiwan and the Commonwealth of Virginia" as well as between their respective port cities.

Norfolk Mayor Paul D. Fraim and Raymond K. Wu, president of the Friends of the Pagoda & Oriental Garden Foundation, jointly presided over the inauguration ceremony, which was attended by approximately 250 guests including Chen Chien-jen, the ROC Representative to the United States, and Owen B. Pickett, a Virginia U.S. House representative.
Virginia Governor James S. Gilmore III sent his congratulations in a written message that was read at the ceremony.

Chen pointed out in his address that he was pleased to see the renovations completed on the pagoda and the new garden completed with the cooperation between the Norfolk City government and the local public, including overseas Chinese living in the area.
He went on to say that these various developments symbolize the "growing friendship and relations" between the people of the two countries.

In the 17 years since Lee's visit, the ROC has improved by leaps and bounds both economically and politically, Chen said, adding that Taiwan is now the world's 17th-largest economy, the 14th-largest trading nation, and the seventh-largest export market for the United States.
Furthermore, it is now a completely democratic country, he said.

The Chinese-American community in Norfolk established a foundation to assist the city to refurbish the pagoda and complete the adjacent garden, which includes a goldfish pond, three oriental gates, a waterfall, and various oriental trees and greenery.
Stephen S.F. Chen, the former ROC Representative to the United States, donated US$50,000 to the foundation in 1998 on behalf of the ROC government.

According to the foundation, the pagoda will function as the focal point of the oriental garden, which will be "a tranquil place of beauty and harmony exhibiting symbolic Chinese artifacts and historical markers which will be an educational experience and bridge for better understanding of eastern culture."

Prefabricated pieces of the pagoda were constructed in Taiwan and shipped to the United States for assembly. The pagoda is included on the Cannonball Trail, a new heritage trail being promoted by the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO MEET PFP CHAIRMAN THURSDAY

TEXT.P: The long-talked-about reconciliation among domestic political parties will finally take a step forward as opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong is scheduled to meet President Chen Shui-bian Thursday.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the President, said Wednesday that he and PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi have worked out technical details regarding the Chen-Soong meeting.
"The meeting will start at 8 p.m. Thursday at the Taipei Guest House," Yu said, adding that both he and PFP's Chung will also be present at the closed-door meeting.
According to Yu, the press will be briefed on the results of the meeting. But it remains unclear whether the two sides will hold a joint news conference or they will brief the press separately.

As for the agenda, Soong reportedly is willing to present opinions on matters related to the common interests of all Taiwan people, including relations across the Taiwan Strait as well as financial and economic issues.
For his part, Yu reaffirmed President Chen's open-minded attitude toward the agenda. "Any topics helpful to national interests and people's well-being can be raised and discussed," he stressed.
This will be the first meeting between Chen and Soong after the March 18 presidential election, in which Soong lost to Chen with a narrow margin.

As Chen's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) controls only about one-third of the Legislative Yuan seats, Chen has pitched for reconciliation and cooperation among major domestic political parties since his inauguration in May.

Due to complex reasons, a Chen-proposed roundtable meeting of top leaders of major parties has long remained on the drawing board. As a result, Chen said last week he will pay visits to PFP Chairman Soong, main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and Hau Lung-pin, convener of the New Party National Campaign and Development Commission, to signify his sincerity to promote inter-party cooperation.
In preparation for Chen's meetings with the three opposition leaders, Yu already met with his PFP and New Party counterparts to set the stage for the much-anticipated inter-party summit talks.

After a meeting with New Party Secretary-General Lee Ping-nan, Yu said the New Party welcomes Chen's visit this week. According to Lee, Chen's visit may take place on Saturday. Nevertheless, he said, some technical details need further discussion.

Meanwhile, Yu is scheduled to meet with KMT Secretary-General Ling Fong-cheng Thursday to arrange a meeting between Chen and Lien, who ended third in the March 18 presidential election. The proposed Chen-Lien meeting has drawn much attention as the KMT controls more than half of the parliamentary seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CEMENT INDUSTRY MOVING OUT DUE TO SAGGING BUSINESS CONDITIONS

TEXT.P: Troubled by long-term sluggishness at home, many Taiwan-based cement companies have accelerated their pace of diversification and are moving off the island in search of a new lease of life.

Contrary to what had been widely believed would be strong demand from central Taiwan areas, which were hard hit by last year's Sept. 21 earthquake, the local cement industry failed to regain momentum in the first half of this year, due to delays in construction of several major public projects and strong foreign competition.
First-half cement sales fell by 7.7 percent as compared to the same period of 1999. Currently, cement prices hang around a low level of NT$2,000 per ton, industry sources said.

Although it has been forecast that demand in the local market may rebound beginning in October this year because of the building of the island's NT$140 billion high-speed rail system and several large-scale construction projects, many cement companies have in turn hastened the pace of their relocation overseas or expansion into other fields to face the challenges of the worsening domestic business climate.

Asia Cement, for instance, has already set up a cement company in mainland China's Jiangxi Province, which is capable of producing 1.5 million tons of cement annually starting in September this year. In addition, it has also edged into power and Internet businesses through spin-off operations, an indication of its desire to broaden its business scope, industrial sources said.

At the same time, Chien Tai Cement has also decided to invest NT$650 million (about US$20 million) to build a distribution center and processing plant at Manila Harbor in the Philippines, in its first bid to expand into overseas markets. The move is expected to create annual profits of between NT$600 million and NT$700 million for the company in the initial stages.

Taiwan Cement's NT$70 billion investment in the Hoping Special Zone in northeastern Taiwan -- the building of a cement plant, a power plant and a port -- has aroused a high-degree of attention from the local industry.

Two mills of the NT$20 billion cement plant -- one of which has already started trial operations while the other one is slated to begin operations in February 2001 -- will be able to produce 5.4 million tons of cement worth NT$10.8 billion per year after officially going into mass production.

Construction of the planned power plant, which carries a price tag of NT$40 billion, is scheduled to be completed in September 2002. The state-run Taiwan Power Company has decided to buy out the power plant, which will have a designed capacity of 1.32 million kilowatts.
First-phase construction of the port has recently been completed and it is slated to begin operations later this month after having received approval from the Industrial Development Bureau.

The objective of the new port is to exclusively handle the shipping out of the 130 million tons of cement to be put out annually by the cement plant within the Hoping complex. The port's transport capacity will be upgraded to 190 million tons after the second phase of construction is complete.
Meanwhile, Hsing Ta Cement has obtained approval from the Interior Ministry for a long-term land development project in Kuansi, northern Hsinchu County.

The 150-hectare lot, which cost Hsing Ta NT$549 million (US$16.8 million), will be the location of a residential area accounting for 22 percent of the total area, with the rest of the lot earmarked for parks, schools and forest areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE SEMINAR OPENS IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: A seminar on trade and economic cooperation among the three Chinese communities -- Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong -- opened in Beijing Wednesday.
The two-day seminar will focus discussion on possible problems following Taiwan's and mainland China's accession to the World Trade Organization and feasible strategies to cope with those problems.
Jing Suping, chairman of Beijing's All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce, called on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to strengthen economic cooperation in his opening remarks.
Noting that the WTO entry will pose great challenges to both Taiwan and mainland China, Jing said the two sides should strengthen cooperation to survive in the increasingly competitive global market.
Wu Wen-ya, director-general of Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, delivered a keynote speech at the opening session.

Wu said both the Taiwan and mainland markets will become more transparent and predictable following their WTO entry. Moreover, he said, the WTO accession will also help increase cross-strait trade opportunities.
Speaking on the same occasion, Hsu Sheng-fa, chairman of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (TCCI), said most of Taiwan's publicly listed Taiwan companies have invested in mainland China.

As many privileges currently enjoyed by Taiwan investors on the mainland will gradually be removed following the WTO entry, Hsu said he hopes the ongoing meeting will discuss measures to help Taiwan-financed companies on the mainland to sustain their market niches and competitiveness.

Hsu said Taiwan has completed planning work for the December opening of the direct "mini three links," which refer to direct trade, transport and mail links between Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and selected mainland Chinese port cities.
Hsu said he hopes mainland authorities will cooperate with Taiwan to ensure smooth opening of the direct "mini three links" late this year.
Moreover, Hsu urged mainland authorities to resume cross-strait dialogue to pave the way for opening of full-fledged direct "three links" between Taiwan and mainland China as early as possible.
Hsu further expressed the hope that the Beijing authorities will offer financial services to Taiwan investors in the mainland.

More than 200 business leaders from Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong are attending the two-day trade seminar. Issues related to monetary services, law, Taiwan investors' interests and Beijing's development project in its western regions will all be included in the agenda.

Last year's meeting, which should have taken place in Taipei, was canceled because of Beijing's irritation over former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's remarks that cross-strait ties should be on a "special state-to-state" basis.
