DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 19, or the 21st day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1216: King John of England, known as John Lackland, dies at the age of 49. During his reign, the English lost most of their possessions in France. The nobility rose against John and forced him to sign the Magna Carta, a cornerstone of English political and civil liberties.
1781: General Charles Cornwallis, British commander, unwittingly delivers his 8,000 troops into the hands of the besieging American forces at Yorktown in Virginia, allowing General George Washington to win the War of Independence for the American colonists.
1812: Tsar Alexander's refusal to negotiate, along with renewed Russian military activity to the south of Moscow, leaves Napoleon Bonaparte with no alternative but to begin retreating from Moscow, which was captured by the French.
1872: The Holtermann Nugget, a slate weighing 235.14 kg, is found in New South Wales, Australia. It contains 82.11 kg of gold, the largest single mass of gold ever found.
1901: Alberto Santos Dumont, a Brazilian aviator, circumnavigates the Eiffel Tower in his airship to win the Deutsche Prize, the first aviation prize.
1925: Chiang Ching-kuo leaves Shanghai for Moscow to study at Sun Yat-sen University there.
1935: The League of Nations imposes sanctions against Italy following its invasion of Ethiopia.
1936: Chou Shu-jen, a modern Chinese writer who used the pen name Lu Hsun and was most admired by the Communist Chinese, dies of illness in Shanghai at the age of 56.
1937: Ernest Rutherford, New Zealand-born British physicist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize in chemistry, dies at the age of 66. He is regarded as the founder of modern atomic theory.
1940: The Burma road is reopened after the British closed the road for three months.
1947: The Taiwan Provincial Government opens Keelung and Kaohsiung as international seaports.
1950: The North Korean capital of Pyongyang falls during the Korean War.
1960: The U.S. State Department establishes an embargo on Cuban-bound shipments of all goods except medicine and foodstuffs.
1960: Mauritania proclaims independence from France.
1963: Sir Alec Douglas-Home succeeds Harold Macmillan as British prime minister.
1968: Republic of China athlete Chi Cheng wins a bronze medal in the women's 80-meter low hurdle event with a time of 10.4 seconds at the 19th Olympic Games held in Mexico City.
1973: Dr. Li Yuan-zu is appointed president of National Chengchi University.
1975: A total of 5,462 athletes begin seven days of competition at the Second Taiwan Area Games in Taipei.
1976: Joseph Jenkins Peal, the minister of labor, youth and sports of the Republic of Lesotho, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.

1987: Wall Street experiences the worst day in its history, known as "Black Monday," with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting a record 508.32 points, knocking US$500 billion off share values. The percentage decline is 22.6, almost 10 percent greater than the 1929 big crash, which heralded the Great Depression.
1990: Mikhail Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, wins parliamentary approval for a plan to switch to a market economy from the communist centrally planned economy.

Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the Book of Songs it is said: `I keep in mind the fine moral qualities which make no great noise or show.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT EXPELS ECONOMICS MINISTER FROM PARTY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's opposition Kuomintang on Thursday expelled Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi from the party, chiding him for "seriously opposing KMT policies and impairing the people's interests."

"The KMT has decided to expel Lin from the party because he joined the Democratic Progressive Party-held administration as a Cabinet member without notifying the KMT leadership in advance and because of his evident opposition to continuing construction of the fourth nuclear power plant, which is a set policy of the KMT," said KMT Evaluation and Discipline Committee Director-General Chien Wei-chang.
Fourteen out of the 19 members of the KMT Evaluation and Discipline Committee took part in a meeting Thursday to discuss how Lin should be dealt with for what he had done.

At first, the participants at the meeting considered withdrawing Lin's KMT membership as punishment. However, some committee members argued against this, saying that Lin should be kicked out of the party in the interests of party justice.
They later decided to expel Lin, making him the first KMT member serving as a Cabinet minister to be kicked out of the party.
Upon being informed of the KMT decision, Lin said he had no feelings and offered no opinions on it.

Meanwhile, the KMT Evaluation and Discipline Committee also decided to have KMT Legislator Chao Yung-ching's membership suspended for one year as a penalty for his public opposition to the fourth nuclear power plant project.

Chao, nicknamed the "environmental protection legislator," has for long publicly opposed continuation of the controversial project, which has faced an unknown fate since the DPP became the ruling party in Taiwan in May of this year. The DPP, which has long insisted upon a "green, nuclear-free Taiwan," opposes in principle the continuation of the project.

The membership suspension will deprive Chao of the possibility of being nominated by the KMT as a candidate in the 2001 legislative elections. It has therefore been speculated that Chao will switch gears and run for the seat of Taipei County magistrate as an independent or join the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI 3 LINKS' EXPECTED TO HELP BREAK CROSS-STRAIT IMPASSE: PM

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday he earnestly hopes that the upcoming opening of direct "mini three links" will help push forward the long-stalled relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Chang made the remarks at a central and local governments coordination meeting, which was attended by several Cabinet members and magistrates of offshore and eastern Taiwan counties.

Reaffirming his call for replacing confrontation with cooperation, Chang said the Republic of China government's decision to open direct trade, mail and transportation links between Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and selected mainland Chinese coastal cities, commonly known as "mini three links," is part of its efforts to forge cross-strait rapprochement.

"The planned opening of the direct 'mini three links' late this year or early next year marks a goodwill gesture aimed at underscoring our sincerity to improve cross-strait relations," Chang explained, adding that he looks forward to seeing significant headway in cross-strait relations following the opening of the direct 'mini three links'".

This was the first time since Chang assumed the premiership that the central and local governments coordination meeting was held in Kinmen. Chang said the move signifies the government's concern for the development in offshore and eastern Taiwan counties, which generally lag behind other parts of Taiwan in urbanization and economic development.
Chang said the opening of direct "mini three links" is also partly aimed at helping boost economic development in Kinmen and Matsu by allowing freer product and personnel exchanges with the mainland.

In the initial stage, Chang said mainland goods that are badly needed by Kinmen and Matsu residents in their daily lives and do not pose any threat to national security will be allowed to shipped directly from such mainland port city as Xiamen to the two frontline islands, which lie very close to the southeastern mainland coast.
The premier also pitched for an end to partisan confrontation and close cooperation among major domestic political parties to promote national interests and people's well-being.

Despite its limited land and natural resources, Taiwan has managed to achieve economic prosperity and political democratization mainly because it has consistently adopted supraparty policy, wise development strategy and emphasis on education. "We must continue this good tradition to overcome various current difficulties and ensure sustainable national development," he added.

Other Cabinet members present at the coordination meeting included Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and Lin Chuan, director-general of the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

The meeting, held at the Kinmen County Government, was also attended by several local government chiefs and lawmakers, including Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai, Lienchiang County Magistrate Liu Li-chun, Penghu County Magistrate Lai Feng-wei, Hualien County Magistrate Wang Ching-feng and Taitung County Magistrate Chen Chien-nien.

Chang and other government officials also inspected several Kinmen infrastructure construction projects in preparation for the opening of the "mini three links," including a new power plant, the Liaolo port expansion project and the Shuitou commercial port construction project, before returning to Taipei Thursday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SHOULD NOT BE ISOLATED NOR APPEASED: IRON LADY

TEXT.P: Communist China is far too important to be isolated, but at the same time it should not be appeased, particularly over Taiwan, wrote former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in the latest issue of Hoover Digest.

The Iron Lady wrote in the quarterly journal published by Stanford University's Hoover Institution that with the end of the Cold War, the nature of the threat to peace and stability has fundamentally changed.

"It is the activities of rogue states and the possibility of unplanned launches of missiles armed with warheads that should now be our main concern. We must also be able to prevent the intimidation of friendly states like Taiwan," she said.
"The way to achieve this is through the construction of an effective system of ballistic missile defense," she stressed in the article titled "A Time for Leadership."

She pointed out that the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty is a Cold War relic and now a worthless document that deserves to be consigned to one of history's shredders. Since only America has the technology to build a global system of ballistic missile defense, America's allies should meet a share of the cost, and any delays must be avoided.

Lady Thatcher emphasized that "if we come to believe that the best way to avoid danger is to evade rather than confront it; if we think that negotiation is always the statesmanlike option; if we prefer empty multilateral gestures to powerful national responses, then we shall pay a heavy price -- and our children and grandchildren will pay it too."

"What we have to do now is to apply to present dangers the lessons and insights drawn from the past. Our tasks today therefore are threefold. First, we have to defend our homelands against present and future threats. Second, we have to maintain our military capabilities and alliances in good shape. Third, we have to project our values and the institutions that nurture them across the globe," she said.
Thatcher said she is convinced that the new threats will likely come from China, Russia, and such rogue states as North Korea, Iran, Iraq and Libya.

"We are apt to say that victory in the Cold War meant the collapse of communism. But, of course, that is not strictly true. Indeed, one Communist power has actually benefited by the implosion of the Soviet Union. China is now the main candidate to become a superpower, and its intentions and capabilities are rightly the subject of intense debate."

Communist China is certainly a rising power -- its already vast population is growing, as is its economy and ambitions -- all three in contrast to those of Russia. And still more than Russia, "China's past history and present ideology suggest that, for the foreseeable future, it remains deeply hostile to the West," she explained.

The argument that economic progress will automatically change this underlying hostility is flawed, according to Thatcher, who said "the ruling elite in China -- which uses the slogans, apparatus, and methods of communism to stay in power -- is not going to go quickly or quietly. It cannot afford to embrace democracy, and at the moment it does not need to."

"The leadership is, after all, able to repress dissent without much difficulty. It has even perfected a system -- combining enterprise, corruption, and slave labor -- that allows it to benefit from growing prosperity," she added.

She concluded that Communist China will likely not come to match the United States in superpower status, but "it is a potentially hostile regional power. In the long run, democratic India may emerge as a counterweight, but today and for the foreseeable future, it is Japan that must be America's strategic partner in the region. Keeping that partnership alive and well is the fulcrum of stability in the Far East."

DOC.HEADLINE: 2000 PARALYMPICS RAISES RECORD AMOUNT IN SPONSORSHIP REVENUES

TEXT.P: The 2000 Sydney Paralympic Games has raised a record US$30 million in cash and goods and service commitments from sponsors, US$6.3 million more than raised at the 1996 Atlanta Paralympics, reported the Sydney Morning Herald on Thursday.

The daily reported that a majority of the Olympic sponsors have thrown their support behind the Paralympic Games. The level of support however only amounts to a small fraction of the US$1.63 billion they spent on the 2000 Sydney Olympic Games.

"Compared to the Olympics, the Paralympics is still a developing brand for sponsors because it is a much younger event and is not as well known. I don't think you can really compare the Paralympics to the Olympics," said Yanti Sujatna Paralympic Games sponsorship manager.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU TO BE DESIGNATED "TRIAL PORT" FOR SHIPPING LINKS WITH M'LAND

TEXT.P: Offshore Penghu Island, located in the Taiwan Strait, will be designated as the "trial port" for Taiwan in conducting direct shipping links with mainland China, said the head of the Mainland Affairs Council on Thursday.

Reporting at the Legislative Yuan on the feasibility of the so-called "mini three links" with mainland China, MAC chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said the council is planning to allow Penghu to conduct direct shipping links with mainland Chinese seaports for "special purposes" on a "case-by-case" basis.

The "mini three links" that the MAC is working on implementing refers to direct trade, transportation, and communications between the ROC-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and seaports in mainland China.

Under the scheme, which is still in the planning stage, Tsai said Penghu could become a distributing point for gravel from mainland China heading for Taiwan; a mid-way stop for cross-strait cultural activity exchanges, including religious pilgrimages; a venue for private cross-strait training activities or meetings; a location to be developed into a computer software industrial park; or a base where cross-strait fishing cooperation can be developed.

In the long run, Tsai added, the MAC envisages the Penghu development plan as part of the "direct three links" project -- direct trade, transportation, and communications links between Taiwan and mainland China -- with Penghu eventually becoming a "special economic zone" to conduct normal direct business and trade exchanges with mainland China while simultaneously being developed into an international tourism, vacation, and meeting center.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR WANTS GOV'T TO ALLOW CROSS-STRAIT CITY-LEVEL EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Thursday expressed the hope that the government will ease its regulations and allow city-to-city exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Ma said that if the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council changes related regulations, and the timing is right, he may be able to visit mainland China next year.

Ma noted that under current regulations, city and county chiefs are allowed to go to the mainland to attend international meetings or cultural activities sponsored by international organizations, noting that Hsinchu Mayor Tsai Jen-chien went to the mainland along this line.

Tsai, who left for Nanjing Wednesday, will attend a conference of chief administrators of major science and technology cities around the world. Hsinchu, the location of Taiwan's first science-based industrial park, is home to thousands of high-technology companies.

Ma said that current regulations do not allow for city-to-city exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, and he expressed the hope that the MAC will speed up the relaxation of the prohibition against such exchanges.
Ma also said that he will mainly visit other Asian countries, and that he would not rule out traveling to any place as long as such trips are in line with regulations and his time allows for it.
On whether he will meet with Tung Chee-hwa, chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, Ma only said that he would not seek deliberately to meet Tung or anyone else.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN WILLING TO MEET WITH PRESIDENT NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan is willing to meet with President Chen Shui-bian next week to exchange views on how to resolve Taiwan's pressing political and economic problems.
Presidential Secretary-General You Shi-kun visited KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng Thursday, in order to pave the way for Chen's meeting with Lien.
You conveyed Chen's wish to visit Lien within one week, and Lin told You that Lien is willing to meet with Chen at the Presidential Office. They then agreed to fix the date next week.

Chen has started a series of meetings with leaders of major opposition parties. He is to meet with People First Party Chairman James Soong Thursday night, and will meet with New Party chief Hau Lun-pin Saturday.
The KMT's Lin told the media that Chen's scheduled meetings with Soong and Hau would not create any pressure for the KMT.
He stressed that if the president is sincere and his meeting with Lien will be constructive for the country's development and the people's welfare, the KMT will give him a proper response.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 20, or the 22nd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1818: Britain and the United States establish a border across the 49th Parallel.
1827: The Battle of Navarino in Greece comes to an end as Britain, France, and Russian fleets annihilate the Turkish and Egyptian fleets.
1890: Sir Richard Burton, British explorer, soldier, diplomat, and scholar, dies of a heart attack in Trieste at the age of 69. He discovered Lake Tanganyika and translated the 16-volume "Arabian Nights".
1891: Sir James Chadwick, English physicist, is born. He won the 1935 Nobel Prize in physics for the discovery of the neutron.
1935: Mao Tse-tung and his Communist forces end their so-called "Long March" at Yenan in Shensi Province. On Oct. 10 1934, the main forces of the Communist Chinese troops fled their bases in Kiangsi Province to the northwest, launching the "Long March."
1935: Arthur Henderson, British politician and founder of the Labor Party, dies at the age of 72. He won the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize for his contribution as president of the World Disarmament Conference.
1943: The Republic of China signs a new Sino-Belgium Treaty and a new Sino-Luxembourg Treaty in Chungking.
1943: The United Nations War Crimes Commission is formed.
1944: General Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with 250,000 troops to fulfill the promise to return he made when his forces retreated from the Japanese.
1949: Britain recognizes the People's Republic of China under Mao Tse-tung.
1950: The ruling Kuomintang sets up the Taiwan Province Reform Commission with Nieh Wen-ya serving as its chairman.
1951: Governor Wu Kuo-chen of Taiwan presides over a ceremony marking the completion of the Akungtien Reservoir in Kaohsiung County, in southern Taiwan.
1955: President Chiang Kai-shek permits self-renewal for General Sun Li-jen, former commander-in-chief of the ROC Army, without taking disciplinary action against him after an investigation commission submitted a report on a sedition case.
1957: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang.
1962 Some 20,000 Chinese troops launch an offensive on Indian military posts along the Himalayan border.
1964: Herbert C. Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, dies at the age of 90. After the stock market crash of 1929, he was unwilling to finance employment through federal intervention and lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
1967: Shigeru Yoshida, Japanese prime minister who dominated Japanese politics in the immediate post-war period, dies.
1968: Jackie Kennedy, widow of late U.S. President John F. Kennedy, marries multi-millionaire Aristotle Onassis.
1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts at improving relations between communist and non-communist nations.
1973: Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the Sydney Opera House in Australia.
1973: Yang Liang-kung, new president of the Examination Yuan, assumes office, while Liu Chi-hung takes office as vice president.
1975: The Fourth Pan Pacific Conference on Regional Science opens in Taipei with more than 100 experts from Japan, the United States, Singapore, and the ROC attending.
1982: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a soccer match in Moscow. A total of 340 are killed.
1999: The government of the Republic of China extends its congratulations to Indonesian President-elect Abdurrahman Wahid for his election victory. Confucius lesson of the day: "Among the means for the regeneration of mankind, those made with noise and show are of the least importance."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO U.S. HIT NEW RECORD HIGH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to the United States hit a new single-month record high in August, following steady monthly increases in this sector since May this year, said sources from the U.S. Department of Commerce on Thursday.
Taiwan exported US$3.69 billion worth of products to the United States in August, representing an increase of 19.4 percent over the previous August's total.
According to the DOC, Taiwan exports to the United States have hit a new record high every month since May, with August's figure being US$120 million higher than that of July.

Cumulatively, Taiwan's exports to the United States in the first eight months of this year totaled US$26.45 billion, for a remarkable increase of US$3.67 billion over the total for the same period the previous year, the latest DOC tallies showed.

With the Taiwan currency continuing to depreciate against the U.S. dollar over the past several months to the benefit of Taiwan's exporters, the island's total annual exports to the United States for 2000 are expected to break the US$40 billion mark, representing a new high in the history of two-way trade between the two countries.
Meanwhile, according to the DOC statistics, Taiwan imported US$2.26 billion worth of commodities from the United States in August, up 36.5 percent over the total for the corresponding month in 1999.

Taiwan imports from the United States in the January to August period amounted to US$16.47 billion, up a noticeable 35.8 percent over the amount for the same period the previous year, the DOC tallies showed.

While both Taiwan's export and import trade with the United States have surged over the past several months, its trade surplus with America has diminished at the same time. In the first eight months of this year, Taiwan's surplus with the United States totaled US$9.98 billion, down 7.8 percent from that of the same period in the previous year.
According to the DOC figures, Taiwan is currently the United States' seventh largest trading partner, its seventh largest import and export market, and its sixth largest source of trade deficit.

Two-way trade between the two countries totaled US$36.97 billion in the first seven months of this year, up 22.6 percent over the figure for the corresponding period a year earlier, the DOC tallies showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN FREIGHTER RAMS PIER IN KAOHSIUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: A South Korean freighter rammed into the wall of a pier in Kaohsiung Harbor, causing a big hole in the pier's wall and damaging the bow of the ship, sources from the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau reported Friday.
Nobody aboard the 51,836-ton ship nor anyone working at the port was hurt, although maritime police and relevant port personnel are investigating the accident.
The Hyundai Emperor was trying to anchor at pier 74 at around 8 a.m. when it ran into the pier wall.

The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau authorities called in divers to inspect the pier from below the water's surface to gain a better understanding of the accident. They have asked Hyundai for a formal maritime report concerning the accident and also for appropriate compensation.
The Hyundai Emperor, which draws nine feet of water, was scheduled to leave Kaohsiung Harbor at 3 p.m. Friday after unloading and loading cargo, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC `CONCERNED' ABOUT U.S. PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said Friday it is concerned about the results of the U.S. presidential election scheduled for Nov. 7.
A senior MAC official, who preferred anonymity, said the council is keeping close watch on the latest development in the U.S. presidential campaign.
The official said that if Democratic Party candidate Al Gore wins, he is expected to continue incumbent U.S. President Bill Clinton's policy on Taiwan-mainland China relations.

According to the official, the Clinton administration's policy on relations across the Taiwan Strait is characterized by four critical elements -- the traditional U.S. "one China" policy, a peaceful solution to the cross-strait dispute, encouraging dialogue between the two sides and the consent of the people of Taiwan to any final settlement of Taiwan Strait issues.
If Republican Party candidate George W. Bush emerges as the victor, the official said, his cross-strait policy may be more favorable to Taiwan.

Judging from his remarks made in the course of the campaign, the official said, Bush supports Taiwan's inclusion in the U.S.-proposed theater missile defense (TMD) system and is likely to throw his weight behind the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, which is pending congressional approval.
Nevertheless, the official noted that it remains to be seen whether Bush will uphold his friendly attitude toward Taiwan if he actually wins the presidency.

For one thing, the official said, many of Bush's relatives have invested in mainland China. Moreover, he went on, the influence of the executive branch and Congress can also affect Bush's cross-strait policy.

While Gore will continue Clinton's current engagement policy with mainland China if he takes the helm of the White House, the official said, he is more likely to adopt decisive measures to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and East Asia.

However, the official refrained from making any forecast concerning the question of whether Gore will encourage Taipei to take more active steps to cope with issues related to the opening of direct cross-strait trade, mail and transportation links, commonly known as the "three links."
He also said Gore is more supportive of U.S. involvement in cross-strait issues, while Bush would prefer to see less U.S. involvement in cross-strait engagement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIRLINES SCRAMBLING TO PROFIT OVER 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: Major domestic airlines in Taiwan are scrambling to get a share of the potentially lucrative air transport market across the Taiwan Strait as Taiwan's steps to open "mini three links" with mainland China accelerate.

TransAsia Airways and UNI Airlines have decided to increase their flights from Taiwan proper to the offshore island of Kinmen from Nov. 1, while Far East Air Transport plans to operate additional flights from Dec. 1 in the belief that direct trade, mail and transportation links between the ROC-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and selected mainland Chinese port cities, commonly known as the "mini three links," will kick off at the end of the year at the earliest.

TransAsia authorities foresee that once the "mini three links" take effect, air transport of passengers and cargo between Kinmen, Matsu and Taiwan will increase by leaps and bounds as processed products originating from mainland China will be legally allowed to enter Taiwan via the offshore islands.

TransAsia has decided to increase one daily round-trip flight to its Taipei-Kinmen route, giving it three such flights a day, while its Kaohsiung-Kinmen round-trip flights will remain unchanged at three per day.

UNI Airlines will also provide three Taipei-Kinmen round-trip flights daily, an increase of one, while the number of its Kaohsiung-Kinmen daily round-trip flights will increase from one to two from Nov. 1.
Far East Air Transport also plans to add one daily round-trip flight on its Taipei-Kinmen route, from Dec. 1.
Currently, only UNI Airlines operates five round-trip flights and five one-way flights between Taipei and Matsu daily and has no plans for an increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT SAYS BEIJING SHOULD ADOPT "SUNSHINE POLICY"

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian has urged Communist China to stop threatening Taiwan and instead resume the long suspended cross-strait dialogue to resolve problems between the two sides, saying Beijing should adopt a "sunshine policy" to win over the people of Taiwan.

Mr. Chen was referring to the reconciliatory approach taken by South Korean President Kim Dae-jung in his efforts to seek greater contact with North Korea as well as to ease tensions between the two sides.

The ROC president told Voice of America in an interview Wednesday that Mainland China's saber-rattling only arouses antipathy among the people of Taiwan and further widens the gap between the two sides.

Taiwan has no intention of entering an arms race with the mainland, but the government will continue to increase its arms purchases to prevent a war across the Taiwan Straits and to defend the island if necessary, said Mr. Chen.

A few days after Beijing published a defense white paper that again threatens an invasion of Taiwan if the island moves toward independence, Mr. Chen repeated comments he made in his May 20 inaugural speech, saying as long as he is president, and as long as mainland China does not use military force against Taiwan, he will not declare Taiwan's independence.

But the president emphasized that the people of Taiwan do not want to reunify with the mainland under Beijing's terms, adding that the two sides should sit down and work together to solve the problem of "one China in the future."

He also said he is convinced that the leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Straits have the wisdom and creativity to work out, based on the principles of democracy and equality, a new definition of "one China" that is acceptable to everyone.
Communist China's leadership has said it is willing to resume a dialogue with Taiwan only if the latter's leaders embrace Beijing's "one China" principle.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.182 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$32.143.
The local currency opened at NT$32.295 and was traded between NT$32.121 and NT$32.310.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$746 million

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER EXPORT ORDERS HIT NEW SINGLE-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export trade has continued to gain momentum over the past several months and export orders posted a record high in September, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Friday.

The value of export orders received in September amounted to US$14.32 billion, marking a single-month high in Taiwan's foreign trade history, thanks to a remarkable increase in orders from the United States and Hong Kong as a result of Washington's granting Permanent Normal Trade Relation status to mainland China, the MOEA officials said.
The September figure was a whopping increase of 33.33 percent over the corresponding month of the previous year and was also a record in terms of month-on-month growth, the officials noted.

Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, attributed the brisk performance in particular to sales of metal, electronics, electronic engineering, information technology and telecommunications products.
Even the plastics, rubber and textile sectors, which showed relatively slower growth than the metal, electronics and telecommunications products, posted evident growth in export orders, Chang noted.

According to MOEA tallies, Taiwan received US$114.50 billion-worth of export orders in the first nine months of this year, up 22.6 percent, or US$21.3 billion, over the corresponding period of the previous year.

The United States continued to be the major source of Taiwan's export orders in September, placing a record US$4.66 billion-worth of orders, while Hong Kong followed with orders worth US$2.69 billion, also a single-month record.
Orders from Japan totaled US$1.47 billion, up a whopping 44.52 percent from the August figure, while orders from Europe amounted to US$2.42 billion, up 18.33 percent.

In related news, Taiwan Institute of Economic Research President Wu Rong-yi said Taiwan's economic and industrial structures are fundamentally healthy and that there is no justifiable reasons for Taiwan stock market investors "spooking themselves."

Wu said the recent plummet in the domestic bourse should not be a cause for Taiwan investors to panic and trigger a crisis of confidence in the government and he stressed that Taiwan is still economically strong.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CHINA POLICY TO REMAIN CONSISTENT: U.S. SECURITY ADVISER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: White House National Security Adviser Sandy Berger said Thursday that U.S. policy toward mainland China should remain "very similar" under a new administration because the current policy receives widespread support from both Democrats and Republicans.

During a speech on foreign policy at Georgetown University in Washington, Berger said: "With China, our challenge has been to steer between the extremes of uncritical engagement and untenable confrontation. That balance has helped maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait."

Fielding questions from reporters after the speech, Berger reiterated Washington's "one China" policy and stressed that the Taiwan issue must be resolved through cross-strait dialogue and via peaceful means.

He went on to say that mainland China's recent defense white paper, which again warned Taiwan against declaring independence or indefinitely delaying reunification, did not differ much from its previous two white papers.
"We encourage both sides to exercise creativity, restraint, and flexibility to engage in direct dialogue, in which we hope that they can ultimately resolve their differences in the future," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AEROSPACE COMPANY RECEIVES ORDERS FOR HELICOPTER PARTS

TEXT.P: Aerospace Industrial Development Corporation (AIDC), Taiwan's only aerospace manufacturer, announced Friday that it has recently received orders for seven S-92 helicopter cockpit assemblies from U.S.-based Sikorsky Aircraft Corp.

Cougar Helicopter, an offshore oil operator based in eastern Canada, has ordered the helicopters and AIDC is scheduled to deliver the first cockpit to Connecticut-based Sikorsky by June 2001 for final assembly.

AIDC, a member of the international team of companies that developed the new Sikorsky medium-lift helicopter, is in charge of producing the cockpit section, which includes electrical harnesses, flight controls, hydraulic lines and environmental controls.
The Central Taiwan-based company also participated in the development of the S-92's twin CT7-8 turboshaft engines with U.S.-based General Electric.

Currently in development, the 20-passenger S-92 is based on U.S. Army Black Hawk and U.S. Navy Seahawk helicopters and will serve a variety of military and civilian uses, including passenger, cargo, aeromedical, search and rescue, resource development, offshore oil, executive transport, and news media applications.

AIDC, a state-run enterprise that produced Taiwan's Indigenous Defense Fighters, signed an aerospace agreement with Sikorsky in January 1996 to manufacture the cockpit components, making up 6.25 percent of the helicopter's total value. It completed the delivery of five development model cockpits in June this year.
Once certified, which is expected in 2002, an estimated 224 helicopters can be sold in six years globally, according to Sikorsky.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK LOWERS ROC ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST TO 6.41%

TEXT.P: The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER) said Friday it has lowered its forecast of Taiwan's economic growth rate for 2000 to 6.41 percent for a combination of factors.
This was the second time that the private economic think tank has adjusted downward its forecast of Taiwan's 2000 economic growth rate.
The CHIER first predicted this year's Taiwan economic growth rate at 6.66 percent in April, but lowered its forecast slightly to 6.6 percent in July.

The institute said it now decides to further lower its forecast because of several major factors -- a drastic stock market plunge, slow progress in reconstruction in areas hard-hit by the devastating earthquake that rattled the island on Sept. 21, 1999, uncertainty about the fate of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant, an exodus of local industries, and a decrease in trade surplus due to increased imports.

The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) and the Directorate-General Budget, Accounting and Statistics echoed the CHIER's view, saying they also plan to make downward adjustments of their forecasts of this year's economic growth rate.
CEPD Chairman Chen Po-chih was quoted as having said that the council may lower its growth rate forecast to 6.4 percent from original 6.57 percent.

According to the Chung-Hua institute, Taiwan's economic performance in the second half of this year was not as brilliant as that in the first half. The institute estimated the economic growth rates for the third and fourth quarters at 6.44 percent and 5.94 percent, respectively.

CHIER researchers said the recent stock market fall has affected private consumption. They predicted that the annual growth rate for private consumer spending will be lower than 6 percent for the second half of the year.

While private investment increased by more than 20 percent in the first half of this year, investments by both the government and state-owned companies registered double-digit declines. As a result, the institute said, the annual growth rate of domestic investment will be only about 7.5 percent.

On the foreign trade front, customs tallies show that exports remained bullish in the third quarter of the year and that export orders received by local manufacturers also continued growing. Nevertheless, imports have also expanded substantially, which has narrowed the growth in trade surplus. Slower growth in trade surplus would cut the trade sector's contribution to economic growth, CHIER researchers said.
They pointed out that this year's domestic economy is characterized by robust growth in substantive industrial production but lackluster performance in the financial sector.

As for next year's economic prospects, the CHIER said uncertainty in the global economy may have an adverse impact on the Taiwan economy. As Taiwan's foreign trade, investment and consumer spending may not grow as fast as this year in 2001, the institute said the island's 2001 economic growth rate is expected to stand at 6.1 percent or even lower.

The institute further said although domestic gasoline prices have risen steadily, the hike has only affected wholesale prices and has not significantly pushed up consumer prices. As a result, the institute said this year's inflation rate will remain low at about 1.41 percent. But the inflation rate may reach 2.14 percent next year.

Meanwhile, the institute predicted that the New Taiwan dollar's exchange rate will remain at an average of NT$31.65 against the U.S. dollar this year, but may depreciate to NT$32.02 against the greenback next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRESENTS ADVISER CERTIFICATE TO FORMER PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presented Friday a "presidential senior adviser certificate" to former Premier Tang Fei.

Tang, who stepped down Oct. 3 for health reasons after it became clear that Chen did not support his idea of continuing the construction of a controversial nuclear power plant, accepted Chen's offer to serve as one of the president's senior advisers without pay, which is mainly a ceremonial post awarded to elder statesmen.
Chen and his secretary-general, Yu Shyi-kun, visited Tang at his home in Taipei and chatted with him for about 30 minutes.
Although the president has recruited scores of advisers, he has never presented the certificate personally before, Yu said afterward.
During their meeting, Chen heaped praise on Tang and expressed thanks for his assistance when he was in need, according to Yu.
Chen also wished Tang a speedy recovery and expressed hope that he will be able to serve the country again, said Yu.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR CALLS FOR `POLICY FREEZE' TO REVIVE PUBLIC CONFIDENCE

TEXT.P: A local financial expert urged the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government Friday to stop presenting any new policy initiatives in order to revive public confidence and maintain domestic stability.

Tseng Chu-wei, a National Chengchi University finance professor, made the call at a seminar on current domestic financial and economic problems sponsored by an opposition Kuomintang-financed think tank.
Tseng said many local people originally expected the new DPP government to come up with fresh policy proposals with innovative thinking.

"However, five months after the inauguration of the island's first DPP-led government, many people are disappointed as the new government still fails to articulate its policies on some sensitive issues, such as relations across the Taiwan Strait and the fate of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project," Tseng noted.

Incoherence and inconsistency of various government agencies' stances on these thorny issues have sparked a crisis of economic and political confidence and triggered a drastic plunge in the local stock market, Tseng said.

"The phenomenon indicates that the new government is not yet ready to cope with those contentious issues," Tseng said, adding that since the government has not had fresh ideas and sufficient capabilities to deal with the issues, it should suspend its presentation of premature policy proposals that are based on the DPP's traditional ideology.

Tseng said the proposed scrapping of the fourth nuclear power plant in terms of the DPP's anti-nuclear stance and the refusal to acknowledge the so-called "1992 consensus" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait based on the DPP's pro-independence platform have deepened public misgivings about the Republic of China's future prospects.

Against this background, Tseng said, the minority DPP government should freeze its presentation of new policy initiatives until it has managed to craft out well-designed, coherent and feasible proposals on major policy issues based on new thinking, not old ideology.

Moreover, Tseng also urged the DPP government to adopt effective measures to stabilize the foreign exchange market. Noting that a dramatic fall in the stock market often would have an adverse impact on the currency market, Tseng said the government should not let the New Taiwan dollar's exchange rate fluctuate too drastically to affect overall financial and economic stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL LEGISLATOR EXPOSES GROUP TRADING IN HUMAN ORGANS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan legislator exposed an organ trading group Friday that advertises for customers and urged people not to fall prey to the group, which masquerades as an official organization.

Legislator Chiang Yi-wen said in a press conference that a local group took out advertisements in the name of the Organ Donation Association (ODA) of the Republic of China that said patients requiring transplants need no longer wait and that a liver could be had for between NT$500,000 (US$15,625) and NT$800,000, while a kidney would cost between NT$1.5 million and NT$2 million.

Joyce Hsu, secretary-general of the ODA, said the advertisement plagiarized contents of ODA periodicals in an attempt to cheat people in need. She lodged the strongest possible protest and sued the group.

Hsu indicated that while there are about 5,000 people in Taiwan awaiting organ transplants each year, only around 200 actually receive transplants because regulations require that organs can only be harvested when the donors are recognized as brain dead, while transplants from living people must be confined to relations such as spouses, parents, children, grandparents, grandchildren, brothers, sisters and their children.

Tan Kai-yuan, director of the Bureau of Medical Affairs under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, said trading in human organs is prohibited in Taiwan, and that violators can be fined NT$450,000. He added that the number of hospitals permitted to carry out transplants is also limited, and that violators face a fine of NT$600,000, while the doctor's license can be revoked for a year.
Chiang said she is promoting a revision of the regulations in an attempt to resolve the bureaucratic difficulties surrounding organ transplants.

However, she expressed concern about recent reports of a debt-ridden individual using the Internet to find a buyer for one of his kidneys and said it is even more alarming that there are already illegal groups trading in human organs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING MUST REACH 'ONE CHINA' CONCESSION: LEE KUAN YEW
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By J.J. Hwang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew said Thursday that no breakthrough is possible for Taipei and Beijing unless the gap in their standpoints on the outcome of a 1992 meeting is shortened.

Lee told the Council on Foreign Relations, a New York-based think tank, that mainland China insists a "one China" consensus was reached in 1992, while Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian believes that both sides only found a "1992 spirit."
"If there is no concession at all to 'one China,' I think there is no way out for them," he said, adding that a "very wide gulf" still exists between Taipei and Beijing.

The former Singaporean prime minister went on to say that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin had told him during his June visit to Beijing that mainland China does not want to use force against Taiwan, but no mainland Chinese leader could remain safe and sound if he were to "lose" Taiwan during his term in office.
Therefore, if mainland China has no other choice, it will abandon ongoing efforts at domestic economic modernization and use force against Taiwan under the principle of "one China," Lee added.
The next U.S. president will have to face the thorny cross-strait issues, he pointed out.
Lee stressed that mainland China will play a critical role in Asia, and its membership in the World Trade Organization will be beneficial to the development of the entire Asia Pacific region.

Lee said that mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji, who has declared that he is confident of being able to solve mainland China's financial problems, must eliminate all the obstacles to his nation's WTO accession during the next two to three years -- otherwise, Zhu's successor will not be as bold in implementing economic reform as he is.

Regarding North and South Korea, Lee predicted that they will not be reunified in the immediate or even medium term because it would not be in either country's national interest. He added that mainland China would not welcome unification of the Korean peninsula, as it would mean losing a buffer state.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZILAND REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR ROC'S U.N. BID

TEXT.P: Swaziland, one of Taiwan's African allies, has reaffirmed its support for the Republic of China's bid for membership of the United Nations and other international organizations, a senior ROC Foreign Ministry official said Friday.

Tao Wen-lung, director-general of the Department of African Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), made the statement the day after the end of the three-day Sixth ROC-Swazi Meeting on Economic and Technical Cooperation in Taipei.

Tao said that in addition to exchanging views on economic and trade information between the two countries, the ROC promised to offer its assistance to Swaziland under the framework of current cooperation agreements.

Swazi Minister of Economic Planning Vincent Sithole headed the Swazi delegation to the meeting. During their stay in Taipei, Sithole and his entourage called on President Chen Shui-bian and officials at MOFA, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the China External Trade Development Council.

The ROC-Swazi Meeting on Economic and Technical Cooperation was inaugurated in 1995 to discuss and review the implementation of economic cooperation projects between the two countries and the annual meeting takes place alternately in Taipei and Mbalane.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO MEET NEW PARTY LEADER SATURDAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will meet with opposition New Party leaders Saturday for wide-ranging talks as part of his efforts to promote inter-party reconciliation and cooperation, the Presidential Office announced Friday.

President Chen will meet with Hao Lung-pin, convener of the pro-unification New Party's National Campaign and Development Commission, at the Taipei Guest House, the Presidential Office said, adding that the meeting will start at 10 a.m.
New Party Secretary-General Lee Ping-nan and Lai Shih-pao, the party's whip in the Legislative Yuan, will also take part in the meeting.

Hao, also a legislator, said he and his colleagues will exchange views with President Chen, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, on a broad range of issues, including relations across the Taiwan Strait, current stock market woes, a crisis of economic confidence and other topics related to national development and people's well-being.

It will be the second time that President Chen has met with leaders of a major local political party to signify his sincerity to promote domestic political harmony and inter-party cooperation. Chen held closed-door talks with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong Thursday night. Chen called his meeting with Soong "a great leap" for Taiwan's democratic development.

As the DPP controls only about one-third of the Legislative Yuan seats, Chen has pitched for an end to inter-party squabbles and an early start of inter-party cooperation since his inauguration in May.

Due to complex reasons, a Chen-proposed roundtable meeting of top leaders of major parties has long remained on the drawing board. As a result, Chen said last week he will pay separate visits to PFP Chairman Soong, main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and New Party leaders to show his determination to forge inter-party rapprochement. KMT Chairman Lien, also a former vice president, has tentatively agreed to meet Chen next week. The exact time, venue and agenda for the much-anticipated Chen-Lien meeting have yet to be worked out.

KMT spokesman Jason Hu said the KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20 and now still controls a majority in the legislature, hopes that the Chen-Lien meeting will focus on substantive issues and achieve concrete results, not just publicity effects.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC RAISES FUEL PRICES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. announced Friday that it will raise its prices for various kinds of fuel by an average of 4.78 percent, effective the same day.

Officials of the firm said the price hike was necessary because of the continuing high price of crude oil in the international market, as well as the continued devaluation of the new Taiwan dollar against the greenback.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HAILS CHEN-SOONG MEETING

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Friday hailed Thursday night's meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, and described it as a success.
Asked whose performance during the talk was better, Chang said diplomatically that he was very much impressed by the performance of both men.
The premier made these remarks while answering questions raised by Kuomintang Legislator Chin Hui-chu at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session.

Chang said that he was especially pleased that the long-expected meeting had finally taken place, because he personally sent the invitation to Soong in his former capacity as secretary general to the president.

On Soong's "I am Taiwanese and also a Chinese" statement, Chang replied that his ancestors indeed came from Fujian province, and he is a citizen of the Republic of China and is also a Taiwanese. He described the Soong's declaration as "very good".
The premier said that he agrees with Soong's assertion that ideological matters should not be brought into economic and financial policies.
Chang also said that the government should uphold the freedom of the press.

In answering questions raised by KMT Legislators Chen Ming-wen, Chang Fu-hsing and Hou Hui-hsien about reform of the statutes regulating the structure of local governments, Chang said that his policies were being carried out to benefit all the people of the nation, and were not aimed at helping any specific political party.
In his administrative report presented to the Legislative Yuan, Chang called on political parties to cooperate each other in place of confrontation.
But KMT legislators said that they suspect the reform of local government statutes is really just a way to weaken the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER'S INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION UP AN ANNUAL 16.49%

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production increased by 16.49 percent in September over the same month last year, but the construction industry suffered a decrease of 38.9 percent, according to statistics from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

MOEA officials indicated Friday that the large annual growth in September's industrial production was partly due to unusually low production caused by the devastating earthquake that hit Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, which caused property damage and power blackouts that affected industrial output.
Of September's industrial production, the manufacturing sector increased by 19.18 percent thanks to booming exports, the officials said.
However, the officials added, internal demand was down in September, which can be seen by the declining construction industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND TOURISTS MAY VISIT TAIWAN STARTING NEXT JUNE: ROC PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said at a legislative interpellation session Friday that a limited number of mainland Chinese tourists may be allowed to visit Taiwan on a trial basis after June of next year.

During the same session, Lin Wen-lang, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, asked Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen why the government still does not allow mainland Chinese tourists to enter Taiwan and also prohibits mainland Chinese from investing in the island when the Taiwan public has been visiting and investing in mainland China for years.

Following next January's scheduled opening of the three "mini-direct links" -- trade, postal, and transport links -- between Taiwan's outlying islands and mainland China, which will allow for a maximum of 1,700 mainland visitors per day, Chang said that the next step will be to allow mainland tourists to visit Taiwan-proper, abiding by the same limitations.

Tsai responded to Lin's claims that Taiwan tourists have been visiting mainland China for nearly 10 years by saying that they actually travel there in the name of visiting relatives or inspecting business operations. The government has not actually allowed the Taiwan public to go to mainland China as tourists, she added.

Tsai said that because Taiwan will soon enter the World Trade Organization along with mainland China, the government will give priority to allowing mainland Chinese investment in Taiwan's service industry. Meanwhile, she added that a special task force will look into the feasibility of allowing mainland Chinese to invest in the stock market and manufacturing.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 TAIWAN TRAWLERS STILL BEING DETAINED BY ARGENTINE AUTHORITIES

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan trawlers detained by Argentine authorities are still awaiting a judicial decision, an official of the Fisheries Department under the Council of Agriculture said on Friday.

The three detained trawlers are the Houtsun 101, Huaching 707 and Chinchuanhsing. Crew members of one such vessel, the Houtsun 101, have already been deported to Taiwan, while its captain, Yen Wen-chien, is expected to be released soon. Crew members of the other two detained trawlers were still detained in Argentina, the official said.

More than 100 Taiwan vessels have fished for squid in waters near the Falkland Islands and the Argentine waters this year, but the three trawlers were detained by Argentine coastal guard cutters for allegedly poaching within 200-nautical miles of the nation's coast, which it claims as its economic territory.

When the Houtsun 101 sank while being escorted to a port in southern Argentina, its crewmembers were rescued and sent back to Taiwan, while skipper Yen Wen-chien was detained and is now awaiting the judicial process.
The other detained trawlers and their crewmembers are also still awaiting a judicial decision on the matter by the Argentine authorities, the official said.

With the squid season in the southern Atlantic fast approaching, the official called on local trawler owners to equip their ships with satellite navigation systems so as to avoid entering into the exclusive economic territory of Argentina and the Falkland Islands. A trawler should report its position every day it is operating in that area, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLOMON APOLOGIZES TO TAIWAN FOR THURSDAY STATEMENT

TEXT.P: The day after blaming Taiwan for a rift in bilateral ties, the Solomon Islands apologized to Taipei Friday, and its prime minister announced a plan to visit Taiwan late this month.

In a press release issued Friday by the Solomon government in Honiara, Edward Hunuehu, a special adviser to Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare said that Thursday's press release criticizing Taipei for not extending sufficient aid to the war-ravaged Pacific island was released without the prime minister's approval.
He apologized for the disturbance it caused in Taipei, and reconfirmed that the relationship between the two countries remains unchanged.
Hunuehu also said that Sogavare has accepted an invitation delivered by Republic of China Ambassador P. Y. Teng to visit Taipei to strengthen cooperation between the two countries.
ROC Foreign Ministry officials, who expressed outrage at Thursday's statement from the Solomons and threatened to take "determined action," said they are looking forward to Sogavare's visit.

In the emotionally-charged statement of the previous day, the Solomon government blamed the diplomatic "inexperience" of Taipei's Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao for the scuffle between the two countries. It also expressed outrage at mass media reports that the tiny island state with a population of 360,000 was asking for US$200 million in aid from Taiwan.
Instead, the statement said, the Solomon has asked for no more than US$60 million.

Thursday's vaguely-worded statement also disclosed that the Solomons were exploring "the one China policy option", an apparent reference to investigating the possibility of opening diplomatic ties with Taiwan's rival Beijing, because of what it called Taiwan's breach of diplomatic protocol in its dealings with the Solomons.

In a bid to vindicate its claim to be a sovereign state rather than a province of People's Republic of China, Taiwan has engaged in a long-running battle with Beijing to court as much overseas support as possible. It often descends into a bidding war, with both Taipei and Beijing competing to offer generous aid to states -- mainly small ones -- in exchange for their support.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES OUTGOING AMBASSADOR OF THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian received the outgoing Dominican Republic Ambassador to Taipei Victor Sanchez and his wife at the Presidential Office Friday.
Chen, on behalf of the people and the government of the ROC, expressed respect and gratitude to Sanchez.

Chen eulogized Sanchez as an outstanding statesman, noting that he has been a parliamentarian and a university professor. In addition to achieving an excellent academic results, Sanchez served as a bridge between Taiwan and Santo Domingo during his three-and-a-half-year tenure in Taipei.
Sanchez also rendered his assistance during Chen's first overseas trip as president, when he attended the presidential inaugural of Dominican President Hipolito Mejia in July.

Chen said that he has instructed the foreign minister to confer the nation's highest honor on Sanchez for his contribution to promoting bilateral relations between the two countries over the past four years.
The president expressed his belief that relations between the two countries will be further cemented on the established basis.
He also asked Sanchez to convey his regards and thanks to former Dominican Republic President Leonel Ferandez for his contributions to relations between the two countries.
President Chen said that he had met with Ferandez several times, and said he hopes the former Dominican president will visit Taipei again next year.

President Chen also asked Sanchez to convey his regards to President Hipolito Mejia. President Chen described Mejia as the best friend of the people and government of the Republic of China. Mejia has visited Taiwan more than 20 times.
President Chen noted that Mejia has accepted his invitation to visit the ROC next March, and said that he will extend his warm welcome to Mejia on behalf of the people and the government of the ROC.

In return, Sanchez said that although he and his wife will leave Taiwan on Saturday, their daughter will get married in Taichung in a few days. The newly-wed couple will continue to stay in Taiwan, Sanchez noted, adding that his mind would always stay in Taiwan.
Sanchez was accompanied by Vice Foreign Minister Lin Chi-cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'THREE LINKS' WITH MAINLAND CHINA THE SOONER THE BETTER: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that he hopes the "three links" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can be opened soon, under the precondition that the ROC's national security is not threatened.

Chang added that the direct trade, mail and transportation links -- the so-called "three links" between Taiwan and mainland China -- involves many problems that cannot be controlled unilaterally by Taiwan, so he cannot set the timetable for opening the links.
Chang made the remark in response to questions from legislators, including Lee Ching-hua and Wu Ching-chih.

Lee said the Cabinet has decided that the country will open the direct three links between Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and selected mainland Chinese coastal cities early next year, commonly known as "mini three links," Lee has described the opening as a "small scale" measure that cannot meet the needs of both sides of Taiwan Strait.

Lee emphasized that establishing the "three links" is no longer a political chip for Taiwan, but is now a "necessity." He asked the premier to set a timetable for the opening of the "three links," as the people's welfare cannot wait.
Legislator Wu reiterated that the "three links" are the best hope for Taiwan's economy.

Chang, who just assumed the premiership, reiterated that the Cabinet has announced many measures that can help promote bilateral economic and trade exchanges with mainland China, and will review the "No haste, be patient" policy with respect to Taiwan investment in mainland China.

The premier said he also hopes for an early opening of the direct "three links" with mainland China, but this issue involves many problems such as the signing of trade and transportation agreements. He said he hopes the two sides can sit down to discuss this issue -- the sooner the better.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES DOMINICAN REPUBLIC OUTGOING ENVOY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu on Friday received the Dominican Republic outgoing Ambassador to Taipei Victor Sanchez and his wife.
The vice president hailed Sanchez for his contributions to promoting bilateral relations between the two countries during his tenure office in Taipei.
The ROC and the Dominican Republic have been maintaining deep-rooted and traditional relations and friendship, Lu said. "We treasure very much these relations and friendship."
Lu went on to say that the ROC possesses abundant of "soft power" -- especially in human rights, democracy, peace, love and high-tech.

The vice president said that Taiwan is willing to share its successful experience with its allied nations. She hoped that exchanges of all kinds and economic cooperation between the two countries will be further strengthened in the near future.

Lu told her visitors that she is planning to set up a Latin Plaza to exhibit products, cultural items and art works from Central American and Caribbean countries so as to promote cultural and economic exchanges between the ROC and its allies in those regions.
In return, Sanchez expressed his gratitude for the assistance the ROC rendered to him and his country during his three-and-a-half year tenure as ambassador in Taipei.
Sanchez was accompanied by his wife and Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan on his farewell visit to Lu at the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT ADVISES CURRENT PRESIDENT TO `HAVE PATIENCE'
DOC.DATELINE: Prague, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui reluctantly gave his embattled successor Chen Shui-bian a word of advice Friday -- "patience."

During breakfast at his hotel in Prague, Lee at first was reluctant to respond to reporters who asked him to give some advice to Chen, who was exactly five months into his presidency. He said that it was not proper for him to give advice in his capacity as a former president.

Lee eventually responded after the reporters praised him as having made major accomplishments early in his tenure despite what the reporter said was less power than Chen enjoys now. Lee slowly mouthed the word "patience" and urged Chen to look farther ahead. "Nursing the head when the head hurts and nursing the leg when the leg hurts" is not a good policy, the former president said.
Lee was in the Czech Republic to attend the fourth Forum 2000 conference on the roles of science, education, and religion in globalization. The forum ended Wednesday.

Lee said that he has not criticized the new administration after it took over the country's helm on May 20 because it is not right for a former president to criticize the incumbent. He went on to say that the current instability in Taiwan is a sign that the public is not yet used to the new government, and has nothing to do with the system.
Members of the new ruling Democratic Progressive Party have no experience at being government officials, he said, adding despite this, things should get better.
Lee and his Kuomintang ruled Taiwan for over five decades, and Chen's rise to power marked the first transition of power from the KMT to another party.

Lee went on to point out that Beijing has kept up a steady barrage of criticism at him when he actually did much to improve cross-strait relations. Present-day cross-strait exchanges and the US$90 billion Taiwan investors have poured into mainland China were made possible because of his policies, he added.
Therefore, he noted that one must look far ahead and not take criticism with an attitude of disgust.
He admitted that it has been hard work promoting political reform in Taiwan, but that thankfully its society was mature enough that there was no bloodshed or rioting during the changeover.

He went on to say that the policies carried out during his term in office were all developed together by various ministries, which took credit for the successes. This was a way to give them the morale to continue promoting their own policies, he said.

Handling technical issues when they come up also requires some attention, he said. For example, if the stock market is not performing well due to external factors, and the Cabinet and the National Security Council have fully discussed the situation, they do not need to make public their full intention because the effect of their measures will be evident later, he said.

Regarding the current impasse between Taipei and Beijing, Lee said that there is always a way out, and that Beijing's biggest problem right now is not the Taiwan issue but its own democratization. He urged Taiwan to look at the problems from Beijing's perspective and not always from its own.

After mainland China enters the World Trade Organization and a system for wireless communications is established, there won't be any more secrets, he said. He also noted that mainland Chinese leaders are worried about how the Communist Party will be able to control the populace of mainland China.

Taiwan and mainland China are just like water and oil -- "unmixable," he added. However, after WTO ascension brings about privatization and greater respect for private rights in mainland China, "opportunities will slowly increase," he said.

Meanwhile, Lee expressed his thanks for an invitation to the 12th annual conference of the Asian Outlook Forum scheduled to be held in Japan from Oct. 29 to Nov. 3. However, he could not just go as he pleases, he said, because of Beijing's political pressure on Japan.

Lee left Taipei last Saturday for Prague at the invitation of Czech President Vaclav Havel, who founded the Forum 2000 think tank together with a private Japanese foundation in 1997. Lee is scheduled to return to Taipei on Oct. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESDIENT CHEN CRITICIZES CONSTITUTION AS DEFICIENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian blamed Friday what he called the "deficiencies of the Constitution" for the difficulties facing his five-month old administration.

In a courtesy meeting with a group of Taiwanese-Americans at his office, Chen complained that under the Constitution, the Republic of China president can not veto bills as his U.S. counterpart might do -- nor can he dissolve the parliament as the president of France is empowered to do.
As the head of state, the U.S. president can steer national policy by vetoing bills passed by a Congress under the control of an opposition party.
And the French Constitution allows the president to call snap parliamentary elections as a last resort to rid themselves of a legislature dominated by another party, Chen said.

He lamented that none of these powers are granted to the president of the ROC by the nation's Constitution. The president can opt to dissolve a hostile Legislative Yuan only at the request of the premier and after a no-confidence motion against him has been passed by the Legislative Yuan.
This constitutional "deficiency" has placed his administration in limbo, because his Democratic Progressive Party is a minority in the Legislative Yuan, said Chen.
As a result, the agenda of the Chen Administration has often been blocked by the legislature since he took power in May.
The president said he is still confident that the constitutional obstacles can be overcome, but he didn't elaborate.
