DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 194.96 points to close at 5,599.74.
The bourse opened at 5,528.36 and fluctuated between 5,599.74 and 5,506.49 during trading.

A total of 2.49 billion stocks worth NT$77.06 billion (US$2.4 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 2.13 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$65.97 billion.

All eight major categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 4.8 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 3.5 percent, cement stocks at 3 percent, bank and insurance shares and textile issues, both at 2.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 2.2 percent, foodstuff stocks at 2 percent, and construction shares at 1.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 314 to 243, with 56 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 21, or the 23rd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Ferdinand Magellan, Portuguese navigator, and his expedition team are blown by storms into a strait that separates South America from Tierra del Fuego and other islands south of the continent and also connects the southern Atlantic and Pacific oceans. The strait now bears his name.
1727: The Ching court and Russia sign a new border treaty at the trading town of Kiakhta in Outer Mongolia.
1833: Alfred Nobel, Swedish industrialist and chemist who invented dynamite, is born. He founded the Nobel Prize to award to the world's leading scientists, artists, and peacemakers.
1879: Thomas Alva Edison, U.S. inventor, successfully tests an electric incandescent lamp with a carbonized filament at his New Jersey laboratory.
1934: Government troops capture Juichin, the Communist Chinese capital in Kiangsi. The main force of rebels is wiped out and the remaining ones flee to the northwest.
1938: Japanese troops finally capture the Chinese city of Canton after months of bombing.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, and Madame Chiang arrive in Taiwan for the first time for an inspection tour.
1950: Communist Chinese forces begin their occupation of Tibet.
1952: The first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference opens in Taipei.
1953: The first Overseas Chinese Day is celebrated in Taipei.
1954: The United States, Soviet Union, Britain, and France agree to end the Allied occupation of Germany.
1958: John Foster Dulles, U.S. secretary of state, arrives in Taipei for a visit. He pursued a policy of opposing the USSR largely through economic and military aid to U.S. allies.
1960: Queen Elizabeth II launches the HMS Dreadnought, Britain's first nuclear submarine.
1960: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Mali.
1964: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC decathlon champion who won the ROC's first Olympic silver medal in 1960, announces his retirement after winning fifth place at the Tokyo Olympics.
1973: The fifth general meeting of the Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations opens in Taipei with more than 400 delegates from 50 countries and areas participating.
1975: The second naphtha cracking plant of the Chinese Petroleum Corporation begins production.
1976: Ding Mou-shih, director general of the Government Information Office, returns from a week's visit to the Republic of Korea.
1979: Moshe Dayan, prime minister of Israel, resigns over the government's refusal to negotiate with Palestinians.
1979: Willy Brandt is elected chancellor of West Germany.
1987: Ho Ying-chin, a Chinese general who received the formal surrender of Japanese forces in China from General Okamura in Nanking on Sept. 9, 1945, dies at the age of 97.
1989: Tens of thousands of Hungarians demonstrate, demanding an end to communism on the anniversary of the 1956 uprising.
1994: The United States and North Korea sign a landmark deal under which Pyongyang is to freeze and then dismantle its nuclear program.
1999: Far East Transport Corp. begins flight operations between Taipei and Kota Kinabala in Malaysia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In another place in the Book of Song it is said, `His virtue is light as hair.' Still a hair is something material. `The workings of Almighty God have neither sound nor smell.' There is nothing higher than that."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices for Taiwan stock index futures were higher Saturday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) capitalization weighted index futures for November moved up 98 points to close at 5,660, with 9,111 contracts traded.
TAIEX index futures for December surged 226 points to finish at 5,680, with 106 contracts changing hands. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX index futures were set Saturday at 5,562 for November, 5,454 for December, 5,458 for next March, 5,549 for next June and 5,881 for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on TAIEX-listed electronics and financial shares, were also higher.
November TE futures moved up 18.1 points to close at 277.25, with 2,489 contract transactions, while December TE futures gained 16 points to finish at 278.5, with 67 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
November TF futures rose 9.6 points to close at 738.2, with 1,045 contract transactions, while December TF futures surged 26.4 points to finish at 741, with 19 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC SIGNS LETTER OF INTENT WITH ITALIAN SCI-TECH COMMITTEE
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Italy are posed to strengthen their sci-tech cooperation with the signing of a letter of intent between the highest-level sci-tech research organizations of the two countries Friday.

The letter was signed by Alberto Conti, director of the Department of International Affairs under the Italian National Research Council, and Hsu Tse-chih, head of the International Relations Department under the ROC's National Science Council.

Hsu and his entourage, who were accompanied by Huang Jui-lung, secretary of the ROC representative office in Italy, also exchanged views with their counterparts on sci-tech exchanges between the two countries.
The signing of the latter of intent is expected to further promote bilateral sci-tech exchanges, including training programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PREPARED TO NEGOTIATE WITH MAINLAND CHINA: ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he is willing to carry out dialogue with mainland China "on the existing foundations," but that Taipei and Beijing did not reach a consensus on the "one China" issue in 1992.

In an interview with a Chinese-language Singapore newspaper published Saturday, Chen added that Taiwan has completed all preparations and is ready to begin negotiations with mainland China at any time.

He went on to express his belief that the leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait have sufficient wisdom and creativity to find a mutually acceptable consensus and common ground between them so that they can handle the issue of "a future one China" under the existing foundations.

Chen explained that the scope of the so-called "existing foundations" is very broad and has different interpretations and definitions under different circumstances. Taking the 1992 meeting between the two sides as an example, he said that while the two sides did indeed discuss the issue of "one China," they did not reach consensus on the issue.

Taiwan does not accept Beijing's claim that the "one China principle" is a consensus between both sides and Beijing does not agree with Taipei's take of "one China, respective interpretations," he added.

However, he continued, despite each side sticking to its own version of the story, they must nevertheless have arrived at some kind of "spirit" that led to the historic 1993 meeting in Singapore between cross-strait negotiators. According to Chen, this so-called "1992 spirit" refers to dialogue, exchanges, and setting aside contentions.

Chen said: "My so-called `existing foundations' means that agreements we've had, I will acknowledge; consensus we've reached, I accept; tacit understandings we've agreed to, I'm not against. These existing foundations already exist, and this is something I cannot deny."

He reiterated that there is no official record showing that Taiwan and the mainland did reach a consensus in the 1992 meeting about the "one China" principle. However, he added, both sides definitely have more similiarities than differences and should be able to put aside and preserve minor differences while seeking common ground.

When questioned as to whether his previous comment that "unification is not the only option" means "Taiwan independence is another option," Chen said that unification, independence, or maintaining the status quo are all choices for the Taiwan people to make. He added that he cannot decide the people's future for them.

He reiterated the principles highlighted in his May 20 inauguration speech, where he promised that as long as mainland China has no intention of invading Taiwan, he will not announce Taiwan independence during his term in office, change the official name of the nation, call a referendum on unification versus independence to change the status quo, promote writing the controversial "special state-to-state theory" into the constitution, or abolish the National Unification Council and the Guidelines on National Unification.

In response to reports of Beijing's claim that Chen's unwillingness to admit being "Chinese" is the key reason the two sides cannot resume dialogue, Chen said that this kind of "word game" is meaningless because what most concerns the people of Taiwan -- regardless of whether they call themselves Taiwanese, Chinese, ethnic Chinese, or a citizen of the world -- is how Taipei and Beijing can interact with each other.

As for remarks made a day earlier in New York by Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew that no breakthrough is possible as far as cross-strait relations are concerned, Chen noted that unless there is concession over the "one China" issue, under the circumstances, it would not be easy to resume negotiations with Beijing before the U.S. presidential elections in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENATE PASSES HOUSE RESOLUTION ON U.N. MEMBERSHIP FOR ROC

TEXT.P: With only a few days left before the end of the current session of the U.S. Congress, the Senate passed Thursday by a unanimous vote a House concurrent resolution in support of Taiwan's participation in the United Nations.

"This is a victory for the people of Taiwan," said Rep. Bob Schaffer (R-Colo.), original sponsor of the resolution, upon learning of the Senate vote. He added that passing the widely supported resolution "once again restates our support and our commitment to the progress of Taiwan's democracy."

Schaffer, who along with 40 of his colleagues introduced House Concurrent Resolution 390 on July 22, wrote a letter to Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott (R-Miss.) Wednesday, requesting the resolution be placed on the Senate calendar to ensure its timely passage. On Oct. 3, the House passed the resolution by an overwhelming vote.

"Congressional support for Taiwan is solid. Taiwan has made enormous strides toward becoming a full democracy and it is unreasonable for the people of Taiwan to be excluded from full participation in international institutions due to threats from mainland China," said Schaffer.

The previous week, Schaffer and 10 other members of the House of Representatives also sent joint letters to Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Sen. Craig Thomas (R-Wyo.), chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs, urging the Senate to support Taiwan's participation in the United Nations and other international bodies such as the World Health Organization.

Formosan Association for Public Affairs President Chen Wen-yen noted that under the constant mainland Chinese threat of military force against Taiwan, the support by both houses of the U.S. Congress will enable Taiwan to seek assistance and support from the U.N. Security Council if necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CAPTURES PARALYMPIC GOLD IN SYDNEY

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei's Chiang Chih-chung broke the world record in men's Class 13 javelin Saturday with a throw of 57.28 meters to capture Taiwan's first gold medal at the Sydney Paralympics.
Canada took silver with 53.66 meters and mainland China took bronze with 52.41 meters.
Chiang's victory brought the Chinese Taipei medal tally to one gold and one bronze, the bronze earned Thursday by Lee Ching-chung in the men's judo competition.
"We are thrilled with Chiang's victory and believe we can win some more medals during the Paralympics," deputy team chief Chang Chao-shen said later in an interview.
"It was a great victory, not only for Chiang and his coach, but also for the whole team," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING INTERVENTION IN TAIWAN'S APEC REP ISSUE `REGRETTABLE'

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office of the Republic of China described as "regrettable" Saturday the fact that Beijing has once again interfered politically to stymie Taiwan's participation in international activities.

The statement was made in response to a report that Beijing is said to have voiced opposition to Taipei's plans to appoint Vice Premier Lai In-jaw as chief Chinese Taipei delegate at the informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum scheduled for next month in Brunei.

The Presidential Office Public Affairs Department said in a press release it is "deeply regrettable" that Beijing interference with the naming of the delegation members has now placed Brunei, the host country of the APEC summit meeting, in a difficult position.

It pointed out that President Chen Shui-bian appointed Lai to attend the summit on his behalf after a meeting with an emissary from Brunei on Oct. 13, on the grounds that Lai is the government's top decision-maker on business and financial affairs and is considered the best choice for the mission by all industrial, business and academic sectors in Taiwan.
The Brunei authorities immediately accepted and acknowledged Taipei's decision, according to the news release.
However, because of Beijing's intervention, Brunei contacted Taipei two days later to say that Beijing's opposition and Lai's selection put Brunei in an awkward position.

Officials from the Presidential Office Public Affairs Department said the ROC government understands Brunei's awkwardness, but will continue to negotiate with the Brunei authorities in the hope that a solution satisfactory to the host country and Taiwan can be worked out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CANCELS TRIP TO FRONTLINE ISLAND

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou canceled a scheduled trip to the frontline island of Matsu Saturday due to adverse weather conditions prohibiting aircraft landings.

Ma was to have visited the island, only a stone's throw from the coast of mainland China, to cheer on pediatricians and gynecologists that Taipei City hospitals have been sending on rotation since July to the island, which has poor medical resource.
Taipei City dermatologists, acupuncturists, cardiologists and ophthalmologists also provide medical assistance to the various provincial and township clinics on Matsu on an irregular basis.
Ma's itinerary was also to have included visits to the local seats of government, Matsu Defense Command and soldiers from Taipei serving on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALLING CURRENCY CAUSING TROUBLE FOR AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The Australian currency hit a new record low of 52 U.S. cents Friday, and economists and political experts anticipate that the expected continuing plunge could have an enormous political impact on the Australian government.
Political analysts have predicted that a fall below the psychologically potent 50 U.S. cents level will be highly dangerous for Prime Minister John Howard.

The experts say Australian voters will be less confident in the Howard government's handling of its economic and financial management and political fallout can be expected in the next election, either in 2001 or 2002.

"The biggest negative for the dollar this year has been the steady price falls that have led to a complete loss of confidence by investors," according to Rory Robertson of the Sydney-based Macquire Bank. "Fundamentals become increasingly less important as hopes for a rebound are crushed," he added.
Australia's economy remains sound, with its gross domestic product growth expected to exceed 4 percent between July 1, 2000 and June 30, 2001.
But the continuous fall of the local currency, though good for exports, is making imports more expensive and many Australian consumers are now feeling the pinch, said Robertson.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WINS PARALYMPIC BRONZE IN WEIGHTLIFTING

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei's Lu Li-hua took the bronze medal Saturday in the women's 44-kg individual power lifting competition at the Sydney Paralympic Games, bringing the total medal tally for Taiwan to one gold and two bronzes.
The tally equals Taiwan's medal haul at the 1996 Atlanta Paralympic Games, according to Chinese Taipei deputy team chief Chang Chao-shen.
Lu's total lift was 87.5 kg, trailing behind Egypt and Nigeria, who took gold and silver with total lifts of 109 kg and 102.5 kg, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TCCI REPRESENTATIVES LEAVE BEIJING AFTER SEMINAR
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Chou Hui-ying and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Members of a Taiwan delegation attending a Beijing-sponsored seminar on trade and economic cooperation among Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong left Beijing Saturday.
The two-day seminar opened Wednesday in Beijing with more than 100 delegates from the three areas participating.
The seminar focused on the issues and strategies to cope with them that will face Taiwan and mainland China following entry to the World Trade Organization.
While in Beijing, the Taiwan delegates called on Wang Zhaoguo, head of the Chinese Communist Central United Front Work Department, and Jia Qinglin, secretary of the Beijing Municipal Committee.

Wang told the Taiwan delegates, who were mainly from the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (TCCI), that mainland China, which is applying for WTO membership with the status of a developing country, will enjoy a five-year buffer period during which it will be willing to offer Taiwan favored trade treatment.
TCCI Chairman Hsu Sheng-fa said the seminar marked the first time the two sides had discussed such issues and added his hope that both sides can strengthen their exchanges in related fields.
He said that after returning to Taipei, the delegates will submit a number of cross-strait trade suggestions to the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET SUBMITS READJUSTED BUDGET PROPOSAL FOR FISCAL 2001

TEXT.P: The Cabinet submitted a readjusted national budget proposal for fiscal 2001 to the legislature Saturday for deliberation.

Total revenues and expenditures remain unchanged at NT$1,458.5 billion (US$45.45 billion) and NT$1,608.2 billion (US$50.12 billion), respectively, but the budget for programs that can be retrenched or deferred has been cut by NT$1.389 billion (US$43.28 million), a sum that will be spent on other programs.

Total expenditures increased by NT$95 billion (US$2.96 billion) over the current fiscal budget, but the Cabinet stressed that funding to carry out government policies are facing obvious limitations, making response measures urgently needed.

Following the resignation of Tang Fei as premier early this month, the Executive Yuan withdrew its original budget proposal for readjustment, to reflect the intentions of new Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to give priority to economic development and improving care for off-shore island residents, aborigines, farmers and fishermen.

Trimmed expenditures also include NT$8.82 million (US$274,852) in pay cuts for the president and the vice president, and NT$4 billion (US$124.65 million) in government subsidies to the national health insurance program.
Most of the budget increases go to transportation construction projects and the agricultural development fund.
The total amount of loans raised and the budget deficit remains the same as in the previous budget proposal.

Social welfare expenditure makes up the greatest percentage of the budget proposal at 18.6 percent, followed by education, science and culture at 16.3 percent. National defense expenditure makes up 15.5 percent, while economic developments make up 14.9 percent of total expenditure.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU MAYOR MAY RETURN FROM MAINLAND CHINA TRIP AHEAD OF SCHEDULE
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Peng Sze-chou and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Mayor Tsai Jen-chien of northern Taiwan's Hsinchu City might cut short an ongoing visit to mainland China because he resents being described at a conference as the mayor of a Chinese city, according to a member of his delegation.

Liu Yu-tung, assistant dean of Hsinchu's National Chiao Tung University School of Humanities, said Saturday that Tsai might return to Taiwan early because a spokesman at the conference he attended said the mayor, a member of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, identified with the "one China principle."
Tsai is originally scheduled to end his trip Sunday.

According to Liu, Tsai attended the second World Technology Cities Conference in Nanjing purely to discuss issues related to science-technology cities and share the 20 years of development experience of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, and did not touch on any political issues.
Liu went on to say that Tsai was in mainland China in his capacity as "Hsinchu Mayor" and not "mayor of Hsinchu City, China."
Tsai is the first local government chief to be allowed to visit mainland China since the inauguration of the Republic of China government in May.
Meanwhile, Hsinchu Deputy Mayor Lin Cheng-chieh said that he had not been in contact with Tsai since the previous evening and did not know if he was indeed returning ahead of schedule.

The Cabinet has recently turned down on political grounds separate applications by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who concurrently serves as DPP chairman, to visit the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN INSISTS ON `OPENNESS' IN CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he holds no preset stance on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and that as a head of state, he will keep himself "hollow and empty" so he can accept all outside opinions.

Chen stressed that consensus and decisions reached by the Presidential Advisory Group on Cross-Strait Relations in the future will be the pivotal basis on which the administration formulates its policies on the thorny cross-strait relations issue.

He made the remarks during a meeting with opposition New Party head Hao Lung-ping and two other party heavyweights at the Taipei Guest House -- Chen's second meeting since his inauguration for fence-mending efforts with the oppositions.

He noted that the 21st century begins only 72 days from now and said he earnestly hopes that people from both sides of the Taiwan Strait will play greater roles in the new era. He added his fervent hope that there will be no war, no conflict, but only peace and glory ahead.
He lauded the New Party as "an efficient and responsible opposition group." He said the party's "small size" is no problem, as long as the party has its own "height and depth."
In his view, Chen said, a mini-party or a minority government is a majority as long as it meets the people's expectations and its policies are aimed at the greatest interests of the people.

Quoting the old Chinese proverb: "When brothers are of one heart, they will create a force strong enough to cut steel," Chen welcomed his meeting with the New Party leaders, saying that as long as all parties stand together, all difficulties, no matter how invincible they seem, will be conquered.
He added that similar meetings will take place in the future so that his administration can hear more opposition voices.

During the meeting, Chen exchanged views with Hao, convenor of the New Party's National Election and Development Committee, Lai Shyh-bao, the New Party whip at the Legislative Yuan and New Party Secretary-General Lee Ping-nan on matters regarding cross-strait relations, constitutional reforms, policies to reinvigorate the domestic economy and bourse, and ways to enhance ethnic harmony.
Commenting on the meeting, Hao also confirmed the significance of the talks, saying that "a good start is half-way to success."
He said that despite its small size, the New Party is also part of the crew of the "Ship of Taiwan" under the helm of President Chen.
However, he noted that Chen's ideological insistence will eventually be detrimental to the development of cross-strait relations.
He pointed out that since Chen's administration took office five months ago, the government has from the very beginning been shadowed by a veil of ideological insistence.

This, he went on, is evident in ex-Premier Tang Fei's resignation, ostensibly on grounds of ill health, Chen and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's jointly held view that there was no consensus reached across the Taiwan Strait in 1992, the Ministry of Education's reluctance to adopt the Hanyu Pinyin romanization plan, and Chen's insistence that he is "ethnic Chinese" rather than "Chinese."

Hao said Chen and the ruling Democractic Progressive Party's insistence on certain ideological issues will eventually cause a stalemate between the ruling and opposition parties, impair cross-strait relations and sacrifice ethnic harmony.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN VICE PRESIDENT TO ARRIVE FOR FIVE-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Salvadoran Vice President Carlos Quintanilla, at the head of a 13-member delegation, will arrive in the Republic of China on Sunday for a five-day visit, according to a press release from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
While in the ROC, Quintanilla and his entourage will call on President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Chang Chun-hsing, and other government officials.
Lu will accompany the Salvadoran dignitaries on visits to several agricultural, economic and sci-tech establishments in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan.
Quintanilla last visited the ROC in April, 1999 in the capacity of vice president-elect. This will be his first visit to the ROC in his capacity as vice president.
Lu visited El Salvador in late September this year and was warmly welcomed by the people and government of El Salvador.
Quintanilla and his entourage are scheduled to depart the ROC on Oct. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOTLINE BETWEEN ROC PRESIDENT, PARTY LEADERS TO BE ESTABLISHED

TEXT.P: The mechanism for a hotline between Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and the heads of the country's various political parties will probably be established next week, according to a top presidential aide.

Chen Che-nan, deputy secretary-general to the president, said in a radio interview Saturday that the establishment of such a hotline and the contact it would provide among the staff members of the different camps will allow the president to exchange opinions with party leaders and effectively resolve problems when faced with major issues.

Chen's remarks came after a Thursday meeting between the president and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong and a meeting earlier Saturday with opposition New Party head Hao Lung-ping, Chen's first meetings with opposition party leaders since his May 20 inauguration.
If a third meeting -- with opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan -- takes place next week, Chen said that the hotline and dialogue mechanism will soon be inaugurated.

However, KMT legislator Chen Hung-chi, who was also present in the radio studio, said that while the establishment of such a hotline might have a symbolic effect on the unstable political situation, the actual effect would remain to be seen.

He pointed out that where there is a lack of consensus, trying to resolve difficulties and issues through the hotline would be more for appearance's sake than any substantial significance such a move might have.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BEATS AUSTRIA TO CAPTURE TABLE TENNIS BRONZE IN PARALYMPICS

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei overcame Austria 3-2 Saturday to finish third and clinch a bronze medal in the men's Class 9 table tennis competition at the Sydney Paralympic Games.
Earlier in the day, the same team lost 1-3 to Nigeria before recovering its composure in the match against Austria.

The victory brought the total medal tally for Chinese Taipei to one gold and three bronze medals in the third day of the games, breaking the haul of one gold and two bronzes at the 1996 Paralympics in Atlanta in 1996, according to Professor Chang Chao-shen, deputy chief of the Chinese Taipei team.
Slovakia and Nigeria were scheduled to compete later in the day for the table tennis gold and silver, organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN VP ENCOURAGES TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN TO INVEST IN EL SALVADOR
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Lawrence Chu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Salvadoran Vice President Carlos Quintanilla encouraged Taiwan businessmen Friday to invest in El Salvador.

Quintanilla made the call at a seminar titled "Central American Trade Opportunities and the Salvadoran Investment Climate," held in Los Angeles where he was making a transit stopover en route to a five-day visit to the Republic of China.

Quintanilla encouraged Taiwan businessmen residing in the United States to take advantage of the benefits afforded by the Central American preferential act promulgated by the U.S. government, by investing, manufacturing and procuring in Central America.

The act, signed by U.S. President Bill Clinton on May 24 and formally put into effect on Oct. 1, is aimed at paving the way for the establishment of an American Common Market, by first offering Central American and Caribbean nations the same treatment as the members of the North America Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) -- no quota restrictions on exports and no import tariffs.

Quintanilla expressed the belief that the act will have a revolutionary effect on the global textile and garment industry, predicting that within two years, more than 50 percent of global textile products and garments exported to the United States will transfer to be manufactured in the Central American region.

Hsia Kuo-wei, a Taiwan businessman who has invested in El Salvador for 10 years, was also present at the seminar to explain investment requirements in Central American nations, especially El Salvador. He encouraged Taiwan businessmen in the textile and garment industry to grab the opportunity to invest in El Salvador.
Quintanilla, who was scheduled to arrive in the ROC on Sunday, said he would like to hold a similar seminar in Taipei to attract Taiwan businessmen to invest in his country.

DOC.HEADLINE: SISTER-TO-BROTHER KIDNEY TRANSPLANT SUCCEEDS

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) surgeons have successfully transplanted a kidney from a woman into her elder brother, using laparoscopy instead of conventional surgical methods, sources from NTUH's Department of Urology said Saturday.

Although it is not the first live-donor kidney transplant in Taiwan, the sister-to-brother transplant marks the first case in Taiwan in which the laparoscopy technique has been used to remove and acquire a kidney from a live donor.

At a press conference announcing the successful transplant, which was performed nearly one month ago, brother Lee Juei-cheng, 36, said he was so touched by the love and unselfishness shown by his younger sister, Lee Chia-ling, 30, that he could find no words to describe his gratitude to her.

Lee said that after five years of dialysis, NTUH doctors told him earlier this year that a kidney transplant would be the only option to keep him alive, whereupon his whole family, including his 62-year-old father, offered to give him a kidney.
After a series of assessments and comparisons, doctors found that a kidney from Chia-ling would be most suitable for the transplant.

Chia-ling, who is married and has two children, accepted the challenge without a second thought, enabling the transplant to be performed in September at the NTUH Department of Urology under the supervision of doctors Chuei Shih-chieh and Lai Ming-kun.
Chia-ling said she has pretty much recovered from the surgery over the past one month, apart from occasional feelings of fatigue.

Chuei and Lai cut a relatively much small opening of 6.5 cm in Chia-ling's lower abdomen and removed her left kidney by hand after a hand-assisted laparoscope removed all connecting blood vessels on the organ.

Chuei described the operation as successful, saying that although it took one hour longer using the laparoscopic technique, the operation saved the donor from losing an excessive amount of blood -- only 50 cc, about one-third of the amount lost during conventional surgery to remove a kidney -- while the size of the incision was also much smaller. The donor also recovered much more quickly, he noted.
Lai also highly recommended the laparoscopic technique for use in Taiwan, saying it offers greater incentives for potential donors to be willing to give up their own kidneys to needy relatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT CONCLUDES CZECH VISIT

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui left the Czech Republic capital of Prague Saturday en route to Taipei via Paris after winding up a week-long visit.
Lee visited Prague to attend the fourth Forum 2000 conference on the roles of science, education, and religion in globalization. The forum ended Wednesday.

He delivered a speech on Taiwan's democratization process and the mainstream values of today's world at one of the sessions of the forum, which gathered some 50 retired heads of state, religious leaders, influential politicians, writers and artists from around the world.

Lee met exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama during the conference and invited him to visit Taiwan again. the Dalai Lama, who last visited Taiwan in 1997, said at a later press conference that he will fly to Taiwan at a date yet to be decided.
The former president also visited Czech President Vaclav Havel on Oct. 17 and they had a 20-minute exchange of views on Taiwan's political and economic achievements.

Lee's Prague visit was made at the invitation of Havel, who founded the Forum 2000 think tank together with a private Japanese foundation in 1997. The Czech Republic does not recognize Taiwan diplomatically, although the two countries maintain close substantive relations.
This was Lee's second overseas trip since he stepped down as president on May 20. He visited Britain in June.
He would not elaborate on which countries he wants to visit next, saying only that he is considering the matter, although many countries have offered him invitations.

Unconfirmed news reports have speculated that Lee is expected to visit Japan to take part in this year's Asian Outlook forum later this month, but the reports have been denied by Lee and he has not applied for a Japanese visa.
Beijing, which protested bitterly to London for allowing Lee to visit, lodged a protest with the Prague authorities over his Czech visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 22, or the 24th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1721: Peter I, known as "Peter the Great," is proclaimed Emperor of all of Russia. He extended his territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores and reformed the administration of the state.
1835: Sam Houston, U.S. politician and general who fought in the Texan struggle for independence from Mexico, is sworn in as president of the Republic of Texas.
1873: The emperors of Russia, Germany, and Austro-Hungary form an alliance.
1906: Paul Cezanne, French painter and leading post-impressionist figure, dies at the age of 67. His most famous paintings include "Mont Sainte-Victoire" and "The Card Players."
1909: Elise de Laroche, French aviator better known as Baronne de Laroche, becomes the first woman to fly solo.
1944: The Military Committee of the National government begins drafting young intellectuals for military service after Chairman Chiang Kai-shek urged 100,000 young men to enter the army on Sept. 14.
1947: Pakistan and India begin a war over Kashmir.
1947: Japanese spy Yoshiko Kawajima is sentenced to death by a Chinese military court.
1950: Popular elections of magistrates are held in Taiwan Province, with Yang Chung-ching elected chief of Hualien County and Chen Chen-chung as chief of Taitung County.
1951: A strong earthquake rocks Hualien, killing 43 people and destroying many houses.
1953: Laos gains independence from France.
1962: U.S. President John F. Kennedy makes his first major move in the showdown with the USSR over the building of ballistic missile sites in Cuba by announcing that Cuba will be placed under a naval "quarantine" -- a blockade -- until the Soviets remove them.
1964: Jean-Paul Sartre, French writer, rejects the Nobel Prize for Literature by saying it would reduce the impact of his writing.
1966: KGB master spy George Blake, who had spied for the Russians for 12 years and was sentenced to 42 years in prison in 1962, escapes from the maximum security wing of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London.
1975: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and philosopher, dies at the age of 86. His "Study of History" explores patterns of growth and the decay of civilization.
1976: The 34,000-ton tanker Tsaineng (Talent) calls at Taichung port, becoming the first vessel to enter Taiwan's fourth international seaport.
1977: The first generator of the first nuclear power plant in Taiwan becomes operational.
1978: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea agree to exchange information on the development and preservation of energy resources at their 13th annual ministerial economic conference.
1986: Yeh Chien-ying, one of the senior leaders of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 89. With the support of Yeh, who commanded a wide following in the army and among senior cadres in 1976, Hua Kuo-feng was able to purge the "Gang of Four" and become Mao Tse-tung's successor.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves a raise in the minimum wage to NT$6,900 per month effective from November.
1992: Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Robert Urbain visits Taipei to relay a message of welcome to Taiwan business leaders intending to invest in Belgium. He also pledges support for the ROC's bid to join GATT.
1993: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of Russia, signs a decree governing private farms, paving the way for the breaking up of state-controlled farms and the move toward a free market economy.
1995: Independent presidential candidate Chen Li-an names Wang Ching-feng, a Control Yuan member, as his running mate.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew rushes to Chiayi immediately after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the southern city at 10:19 a.m. injuring more than 320 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Time and venue for meeting between President Chen and main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan will be decided soon.
The China Times:
Direct cross-strait 'three links' can become reality sooner than expected so long as Beijing shows sincerity, says President Chen.
The United Daily News:
President Chen says the government will refer to conclusions reached by the President's Advisory Group on Cross-Strait Relations in formulating policy toward mainland China.
The Liberty Times:
Four-star generals to be among public functionaries to be impeached over the Lafayette-class frigate procurement scandal.
The China Post:
President Chen again denies 'one China' accord.
The Taiwan News:
Vice Premier Lai In-jaw ruled out of APEC forum because of pressure from Beijing.
The Taipei Times:
President Chen still wants Lai at APEC forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT MAKES TRANSIT STOP IN PARIS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China president Lee Teng-hui made a transit stop at Paris Saturday on his way back to Taipei from Prague.
Lee and his wife arrived at the Charles De Gaulle Airport after attending an international conference, Forum 2000, in Prague. They were greeted by Taiwan's representative to France Kuo Wei-fan.
Owing to the ground crew strike at the airport, Lee and his entourage were unable to use the airport's VIP lounge and were taken to a restaurant at the airport instead.
Lee chatted with Kuo over a launch at the restaurant, and expressed concerns about Taiwan's ties with Paris.

The former ROC president told reporters that he hopes to visit France some day, but the possibility seems dim given the warm relations between Paris and Beijing which has gone out of its way to prevent any of its allies to host the former Taiwan leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: 16% OF CHEN'S SUPPORTERS WOULD SWITCH: POLL

TEXT.P: About 16 percent of those who voted for Chen Shui-bian in the March 18 presidential election would change their minds if the clock could be turned back, according to the results of a public opinion poll released Sunday.

The same poll, conducted by an association affiliated to the main opposition Kuomintang, also found that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has received the largest share of the blame for the recent domestic stock market slump.

The telephone poll of 1,095 adult residents conducted by the Chinese National Development Association from Oct. 19-20, found that if the presidential election were to be held again, 15.9 percent of those who voted for Chen in March said they would cast their ballots for other candidates; 66.9 percent said they would not switch their allegiance; 11.6 percent either said "it depends" or "it's hard to answer;" and 5.9 percent said they would not go to the polls or would spoil their ballots.

According to the survey, 32.3 percent of those interviewed said they voted for Chen in the March presidential election, 24.7 percent said they opted for independent candidate James Soong (now chairman of the People First Party (PFP)), 12.7 percent voted for KMT candidate Lien Chan, and 29.7 percent either said they did not vote, spoiled their ballot, or refused to answer the question.

The survey results show that 27 percent of the respondents said they think that the DPP is to blame for the drastic stock market fall over the past five months. In contrast, 17.3 percent said the KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20, should be blamed for the stock market woes. Only 0.2 percent said they feel the PFP, which was founded after the March 18 presidential election, should take the blame for the stock market plunge.

Meanwhile, 11.1 percent said they think all major domestic political parties should be held responsible for the bearish stock market, while 14.5 percent said the question needs further observation and 20.8 percent either declined to answer the question or said they have no opinions about the issue.

As for the main reasons behind the poor stock market performance, 23.1 percent cited uncertainty surrounding the government's financial and economic policies; 16.3 percent blamed opposition parties for countering the government simply for the sake of opposing; 10.4 percent put the blame on the DPP for its refusal to uphold the fourth nuclear power plant construction project; 6.8 percent cited strained relations across the Taiwan Strait; 5.8 percent blamed the DPP's insistence on its traditional ideology (pro-Taiwan independence and anti-nuclear energy); 20.5 percent said it depends; and 16.6 percent said they do not know or have no opinion.

Asked whether the recent financial and economic meeting chaired by President Chen Shui-bian could help upgrade public confidence in the government, 40.2 percent gave a negative answer; 26.1 percent said it could help; 17.4 percent either said "it depends" or "it's still hard to evaluate"; and 16.3 percent said they have no opinion.

If the DPP fails to sustain Taiwan's economic growth, 38.2 percent said that not voting for the DPP in the next election is the best way to hold the party responsible for its failure; 9.6 percent said a recall of the president would be the best way; 8.1 percent preferred to see legislators hold a no-confidence vote against the premier; 4.4 percent said economic performance has nothing to do with the ruling party; 2 percent said they see no need to weigh the DPP's responsibility for the poor economic performance; 20.3 percent either said "it depends" or "it's hard to answer"; and 17.4 percent said they have no opinion.

According to the poll, 26.8 percent of those interviewed said they feel that Chen gives the top priority to the DPP's opinions in his policy-making, while 24.4 percent said they think that Chen places more emphasis on the opinions of the general public, and 37.9 percent either said "they don't know," "it depends" or have no opinion about the issue."

DOC.HEADLINE: BILLS INTRODUCED TO BALANCE PRESS FREEDOM AGAINST NATIONAL SECURITY

TEXT.P: Draft bills designed to draw a fine line between the protection of state secrets and the freedom of the press have been presented to the Legislative Yuan, a Government Information Office (GIO) official said Sunday.

Su Cheng-ping, general director of the GIO, said in an interview with a local TV station that a bill aimed at protecting classified information from the press and another designed to open other government information to public scrutiny have been brought to the legislature for approval.
The bills are the brainchildren of the GIO and an attempt to balance press freedom against the government's need to keep secret information vital to national security.
The editor-turned-government spokesman acknowledged that there are often conflicts between press freedom, judiciary independence and national security.
"Drawing a clear line between them is the only way to reconcile the competing demands," Su said.

He made the comment in response to questions about a flurry of recent government crackdowns on the publication of alleged government secrets by local newspapers after they scrambled to publish the transcripts of the depositions of witnesses involved in several high-profile military scandals and other documents related to these cases.

Prosecutors, irritated by the disclosure of the information, ordered a search of the offices of a local newspaper and indicted a former police officer who was a member of the police task force charged with looking into the scandal surrounding the navy's purchase of warships six years ago.
Angered by the Oct.3 search, the China Times Express is now vigorously pushing for legislation to strip prosecutors of the power to order searches.

Meanwhile Lin Keng-chiang, now secretary-general of the Coast Guard Administration was indicted Saturday for revealing secret information about the navy scandal to a local electronic newspaper, the "tTimes,"

The prosecutors based their indictment on the grounds that Lin was one of two investigators who had access to the top-secret information and the only one who refused to undertake a lie detector test to support his claims of innocence.
Dismissing the reasoning behind the indictment as "absurd," Lin said he refused to take the test because he felt it was an "affront" to him, while its results are inadmissible in court.
In its Sunday edition, the tTimes criticized the evidence listed in Lin's indictment as "fragile."
Newspaper officials said that as responsible journalists, they did not reveal their sources to the investigating prosecutors.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT RETURNS FROM PRAGUE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui returned to Taipei Sunday afternoon after attending the Forum 2000 conference in the Czech Republic capital of Prague.
Lee was greeted at the airport by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and the former secretary-general of the presidential office, Huang Kun-huei.
Lee left Taipei on Oct. 14 for the four-day Forum 2000, which brought together about 50 world political leaders and spiritual leaders to discuss the future of mankind.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSOLUTION OF COMMUNISM WILL BE REPEATED ON TIANANMEN SQUARE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The dissolution of communism in Moscow's Red Square in 1991 will be repeated some day on Beijing's Tiananmen Square, exiled Chinese dissent Harry Wu said in a recent interview.

In an interview with the French weekly L'Express which hit newsstands Sunday, the dissent who spent many years in labor reform camps in mainland China appealed to European leaders to help mainland China rid itself of dictatorship.

In the interview, released to coincide with a meeting in Yangzhou, southern China, between French President Jacques Chirac and his mainland Chinese counterpart Jiang Zemin, Wu said Beijing's crimes against human rights in wiping out political rivals are "no less than those of Adolf Hitler."
He estimated the victims of communist Chinese suppression since 1949 to number about 50 million and said that persecution of political dissent is even more vigorous at present.
The Beijing regime even sells the organs of executed criminals, Wu claimed.

He called Beijing's threat of using force to reunite with Taiwan a bluff aimed at rallying the mainland people behind a banner of nationalism. He further noted that a separate and prosperous Taiwan funneling investment into mainland China would best serve Beijing's interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAS NOT CHANGED 'GO SOUTH' POLICY: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said recently that Taiwan's "go south" policy has remained unchanged.
Chen made the remarks in a recent interview with Singapore's Chinese-language daily Lianhe Zaobao, which published the full text of the interview in its Sunday issue.
Chen, the ROC's first president from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, said Taiwan is one of major countries in Southeast Asia.

It is regretful that the ROC has been barred from taking part in activities of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) simply because of political reasons, Chen said, adding that it's a great loss to ASEAN member states and their people.

Chen further said his administration has not changed the previous Kuomintang government-initiated "go south" policy under which Taiwan has encouraged its businesses to invest in Southeast Asian countries with a view to cooling their craze for investing in mainland China.

Under the "go south" policy, Taiwanese entrepreneurs have poured more than US$40 billion into major Southeast Asian countries for various investment projects, making Taiwan a major source of foreign capital in Thailand, Indonesia, Vietnam, the Philippines, Malaysia and other nations in the region.

Chen said the ROC is more than willing to fulfill its obligation as a member of the Global Village and share its developmental experience with other developing countries. Due to mainland China's opposition, Chen said, the ROC has been shut out of nearly all major international organizations, including the United Nations, the World Health Organization and ASEAN.

Touching on Taiwan's controversial fourth nuclear power plant project, Chen said the issue should not be politicized. According to Chen, whether Taiwan should build a fourth nuclear power plant is publicly discussed only after the DPP came to power in May. Under the previous KMT government, Chen claimed, construction of a fourth nuclear power plant is a must. The KMT government had never presented alternatives to the project.

Chen said his administration has presented the issue for public discussion and debate. He stressed that it's up to the Executive Yuan (Cabinet) and the Legislative Yuan to pool wisdom to decide the project's fate. Chen said a final decision on the issue will be made in bear future.

As for Taiwan's recent stock market slump, Chen said it's not an issue unique to Taiwan. In fact, Chen said, major stock markets around the world have suffered setbacks in recent weeks. "As 85 percent of Taiwan's stock investment concentrates in science-technology stocks, our bourse would certainly be affected when the U.S. technology-heavy NASDAQ drops," Chen said.

Another special feature of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) -- individual or retail stock investors account for 87 percent of the island's stock investors -- has added up to market volatility, Chen noted, adding that Against this backdrop, short-term speculative stock trading has become a social problem in Taiwan.

Nevertheless, Chen stressed that Taiwan's economic fundamentals remain sound and healthy, with the economic growth rate expected to reach 6.32 percent in the fourth quarter this year. Exports, imports and foreign orders have all grown substantially and the inflation rate remain low, Chen said, adding that he remains confident in Taiwan's economic prospects.

As for Taiwan's trade policy toward mainland China, Chen said so long as Taiwan's national security can be ensured, his administration will largely ease restrictions on commercial exchanges with the mainland based on reciprocity, proportion and general market principles.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90% FARMERS SUPPORT OVERHAUL OF FARMERS ASSOCIATIONS LAW

TEXT.P: Nearly 90 percent of local farmers responding to a recent public opinion poll support Proposed revisions to the farmers association election law to ensure clean election of major executives and board members, according to survey results released Sunday.

The telephone poll of 1,001 farmers randomly selected from around the island, conducted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) from Oct. 18-21, found that 88.2 percent of the respondents support revisions to regulations governing election of delegates of grassroots farmers associations, directors, supervisors and secretaries-general.

According to the poll, the respondents support the DPP-proposed stricter restrictions on the qualifications for those who intend to take part in the elections for managerial posts in grassroots farmers associations.
DPP officials said the restrictions are necessary to prevent those with criminal records from joining future elections to continue control of local farmers associations.
The Council of Agriculture said one-third incumbent farmers associations executives, delegates and board members have previous criminal records or close links to criminal rings.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REMAINS WORLD'S LARGEST EXPORTER OF NOTEBOOK COMPUTERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports in personal and notebook computers have increased by more than 40 percent over last year, with local notebooks accounting for 60 percent of the global market, industry sources said Sunday.

With this excellent performance and solid base, the information industry is also working hard to develop related spheres such as telecommunications products, information appliances and servers, in an effort to also gain a niche in the global market, according to the sources.

Global computer demand is expected to increase by less than 15 percent this year amid the global economic recession. However, Taiwan's exports in desktop computers is expected to reach 2.9 million units, up 49 percent over the year-earlier level, said the sources.

The total production value of domestic desktop computers is expected to reach US$80 million this year, representing an annual increase of more than 10 percent and accounting for 24 percent of the global market.

Taiwan's notebook exports are expected to reach 14 million this year, an annual growth rate of 44.32 percent. Total production value will increase from last year's US$11 billion to US$15 billion, while its world occupancy rate will climb from 49 percent to 60 percent.

As the world's third-largest information technology hardware manufacturer, Taiwan's information industry is also conducting research and development in software products and increasing added value in its products, according to the sources.

For example, the sources went on, four major notebook manufacturers are shifting part of their efforts to the development of Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) mobile phones, with total production expected to reach 20 million units next year. Along with its original production, Taiwan's WAP mobile phones are also expected to gain an important position in the world market, they added.
Many other domestic computer giants have formed R&D teams to develop software related to information appliances, in efforts to gain an edge in the field within five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD CHINESE WRITERS ASSOCIATION TO HOLD ANNUAL MEETING IN U.S.

TEXT.P: The World Chinese Writers Association (WCWA) will hold its largest-ever annual meeting in Los Angeles on Nov. 6, a senior association official said Sunday.
Association Board Chairman George S.C. Huang said that more than 350 Chinese writers from 75 countries and regions around the world will take part in the association's fourth bi-annual gathering.

Huang said U.S. President Bill Clinton and Gao Xingjian, winner of the 2000 Nobel Prize in Literature, will be invited to attend the gathering and added that the WCWA will also invite Gao to visit Taiwan.
The WCWA is a worldwide organization with affiliate associations spanning Asia, Europe, North America, South America, Oceania, Central America and Africa, Huang said.

In conjunction with the meeting, an international academic seminar on the "inheritance and outlook of World Chinese Writers" will also be held. The seminar will be jointly sponsored by a German university, together with Taiwan's Soochow and Shih Hsin universities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO PLAY DECISIVE ROLE IN TATAN GAS-FIRED POWER PLANT

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will play a decisive role among three joint ventures of local and foreign oil companies who will bid for a NT$400 billion natural gas power plant project at Tatan, a senior CPC official said Sunday.
CPC Chairman Chen Tsao-wei said the company will choose a cooperative partner who can offer the best conditions and the lowest costs for the project.

Three local and foreign oil company joint ventures are said to be vying for the project -- Holland's Shell Oil Co. with Evergreen Group, France's Total Fina Elf with the Far East Group and the U.S. Mobil Oil Company with the Tuntex Group.
Originally, Shell was to have formed a partnership with Tuntex, but the lines were redrawn when Evergreen stepped into the ring.

The Tatan natural gas-fired plant, which will be capable of generating 400 kilowatts of power, will cost NT$130 billion to build. It will burn NT$18 billion-worth of natural gas per year, rising to NT$400 billion-worth in the coming 25 years.
The project will be Taiwan's largest-ever single procurement project.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO MAKE ITS POLICIES CLEAR

TEXT.P: Several participants in a seminar urged the government Sunday to make its policies clear and respect market mechanisms by reducing intervention to ensure the nation's solid financial development.

Legislator Lai Shyh-bao and several scholars were speaking at a seminar aimed at hammering out constructive suggestions for the government. They made the suggestions because the local bourse has been in a serious slump since President Chen Shui-bian assumed his post on May 20.

Lai, of the opposition New Party, said the government has intervened too much in the stock market while failing to make decisions on crucial policies such as whether or not construction of the fourth nuclear power plant will continue, which analysts have blamed for the lack of confidence among investors.
He said that although short-term government intervention in the stock market may reduce the speed of the slump, it is harmful to the market's long-term development.
He suggested that the government quickly make decisions on the country's crucial construction projects and present basic economic policies to ensure a more solid financial market.
Tseng Chu-wei, professor of finance at National Chengchi University, said one of the reasons behind the mounting problems is the government itself.

He claimed that fact that the country's industrial development is inclined too much toward the high-tech sector is because of excessive intervention by the government, which he said always uses intervention as a knee-jerk reaction when short-term problems occur.
He suggested that the government should find a complete solution to the many financial problems instead of presenting short-term measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD SPEAKS ON LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS, `3 DIRECT LINKS'

TEXT.P: The head of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) predicted Sunday that none of Taiwan's three major political parties will nominate members for more than half of the contended seats in next year's crucial legislative elections.
DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh made the remarks when he was interviewed by the media in southern and northern Taiwan in a teleconference.

He was asked how the DPP expects to change the current situation of a government with a legislative minority in view of the party's suggestion that nominations for less than half of the contested seats in the legislative election should be submitted.
Hsieh responded that the number of DPP nominations will be close to half of the contested seats in the legislature -- or 88, if the proportional seats of each political party are discounted.

He said that through cooperation with other political parties and independents, as well as proportional seats in the future, any party that can gather close to half of the seats will be the dominant force in the legislature.

Currently, the DPP accounts for slightly less than one-third of the seats in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition Kuomintang, despite suffering a defeat in the March presidential election, is still the dominant force in the legislature.

On reports that the DPP is likely to cooperate with the opposition People First Party (PFP) headed by former KMT stalwart James Soong in the hope of playing off the PFP and KMT for the benefit of the DPP, Hsieh said that the public should not see this as DPP connivance.
Hsieh said that the DPP actually hopes to promote the reconciliation of the country's political parties and help ease the party rivalry.

Hsieh also addressed the "three direct links" with mainland China, saying that the mainland should shoulder the blame for the delay of direct trade, postal and transport links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Hsieh's remarks followed President Chen Shui-bian's statement Saturday that as long as Beijing shows sincerity, cross-strait links might be put in place sooner than generally expected.

Both Soong and Hau Lung-bin, convenor of the New Party's National Committee of Campaign & Development, expressed concern during recent meetings with Chen about the ideology of the pro-independence DPP, which they said might affect cross-strait relations.
Hsieh said, however, that Beijing is also insisting on its own ideology, and he expressed the hope that both sides can put aside their ideological differences in order to resume dialogue.
Commenting on the format of his press conference, he said that if high-level officials from both sides cannot meet in person at present, it might be a good idea to organize a teleconference for them.

He also pointed out that he said long ago that the term "Chinese" could refer to blood, history or politics. With the exception of the island's aboriginal population, he went on, most of the ancestors of local residents originally came from the mainland and so could be referred to as Chinese. However, he continued, if "China" in political terms were to refer to the People's Republic of China, 85 percent of local people would not consider themselves Chinese.

On Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew's recent statements to the effect that the prolonged stalemate in cross-strait relations is not in Taiwan's favor, Hsieh noted that the mainland also has a lot of problems and that time is not necessarily on Beijing's side.
He went on to say that while as a democratic society, Taiwan has already extended numerous olive branches to the other side of the Taiwan Strait, Beijing's policy is not so clear.

Although Beijing has shown some flexibility and goodwill toward Taiwan, he said, the mainland offers different interpretations of its "one China" principle to Taiwan and to the rest of the world, and Taiwan must remain on guard.

DOC.HEADLINE: C. K. YEN MEMORIAL SOCIETY INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: An association formed to raise funds for a memorial hall to honor former Republic of China President C.K. Yen was inaugurated Sunday.

Yen, who died in 1993, held a number of important government posts during his career, including commissioner of the Financial Department of the Taiwan provincial government, economics minister, finance minister and Taiwan provincial governor, before serving as the nation's president from 1975 to 1978.

President Chen Shui-bian sent a written congratulatory message that was read at the inauguration ceremony, which was attended by a number of government and civic leaders, including Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh, Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi, National Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen and former Secretary-General to the Cabinet Wang Tso-ming.

Vice Education Minister Fan Hsun-lu, one of the chief promoters of the idea of a C.K. Yen Memorial Hall, spoke highly of the ex-president, saying that a memorial hall would be a fitting sign of respect for him.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CALLS FOR GOVERNMENT TO FOLLOW GOODWILL WITH ACTION

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou called Sunday for the government to "follow its goodwill with action" and act on the results of an upcoming meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition Kuomintang chairman Lien Chan.

Ma's remarks followed recent meetings between Chen and other opposition leaders, including People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong and New Party head Hau Lung-bin. A meeting between Chen and Lien is expected soon.

Ma, who is a KMT Central Standing Committee member, said that he is glad to see Chen finally change his attitude and accept consultations with other political parties, but he also said that if there is only the form of consultation and no real substance, it will not help solve the problems faced by the government.

Chen's government is seen to be going nowhere after five months in the office because of its minority status, according to Ma. Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) holds less than one-third of seats in the Legislative Yuan, while the vanquished KMT is still the dominant force in the legislature.

Ma said that it is easy to show goodwill, but it is difficult to follow it through, adding that for the real benefits of political consultation, the government must show more sincerity and substantial action and address the major issues of public concern, such as the controversial fourth nuclear plant and cross-strait relations, so as not to give the impression that the administration is dragging its feet in the process of policy-making.
He went on to say that the new government should return to the mainstream public will, and not work against the consensus of the majority of the people of Taiwan.

On cross-strait relations, Ma said that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung stressed the speeding up of direct trade, postal and transport links -- the so-called "three direct links" -- with the mainland, but he noted that the two sides have locked horns on the issue of "one China."

He said that the stance of the KMT is that both sides should return to the agreement reached in 1992 -- "one China, separate interpretations" -- which Ma said is also the consensus of the majority of people in Taiwan.
He said that if the government insists on acting against the will of the majority, "the results will be clear."

Ma said that if the government does not waver and acts quickly on its decision-making, it will put the government in tune with the needs of the people. In this way, he said, a minority government could also succeed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG FOUNDER LI HONGZHI APPEARS IN SAN FRANCISCO

TEXT.P: Falun Gong Founder Li Hongzhi attended a ritual of Falundafa Saturday in San Francisco, his first public appearance since the Chinese government outlawed his organization as an "evil cult" in July 1999.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said Sunday that Li delivered a 30-minute speech at the ritual and left immediately after the speech. Some 500 Falun Gong followers attended the ceremony. Falun Gong is also called Falundafa.

The Falun Gong sect was founded by Li in 1992. Since then, the spiritual movement has expanded rapidly with tens of millions of followers in China and overseas. The Chinese government has not only issued a warrant for his arrest but also allegedly put a price on his head, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION IMPORTANT TO TAIPEI: SAYS ROC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said in an interview with CNA Sunday that the ROC government is paying great attention to the U.S. presidential election as it is very important to Taiwan.
He noted that the election will play a crucial role in the development of the triangular relationship between Washington, Beijing and Taipei.

As a foreign minister, Tien said that he cannot openly indicate his favored candidate, but he added that it can be assumed that Taipei's access to the Republican camp is broader than its access to the Democratic camp.
He admitted that U.S. policy is very important to the ROC's national security and national survival.
For instance, he said, if the new U.S. government is more friendly toward Taiwan, Taiwan will be able to buy more advanced weapons, while U.S. support for Taiwan will become more stable.
Furthermore, Tien went on, such a friendly government will take more positive steps to prevent a military invasion by mainland China and will support Taiwan's bid to join international organizations.

The scholar-turned-foreign minister said his ministry attaches importance to the work of promoting better relations with Washington, because European countries, Japan and Australia usually watch the moves made by the United States before deciding their own moves.

In the interview, Tien also stressed that the ROC government will continue its efforts to enhance relations with the European Union, as the E.U. has become a very important regional group in the international community.

He said that priority will be given to the proposed establishment of offices between Taipei and the E.U. and added that efforts will be also be made to promote relations with other European organizations, including the Council of Europe.

Regarding the recent twists in the development of Taipei's diplomatic relations with the Solomon Islands, Tien said that his ministry's basic stance is that "we have to do our utmost to maintain formal relations."

Although the Solomons government demanded more financial aid from Taipei and began negotiating with Beijing, Tien said that Taiwan will not return to the old-school method of severing ties with any country which engages in negotiation with mainland China.
He said that Taipei has been monitoring the incident with great prudence and added that so far, the relationship between the ROC and the Solomon Island remains positive.
In the interview, Tien denied speculation that he is not in harmony with President Chen Shui-bian after being excluded from some of Chen's interactions with foreign countries.
But he admitted that he has not fully adjusted to the political circumstance since he took over the post last May.
Tien also voiced regret that he has no time to make frequent foreign trips to make new friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI REPRESENTATIVE TO APEC LEADERSHIP CONFERENCE TO BE REPLACED

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government will replace President Chen Shui-bian's representative to next month's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) informal leadership conference because of pressure from Beijing.
Last week, Chen appointed Vice Premier Lai In-jaw to attend the annual informal leadership conference in Brunei on his behalf.
But government officials said Sunday that Taipei has been told by the host country that it "has encountered huge difficulty" to accept Lai as President Chen's representative.

The officials disclosed that among the favored choice as Chen's representative are Jeffrey Koo, president of the Chinese National Association of Commerce and Industry, and Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh.
Meanwhile, Andrew Hsia, director of the International Organizations Department under the Foreign Ministry, will attend the APEC ministerial conference.
