TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 81.21 points to close at 5,680.95.
Market turnover amounted to NT$87.42 billion (US$2.72 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 23, or the 25th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1812: An anti-Napoleonic faction in Paris headed by General Claude Francois de Malet tries to mount a coup d'etat, believing Napoleon to be dead in Russia.
1924: During China's warlord era, Feng Yu-hsing, Hu Ching-yi and Sun Yueh form an allied force to launch a military coup resulting in the resignation of Tsao Kun who was elected president of the Beijing government in Oct. 5, 1923.
1926: Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party.
1928: The Republic of China government formally establishes the Ministry of Education.
1948: Changchun, a city in Kirin Province, northeastern China, falls to communist troops.
1952: Ukrainian-born microbiologist Selman A. Waksman wins the Nobel Prize for Medicine or Physiology for discovering the antibiotic streptomycin, an agent effective in the treatment of tuberculosis.
1955: Ngo Dinh Diem is elected president of South Vietnam.
1956: Hungarian students and workers demonstrate in Budapest against Soviet occupation.
1957: ROC Vice President Chen Cheng is elected deputy director general of the Kuomintang.
1958: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles issue a joint communique reaffirming solidarity between the two countries and stating that Kinmen and Matsu islands are "closely related" to the defense of Taiwan and Penghu under present conditions.
1964: The 10th Conference of the Asia Pacific Anti-Communist League opens in Taipei.
1966: The Ministry of the Interior sets aside today (the ninth day of the ninth lunar month) as Double Nine Festival, also known as the Chung Yang Festival, to honor senior citizens.
1968: Nigerian President Hamani Diori arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1969: The United States starts pulling its troops out of Vietnam.
1973: The ROC suspends diplomatic relations with Upper Volta following Ouagadougou's recognition of Beijing.
1974: Brig. Gen. Abboud Salem Hassan, commander-in-chief of the Royal Jordanian Air Force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: The first Chung Cheng Cup Martial Arts Tournament opens at the Taipei Athletic College with Wang Sun-teh, president of the Taipei Martial Arts Association, presiding.
1980: An economic cooperation agreement is signed in Taipei between La Chambre de Commerce of D'Industrie de Marseilles of France and the Far East Trade Service of the ROC.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in Literature, delivers a speech entitled "To Free China" at Taipei City Hall.
1983: Muslim suicide bombers blow up the U.S. and French headquarters in Beirut, killing more than 200 U.S. marines and French paratroopers.
1992: Emperor Akihito of Japan arrives in Beijing for a six-day visit.
1997: Hong Kong's stock market falls victim to Southeast Asia's economic turmoil, with the Hang Seng index falling more than 10 percent in its biggest crash in history.
1998: A Tokyo court hands down the first death sentence to a member of the Japanese doomsday cult that carried out the 1995 Tokyo subway gas attack.
1999: Taiwan finishes second with 15 medals in the 1999 Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championship held in Perth, Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 81.21 points to close at 5,680.95.
The bourse opened at 5,644.73 and fluctuated between 5,718.17 and 5,539.97 during trading.

A total of 2.26 billion stocks worth NT$87.42 billion (US$2.72 billion) changed hands, compared with the previous trading session which saw 2.49 billion shares traded for a market turnover of NT$77.06 billion (US$2.4 billion).
Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 3 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.2 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with foodstuff stocks moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by construction shares at 1.2 percent, textile issues at 1 percent, cement stocks and plastics and chemical shares, both at 0.3 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 447 to 104, with 64 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices for Taiwan stock index futures were higher Monday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) capitalization weighted index futures for November moved up 10 points to close at 5,670, with 8,971 contracts traded.
TAIEX index futures for December gained five points to finish at 5,685, with 98 contracts changing hands, while March 2001 futures surged 263 points to close at 5,819, with only one contract traded.
June 2001 futures rose 200 points to finish at 5,847, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for September futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile reference levels for TAIEX index futures were set Monday at 5,660 for November, 5,680 for December, 5,556 for next March, 5,647 for next June, and 5,979 for next September.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on TAIEX-listed electronics and financial shares, reported mixed results.
November TE futures rose 1.25 points to close at 278.5, with 2,486 contract transactions, while December TE futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 278.7, with 27 contracts changing hands.
March 2001 TE futures moved up 6.1 points to close at 280, with two contracts changing hands, while June 2001 TE futures fell 3.55 points to finish at 280, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for September 2001 TE futures.
November TF futures moved down 6.6 points to close at 731.6, with 639 contract transactions, while December TF futures decreased 6 points to finish at 735, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIR CALLS FOR CONTINUATION OF 4TH NUKE PLANT PROJECT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman Vincent Siew on Monday urged the government to resume the fourth nuclear power plant project, saying that "to build" is better than "not to build."

Siew, who was a hard-core supporter of the project during his term as the Republic of China premier when the KMT was in power, said completion of the project is essential to meeting the needs of Taiwan's economic development, which will result in growing demands for electricity.

The replacement plans that have been put forth by the Chen Shui-bian administration are full of uncertainties, making it necessary to continue and complete construction on the nuclear power plant, Siew noted.
President Chen, who campaigned for the presidency on an anti-nuclear platform, has made moves to scrap the project, which is already 33 percent completed.

Siew said scrapping the project is also impractical as it would not only involve heavy compensation payments, but would also scare foreign investors away from the island, risking undermining the country's reputation in the international community.

Meanwhile, Siew suggested that the government enact relevant laws stipulating that no new nuclear power plants be constructed in Taiwan in the future, not even when the operational terms of the existing three nuclear power plants expire, in order to support its policy of keeping Taiwan "green and nuclear-free."

Siew said that although it seems the government is already determined to scrap the project and that it is only "a matter of time" before it officially confirms the discontinuation, anything is possible, particularly as things can change quickly in politics. He said it is still hard to say at the present time that the project is dead for certain.

Meanwhile, Siew blamed Taiwan's slumping stock market, which has lost one-third of its value since the inauguration of the Chen administration on May 20, on to two major factors -- investors' crisis of confidence in the government and the impasse across the Taiwan Strait.

Siew suggested that the government stop playing the "word game" in its overall policies, adding that the government must secure continuity and stability in its policies in order to restore the general public's confidence.

As for the development of cross-strait relations, which also has a decisive influence on the performance of Taiwan's bourse, Siew suggested that a common market be established across the Taiwan Strait to accelerate cross-strait exchanges, narrow the ideological gap between the two sides, and eventually end the political deadlock.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOOL PRICES SEEN HITTING 3-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: Global wool prices are expected to hit their highest level in more than three years as a prolonged recovery in the market continues, according to a statement by the Australian Wool Industry Secretariat on Monday.
The AWIS, which represents wool exporters and processors, attributed the higher prices to strong demand from mainland China and other major markets, such as Europe, South Korea, and India.

AWIS executive director Bob Quirk told reporters that wool prices could hit A$8.00 per kilogram (US$4.71 per kilogram) by the end of this year, up from the present price of A$7.42 per kg (US$4.36 per kg).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS SILVER IN MEN'S TABLE TENNIS AT PARALYMPICS

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei had to settle for the silver medal after losing to the South Korean side in the 2000 Paralympics men's Class 5 table tennis finals on Sunday night.
Chinese Taipei was initially able to build a 2 games to 1 lead, but the Korean side proved too strong, coming back to win the next two games and the gold medal.
"It was an exciting competition between our team and the Korean team tonight," a spokesman for the Chinese Taipei told the CNA.
Sunday's victory brought Chinese Taipei's overall medal tally to six -- one gold, one silver, and four bronze medals -- after only the fourth day of the 2000 Paralympic Games in Sydney.
"We hope our team will be able to score more victories in the next few days," the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEENAGE GIRL AMONG FINALISTS IN INT'L WEB PAGE DESIGN CONTEST

TEXT.P: A junior high school girl from southern Taiwan is hopeful of winning the top prize in the international Thinkquest Web page design contest, sources from Kaohsiung said Monday.

Fourteen-year-old Lin Pei-ying, the first Taiwanese student ever to be chosen as a finalist in the TQ contest, is going to travel next month to Egypt where she will meet with her two Web "pals" for an interview and final test for the ultimate prize. If Lin and her two co-authors win the top prize, they will receive US$25,000 each for their work.

Although Lin has never met in person with her two Web pals, the three of them have cooperated closely over the past half year to jointly design their Web page titled "The Learning Curve," which was chosen as one of the 24 finalists in the TQ contest of the best works designed by young brains from around the world.

The TQ contest, sponsored by the renowned non-profit Advanced Network and Service, received 1,150 Web page design entries from teenage students from around the world this year. Eight of those entries came from Taiwan, according to Sin Yu-chien, an ANS spokesperson in Taiwan.

All the creators of the 24 chosen works will go to Egypt to take part in individual interviews and assessments by international judges. All the contestants and their coaches will be entitled to cash prizes of between US$15,000 and US$75,000, Sin noted.

"The Learning Curve," the Web page that Lin and her co-authors created, is in English, although Lin and another of the creators, Jaen Saul, an Estonian, do not have a good command of English. The third member of the team is a Canadian teenager, Sin said.

In an interview with the Taipei Chinese-language daily China Times, Lin said she thinks Saul, is "simply a genius" because he can use more than a dozen kinds of programming languages despite the fact that he has never even bought a book about the Web or Internet and can hardly speak English.
Co-writing the Web page was also a challenge and at times tiring because the three authors all live in different time zones, Lin said.

Lin, who became "obsessed" with Web page designing at the age of 12, said she feels thrilled about meeting her Web pals next month in Egypt. The "virtual" friendship will soon become "reality," she said.
A veteran HTML user, Lin said she is continuing to learn COBOLs, including Linux and PHP, to further enhance her skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALACE MUSEUMS ON BOTH SIDES OF TAIWAN STRAIT TO BOOST EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Senior leaders of the national palace museums on both sides of the Taiwan Strait met in Taipei Monday to forge rapprochement and cooperative ties.

Tu Cheng-sheng, director of the National Palace Museum in Taipei, said he is very pleased to discuss with Tan Bin, deputy director of the National Palace Museum in Beijing, concrete measures for promoting bilateral exchanges and cooperation.

For his part, Tan told Tu that the striking similarity between appearances of the Taipei and Beijing palace museums makes him feel at home. "I hope the two museums can work out a feasible formula for exchanges and cooperation," he added.

Nestled along wooded slopes outside downtown Taipei, the palace museum is home to more than 600,000 pieces of Chinese artwork. Along with the British Museum, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Louvre, the Taipei palace museum is regarded as among the world's greatest.

As mainland Chinese officials see the Taipei palace museum collection as a giant cache of treasures "stolen" by the Kuomintang government during the Chinese civil war in the 1940s, they had threatened to take the collection back to the mainland. Taiwan has taken the threat seriously. When the museum sent exhibits in 1996 and 1997 to the United States for display at several noted U.S. museums, it did so only after the United States guaranteed the artifacts immunity from judicial seizure.

Tu said the Taipei palace museum has staged a series of exhibitions of cultural relics and artifacts from mainland China in the past few years, including the "Mysteries of San-hsing-tui," which features bronze, gold and jade relics from a 3,000-year-old Chinese kingdom, and an exhibit showcasing silk, lacquerware and paintings from the Han Dynasty (202B.C. - A.D. 220).

"We have accumulated plenty of experiences in organizing exhibitions of mainland cultural relics and art treasures through all those events," Tu said, adding that the museum is now preparing for an exhibition of Tang Dynasty cultural relics scheduled for 2002.

Tu said the Taipei palace museum is also no stranger to lending its collection for overseas exhibitions. In the past, the palace museum sent selected pieces of Chinese art for display at major museums in the United States and France. It is now planning to lend its exhibits for display in Germany next year.

Noting that the U.S., French and German authorities had all guaranteed safe return of the artworks, Tu said the museum would consider sending its exhibits to the mainland only after Beijing authorities offer similar guarantees.

In response, Tan said although he personally cannot decide mainland China's national policy, the Beijing palace museum is willing to ensure the safe return of art treasures loaned by the Taipei museum.

If political obstacles to shipping Taipei's art treasures to the mainland for exhibition cannot be removed soon, Tu said, the two sides can consider cooperation in holding joint exhibitions in third countries or areas.

Tan immediately voiced his support for Tu's proposal, saying that the Beijing palace museum is willing to join forces with its Taipei counterpart in staging exhibitions in third countries at proper times and under proper terms.

Tan and five of his colleagues are currently on a weeklong visit in Taipei. During his stay, Tan said he will hold further talks with Tu on a possible framework for future exchanges between the two museums.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER UNEMPLOYMENT RATE HIGHEST SINCE 1985

TEXT.P: The number of unemployed people in Taiwan totaled 304,000 in September, announced the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics under the Executive Yuan on Monday.
The unemployment rate for September was 3.1 percent, the highest level for the same month since 1985, according to the DGBAS.
The DGBAS also said that the unemployment rate for people aged between 45 and 55 was higher than that of any other age group.

Moreover, according to the DGBAS, the number of people losing their jobs due to company shutdowns or layoffs in September was 3,000 higher than the number for August, reflecting Taiwan's sluggish economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCKETING INT'L SUGAR PRICES CAUSE PURCHASE RUSH IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Due to the continuing climb in the international price of sugar, domestic sugar traders predicted that Taiwan Sugar Corporation will raise its prices in January, which has resulted in a sugar purchase rush.
The international sugar prices have nearly doubled since April of this year.

The chairman of the Fair Trade Commission, Chao Yang-ching, said during the interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan Monday that the Taisugar is currently keeping domestic sugar prices unchanged in order to stabilize the market's supply and demand.
The Council of Agriculture and the Taisugar on Monday both appealed to domestic sugar traders to maintain import orders.
They added that the unrefined sugar imported for emergent need will soon arrive and that the country's brown sugar stores are still sufficient to meet market demand. (Yolanda K.C. Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPAQ SEEKING TAIWAN PARTNERSHIP IN BIO-TECH

TEXT.P: U.S. computer giant Compaq is seeking a partnership in Taiwan to boost its new investment arm stretching into the field of biotechnology, sources from Compaq Taiwan said Monday.

Compaq's headquarters in the United States announced recently that it will invest US$100 million to help the research and development of the world's burgeoning life sciences, which include genomics and bioinformatics, said Lai Chao-hui, vice president of Compaq Taiwan.
Taiwan will be one of the locations where part of the US$100 million Compaq investment will be used for the new program, Lai noted.

At a seminar titled "Decoding Human Genomic Sets -- Exploring Biotechnology High-Performance Computing," Compaq introduced the cutting-edge Compaq Alpha Server and its envisaged applications in decoding human genomic sets.

According to Bruce Foster, marketing manager of Compaq's bio-tech and chem-tech department, the Compaq Alpha Servers, which use the high-performance Tru64 Unix operating system and TruCluster software, have already been used widely in space programs and in seismologic and meteorological research because of their high-performance computing capabilities.
Meanwhile, Lai noted that Taiwan is Compaq's first appointed OEM supplier worldwide of servers to multi-processing Intel CPUs, supplying about 100,000 units of such servers a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.014 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$32.076.
The local currency opened at NT$31.995 and was traded between NT$31.995 and NT$32.125.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$647 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE FOR MIDDLE-AGED AND OLDER WORKERS ESCALATING: CLA

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) called a meeting Monday to address the high rate of unemployment among middle-aged and older workers in Taiwan.
CLA statistics show that the number of jobless middle-aged and older workers surged to 42,000 by March this year, compared with only 17,000 in 1986.

CLA Vice Chairman Kuo Jen-chi presided over Monday's meeting, in which the participants discussed the reasons for the high rate of unemployment for this specific age group and reviewed the current measures to address the problem.

The officials noted that the current retirement payment system is the major hurdle for middle-aged and older workers seeking jobs. The Basic Labor Law stipulates that laborers who have worked for 25 consecutive years, or who have worked for 15 years and have reached the age of 55, must be given retirement payments by their employers. Employers therefore tend to be reluctant to hire older workers.

In addition, current labor insurance regulations stipulate that it is compulsory for part-time workers, no matter how long or short their working hours, to take part in the insurance system, putting an added burden on their employers.
Moreover, the language of current employment regulations does not explicitly guard against discrimination based on a job-seeker's age.

The officials also said that plant closures and business downsizing are mainly to blame for the high unemployment rate among middle-aged and older workers. The fact that these workers are often the main source of a family's income and that they are often unable to enter new lines of work has a major negative effect on Taiwan society, the officials pointed out.

Participants at the meeting seemed helpless in thinking of ways to deal with the problem. Labor officials from local governments expressed the hope that the CLA and other government agencies can work together to review the structure of the nation's industry and revive industrial development so as to provide more employment opportunities for middle-aged and older workers.

Kuo said that of all the government social welfare programs available, the subsidies given to employers to encourage them to hire jobless middle-aged or older workers, the subsidies given to the jobless while receiving vocational training, and sponsoring job fairs have shown good results and are worth further promotion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL, KMT TOP AIDES TO DISCUSS HIGH-PROFILE MEETING

TEXT.P: Top aides of Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and majority opposition Kuomintang party leader Lien Chan are scheduled to meet Tuesday to thrash out details regarding an impending meeting between Chen and Lien.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng was expected to call on Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun at the Presidential Office to settle the time and venue of the high-profile meeting, as well as the issues to be discussed and the format the meeting is to take.

According to KMT legislator Huang Hsiang-chou, Lien told him and other KMT legislators during a meeting earlier in the day that he had already left his schedule open for Thursday and Friday, and that he wishes the meeting with Chen to be entirely open-door and to take place in the Presidential Office during office hours.

Yu told reporters later in the day that the Presidential Office will be as open as possible and will try to accept all of Lien's terms and conditions. He added that the office will respect Lien's interest in showing sincerity, but that the KMT had not yet told him explicitly about the three conditions regarding the venue, the time and the open-door policy.

According to Huang, the reason for the requests is because the public has the right to know and because it will prevent either side from coming up with a conflicting version of the meeting afterward, thereby raising cause for suspicion or causing an outbreak of "hidden contentions" in the future.

Huang went on to say that Lien wants the meeting to take place during office hours at the Presidential Office because it is a formal meeting that should not take place after office hours or in the Taipei Guest House, as did the president's two previous meetings with opposition party leaders.

Huang said that he and the other legislators have suggested to Lien that he should bring along officials who once served under the KMT administration -- such as former Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang and former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi -- in order to present concrete administrative advice at the meeting.

According to Huang, the topics to be discussed at the meeting will include cross-strait issues, financial and economic issues, the operation of constitutional government, the aims of post-quake reconstruction and local government system reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGED TO TREAD CAREFULLY WITH SOLOMON ISLANDS' DEMANDS

TEXT.P: With a visit to Taiwan by the Solomon Islands prime minister scheduled for the end of this month, legislators urged the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Monday to tread carefully with regard to the issue of the country's repeated demands for aid from the Republic of China government.

Answering lawmakers' questions at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session, Vice Foreign Minister David Tawei Lee said MOFA takes great care of every penny of taxpayers' money that it spends, but he added that the ROC has an obligation to help its allies settle their internal disturbances. He added that MOFA has not yet decided what kind of assistance will be offered.

Legislator Yen Chin-fu (DPP-at large) said that the foreign aid should be granted with wisdom. If the government approves the Solomon Islands' repeated financial demands, he claimed, the government may suffer a "double loss."

Lee replied that although the Solomon Islands government has demanded huge economic assistance from the ROC, Taipei has not consent to their demands. He promised that future government decisions will not disappoint the people of Taiwan.

Legislator Lee Hsien-jen (KMT-Taipei County) said that although the Solomon Islands government has apologized to the ROC government for an aggressively worded press statement in which it threatened to seek ties with Beijing, it has already hurt the ROC's image. He expressed the hope that other ROC allies will not follow Solomon Islands' suit.
David Lee replied that "lack of forbearance in small matters can upset great plans. We will carefully observe it at first and then take action," he added.
Legislator Parris Chang (DPP) the government to take "drastic measures" to halt Solomon Islands' repeated financial demands.
Lee answered that as a diplomat, he should do whatever he can to sustain the nation's interests. To this end, he said, he will suffer all disgrace and insults in order to accomplish his task.

Meanwhile, asked who will replace Vice Premier Lai In-jaw at the upcoming summit meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Brunei, Secretary-General to the President Yu Shyi-kun said that President Chen Shui-bian will make a decision within a couple of days.
Yu did not rule out that Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh is one of the candidates who might be chosen by Chen to represent him at the APEC summit.
Yu made the remarks in answer to a question raised by Legislator Chao Yung-ching (KMT-Taipei County) at the same interpellation session.

Chen had originally appointed Vice Premier Lai In-jaw to represent him at the APEC summit meeting, but, yielding to pressure from Beijing, Brunei demanded that the ROC send a lower-ranking official or a leading entrepreneur in his place.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERALL REVIEW NEEDED OF KOREAN PENINSULA TIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China needs panoramic, comprehensive thinking to cope with relations with North and South Korea, Vice Foreign Minister David Tawei Lee said Monday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Lee said the Northeast Asian situation is changing rapidly following a recent historic summit meeting between the leaders of long-feuding North and South Korea.
Against this backdrop, Lee said, Taiwan must make an overall review of its relations with the two Koreas in order to craft new strategies for dealing with the changing regional political climate.
The ROC currently does not maintain diplomatic ties with either North or South Korea, although Lee said the ROC has maintained contact with North Korea through private channels.

"Many legislators have also devoted much energy to helping improve relations with Pyongyang over the past years," Lee said, adding that the East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has consistently paid close attention to developments in Taipei-Pyongyang relations and has sent officials to accompany delegations of legislators and business executives on market-inspection tours of the reclusive Stalinist state.

As for relations with South Korea, Lee said direct airlinks have not been resumed since the two countries severed diplomatic ties in August 1992. The two countries have not yet established an institutionalized consultative mechanism for trade and economic consultations, he added.
"We really need innovative and comprehensive thinking to seek major breakthroughs in our relations with North and South Korea," Lee said.

Asked about relations with Tibet, Lee said communication channels between Taiwan and the Tibetan government-in-exile in northern India have long existed and operate smoothly. Nevertheless, he went on, the government has no immediate plans to set up a representative office in Dharamsala, where the Tibetan government-in-exile is located.

Touching on a planned visit to Taiwan by the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, Lee said the government will grant him an entry permit. In view of Beijing's sensitivity to engagements between Taiwan and the Dalai Lama, Lee said, MOFA will handle the Dalai Lama's visa application in a manner acceptable to the Tibetan spiritual leader and in accordance with ROC law and relevant regulations.

Turning to the ROC's foreign aid policy, Lee said the ROC has offered assistance to other countries in several different ways, including technological cooperation, soft loans, encouraging Taiwan businessmen to invest in countries that recognize the ROC, donations of cash or merchandise, emergency relief and humanitarian aid.

In fact, he continued, the government's budget for foreign aid is limited, with the amount accounting for a mere 0.11 percent and 0.15 percent of Taiwan's gross national product (GNP) in 1998 and 1999, respectively.

Lee said MOFA will continue courting public support for a gradual increase in the ROC's foreign aid ratio to 0.7 percent of its GNP, the minimum level set by the United Nations for advanced countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC EXPECTED TO ANNOUNCE OIL PRICE HIKE TUESDAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is likely to announce an increase in domestic gasoline and diesel oil prices Tuesday amid soaring international oil prices, sources close to the CPC said Monday.
The international crude oil was US$33.21 per barrel Monday, with the CPC's import costs between US$30 to US$31 per barrel.

However, since the CPC's current oil prices correspond with its last oil import cost -- between US$28 and US$29 per barrel -- CPC officials said current domestic oil prices no longer reflect CPC costs.
The sources said the price hike will likely be NT$0.3 per liter at most.

After the Ministry of Economic Affairs recently scrapped the implementation of unified oil prices in Taiwan, the CPC has authorized its gas stations to implement more liberal oil prices within a limit of NT$0.3 per liter to further elevate their competitiveness among other private producers of petroleum products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIRLINES DROPPING DOMESTIC ROUTES

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based aviation companies are facing cutthroat competition on domestic flight routes, as serious oversupply has led to persistent business losses, according to local industry sources.

The recent suspension of fight services by the Far East Air Transport Corp. (FAT) on the Taipei-Chiayi route is only the tip of the iceberg, the sources said, adding that FAT's decision to temporarily stop serving the route is an illustration that local carriers are unable to continue taking care of public transport needs as a result of a huge business crisis.

The Civil Aeronautic Administration (CAA) in May ordered four local airlines -- FAT, TransAsia Airways, Mandarin Airlines and UNI Airlines -- to slash a total of more than 100 flights per week on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route, in a bid to help secure public air traffic safety to reduce operation costs for aviation companies amid the vicious competition.

In addition to the increasingly difficult domestic routes, flights between Taiwan proper and offshore island destinations constitute another major headache for the local aviation industry. Carriers which operate flights to the Penghu islands, Green Island and Orchid Island have claimed that they might not continue to follow with the CAA's policy of serving those remote areas.

Local aviation companies said government subsidies are not enough to cover the overall losses they have sustained by operating the offshore routes. Although they have cooperated with government policy in serving these routes, they have complained that the CAA has failed in turn to earmark international routes to them as a reward.

Despite the fact that demand for new domestic airports is still running high, industry sources said subsequent developments remain to be seen as all local aviation companies are busy trimming their fleets as part of efforts to reduce costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT MEETS WITH EL SALVADORAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu held talks Monday with El Salvador Vice President Carlos Quintanilla at the Presidential Office.

Lu, who visited El Salvador last month, welcomed Quintanilla and said that since her return from the trip, she has launched various activities to introduce Latin American culture to the people of Taiwan.

She told her visitor that she is planning to set up a "Latin Square" in Taipei for an exhibition of cultural articles and special products from Latin America and "will promote correspondence between penpals" of the two countries.
Lu also said that she will urge local people to support a plan to provide care for 10,000 poor Latin American children on United Nations Children's Day on Dec. 20.
Quintanilla expressed his appreciation for the warm hospitality extended to his delegation by the ROC government and people and for Lu's plan to help the Latin American children.
He said that the main purpose of his trip is to learn from Taiwan's success, especially in the fields of agriculture and investment, as well as science and technology.
After the talks, Lu hosted a luncheon in honor of the delegation at the Taipei Guest House.
Quintanilla and other members of his delegation later made a fact-finding visit to Taoyuan in northern Taiwan to see agricultural and industrial establishments, at Lu's invitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT YOUTH SUMMIT TO BE HELD IN BEIJING, TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A cross-Taiwan Strait youth summit jointly organized by Taiwan's Tamkang University and mainland China's Chinese Academy of Social Sciences is tentatively scheduled to be held in Beijing and Taipei in December and March, respectively.

According to Wang Ming-yuan, director of the youth department of the Republic of China's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the students attending the summit will mainly discuss public issues of concern to contemporary youth and will not exclude political issues from their talks.

According to Wang, political reality dictates that the DPP cannot officially organize the summit because mainland China cannot accept his party's pro-independence platform. Therefore, he went on, the summit's Taiwan organizers will be private foundations and Tamkang University's Institute of Mainland Studies, while the DPP will only play a catalytic role.

Wang, who visited Beijing last week to work out the details of the summit with Yu Keli, deputy director of the Institute of Taiwan Studies under the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, said the academy will select its mainland delegates from various celebrated mainland Chinese centers of learning such as Peking University, Tsinghua University, Renmin University of China, and Shanghai's Fudan University.
He added that the 15 Taiwan representatives will be selected from those college students who have participated in congressional assistant training programs and youth policy training camps.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7 MAINLAND CHINESE FISHERMEN INJURED IN FIGHT WITH TAIWAN FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: Seven fishermen from mainland China were injured during a fierce clash with Taiwan fishermen off the coast of northern Taiwan Monday, according to coastguard officials in Keelung.

The officials said the Manglai, a local fishing boat registered in Suao, Ilan County, was operating Sunday in the vicinity of Chilungyu (Chilung islet) off Keelung when it rammed a floating hostel for mainland fisherman, the Mingchiang No.1.
The mainland fishermen boarded the Manglai to demand compensation from Captain Hsu Tien-chu and punched him.
Coastguard officers who rushed to the scene persuaded the two sides to make up and they agreed to sign a reconciliation agreement.

But the Manglai mobilized more fishermen Monday morning to get even with the mainland fishermen. Armed with steel bars, clubs and glass bottles, they boarded the Mingchiang No.1 and attacked the mainland fishermen, injuring seven, one of whom was hit on the leg by a signal flare.
All the injured were taken to a Keelung hospital for treatment and the coastguard sent boats to nearby areas to step up patrols.
Coastguard officials were reported to be investigating the clashes and tracking down the thugs responsible for the injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL HUMAN RIGHTS ADVISORY GROUP TO BE INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A human rights advisory group under the Presidential Office will be formally inaugurated Tuesday, with Vice President Annette Lu as its chief convener.

According to regulations governing the formation of the advisory panel unveiled by President Chen Shui-bian in September, the main missions of the group will include promoting legislation of a national human rights bill and establishment of a national human rights commission, studying human rights policy proposals, taking part in international human rights activities, promoting human rights education and reviewing Taiwan's human rights conditions.

Vice President Lu announced the 21-member roster of the new advisory group in a press conference Monday. Lu said all of the members have either been good at human rights issues or had much contribution to Taiwan's human rights development.

The members included noted writer Bo Yang; lawyer Yu Mei-nu; Chai Sung-lin, president of the Chinese Human Rights Association; Ho Teh-fen, a National Taiwan University law professor; Catholic Cardinal Paul Shan; Providence University professor Hsu Shih-kai; and Taiwan News President Yang Hsien-hung.
Lu said the group will be divided into six panels, each of which will take charge of one category of the group's six different missions.
The group will call a plenary session every four months, and, if necessary, the chief convener can call extraordinary meetings. Each panel can hold working meetings anytime.
President Chen Shui-bian will deliver a speech at the group's inaugural session to be held at the Taipei Guest House.

Bo Yang, who will head the advisory group's human rights education division, said the group will begin to sponsor "human rights weddings" from Dec. 10, also World Human Rights Day. According Bo Yang, the group plans to organize four "human rights weddings" per year.

"Those who take part in human rights weddings will be required to sign specially drawn up nuptial certificates promising to respect each other and their children with deeds rather than words," Bo Yang said, adding he hopes that next year will mark the start of a "baby boom of human rights families."

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRICITY PRICE HIKE UNLIKELY IF NUCLEAR PLANT ABANDONED: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The possibility that domestic electricity prices will be increased due to the suspension of construction of the fourth nuclear power plant is very slim, a high-ranking economic official said Monday.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the comment to reporters at the Ministry of Economic Affairs while attending a preparatory meeting for an upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit in Brunei.

Chen said that plans for substitutes for the fourth nuclear power plant, such as natural gas- or coal-fired power plants, greatly reduce the possibility that domestic electricity prices will be raised.

He elaborated that in the past, the thermal efficiency of natural gas-fired plants was only 30 percent, but the figure today can be expected to be raised to 60 percent. The cost of coal for power generation is also lower than the cost of fuel for nuclear power plants, he added.
Chen said that at present, Taiwan is not subject to regulation by the international convention on the control of carbon dioxide emissions.
Chen also cited a European Union (EU) resolution passed last year that says EU member nations cannot ease carbon dioxide emissions by building nuclear power plants.
He added that Taiwan should not confuse the fourth nuclear power plant issue with the decrease of carbon dioxide emissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 HOGS CONFIRMED TO HAVE BEEN INFECTED WITH FMD

TEXT.P: The specter of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) returned to Taiwan when five hogs in northern Taiwan were confirmed to have been affected with the disease, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday.

Lee Chin-lung, director of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health, Inspection and Quarantine, said that a veterinarian stationed at a slaughter house in Taoyuan County a day earlier found five hogs awaiting slaughter that he suspected might have been infected with FMD.
The suspect animals were immediately killed and specimens taken for further examination revealed that they had been infected with o-type FMD, bureau officials said.
Bureau officials were reported to be embarking on a large-scale tracking operation of the source of the infected hogs and to have begun quarantining livestock in areas neighboring the abattoir.

Taiwan officials killed tens of thousands of hogs in the wake of a large outbreak of FMD three years ago, dealing a huge blow to its pork export industry and almost decimating the hog raising industry.
Further cases have since been reported, but nothing as serious as the 1997 outbreak, thanks largely to the government's rigorous enforcement of a vaccination campaign in hog farms islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOPE FOR PRO-TAIWAN BILL DIMS IN US CONGRESS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: With just one week left before the adjournment of the U.S. Congress and two weeks to go before the Nov. 7 election of lawmakers, hopes for a bill aimed at strengthening military ties with Taiwan seem dim, Congress sources said Sunday.

Although backers of the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) are expected to push for its approval again in the next Congress session, its passage will hinge on whether its leading sponsor -- the Republican Party -- can control Capitol Hill and win the White House in the presidential election which will be held along with the congressional election on Nov. 7.
Republican presidential candidate George W. Bush has declared his support for the TSEA, while the Democrats Al Gore is following the line of the Clinton administration and speaking out against it.
The act, which passed the House of the Representatives overwhelmingly by 341 to 70 on Feb. 1, has been shelved ever since its arrival in the Senate.

In light of the fact that several appropriation bills are pending in the Senate over the next few days, and because the Democratic senators are not enthusiastic about the act, it is absolutely impossible that it will be put on the agenda before the adjournment, according to the sources.
The sources, who are aides to senators backing the bill, also ruled out the possibility of dismantling the act and tacking its provisions separately on to the end of related appropriation bills.

Technically, Congress, which officially ended its term in January, may reconvene to proceed with unfinished bills, but the chances of a lame-duck Congress debating such a controversial bill is almost non-existent unless there are dramatic changes in the stability prevailing across the Taiwan Strait, the sources said.

Government officials argue that closer military ties with Taipei called for in the TSEA would tilt the delicate balance Washington takes pains to maintain between Taipei and Beijing and thereby jeopardize Taiwan's security by triggering an angry response from Beijing.
Claiming that Taiwan's security is well ensured under the existing legal framework, the officials threatened to recommend that the president veto the TSEA if it should be passed by the Senate.

The act was introduced to the Senate in March by Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Jesse Helms, a Republican from North Carolina, and to the House in May by Representative Robert Torricelli, a Democrat from New Jersey.

In addition to closer military exchanges with Taiwan, the original bill also provided for the sale of Aegis missile destroyers to Taiwan. But this part was eliminated from the final version before it passed through the House of Representatives in February.
The Senate replaced its own version with the House's act after it cleared the House of Representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM TO AFFECT TAIWAN TUESDAY: CWB

TEXT.P: Tropical storm Yagi, the 19th such storm to affect the Pacific region this year, is expected to affect Taiwan Tuesday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) announced Monday.
The CWB also issued a sea warning for areas to the east and northeast of Taiwan.
The CWB said Yagi was located about 930 kilometers east of Taiwan as of 8:20 p.m. Monday and was moving in a westerly direction at a speed of 23 kilometers per hour.
Because of a concomitant cold front that will also be approaching Taiwan that day, northern and northeastern parts of Taiwan are expected to experience rain accompanied by a drop in temperature.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT'S CHANCE TO VISIT JAPAN SAID SLIM
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The chances of former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui visiting Japan this year are "almost hopeless" after the Japanese sponsor of a seminar revealed that Lee intended to apply for a Japanese visa, a major Japanese newspaper said Monday.

The Sankei Shinbum said that Japanese Senator Masakuni Murakami told the former ROC president during a visit to Taiwan in mid-September that the timing for Lee's visit to Japan was not right at that time, adding that he hoped Lee would not attend an Asian Outlook Forum conference scheduled at the end of the month in Matsumoto. Lee responded by saying that he hoped to visit Japan at another date in a private capacity.

Murakami, who is now the vice president of the Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council, a supra-party group in the Japanese parliament, then began maneuvering quietly and cautiously to try to create an environment favorable a visit to Japan by Lee later in the year.

The newspaper reported that sources related to the council had originally planned to travel to Taipei last Saturday to exchange views with the former president on his visit, but as Japanese sponsors of Asian Outlook announced last Wednesday that Lee was to apply for a visa, the issue had aroused attention and drew an immediate strong reaction from Beijing.

As Japanese Foreign Ministry became more cautious over the issue, the Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council had to suspend and review the planning of Lee's visit. The chances of Lee's visiting Japan at the end of the year are now "almost zero," according to the newspaper.
The Asian Outlook Forum was founded by a group of Taiwanese and Japanese scholars and senior business executives 12 years ago to promote substantive ROC-Japanese relations.

Over the subsequent years, the forum has held its annual conference alternately in Japan and Taiwan. As Lee ended his 12-year stint as the ROC head of the state in May, the forum has decided to disband after its 2000 annual conference and it had been hoped that he would attend.

Lee, an outspoken critic of Beijing's diplomatic squeezing of Taiwan, returned to Taiwan Sunday after attending the fourth Forum 2000 conference in Prague on the roles of science, education and religion in globalization. Forum 2000 is a think tank jointly founded by Czech President Vaclav Havel and a private Japanese foundation in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY REFUSES COMPENSATION FROM MAINLAND CHINESE MURDERERS

TEXT.P: The family of a Taiwanese councilor killed in a botched kidnap attempt during a trip to mainland China in 1998 rejected compensation Monday from her mainland Chinese murderers.

Lin Ping-hui, father of murdered Kaohsiung City councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan, told a press conference that he decided to forsake his right to demand cash compensation from his daughter's mainland murderers for "humanitarian reasons."

According to rulings by mainland China's Anshan Intermediate People's Court and the Liaoning People's High Court, the four convicted mainland murderers must jointly compensate the Lin family 452,000 renminbi (about US$54,603) in addition to receiving criminal sentences.

The mainland courts meted out harsh sentences for the four convicts -- Yang Rongsung was given the death sentence; Huang Shihdong was sentenced to life imprisonment; Zao Chuang was given a 15-year jail term; and Zhang Shihfeng was sentenced to 14 years.

Chang Ken-ming, the Lin family's lawyer, said the mainland court verdicts allow the Lin family to seek compensation by applying for the confiscation of the houses of the four convicts or other property belonging to them.
"As such a move would increase the plights of the families of the four murderers, the Lin family has decided to forsake its civil lawsuit claim for compensation," Chang said.

Lin Ti-chuan, a member of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was kidnapped during a trip to the northeastern mainland province of Liaoning in July 1998. Her captors repeatedly injected her with sedatives, resulting in an overdose that killed her at an age of 32.

The DPP, now the Republic of China's ruling party, issued a statement Monday praising the Lin family's leniency. It also recognized the mainland law enforcement officers' efforts to bring the murderers to justice.

Nevertheless, the DPP expressed its regret that the mastermind behind Lin's abduction, identified as Li Guangzhi, remains at large. "We hope mainland law enforcement authorities will make continued efforts to arrest the suspected mastermind," it added.

The DPP also called on mainland Chinese authorities to strengthen law and order and take effective measures to protect the safety and legitimate rights of Taiwan people traveling or doing business on the mainland. "We hope similar tragic cases will never happen again," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-BELGIUM ECONOMIC CONFERENCE HELD IN BRUSSELS
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The 15th Belgium-Republic of China Economic Cooperation Conference opened in Brussels Monday to discuss ways of bolstering economic cooperation between the two countries.
A 25-member delegation from Taiwan was headed by Wang Chung-yu, chairman of the Kaohsiung-based China Steel Corp.

Wang said at the opening of the conference that two-way trade between Taiwan and Belgium last year dropped 12.7 percent from the preceding year and that efforts by both sides are required to create more business opportunities.
He noted that Belgian enterprises can use Taiwan as a springboard to explore other markets in the Asia-Pacific region.

A Belgian banking expert presented a report titled "The Euro and Entrepreneurs," while the Taiwan delegation explained the criteria for foreign bidders wishing to take part in the Taiwan government's procurement projects.
Major topics discussed at the conference were focused on the fields of transportation, energy, the environment and biochemistry
A joint statement issued at the conference said that such conferences can contribute greatly to the expansion of bilateral economic and trade cooperation.
Members of the Taiwan delegation were planning to visit Belgian industrial establishments on Tuesday. The next conference will be held in Taipei in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 24, or the 26th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1632: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the Dutch microscopist who was the first man to see bacteria, is born.
1648: France and the Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War.
1861: The chief justice of California sends the first U.S. transcontinental telegram from San Francisco to President Abraham Lincoln in Washington.
1891: Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, dictator of the Dominican Republic from 1930 until his assassination on May 31, 1961, is born.
1901: Mrs. Ann Edison Taylor, 43, a teacher, is unhurt after going over Niagara Falls in a padded barrel to raise money to help pay her mortgage.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung is opened to traffic. An inauguration ceremony is held at the Taichung Park.
1922: The Irish parliament adopts a constitution for an Irish Free State.
1929: Share prices collapse as nearly 13 million shares change hands in panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange in what became known as "Black Thursday."
1931: Notorious Chicago gangster Al Capone, who has dominated organized crime for the past six years, receives an 11-year sentence and an US$80,000 fine for tax evasion.
1931: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: New Zealand aviator Jean Batten breaks the record by flying from Australia to England in just five days, 18 hours, and 18 minutes.
1944: The Japanese battleship "Musashi," one of the largest ever built, is sunk by U.S. planes during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
1945: The United Nations Charter, adopted by the San Francisco Conference in June 1945 and ratified by 26 nations, formally comes into force.
1945: Vidkun Quisling, former head of the "puppet" government established in Norway by the Nazis in 1940, is executed at Akershus Fortress in Oslo.
1957: French fashion designer Christian Dior dies at the age of 52. He was noted for his "New Look" of 1947 that emphasized narrow shoulders, tight waists, and long, full skirts.
1960: Communist China and Mali establish diplomatic ties.
1964: Northern Rhodesia becomes independent from Britain as the Republic of Zambia, with Kenneth Kaunda as president.
1976: China's Chiang Ching, who was dragged from her bedroom by armed guards on Oct. 6 and charged with treason, finds the going rough now that her late husband Mao Tse-tung is no longer around to protect her.
1986: Cheng Tsai-tien, 26, a communist Chinese pilot, lands his MiG-19 jet fighter in South Korea after flying it from mainland China's Shantung peninsula to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: American television preacher Jim Bakker is sentenced to 45 years in jail and fined US$500,000 for swindling his followers out of millions of dollars.
1990: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes a partial revision of the Corporate Law.
1999: Gerardo Rocha, rector of the University of Santo Tomas in Chile, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
KMT head expects meeting with President Chen to be broadcast.
The China Times:
The Control Yuan is mulling whether to impeach high-ranking generals over the Lafayette-class frigate procurement deal.
The United Daily News:
September jobless rate highest since 1985.
The Liberty Times:

The China Post:

The Taiwan News:
Tropical storm Yagi heads toward Taiwan.
The Taipei Times:
Illegal waste dump found in Taichung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 237.68 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its upward streak on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 237.68 points to close at 5,918.63.
Market turnover amounted to NT$106.2 billion (US$3.31 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO ONLY BUY PORK THAT HAS MET GOV'T SAFETY STANDARDS

TEXT.P: An official at the Council of Agriculture Tuesday urged the public to only buy pork that has passed government safety standards after new foot-and-mouth disease cases were reported in northern Taiwan for the first time in 18 months.

Lee Chin-lung, director of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health, Inspection, and Quarantine, noted that the bureau began on Oct. 4 to implement the scheme of stamping the surface of pork from legal slaughterhouses that had passed meat sanitation requirements. He said the system was put in place to protect the consumer's safety.

Lee said that the bureau has also assigned an additional 150-plus veterinarians to slaughterhouses and meat freezing plants around the island since July to further ensure the safety of meat for the consumer market.

Lee made the remarks after five hogs waiting to be slaughtered at a meat freezing plant in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan were found Sunday to have been infected with FMD. The hogs were then immediately put down.

COA officials said that the latent period of FMD in pigs after they have been infected is usually two to three days, adding that during that period, the infected hogs will not exhibit any symptoms of the disease. They also said that the hogs detected to have FMD this time had passed examinations at the meat market and were only found to have the disease during tests at the meat freezing plant.

COA officials began quarantining livestock in areas neighboring the meat freezing plant immediately after detection. They initially traced the origin of the infected hogs back to Yunlin, central Taiwan. The hog owner, surnamed Wu, trucked a load of 50 hogs, including the 5 infected ones, to the meat market in Taoyuan on Friday, the officials said.
COA officials said the reappearance of new FMD cases was due to hog growers' lax attitude toward vaccination or to the illegal trade in sick or dead pigs in disregard of the rights of consumers.

Taiwan slaughtered tens of thousands of hogs in the wake of a large outbreak of FMD three years ago, dealing a serious blow to its pork export industry and almost totally decimating the local hog raising industry.

Further cases have since been reported, but nothing as serious as the 1997 outbreak has occurred, thanks in large part to the government's rigorous enforcement of vaccination requirements at hog farms islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 237.68 points to close at 5,918.63.

Encouraged by an upward streak in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,701.15, and due to heavy purchases of electronics shares by investors, the index continued to go up. The bourse fluctuated between 5,933.42 and 5,645.05 during trading.

A total of 2.94 billion stocks worth NT$106.2 billion (US$3.31 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.26 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$87.42 billion (US$2.72 billion).

All the eight major categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 5.9 percent, followed by textile issues at 2.8 percent, foodstuff shares and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 2.2 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.8 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.6 percent, cement stocks and construction shares, both at 1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 445 to 104, with 70 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index future market were higher Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November moved up 250 points to close at 5,920, with 10,886 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for December gained 236 points to finish at 5,921, with 109 contracts traded, while March 2001 futures surged 274 points to close at 6,093 with two contract transactions.
June 2001 futures rose 122 points to finish at 5,997, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for September 2001 futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,670 for November, 5,685 for December, 5,819 for next March, 5,875 for next June, and 5,989 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
November TE futures moved up 19.45 points to close at 297.95, with 2,172 contract transactions, while December TE futures gained 17.4 points to finish at 296.1, with 38 contracts changing hands.
March 2001 TE futures rose 10.45 points to close at 299.45, with two contract transactions, while June 2001 TE futures increased 13.5 points to finish at 293.5, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for September 2001 TE futures.
November TF futures moved up 25.4 points to close at 757, with 953 contract transactions, while December TF futures surged 38 points to finish at 773, with seven contracts traded.
March 2001 TF futures rose 28.4 points to close at 789, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIZATION IMPORTANT TO CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: The democratization of Taiwan holds out a model for mainland China's possible political transition toward a more pluralistic society, which in the end is the most fundamental requirement for peacefully resolving cross-strait differences, noted two American experts Monday.

Bates Gill, director of the Brookings Center for Northeast Asian Studies, and Nicholas Lardy, senior fellow in the Brookings Foreign Policy Studies program, stated in an article they co-authored in the latest issue of the Brookings Review that now, as for much of the past 50 years, Taiwan is the hottest potential flash point in U.S.-PRC security relations.

"A more confident Taiwan, increasingly aware of its `separateness' from the mainland, has prompted Chinese reactions that are at best inflexible and dismissive of the changed circumstances and at worst provocative and potentially dangerous in the face of new realities," they said.
A top priority for the new U.S. administration, the experts emphasized, should be to revisit American policies toward the U.S.-PRC-Taiwan triangle.

"The fundamental U.S. interest remains unchanged -- to avoid war in the Taiwan Straits. Washington should oppose any unilateral and unprovoked declaration of independence on the part of Taiwan, as well as any use of force by China against Taiwan."

Beyond this fundamental baseline for U.S. policy, the two authors added, several other steps are necessary. First, the next administration will need to help build on and strengthen what hopeful, though cautious, momentum has been generated in the wake of Chen Shui-bian's election. It should urge both sides to devise new ways to enable direct bilateral negotiations, economic interactions, cultural exchanges, and confidence-building measures to proceed more freely.

Second, the new administration will very early in its tenure face some key decisions on Taiwan arms sales, especially regarding missile defense for the island. The United States should maintain its intention of equipping Taiwan to defend itself against potential Communist Chinese coercion and military threats as long as Beijing holds out the use of force as a possible means of resolving its differences with Taipei.

Armed with this understanding, they said, "providing lower-tier, land-based missile defenses to Taiwan is consistent with U.S. commitments under the Taiwan Relations Act and is entirely appropriate given China's continuing buildup of short- and medium-range missiles opposite Taiwan. Other follow-on sales of more capable missile defenses should await far more study of their diplomatic and military-technical implications."

The experts continued that the United States should also urge Taiwan to be more serious in developing its "passive defenses" -- such as hardening its command posts, shelters, and other key facilities -- to better withstand a possible Communist Chinese ballistic missile attack.

U.S. policy needs to operate on the understanding that the continued maturation of democracy in Taiwan "presents a small, sensitive, but nonetheless hopeful opportunity for the cross-strait relationship," they said.

"Caution and careful diplomacy here are critical: `support for democratization' cannot be equated with `support for independence.' But the next administration must earnestly and actively acknowledge the growing centrality of democratization to the Taiwan question," they concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. UNVEILS PLANS FOR FORUM ON SECURITY IN N.E. ASIA

TEXT.P: In the wake of Washington's unveiling of plans for a new international forum aimed at improving security in Northeast Asia, Mainland China stated it does not want any confrontation with the United States regarding the issue of Taiwan.

In a speech at the National Press Club in Canberra on Monday, Dr. Morton Halperin, director of policy planning in the U.S. State Department, said mainland China complained about U.S. interference in the Taiwan problem because Beijing regards it as an internal affair. But at the same time, he noted that Beijing needs U.S. support for the "one-China" policy in resolving the issue.

Speaking of the new forum, Halperin said it will be comprised of the United States, Mainland China, Russia, Japan, and both North and South Korea, saying the purpose of the forum is to improve security across the potentially explosive northern Asian region. The issue of Taiwan is expected to be excluded from the forum.
He said Washington believes that solving Northeast Asia's problems requires a separate multilateral forum as other forums, including the ASEAN Regional Forum, have proven inadequate in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIBERAL INTERNATIONAL TO DISCUSS DRAFT RESOLUTION ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Liberals from around the world will discuss, among other things, a draft resolution on Taiwan when they meet in Ottawa, Canada Oct. 26-28.

The draft resolution, proposed by the Dutch Group of Liberal International, welcomes the election of Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu as president and vice president of the Republic of China respectively as a decisive step on the path toward full democracy in Taiwan.

Taking notice of the inaugural speech of President Chen in which he stated that he will not take the initiative in changing the present status of Taiwan, and acknowledging the significant political, legal, and economic progress made in mainland China over the last several years, the document calls for a resumption of cross-strait dialogue that will lead to enhanced co-operation between the two sides based on respect for human rights and democratic principles.

The proposal rejects any suggestion that the political status quo in Taiwan can be changed in any way other than by the consent of its inhabitants, and it calls upon the international community to strengthen its ties with both mainland China and Taiwan.
It finally calls upon political parties within the Liberal International to work together closely with Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party in defending democracy on the island.

Delegates from over 60 countries, including two from Taiwan's DPP, will attend the three-day congress. The two delegates from Taiwan will be Chia-wen Yao and I-Chung Lai. Yao, also a presidential advisor, will meet with Taiwan expats in Montreal before coming to Ottawa for the Liberal International congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN, KMT CHAIR TO MEET FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The much-anticipated meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and majority opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan will be held Friday at the Presidential Office, Secretary-General to the President Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday.
Yu made the announcement after meeting with KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng.

Yu said President Chen originally planned to pay a visit to Lien at the KMT headquarters near the Presidential Office. However, Lien expressed his wish to meet Chen at the Presidential Office to show his respect for the country's head of state.

"President Chen then accepts Lien's suggestions concerning the venue and format for their meeting to signify his sincerity to seek advice from opposition party leaders," Yu said, adding that the meeting will start at 10 a.m. and be entirely open-door.
As for the agenda, Yu said President Chen will impose no limits on topics to be raised and discussed during his meeting with Lien, also a former vice president.

According to Yu, Chen expects to exchange views with Lien on relations across the Taiwan Strait, financial and economic issues, post-earthquake reconstruction, inter-party cooperation and eradication of "black gold" politics or shady connections between politics and organized crime.
Yu and Deputy Secretary-General to the President Chen Tseh-nan as well as KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng and spokesman Jason Hu will also be present at the high-profile Chen-Lien meeting.
This will be the first meeting between Chen and Lien after the March 18 presidential election, in which Lien ended third by garnering 23 percent of the vote.

Lien himself said Tuesday that he hopes to discuss issues related to the country's constitutional system during his meeting with Chen, the Republic of China's first president from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

"This is a fundamental issue related to the operation of our overall political system and governing mechanism," Lien explained, adding that he has no plans to raise proposals concerning the formation of a coalition government.

The KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20, still controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan, while the ruling DPP controls slightly less than one-third of the legislative seats. Against this background, some legislators and political observers have pitched for the formation of a coalition government to ensure smooth government operations and maintain domestic stability.

Commenting on the proposal, Lien said what the KMT is concerned is the nation's well-being and constitutional system, not acquisition of government posts. "Therefore, we have no interest in talking about the coalition government issues during Friday's talks with the president," he added.
As for financial and economic topics, Lien said he will focus on major policy issues and will present feasible strategies to help resolve current financial market woes.

As part of his efforts to end squabbles and promote rapprochement and cooperation among major domestic political parties, President Chen held closed-door meetings with the top leaders of two other opposition parties -- People First Party Chairman James Soong and New Party leader Hao Lung-pin -- last week.
