DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.028 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 32.048.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 31.992 and was traded between 31.992 and 32.105.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$531 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION ON TAIWAN'S 4TH NUKE PLANT BEHIND SCHEDULE

TEXT.P: Ongoing construction on Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant has lagged behind schedule due to the belief that the new government is in favor of scrapping the project, according to Ouyang Min-sheng, vice chairman of the Atomic Energy Council.

Despite the adverse effects of the government's anti-nuclear stance on the morale of the project crew, Ouyang said Tuesday during the 10th inspection tour of the construction site by an environmental protection supervisory committee that state-run Taiwan Power Company will continue to strive to stay on schedule and will not purposely slow down its progress.

A senior Taipower official noted that the project should be 38 percent complete at this stage but is presently only 33 percent complete, adding that if the government were to decide to finish the project, the date of completion would be delayed by six to 10 months.

Ouyang, who is a member of the traditionally anti-nuclear ruling party, said that his council cannot take on either a pro-nuclear or anti-nuclear stance and has consistently supervised the project from a professional point of view.

He went on to say that Taipower has been under a lot of pressure to make sure it upholds a high standard of quality in its construction project under the supervision of anti-nuclear organizations, environmental protection groups, and his council. He added that the public can therefore be assured of its safety.

As a member of the Democratic Progressive Party, Ouyang said that he is naturally highly rebellious and resolutely against autocratic decision-making, adding that a fair evaluation should be made on the issue of the plant's fate. As a government official, however, he added that he will have to carry out orders according to the Cabinet's policy.

The Cabinet has yet to announce a decision on the future of the nuclear plant, but Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi has already made a recommendation to halt the project following an evaluation by his ministry that many believe led to the resignation early this month of the then premier Tang Fei -- a stalwart of the pro-nuclear Kuomintang -- for his unwillingness to endorse the recommendation. The official stated reason for Tang's resignation was his ailing health.
Lin, ironically also a member of the KMT, has been stripped of his party membership for turning against the party's pro-nuclear platform.

The legislative caucuses of the opposition parties, including the KMT, the People First Party, and the New Party, arrived at a consensus Tuesday to urge Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to make a declaration on the Cabinet's stance toward the project before the government budget for fiscal year 2001 enters final evaluations at the end of the month.
However, the DPP legislative caucus disagreed with using the budget proposal as a "hostage" to "threaten" the Cabinet into making an announcement on the ultimate fate of the nuclear plant.
The KMT pointed out that if the Cabinet is not planning to go ahead with the legislature-approved budget for the nuclear power plant, then "what use is there for evaluating the next budget?"

The DPP has argued that approved budgets for the plant can be simply withheld in times of "national emergency," but the KMT maintains that the case can only be overturned in the legislature by another vote to halt the plant's construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMED FORCES COMBINED SERVICE BRANCH TO COMPLETE REDUCTION PLANS

TEXT.P: The Combined Services Force of the Republic of China Armed Forces is scheduled to complete its reduction plans in 2001, the CSF's deputy chief of staff said Tuesday.

Maj. Gen. Yao Hsi-cheng noted at a routine Defense Ministry press conference that the CSF has already completed the first two stages of the armed forces' streamlining project and is currently executing the third and final stage -- the reorganization of high-level staff and force structures.

He went on to say that a total of 191 departments and agencies under the CSF have already been cut down or merged while a total of 3,301 commissioned and non-commissioned officers and enlisted personnel -- including 13 general-grade officers -- have been retired, decommissioned, transferred to employee-status, or reassigned to military instructor positions.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS CALL FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT SHIPPING LINKS SOON

TEXT.P: Ten legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on Tuesday urged the government tration to promote the implementation of direct shipping links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait immediately.

DPP Legislators Su Huan-chih, Wong Chin-chu, Wang Tuoh, Perng Shaw-jin, Ho Chia-jong, Wang hsueh-fung, Yang chiu-hsing, Tang Jinn-chuan, Chung Chin-chiang, and Chiu Tai-san appealed for the immediate planning of direct transport links during a press conference. They called on the government not to wait until both Taipei and Beijing have joined the World Trade Organization.

Legislator Su said he has "mixed feeling" about proposing direct cross-strait shipping links as a member of the pro-independence DPP, but as this is the only viable solution to Taiwan's economic difficulties and is the key to Taiwan's globalization, as well as the most important step toward cross-strait reconciliation, he added that he has to make the proposal based on his conscience.

The substantive measures they asked the Executive Yuan to implement in the near future include the opening of cross-strait passenger shipping services, direct cross-strait telecommunications services, and the speedy construction of international airports in southern and central Taiwan. They also requested that mainland China open ports in Shanghai, Guangzhou and elsewhere for direct shipping to Taiwan.

Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said at the press conference that direct trade, postal, and transport links across the Taiwan Strait and the "mini three direct links" between Taiwan's offshore islands and mainland China are the goals of the new government.
He said that as long as there is a risk management mechanism in place, then increased trade and cultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait will be acceptable.

Chen said the new government has also felt the growing pressure with the passage of time for the establishment of such links, but he added that simply rushing things is not the way to proceed and that these goals should be accomplished according to legal procedures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM YAGI POISED TO STRIKE TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning Tuesday for tropical storm Yagi, the 19th tropical cyclone to affect the Pacific region this year, as it gathered strength and was poised to strike Taiwan the following day.

According to the CWB, Yagi's position as of 2 p.m. Tuesday was approximately 570 kilometers east of Taiwan, headed west at 19 kilometers per hour, with maximum sustained winds near its center of 28 meters per second and gusts of up to 35 meter per second.

Forecasters predicted that if Yagi stays on its current course, its center will pass through Taiwan. Yagi's current storm radius is 150 kilometers, but the CWB predicts that its area of influence will grow.

The bureau urged the public to beware of torrential rain expected to reach a peak from Wednesday afternoon to Thursday and warned people living in mountain areas to beware of mudslides and flash floods.

Traditionally, typhoons and tropical storms hitting Taiwan later than September have had devastating effects on the island when combined with winter's northeast monsoon, which brings steady rain to the windward (northeastern) side of the island.
Although Yagi is smaller than most "autumn typhoons" -- the most recent and damaging of which struck Taiwan in 1998 -- the CWB warned that the public should still take care.

Typhoons Zeb and Babs hit the island back-to-back in mid- and late-October of 1998. Zeb caused 28 deaths and agricultural losses totaling NT$5.16 billion (US$161 million), while Babs caused three deaths and agricultural losses of NT$400 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 46% OF NANTOU RESIDENTS DISSATISFIED WITH RECONSTRUCTION EFFORT

TEXT.P: Some 46.6 percent of residents in central Taiwan's Nantou county are dissatisfied with the Nantou county government's reconstruction efforts, a poll showed Tuesday.

Nantou's public opinion center conducted the survey to learn the attitude of the county's residents over one year after the magnitude 7.3 earthquake hit Taiwan Sept. 21 last year. Nantou bore the brunt of the devastating earthquake.
Although only 33.5 percent of the poll respondents said they are content with the progress of reconstruction, most gave high marks to the private groups participating in the effort.
The areas that residents are most dissatisfied with are efforts toward the reconstruction of roads and bridges, the prevention of mudslides, and the reconstruction of homes and schools.
Forty-five percent of those surveyed said they believe that it may take between three and 20 years for Nantou to return to the state it was in before the killer temblor struck.

In addition, although city and county chief elections are still more than a year away, the poll found that only 16.8 percent of the residents would support the reelection of incumbent Nantou Magistrate Pang Pai-hsien, compared with the support rating of 31.8 percent he received in the last election.
Some 36.5 percent of the respondents said they won't support Pang's reelection, and 45 percent said that they are still undecided.
The center called 1,154 people and received 735 valid samples. The poll's margin of error is 3.6 percent, according to its authors.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO WIPE OUT NON-ECONOMIC BARRIERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday his administration will do its utmost to wipe out non-economic barriers to Taiwan's sustainable economic development by promoting inter-party and cross-Taiwan Strait reconciliation.
Chen made the pledge while addressing students and faculty members at National Dong Hwa University in the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien.

Chen said he is convinced that reconciliation among major domestic political parties and between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can gradually remove non-economic barriers to Taiwan's economic development.

Noting that his recent meetings with the top leaders of major opposition parties were first steps to forge inter-party rapprochement and reconciliation, Chen said he will make continued efforts to improve inter-party relations to ensure smooth government operations and upgrade administrative efficiency.

In addition, Chen said his administration will continue sparing no efforts to seek a breakthrough to the long-stalled relations across the Taiwan Strait. "We believe a thaw in cross-strait relations will help maintain peace in the Asia-Pacific region and clear away non-economic obstacles to our economic development," he added.

Chen, the Republic of China's first president from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said his administration has given the top priority to sustaining the island's economic development.

"We have unveiled many measures to revive domestic economic vitality and will continue working out strategies to help local enterprises expand their business empire while keeping business roots in Taiwan," Chen stressed.

After an inspection tour of the Dong Hwa University's biotechnology development center, Chen said he hopes the center can help boost the development of biotechnology industry and overall economy in eastern Taiwan.

Quoting government tallies, Chen said Taiwan's annual biotechnology industry production amounted to NT$16.2 billion (US$514.29 million) in 1998 and is expected to reach NT$90 billion by 2006. "We believe that the Dong Hwa University biotech center will play a leading role in bolstering Taiwan's biotechnology development and upgrading eastern Taiwan's overall economic development," he explained.
Later in the day, Chen inspected an eastern Taiwan railway improvement project aimed at modernizing the 337 km-railway comprising the Ilan line, North Link line and the Hualien-Taitung line.

Chen demanded that the renovation project, launched in July 1991, be completed in June 2003 as scheduled. Chen said the NT$48.64 billion project is expected to help facilitate exploration of resources in eastern Taiwan and balance development in eastern and western parts of the island.
The improvements will include electrification, double tracks, heavy rails, a centralized traffic control system, new locomotives, repair facilities and the relocation of the Hualien depot.

President Chen also paid a visit to Mennonite Hospital in Hualien before ending his eastern Taiwan inspection tour. Chen was briefed on the hospital's elderly people long-term medical services and community daycare programs.
Chen expressed his admiration for the Christian hospital's contribution to the upgrading of medical services in eastern Taiwan, particularly in remote aboriginal communities, over past decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN WHEELCHAIR SPORTS FEDERATION TO BE HEADED BY ROC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Asian Wheelchair Sports Federation was formally established Tuesday, with Lai Fu-huan, deputy chairman of the Republic of China's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, elected as its chairman.
A total of 25 representatives representing 13 countries in the region took part in the federation's founding ceremony in Sydney.

The delegate representing mainland China walked out during the ceremony in protest over the election of an official from Taiwan, but the rest of the delegates insisted on completing the meeting, which approved the association's charter and agenda, according to news reports from Sydney.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPLIED MATERIAL EXECUTIVE OPTIMISTIC ABOUT SEMICONDUCTOR SECTOR (I)

TEXT.P: Global demand for semiconductors will remain strong, and the outlook for the industry is bright, a United States-based industry leader said recently.

Ashok K. Sinha, president of the Interconnect Systems and Modules Business Group under the U.S.-based Applied Material, told CNA that he wholeheartedly agrees with remarks made by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) Chairman Morris Chang that there will be no cloud to cast a shadow over the semiconductor industry's future in the coming 20 years.
Sinha, however, pointed out that an increasing lack of semiconductor devices such as resistors and capacitors will be the prime obstacle facing the industry in the future.

He also warned that mainland China may pose a major threat to Taiwan within three years if Taiwan fails to integrate its expertise and management experience with mainland companies and the island fails to obtain a leadership role in the sector.
Following is the full text of the interview with Sinha:
Q: As more and more companies have joined the rush to build plants to produce 12-inch silicon wafers, do you think that will lead to a problem of oversupply?

A: I am not worried about this problem at all. The marketing of 12-inch wafers is aimed at reducing production costs and increasing the output of chips to meet market demand. I think that demand for semiconductors will continue to grow quickly due to new types of applications of the Internet, cellular phones, digital televisions, and consumer electronic products. Demand will still surpass supply in the market.

There are three major noteworthy trends in the coming century. First, the approach of the 0.1 micron process; second, the development of copper interconnectors; and third, the replacement of 8-inch silicon wafers with 12-inch types.

According to Moore's Law, each three-year period represents a generation in the semiconductor process, while the development of semiconductors' size usually takes 10 years from one size to another. The development of new processing materials, such as the use of copper to make interconnectors, may take 30 years.
The occurrence of all three events in this century will have a significant impact on the development of the semiconductor industry.

The plants which are being built at the moment -- most of which are 12-inch wafer production facilities -- will start mass production next year, and I predict that the output of 12-inch wafers will account for more than 50 percent of the world's total silicon wafer production within five years.

In addition, the technology of copper interconnectors is also expected to become a leading trend in five years. The technology will be extensively applied in highly efficient and low power-consumption chips. With regard to the 0.1 micron process, the technology will be still some way off in five years, as lithography remains a very difficult technology. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: APPLIED MATERIAL EXECUTIVE OPTIMISTIC ABOUT SEMICONDUCTOR SECTOR (II)

TEXT.P: Q: Is there any concrete proof to support your theory that demand for semiconductors will continue to remain strong?

A: Production value of the global electronics industry will exceed the level of US$1 trillion for the first time to reach US$1.35 trillion this year, up a record 7 percent from the level posted in 1999.

Demand for personal computers is expected to hit 1.4 billion units across the world this year, while global output of mobile phones is estimated at 4 billion units. The output of the world semiconductor sector will be worth US$195.8 billion in 2000, accounting for 18.9 percent of the entire electronics industry.

A booming electronics industry will also drive the semiconductor sector to continued growth, as capitalization spending in the semiconductor industry is forecast to increase by 68.8 percent this year, also a historic high.

Q: Do you agree with the remarks made by TSMC Chairman Morris Chang that "there will be no cloud overshadowing the future of the semiconductor industry in the 20 years ahead?" Do you think that such worries really do not exist in light of an analysis made by Salomon Smith Barney in July this year that offers a negative view of the industry's future?

A: I do agree with Chang's remarks, and I am optimistic about the prospects for the semiconductor industry. Stock analysts only set their eyes on short-term profits. Judging from a long-term basis, I believe that there will not be an oversupply of semiconductors, demand for which will jump noticeably as a result of many new Internet-related applications.

As to the looming lack of devices such as capacitors and resistors, I think this situation will deteriorate next year, because increased production of these elements takes time. As the semiconductor sector is a closely integrated industry, up-stream and down-stream companies rely heavily on one another. That means a lack of certain devices will affect the entire production process, even though many orders are already in the works.

Q: As global capital expenditure in the semiconductor industry is estimated to hit a record high of US$55.1 billion this year -- a 27.1 percent rise over 1999 -- do you think that will have an impact on Taiwan's status in this sector? What do you think of the world's capital movements next year?

A: Taiwan capital spending will account for 20 percent of the world's total expenditure in this sector this year, making the island probably the world's second-largest investor after the United States. I have predicted that the world's capital allocation will slow down in 2001 and increase by a moderate 28 percent.

However, global spending in DRAM is likely to expand markedly next year as world demand for DRAM will continue to grow due to a recovering world economy and the development of electronics products. After a two-year halt in investment in this field, Japan and South Korea are expected to largely expand their DRAM output in 2001, a move which may worsen business conditions in 2002.

Q: What is your opinion about an ongoing mainland China investment fever among Taiwan businesses, as many local semiconductor makers have relocated to the mainland. Do you think that mainland China's semiconductor industry will threaten the local sector?

A: Taiwan is strong in manufacturing and business management. If Taiwan can share its expertise and experience with mainland China, coupled with the mainland's production capabilities, then Taiwan will be able to achieve a leadership role in the world's semiconductor industry.
In my judgment, the mainland's semiconductor industry is likely to pose a threat to the Taiwan industry within three years should Taiwan fail to seize the present opportunity.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOSCOW CITY BALLET PERFORMS IN HSINCHU, NORTHERN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The world-renowned Moscow City Ballet is to perform Swan Lake at the Hsinchu City Cultural Center Wednesday.
Since its founding in 1989, the Moscow City Ballet has made numerous performances around the world and has been invited to perform in Taiwan several times.

The Moscow City Ballet, which is considered to be on a per with the New York City Ballet, includes in its repertoire works such as Swan Lake, Sleeping Beauty, Don Quixote, Giselle, Cinderella, and Nutcracker Suite.
The Moscow City Ballet will also perform in Taichung, central Taiwan, on Thursday and Friday; in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, on Saturday and Sunday; and in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, on Oct. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUILD ROC INTO `PERFECT DEMOCRACY,' URGES PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the people of Taiwan Tuesday to work together to develop the Republic of China into a country characterized by perfect democracy, rule of law and human rights.
Chen made the appeal in a keynote speech delivered at the inaugural ceremony for the President's Advisory Group on Human Rights.
Noting that human rights, rule of law and democracy are the three pillars of a modern country, Chen said protection of human rights is a measurement of the legitimacy of a constitutional democracy.
"I'm hopeful that the ROC can become a country blessed with perfect democracy, rule of law and human rights through concerted efforts of all residents on the island," Chen said.
He expressed his admiration and respect for people of Taiwan who have been jailed or endured other suffering in the name of promoting Taiwan's democratization and human rights development.

Quoting Bo Yang, a noted writer who spent some 10 years in jail for his commitment to democracy on the island during the era of martial law, Chen said past mistakes can be tolerated and forgiven, but should not be forgotten.

"Those who forget previous mistakes are likely to repeat their past wrongdoings. We must explore, record and reflect on past events, learn lessons from previous mistakes and continue moving forward," Chen stressed.
As human rights form the core and basis of a constitutional country, Chen went on, Taiwan must address human rights issues on three dimensions.
First of all, he said, Taiwan should promote human rights consciousness and education at various levels, from schools to on-the-job training for public functionaries and professionals.
Second, Chen said, Taiwan must introduce international human rights standards to upgrade its human rights concepts and guideposts.
Third, he continued, Taiwan must enshrine a comprehensive human rights protection and promotional mechanism.

Chen, the ROC's first president from the Democratic Progressive Party, further said that his professional experience as a lawyer has made him fully aware that human rights protection cannot solely rely on law, because no matter how perfect legal regulations are, they leave room more or less for law enforcement officers to act on their discretion.

"How this discretion is exercised hinges on law enforcement officers' human rights concepts and standards," Chen said, adding that he hopes Taiwan can set up a human rights research center to upgrade its overall human rights standards.

Noting that the ROC completed its first-ever peaceful transition of power between different political parties in May, Chen said he is hopeful that the formation of the new human rights advisory group will facilitate the promotion of human rights education, legislation and policy formulation.

Speaking on the same occasion, Vice President Annette Lu, who concurrently serves as chief convener of the human rights advisory group, said the group will dedicate itself to defending the dignity and human rights of the 23 million people of Taiwan.

Lu, who was once jailed for her pro-democracy activities during the martial law era, said the period from Dec. 4-10 will be designated as Taiwan's "human rights week," when a series of seminars and exhibitions will be held in major cities around the island to promote human rights education.

According to regulations governing the formation of the advisory panel unveiled by Chen in September, the main missions of the group will include promoting legislation of a national human rights bill and the establishment of a national human rights commission, studying human rights policy proposals, taking part in international human rights activities, promoting human rights education and reviewing Taiwan's human rights conditions.

The group is composed of 21 members noted for their expertise in human rights and contributions to Taiwan's human rights development. The members include Bo Yang; lawyer Yu Mei-nu; Chai Sung-lin, president of the Chinese Human Rights Association; Ho Teh-fen, a National Taiwan University law professor; Catholic Cardinal Paul Shan; Providence University professor Hsu Shih-kai; and Taiwan News President Yang Hsien-hung.

The group will hold a plenary session every four months, and if necessary, the chief convener can call extraordinary meetings. The members will be divided into six panels, each of which can hold working meetings at any time.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DEPUTY REPRESENTATIVE TO U.S. TO ASSUME POST NOV. 1

TEXT.P: Taiwan's newly appointed deputy representative to the United States, Lee Ying-yuan, is scheduled to leave Friday for Washington, D.C. to assume his post.

In an exclusive interview with CNA, Lee, a Democratic Progressive Party legislator before being appointed to the deputy representative post, said his top priority in his new job in the U.S. capital is to accelerate exchanges of visits by ministerial-level officials from Taiwan and the United States.

If the two countries cannot exchange visits by ministerial-level officials in the near future because of the political situation, Lee said, he will see to it that at least exchanges between vice ministerial-level officials become more frequent.

He also suggested that Taiwan's government-run or private academic and research institutes should increase their exchanges with U.S.-based think tanks so as to help open up communication channels between the two countries. This could help the government expand contacts with the United States from "points" to "lines" and even "spheres," he added.

Describing his new job as "highly challenging," Lee said he will do his utmost to collaborate with Chen Chien-jen, Taipei's chief representative in the United States, in an effort to further effect Taiwan's diplomatic front in the United States.
Lee visited the Legislative Yuan Tuesday to seek support in his new position from legislators from the ruling and opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO CHILE TO SEEK STRENGTHENED BILATERAL TIES

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Republic of China Representative to Chile Francisco Huang was scheduled to leave Wednesday for Santiago, Chile, to assume his duties.

In an exclusive interview with CNA, Huang said that he will do what he can to strengthen relations between the ROC and Chile. He will also make efforts to promote economic and cultural, as well as tourism interchanges, between the two countries, he added.
Huang, a career diplomat and an expert on Latin American affairs, will replace Steven F. Wang, who will be reassigned.
He noted that the people of Taiwan know little about Chile, which is located on the western coast of South America, separated from neighboring Argentina by the Andes mountain range.

The ex-chief of the Protocol Bureau of the Presidential Office described Chile as a potential market for ROC tourists and investors. He said he will try his best to explore the market by inviting ROC tourists and investors to travel to the country and invest there.

He said he will also promote academic interchanges between the two countries and revealed that National University of Chile will shortly enter into sisterhood ties with Tamkang University. The two universities will arrange interchanges of professors and students with the aim of promoting better bilateral understanding.

Huang said that he will also promote cultural interchanges by inviting Chilean and Chinese painters to hold alternate exhibitions in Taiwan and Santiago. He also pointed out that several local artists have already taught Chinese painting in Santiago.
Chile, with a population of 14 million, is 21 times the size of Taiwan.
Two-way trade totaled US$860 million in 1998, with copper, seafood, timber and fruit listed as Chile's main exports to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYMPOSIUM ON TAIWAN DEMOCRACY HELD IN WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A former White House official said at a symposium in Washington Monday that the Taipei government should eliminate uncertainty in its policy toward mainland China.
Douglas Paal, who worked for the Reagan and Bush administrations, also suggested that the new U.S. government that will be inaugurated next January strengthen high-level interaction with Taipei.

Speaking at the symposium on "the new era of Taiwan democracy," Paal noted that such unexpected incidents as former President Lee Teng-hui's 1995 visit to the United States and his 1999 statement redefining Taiwan's ties with the mainland as a "special state-to-state relationship" toughened Beijing's stance against Taiwan.

Therefore, he suggested, the government under President Chen Shui-bian should take steps to eliminate the element of surprise and uncertainty over cross-Taiwan Strait relations in exchange for time for negotiations with Beijing.

Former U.S. Ambassador to Beijing James Lilley told the symposium that Taiwan should not ignore the threat from mainland China and added that it is important for Taiwan to pay attention to trends and follow the trends of history.
He said that Beijing talks about democracy and human right and added that Taipei should follow this trend to encourage the mainland to develop in the right direction.
Another American participant said that Washington should continue to honor the Taiwan Relations Act and should enhance military exchanges with Taiwan.

Three participants from Taipei -- Lin Chia-lung, Cheng Yu-ping and Sheng Chih-jen -- also reported on Taiwan's political development since the inauguration of the Democratic Progressive Party administration last May.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST 9 MONTHS INBOUND INVESTMENT SETS NEW RECORD

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese and foreign investment in Taiwan in the first nine months of this year totaled US$5.5 billion, an increase of 110 percent over the same period of the previous year, an official of the Investment Commission said Tuesday.
The figure also broke the US$4.27 billion recorded for the whole of 1997, the official added.

In the month of September alone, a total of 113 investment cases were approved, 17 percent less than for the same period of the previous year. However, in terms of value, approved investment totaled US$567 million, an increase of 14 percent, the official said.
He attributed the year's increase to the opening of the domestic telecommunications market.
Garmin Ltd. of the British Cayman Islands remitted US$88.48 million to invest in a Taiwan company, the biggest single investment for the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5.1-MAGNITUDE QUAKE JOLTS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 5.1 on the Richter scale jolted Taiwan Tuesday, but there were no reports of casualties or damage, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

The quake hit at 3:11 p.m. and its seismic center was recorded at 23.93 degrees north, 121.47 degrees east, about 13.5 kilometers north of the island's Hsilin seismology post in Hualien, eastern Taiwan. It originated 19 kilometers under the earth's surface, according to CWB officials.

The quake's intensity around the island was recorded as four in Taroko, Hualien County, and Hualien City; three in Nanshan, Ilan County; two in Sun-Moon Lake, Nantou County; and one in Chupei, Hsinchu County; Taichung City; and Chiayi City.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INTERNET FIRMS WILL JOIN MERGER TREND NEXT YEAR: SURVEY

TEXT.P: A recent survey by the Wintel public opinion survey agency shows that many Taiwan Internet companies will exhaust their funding in the first half of next year.
As a result, the agency predicts that many Internet firms will go bankrupt or merge with others in order to survive in the second half of next year.
The survey was conducted among 461 corporations with a response rate of 62 percent.
Seventy-eight percent of the respondents said that mergers will be the future trend among Internet companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE RETIRED ADMIRALS IMPEACHED OVER FRIGATE PROCUREMENT SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Three former high-ranking generals from the Republic of China Navy were impeached Tuesday by the Control Yuan for their connection with Taiwan's purchase of Lafayette-class frigates 10 years ago.

Admiral Yeh Chang-tung, former navy commander-in-chief, Vice Admiral Lei Shueh-ming, former director of the navy's Fleet Control Office and Yao Neng-chun, former director of the navy's Arms Acquisition Office, were accused by a five-member Control Yuan task force of negligence leading to the procurement scandal.
Former Chief of the General Staff Hao Pei-tsun and Admiral Hsia Tien, who is currently Taiwan's representative to Austria, were not on the impeachment list, contrary to rumors circulated Sunday.

The impeachment list was made public late Tuesday after 11 members of the Control Yuan, the ROC's highest-level watchdog body, had a six-hour discussion of the impeachment list recommended by the five Control Yuan members who investigated the case.

The five Control Yuan members -- Kang Ning-hsiang, Ma Yi-kung, Chao Jong-yao, Lin Chiu-shan and Ku Teng-mei -- had recommended earlier in the day that six former high-ranking military officials be impeached.

The long-running investigation by the Control Yuan task force was prompted by the murder of naval Captain Yin Ching-feng six years ago and the relationship between his death and the navy's arms procurements.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER REGRETS IMPEACHMENT OF THREE RETIRED ADMIRALS

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Premier Hau Pei-tsun issued a statement Tuesday expressing regret that three of his former colleagues in the ROC Navy have been impeached for their connection with an arms purchase scandal 10 years ago.
Hau, who served as chief of the General Staff for eight years, was also questioned over the case by a Control Yuan task force on Oct. 5, but escaped impeachment.

He said in his statement that "some scandals might have occurred" in the process of price negotiations and payments, but that this did not mean that the decision to buy French Lafayette-class missile frigates was a wrong decision.
Hau affirmed the "wise decision" of the Control Yuan not to impeach him, but expressed regret over the impeachment of the three retired naval officers.
He stressed that he believes the three impeached officers are clean and capable, and expressed hope that related government agencies will carefully examine the case and clear their names.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 105.15 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its upward streak on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 105.15 points to close at 6,023.78.
Market turnover amounted to 107.96 billion (US$3.37 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 25, or the 27th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1825: The Erie Canal, which connects the Great Lakes with New York City via the Hudson River, is opened, assuring the future prosperity of the upper Midwest region of the United States.
1825: Johann Strauss the Younger, Austrian composer, is born. He is best known for his waltzes, such as the ever-popular "The Blue Danube," and for operettas such as "Die Fledermaus."
1881: Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter, sculptor, graphic artist, ceramist, and designer, is born. He became one of the greatest and most versatile 20th-century artists.
1909: Prince Ito Hirobumi, former Japanese premier and resident-general in Korea, is assassinated by a Korean nationalist.
1914: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China, marries Soong Ching-ling in Tokyo, Japan.
1928: The National government begins to implement the five-yuan system -- Executive Yuan (the Cabinet), Legislative Yuan, Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan, and Control Yuan.
1936: Leaders from Germany and Italy meet to form the Berlin-Rome Axis, providing mutual assistance and opposition to communism.
1938: Chinese troops evacuate Wuchang and Hankow during the War of Resistance against Japan.
1938: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini formally declares Libya a part of Italy after years of slowly colonizing the country.
1945: Taiwan is formally retroceded to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation. Chen Yi receives the formal surrender of Japanese rulers at a ceremony held at the Chung Shan Hall. The National government declares Oct. 25 as Taiwan's Retrocession Day.
1945: In order to obstruct ROC troops from entering Manchuria, the Soviet Union "voluntarily" pulls out its garrison troops from Yingkow, and allows Chinese communist troops to occupy Yingkow, a city in southern Liaoning Province.
1949: Government troops win a victory at Kinmen (Quemoy) against a Communist Chinese attack.
1950: Beijing launches a movement to resist U.S. aggression and to aid North Korea and Chinese Communist "volunteer-troops" formally entering North Korea to join the Korean War.
1951: The Korean conflict truce talks, which began July 10 at Kaesong after Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, acting on instructions from Washington, suggested a meeting between Allied and communist military officers to discuss a truce, are moved to Panmunjom.
1952: The United States blocks Communist China's entry into the United Nations for the third year in a row.
1966: The first open school in Taiwan is inaugurated at the Provincial Taipei College of Business.
1975: The China External Trade Development Council and the Chamber of Industry of Uruguay sign a cooperation agreement.
1976: An eight-member delegation leaves for the United States to attend the first World Conference on Agricultural Education for Youth and Adult Leaders.
1979: Military personnel and civilians in Kinmen take part in celebrating the 30th anniversary of the Kuningtou victory.
1985: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to implement health insurance for farmers.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek returns from the United States for a celebration marking the centennial anniversary of the birth of the late president.
1986: The 1986 Taiwan Area Athletic Meet opens in Kaohsiung.
1988: A comprehensive farmer health insurance plan is initiated.
1996: Israel begins redeployment of its West Bank troops to further a peace deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1999: Former U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decision and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "A great man is one who has not lost the child's heart."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 105.15 points to close at 6,023.78.

Affected by a drop in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 5,914.37, but due to a hike in semiconductor stock prices and communications shares after purchases made by government funds, share prices began to go up. The bourse fluctuated between 6,035.17 and 5,898.97 during trading.

A total of 2.91 billion stocks worth NT$107.96 billion (US$3.37 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.94 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$106.2 billion (US$3.31 billion).

Half of the eight major categories posted losses, with foodstuff shares and construction stocks moving down the most, both at 1.6 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 1.1 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 3.2 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.4 percent, cement stocks at 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 328 to 212, with 78 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally higher Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November moved up 52 points to close at 5,972, with 7,669 contracts traded.
TAIEX Index futures for December gained 39 points to finish at 5,960, with 60 contracts traded, while March 2001 futures lost 42 points to close at 6,051, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,920 for November, 5,921 for December, 6,093 for next March, 6,003 for next June, and 6,239 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
November TE futures moved up 5.05 points to close at 303, with 2,715 contract transactions, while December TE futures gained 5.9 points to finish at 302, with 35 contracts changing hands.
June 2001 TE futures rose 4 points to close at 297.5 with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures moved up 19 points to close at 776, with 1,642 contract transactions, while December TF futures gained 3 points to finish at 776, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.
