DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER CONFIRMS FORMOSA PLASTICS' M'LAND INVESTMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Wednesday that he will meet with executives of the Formosa Plastics Group in a week to gain a better understanding of the business conglomerate's latest plans on investment in mainland China.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Lin said he has learned that the FPG is planning to develop a PVC manufacturing complex on Meishan Island of Ningbo, Zhejiang Province at an estimated cost of US$100 million, contrary to rumors circulated previously that the group was planning to develop a naphtha cracking plant on the mainland.

Lin said that although FPG President Wang Yung-tsai has openly claimed that the group has no other choice but to invest in mainland China for long-term and sustainable development, the FPG has not yet filed any applications with the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs for its new mainland-bound investment projects.

Noting that the FPG plans to invest US$100 million in a PVC plant project on Meishan Island, Wang said recently that the FPG is "leaving" Taiwan mainly because of its labor shortages, problems with foreign laborers, public utilities instability, and the government's decision to shorten the workweek.

Wang, who has just returned from a fact-finding trip to the mainland, said mainland China's overall investment environment has improved remarkably fast over the past four years and is thriving. And in addition to mainland China's cheap real estate and labor costs, the mainland authorities are also offering investment incentives to Taiwanese business groups who are interested in developing the petrochemical industry, he added.
Meanwhile, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang urged Taiwan business groups to consider carefully any plans to invest in mainland China.

Yen said that despite the mainland's low-cost real estate and cheap labor, raw materials, and public utilities, the concealed risks to foreign businesses operating in mainland China are present and real.

He said Taiwanese businesses must take to heart the hidden risks, including the fact that listed companies on the mainland are not allowed to sell their own stocks freely, before they decide to proceed to invest there.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIR NOT OPPOSED TO MEETING MAINLAND PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday he does not rule out the possibility of meeting mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to help break the long-stalled relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Lien was responding to a suggestion by Legislator Pan Wei-kang, also a KMT Central Standing Committee (CSC) member, that the KMT take the initiative to promote party-to-party exchanges with the Chinese Communist Party to boost mutual understanding and prevent miscalculation of the cross-strait situation.

Speaking at a weekly CSC meeting, Pan said she is worried that some senior ROC government officials' recent remarks concerning the sensitive cross-strait issues may cause miscalculation on the part of mainland authorities and thus affect stability in the Taiwan Strait.

"As the Republic of China's largest opposition party, the KMT should not sit idly and should instead take steps to help forge cross-strait rapprochement," Pan said, adding that the KMT should send its top official in charge of mainland research, chang Jung-kung, to visit mainland China to promote party-to-party exchanges with the Chinese Communist Party (CCP).

Pan said more than half of the 117 KMT legislators have thrown support behind her calls for KMT-CCP exchanges and a meeting between Lien and Jian, who concurrently serves as the CCP general secretary.
Responding to Pan's proposals, Lien said he has on many occasions expressed the KMT's determination to play a more active role in the development of cross-strait relations.

As part of its efforts in this regard, Lien said, KMT think tanks will sponsor a series of seminars in Taiwan, mainland China or third places to discuss issues related to the signing of a cross-strait peace agreement and the formation of a cross-strait peace zone.

Lien, also a former ROC vice president, further said since the KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20, is no longer a ruling party, it now has greater room to work for cross-strait rapprochement. The KMT still controls a comfortable majority in the Legislative Yuan.

Lien said he does not oppose talks with the top Chinese Communist Party leader. "Nevertheless, a Lien-Jiang meeting will certainly involve many complex issues, we need further studies before a decision can be made," Lien explained, adding that he will ask the KMT's policy research department to study the proposal.

At Wednesday's meeting, KMT CSC members also passed five recommendations for the agenda of Lien's scheduled meeting with President Chen Shui-bian on Friday -- continued construction of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant; upholding the Meinung reservoir project; upholding the 1992 consensus on "one China, separation interpretation"; supporting eradication of "black gold" politics; and respecting human rights, press freedom and proper procedures in anti-"black gold" operations.
The high-profile Chen-Lien meeting will be held at the Presidential Office at 10 a.m. Friday in an open-door format.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER MAY REPRESENT ROC AT APEC LEADERSHIP MEETING

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will send former Premier Vincent Siew to attend the informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum scheduled for next month in Brunei, government sources said Wednesday.
The sources said that the ROC government has informed Brunei of its choice of representative and is now awaiting a reply from Brunei.
President Chen Shui-bian had originally wanted to send Vice Premier Lai In-jaw to attend the summit meeting on his behalf, and the Brunei authorities accepted Taipei's decision.
However, due to intervention by mainland China, Brunei later informed the ROC government that Beijing's opposition to the selection of Lai had put Brunei in an awkward position.

Sources said the Presidential Office had considered such alternatives as chairman Jeffrey Koo of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce; Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica; and Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of China, but had decided on Siew after taking into consideration many different factors.
Siew, currently serving as the vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, had attended similar APEC meetings in 1993 and 1994 on behalf of the ROC president at the time, Lee Teng-hui.
Siew said that President Chen did ask him last week about attending the APEC meeting on his behalf and that he has informed KMT Chairman Lien Chan about the matter.
Lien said that with the nation's interests as its top priority, the party is willing to comply with the request, although he said that the matter must be discussed between the two parties.
Meanwhile, the KMT caucus in the Legislative Yuan said Siew is a suitable candidate to represent the ROC at the APEC meeting.
Legislator Chiang Chi-wen said that Siew has a lot of experience in financial and economic matters and that she hopes Siew will accept the invitation without hesitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SECURITY SYSTEM READY FOR `MINI THREE LINKS' SAYS NSB HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's national security system is ready for the government's plan to allow Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu to launch the "three mini links" with mainland China, said National Security Bureau Chief Ting Yu-chou on Wednesday.

The NSB has completed planning on measures to safeguard national security, including personnel training, the establishment of relevant facilities at appointed ports, the establishment of inspection and surveillance points, and the completion of other related arrangements, Ting noted.

After long discussions and debates, the government decided recently to open direct trade, mail, and transportation links between Kinmen and Matsu and selected mainland Chinese coastal cities as part of its efforts to forge cross-strait rapprochement.

Ting noted that although the related security planning has been mapped out, the question of funding the implementation of the plans is still up in the air as the costs were not included in the government's budget plan for this year.

Ting, however, said a concrete plan on the much discussed "direct three links" -- direct trade, mail, and transportation links between Taiwan proper and mainland China -- still requires the input of a lot of time, wisdom, and careful assessment as it involves serious national security concerns and other vital issues.

Meanwhile, in Kinmen, where the mood recently has been upbeat in preparation for the implementation of the "mini three links," a two-day seminar on tourism promotion kicked off Wednesday as part of efforts to usher in a "new era" of business prosperity.
Some 200 people are attending the seminar, which is focusing discussions on five areas of business -- tourism, hotels and restaurants, tour buses, dining, and sales of folk products and souvenirs.

Addressing the opening of the seminar, Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Tah-jen said that if the "mini three links" are planned and implemented well, they will create a second spring of prosperity for Kinmen.

Under the government's "mini three links" plan, up to 700 mainland Chinese citizens will be allowed to arrive in Kinmen per day for business or pleasure, while a maximum of 150 mainland citizens per day will be able to visit the smaller Matsu.

In related news, quarantine sources from Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan suggested Wednesday that the government reinforce quarantine efforts in Kinmen and Matsu as waves of people, products, and even animals from mainland China are due to land there in a couple of months.

Chang Shien-ching, director of the Kaohsiung County Animal Quarantine Department, urged the government to pay extra attention to the possible threat of animal diseases or epidemics from mainland China after the implementation of the "mini three links."

Chang noted that while related quarantine agencies in Taiwan proper are capable of controlling the O-type foot-and-mouth disease, which is endemic to Taiwan, many other types of FMD virus originating from mainland China will easily be able to be brought into Taiwan via Kinmen and Matsu once the two outpost bases open there gates to mainland Chinese imports, thus posing a serious challenge to Taiwan's quarantine system.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS FOR OCTOBER EXPECTED TO SET RECORD 1-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The total value of exports for October is expected to hit US$13.7 billion, setting a new record high for a single month, the Ministry of Finance predicted Wednesday.

The officials said that in the first part of October, exports totaled US$9.3 billion, while imports amounted to US$8.59 billion, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of US$710 million. The figures show that Taiwan's exports have continued to be brisk during the first half of October.
As the price of agricultural and industrial raw materials rose rapidly in October, growth in the total value of imports began to slow down in the first half of October.
Looking ahead, the officials said that if the price of world crude oil stabilizes and the global economy continues its stable growth, then exports are expected to continue to grow.
They estimated that exports and imports in October will grow by 20.6 percent and 15.5 percent from the same month last year respectively.

They also predicted that growth in the total value of exports this year will hit 23.3 percent, while growth in the total value of imports will likely hit between 27 percent and 28 percent, or slightly lower than the estimated figures released earlier by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.024 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 32.072.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 31.989 and was traded between 31.989 and 32.100.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$463.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND PUBLISHING GROUP HEAD ARRIVES IN TAIPEI TO PROMOTE EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Zhao Jiqing, head of a publishing group in mainland China, arrived in Taipei Monday night for a two-week visit to promote exchanges between the publishing industries on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The president of China Light Industry Press was invited to visit by the Magazine Business Association of Taipei.

China Light Industry Press has actively engaged in international exchanges in recent years and has established extensive contacts with the publishing industries in Taiwan, Japan, the United States, Germany, France, the Netherlands, Singapore, and Hong Kong.
Zhao's press, which was founded in October 1954, has in recent years focused on publications dealing with fashion, nutrition and health, and decorative designs.
The Magazine Business Association of Taipei will sponsor a seminar Friday on exploring the possibility of cooperation between the publishing industries of mainland China and Taiwan.

Participants in the seminar are expected to give an introduction to the present publishing environment on the mainland, foreign investment in the publishing business, models of cooperation, and also discuss possible magazine industry developments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB FORMALLY CEASES CONTROVERSIAL `POLITICAL SURVEILLANCE' WORK

TEXT.P: Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) Director Wang Kuang-yu said Wednesday that the bureau has been formally freed from the responsibility of carrying out controversial "political surveillance" work.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Wang said Premier Chang Chun-hsiung had already approved a revision to the MJIB's duties, freeing the bureau of the work of monitoring the activities of major domestic political parties and local factions, as well as suspected wrongdoing by various government agencies.

Wang told lawmakers that the so-called "political surveillance" was originally included in the MJIB's "national conditions survey." After the revision of the bureau's work content, Wang said, the "national conditions survey" has been redesignated as the "domestic security survey."

According to the revised MJIB work rules, Wang said, the "domestic security survey" will comprise 21 items in six categories, including mainland China's Taiwan-targeted activities; unfriendly activities of foreign nationals; unconstitutional and unlawful activities; financial and economic activities; science and technology development; information security; social stability; early warning of threats to domestic public order; and other activities that may affect national security.

Wang said the scrapping of surveillance of political parties, factions and individual political figures and of suspected wrongdoing by government agencies from the "domestic security survey" complies with general public opinion and democratic trends.

Noting that national security is critical to Taiwan's survival, Wang said the MJIB is an integral part of the Republic of China's national security intelligence mechanism. "And I believe that the latest revision of the scope of the bureau's security survey will not affect overall national security protection operations," he added.

In fact, the MJIB stopped monitoring major opposition parties and their leaders as well as government wrongdoings -- commonly known as "political surveillance" in local society -- in September, under pressure from reform-minded grassroots MJIB agents and opposition parties. But the cancellation was not formalized until Tuesday, when Premier Chang endorsed the proposed revision to the MJIB's work content.
The revision marks a formal end to the decades-old "white terror" political persecution tactics used by the previous Kuomintang government against opposition politicians and parties.

A group of reform-minded MJIB agents formed an association in August to push the new Democratic Progressive Party government to end the "white terror" surveillance against opposition political figures to signify Taiwan's success in democratization.

In the past, the MJIB conducted "political surveillance" under the guidance and supervision of the National Security Bureau (NSB) under the Presidential Office. Therefore, cancellation of this work from the MJIB's duty list required the approval of both the NSB and the president before the premier could endorse it.
NSB Director Ting Yu-chou said President Chen Shui-bian had ordered a quick completion of all legal formalities to formally free the MJIB from the controversial operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON YAGI GRADUALLY INFLUENCES NORTHEASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Moderate Typhoon Yagi has diminished and its speed slowed on Wednesday afternoon, the Central Weather Bureau reported Wednesday.

At 6 p.m., Yagi's center was recorded about 290 kilometers north-eastnorth of Ilan County, eastern Taiwan. It was moving west at a speed of 5 kilometers per hour, down from 9 kilometers per hour recorded earlier.
The CWB forecast that Yagi's center will be 25.6 degrees north, 123.1 degrees east, or 180 kilometers north-eastnorth of Taipei at 5 p.m. Thursday.
Weathermen urged vessels in the waters off northern, northeastern, southeastern Taiwan and the northern Taiwan Strait to be on alert.

The CWB said heavy rain will affect northern and northeastern Taiwan from Wednesday evening through Thursday. Weathermen cautioned people living in mountainous areas to watch for cave-ins, falling rocks, flash floods and mudslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWBORN MALES MORE AT RISK THAN FEMALE INFANTS

TEXT.P: Newborn boys are truly the weaker of the two sexes, at least in the first few months of life, according to new research results from the United States.
The research showed that newborn boys, particularly those born very prematurely, are more likely to die or be seriously ill than their female counterparts, reported the Sydney Morning Herald.
The research found that of 6,500 babies born prematurely in 12 American cities over a two-year period, one in four of the males died compared to one in seven of the females.

The male infants also had a higher rate of complications over the first few weeks of life. There were also more cases of bleeding in the brain and urinary tract infections among the male infants, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S PLAN TO EXPLOIT TIBETAN OIL RESOURCES FACES INT'L OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: Mainland China is facing international opposition to its plans to exploit the oil resources of the Tibetan Plateau, reported the Australian on Wednesday.
Foreign oil firms are also expected to encounter protests from environmentalists and the Tibetan government in exile established by Tibet's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, reported the daily.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily reported that Communist China is trying to exploit the massive oil reserves of Tibet in order to develop the vast and impoverished western part of the mainland, and giant oil companies such as BP Amoco, Shell, Agip, and Exxon Mobil are all lining up for a slice of the exploration action.

But the potential for destruction to the delicate ecology of the Tibetan plateau and the likely displacement of the already underprivileged Tibetan population has led to a backlash among China's neighbors and has reinvigorated international environmental and pro-Tibet campaigners, the daily reported.
It reported that supporters of the Dalai Lama's government in exile are focusing on plans to build a 935-km long natural gas pipeline from Sebei in Qinghai to Lanzhou, the capital of Gansu province.

Opponents argue that the exploration efforts will speed up the settlement of Han Chinese on lands traditionally occupied by Tibetan and Mongolian nomads, adding that similar past patterns have shown that the indigenous people generally are marginalized from economic development.
The daily quoted a spokesman for the International Campaign for Tibet as saying that "when you try to develop areas based on resource extraction, it just turns them into colonies."
The Tibetan government in exile has also called for the immediate cessation of the oil exploration and exploitation plans.
"These projects, as they are now conceived, will cause harm to the Tibetan people," the government in exile said.
Foreign oil companies have poured a total of US$3 billion into Chinese oil companies in a bid to secure a foothold in the development of the industry, the daily reported.

Environmentalists recently succeeded in reversing a World Bank decision to fund a project to move Chinese farmers on to Tibetan lands in Qinghai, and this has encouraged them to lobby against the involvement of global companies in such projects, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT HOPES TO ATTEND CENTRAL AMERICAN SUMMIT IN 2001

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Wednesday that he can attend next year's summit in Central America between Central American countries and the ROC.
Chen revealed his wish while receiving visiting El Salvador Vice President Carlos Quintanilla.
He also expressed welcome for a visit to Taipei in December by El Salvador President Francisco Flores and added that he is happy with the high-level exchanges between the two countries.

The president said it gave him great pleasure to see Quintanilla again so soon. The two met in August in Dominican Republic when Chen made his first official overseas trip to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa after his inauguration on May 20.

Wednesday's meeting coincided with the 55th anniversary of the retrocession of Taiwan from Japanese occupation and Chen said that if Taiwan had not escaped Japanese rule 55 years ago, the country would not have the progress in democratization and economic prosperity which it now enjoys.
Chen said the ROC wishes to share with El Salvador, one of its closest allies, the fruits of its progress in various aspects.
The president also expressed gratitude to El Salvador for its long-term support of the ROC's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.
Chen added that he hopes Quintanilla's visit will lead to more local enterprises investing in El Salvador, bringing more trade opportunities to the Central American country.
Quintanilla and his delegation was scheduled to leave Taiwan Thursday. (Elisa Kao)

DOC.HEADLINE: GOLDMAN SACHS MULLING INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN ASSETS MANAGEMENT FIRM

TEXT.P: Efforts to bring assets management companies into Taiwan has borne fruit, with well-known international investment bank Goldman Sachs group expressing interest in setting up in Taiwan, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said Wednesday.

The venture being contemplated by Goldman Sachs will have capitalization of NT$30 billion (US$937 million), which will be financed either by the bank alone or by Goldman Sachs in conjunction with its local partners, said Yen, the driving force behind the system.
He noted that the potential investor was not ruling out the possibility that local finance institutions could join the venture by turning over their bad loans to the new company as an investment.
However, Yen continued, a bill exempting assets management firms from the legal obligation of auctioning off bad loans taken from finance institutions is pending in the Legislative Yuan.
The auction, conducted under court supervision, is time-consuming and would tie the hands of assets management firms in handling the bad loans purchased from banks.
With the exemption in place, assets management firms will be able to deal with these bad loans speedily, said Yen.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING STOCK MARKET PUSHES UP CAR SALES

TEXT.P: A recent surge in the local bourse has helped ease the decline in car sales since the beginning of this month, automobile industry sources said Wednesday.

Prompted by the rising stock market, which has rebounded more than 1,000 points over the past few days, plummets in automobile sales reduced from a 30 percent drop during the first 10 days of this month to a 5.8 percent fall at present, the sources said.

As many agents have geared up to stimulate car sales by attracting potential buyers with preferential packages, the sources added that they expect car sales for the whole of October to remain at a similar level to the September level.

The local new car market is always closely related to the performance of the stock market, according to the sources, which elaborated that a total of 16,655 new cars were sold in the first 20 days of October, a 5.8 percent fall compared to the same period of a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT PITCHES FOR GLORIFICATION OF `TAIWAN SPIRIT'
DOC.DATELINE: Chunghsing New Village, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the "Taiwan spirit," jointly created by various ethnic groups on the island, is a common asset that can be used by all local residents to face the challenges of the new century.
Chen made the remarks at a cocktail reception to mark the 55th anniversary of the restoration of Taiwan to Chinese rule in 1945 after half a century of Japanese occupation.
Chen, the Republic of China's first president from the Democratic Progressive Party, said Taiwan has come a long way in charting its own destiny since the end of Japanese colonial rule.

Over the past 55 years, Chen said, the people of Taiwan have worked diligently to achieve economic prosperity and political democratization. "This marvelous Taiwan developmental experience, created by all our people, has attracted world attention and should give our people confidence in our country's future," he explained.
He further said the brilliant Taiwan experience lies in the "Taiwan spirit" characterized by confidence, hope, dreams, sweat and wisdom.

Noting that the "Taiwan spirit" integrates the essences of the Han (Chinese) culture and the Nantao (southern island) culture, Chen said the people of Taiwan should continue "glorifying" this common asset.

With the 21st century just around the corner, Chen went on, all Taiwan residents, regardless of their ethnic origins and party affiliations, should stand united to consolidate the island's democratic achievements and create yet another economic boom and accelerate reconstruction in the areas hard-hit by a devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999.

The reception, chaired by Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, was attended by senior government officials, representatives from Taiwan's sister states and provinces around the world, as well as representatives of the 921 earthquake victims.
2000 marks the first year since 1945 that Taiwan's Retrocession Day has not been recognized as a national holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO OPEN DOOR WIDER TO MAINLAND SCIENTISTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will open its door wider to mainland Chinese science-technology professionals in a gradual manner, National Science Council (NSC) Chairman Weng Cheng-i said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Weng said the NSC has drafted a revision bill to the current regulations governing the entry of mainland scientists, engineers and other technological experts.
According to the NSC-proposed revision, the maximum period of stay for mainland science-technology professionals will be extended from current two years to three years.
Weng said the draft revision bill has been referred to the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, for screening.

Meanwhile, Weng said, the NSC has asked the Ministry of the Interior to revise relevant entry regulations to allow mainland scientists and technological experts eligible for staying in Taiwan for more than six months for research purposes to take with them their spouses and children.

During the meeting, some legislators suggested that the government draft a bill granting permanent residency to qualified mainland scientists and technological experts and their families to attract more mainland professionals to work and settle in Taiwan to help resolve manpower shortage problems faced by local companies.
In response, Weng said the NSC is willing to gradually adjust its policy and regulations based on the domestic demand and the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Speaking on the same occasion, MAC Vice Chairman John C.C. Teng, said the government will give the priority to attracting overseas mainland-born scientists and technological experts to work in Taiwan.

As an influx of mainland professionals may have an impact on the local job market and cause many complex problems, including marriage, education and health insurance, Teng said, regulations governing employment of mainland scientists and engineers should be eased gradually, not hastily.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIC PARTY ADVISORS EXPLAIN GORE POSITION ON CHINA-TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A future Gore administration would continue U.S. policy on "one China" while emphasizing its support for the people of Taiwan, according to senior advisors to the Democratic presidential candidate.

Marc Ginsberg, senior coordinating foreign policy advisor to the Gore campaign, said that he expects "the policy of `one China' based on the (1972) Shanghai communique would continue but on the basis of peaceful efforts and resolution, not armed conflict."

"The Taiwanese people deserve to know that the United States will stand by their side and that we will be there for them ... because they have proved they are strong friends of ours," Ginsberg told Taiwan reporters.

Beijing must engage Taiwan to resolve cross-strait differences, he said, adding that a Gore administration would try to play "a constructive and important role on behalf of both parties consistent with our long-stated bi-partisan policy."

Answering questions after a briefing on foreign policy positions of the Gore campaign, Ginsberg also said that a Gore administration would not abandon Taiwan and would provide weapons necessary for the island's defense.

During the briefing, another advisor to the campaign suggested that, as president, Gore would likely try to avoid the controversies and partisan attacks that have dogged the Clinton administration's conduct of U.S. China policy.
"Al Gore is going to approach all foreign policy issues, trying to build a bipartisan coalition, this one in particular," said Bruce Jentelson.
"Given our history in the region and given the contentiousness of this issue, it's even more important that we improve on the bipartisan nature of this policy," he said.

During the briefing, Jentelson laid out the principle of a Gore administration's China policy as trying to "maximize the areas of cooperation with the People's Republic of China, and at the same time be very clear about where our differences are."
He said a President Gore would ensure that, where there are differences with Beijing, the United States would stand up for American interests and for its allies in the region.
Rejecting criticism by the Bush campaign, both Jentelson and Ginsberg stressed the importance with which Gore views U.S. ties with Japan and other allies in Asia.
"There's no doubt that one of the most important objectives of a Gore administration will be to strengthen our security commitments with Japan," said Ginsberg.
He also described ties with Australia, Thailand, the Philippines, South Korea and Taiwan as "cornerstones" of U.S. relations with the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRUDE OIL PRICE WILL AFFECT TAIWAN'S GROWTH RATE: CEPD OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A ranking official with the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday that Taiwan's economic growth rate will be affected by the international price of crude oil.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said that if the price of crude remains high next year, it will become hard to attain the 6 percent real growth rate set for next year unless tariffs for crude imports and the commodity tax for petroleum products are slashed.
But he added that Taiwan will have no problem attain the 6.1 percent growth rate set for this year, even if the price soars to US$40 per barrel by the end of this year.

The CEPD official made the remarks at a seminar organized by the China External Trade Development Council to analyze the fluctuation of international crude prices and its effect on Taiwan's economy and trade.

Participants invited to the seminar included specialists from the Chinese Petroleum Corp., the Energy Commission under the Economics Ministry, the Lee Chang Yung Chemical Industry Corp. and the Taiwan Economic Research Institute.

According to Hu's analysis, Taiwan's growth rate this year will reach 6.57 percent if the price of crude averages US$27 per barrel in the fourth quarter of this year. However, it will go down to 6.47 percent and to 6.13 percent if the price averages US$30 or US$40, respectively.
However, he noted that the crude price will have little effect on Taiwan's foreign trade, as foreign trade's dependence on energy has dropped significantly.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER EXPRESSES WILLINGNESS TO ATTEND APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Former Premier Vincent Siew said Wednesday he would be willing to attend the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit of leaders on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

Siew, who is also an opposition Kuomintang vice chairman, called the appointment "a task, a responsibility, but not a post." He said he will accept it if it serves the national interest without compromising the stance of his party.

In response to questions from the media after the weekly meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee, Siew confirmed that he had been consulted by Chen on the possibility of representing the president at the Nov. 15-16 summit in Brunei.
But Siew said he was told at the time that he was only one of a number of choices being weighed by Chen and added that he has yet to hear any more about the issue.

Siew, who represented former President Lee Teng-hui at the annual summits in 1993 and 1994 when he served as chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said it is his understanding that his private status is not an obstacle to his being an envoy at the APEC summit.

Meanwhile, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said Chen, who is a Democratic Progressive Party member, should consult the KMT before appointing Siew, although he stressed that his party would give the national interest top priority when weighing its decision.

Describing the KMT, which lost ignominiously in the March presidential election, as "rich in talented people," Lien said his party did not grudge its members being tapped by the DPP for government service, but added that the "formality" of consultation between the two parties should be followed.

Although the Republic of China is a member of APEC, its president has never rubbed shoulders with his APEC counterparts at the summit since the conference was launched in 1993 in Seattle, due to opposition from Beijing.

Beijing, which claims Taiwan as part of its territory, threatened to boycott the summit should the ROC president attend in person, forcing Taiwan to settle for having a ministerial-level official at the occasion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRMS REPORT OPTIMISM ABOUT ELECTRONIC COMMERCE PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: More than 63 percent of Taiwan's big firms are optimistic about the prospects for e-commerce, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.

The poll conducted by Internet firm Superpoll.net, also reveals that 83 of these firms believe that non-high tech firms lack personnel familiar with e-commerce, and 59 percent said there is a shortage of firms specialized in setting up the e-commerce mechanism for such businesses.

The survey conducted among 108 firms selected from those ranked between 500th and 1,000th on the island by size, also reported 90 percent of those interviewed as saying they are optimistic about the future of worldwide e-commerce.
Ironically, about 77 percent of the firms polled admitted that they know little about e-commerce, while 82 percent said non-high tech industries rarely conduct commerce via the Internet.
As to the negative aspects of e-commerce, 87 percent listed the lack of security when trading online, while 76 percent pointed out the "risk of ordering goods sight unseen."

When it comes to the direction for future development, 27.8 percent emphasized the need for the establishment of a security mechanism and 20.4 percent said government should guide and promote the concept.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPERATION OF TAIWAN FOREIGN EXCHANGE `VERY TRANSPARENT': OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official with the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) claimed Wednesday that the operation of the Taipei Foreign Exchange is the "most transparent of its kind in the world."

Chou A-ting, director-general of the CBC's Foreign Exchange Department, told the media that the trading of the Taipei Foreign Exchange is announced every 15 minutes and added that the information on inter-bank trading is also available to the public.

In response to a complaint that the Taipei Foreign Exchange lacks advanced trading instruments, he said that the CBC provides the results of trading every month and permits trading in 18 foreign currencies.
Regarding the charges in trading and procedures, Chou said that they are "comparatively lower" than many other foreign exchanges around the world.

He admitted that the scale of trading on the Taipei Foreign Exchange -- about US$5 billion - US$6 billion daily -- is far smaller than the scale of its Singapore counterpart, which amounts to over US$100 billion per day, but he noted that most of the volume in Singapore trading is from trading in foreign currencies other than the Singapore dollar.
Asked whether the scale of trade in Taipei will increase after Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization, Chou replied obliquely that the CBC will ask banks to step up their risk management.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER SEEKS KMT SUPPORT FOR REFERENDUM ON NUCLEAR PLANT

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Trong Tsai visited a faction of the opposition Kuomintang on Wednesday to seek support for holding a referendum to solve the issue of the fourth nuclear power plant.

Tsai sought support from the KMT faction, which calls itself "The E-generation," after eight members of DPP's "Mainstream Alliance" faction expressed conditional support for continuation of the construction of the plant, and a survey conducted last week among alliance members revealed that 26 supported the holding of a referendum to decide whether to continue with the project.
The plant has become a political hot potato for the DPP, with opinion sharply divided over whether or not it should be scrapped, challenging the party's anti-nuclear platform.

Tsai said that although Taiwan's democratic system is well-developed, there is no system in place to allow for referenda to be used as a means of determining major national policy. He described a referendum as "the highest performance of public opinion."

However, the head of the KMT's "E-generation," Chen Hung-chi, said the holding of a referendum would waste a great deal of time and suggested instead that the government should seek compromise with the KMT-dominated Legislative Yuan to find a feasible method of resolving the nuclear project controversy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
KMT Chairman says the Kuomintang is willing to help the DPP government tide over difficulties facing the country.
The China Times:
Local information-technology companies are scrambling to invest in mainland China.
The United Daily News:
Prosecutor Hung Wei-hua leaves for France to seek clues to the Lafayette-class frigate procurement scandal.
The Liberty Times:
The South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu will forge diplomatic ties with the ROC.
The China Post:
Government handling of nuke plant rapped.
The Taiwan News:
Typhoon Yagi slows down but stays threatening.
The Taipei Times:
Former Premier Vincent Siew is tapped to represent Taiwan at APEC summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 26, or the 29th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1879: Leon Trotsky, Russian communist leader who, with Lenin, organized the October Revolution, is born. He was forced into exile by Stalin, sentenced to death in a Soviet court, and murdered in Mexico, where he had found asylum.
1919: Francois Mitterand, French president from 1981, and founder of the French Socialist Party, is born.
1931: Japan turns down a proposal of the Council of the League of Nations which adopted a resolution on Oct. 24 urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: Chinese troops begin a withdrawal from Shanghai to the northern Soochow River after Japanese troops capture Tachang. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on Nov. 11.
1942: The aircraft carrier USS Hornet is sunk after being attacked by Japanese aircraft in the Solomon Islands battle.
1944: After three days, the battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines ends with victory for the United States. Over 30 ships are sunk in the great sea battle, most of them Japanese, including the Japanese navy's last four aircraft carriers.
1947: Hillary Rodham Clinton, American first lady, is born.
1954: Britain and the United States end their occupation of Trieste and return control of the area to Italy.
1951: Winston Churchill is appointed British prime minister for a second time.
1955: The Republic of South Vietnam is proclaimed under Ngo Dinh Diem.
1961: Outer Mongolia is admitted into the United Nations.
1964: The Republic of China opens a consulate in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
1964: The Republic of China and Panama sign a trade agreement in Panama City.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Belgium as the latter establishes ties with mainland China.
1971: The Republic of China withdraws from the United Nations.
1973: President Richard Nixon prepares to launch World War III after hearing that the Russians are sending arms to the Middle East as war rages there.
1973: U.S. Ambassador-at-large David M. Kennedy arrives in Taipei for a three-day private visit.
1975: The First Taiwan Area Games opens in Kaohsiung with 4,980 athletes participating.
1976: The 1976 Sino-American Conference on Science Cooperation opens in Taipei to review the year's joint programs and to make plans for 1977.
1979: Park Chung Hee, president of South Korea, is slain by Kim Jae Kyu, the head of the Korean intelligence agency.
1989: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes near Taiwan's Siulin Village in Hualien County on its way from Hualien to Taipei, killing 54 people on board.
1993: The ROC and Mexico sign a pact to promote investment and technology transfers.
1994: Israel and Jordan sign a peace treaty in a ceremony at their mutual border attended by U.S. President Bill Clinton, ending 46 years of hostility.
1995: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is hospitalized in Moscow after an apparent heart attack, the second in four months.
1999: Nanking Software Park, the largest software manufacturing park in Asia, is opened by President Lee Teng-hui in suburban Taipei.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sages are of the same species as ourselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 81.93 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the bechmark weighted price index moving down 81.93 points to close at 5,941.85.
Market turnover amounted to NT$101 billion (US$3.16 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY WORKING TO LEGALIZE TAIWAN SCHOOLS ON M'LAND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education is seeking the legalization of mainland China-based schools established for children of Taiwanese businesspeople, sources from the MOE said Thursday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Education Minister Ovid Tzeng said the MOE is currently discussing with the Mainland Affairs Council, the top agency formulating Taiwan's mainland China policies, matters concerning legalizing Taiwan educational institutions established in mainland China for children of Taiwan citizens maintaining business operations there.

Tzeng said the MOE and MAC are working on adding an article to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area to formally legalize the Taiwan schools in mainland China.

After years of preparation, the first Taiwan school, situated in Dongguan in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong, began operating on Sept. 2. The school was established after it obtained official approval from authorities of Taiwan, Beijing, and the local government.

The school in Dongguan only accepts children of Taiwan citizens, and the faculty is also entirely comprised of Taiwan citizens. Also, the management of the school and the curriculum are based on the educational system in Taiwan.

According to Tzeng, there are about 200,000 Taiwanese businesspeople working or operating companies in mainland China, with most of them living in the coastal provinces. Family affairs, particularly children's education, are of major concern to this group, he noted.

Most of these Taiwan businesspeople prefer to have their children educated within a Taiwan educational institution, said Tzeng, adding that most have not chosen foreign schools because of the prohibitively high costs nor mainland Chinese schools because of their concerns about the possible ideological influence on their children.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 81.93 points to close at 5,941.85.
Affected by a drop in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 5,937.22 and continued to move down due to profit-taking selling. The bourse fluctuated between 6,011.05 and 5,909.35 during trading.

A total of 2.63 billion stocks worth NT$101 billion (US$3.16 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.91 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$107.96 billion (US$3.37 billion).
Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with cement stocks and foodstuff shares both moving up by 1.6 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by textile issues and plastics and chemical shares, both at 1.3 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.2 percent, construction stocks at 0.5 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 434 to 122, with 58 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November moved down 97 points to close at 5,875, with 6,700 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for December lost 69 points to finish at 5,891, with 69 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,972 for November, 5,960 for December, 6,051 for next March, 6,055 for next June, and 6,291 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
November TE futures moved down 5 points to close at 298, with 1,494 contract transactions, while December TE futures lost 4 points to finish at 298, with 13 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
November TF futures moved down 16.2 points to close at 759.8, with 1,938 contract transactions, while December TF futures lost 15.6 points to finish at 760.4, with four contracts traded.
March 2001 TF futures plunged 28.2 points to close at 779.8, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT'S AIDE DENIES U.S. TRAVEL PLAN

TEXT.P: A close aide to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui Thursday denied a newspaper report that Lee will visit his alma mater, Cornell University, in Ithaca, New York State in December.

Su Chih-cheng, head of Lee's office during his 12-year presidency, said Lee, who just returned from a visit to the Czech Republic to attend an international seminar, has no new overseas travel plans before the end of this year.
Su, now deputy director of the Taiwan Research Institute, a private think tank, admitted that Lee indeed received an invitation from a U.S. foundation to visit Washington, D.C.

According to Su, the U.S. foundation had sent the invitation through the ROC's representative office in the United States and planned to cite Lee for his achievement in promoting Taiwan's democratization.

As Lee just retired in May this year and the foundation is located in the politically sensitive U.S. capital city, Su said, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) had suggested that Lee turn down the invitation to avoid affecting the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangular relations.

"After a prudent study, the MOFA said a U.S. visit by Lee at this moment, no matter conducted in any format, is not expected to have positive, constructive effects on relations across the Taiwan Strait. Therefore, Lee has politely rejected the invitation," Su explained.

The China Times, a Taipei daily, reported Thursday that Lee has been invited to attend a fund raiser to be held at Cornell University in December to raise donations from alumni for a science-technology research project. In addition, the paper, Lee will also visit New York and several other major U.S. cities except Washington, D.C.
However, Su categorically denied the report, saying it is unfounded and completely wrong.

"If Lee were to visit the United States in December, he certainly would have made every possible effort to prevent any premature exposure of his travel plan," Su stressed, adding that as the weather is getting cold, the 78-year-old ex-ROC president will not travel abroad in the rest of this year.

Lee, an outspoken critic of Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan and an active promoter of Taiwan's distinctive identity, managed to make a high-profile visit to the United States in June 1995, making him the first ROC president to set foots on the U.S. soil. During that visit, Lee delivered a speech, titled "Always in My Heart," on Taiwan's progress in economic development and political democratization.

The visit, however, infuriated Beijing and strained Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations. Beijing even test-fired missiles and conducted live-fire military exercises at Taiwan's doorstep between 1995 and 1996 to intimidate Taiwan. Beijing's saber-rattling, also known as the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis, also prompted U.S. President Bill Clinton to spell out a new "three noes" policy toward Taiwan -- no support for "one China, one Taiwan"; "no support for Taiwan independence"; and "no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations which require statehood."

Although Lee has no longer held any government posts since he stepped down from the presidency in May, Beijing still opposes Lee's any overseas visits. Beijing lodged protests with London when Lee visited Britain in June. It also tried to pressure the Czech Republic to block Lee's visit earlier this month, but to no avail.
