DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. MUST WARN CHINA IT WON'T LET TAIWAN BE COERCED: EXPERT

TEXT.P: While recognizing that the Taiwan issue could bring America and Communist China into a military conflict, the next U.S. administration must warn Beijing that it will not stand idly by if China coerces or uses military force against Taiwan, noted a renowned American expert in Asian affairs.

Richard Haass, vice president of the Brookings Institution and director of the Brookings Foreign Policy Studies program, wrote in the latest issue of the Brookings Review that the United States' bilateral relationship with China is fast becoming the most difficult issue for Washington to manage.

Areas of cooperation, including working toward the expansion of trade and toward promoting stability on the Korean peninsula, risk being overwhelmed by differences over Taiwan, human rights, Beijing's assistance to Pakistan's nuclear and missile programs, U.S. plans for theater and national missile defense systems, and humanitarian intervention, he said.

"Complicating matters is the political reality that in both countries, there are those who see the other as the principal obstacle to a successful foreign policy and who see a competitive if not adversarial relationship as all but inevitable," said the former special assistant to President George Bush.

Haass pointed out that negotiations cannot eliminate these differences and what is required instead are regular consultations, attempts at cooperation in selected areas, and special care at making sure areas of disagreement do not spill over and affect the entire relationship.

"Taiwan should be singled out, however, as the one issue that could bring the United States and China into direct military confrontation. China must understand that the United States will not stand idly by if China coerces or uses military force against Taiwan."

This posture needs to be balanced, however, by U.S. diplomacy that both encourages a mainland China-Taiwan cross-strait dialogue and discourages any unilateral declaration of independence by Taiwan, emphasized the Asia expert.

Regarding the controversial missile defense programs, Haass said even a modest national missile defense system could pose a threat to Communist China's arsenal, which is far smaller than Russia's. Moreover, theater missile defense inevitably becomes entangled with the Taiwan issue, "as China is sure to view U.S. missile defense plans for Northeast Asia as enabling Taiwan to declare independence with impunity," he added.

"There is no way to eliminate these Chinese concerns and probably no way to avoid a decision by China to increase the size and capability of its nuclear arsenal, something likely to happen to some degree regardless of U.S. missile defense plans," he stressed.

"But the United States can alleviate the adverse consequences, both by making clear that any national missile defense is limited and by working to discourage a declaration of independence by Taiwan," concluded Haass.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISM SECTOR RESPONDS FAVORABLY TO ALLOWING M'LAND VISITORS

TEXT.P: ROC Premier Chang-Chun's recent announcement that the government will allow a limited number of tourists from mainland China to visit Taiwan each year has been favorably received by the local tourism sector.

Following a series of "goodwill" policies announced by the new government to address the cross-strait impasse, the premier announced Oct. 20 that visitors from mainland China will be able to take leisure trips to Taiwan beginning next June. The announcement has still not been formally acknowledged by mainland Chinese authorities.

In the wake of the announcement, leaders of the tourism sector have expressed the hope that the government will quickly work out relevant regulations on the market opening so as to allow them to move accordingly.

Shih Tsun-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Folklore Village, a recreation center in central Taiwan, said he feels the government's opening of the island to mainland Chinese tourists will definitely have a positive effect on Taiwan's tourism industry, which has been heavily battered by the devastating earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999.

Shih said that based on mainland China's huge population, about 3 million to 5 million tourists could be expected to be able to visit Taiwan from the mainland per year, making this group an irresistible attraction to Taiwan's tourism operators.

Chuang Hsiu-shih, owner of the renowned Leofoo Zoo and Theme Park and the five-star Hotel Westin Taipei, said the number of mainland Chinese tourists that the government plans to allow in should not be too few, saying 200,000 a year would not be enough.
He said the number should be more like 500,000 or more tourists per year to make it "cost efficient" for Taiwan tourism operators.

Although official regulations are not yet available, members of the domestic tourism industry have envisaged that the average itinerary for a mainland Chinese tourist would likely be a tour of 7-10 days at a cost of between NT$35,000 and NT$40,000, with Sun Moon Lake, Mt. Ali, and Taroko Gorge being major travel destinations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES RELOCATING TO M'LAND NOT AN EXODUS: LIN

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Thursday that the relocating to mainland China by parts of Taiwan's business and industrial sectors does not constitute an "industrial exodus."
Lin, speaking in the Legislative Yuan, noted that it is a natural development for Taiwan companies to choose to relocate their manufacturing operations to mainland China one after another.

He attributed the trend to an assortment of factors, including Taiwan's labor shortages, unstable public utilities supplies, saturation in certain domestic markets, Taiwan and mainland China's impending entry into the World Trade Organization, which mandates free trade among all trade entities, and particularly cheap real estate and labor on the mainland.

Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yi-shih ridiculed Lin in the Legislative Yuan by saying that Yulon Motor Co., one of the leading automobile manufacturers in Taiwan, demonstrated a lack of confidence in the government by deciding to invest on the mainland after Lin assumed the post of economics minister. Lin was president of China Motor Corp., an affiliate of Yulon Motor, before being appointed to his present post in Chen Shui-bian's administration.

Discounting the legislator's ridicule, Lin said Yulon's plans to invest on the mainland have nothing to do with him, nor with the possibility of water, electricity, and other public utilities shortages in Taiwan in the future.

Lin said he knows that Yulon began discussing possible investments on the mainland seven or eight years ago on the grounds that Taiwan's motor market was expected to become saturated in a few years. And the truth is that that expectation came true, Lin said, pointing out that the combined annual output of cars shrank to 430,000 units last year from an average of 570,000 units per year a few years ago.
He said Taiwan's auto industry has no choice but to "move out" in order to survive, but he added that the relocating of operations out of the country does not constitute an exodus.
Taiwan newspapers reported Thursday that Yulon plans to invest some US$16 million to acquire a 25 percent stake in Fengshen Motor, one of the leading automobile manufacturers in mainland China.
The Yulon investment plan has already received approval from mainland Chinese authorities. The company plans to file a formal application with the Investment Commission for government approval.

Yulon's mainland investment plan comes on the heels of Formosa Plastics Group's announcement that it is planning to invest US$100 million in developing a PVC manufacturing complex on Meishan Island in Ningbo, located in mainland China's Zhejiang Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN STUDENTS AT AUSSIE UNIVERSITIES INCREASING

TEXT.P: Australian universities have been attracting more and more foreign students in recent years, said Education Minister David Kemp on Thursday.

In a statement faxed to the CNA, Kemp said that "education is continuing to prove itself as one of Australia's major export earners with a 30 percent growth in university enrollments by overseas students over the last two years."
He said there has been an 80 percent increase in the number of overseas students enrolled in higher education courses since 1996.
He noted that there were 95,540 overseas students enrolled in higher education courses for the year 2000, compared with 53,188 in 1996.

A spokesman for the Education Department told the CNA that Taiwan was one of the top ten educational markets for Australia, but he added that a specific breakdown in the country of origin of foreign students studying at Australian universities would not be released until early 2001.
"However, we regard Taiwan as a major educational market for us and will continue our promotional campaigns to attract more Taiwanese students to Australia," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TAIWAN TOURISTS TO MACAU UP OVER LAST YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Jen Chung-hung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan tourists to Macau in the first nine months of this year was 31 percent higher than the number in the same period last year, according to statistics released Thursday by the Macau Statistics and Census Bureau.

The MSCB's statistics show that the number of tourist arrivals in Macau in September totaled 725,469, up 36.2 percent from the 532,588 in the same month last year. The majority of these tourists came from Hong Kong, mainland China, Taiwan, or Japan, with Taiwan tourists accounting for 16.5 percent of the total.

In the first nine months of this year, a total of 6,840,344 tourists arrived in Macau, an increase of 24.1 percent over the total number in the same period last year. The number of Hong Kong tourist arrivals in Macau during the period grew by 17.7 percent; the number of mainland Chinese tourist arrivals grew by 43.2 percent; and the number of tourist arrivals from South Korea grew 38.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE FIREFIGHTING DELEGATION VISITS QUAKE-AFFECTED NANTOU

TEXT.P: A firefighting delegation from Japan visited Nantou County, Central Taiwan Thursday, which was hard hit by the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake last year.
The 35-member delegation from Ibaraki prefecture, northeast of Tokyo, called at the Nantou county government and was received by Lai Ing-fang, deputy magistrate of Nantou County.

Lai extended his sincere appreciation to the Japanese government and people for their assistance in the wake of the earthquake, including the sending of a rescue team, the contribution of prefabricated houses, and sustained donations.
Lai expressed hope that the Japanese delegation would continue to contribute their valuable opinions on rescue and reconstruction efforts.
The delegation later held a meeting with firefighting staff in Nantou to exchange views with them.

In the afternoon, they visited the old Chichi railway station, one of the landmarks of the picturesque county, which was particularly badly damaged by the 7.3-magnitude earthquake and has since been in disuse.

The Japanese delegation said that they were there to learn, adding that although Taiwan's rescue equipment may not be as advanced as Japan's, the firefighting and rescue teams displayed unselfish devotion to their jobs, which they said deserve deep respect and admiration.
The delegation, which arrived Wednesday for a three-day visit, came especially to express concern about the quake-affected areas and the post-quake reconstruction.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ANNOUNCES OIL PRICE HIKE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced Thursday that it will increase domestic gasoline and diesel prices by NT$0.3 and NT$0.2 per liter, respectively, starting from Friday.
CPC officials said the price hike is due to soaring international crude oil prices and is based on the calculation of US$33.056 per barrel for crude.
After the adjustment, the retail price for 98 unleaded gasoline will be NT$21.5 per liter, although the CPC officials said CPC gas stations are authorized to adopt "more liberal" prices.
Retail prices for 95 and 92 unleaded will be NT$20.50 and NT$19.50 per liter, respectively, while diesel will cost NT$14.90 per liter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR TAIWAN STRAIT CONFLICT PREVENTION MECHANISM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday pitched for the establishment of a Taiwan Strait conflict management and prevention mechanism to maintain regional peace and stability.
Chen made the appeal during a meeting with C. Daniel Mote, president of the University of Maryland, who is currently on a weeklong visit to Taipei.
According to Chen, there are now three possible flashpoints in the Asia-Pacific area -- the Korean peninsula, the South China Sea and the Taiwan Strait.

Chen said long-feuding North and South Korea are engaging in detente and that the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) has provided a forum for prevention and management of South China Sea disputes or conflicts.

In contrast, he went on, the Taiwan Strait is the only area where no effective dialogue mechanism exists. With a view to preventing cross-strait conflicts, he said, both Taiwan and mainland China should endeavor to thrash out conflict management or preventive diplomacy measures.
Chen told his guest that the Republic of China government has consistently given priority to improving and normalizing cross-strait relations.

"Although there are still some `blind points' or obstacles to the development of cross-strait relations, I'm convinced that we'll be able to find a way out with goodwill, wisdom and creativity," Chen said, adding that his administration will do its utmost to avoid any possible cross-strait conflicts for the well-being of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

For his part, Mote said the University of Maryland has set up a global ethnic Chinese affairs study center and a conflict management and research center which has studied all major conflicts around the world over the past two decades.
"We hope to contribute to the study of cross-strait issues, disputes and conflicts through the cooperation of these two organizations," Mote said.
During his visit, Mote will sign a memorandum of understanding on cooperation between the University of Maryland (UOM) and the ROC's National Yang Ming University.
Chen said he will be pleased to see the prestigious U.S. university strengthen exchanges and cooperation with Taiwan's educational and research institutes.
Mote told Chen that for the University of Maryland, the ROC is an important country because it has the world's largest UOM alumni club outside the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SUPPORTS CHOICE OF WLFD CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the government supports the choice of Clement C.P. Chang to head both the Asian Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy (APLFD) and the World League for Freedom and Democracy (WLFD).
Chen made the comment as he received delegates to a joint executive committee of the WLFD and the APLFD, which opened in Taipei earlier in the day and was chaired by Chang.
Chang is contesting with Yao Eng-chi, president of the APLFD's ROC chapter, to head the WLFD, a non-government organization.
He spoke highly of the WLFD's contributions to promoting freedom and the universal values of democracy over the years in every corner of the world.

Chen went on to describe the ROC as a free and democratic country whose people uphold freedom and "love" democracy. The people enjoy 100 percent freedom of speech that allows them to voice criticism of the government and even the president, he said.

Chen said that the ROC is "a member of the global village" and that ROC citizens are also global citizens. "We (the ROC) will not raise fences for ourselves and hope that we can rejoin the United Nations so that we can fulfill our international obligations," he continued.
He added his hope that the WLFD can help the ROC rejoin the United Nations.
Meanwhile, another WLFD executive committee meeting convened by Yao, will be held Friday in New York.
Yao claimed that he has obtained support from 16 WLFD executive committee members for his chairmanship, showing that the WLFD executive committee is split between Chang and Yao.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BECOMING A COUNTRY OF `MODERATE' ECONOMIC GROWTH: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan is becoming a country of "moderate or even low" economic growth and its unemployment rate reached a 20-year high last year, a national policy advisor said Thursday.

Hsiao Hsin-huang, who is also a research fellow of social science at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's most prestigious academic institution, based his remarks on statistics from the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
He said that this is not a bad condition and is a tendency when economic development matures. However, he went on, the climbing unemployment rate is worth observing.

He also noted that although Taiwan people are getting richer, the distribution of wealth is getting worse. He suggested that the government should figure out on how to maintain a society of "equal wealth."

According to DGBAS statistics, Taiwan's economic growth reached 5.4 percent in 1999 after emerging from the shadow of the Asian financial crisis, with its gross national product (GNP) totaling US$290.5 billion, the 16th-highest in the world.
Taiwan's per capita GNP registered US$13,235, or 25th place in the world, the statistics show.
However, Hsiao said Taiwan's unemployment rate reached a record high of 2.92 percent last year, due mainly to the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, and had climbed to 3.16 percent by August this year.
Last year, labor disputes continued to surge, totaling 5,860 cases, an increase of 40 percent over the previous year, Hsiao added.

Meanwhile, a public sanitation expert said that according to a human development index compiled by the United Nations, the per capita Gross Domestic Product in Taiwan has registered US$19,197, the 21st-highest in the world, while its life expectancy registered 31st place.
Chien Chien-jen, director of the School of Public Sanitation of National Taiwan University, said this shows that Taiwan's high GDP has not brought health and longevity for its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD TO VISIT CHICAGO, NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his wife will visit overseas Chinese communities in Chicago and New York in early November, sources with the local chapter of the KMT said.

Lien's wife arrived in San Francisco on Wednesday for a three-day stay before flying to Chicago to meet up with her husband. She was greeted at the airport by Victor Tseng of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco and Kuo Yun-kuang, head of the KMT's party affairs service center in northwestern United States.

Lien is scheduled to arrive in Chicago on Nov. 1, where he will attend a meeting of the board of directors of the University of Chicago and visit overseas Chinese communities in Chicago and New York in early November to thank those who have supported the KMT for many years.
This will be Lien's second visit to the United States since the March 18 ROC presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA MUM ON TIES WITH VANUATU

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) declined Thursday to confirm a press report that the Republic of China is to forge full diplomatic relations with the South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu.

However, several local newspapers said a breakthrough is due soon on the establishment of full-fledged diplomatic ties with Vanuatu and that Vice Foreign Minister David Tawei Lee had left for Vanuatu to discuss relevant issues.
MOFA spokesman Henry Chen would not comment on the report and said only that the ROC has consistently worked hard to strengthen relations with its diplomatic allies and non-allies.
While maintaining formal diplomatic ties with mainland China, Vanuatu "exchanged recognition" with the ROC in 1992, one step short of full diplomatic relations.

Chen said ROC-Vanuatu relations, including trade and agricultural exchanges, are cordial. He went on to stress that grasping every possible chance to forge rapprochement and cooperative ties is MOFA's basic working principle and attitude.
In view of the ROC's difficult diplomatic situation, Chen said, MOFA will not give up any chance of upgrading relations with other countries.

As for Lee's ongoing overseas trip, Chen said he had indeed traveled to a country that does not recognize the ROC. "But he is not in Vanuatu to discuss issues related to upgrading bilateral ties," he added.

Because of Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, the ROC currently maintains formal diplomatic ties with only 29 countries, most of which are located in Latin America, Africa and the Pacific Ocean.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA ADJUSTS ECONOMIC GROWTH DOWNWARDS TO 6.3 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading research institute announced Thursday that it had adjusted the economic growth rate this year for the island after days of stock market slump and decreased investment in Taiwan.
The Institute of Economics of Academia Sinica adjusted the economic growth rate for this year to 6.3 percent.

The non-profit Chang-Hwa Institute for Economic Research had earlier adjusted economic growth this year to 6.41 percent, down by almost 0.2 percent. The Directorate Generate of Budget, Accounting and Statistics is also expected to lower its forecast of the economic growth rate to around 6.4 percent next month.

The Institute of Economics had predicted in July that economic growth this year would be 6.44 percent, but as economic recovery has not been as good as predicted, it had to adjust the figure downwards.

Institute Director Hu Teh-cheng said that in anticipation of the entry of both sides of the Taiwan Strait into the World Trade Organization, many traditional industries in Taiwan have moved to the mainland, while some technology industries have also tried to move to the mainland, which he described as an inevitable trend.

He said that the domestic economic situation is still good, but added that as the fourth quarter will not be as optimistic as originally predicted, the institute had to adjust its predication downwards.

Hu also said that economic growth next year will hinge on the world economic situation, especially the economy in the United States. (By Lilian Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP031 10-26-00 DEBATE OVER TAIWAN'S CONTROVERSIAL NUCLEAR PLANT HEATS UP

Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) The debate over the ongoing construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant continued to gather heat Thursday as various factions within the ruling and opposition parties offered diverse solutions to settle the controversial issue.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who serves concurrently as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, confirmed that the KMT has prepared a draft bill to guarantee that the fourth plant will be Taiwan's last nuclear plant and set up a timetable to scrap the existing three nuclear plants.

The KMT apparently plans to introduce the bill if and when the Cabinet officially announces its decision to stop administering the budget for the plant's construction, which would effectively touch off an open war between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party government and the KMT-majority legislature.

Thursday's development came on the heels of a call at a DPP Central Standing Committee meeting the previous day from newly appointed Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen to his fellow DPP members to "be prepared for a fight over the nuclear plant issue."

Chiou's fighting words elicited a strong backlash from the KMT's legislative caucus, which announced that it will also be ready to go into battle and added that no one country in the world can simply stop executing a budget that has been passed by the legislature, because to do so is illegal.

Opposition People First Party legislative caucus spokeswoman Lee Ching-an also responded by saying that Chiou's words are a sign that the DPP cannot seem to recognize the fact that it is a minority government. She added that any budget that has been approved by the legislature should continue to be carried out -- including the one for the fourth nuclear plant.

However, Hsu Tien-tsai, convener of the DPP's legislative caucus, attempted to clarify his party's position by saying that the DPP has "always maintained a humble attitude." He further expressed his hope that the different party caucuses can arrive at a mutually acceptable timetable for the Cabinet to make a final decision on the issue before the opposition parties make good on their threat to freeze the national budget bill for the next fiscal year.

A consensus was reached at a meeting of the various caucuses later in the day for the legislature to go ahead with evaluations and general interpellations for the national budget because a DPP legislator relayed a "tacit understanding" that the Cabinet will decide on the issue by Nov. 15.

Meanwhile, Hsu said that a national referendum may be the best solution to the controversial issue. He added that the Cabinet should first announce its policy decision of abolishing the fourth nuclear plant, which could then be seconded by a vote by the entire electorate.

Hsu's offered solution was supported by a faction of the KMT. Legislators of the so-called "E-generation" pointed out that a referendum may be a feasible solution and added that the possibility of the Cabinet being able to actually implement the KMT's prepared draft bill to scrap the existing nuclear plants while upholding the continued construction of the fourth plant is slim.

The E-generation claimed that if the DPP actually respected the law, it would not have proposed scrapping the fourth nuclear plant in the first place. The KMT faction also announced its own draft bill for a national referendum to decide the plant's fate.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT SINCERELY WANTS TO MEET WITH KMT LEADER: AIDE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian sincerely wants to hear the views of opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan when they meet Friday, a Presidential Office official said Thursday.
To demonstrate his sincere wish to reconcile with Taiwan's opposition parties, the official said that Chen has accepted the KMT's demand to open the Chen-Lien meeting to the media.
Last week, Chen held separate talks with People First Party Chairman James Soong and New Party chief Hau Lun-pin to exchange views on a broad range of issues.
On those occasions, press conferences were held after the closed-door meetings.
Because Friday's meeting will be open to the media from beginning to end, there will be no press conference afterward.

The Chen-Lien meeting has drawn much public attention because of the width of the policy gap between the KMT and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over issues such as cross-strait ties, economic and financial development, and whether to stop the fourth nuclear power plant project.
The KMT maintains a majority of the seats in the Legislative Yuan and without the party's cooperation, it is hard for bills submitted by Chen's government to get approved by the parliament.

Chen's aide said that during his meeting with Lien, Chen may also ask the KMT to let former Premier Vincent Siew, a KMT vice chairman, represent the president at the informal leadership conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to be held in Brunei next month.

The meeting, to be held at the Presidential Office, will be attended by Presidential Secretary-General You Shi-kun and Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Chen Che-nan on the DPP side, and by KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng and the party's spokesman Jason Hu on the KMT side.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Victor Lai) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: This is to replace CEP item 25, with a correction to the first line of the first paragraph concerning the date. "...Wednesday" should be changed to "Thursday". PRESIDENT CALLS FOR TAIWAN STRAIT CONFLICT PREVENTION MECHANISM

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PREMIER TO REPRESENT PRESIDENT AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has appointed former Premier Vincent Siew to represent him at an informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, the Presidential Office announced Thursday.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, told a press conference that Brunei, the host country of this year's APEC summit, has agreed to Siew's presence at the annual leadership meeting on behalf of Chen.
According to Yu, Chen has informed opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and Siew, a KMT vice chairman, of Brunei's consent to his choice of proxy at the APEC summit scheduled for Nov. 15-16.
"Siew has accepted President Chen's assignment," Yu said.

APEC, a regional forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, is one of the few international organizations which simultaneously accept the Republic of China and mainland China as full members.
However, because of Beijing's opposition, the ROC president has been unable to attend the annual APEC summit in person and has instead had to name a delegate to represent him.

Chen, the ROC's first president from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), originally appointed Vice Premier Lai In-jaw to attend the 2000 APEC summit on his behalf. The proposal, however, met strong opposition from Beijing and at Brunei's request, Chen was forced to pick another proxy.

This will be the third time that Siew has represented the ROC at the annual APEC informal leadership meeting. During the KMT government era, Siew represented former President Lee Teng-hui at the 1993 and 1994 APEC summits in his capacity as chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.
Siew is well-versed in trade, economic and financial affairs and also once headed the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.

As the DPP and the KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20, are not fully consistent in their stances on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait, it remains to be seen how Chen and Siew will work out terms regarding Siew's speeches at the APEC summit, particularly those related to cross-strait relations.
KMT spokesman Jason Hu, also a former ROC foreign minister, said Lien has agreed to Siew's attendance at the upcoming APEC summit on Chen's behalf.
Meanwhile, asked whether Lien would discuss APEC-related issues with Chen during a meeting scheduled for Friday, Hu said he could not make such a prediction.

As part of his efforts to promote inter-party rapprochement and cooperation, Chen was scheduled to meet Lien at the Presidential Office Friday in an open-door meeting to exchange views on a range of issues.
Chen held separate talks last week for the same purpose with the top leaders of two other opposition parties -- People First Party Chairman James Soong and New Party convener Hao Lung-pin.
As the KMT still controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan, the Chen-Lien meeting is expected to be the focus of much attention.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES US$ 1 MILLION TO PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government Thursday donated US$1 million to Paraguay in an attempt to help the South American country expand its fruit exports.

Liu Ting-tsu, ROC ambassador to Paraguay, made the donation on behalf of the ROC government to Paraguayan Minister of Agriculture and Livestock Enrique Garcia de Zuniga at the opening ceremony of a pineapple export center.
Liu told farmers that pineapple is an export item with a great potential market, since many former major pineapple exporters, such as Hawaii, Taiwan and the Philippines no longer export the fruit.

The ambassador said there is high global demand for pineapples and that Paraguay is ideally suited to pineapple cultivation. He added that the ROC government is very willing to support and help Paraguay become the world's main supplier of pineapple and its by-products.

Also in the name of the ROC government, Liu made a donation of US$300,000 on Oct. 23 to the office of the First Lady of Paraguay in support of her promotion of a social welfare program to help Paraguay's poor resolve water and sanitation problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR GIANT URGES OPENING TO MAINLAND CHINA MARKET

TEXT.P: The head of a Taiwan semiconductor giant urged the government Thursday to open up to the mainland Chinese market or face the stifling of Taiwan's industry.
Morris Chang, chairman and Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), made the remarks in a speech on Taiwan's electronics industry.

Chang said that there are two things crucial to the successful development of Taiwan's industry in the future. One is to open up to the mainland market or risk having the lifeline of its industry stymied, adding that this is where Taiwan lags behind other nations in terms of competitive edge.

He described the second factor as the need to establish a long-term steady policy and stable investment environment, adding that the Taiwan stock market, although it boasts the fifth-largest turnover of the world's bourses, is still not sound enough. He also pointed out that it is very difficult for people in other countries to find information about the Taiwan stock market.
According to Chang, the Taiwan stock market is like a casino, which he said affects major shareholders' plans to have long-term sustainable business management.

He stressed that cross-strait tensions have to be eased, saying that if the political situation is unstable, businesses will not be able to obtain the best possible results even if they perform well, which he said will certainly affect long term investment.
Meanwhile, an official in the information industry said that it would not be detrimental for the domestic information industry to move to the mainland.

Ke Chi-sheng, deputy CEO of the Institute for Information Industry, said that as long as high value-added information industry stays in Taiwan, and conducts R&D on forward-looking products, Taiwan will still maintain its leading position.

Ke made the remarks after reports said several leading domestic information product manufacturers are planning to invest in the mainland in anticipation of its imminent entry into the World Trade Organization, which they see as a boon to the domestic information industry.
Ke said that Taiwan is presently the third-largest information hardware producer in the world and it is expected to maintain growth of over 10 percent.

But, affected by a drop in demand for personal computers and the ever-dropping price of computer products, Ke said Taiwan has to move some of its low value-added information products, such as monitors and peripherals, to the mainland so as to take advantage of the cheap labor, land and technology talent there.

He noted that the mainland's information industry grew by 30 percent last year and said its annual production could surpass that of Taiwan this year, which could be attributed to Taiwan manufacturers' setting up plants in the mainland.
Ke said that Taiwan's information industry should focus on information appliances and imbedded software, as well as technology related to e-commerce and mobile phones.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN TO ATTEND APEC MEETING WITH KMT HEAD'S BLESSING

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said Thursday that he will do his best to accomplish the "very important mission" of attending the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian.
Brunei, the host nation, formally notified the ROC Foreign Ministry earlier in the day that it had accepted Siew as Chen's envoy.

Siew, who is currently a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, said through a member of his staff that he received the blessing of KMT Chairman Lien Chan after Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun announced at an evening press conference that Chen had appointed Siew to represent him during the Nov. 15-16 informal leadership summit.
According to Siew, Lien urged him to do his best "for the nation and for the party."

Earlier in the day, Siew told reporters that because he has no consensus with Chen on issues such as "one China" and "the 1992 consensus," if he is to attend the APEC meeting on Chen's behalf, authorization issues must be clarified before he participates in the summit.
However, he went on to say that APEC members have an overt agreement not to discuss politics or bilateral relations, with talks to focus on regional and multilateral economic cooperation instead.
Siew attended the summit on behalf of former ROC President Lee Teng-hui in 1993 and 1994 as chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

Chen had originally named Vice Premier Lai In-jaw to attend the conference, but Brunei later informed the ROC government that Beijing's opposition to Lai's selection had put Brunei in an awkward position.
Although the Republic of China is a member of APEC, its president has never rubbed shoulders with his APEC counterparts at the summit due to opposition from Beijing.

Beijing, which claims Taiwan as part of its territory, threatened to boycott the summit should the ROC president attend in person, forcing Taiwan to settle for having a ministerial-level official at the occasion.

APEC, a regional forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, is one of the few international organizations which simultaneously accept the Republic of China and mainland China as full members.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLIANCE FORMED TO SUPPORT `COMFORT WOMEN' IN MOCK TRIAL

TEXT.P: Several private groups in Taiwan formed an alliance Thursday afternoon to lend support to a number of local "comfort women" during a mock "world court" scheduled to be held in Tokyo in December.
The Taiwan Action Alliance to Support Comfort Women is made up of members of various local groups, including the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation and the Taiwan Alliance of Medical Professionals.
Wang Nien-tsu, a spokeswoman of the newly formed alliance, said that to help the 100 members participate in the mock trial, it has set a goal of raising NT$5 million (US$154,800).
Wang said the alliance will launch a signature campaign between 1:30 p.m. and 5:30 p.m. at Taipei Railway Station Sunday to support their cause and solicit donations.
The trial session, to be held Dec. 8-12 in Tokyo, is to be sponsored by a voluntary Japanese civic organization called The Violence Against Women Brought by War.

Two former "comfort women" from Taiwan, mainland China, Korea, the Philippines, Indonesia and the Netherlands will make representations in the court accusing Japan of war crimes and its government of irresponsibility.
During the mock court session, prosecutors from the six countries will submit bills of indictment and the comfort women will give their accounts of the accusations.
A verdict to be handed down by the court on Dec. 12, though non-binding in nature, will be jointly reached by law experts from the six nations and Japan and will become a historical record.
In addition to the 12 former comfort women, now in their 70's or 80's, more than 300 people from six nations, together with 700 from Japan, mostly human rights activists, will attend the session.

More than 200,000 young women from Taiwan, mainland China, South Korea, North Korea, the Philippines and Indonesia were abducted by the Japanese and forced to serve as sex slaves for the Japanese Imperial Army some 50 years ago.

According to an investigative report released early last year by National Taiwan University lecturers Lee Kai-min and Chiang Mei-fen, between 1932 and 1945 in Taiwan alone, nearly 2,000 women were sent by the Japanese to military brothels in Southeast Asia and Okinawa.

The report noted that although half a century has passed, the comfort women are still suffering, with half of them divorced or never having married, while 60 percent of them were rendered infertile as a result of their brutal treatment.

Until 1992, the Japanese government denied that its military was involved in running frontline brothels during the war, and even though it later admitted the existence of the brothels, it has refused to apologize or provide compensation to the surviving comfort women, saying that all questions of compensation have already been settled with the nations concerned.
The Japanese government instead set up a private Asian Women's Fund in June 1995 which offers to give each surviving comfort woman 2 million yen (about US$17,000) in compensation.
However, most of the surviving women, including those from Taiwan, have turned down the offer because the money comes from private donations rather than from the Japanese government.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPEACHED FORMER NAVY TOP BRASS DISPUTES CHARGES

TEXT.P: Former Commander-in-Chief of the Navy Admiral Yeh Chang-tung claimed Thursday that he has been falsely accused in an impeachment brought against him Tuesday by the Control Yuan.

In a defense of his role in choosing the French-made Lafayette-class missile frigate in preference to the South Korea-manufactured Ulsan frigate in 1989 as the navy's backbone, Yeh said the Lafayette frigate is superior to Ulsan in its anti-submarine and anti-blockade capabilities.

Although the navy initially intended to buy 16 2,000-ton Ulsans to replace its aging fleet, its evaluation revealed that the Lafayettes would also meet the needs of the force, Yeh said at a press conference.

Yeh made the comment to dispute the impeachment's charges that the Lafayettes, a blue-sea warship with a displacement of 3,000 tons, did not suit the navy's needs, considering the geography of the Taiwan Strait.

As to allegations that he deliberately concealed the navy's switch from Ulsans to Lafayettes and kept then-President Lee Teng-hui in dark, Yeh said Lee was fully aware of the decision change and was kept informed of the entire purchase process.

Yeh said he personally reported to Lee at a military conference on Dec. 18, 1990, about the initiation of a letter of intent with French authorities on the purchase of six Lafayettes, and was directed by Lee "to negotiate with France aggressively and wrap up the contract as soon as possible."
Lee's directions were recorded in the conference minutes stored at the General Staff Headquarters, according to Yeh.

He also argued that the navy did not inflate the price tag of the Lafayettes as accused by the impeachment papers, but that it rather listed a higher price in the budget to account for possible fluctuations in the foreign exchange rate.

Even the higher price listed in the budget had to be revised upward seven times from NT$4 billion apiece to NT$15.1 billion (US$125 million to US$471.87 million), because the navy, as well as the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology, which designed the weapons system for the warship, constantly revised the specifications of the ship to counter the rapid increasing military force of Beijing, Yeh said.
He said he was sure that no kickbacks were involved in the purchase of the hulls of the six Lafayettes while he was at the helm of naval headquarters.

The retired admiral said that the members of the Control Yuan presiding over the hearing of the case seemed prejudiced against him, summoning him while he did not feel well and refusing his request afterward for a chance to explain the details of the case.

Branding the impeachment the "most bitter insult" he has ever suffered in his military career, Yeh compared himself as Yue Fei, an ancient Chinese general who was framed by a treacherous minister and killed by the emperor.
Yeh and two retired vice-admirals were impeached Tuesday for their alleged inappropriate implementation of the navy's acquirement of Lafayettes.

The impeached will answer the charges before the Committee on the Discipline of Public Functionaries. Given the fact that all of them are retired, a guilty verdict from the committee will do no harm to them other then compromising their honor.
Taiwan ordered six Lafayettes from France in 1991 at about US$2.8 billion. A scandal surrounding the deal erupted in Paris in 1998, when big kickbacks involved in the sales came to light.
Former French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, who approved the sales in 1991, was investigated under the suspicion of having received bribes for the contract.
Taiwan began to look into the sale after the French authorities opened their judicial investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL NOT INCUR FINANCIAL TURMOIL: FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not incur financial turmoil in light of various economic indicators, but the rise of overdue loans and the bubble in the domestic construction sector are alarming signs, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said Thursday.
Yen made the remarks while calling on the Taiwan Alliance, a political faction in the Legislative Yuan.

Ho Chih-hui, a Legislative Yuan party whip of the opposition Kuomintang, said that despite government measures such as deferring payment of enterprise loans that transfers the risk to financial institutions, there will probably be financial turmoil within six months.
In reply, Yen cited various economic statistics to back his claim that no financial turmoil will occur in Taiwan.
He said domestically oriented financial turmoil mainly occurs in nations with long-term unfavorable balance of trade, such as Southeast Asian nations.
Typical phenomena of these nations are that their debt-raising accounts for a very high percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) and their economies' fundamentals are not good, he said.

Yen further pointed out that Japan, despite having high foreign exchange reserves, has had zero economic growth for many years. This, plus a great deal of loans to Southeast Asian nations that are hard to collect on, resulted in financial turmoil in Southeast Asia, he said, adding that basically, Japan is a victim of the Southeast Asian turmoil that broke out in 1997.

He said that Taiwan has enjoyed trade surpluses in two-way trade with many nations, owns a lot of foreign exchange reserves, maintains economic growth rate between five to six percent, and has very low debt-raising. These factors, he went on, make the likelihood of Taiwan suffering financial turmoil very slim.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 27, or the first day of the tenth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1728: Captain James Cook, English navigator, is born. His voyages in the ship Endeavour led to the European discovery of Australia, New Zealand, and the Hawaiian Islands.
1858: Theodore Roosevelt, U.S. statesman and president, is born. He won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts in ending the Russo-Japanese War.
1921: Yen Fu, a noted Chinese translator who introduced Western culture to China, dies in his hometown of Minhou in Fukien Province at the age of 67.
1922: The Italian government resigns under increasing pressure from the fascist movement under Benito Mussolini.
1927: Mao Tse-tung leads his followers and reaches Chingkangshan mountain in Kianghsi Province to establish a stronghold for the Chinese Communist Party.
1930: The Wuhsheh Incident occurs when Taiwan's aboriginal inhabitants in the Wuhsheh area of Taichung County launch their resistance campaign against Japanese rule and kill 134 Japanese.
1931: Representatives from Nanking and Canton meet in Shanghai for peace negotiations.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States to address a joint session of the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives.
1947: The Ministry of the Interior announces that the "Democracy Alliance" is an illegal organization subject to crackdown in accordance with current laws.
1947: The Sino-American Relief Treaty is signed in Nanking under which US$30 million worth of relief goods are to be shipped to Taiwan.
1955: Taiwan's first sex-change operation is successfully carried out at the Army First Hospital.
1961: The 16th United Nations General Assembly votes in favor of the admission of Outer Mongolia. The Republic of China abstains from the vote.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a treaty of amity in Seoul.
1971: The Republic of Congo changes its name to the Republic of Zaire.
1974: Teizo Horikoshi, president of the Interchange Association of Japan, and Sadan Iguchi, a director, arrive in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1978: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt shares the Nobel Peace Prize with Premier Menachem Begin of Israel.
1979: St. Vincent and the Grenadines becomes independent from Britain.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on Korean Ambassador Ock Man Ho to express condolences over the death of President Park Chung Hee.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan defends his decision to send a 2,000-strong force of Marines and Army Rangers to the Caribbean island of Grenada.
1986: An international conference on "Chiang Kai-shek and Modern China" opens in Taipei, and more than two hundred Chinese and foreign scholars attended the four-day meeting.
1987: A referendum in the Republic of Korea approves constitutional reforms, including the establishment of direct presidential elections.
1990: Moscow City Mayor Gavriil H. Popov arrives for a formal visit to the ROC to discuss the strengthening of ROC-Soviet trade relations.
1994: The Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the "Wildlife Conservation Law," greatly toughening penalties against violators and stipulating that the breeding of endangered animals in captivity must cease within three years.
1997: The Dow Jones index drops 554.26 points, its largest one-day decline in terms of points.
1999: The International Relations Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives amends and passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, aiming at extending U.S.-Taiwan security ties.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sense of mercy is in all men; the sense of shame is in all men; the sense of courtesy and respect is in all men; the sense of right and wrong is in all men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 136.68 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 136.68 points to close at 5,805.17.
Market turnover amounted to 79.37 billion (US$2.48 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 136.68 points to close at 5,805.17.

Encouraged by a rise in the U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,991.83, but due to profit-taking selling pressure later, share prices began to go down. The Bourse fluctuated between 6,003.38 and 5,804.92 during trading.

A total of 2.05 billion stocks worth NT$79.37 billion (US$2.48 billion) changed hands, a decreased from the previous trading session which saw 2.63 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$101 billion (US$3.16 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.9 percent, followed by textile issues and electrical shares, both at 2.6 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 2.3 percent, foodstuff shares and bank and insurance stocks, both at 1.9 percent, construction shares at 1.6 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 1.1 percent.
Losers outnumber gainers 470 to 69, with 76 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, FRANCE TO STEP UP PROTECTION OF INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By M. J. Tzou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: France and Taiwan will step up their cooperation in the protection of intellectual property rights, said Republic of China official Chen Ming-pang on Thursday.

Chen, the director general of the Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, made the remarks after concluding consultations with his French counterpart Philippine Hangard in western France.
Chen said that both sides discussed the two countries' laws and regulations concerning intellectual property rights protection and their implementation during the consultations.

Chen said that France and Taiwan will step up their cooperation in the protection of trade marks and patents, respect intellectual property rights of all forms of industrial technology, and further protect the rights of consumers.

The consultations were held in western France's rich brandy producing region. Chen, accompanied by Hangard, visited French brandy cellars to learn how France establishes its spirit brands and also how the spirits are assessed and classified.

Chen noted that French wine has always been popular with Taiwan consumers, but he added that some rogue businessmen have tried to sell wine falsely labeled as French for profits at the expense of consumers.

Consultations on this problem have led to an agreement between both sides to set up a comprehensive certification system under which the original information of all trade mark and brand wines will be provided in order to protect the image of French spirit manufacturers and the rights of Taiwan consumers.
Although trade marks for wines and liquors were the focus of this year's consultations, both sides also exchanged views on patent protection of biotechnology and aerospace technology.

Chen stressed that the strengthened patent and copyright protection will increase the advanced countries' trust in the Taiwan market, promote bilateral understanding, facilitate technology cooperation and transfers, and promote the upgrading of Taiwan's industries.

To step up the crackdown on imitation products and to increase cooperation in the protection of intellectual property rights, Hangard will visit Taipei on December 8 to preside over a seminar, during which he will explain the French approach to the protection of intellectual property rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

November TF futures moved down 26.4 points to close at 733.4, with 931 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE CARMAKER SEES OPPORTUNITIES IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Sales of automotive vehicles in mainland China could be good after Beijing joins the World Trade Organization and the country's import tariffs are substantially cut, predicted an Australian carmaker.

Peter Hanenberger, the head of Holden, told reporters Thursday that the mainland Chinese car market could become lucrative after Beijing becomes a WTO member because its import tariffs will drop to about 25 percent by the year 2006 from the current 80 to 100 percent.
"We see China outpacing all other countries in industry growth to 2010," he said, adding that 1.8 million new vehicles were sold in mainland China last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP THREATENS TO TOPPLE CABINET IF NUKE PLANT PROJECT SCRAPPED

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party on Friday threatened to dissolve the Cabinet by calling for a motion of no-confidence if and when the Cabinet announces the scrapping of the fourth nuclear power plant project.

The PFP party caucus at the Legislative Yuan made the vow to topple the Cabinet only a couple of hours before Premier Chang Chun-hsiung made a surprise announcement at noon that the administration has decided to call a permanent halt to the project based on six major reasons, taking the legislature as well as the public by surprise.

After heated debates on the controversial project Thursday at the Legislative Yuan, lawmakers from the ruling and opposition parties reached a "tacit understanding" that the Cabinet would decide on the issue by Nov. 15.

At a national affairs forum at the Legislative Yuan Friday morning, PFP Legislator Chen Chen-sheng said that scrapping the fourth nuclear power plant project would be "seriously illegal" because the project was passed by the legislature years ago and that such a move would necessitate the opposition parties to take urgent steps to hold a no-confidence vote.

The PFP legislative caucus spokeswoman, Lee Ching-an, also said Friday morning that halting construction on the US$5.6 billion nuclear power plant would violate the Republic of China Constitution and would be in blatant disregard of the people's will and the opinions of the opposition parties as well as many academics and experts.

Arguing that any budget that has been approved by the legislature should continue to be carried out, including the one for the fourth nuclear power plant, Lee said a motion of no-confidence would be exercised as soon as the Cabinet were to announce the scrapping of the project.

PFP Legislator Wang Tien-ching reminded the Democratic Progressive Party-led administration not to forget that it is only a minority government and that the DPP is only a minority party in the Legislative Yuan.
Wang urged the opposition Kuomingtang, which has a majority in the legislature, to "stand up" bravely against the DPP-controlled Cabinet.
"The Kuomintang cannot say it is qualified to be the ruling party if it does not dare to voice its opposition to such a critical decision," he added.

Meanwhile, Tseng Yung-chuan, the Kuomintang legislative party whip, declined to voice support for the PFP no-confidence proposal, despite the fact that some KMT legislators publicly seconded the PFP proposal at the Legislative Yuan national affairs forum.
Tseng said a no-confidence vote would be improper now that Taiwan's political situation has already become chaotic since the DPP-led administration of Chen Shui-bian was inaugurated on May 20.
Tseng stressed that the KMT would not cast a no-confidence vote against Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and his administration even if the move would benefit the KMT.
Instead, he noted, the KMT will take a lawful approach towards finding a solution to the disputes over the fourth nuclear power plant project.

The KMT will propose a draft bill on nuclear power utility in the Taiwan area, suggesting that construction on the fourth nuclear power plant be completed, the three existing nuclear power plants be scrapped when their operating life spans come to an end, and that no new nuclear power plants be built in Taiwan in the future.
Meanwhile, at least three KMT lawmakers voiced support for the PFP's call for a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet.

KMT Legislator Wu Ching-chih said he supports the no-confidence move, adding that President Chen Shui-bian should first be recalled before the Cabinet is toppled by a no-confidence vote in the name of justice for the legislature and the people of Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Lai Shyh-bao, convenor of the opposition New Party legislative caucus, said the New Party does not oppose the no-confidence motion in principle, but would think about it carefully before making such a move.

Toppling the Cabinet, which may possibly lead to President Chen dissolving the Legislative Yuan, would be too great a cost to society and would likely sink the whole country into unrest, Lai pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET ANNOUNCES HALT TO 4TH NUCLEAR POWER PLANT

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced a decision Friday to halt construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant, saying the move is the only choice for building a nuclear-free homeland.

"We must make a rational, responsible and conscientious choice for the well-being of our descendants and the only planet of the mankind, and the choice is that we must cease construction of the fourth nuclear power plant," Chang told a press conference.

Chang said the decision may not be able to satisfy all local people at the moment. "But I'm convinced that some day we can tell our offspring that we once bravely made the right choice for Taiwan," the premier said confidently.

Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Lin Chuan, director-general of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, and Atomic Energy Council Chairman Hsia Der-yu were present at the news conference to throw their weight behind the decision.

Chang cited six reasons to back the decision -- the scrapping of the fourth nuclear power plant will not cause domestic power shortages; concrete, feasible alternatives to the nuclear power plant are available; there is still no proper ways to resolve the thorny nuclear waste disposal problem; management of any nuclear disaster is no easy task; the loss to be caused by a halt to the fourth nuclear power plant project is lower than the cost needed for continued construction of the plant; and the government is determined to develop Taiwan into a nuclear-free "green silicon island."

In his statement, Chang stressed that the security issue surrounding the nuclear power plant is not just an economic problem, but rather a problem related to the lives of the 23 million residents on this island.
Chang further reminded local people that disposal of radioactive waste from nuclear power plants is not easily soluble. There is still no proper way for permanent disposal of nuclear waste, he added.
As for domestic power supply, Chang said even no alternative measures are taken following the termination of the fourth nuclear power plant, Taiwan will not face a power shortage in seven years.

Chang said the government has drawn up a comprehensive package of measures as alternative to the nuclear power plant, including encouraging private investment in construction of more fossil fuel power plants and promoting liberalization of the power generation industry.

Quoting an estimate by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Chang said the government would have to invest an additional NT$120 billion (US$3.8 billion) if construction of the fourth nuclear power plant were to be continued. "Moreover, we would have to spend a still-incalculable-amount of money for nuclear waste disposal," he added.

Chang said the decision to halt the fourth nuclear power plant was made after a prudent review of all possible issues. "We hope that all major domestic political parties and the general public will throw their support behind the decision and work together with the government to sustain Taiwan's economic development and build a nuclear-free environment," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRY EXPRESSES SHOCK OVER ANNOUNCEMENT TO SCRAP NUKE PLANT

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwan's industrial sector expressed their shock over Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's surprise announcement Friday at noon that the fourth nuclear power plant project will be halted for good.

Members of the Chinese National Federation of Industries complained vehemently about the Cabinet not demonstrating any sense of justice nor integrity concerning the controversial and much-debated project.

Noting that the six major reasons Premier Chang stated for scrapping the project were unjustifiable, particularly the expressed reason that "the alternative plan is highly viable," they lambasted the administration by saying that "in trying to deceive others, it has only ended up deceiving itself."
The CNFI has long been noted for its determination to prevent energy cost increases and to prevent power shortages from occurring in Taiwan's industrial sector.
Wu Si-chung, chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronics Manufacturers Association, said Chang's announcement about scrapping the fourth nuclear power plant project is absolutely unacceptable.

Terming it a sheer "reckless decision," Wu said the Cabinet should make sure that alternative plans are totally feasible and that the costs incurred from scrapping the project are not transferred to the industrial sector and the general public before it makes such a shocking and far-reaching decision.
Voices from the semiconductor industry, Taiwan's flagship and cash cow industry, expressed helplessness over Chang's announcement.
A spokesman for the Taiwan Semiconductor Industrial Association said scrapping the fourth nuclear power plant would double the uncertainty factors regarding investor's willingness to invest.

He predicted that the probability of semiconductor manufacturers, both domestic and foreign, locating their production lines in Taiwan will increasingly diminish in the wake of the government's decision.

Meanwhile, Hu Cheng-tah, vice president of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., one of the world's leading silicon wafer foundries, said the fourth nuclear power plant is required to meet the energy needs of the semiconductor industry, which requires a steady supply of high-quality power that only nuclear power plants can provide.
The costs to the nation of scrapping the project will be much higher than completing the plant if one factors in the social costs and the costs to the industrial sector, Hu said.

Noting that none of the government's alternative plans are viable, Hu said it would be a natural development if members of Taiwan's high-technology industry relocate their operations abroad one after another.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DEMANDS IMPEACHMENT FOR PREMIER

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang Legislative caucus called Friday for the Control Yuan to impeach Premier Chang Chun-hsiung for his announcement of the scrapping of the fourth nuclear power plant project, a move the KMT termed "illegal and impairing the public interest."

The KMT legislators demanded the Control Yuan, Taiwan's highest watchdog body, to impeach Chang as his announcement "violated the ROC Constitution and was illegal and invalid" because continuation of the construction of the nuclear plant was an issue passed by the legislature years ago, said Hung Yu-ching, executive director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee.
"No country in the world can simply stop executing a budget that has been passed by the legislature, because to do so is illegal," Hung noted.

In addition, he maintained, a motion proposed by the then-opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to overturn the KMT-initiated decision to build the plant was rejected by the Legislative Yuan two years ago, making Chang's announcement of the scrapping doubly illegal.

Hung stressed, however, that even if a no-confidence motion would benefit the KMT, the former ruling party will never call a no-confidence vote to topple the Cabinet, saying that as the DPP has already led the country into chaos since it became the ruling party in May this year, toppling the shaky Cabinet would be rubbing salt into the wound.
Control Yuan members Lee You-chi and Lin Shih-chi received the appeal made by Hung and around 10 other KMT members and promised that they will look into the case.

Meanwhile, Tseng Yung-chuan, the KMT legislative party whip, lambasted the ruling DPP as "ridiculously insolent and mad" for making the announcement at "a bad time" -- immediately after KMT Chairman Lien Chan's talks with President Chen Shui-bian about the fourth nuclear power plant project in an ostensible fence-mending meeting that same morning.

Noting that the announcement will certainly whip up a political and economic storm in Taiwan, Tseng said the DPP had better brace itself to face "growing economic inertia, social unrest and people's anxiety" in the immediate future.
KMT Vice Chairman and former Premier Vincent Siew described Chang's Friday surprise announcement of the scrapping of the fourth nuclear power plant as an "unwise and reckless" decision.

He said the government will have to bear all the repercussions of the long-debated case because it made the decision unilaterally without reaching consensus with opposition parties and without coming up with any viable alternative plans.
The KMT secretary-general also blasted the Cabinet for playing what he described as "a double-handed scheme" and for demonstrating "not the slight sense of sincerity."
"How could President Chen, as smart as he is, allow a stupid thing like this to happen?" he asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOPPING CONSTRUCTION OF NUKE PLANT `UNWISE:' FORMER PREMIER

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew described the government's decision Friday to stop the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant as "incomplete and reckless."

Siew, who has been appointed by President Chen Shui-bian as his special envoy at the informal summit of the 2000 Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum scheduled to be held in Brunei on Nov. 15-16, said the Chen administration will have to bear the consequences of its decision.
He claimed that the government's decision was "incomplete and reckless" as the government did not prepare sufficient alternative measures to the controversial power plant.
However, he disagreed with a proposal to topple the Cabinet because it would bring political turmoil to Taiwan and affect national economic development.

Unless private power plants can begin operations within the next several years, he went on, the Chen administration's promise that Taiwan will not lack electricity in the next seven years will not be enough to convince local businesses.
Speaking during an interview with a local radio station, Siew said that the decision to stop construction of the plant will also affect the local stock market.
He called on the government to use effective actions, not words, to speed up economic development. If the people lack confidence, economic development will decline, he pointed out.
He also cited the Bayer investment case in Taichung, claiming that there has been "no major foreign investment in Taiwan" since the Bayer investment case failed in 1998.
Siew also said that halting construction of the fourth nuclear power plant will also prompt more local enterprises move from Taiwan to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.174 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 32.267.
The local currency opened Friday at 31.995 and was traded between 31.995 and 32.290.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$426 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER TO FORM TASK FORCE TO HANDLE NUCLEAR PLANT ISSUE

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) said Friday it will immediately halt construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant in line with the government's decision to scrap the controversial project.

The state-run company made the statement after Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced at noon that his Cabinet had decided to cancel the fourth nuclear power plant project to protect future generations from possible radiation contamination.

"Taipower will abide by the government's decision to stop construction of the plant," Taipower Chairman Hsi Shih-chi said at a press conference, adding that the company will form a special task force to handle the halting of the project and its consequences.

The Legislative Yuan passed a budget of NT$125.5 billion (US$3.98 billion) for the project in July 1994. Of this amount, some NT$50 billion has already been spent on the plant, which is about one-third complete. According to the current budgetary regulations, Taipower will have to return the remaining budget to the national coffers.

Taipower officials said they are worried about the budget needed for compensating foreign suppliers of nuclear power generation equipment following the halting of the project. According to their estimates, Taipower will need NT$30 billion to NT$90.3 billion for compensating relevant equipment suppliers.
Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Boston-based Stone and Webster Engineering Corp. and General Electric Co. are supplying the two 1,350-megawatt boiling water reactors for the plant.
Taipower officials said they will try to re-sell the equipment to reduce their losses. However, they admitted that it will not be easy to find suitable buyers.

Asked whether Taipower will raise electricity rates to offset its financial losses incurred from the halting of the project, Taipower Chairman Hsi did not make a direct response, saying only that it will depend on whether the government demands that Taipower absorb the compensation cost.
In fact, Hsi said, an across-the-board power rate hike is long overdue because fuel costs have increased significantly in recent years due to rises in oil and natural gas prices.

As an alternative to the fourth nuclear power plant, Hsi said Taipower will take active measures in support of the government's policy of encouraging private investment in construction of more fossil fuel power plants to ensure sufficient domestic electricity supplies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO FILE NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION AGAINST CABINET

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) announced Friday it will file a no-confidence motion against the Cabinet and another motion to suggest that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung be impeached.

The PFP party caucus at the Legislative Yuan made the announcement at a press conference to blast the decision earlier in the day to scrap construction of the fourth nuclear power plant and also urged "conscientious and intelligent" legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the other opposition parties to support the PFP move.

PFP Legislator Chen Chen-sheng said at the press conference that it is illegal to halt construction of the plant and it is unjustifiable for the Cabinet not to carry out the plant's already-passed budget simply on the grounds that the ruling party has changed.

Lee Ching-an, PFP spokesperson at the Legislative Yuan, said the suspension of the construction of the plant will have an adverse effect on political stability. Faced with "a government which abuses its power," the PFP must exercise its right to bring no-confidence and impeachment motions "on behalf of the people of Taiwan."
Discontent with the opposition Kuomintang's attitude toward the Cabinet's scrapping of the plant, several PFP legislators urged the KMT to support the motions to topple the Cabinet and impeach Chang.

According to the KMT, however, toppling the Cabinet would waste a great deal of time and would have an adverse effect on social and political stability and the party will not do anything that will result in social and political instability.
PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei wondered why the KMT did not insist on its policy to build the plant and urged the KMT to safeguard its stance on the nuclear project.
PFP Legislator Wang Tein-ging said that now that the KMT is a majority party in the Legislative Yuan, it should stand bravely to maintain the welfare of the people of Taiwan and the dignity of law.
PFP Legislator Chin Huei-chu said it is shameful that the Cabinet has failed to respect the Legislative Yuan's decision to construct the plant made when the KMT was in power.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL IPR SEMINAR TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An international intellectual property rights (IPR) seminar will open in Taipei next Monday, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced Friday.

AIT officials said that the purpose of the seminar is to provide judges, prosecutors, and policy and enforcement officials with IPR responsibilities in Taiwan a better understanding of international IPR obligations and norms, with the focus on Taiwan's preparation for entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The seminar will be jointly sponsored by the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Board of Foreign Trade, the Intellectual Property Office and AIT, and will be held at the Judges and Prosecutors Training Institute.

Discussions will be focused on international IPR standards under the Trade-Related Intellectual Property System of the WTO and the WIPO Copyright Treaty. The seminar will continue on a basis of two-day seminars until Nov. 8.

Six IPR experts from the United States, including representatives from the Patent and Trademark Office, Customs, the Department of Justice, and federal judges will arrive in Taipei to take part in the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. UNDERSECRETARY OF COMMERCE ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR BRIEF VISIT

TEXT.P: Robert LaRussa, under secretary of the International Trade Administration of the U.S. Department of Commerce, arrived in Taipei Friday to discuss the steel trade, according to the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).
LaRussa is responsible for formulating and leading U.S. trade policy as head of the International Trade Administration at the U.S. Department of Commerce.

Prior to assuming his current position, LaRussa was the assistant secretary for import administration, which administers the anti-dumping and countervailing duty trade laws. He played a key role in advancing the U.S. position on dumping and subsidy issues in the World Trade Organization and U.S.-mainland China bilateral negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RESPECTS CABINET DECISION TO HALT NUKE PLANT PROJECT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian respects the Cabinet's decision to halt construction of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant, Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.

According to a Presidential Office press release, Yu said that Chen understands the decision, announced earlier in the day, was made with the country and the people's long-term best interests in mind and that the reasons behind the decision are "fairly adequate."

Yu said that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung had fully explained the decision-making process behind the announcement to Chen days ago and pledged that the country will not be at risk of a shortage of electric power once the plant is scrapped. Yu also quoted Chang as saying that the opinions from all sides were heard and that professional assessments were heeded.

The top presidential aide went on to say that Chang also promised all alternative plans to the nuclear plant will be "absolutely feasible" and will not adversely effect the country's economic development.

From the information provided by the Cabinet, Yu said that a nuclear power plant can generate electricity for 30 or 40 years but leaves behind a large amount of nuclear waste material. He added that even if a nuclear disaster does not occur in Taiwan, nuclear power is not a cheap source of energy. Furthermore, he went on, just a single disaster would be destructive to the people of Taiwan.

Yu pointed out that advocating a halt to the plant's construction in the current political reality is not beneficial to Chang's Cabinet because he will face immense pressure from the legislature, where the opposition has a majority.

However, Chang's final decision to scrap the plant shows his courage and wisdom, Yu said, adding that it also shows that the anti-nuclear policy is "definitely not an insistence on a political party's private wishes or ideologies, but for the benefit of future generations and to shoulder the historic responsibility of living on this piece of land."

Because Chang's announcement came hot on the heels of a historic meeting between the president and Lien Chan, chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, that took place only hours earlier, the KMT accused Chen of "double-dealing" and called into question whether Chen had known beforehand that the Cabinet was going to announce the decision.
