A presidential aide denied the allegations and said that a tacit understanding had existed between Chen and Chang for a decision to be announced in the near term, but that Chen did not tell Chang when to make the announcement.

The aide asked people "not to politicize" the circumstances. He went on to say that the Cabinet is under a lot of pressure and that whether the announcement was made Friday, Saturday, or next week, it would still come under fire.

He added that certain effects can be foreseen -- including a stock market plunge -- but asked the opposition parties not to use extreme measures such as toppling the Cabinet before evaluating the consequences of such actions.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL CEO PROMOTES TECHNOLOGY TRAINING FOR TAIWAN TEACHERS

TEXT.P: Intel Chief Executive Officer Craig Barrett announced on Friday his company's plans to include Taiwan in its "Intel Teach to the Future" project, which will give 10,000 local teachers technology training to improve the quality of education.

Barrett, who met in Taipei with Republic of China Education Minister Ovid Tseng, pointed out that students in the era of "knowledge-based economy" must learn to innovate and express themselves, the key to which rests in education and begins with teachers.

Therefore, he continued, teachers must incorporate the effective use of technology in the classroom and learn critical thinking in order to combine knowledge and life experience, which can then be taught to the next generation so that the students can learn independent thinking and analysis.
Tseng agreed with Barrett's assessment and noted that Taiwan students still lag behind in such abilities, which Tseng said are necessary in today's industries.

Barrett said that Intel will provide the equipment, the curriculum planning, and the millions of U.S. dollars in funding so that 10,000 elementary and middle school teachers can learn essential computer skills through 40 hours of lessons and 20 hours of self-study. The project is scheduled to begin in the latter half of next year and will take approximately three years to complete.

According to Barrett, Intel is promoting the project around the world, with as much as US$100 million invested in the training of 400,000 teachers in countries including the United States, mainland China and India.

Regarding the mass exodus of Taiwan high-tech manufacturing companies to mainland China, Barrett said it is not a crisis because companies move out to areas of lower production cost as a global trend. He added that as long as Taiwan can upgrade its industries from manufacturing-based to design-based, it should be able to cope with the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOLDS MEETING WITH KMT CHAIRMAN (I)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan held their first meeting Friday since Chen's election in March, in which Lien urged Chen to convene a National Unification Council (NUC) meeting.
Lien said that if Chen can restore the NUC's original responsibility and mission, he would be willing to take part in the meeting on behalf of the KMT.

Lien is the last of three major opposition leaders to meet with Chen. The president met last week with James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP) and Hao Lung-bin, convenor of the National Committee of Campaign and Development of the New Party.

Cross-Taiwan Strait relations dominated the much-hyped meeting, which went on for two hours rather than the originally planned one hour, although both men also touched on the domestic financial and economic situation, shortened working hours, the domestic energy problem and the controversial fourth nuclear power plant.

Lien said cross-strait relations should be based on peace, stability and development, should not jeopardize the status quo, should not be provocative, and should seek positive exchanges on a rational basis.

Lien said that although Chen promised during his inauguration speech that there would be no question of abolishing NUC and National Unification Guidelines, the NUC exists now only in name and not in substance.

He said the NUC clearly defines cross-strait relations in the belief that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait may have disputes over their systems, but never on the issues of national unification or independence.
Lien said that if the president will restore the original responsibilities and mission of the NUC, he would like to represent the KMT at NUC meetings.

Chen for his part stressed that a National Development Conference meeting four years ago decided to set up an advisory group on cross-strait relations, and added that a book published by Lien during the presidential campaign also appealed for the convening of a supra-party team, which became the basis of forming the President's Advisory Group on Cross-Strait Relations headed by Lee Yuan-tseh, respected Nobel laureate and president of Academia Sinica.
Chen expressed hope that Lien would take part in this advisory group.

The president said that he set the tone for the policy toward the mainland in his inaugural speech, which is that leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should use wisdom and creatively to deal with the question of a future "one China."

Lien said that the NUC is in itself a supra-party organization, and that because the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) would not attend the council meeting, the KMT government suggested setting up other consultation organizations. But as the DPP is now in power, he continued, there is no need for an overlap, and he urged the president "to show leadership" by convening a NUC meeting.

Lien also said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait did reach an agreement in 1992, adding that Taipei told Beijing in October that although both sides agreed on "one China," they had different views about its interpretation. In November, Beijing responded that it would accept "separate interpretations" of "one China."

He added that if it is not agreeable to the president to use "one China, separate interpretations," the term could be replaced by "the 1992 agreement." He said that this could be a basis for cross-strait dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-LIEN MEETING (II)

TEXT.P: The controversial fourth nuclear power plant was another subject on which the two sides failed to find common ground.

Lien suggested decommissioning the island's older first, second and third nuclear power plants while continuing construction of the fourth nuclear power plant, with the understanding that this would be the island's last.

He claimed that northern Taiwan will lack 2,100 megawatts of electricity by 2005, and that southern Taiwan will need 3.7 million tons of water in 2006, but can only obtain 2 million tons of water. As alternative energy sources are not clear, he went on, it will affect investors' decisions to invest in Taiwan.
Chen said that as the power capacity of the first and second nuclear power plants will surpass that of the fourth, there is no reason to continue with its construction.

Chen said that a report by the Ministry of Economic Affairs has clearly stated that northern Taiwan will not be short of electricity in seven years, and that suggesting construction of new nuclear plants to replace old ones is a blinkered attitude.

On Lien's criticism that the misery index on the island has risen since Chen's administration took office, Chen said that this is because a majority of the people still cannot adjust to the political changeover, saying that the top priority is to stabilize cross-strait and foreign relations and then continue to develop the economy.
He said that many of the problems did not arise in one day, but have accumulated over a long period of years and that it is unreasonable to expect a new government to solve them in a short time.
Lien also suggested that the president convene a national industrial conference to learn and help solve the difficulties faced by industry.

He said the industrial conference could discuss which industries should be upgraded, which have no chance of being upgraded and must undergo transformation, and which are too costly and should move overseas to survive.
Chen said that he would ask related government agencies to prepare for such a meeting.

In light of the domestic investment environment, Lien also suggested that the president consider putting off for two years the implementation of an 84-hour two-week work period bill scheduled for next year, to which Chen replied that as the bill was first proposed by the KMT, the KMT should consult within the Legislative Yuan for any changes.
He said he had no ideas on the issue.

Chen also expressed the hope that Lien would use his clout to support the government's crackdown on "black gold," or government links with organized crime, as well as the anti-corruption campaign, in the legislative election next year.

Lien claimed that the crackdown on "black gold" was the established stance of the KMT and a national consensus, but he also urged Chen's government to respect procedural justice, human rights and journalistic freedom in the process of the crackdown.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC ALTERNATIVE TO MILITARY SERVICE TO BEGIN NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry announced Friday that the first batch of draftees to be posted to Taiwan's overseas technical missions as an alternative to military service will be ready by the end of next year.

Huang Nan-huei, director-general of the ministry's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, said at a routine press conference that the Cabinet officially approved adding "diplomatic service" as a new category of alternative military service on Monday.

Huang said that applications will be accepted for an estimated 35 vacancies beginning May 2001. Approved draftees will begin five weeks of basic military training in August, followed by three months of foreign language and specialization training, he added.

He went on to say that they will be ready to be shipped abroad in December to serve as assistants in anywhere from five to seven of Taiwan's 40 overseas technical missions, which are located in 34 countries.
Huang said that most of the first batch will be sent to Taiwan's allies in Central America and Africa.

Because the difficulty of supervising the draftees will increase due to their overseas work locations, Huang said that his ministry is working on drawing up measures, with initial designs leaning toward giving the ROC embassies -- particularly military attaches -- complete authority over the draftees.
Huang added that a total of NT$16 million (US$496,000) has already been allocated to cover the cost of air tickets and overseas medical expenses for the 35 draftees.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-ROC PREMIER'S PRESENCE AT APEC SUMMIT UNCERTAIN

TEXT.P: Former Premier Vincent Siew's attendance at an upcoming summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian has become uncertain as Siew's party had not endorsed the arrangement as of Friday.

Siew is a vice chairman of the Kuomintang, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20 and now still controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan. The KMT decided to re-evaluate whether to allow Siew to represent Chen at the APEC summit following the Chen administration's announcement of a halt to the construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced the decision to scrap the controversial plant just half an hour after Chen, a stalwart of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), held talks with KMT Chairman Lien Chan on a range of issues facing the country, including whether to continue construction of the fourth nuclear power plant in Kungliao, a coastal township in northern Taiwan.

Many KMT Central Standing Committee (CSC) members and legislators were angered by the DPP-led government's anti-nuclear decision and the timing of its announcement of the decision. They said the timing of the announcement signified Chen's insincerity in wishing to promote inter-party rapprochement and cooperation and suggested that the party have second thoughts on whether to approve Siew's attendance at the APEC summit.

Siew said he agreed to Chen's appointment mainly based on the consideration of national interests. "I would be pleased to accept the assignment, but only with my party's consent," Siew said, adding that he would leave the decision to Lien's discretion.
Lien told Chen Thursday that he agreed in principle to Siew's attendance at the APEC summit but that he would have to further discuss the issue with the party's CSC members.

After listening to suggestions from Siew and the CSC, Lien said he would make a final decision after further observation of the DPP government's actions following its announcement of the halt to the plant's construction.

APEC, a regional forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, is one of the few international organizations which simultaneously accept the Republic of China and mainland China as full members.
However, because of Beijing's opposition, the ROC president has been unable to attend the annual APEC summit in person and has instead had to name a delegate to represent him.

Chen, the ROC's first president from the pro-independence DPP, originally appointed Vice Premier Lai In-jaw to attend the 2000 APEC summit on his behalf. The proposal, however, met strong opposition from Beijing and at Brunei's request, Chen was forced to pick another proxy.
The 2000 APEC leadership meeting is scheduled for Nov. 15-16 in Brunei.

Commenting on the KMT's decision to reconsider its consent to Siew's presence at the APEC summit, Secretary-General to the President Yu Shyi-kun said he hopes the KMT will honor its original decision.
Yu said a change of the ROC's representative to the APEC meeting would affect Taiwan's national image and cause unnecessary trouble and inconvenience to host Brunei.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD BLASTS ROC PRESIDENT FOR ABOUT-FACE AFTER MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's handling of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant issue received flak Friday from opposition Kuomintang leader Lien Chan, who said his actions were "rude, impolite, and immature."

Lien said at a meeting of the KMT's Central Standing Committee that he was very sincere and full of goodwill when he called on Chen earlier in the day at the Presidential Office to discuss issues that included the nuclear plant project.

He went on to say that Chen agreed the meeting should not be simply a formality, but rather should have concrete results. Furthermore, Lien said that Chen agreed to give careful thought to the nuclear plant issue, but Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's announcement of the scrapping of the project came almost immediately after the meeting between Chen and Lien ended.

Lien asked what the country is coming to when a nation's leader says one thing and does another half an hour later. This is a sign of "disrespect and lack of sincerity" to him, to the legislature, where the KMT holds the majority, and to most of the public, he said. Lien expressed regret and condemned Chen's "trickery" for what he described as the "private interest of a political party."
The KMT had already studied various ways to respond, Lien said, adding that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's "major historical error" is only the beginning and not the end of the problems.

Lien stressed that he did not feel humiliated or cheated because he "knew what kind of man he was facing" and already had "thorough considerations" before heading to his meeting with Chen. He added that the person and the government he faced turned out to be "as he had expected," and he felt it was "a pity."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAVYWEIGHTS SUPPORT CABINET DECISION TO HALT 4TH NUKE PLANT

TEXT.P: Several heavyweights from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lent their support Friday to the Cabinet's decision to halt construction of the fourth nuclear plant
Meanwhile, residents in the vicinity of the construction site in northern Taiwan were elated by the decision.
DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh said that his party fully supports the Cabinet's policy and will publish pamphlets to explain the reason for opposing nuclear power.

Hsieh said that although there are differences in the party over how to solve the controversial project, into which the previous Kuomingtang-led administration had already pumped millions of dollars and which is now 30 percent complete, there has never been any support within the DPP for its continued construction.
He said that his party's opposition to the plant did not start only after it took power, but is a long-standing stance based on the long-term sustainable management of Taiwan.

He said the construction of the plant involves not only economic and employment problems, but that concern should also be given to the storage of nuclear waste and the possibility of nuclear disasters.

He said the government might have to pay huge sums in compensation for breaching contracts with suppliers of the plant's equipment, but added that if the private sector can construct power plants, the government will save billions in expenditure, which would go some way toward balancing the compensation payouts.

Residents in Kungliao, Taipei County, set off firecrackers upon hearing the news. Wu Wen-tung, an anti-nuclear activist, said the road to fight against nuclear power is long and winding and the cost paid is too high.
He expressed the hope that future administrations will be cautious in public works so as to avoid paying huge costs like the Kungliao plant.

Meanwhile, DPP veteran Shen Fu-hsiung said the political situation will be turbulent after the halt of the plant's construction, but he predicated that the KMT, which dominates the Legislative Yuan, and the opposition People First Party (PFP), which only holds 19 seats, will not topple the Cabinet.
Shen said that DPP legislators will now take up "battle stations" to brace for the chaotic situation in the legislature.
Hsu Tain-Tsair, party whip of the DPP in the legislature, said that the DPP caucus will form a team to deal with the impact caused by the halt of the plant's construction.
He said that the DPP will watch closely possible proposal by the PFP to topple the Cabinet and if it makes such a proposal, then the caucus will "protect the Chang Cabinet by all means."
Former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh said that he fully supports the Cabinet's decision, saying that "delaying the decision is absolutely not a good thing."

He also said that some may feel that they have been "tricked" by the premier's abrupt announcement despite an agreement Thursday that the decision would only be made Nov. 15, but added that "they should not take the matter too seriously."

Chen Poh-chih, chairman of the Council of Economic Planning and Development, revealed that when the debate for the plant's budget heated up in July 1994, he advised then President Lee Teng-hui as a scholar not to endorse the plant.
He also said that a "heavyweight business in the United States" supported the decision to halt construction, although he did not reveal its identity.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PROSECUTOR RETURNS FROM FRANCE

TEXT.P: A prosecutor reportedly on a mission to France to probe the scandal surrounding Taiwan's acquisition in the 1990s of six warships, returned to Taipei Friday.

Speaking to reporters at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon his return, Hung Wei-hua denied that he had gone to Paris to seek information about Taiwan's purchase of six Lafayette frigates from France and disputed local reports that his activities in Paris were closely monitored by the French authorities.
Instead, the prosecutor charged with probing the case said his visit was a vacation.
A local newspaper had claimed that Hung headed for Paris on Oct. 18 to seek clues about huge kickbacks involved in the Lafayette deal.

Hung's departure from Taiwan was kept low-profile out of concern that his mission might be thwarted by the French authorities. Taiwan could not ask France for legal assistance due to the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries, according to the paper.
The frigate scandal erupted in Paris in 1996 when an ex-mistress of former French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas accused him of accepting bribes to approve the sale of the warships in 1991.

The Taipei authorities began looking into the case after Dumas was forced to resign from his post as president of the Constitutional Court earlier this year and was eager to find out what clues the French authorities had in their possession.
The investigation has already seen the arrest of two retired Republic of China naval officers for inflating the prices of the warships, but has otherwise made very little progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE URGED TO STOP GOVERNMENT FROM SCRAPPING NUCLEAR PLANT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou urged the Legislative Yuan Friday to halt the government's decision to scrap the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant.
Ma claimed that halting construction of the plant will shock local economic development and Taiwan's international image.

He expressed belief that a legal proposal by the opposition Kuomintang was a way to stop the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government from scrapping the plant and stop Taiwan's "continued decline."

He criticized the timing of Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's announcement of the decision to scrap the plant, saying that it was inappropriate to make such an announcement so soon after a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and KMT Chairman Lien Chan.
The move showed disrespect to Lien, who Chen had repeatedly described prior to the meeting as one of the men whose suggestions and advice he would seek, said Ma.

The premier's announcement will certainly deal a heavy blow to domestic economic development and Taiwan's international image, which will be reflected in the local stock market, investment willingness and the moving of enterprises from Taiwan to other nations.

He urged Chen to "hear the voice of the populace" and correct the "wrong decision." Otherwise, he went on, Taiwan might end up like the Philippines and Argentina, both of which went from riches to rags.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUCLEAR PLANT DECISION WILL REFLECT ON STOCK MARKET: EX-CEPD HEAD

TEXT.P: Former Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) P.K. Chiang said Friday that the Chen administration has lost a good chance to recover the people's confidence by announcing the halt to construction of the fourth nuclear power plant.
The move action will exacerbate the mistrust of the people toward the government, Chiang said, adding that this will certainly reflect on economic development and the stock market.
Chiang, now executive head of a Kuomintang think tank, strongly criticized some members of Cabinet as having lost their professionalism and conscience after assuming power.
He made the remarks at a press conference held at the KMT Central Standing Committee.

He said that he felt deeply affected by the announcement of the halt to construction of the plant so soon after the end of what was supposed to have been a rapprochement meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and KMT Chairman Lien Chan. The KMT had originally worked out measures to help the Chen administration cope with local economic development, he said, adding: "My heart has been disappointed after hearing the government's decision."
The Chen-Lien meeting should have created a cordial atmosphere that would have reassured the public, he said, but added that the DPP-led government had destroyed this mood.

Chiang quoted People First Party Chairman James Soong, saying he "does not underestimate the economic situation and overestimate the government capability to deal with the event." He said that many major investments have encountered difficulties in counties or cities governed by the DPP. This, he claimed, reflects whether the government's alternative measures for the plant will succeed or not.

He criticized Economics Minister Lin hsin-yi and CEPD Chairman Chen Po-chih's declaration that Taiwan will not lack electricity supplies in the coming seven years, saying that Taiwan will naturally not lack electricity, as all the domestic enterprises will leave Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLOMON ISLANDS PRIME MINISTER TO VISIT ROC

TEXT.P: Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare will arrive in Taiwan Monday for a weeklong visit, a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.
Henry Chen said that during his stay in Taiwan, Sogavare will meet with President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Huang-mao and other government officials.
Sogavare will also visit cultural and economic establishments of the Republic of China, and host the opening ceremony of the Embassy of Solomon Islands in Taipei.
The visit is aimed at strengthening the bilateral relationship and exploring new opportunities in trade and investment between the ROC and Solomon Islands, according to Chen.
Sogavare will give a briefing on the outcome of the Townsville Peace Talks and the implementation of a peace agreement signed by the belligerent factions in Solomon Islands during his stay.

On reports that the war-ravaged Pacific island nation may want to ask Taiwan for US$34 million in aid and US$25 million in loans, Chen said that Solomon Islands has yet to convey such a wish and added that the two sides have not talked about anything related to financial assistance.
Chen said that the ROC will do its utmost to assist its allies, but will have to take into consideration its capacity to provide such assistance.
Wire reports said last week that Solomon Islands was considering switching diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in exchange for a huge financial payoff from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA CLARIFIES REPORT OF DECLINE IN ROC'S APPEAL TO INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Friday that Taiwan has attracted more inbound investment than its own outbound investment so far this year.

Lin made the remarks after local business monthly CommonWealth published the results of a recent survey which show Taiwan's ranking as a popular Asian investment destination has declined from third place in 1999 to second last among the 11 countries included in the study.

Quoting statistics compiled by the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), Lin said foreign and overseas Chinese investment in Taiwan amounted to US$5.59 billion in the first nine months of this year, up 111 percent from the same period of 1999.
In comparison, outbound investment by Taiwan enterprises totaled US$3.07 billion during the January-September period.
Lin said the figures indicate that Taiwan remains attractive to foreign and overseas Chinese investors.

He admitted that Taiwan cannot compare with mainland China in terms of land and labor costs. Nevertheless, the minister said, the MOEA will continue working hard to improve Taiwan's investment climate by integrating all its resources and upgrading its administrative efficiency.
According to the CommonWealth survey, Taiwan was ahead of only the Philippines in its appeal to foreign investors among the 11 Asian countries compared.

The magazine sent out 617 questionnaires to foreign businessmen from Oct. 9-20 to explore their views on Taiwan's general investment climate and its new government's performance. A total of 148 valid replies were collected.

Survey results show that about 60 percent of the respondents were dissatisfied with President Chen Shui-bian's performance. Chen is the Republic of China's first president from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party.

According to the survey, 49 percent said they have no confidence in Premier Chang Chun-hsiung-led Cabinet's crisis management capability, compared to 41.78 percent who said they are confident of the Chang Cabinet's ability to manage economic and financial crises.

The survey also found that the percentage of foreign investors who think Taiwan's investment climate has worsened has increased from 25 percent to 76 percent over the past six years, while the ratio of those who intend to expand investment in Taiwan has declined from 36.7 percent in 1994 to 15.1 percent this year.

According to the survey, foreign investors in Taiwan hope that the new DPP government can improve Taiwan's investment climate by improving relations with mainland China, maintaining political stability and wiping out corruption and shaddy connections between politics and organized crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPEACHMENT OF RETIRED ADMIRALS CRITICIZED

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan's impeachment of three retired admirals for their roles in Taiwan's purchase of six French-made frigates drew fire from legal experts and scholars at a symposium Friday.
They accused the Control Yuan of stepping beyond its jurisdiction and degenerating into an instrument of political suppression by impeaching Tuesday a former naval head and two of his vice admirals.

Che Chung-chuan, a former member of the Control Yuan, said the five-member panel which passed the impeachment exceeded their authority by disapproving of the navy's choice of weapons systems when they are mandated only to expose irregularities and dereliction of duty by government employees.

He said the navy is free to choose the arms they deemed best suited to their demands and that the Control Yuan panel was trying to pull strings in the navy's decision to acquire warships by claiming in their impeachment that the Lafayette-class frigates bought from France did not meet the navy's needs.

Policy making is something to be supervised by the popularly elected Legislative Yuan, rather than the Control Yuan, which consists of members nominated by the president and approved by the National Assembly, said Che.

Furthermore, the process of impeachment is supposed to be brought against government officials and active military officers, and it is a waste of time to impeach three retired admirals, to whom no punishment can be applied.
Che banded the impeachment as illegal, arguing that the negotiations on the purchase of the Lafayettes began from 1989, which is too long ago to be pursued by impeachment under the law.
He blamed the Control Yuan panel for deliberately "spilling the beans" about the outcome of their investigation before the impeachment was formally put forward.

Che said the panel deviated from its original purpose of unearthing alleged huge kickbacks in the deal and the possible links between the kickbacks and the death of a navy captain who was involved in the deal.
Legislator Lee Ching-an of the People First Party blamed the Control Yuan for ruining its own credibility and debasing itself into a tool used by politicians to strike at their political rivals.

The controversial impeachment was passed Tuesday on the grounds that the Lafayettes did not meet Taiwan's defense needs and the purchase decision was made without following the due policy-making process.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL VISITS MONTREAL SEEKING RECOGNITION OF HOMELAND

TEXT.P: Senior Taiwanese presidential adviser Yao Chia- wen visited Montreal Thursday to ask in person what his bosses can't: that the international community recognize Taiwan as a nation independent of communist China, a major daily in Quebec reported Friday.

The Montreal Gazette, the only English newspaper in Canada's second largest city, quoted Yao as saying the internatonal community knows Taiwan is an independent state, but won't acknowledge the fact because it is afraid the communist Chinese government would attack Taiwan.

"We believe that Taiwan is qualified to be member of the international society. We have improved our human rights situation. We have reform- ed our political situation to be a free, liberal and democratic government. Under the standards of civil society, we are a good country," Yao was quoted.

The Gazette quoted Robert Henderson, a political and economic consultant who studies Taiwan, as noting, "A lot of Chinese would love to have what the Taiwanese have." But the threat of a Chinese military strike still worries Taiwan, added Henderson.
Ellen Huang, a Taiwanese TV talkshow celebrity, was quoted as saying the Taiwanese would not know how to stop China if war broke out.
But Yao argued attacking Taiwan now would only confirm to the world that China is a repressive regime, the daily said. "He said he doubts China really wants to invade Taiwan," it added.

Yao reasoned China can't use the military force in the near future because of international relations: "They want to host the Olympic Games. They want to become a member of the WTO. They want to persude American people to invest in their country."
Still, Yao was quoted as adding, "China's military generals may feel differently."

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR SUGGESTS `TAIWAN SQUARES' TO PROMOTE TRADE WITH EUROPE

TEXT.P: An idea to establish "Taiwan Squares" with trade and cultural activity functions in major European cities was introduced Friday at a public hearing held at the Legislative Yuan.
Chang Wei-pang, a professor at Tamkang University, introduced the concept at a public hearing on how the government can assist Taiwan enterprises wishing to make inroads into European markets.

Hearing organizer Legislator Chuo Jung-tai said that according to statistics compiled by the Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Taiwan's exports to Europe in the first eight months of this year accounted only for 15.7 percent of the island's total exports during the period, while the growth rate of its exports to Europe in the period was much lower than those to other areas.
This, coupled with the small- and medium-sized enterprise-led economy in Taiwan makes it all the more necessary for the government to help Taiwan enterprises to promote trade with Europe, he said.

Chang said that the most effective and feasible method to achieve the goal would be to rent or buy office buildings in major European cities to set up "Taiwan Squares" with various advertisement hoardings to attract European businessmen to do business with Taiwan.

Chen Chien-chun, deputy director of the European Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), said MOFA has long known about the "Taiwan Squares" concept, but added that such an idea would be too expensive for the government to contemplate.

He suggested that large-scale domestic business groups or syndicates should consider establishing such facilities and request that MOFA personnel based abroad could be stationed there to help Taiwan businessmen promote trade with Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S SCRAPPING OF NUCLEAR PLANT `UNDERSTANDABLE:' U.S. BUSINESSMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A U.S. business leader described as "regrettable but understandable" Taiwan's decision Friday to halt construction of its fourth nuclear power plant.

Rupert Hammond, President of the U.S.-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, told CNA that the United States should leave Taiwan's government and people to decide whether to go ahead with the construction of the plant and that Washington has absolutely no role to play in the matter.

However, he went on, the Taiwan government should compensate the foreign builders, notably U.S. firm General Electric -- which is contracted to build the plant's reactor -- according to the terms of their contracts, or it will damage the island's international image as a reliable trade partner.
In order to attract foreign investment, he continued, Taiwan should convince potential foreign investors that the island will have abundant electricity after 2005 even without the nuclear plant.

He was responding to an announcement earlier in the day by ROC Premier Chang Chung-hsiung that the government had scrapped construction of the nuclear plant despite it being already 30 percent finished and despite the fact that the move will incur huge compensation claims from foreign companies contracted to supply the plant's equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 28, or the second day of the tenth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: Christopher Columbus discovers Cuba on his first voyage to the New World and claims it in the name of Spain.
1636: Harvard College is founded at Cambridge by the General Court of Massachusetts on the comparatively modest sum of US$740, part of US$1,440 bequeathed to the university by Mr. John Harvard, assistant pastor of the First Church of Charleston.
1746: An earthquake completely destroys Lima and Callao in Peru, killing more than 18,000 people.
1794: Robert Liston, the Scottish doctor who performed the first operation in Britain on an anesthetized patient, is born.
1886: A statue called Liberty Enlightening the World, the largest present ever sent to the American people from the French, is inaugurated on Liberty Island in the Upper Bay of New York Harbor by President Grover Cleveland.
1891: A strong earthquake rocks the Niphon Islands in Japan, killing 10,000 people and leaving more than 300,000 others homeless.
1901: Taiwan's first Shinto shrine is inaugurated on Yuanshan in Taipei during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan.
1912: Sir Richard Doll, the British cancer researcher who proved the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, is born.
1914: Jonas Salk, the American microbiologist who developed a polio vaccine, is born.
1950: Finland establishes diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1953: A launch ceremony for the first batch of U.S.-provided fishing boats to Taiwan is held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
1962: Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev informs U.S. President John F. Kennedy that work on missile sites under construction in Cuba will be halted and that missiles already delivered will be shipped back to the USSR.
1966: Wu Chen-nan, former leader of the "Taiwan Independence Revolutionary Council" in Japan, returns to Taiwan.
1971: The British House of Commons votes in favor of joining the European Economic Community by a vote of 356-244.
1972: Two pandas, a gift from Communist China to Japan, arrive at the Ueno zoo in Tokyo.
1973: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi and two other Japanese leaders arrives in Taipei to extend birthday congratulations to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1977: Taiwan's first experimental geothermal power plant goes into operation in Ilan.
1979: Movie star James Mason arrives in Taipei to attend the Golden Horse Awards presentation ceremony at the invitation of the Movie and Drama Association of the ROC.
1980: Asaad Abdul Aziz Al-Zuhair, the first resident Saudi Arabian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Felipe Gonzales, 40, becomes Spain's first Socialist prime minister in a landslide victory.
1989: More than 10,000 people rally in protest of the government on the 71st anniversary of Czechoslovakia's independence.
1992: Australian Tourism and Resources Minister Alan Griffiths visits Taipei to promote closer bilateral trade relations. He is the first Australian minister to visit Taipei since 1972.
1993: An explosion occurs at Taiwan Power Company's Hsintienlun power plant in central Taiwan, killing six people and injuring 26 others.
1993: Communist China resumes trade relations, cut off since July, 1960, with South Africa.
1999: Renowned Japanese writer Ayako Sono arrives in Taipei, bringing with her a cash donation of 300 million yen (US$2.88 million) and immeasurable compassion for Taiwan's earthquake victims.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "He who attends to his smaller self becomes a small man, and he who attends to his greater self becomes a great man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Cabinet scraps fourth nuclear power plant, braces for political storm.
The China Times:
Political storm looming large following the scrapping of the fourth nuclear power plant project.
The United Daily News:
Opposition angry at the abrupt Cabinet announcement to cease construction of the fourth nuclear power plant.
The Liberty Times:
The timing of the announcement of the cancellation of the nuclear power plant caught virtually everybody off guard.
The China Post:
Fourth nuclear power plant to be scrapped: Premier Chang.
The Taiwan News:
Premier halts fourth nuclear power plant.
The Taipei Times:
Cabinet pulls plug on power plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONCERNED ABOUT TAIWAN'S FULFILLMENT OF CONTRACTUAL OBLIGATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States Friday reiterated its concern about Taiwan's fulfillment of its contractual obligations after the island decided to halt construction of a controversial nuclear power plant.

U.S. Statement Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the decision on whether to proceed with the construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant is a choice for Taiwan authorities to make.

"And our major concern is that contract provisions all be fulfilled," Boucher said, referring to a business contract previously reached between Taiwan and General Electric Co. about the supply of nuclear power generation equipment to be installed in the fourth nuclear power plant.

In a surprise move, the Republic of China government announced its decision Friday to pull plug on the nuclear power plant to protect the people of Taiwan and their offspring from possible radiation contamination.

Asked whether the State Department has anything to say on Taiwan's decision, Boucher said: "We certainly think it's a decision for them (Taiwan) to make, and at the same time, we will advocate on their behalf to see that contract provisions are obeyed."
Boucher further noted that the design of the nuclear reactor to be sold to Taiwan has been certified by the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

"It's safe for construction in the United States. So, you know, we would hope that this would not reflect in any way on the quality of this reactor, which is certified," Boucher stressed in an effort to prevent any doubt about the quality and safety of the U.S.-made nuclear reactors.

As for whether the State Department has concern that the incident might have an adverse impact on the U.S. business confidence in Taiwan, Boucher said: "I think that's maybe better for businesspeople to comment on than for me."

According to an estimate by Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs, the ROC's state-owned Taiwan Power Co. will have to compensate foreign power generation equipment suppliers NT$30 billion (US$952.38 million) to NT$90.3 billion (US$2.87 billion) for scrapping the reactor deal.
Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Boston-based Stone and Webster Engineering Corp. and General Electric Co. are supplying the two 1,350-megawatt boiling water reactors for the Taiwan plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER URGES ACCUSED FORMER HEAD OF STATE RADIO TO RETURN

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan on Saturday urged Chu Wan-ching, a former Central Broadcasting System director who is currently in the United States despite travel restrictions, to return as soon as possible to answer prosecutor inquiries.

Chu was charged with embezzlement and released on NT$500,000 (US$15,500) bail Oct. 12, after which she immediately took a flight to Los Angeles, claiming that she did not know she was barred from leaving the country. She had stressed that she had only left for the United States in order to accompany her son to a military boarding school in Pennsylvania whose reported registration deadline was Oct. 14.

She told reporters Friday that she had originally intended to return to Taiwan as soon as she could, but concerns that she might be arrested and taken into custody immediately upon her return made her decide to ask Taipei prosecutors for a three month leave of absence during which she will wait for an official green card to be issued.

She added that if she were arrested, it would be even more difficult for her to defend her innocence. Therefore, she said she will return after her lawyer has found out everything about the case for her.

Speaking to the press at the inauguration ceremony of the Taiwan Criminal Law Association, Chen assured Chu that the so-called "white terror," "unfair justice," and "political persecution" may have been a part of Taiwan's past, but that they no longer exist, particularly since the new government took over in May.
He advised Chu to return in order to clarify certain "points of doubt," adding that some "unnecessary suspicions" would otherwise have an unfavorable effect on Chu's defense.

Chu announced that she received her temporary green card under a priority immigration article for talented and outstanding individuals on Friday after completing a process of deferred inspection at the U.S. Immigration Office in Los Angeles. She said that she will apply for her Social Security card in the next few days and wait for her permanent resident status to be approved.

She added that the pressing matter at hand is to ask the prosecutors to look into the NT$16 million (US$496,000) she was accused of embezzling from the CBS Trust Fund. (By Chu Lu-sheng and Fang Wen-hung) ENDITEM/Li ZCZC CEP005 10-28-00 EX-FINANCE MINISTER ORDERED TO POST NT$600,000 BAIL

Taipei, Oct. 28 (CNA) Former Finance Minister Paul Chiu was ordered to post NT$600,000 bail after he was formally questioned Friday night by a Taipei district prosecutor about his alleged wrongdoings during his tenure as finance minister.

Chiu was accused of instructing four domestic financial institutions organized into a banking group to bail out financially troubled Hung Fu Securities Finance Corp. and of providing the banks with false Hung Fu financial statements in 1998, resulting in large losses for the banking group.

The four members of the banking group are the International Commercial Bank of China, the Shanghai Commercial and Savings Bank, the United World Chinese Commercial Bank, and the International Securities and Finance Corp.
It was reported that Chiu instructed the banking group to take over Hung Fu Securities Finance Corp. by buying its stocks at a price of NT$6 each, lower than par value.

After checking Hung Fu's assets and liabilities, the banking group found that the failing corporation's shares were actually only worth NT$0.12 per share, resulting in a huge financial loss for the banking group.

After a six-month investigation, Prosecutor Meng Ling-shih of the Taipei District Prosecutors Office summoned Chiu to be questioned Friday night about his alleged misconduct in the Hung Fu case. Chiu was ordered to post NT$600,000 bail shortly after the interrogation.

Chiu defended his innocence Saturday by saying that his conduct concerning the Hung Fu case was totally in line with the Banking Law, according to which the Ministry of Finance had the right to settle the Hung Fu case by seeking feasible bailout measures.

Chiu went on to say that the banking group had reached an agreement with Hung Fu boss and Taipei City Councilor Chen Cheng-chung in 1998 when Hung Fu Securities Finance Corp. was faced with a financial crisis.

According to the agreement, Chen had to refund any excess money obtained by selling Hung Fu's shares if the banking group found that the net value of the corporation's shares were lower than what the banking group paid for them when taking over the corporation, or else the banking group could choose not to buy Hung Fu's shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE NEVER PROMISES BEIJING DEADLINE FOR ARMY TRAINING IN ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Singapore's influential former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said Friday he has never promised mainland Chinese leaders a deadline for ending the Southeast Asian city state's military training cooperation with Taiwan.

Lee, now a senior minister, made the remarks at a dinner in response to an inquiry about his answer to a question by former mainland Premier Li Peng some 10 years ago concerning Singapore's dispatch of armed forces to Taiwan for training purposes.

Lee said he didn't promised Li when Singapore will stop sending its troops to the Republic of China to receive necessary military training. "I had instead clearly told Li that Singapore intends to continue sending its military servicemen to Taiwan for training and military exercises," he explained.

The respected Singapore elder statesman went on to say that he had asked mainland authorities to inform Singapore in advance once mainland China would take military action against Taiwan so that Singapore can evacuate its troops from the island in time.

Lee said Singaporean troops in Taiwan have consistently worn the ROC's military uniforms to avoid causing any inconveniences for local residents. As a result, Lee said, Singapore military servicemen would face risks if mainland China attacks Taiwan. "Therefore, we are hopeful that Beijing would notify us in advance so that we have enough time to evacuate our troops from Taiwan," he added.
Under a cooperation program, Singapore has regularly sent its troops to Taiwan for basic combat training and exercises for past decades. The cooperation program has proceeded smoothly.

Singapore recognizes Beijing, while maintaining close substantive ties with Taiwan. Lee himself also maintains friendly relationships with top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. He made a low-profile visit to Taipei in September for wide-ranging talks with ROC President Chen Shui-bian and other senior government officials in charge of relations with mainland China.
Lee has repeatedly encouraged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume dialogue, but he has also made it clear that he has no intention of mediating cross-strait negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOV'T TO BASE CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS ON TRADE: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government hopes to establish a trade-driven relationship with mainland China in which bilateral trade can replace ROC investments in the mainland, said Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung Saturday.

Chen said at a MAC-sponsored seminar on cross-strait relations and mainland issues that direct trade, postal, and transport links between Taiwan and mainland China are "unavoidable" and part of an "inevitable trend."

He said that the new government's principle goal following the establishment of the links will be to let bilateral trade and economic relations move ahead of political contentions between the two sides so that a structure of mutual economic development and co-existence can be instituted.

He went on to say that "stability supercedes all" while the government is carrying out this trade-based policy and that many plans under consideration are meant to lay the groundwork for mutual orientation.

The plans under consideration include the initial implementation of the three links between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China's Fujien province starting in January, the opening up of Taiwan-proper to mainland tourists next June, the re-evaluation of the government's "no haste, be patient" policy toward Taiwan investments in mainland China, and the granting of longer periods of stay in Taiwan for mainland journalists.
Chen stressed that "commerce civilizes people," adding that he hopes normalized trade relations can be established soon so as to bring about a detente in cross-strait relations.

President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration speech laid the foundation for the new government's mainland policy, which revolves around "goodwill conciliation, proactive cooperation, and eternal peace," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREDIT CARD COUNTERFEITERS BUSTED

TEXT.P: Taipei County police arrested three suspects Saturday and discovered in their possession 599 counterfeit credit cards, various pieces of equipment used to fabricate them, and over NT$1 million worth of goods purchased with the cards.

In what is the largest credit card counterfeiting bust ever in northern Taiwan, police also found nine counterfeit identification cards, five phony fiscards (ATM cards), two fake driver's licenses, one forged national health insurance card, and 1,500 grams of amphetamines.
Police said that the main suspect, surnamed Wang, is also alleged to have been involved in the kidnapping of a businessman and an overseas Chinese from Malaysia.
Police believe that Wang may have colluded with certain businesses and installed microchips inside their credit card machines in order to record confidential information from each transaction.

After the counterfeit cards were fabricated at his apartment, his girlfriend, surnamed Chen, and another man, surnamed Chuang, would then purchase goods from stores nationwide and sell them for half the purchase price, police added.

According to the police, Wang's credit cards have already caused over NT$50 million (US$1.5 million) in losses to domestic financial institutions. They also calculated that the 599 cards have a combined credit limit as high as NT$60 million (US$1.9 million).

Records from the National Credit Card Center show that a total of NT$1.2 billion (US$37.2 million) in losses were incurred from January to June from transactions with fake credit cards alone, a figure equivalent to the total amount of such losses from the previous year, indicating a marked increase in such crimes.
A spokesman for the center said that Taiwan has become the area with the highest amount of credit card fraud in terms of both dollar figures and number of cases in the Asia Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON TO HIRE MORE SPECIALISTS TO COUNTER ESPIONAGE

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of Defense is hiring 450 new counterintelligence specialists over the next three years to protect defense secrets against what is seen as a growing threat posed by foreign spies, including those working for Communist China, reported the Washington Post on Friday.

Senior U.S. defense officials said the decision was made after learning that Communist China has obtained classified U.S. missile technology, including critical information about the heat shield that keeps America's most advanced missiles from burning up as they reenter the atmosphere, reported the daily.

According to Pentagon officials, 150 new counterintelligence specialists will be hired each year for the next three years. They will be hired from both the civilian and military sectors and will be assigned equally across defense laboratories and contractors working for the U.S. armed forces.
The Pentagon admitted the hiring surge is in recognition of what is seen as an increased overall foreign espionage threat.

A recent study by the Defense Security Service says that in 1999, the service received reports of suspicious activities concerning interests associated with 56 different countries -- an increase over the previous two years, the Voice of American radio station reported Friday.

The report does not identify any nations by name, but it states 45 percent of the suspected foreign activities involved Asian nations, adding the U.S. technologies generating the most foreign interest last year included information systems, sensors and lasers, aeronautics systems, and armaments, said the VOA.
Pentagon officials, however, recently confirmed they are cooperating with other intelligence agencies in a probe of Communist Chinese espionage aimed at collecting classified U.S. missile technology.
That investigation stems from a review of newly-translated military documents provided by a Communist Chinese defector, reported the Washington Post earlier.
The U.S. intelligence community had originally been focusing its investigation on the possible theft of nuclear secrets by Chinese spies.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIBERAL INTERNATIONAL CALLS FOR PEACE ACROSS TAIWAN STRAITS

TEXT.P: A working commission of the 50th Congress of the Liberal International being held in Canada passed a resolution Friday supporting Taiwan's democracy and calling for peace across the Taiwan Strait.

The resolution, proposed by the Dutch group of the Liberal International and containing an amendment by Foklpartiet Liberalerna of Sweden, welcomes the election of Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu as president and vice president of the Republic of China respectively, saying the election "emphasized the democratic achievements of Taiwan."

It also reaffirms the Liberals International's firm conviction that political leadership has to be democratically legitimized and be based on free and fair elections, the rule of law, and the principle that people have the inherent right to decide on their political future through their political institutions.

The resolution, expected to be adopted in the plenary session on Saturday, takes note of Chen's inaugural speech in which he stated he will not take the initiative to change the present status of Taiwan.

It also acknowledges the significant developments in different parts and sectors of society in mainland China over the last years and calls for a resumption of the cross-strait dialogue between mainland China and Taiwan to enhance cooperation between the two sides based on a respect for human rights and the democratic principles stated above.
The document rejects any suggestion that the present political status quo on Taiwan can be changed by any means other than by the consent of its inhabitants.

It urges the international community to strengthen its ties with both mainland China and Taiwan and calls upon political parties within the Liberal International to work together closely with the Democratic Progressive Party of Taiwan in defending democracy on the island and the right of its people to decide their future.

Dr. Matyas Eorsi, who chaired the commission meeting, told the CNA that he's "99.9 percent sure, perhaps plus one" that the commission's adoption of the Taiwan resolution will be accepted by the plenary meeting tomorrow.

Eorsi is the deputy leader of Hungary's Alliance of Free Democrats and the secretary-general of the ELDR Group of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. He's also a good friend of the ROC representative in Hungary, Jo-shui Leng.

Taiwan's Yao Chia-wen and Lai I-chung of the DPP are among the hundreds of delegates from 65 countries attending the three-day Liberal International meeting in Hull, Quebec. The meeting concludes on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE DAILY VICTIM OF BEIJING'S MEDIA WEB SITE CONTROLS

TEXT.P: Australia's oldest and leading newspaper has become one of the latest victims of Beijing's strict controls on foreign media Internet sites.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday reported that its Web site is unavailable through Chinese Internet service providers and that its bureau in China's capital has tried hard to find out the actual reasons why citizens of the country are being denied access to its news services.
The websites of the Australian and the Australian Financial Review -- two other major dailies from Australia -- remain available, the daily reported.
The Web sites of other major foreign media organizations, such as the New York Times, the Washington Post, CNN, and the BBC, are either routinely blocked or rarely accessible, the daily reported.

The daily quoted the People's Daily -- the Chinese Communist Party's mouthpiece -- as calling on official media to strengthen their "political thought work" in the face of a flood of information available via the Internet.
The daily also quoted the same paper as saying that "enemy forces at home and abroad are sparing no effort in using this battle front to infiltrate us."

Meanwhile, a number of domestic sites that challenged the Chinese government have been closed this year as part of Beijing's efforts to control Chinese citizens' access to certain kinds of information, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA FACING SERIOUS SOCIAL PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Mainland China is facing serious problems involving the spread of bigamy, domestic violence, drug addiction, and gambling, and authorities in Beijing are finding it difficult to solve them, reported the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily reported that members of mainland China's parliament are locked in discussions over the countries apparent moral decay regarding sex, marriage, and other social issues.

The daily reported domestic violence alone affects about 100 million people throughout China, and a series of surveys show that one in three abused wives were beaten by their husbands at least four times a month.

With affluence has come philandering. Infidelity, concubinage, bigamy, and extra-marital affairs have all been identified as growing problems as mainland China emerges from the moral strictures imposed in the 1950s and 1960s, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: 51% SUPPORT 'NO CONFIDENCE' VOTE AGAINST CABINET: KMT POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of respondents to a public opinion poll support an opposition call for a vote of no-confidence against the Cabinet in the wake of its decision to halt construction of the fourth nuclear power plant, the Kuomintang said Saturday.

Quoting the results of a telephone poll of 1,066 randomly selected adult residents, the main opposition party said 51.13 percent of those interviewed have thrown explicit support for a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet.

Survey results also show that 33.87 percent of the respondents gave a thumbs-down to the no-confidence vote proposal, and 15.01 percent either said they have no opinion or don't know whether such a move is needed.

The KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20 and still controls a majority in the 221-member Legislative Yuan, was angered by the Cabinet's abrupt announcement of its "scrapping the fourth nuclear power plant" decision shortly after a high-profile meeting between KMT Chairman Lien Chan and President Chen Shui-bian Friday. The party then conducted the survey in the evening to explore the general public opinion about the Cabinet's anti-nuclear decision.
Another opposition party -- the People First Party (PFP) -- has been seeking the KMT's support for launching a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet over the nuclear power plant issue.

Wang Tan-ping, an executive secretary of the KMT's Central Policy Coordination Department, said Saturday that the KMT has not called for a no-confidence vote mainly because of three major reasons -- the Cabinet is fully dominated by President Chen who is the "culprit" of the current domestic political disorder, not the Cabinet itself; since Chen has shown no respect for the country's constitutional system, a parliamentary re-election following the no-confidence vote against the Cabinet is not expected to effectively improve relations among the Presidential Office, the Cabinet and the Legislature; the KMT does not want to see further political instability.

Nevertheless, Wang said the results of the latest opinion poll have prompted the KMT to have a second thought of its previous reluctance to call a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet. "We now do not rule out that possibility," he said.

But Wang stressed that the KMT will make a further evaluation before deciding on whether to support a PFP-initiated no-confidence vote against the Cabinet as opinion polls conducted by two mass circulation local newspapers have shown different trends concerning the public opinions about the "toppling the Cabinet" issue.

A China Times poll conducted Friday found that only 25 percent of the respondents said they support a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet simply for the nuclear power plant scrapping, while 44 percent said they oppose the proposal and 30 percent didn't express their opinion.
According to a similar United Daily News survey, the ratios of proponents and opponents to the no-confidence vote proposal were 32 percent to 43 percent, and 24 percent said they have no opinion.

Lin Chih-chia, a KMT legislator from the Taipei County constituency, the site for the fourth nuclear power plant, said most of the 115 KMT legislators do not support a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet for the moment because a re-election would weaken the party's dominance in the legislature and add to the country's political uncertainty.

Many observers have said no party would be able to control majority seats in the legislature if a parliamentary election is held at the moment. President Chen's Democratic Progressive Party now controls only 68 seats in the legislature.

Meanwhile, the KMT's Friday poll also found that 54.41 percent of those interviewed agreed with the saying "the Cabinet's announcement of a halt to the nuclear power plant immediately after a long-awaited meeting between Lien and President Chen indicates that the president has played jokes on the KMT's sincerity to promote inter-party rapprochement"; 28.89 percent disagreed with the accusation; and 16.7 percent said they don't know.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL SCI-TECH CONSULTING COMMITTEE TO BE SET UP NOV. 1

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Saturday presided over a preparatory meeting of the Presidential Science and Technology Consulting Committee in her capacity as the chairwoman.
A ceremony will be held on Nov. 1 at the Taipei International Conference Center to formally inaugurate the committee.
Addressing the preparatory meeting, Lu said that faced with a brand new century, Taiwan should attach great importance to science and technology development.
She said that President Chen Shui-bian in August approved the establishment of the committee and assigned her to be the head of the committee.
She stressed that the functions of the consulting committee will not conflict with those of the Cabinet's Science and Technology Advisory Group.

Lu indicated that the purpose of the Presidential Science and Technology Consulting Committee is to increase the nation's competitiveness, strengthen national security, promote the nation's long-term development, as well as advise the president on related issues.

After much discussion, the preparatory meeting picked 59 committee members from 523 names in the field of science and technology recommended by all walks of life, said Lu, adding that she believes those chosen will surely make an important contribution to aiding the president with their professional knowledge.
The committee will be organized into 12 divisions, with a convenor to chair each respective division.

Meanwhile, Lu, speaking on the issue of the fourth nuclear power plant, said that she had not attended the decision-making meeting that led to the announcement by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung that the project would be scrapped.
She expressed her regret over the political turmoil caused by the scrapping of the nuclear power plant project, adding however that the issue has become over politicized.
Lu urged the public to calm down and view the issue with a rational attitude so that the political turmoil the controversy has caused can be solved in a beneficial manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 29, or the third day of the tenth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1618: Sir Walter Raleigh, English courtier, navigator, colonizer, and writer, is beheaded in the Tower of London for treason against King James I at the age of 54. His literary works include poetry, memoirs, and a world history.
1863: Henri Dunant, Swiss philanthropist, founds the International Red Cross. He was a joint recipient of the 1901 Nobel Peace Prize.
1881: The first national political party is founded in Japan.
1897: Joseph Goebbels, German Nazi propaganda chief who poisoned himself when the Allies entered Berlin, is born.
1911: Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-born American journalist and newspaper publisher, dies at the age of 64. He owned papers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes.
1923: The Republic of Turkey is proclaimed, with nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk as its first president.
1927: Russian archaeologist Peter Kozlov discovers the tomb of Genghis Khan in the Gobi Desert.
1929: "Black Tuesday" follows "Black Thursday" on Wall Street as the crisis of confidence hits the New York stock market, leading to the Great Depression of the 1930s.
1932: The Normandie, one of the three most luxurious ships ever built, is launched in France. The 300 meter-long vessel crossed the Atlantic Ocean in just over four days. A fire destroyed the ship while berthed in New York Harbor in 1942.
1942: Nazis massacre 16,000 Jews in Pinsk, Russia.
1944: In his capacity as supreme commander of the China Theater of War, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appoints U.S. General Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China Theater of War. Meanwhile, U.S. General Daniel L. Sultan is appointed commander-in-chief of the U.S. Expeditionary Forces in India.
1945: Anna Rosenberg is given the first U.S. Medal of Freedom ever awarded to a woman.
1953: The North American F-100 Super Sabre jet fighter sets a record at 1,215 km/h, becoming the first jet able to be operated at supersonic speeds.
1962: The ROC Foreign Ministry issues a statement refusing to recognize India's position of using the "McMahon Line" as the border line between India and China.
1964: Tanganyika unites with Zanzibar, becoming Tanzania.
1974: A five-member Korean parliamentary mission headed by the chairman of the Korean Democratic Republican Party, Rhee Hyo Sang, and 130 members of the Japanese Diet, arrive in Taipei to take part in celebrations marking President Chiang-kai-shek's 87th birthday.
1975: Helmut Schmidt arrives in Beijing, becoming the first West German chancellor to tour the Chinese mainland.
1977: Taiwan's first IC (integrated circuit) plant, under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, is inaugurated at Chutung in Hsinchu County.
1980: A declaration by Teng Hsiao-ping (Deng Xiaoping,) vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, that Mao Tse-tung made serious political mistakes during his rule, is made public.
1981: The Chinese National Federation of Industries and the Chamber of Industry of Guatemala sign a cooperation agreement to promote economic, trade, and cultural relations.
1984: The Chinese team from Taiwan wins second place in the World Amateur Baseball Championship in Cuba.
1985: The first prototype of "Ching Kuo," the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, bursts its nose-wheel during a test flight at the Chingchuenkang Air Force base in Taichung.
1986: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that ROC-U.S. trade talks on wine and tobacco imports are stalemated. Washington charged that Taipei failed to keep promises of providing greater market access for U.S. beer, wine, and tobacco, and said the United States would draft retaliatory measures against the ROC under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974.
1998: John Glenn, U.S. astronaut, blasts off aboard the space shuttle Discovery at the age of 77, 36 years after his first extra-terrestrial mission.
1999: Carleton S. Fiorina, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard Co., the world's No. 2 computer maker, arrives in Taipei for a two-day whirlwind visit.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "When a ruler regards his ministers as his hands and feet, they regard him as their belly and heart; when he regards them as dogs and horses, they regard him as a common citizen; when he regards them as dirt and grass, they regard him as a robber and enemy."
