DOC.HEADLINE: QUESTION MARK HANGS OVER TAIPEI'S ENVOY TO APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: With two weeks to go before the summit of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, uncertainty looms larger over who will represent Taiwan at the meeting of one of the few international organizations to which the island is still a member.
President Chen Shui-bian took the Kuomintang to task on Saturday after its leaders reneged on their promises to allow its vice chairman Vincent Siew to attend the APEC summit on behalf of Chen.

The president, who defeated Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his running mate Siew in March's presidential election, blamed the opposition for not being able to come to terms with their failure. He added that he himself has already shrugged off the bitter rivalry between the two parties during the presidential campaign and has offered Siew the chance to reenter the political limelight.

Chen consulted Siew last week on the possibility of taking part in the APEC gathering as his personal envoy after the summit host Brunei expressed reservations about Taiwan's initial choice of Republic of China Vice Premier Lai Ying-chao. Brunei's reservations stemmed from pressure from Beijing to limit Taipei's envoy to the APEC summit of heads of state to a government minister.

Siew, who attended the APEC summits in 1993 and 1994 while serving as the chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development under President Lee Teng-hui, had agreed to accept Chen's offer, subject to the approval of his party.

Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan had initially given the nod to the arrangement, but this was before Friday's sudden announcement by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung that construction on Taiwan's controversial fourth nuclear power plant would be halted. The announcement came almost immediately after the live broadcast meeting between Chen and Lien to hear the latter's opinions on national issues, including his strong support for completion of the nuclear plant project.
Lien criticized Chen for damaging trust between the two parties by pretending to listen to the opposition only to flagrantly spurn their recommendations.
He announced a delay in the party's approval of Siew's assignment to the APEC summit, a move which invoked Chen's criticism of the KMT for its flip-flop.
Jason Hu, the Kuomintang spokesman, said Saturday that Chen's criticism of the Kuomintang can only have a negative affect on the possibility of the party approving Siew's assignment.
Caught in the fire between the Kuomintang and Chen, Siew stuck to his initial stance by saying Sunday that the Kuomintang has the final say on whether he should serve as Chen's envoy.
Attending a funeral in Kaohsiung, Siew told reporters that the tensions between the Kuomintang and President Chen have complicated the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP POLL FINDS 33% SUPPORT DECISION TO HALT NUCLEAR POWER PLANT

TEXT.P: Only 33.2 percent of the Taiwan public supports the Cabinet's decision to halt construction on the island's fourth nuclear power plant, while 47.5 percent are against the decision, a poll unveiled Sunday by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party shows.

The DPP conducted the survey on the controversial project and the political storm unleashed after Premier Chang Chun-hsiung abruptly announced the decision to halt its construction Friday shortly after a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and Chairman Lien Chan of the opposition Kuomintang during which the president said he would give more thought to the project.
The poll was conducted between Oct. 27 and 28, with 1,189 effective samples collected. The margin of error of the poll is 2.8 percent.

Although the number of those who support the Cabinet's decision is greater than the number of those who are against it, DPP official Chen Chun-lin stressed that the gap has narrowed since a similar survey was conducted Oct. 2-3. At that time, 54 percent said they were opposed to the halting of construction on the nuclear power plant, while 27. 9 percent said that they were in favor of scrapping the project.

One noteworthy phenomenon that the poll found was that only 62.2 percent of respondents who are leaning toward the DPP said they support the Cabinet's decision, while 23.4 percent said they are against it.

Some 48.8 percent of those polled also said they had no confidence in state-owned Taiwan Power Co.'s ability to handle a nuclear emergency, and 50 percent said they had no confidence in Taipower's ability to safely dispose of nuclear waste.

On the question of the nuclear power plant's location, 55.1 percent of those surveyed said they would be opposed to the site being located in their city or county. Also, 77.1 percent of the respondents agreed that the construction of a nuclear plant must have the consent of the local people.

DPP Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen said the poll figures reflected the Taiwan public's conflicting attitude, pointing specifically to the fact that 47.5 percent of respondents said they are opposed to scrapping the nuclear plant project, while nearly half said they have no confidence in Taipower's ability to handle nuclear emergencies or safely dispose of nuclear waste, and over 77 percent said that construction of the nuclear power plant must have the consent of the local people.

Asked if they would be opposed to continued construction if energy alternatives were indeed feasible and there were no fears of future power shortages, some 58.4 percent said they would, while 29.9 said they would not.

Some 56.1 percent of those surveyed also said that they are opposed to the threats by opposition parties that they will boycott the review of the general budget submitted by the Cabinet because of the Cabinet's decision on the power plant.

Some 51.1 percent of the respondents also said that since the Cabinet has made its decision, the other political parties should cast away their differences so as not to affect political and economic stability, while 37.7 percent said they are opposed to the idea.
Wu said that this showed that over half of the people would not like to see the political situation continue in a chaotic state.
He suggested to the opposition parties that the time is not right for a political struggle, saying that this will not be beneficial to Taiwan's long-term development.

On the question of whether the nuclear power plant controversy will trigger moves to topple the Cabinet or recall the president, Wu said that as the public poll shows that even the opposition's more moderate option of boycotting the Cabinet's general budget doesn't have the support of half the people, the more drastic mentioned alternatives would not come about.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION DIVIDED ON HOW TO BLOCK GOVERNMENT'S ANTI-NUCLEAR POLICY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's three opposition parties, the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP), and the New Party, are united against the government's decision to scrap the fourth nuclear power plant, but they are divided on how to go about trying to block it.

Shocked by the government's abrupt announcement Friday that it will halt construction on the island's fourth nuclear plant, PFP Chairman James Soong said Sunday that he is willing to call on the KMT and the New Party to explore the possibility of working on a joint front to stop the government from scrapping the project, which is already one third complete.

Soong said that although the administration of President Chen should bear much of the responsibility for the current political upheaval, those who revised the Republic of China Constitution to make possible a divided government under which the executive branch and the legislature are controlled by different parties should also be blamed.

He pointed out that the root of the current crisis is the administration of the minority party Democratic Progressive Party's insistence on following its own path without respect for the opinions of the majority opposition KMT, which he added is too afraid to oust the Cabinet and thereby risk losing its majority status in the Legislative Yuan.

Claiming that the administration has destroyed the minimum trust needed to maintain its rules, Soong said the only way to sort out the crisis is for the Legislative Yuan to topple the Cabinet with a vote of no-confidence.
However, he said he is keeping his mind open to the KMT's suggested option of introducing a recall of President Chen at the legislature.

With 141 seats between them in the 220-seated Legislative Yuan, the three parties could together push through a motion of recall, but there is a technical problem -- they would first have to work out the law regulating the implementation of the recall of the president, and this could be a time-consuming process.
The KMT leader, Lien Chan, made a similar call for unity among the opposition parties in Kaohsiung Sunday.
Without mentioning the PFP by name, Lien urged all opposition parties to work out a consensus on how to protect the welfare of the people.

The New Party, which controls nine seats in the legislature, said that it would join forces with the other two opposition parties to boycott the government's decision, but the party has not mentioned which option it prefers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARGENTINE PARLIAMENTARIANS TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A group of nine Argentine parliamentarians will make a weeklong visit to the Republic of China from Oct. 30 to Nov. 5 at the invitation of the ROC government.

During their stay in Taipei, the Argentine parliamentarians will call on the Legislative Yuan and also officials at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Economic Affairs Ministry, as well as visit economic and cultural establishments in Taiwan.
A spokesman for the Argentine parliamentary mission said that they will also exchange views with Taiwan's officials on how to promote economic and trade relations between Taiwan and Argentina.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES BEGINS TAIPEI-PENANG-MEDAN ROUTE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines on Sunday inaugurated a new flight route between Taipei, Penang in Malaysia, and Medan in Indonesia, the fourth new route that CAL has opened this year.
CAL resumed its direct flight services to Manila on Oct. 8 and earlier this year began chartered flights to India and Japan's Hokodate.

Tzung Tsai-yi, director general of CAL, said at the inauguration ceremony that the airline has performed exceptionally well in recent years thanks to the efforts of the company's more than 9,000 employees.
He said he feels glad that CAL can spread Taiwan's culture, materials, and information abroad and bring foreign culture and resources back to Taiwan through the expansion of its air routes.
Malaysia's representative to the Republic of China Abdul Rahim Bakri and Indonesia's representative Iskandar Sabirin also attended the inauguration ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CALLS ON PRESIDENT CHEN TO ABANDON HIS IMPERIAL ATTITUDE

TEXT.P: A senior official of the opposition Kuomintang Sunday called on President Chen Shui-bian to abandon his imperial attitude.
KMT Spokesman Jason Hu also called on President Chen to give up carrying out arbitrary actions, adding that the president cannot force his political rivals to accept his arbitrary decisions.

He pointed out that President Chen has commented that his political rivals cannot stand to be losers. Hu went on to say that if a winner is not sincere and has no credibility, how can a loser willingly accept such arbitrary decisions.
"Should a loser completely subject himself to the winner. Such a scenario is not a real democracy, it is an imperial system," Hu said.
Hu made these remarks in response to a speech by President Chen given at a gathering in Tainan Saturday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION URGED TO FIRST CAREFULLY CONSIDER ANY ACTIONS AGAINST GOV'T

TEXT.P: A presidential aide Sunday called on the opposition parties to first carefully consider whether Taiwan can afford to accept the serious consequences before taking any action against the Chen administration in the wake of the decision to halt construction on the fourth nuclear power plant.

Kuo Yao-chi, director of the Presidential Public Affairs Office, called on the opposition to deal with the situation in a rational manner and not take any drastic measures without first carefully considering the ramifications on the country.
The opposition parties have said that they are considering either taking a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet at the Legislative Yuan or utilizing the right to recall the president.

Kuo went on to say that every political party has to consider its own interests and that the Presidential Office will deal with the issue with a serious attitude if any anti-government action is pursued by the opposition.
She stressed that the opposition should consider whether its actions will run counter to the public's desire for political stability.

President Chen Shui-bian will meet with the heads of the Executive Yuan, the Legislative Yuan, the Examination Yuan, and the Control Yuan on Monday to try to settle the dispute caused by the Cabinet's decision to scrap the fourth nuclear power plant project.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S UMC LISTED SECOND LARGEST CHINESE ENTERPRISE IN WORLD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's major IC maker, United Microelectronics Corp., was listed as the second largest among the top 500 Chinese enterprises in the world in a survey conducted by the Hong Kong-based Yazhou Zhoukan (Asian Weekly).
It was the first time that UMC edged out Cathay Life Insurance Co. Ltd to become Taiwan's largest company.
The number of Taiwan enterprises listed in the recent survey climbed to 237, with one third of them being electronic and computer companies.

The survey results show that the new economy based on information technology is redrawing the world's Chinese enterprises' wealth map. Six of this year's top ten Chinese enterprises belong to the new economy.

The results of the survey also reflect the fact that, in Hong Kong, the traditionally strong enterprises of real estate and finance are giving way to information technology companies, which have been making great strides up the list.
A Hong Kong economist suggested that Hong Kong enterprises take up Taiwan's development model by making good use of scientific technology in order to elevate their competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 30, or the fourth day of the tenth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1735: John Adams, the second president of the United States, is born. He was one of the signatories to the Declaration of Independence, and he negotiated the end to the War of American Independence.
1910: Swiss philanthropist Henri Dunant dies at the age of 82. He founded the International Red Cross and shared the first Nobel Peace Prize with Frederic Passy of France in 1901.
1911: On the advice of the regent Prince Chun, Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, grants a constitution to combat growing support for the revolutionary forces of Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party launches armed rebellions at Haifeng and Lufeng in Kwangtung Province.
1937: The National government decides to move the capital from Nanking to Chungking.
1952: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations is set up in Taipei following the first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference which opened in Taipei on Oct. 22.
1953: Wu Ching-heng, former chairman of the Presidium of the Constituent Assembly, dies in Taipei at the age of 88.
1962: The ROC government rejects the McMahon Line as the boundary between China and India.
1973: Tsengwen Dam and Reservoir, the largest in Taiwan, is completed and dedicated as a birthday present to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: Economic Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for Saigon to take part in the eighth Sino-Vietnamese Ministerial Conference on economic cooperation.
1974: Nobusuke Kishi, former Japanese prime minister, and Mitsujiro Ishii, former speaker of the House of Representatives, arrive in Taipei to join in birthday celebrations for President Chiang.
1974: The first F5E Freedom jetfighter made in the Republic of China rolls off the assembly line.
1975: Ground for the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, named after the late president, is broken by Adm. Ni Yue-si, president of the ROC Amateur Athletic Federation, and Wang Yung-ching, the donor.
1975: Li Teng-hui, the ROC minister of state, leaves for Nakualofa at the head of an envoy to attend the 100th anniversary of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives U.S. Rep. John B. Conlan (R-Ariz.) as well as French parliamentarians headed by Rene Radius.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the establishment of National Chiang Kai-shek University in central Taiwan.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the code on gold trading and importation, to be effective Nov. 1.
1986: The ROC-made "Sky Bow" and "Sky Sword" missiles are officially renamed the "Chung Cheng (Chiang Kai-shek) 100" series in a renaming ceremony presided over by Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
1988: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, presides over one of the biggest mass wedding ceremonies in history, held in Yongin, South Korea where 6,516 couples tie the knot.
1990: Communist China announces the results of a nationwide census which shows its population totals 1.13 billion people.
1990: The Republic of China establishes trade and consular ties with Bolivia.
1995: Voters in the province of Quebec vote in favor of remaining part of Canada in a referendum.
1995 Fire breaks out on a subway train below the streets of Baku, capital of the Republic of Azerbaijan, killing 337 people and injuring at least 270 others.
1997: Mary McAleese, a Belfast lawyer, is elected President of Ireland.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the Republic of China has never forsaken its goal of promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "There never was a man trained to benevolence who neglected his parents. There never was a man trained to righteousness who made his ruler an after-consideration."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 146.09 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 146.09 points to close at 5,659.08.
Market turnover amounted to 12.93 billion (US$0.4 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 146.09 points to close at 5,659.08.

Affected by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's decision Friday to halt construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear plant, the bourse opened at 5,644.26 and continued to go down before purchases made by government funds. The bourse fluctuated between 5,666.96 and 5,615.9 during trading.

A total of 0.56 billion stocks worth NT$12.93 billion (US$0.4 billion) changed hands, a record low since Sept. 27 1999 and a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.05 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$79.37 billion (US$2.48 billion).
Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 2.5 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 3.2 percent, followed by textile issues at 3.1 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.5 percent, construction stocks at 2.3 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 544 to 30, with 18 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November moved down 100 points to close at 5,600, with 6,715 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for December lost 197 points to finish at 5,542, with 51 contract transactions, while June 2001 futures plunged 207 points to close at 5,724, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,700 for November, 5,739 for December, 5,779 for next March, 5,931 for next June, and 6,019 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
November TE futures moved down 10.05 points to close at 277.95, with 314 contract transactions, while December TF futures lost 10.2 points to finish at 281.8, with 12 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were reported for other months.
November TF futures decreased 25.6 points to close at 707.8, with 291 contract transactions, while December TF futures fell 25.6 points to finish at 708.4 with 10 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CERTAIN CANCER DRUGS CAN REDUCE ARTHRITIS: REPORT

TEXT.P: British scientists have discovered that some cancer drugs could help substantially reduce rheumatoid arthritis, according to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday.

The daily reported that a research team at the University College London used a combination of chemotherapy drugs and a common corticosteroid to destroy a type of white blood cell in 20 severely affected patients.
Team leader Professor Jonathan Edwards said all but two of the patients improved substantially, with the disease going into remission in many of the treated patients.
The breakthrough focuses on the role of B-cells -- white blood cells that defend the body against viruses and bacteria by making antibodies, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OPTING FOR RECALL OF PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang has decided to move to recall President Chen Shui-bian rather than to call for a no-confidence vote against Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, said a KMT heavyweight Monday.

Hung Yu-chin, executive director of the KMT's Coordination Committee, said the KMT, in cooperation with the KMT legislative caucus and sub-groups, will push for President Chen Shui-bian's recall in retaliation to Chen's apparent disrespect for the majority in the Legislative Yuan as evidenced by last Friday's sudden announcement by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung that construction of Taiwan's controversial fourth nuclear power plant will be halted.

After Premier Chang's announcement, the KMT, which holds a majority in the Legislative Yuan, made calls for the Control Yuan to impeach the premier while launching a vitriolic attack on President Chen and his Democratic Progressive Party-led administration.
Terming it "against the public interest," the KMT declared that the DPP-led government's action of simply stopping the carrying out of a budget that had been passed by the legislature illegal.

The KMT said what was particularly infuriating about the decision to scrap the nuclear power plant project was the "poor timing." The premier's announcement came almost immediately after Chen's ostensible fence-mending meeting with KMT Chairman Lien Chan that same morning.

Ting Shou-chung, deputy executive director of the KMT's Coordination Committee, said the party has chosen to move to recall the president rather than to push to have Premier Chang step down because they feel Chang is only a puppet of the president and Chen will only replace him with a similar figure if lawmakers force him out with a vote a no-confidence.
Ting noted that recalling the president is not as difficult as one would imagine, saying that it is feasible as long as all the opposition parties are united at heart in common purpose.

He added that all that is required is a minimum of 57 legislators to propose a motion to recall the president, 150 legislators to endorse the motion, and half the ROC citizens participating in a vote, or 3.51 million of 7 million people, to support his recall.

Ting said Chen's personality and his method of doing things are the root of the present political chaos in Taiwan. Dealing with the problem at its root by recalling the president is the only way to end the chaos, he stressed.

Meanwhile, the KMT legislative caucus announced that beginning Tuesday, the doors to the Legislative Yuan will be closed to Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, all the negotiating channels between the administration and the legislature will be shut down simultaneously, and the screening of the general budget for next fiscal year will also be halted.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN WILL RESPECT LEGISLATURE'S DECISION: PRES'L OFFICE

TEXT.P: If the Legislative Yuan passes a resolution to overturn the decision made by the Executive Yuan to halt construction on the fourth nuclear power plant, the Executive Yuan will respect and accept it, an official of the Presidential Office said Monday.

Chen Che-nan, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said in a press conference held at the Presidential Office that the Executive Yuan will respect the resolution if passed by the Legislative Yuan according to lawful procedures.

Chen's remarks came amidst a political storm unleashed by the Cabinet's abrupt announcement last Friday to scrap the nuclear plant project shortly after President Chen's meeting with Lien Chan, chairman of the largest opposition party Kuomintang, during which Chen promised to give more thought to the nuclear project.

To try to defuse the political storm, President Chen will convene an informal meeting with the presidents of the five Yuans, including Chang Chun-hsiung of the Executive Yuan, Wang Jin-pyng of the Legislative Yuan, Weng Yueh-sheng of the Judicial Yuan, Fredrick Chien of the Control Yuan, and Hsu Shui-teh of the Examination Yuan. Also attending the meeting will be Vice President Annette Lu and Secretary-General to the President Yu Shyi-kun.

Chen said that faced with the large dispute between the executive and legislative branches of government, President Chen hopes the meeting Monday night will help in calming things down and returning things to the rule of law.
If the Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the budgetary law and the energy law, then the Executive Yuan and the president will respect and accept the decision, Chen said.
The budget for the fourth nuclear power plant had cleared the Legislative Yuan during the rule of the previous KMT-led government.

On the question of the Cabinet accepting the resolution made by the Legislative Yuan that runs counter to the anti-nuclear platform of the DPP, Chen said that this is out of the question, noting that the president is the president of all the people and not just of the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIR MEETING WITH OTHER OPPOSITION PARTY HEADS FOR COLLABORATION

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang called emergency meetings between party chairman Lien Chan and the heads of the other opposition parties Monday in an attempt to cement their unity in a fight against President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

KMT spokesman Jason Hu said Chairman Lien Chen called on People First Party Chairman James Soong, whom the KMT expelled early this year for defying party rules and running in the presidential election without party approval, at around 3 p.m. for an emergency meeting in the wake of the surprise move by the Cabinet last Friday to pull the plug on the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project.
Later in the afternoon, at around 4:30, Lien will meet with Hao Lung-ping, convenor of the New Party's National Election and Development Council, for a similar meeting, according to Hu.

Meanwhile, Hu said, Lien is still undecided on whether he will leave for the United States Wednesday as previously scheduled. Lien, the only overseas board member of the University of Chicago, had promised to attend the prestigious university's board meeting later this week. Lien was also scheduled to visit New York to meet his overseas Chinese supporters there.

Hu, who declined to speculate on whether Lien will cancel the planned trip at this critical juncture in Taiwan's politics, said only that the party chairman will make a "proper and responsible" decision soon, placing the need to maintain political stability at the top of the list in his decision-making.
In related news, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is a KMT cadre, said he will decide later Monday on whether to attend a meeting called by President Chen Shui-bian for Monday evening.

The president is calling an emergency meeting with the heads and executives of the five branches of the central government -- the Legislative Yuan, the Judicial Yuan, the Examination Yuan, the Control Yuan, and the Executive Yuan -- to look for a solution to the ongoing political chaos and constitutional crisis that was heightened by last Friday's announcement to scrap the nuclear power plant project.
Wang said he will finalize his decision on whether to attend the president's meeting soon after exchanging views with leaders of the ruling and opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DECLARES POLIO-FREE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has completely eradicated the virus that causes polio, once one of the most feared diseases, the Department of Health (DOH) announced Monday.
DOH Minister Lee Ming-liang made the announcement in protest of the World Health Organization's deliberate ignorance of the ROC's public health achievement.

WHO declared 37 countries and areas in the western Pacific region polio-free Sunday, claiming a victory against the highly infectious disease. Dr. Shigeru Omi, WHO western Pacific regional director, said at a meeting held in Kyoto, western Japan that the West Pacific has become the second region to be certified polio-free after the Americas in 1994.
The WHO list of polio-free West Pacific countries and areas included mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau, but deliberately omitted Taiwan as WHO regarded Taiwan as part of mainland China.
The ROC was a founding member of WHO, but lost its membership in the organization after it was expelled from the United Nations in 1971. WHO is a U.N. affiliate.
Lee said it is regrettable that WHO has ignored the ROC's achievement in eradicating the polio virus simply because of political reasons.

Noting that no case of polio has been confirmed in Taiwan since 1989, Lee said the ROC has successfully eradicated the debilitating childhood disease through a massive immunization campaign starting in 1964. A polio outbreak, however, hit Taiwan in 1982, with 1,000-plus cases being confirmed. The ROC then revised its immunization program by using a new five-dose vaccine, and no polio case has since been reported.

Lee said as the current polio vaccine is highly effective and safe, the existing immunization policy will not change. Nevertheless, Lee said the DOH will continue its close monitoring to prevent inflow of foreign polio cases.

Over the past few years, Lee said, the ROC has donated more than US$2 million to help eradicate the polio virus in other parts of the world. "We feel deep regrets over WHO's failure to recognize our efforts simply because of Beijing's pressure," Lee said, adding that the ROC will lodge protests with WHO over its failure to include Taiwan in its latest list of polio-free countries and areas.
Meanwhile, Lee said the DOH's next work goal is to eradicate measles and German measles so that Taiwan can join the ranks of advanced public health countries.

Polio is highly contagious virus transmitted by direct person-to-person contact, contact with infected secretions from the nose or mouth, or contact with infected fecal matter. Polio can strike at any age. However, children under the age of three are the majority of its victims. Once contracted, its effects are almost always irreversible.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTIES DECLARE PREMIER `PERSONA NON GRATA'

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition parties on Monday declared Premier Chang Chun-hsiung "persona non grata" for his announcement of a major policy turnabout that was not only "illegal" but also "sacrificed the public interest."

The opposition camp, including Kuomintang, People First Party, New Party and the Non-partisan Lawmakers Alliance, made the declaration Monday afternoon after a meeting called in the wake of Chang's surprise announcement last Friday to pull the plug on the fourth nuclear power plant project.

Opposition New Party Legislative Yuan party whip Lai Shyh-bao said Chang is now not welcome or accepted by the New Party, stating that the premier, "the puppet of President Chen Shui-bian," also does not need to go to the Legislative Yuan for an interpellation session by lawmakers Tuesday as scheduled.

Lai called for Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a Kuomintang cadre, not to attend the meeting called by President Chen for Monday evening that is apparently aimed at seeking a solution to the political crisis that was heightened by the announcement to scrap the nuclear power plant project.
Lai also noted that the New Party legislative caucus is fully supportive of a no-confidence vote against Premier Chang or a move to recall President Chen.

The New Party will also throw its support behind moves to introduce other statute amendments, including an amendment to the National Budget Law, and moves to suspend screening of the general budget for next fiscal year in an effort to seek justice for the legislature and the people, Lai added.

Meanwhile, New Party legislators said they will collaborate with KMT lawmakers to request a constitutional interpretation by the ROC Council of Grand Justice of the legal basis for Premier Chang's announcement of the scrapping of the controversial nuclear power plant project.

The opposition lawmakers will request that the grand justices determine whether the Executive Yuan had the right to unanimously announce that it will not carry out a budget that had been passed by the legislature, said New Party Legislator Feng Ting-kuo.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN DEFENSE MINISTER VISITS CENTRAL NEWS AGENCY

TEXT.P: Macedonian Defense Minister Ljuben Paunoski said Monday during a visit to the Republic of China's Central News Agency (CNA) that the establishment of diplomatic relations between the two nations is mutually beneficial.

Paunoski, who was a journalist for 15 years before taking up a position in the Macedonian government as cultural minister, was warmly received by CNA President Bill Wang, who praised Paunoski for his contributions to the promotion of peace and security in the Balkans and in Eastern Europe.

CNA, a wire service with over 400 employees and correspondents stationed in some 30 major cities around the world, signed an agreement with the Macedonian Information Agency earlier this month to exchange news and other services.

Paunoski, who worked to strengthen his nation's cooperative ties with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization upon taking office, said that the most important goals for Macedonia at the moment are rebuilding, educational development and the establishment of a strong national defense.
He signed a military cooperation memorandum with ROC Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen later in the day, the ROC's first agreement of its kind with a European nation in recent years.
Paunoski, who arrived in Taipei Sunday, is scheduled to call on various government officials and visit several military installations during his week-long stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO UNVEIL REVISED MAINLAND INVESTMENT POLICY IN 2 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Monday the Ministry of Economic Affairs will unveil a revised package of regulations governing investment in mainland China.

In addition, Lin said, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will also finalize a blueprint before the end of this year concerning the opening of direct "three links" (trade, mail and transport) across the Taiwan Strait.
Lin made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan committee meeting.

Opposition New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao said the Cabinet's abrupt decision to halt construction of the fourth nuclear power plant has added up to domestic political and economic uncertainty and triggered a further stock market slump. At this time of crisis, Lai said the MOEA should immediately ease restrictions on mainland China-bound investment and announce a timetable for opening direct "three links" to help restore local enterprises' confidence in the government.

In response, Lin said, the MOEA has formed a joint task force with the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Finance and the Central Bank of China to review the previous Kuomintang government's "no haste, be patient" policy on mainland investment.

"The task force is expected to come up with a revised policy proposal in two months," Lin said, adding that the new package will offer local companies greater freedom in deciding whether to invest on the mainland.
Meanwhile, Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said the inter-ministerial task force will meet Tuesday to review the "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy.

Chen said the MOEA basically has completed a policy review. "We want to listen to the evaluation results concluded by other ministries at Tuesday's meeting," he noted, adding that the MOEA will refer to their opinions in deciding which industries will be allowed to invest on the mainland.

The government currently still bans companies in some industries, including upperstream petrochemical industry and high-tech wafer industry, to invest on the mainland. However, some companies in those fields have reportedly launched investment projects on the mainland.

Chen said the MOEA is considering allowing some high-tech companies to invest on the mainland on a case-by-case basis if they meet some conditions. "For instance, if those companies are satellite plants of multinational firms, they may be allowed to invest on the mainland on a case-by-case basis," he explained.

Chen further said the MOEA is evaluating cross-strait capital movement resulting from mainland China-bound investments by local companies publicly listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange and over-the-counter market.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL SIGNS MEMORANDUM ON TECHNICAL COOPERATION WITH IDB

TEXT.P: Intel, the world's largest maker of silicon wafers, entered into a technical cooperation agreement with Taiwan's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) Monday to help the local information industry upgrade its technology.
The signing marked the first time Intel has signed a technical cooperation memorandum with a government agency in Taiwan.
IDB Director Shih Yen-hsiang and Huang Yi-sung, Intel's sales supervisor for the Asia Pacific region, inked the memorandum, effective immediately, on behalf of their respective parties.

Under the memorandum, the IDB will conduct technology exchanges with Intel to jointly promote integrated development of the information technology industry and wireless telecommunications industry in Taiwan.

In addition to the technical cooperation, the two sides also agreed to hold an Intel Wireless Client Forum every year, together with a related exhibition circuit so as to upgrade local industry and Internet competitiveness.

Shih said that through technical cooperation pacts with major world information technology makers and academic institutes, the production capacity of the local information apparatus (IA) industry will reach 50 million units by 2005 and be valued at US$6 billion, representing 30 percent or 40 percent of the global IA market.

Shih forecast that the IA industry will become a focus industry in the next century and noted that four local makers entered into an IA research and development project last year. In addition, more than 200 local makers have formed a Federation of IA, indicating that the development of IA products will be a mainstream industry for years to come.

Shih went on to say that local IA makers produced a total of 3,400,000 units last year with a total value of US$800 million. IA production capacity is expected to hit seven million units with a worth of US$1.4 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-ROC PRESIDENT CALLS FOR NEW THINKING TO RESOLVE CONFLICTS
DOC.DATELINE: Matsumoto, Japan, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui Monday urged the world to use new thinking and new attitude to cope with new challenges of the new century.
Lee made the appeal in a 15-minute taped speech broadcast at the opening of the 12th conference of the Asian Outlook Forum held in the central Japanese city of Matsumoto.
Noting that reckless use of force cannot resolve conflicts and disputes, Lee said war would only bring hatred, regret and incurable scars.
"With the 21st century just around the corner, we should learn lessons from history and use new thinking and new attitude to deal with challenges the world faces," Lee said.

Although Lee didn't make any direct reference to problems faced by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, his remarks were widely believed to be aimed at reminding mainland Chinese leaders of using new thinking to handle cross-strait disputes or related problems.

Lee, an outspoken critic of mainland China' diplomatic embargo against Taiwan and active advocate of Taiwan's distinctive identity, was forced to give up its plan to attend the current Asian Outlook Forum meeting in person because Beijing had strongly pressured Japan to reject Lee's visit.

The Asian Outlook Forum is a private think tank jointly founded by Taiwan and Japanese academics and business executives 12 years ago to promote substantive Taipei-Tokyo relations during Lee's presidency. As Lee already retired in May this year, the forum has decided to disband after its current meeting.

In his taped opening remarks, Lee expressed his gratitude for all those who have participated in the forum's activities over the past 12 years. "The forum has contributed much to the improvement of mutual understanding between our two countries and the expansion of cultural, economic and academic interchanges," he noted.

More than 250 delegates from Taiwan and Japan are attending the two-day seminar. The ROC delegation is headed by Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Commerce and Industry, while the Japanese mission is led by Masao Kamei. Several scholars from the United States, France and Russia have also been invited to present papers on issues related to Asia-Pacific security and globalization.

Masajuro Shiokawa, a member of the lower house of the Japanese Diet (parliament), said Lee's absence from the meeting reflects the complexity of international relations. Shiokawa highly praised Lee for his achievement in promoting Taiwan's democratization and economic development during his 12-year stint. Shiokawa said he hopes new ROC President Chen Shui-bian will continue strengthening ROC-Japanese ties and cooperation and contributing to peace and stability in Asia. The meeting is scheduled to close Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADERS MEET TO DISCUSS POLITICAL TURMOIL

TEXT.P: Two opposition leaders met Monday to discuss integrating their opposition strength to cope with the political turmoil caused by the Cabinet's halting of construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant.

Accompanied by Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng and Spokesman Jason Hu, KMT Chairman Lien Chan called on People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung, PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi and other high ranking PFP officials.
After the meeting, Hu held a press conference to explain a three-point consensus reached by the two parties. The points of the consensus are as follows:
-- Both sides agree to establish communication channels at chairman, secretary-general and legislative party cadre levels; and
-- Both sides urge those who love Taiwan to unite and make vigorous efforts to turn the tide, with the ultimate goal of preventing anyone from ruining "the Taiwan miracle."

It was the first time Lien and Soong had met since campaigning started for the March 18 presidential election. The two political heavyweights verbally assailed one another during the bitter election battle.
Soong, originally a KMT stalwart and former Taiwan provincial governor, formed the PFP after the election in which he came in a close second to President Chen Shui-bian.

Lien is scheduled to leave Taipei for Chicago Nov. 1 to attend a meeting of the board of directors of the University of Chicago, visit overseas Chinese communities in Chicago and New York, and inspect party affairs of the KMT's overseas offices in the two cities.
Many KMT legislators have suggested that Lien cancel the visit and Hu told reporters that Lien was inclined to call off the U.S. trip, but had not made a final decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MORE FALUN GONG PRACTITIONERS BEATEN TO DEATH

TEXT.P: Three practitioners of Falun Gong were beaten to death in detention center recently, the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said Monday.
The three victims of police brutality were Wang Bing, 47, of Heilongjian; Xie Gueiying, 32, of Anhuei, and Liu Yucai, 60, of Jilin.
At least 62 Falun Gong members have reportedly died in police custody since July, 1999, when the Chinese government outlawed the Falun Gong organization as an "evil cult."
It is apparent to see from the recent deaths of Falun Gong members that the Chinese government has intensified its crackdown on the spiritual movement, the information center added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RELEASE POLITICAL PRISONERS

TEXT.P: The Standing Committee of China's National People's Congress was urged Monday to enact laws to protect human rights and release all political prisoners, a human rights group said.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said Monday that the wives of Wang Yucai and five other founders of the outlawed "China Democracy Party" made the urge jointly in an open letter to the committee. The five CDP founders, who have been sentenced to long prison terms on "subversion" charges, are Wu Yilong, Zhu Zhengming, Mao Qingxiang, Zhu Yufu, and Xu Guang.

Wang Yucai's wife Hu Jiangxia was quoted by the information center as saying Monday that China should respect human rights and release all political prisoners according to the International Covenant on Economic, Social, and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which were signed by Beijing in 1997 and 1998 respectively.

Although it had signed the two international covenants, the Chinese government arrested more than 20 leaders of the first would-be opposition party in China in late 1998, and sentenced several of them to many years in prison on "subversion" charges, the information center added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, MACEDONIA SIGN MEMORANDUM ON MILITARY COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen signed a memorandum on military cooperation with his Macedonian counterpart Ljuben Paunoski in Taipei Monday.

Under the terms of the memorandum -- the first of its kind entered into by the ROC government with a European country -- the two countries agreed to strengthen military cooperation and exchanges based on equality and mutual benefit.
The document-signing ceremony took place at the Defense Ministry, witnessed by ROC Vice Foreign Minister David Lee and Macedonian Minister to Taipei Verka Modanu.
A spokesman for the ROC Defense Ministry said that the memorandum was signed on the principles of observing democracy and rule of law, with respect to human rights and freedom.

The two countries agreed to abide by the principles of international law, to refrain from using and threatening to use military force and to improve mutual understanding and promote world peace, security and stability.
The spokesman said the memorandum will help consolidate friendly relations between the two countries.
Following the signing of the memorandum, the two countries will station military groups in each other's country, step up military cooperation and exchanges and exchange military attaches.
Cooperation projects will be centered on humanitarian, medical, emergency aid and material cooperation in the initial period.
The two countries also agreed to enter close cooperation on military education, military exercises, logistics support and exchanges of military cadets.
Regarding intelligence information cooperation, further discussions will be conducted, according to the spokesman.

The ROC Defense Ministry said that the memorandum will serve as the ROC's window for exploring relations with European countries and added that it will also be instrumental to the promotion of Taiwan's military cooperation with European countries.
Later, the Defense Ministry hosted a dinner in honor of the Macedonian defense minister and other members of his delegation, who arrived in Taipei a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DEFENDS HALT TO 4TH NUCLEAR POWER PLANT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Monday defended the government's decision to halt construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant, saying that the government must make a responsible decision for Taiwan's future generations.

Chen said the controversy surrounding the fourth nuclear power plant has long existed. "We should not leave the difficult problem to our future generations and should instead make the right choice for them. This is a sacred mission," the president said, adding that he hopes local people can face the issue calmly and rationally.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with the Republic of China delegations to the just-concluded Asian mathematics and physics competitions and the 2000 international natural science and information technology Olympics contests.

Chen's call was seen part of his efforts to calm the outrageous backlash from opposition parties over the Cabinet's abrupt announcement of its decision to halt construction of the partially completed fourth nuclear power plant.

While major opposition parties have been discussing joint strategies to fight against the Chen administration's decision to scrap the nuclear power plant project, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh threw his support behind the decision to halt construction of the plant.
"I think it's a good decision," said Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry.

The island's foremost scholar further said unless Taiwan has the capability to treat radioactive waste from nuclear power plants, it should not continue to build any new nuclear power plants. "Every time I see the Orchid Island, where radioactive waste from Taiwan's three nuclear power plants has been stored, I feel sorry," he added.

Lee said many Western countries have endeavored to seek effective ways to save energy and cut the demand for electricity after the energy crisis in the 1970s. Regrettably, Lee said, Taiwan didn't do so.

As many traditional energy-consuming industries have moved abroad, Lee said, Taiwan's demand for electricity has declined. Against this backdrop, he said, it is understandable and reasonable for the new ROC government to halt construction of an additional nuclear power plant.

Meanwhile, Frank Hsieh, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said the party is willing to modestly accept criticism from opposition parties concerning its handling of the nuclear power plant issue.

"Nevertheless, we hope opposition parties will stop their moves to promote a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet or a recall of the president to add to domestic political instability," Hsieh said, adding: "The nuclear power plant controversy is basically a public policy issue, we have better leave it to be judged by the general public."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Opposition leaders agree to forge regular dialogue channels.
The China Times:
Proposal to recall President Chen receives enough endorsements from opposition lawmakers.
The United Daily News:
KMT Chairman Lien Chan meets opposition party leaders James Soong and Hao Lung-pin.
The Liberty Times:
President Chen will respect legislature's decision on whether to continue or halt construction of the fourth nuclear power plant.
The China Post:
President Chen takes charge of government.
The Taiwan News:
Lien visits Soong, hitting back at Chen.
The Taipei Times:
KMT moves to impeach the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 114.9 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 114.9 points to close at 5,544.18.
Market turnover amounted to 64.7 billion (US$2 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 31, or the fifth day of the tenth month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Martin Luther nails his 95 theses against papal corruption in Rome to the church door in Wittenberg.
1887: Chiang Kai-shek, the late president of the Republic of China, is born at Hsikou in Fenghua County, Chekiang Province.
1916: General Huang Hsin, leader of the Revolution that overthrew the Ching dynasty, dies in Shanghai at the age of 43.
1947: The United Nations sets aside Oct. 24 as "United Nations Day."
1952: The China Youth Corps is organized with Chiang Ching-kuo serving as director.
1957: Tsung Dao Lee and Chen Ning Yang share the Nobel Prize for Physics for work disproving the law of conservation of parity.
1958: Nobel Prize winning author Boris Pasternak is expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union and faces possible exile for his "Dr. Zhivago."
1966: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Lesotho.
1971: China Television Service, the third commercial TV network in the Republic of China, begins regular programming.
1972: The Southern Cross-Island Highway, which took four-and-a-half years to build at a cost of nearly NT$500 million, is opened to traffic.
1974: People throughout the Republic of China celebrate the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1974: Alfred Jenkin, former deputy director of the U.S. Liaison Office in Peiping, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan addresses leaders gathered to pay tribute to President Chiang Kai-shek on the late leader's 90th birthday, then breaks ground for the Chung Cheng Memorial Hall to honor President Chiang.
1976: Taichung port in west central Taiwan is formally opened.
1978: The Taiwan Area Freeway, with a total length of 377 km, is fully opened to traffic on the 92nd anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1978: The Sino-Saudi Arabian Bridge over the Choshui River in central Taiwan, which was built with low-interest loans from Saudi Arabia, opens to traffic as a part of the newly completed North-South Freeway.
1979: The government holds a rally honoring the late President Chiang Kai-shek's 93rd birthday at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
1979: Representatives of retired servicemen meet at the Taipei City Auditorium to mark the first Veterans Day, also marking the 25th anniversary of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen.
1981: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives J.A. Guevara Moran, the minister of agriculture and pasture of the Republic of El Salvador.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old MiG-19 pilot in the Communist Chinese air force who flew to a U.S. military base outside Seoul on Oct. 16, arrives in Taipei.
1983: Taipei's Kuantu Bridge, the first multi-arch steel bridge in East Asia, opens to traffic. The construction of the bridge, 809 meters long, took three years and cost NT$700 million to complete.
1984: Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Indian prime minister, is shot dead as she walks in the garden of her home in New Delhi. She was 67.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek presides over and addresses a mass rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to mark the 100th birthday of the late President Chiang.
1996: Former Polish President Lech Walesa visits the Republic of China.
1999: A delegation from the Taiwan Roots Medical Organization leaves for a visit to four African countries to evaluate the possibility of providing medical care to one of them.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "If you will practice a benevolent government, then the people will love all above them, and will die for their officers."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 114.9 points to close at 5,544.18.

Affected by the political tensions caused by the confrontation between Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties, the bourse opened at 5,530.8 and continued to go down despite purchases made by government funds. The bourse fluctuated between 5,626.03 and 5,502.67 during trading.

A total of 1.83 billion stocks worth NT$64.7 billion (US$2 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 0.56 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$12.93 billion (US$0.4 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 2.7 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues and electrical stocks, both at 2.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 2 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.9 percent, textile issues at 1.8 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 485 to 70, with 43 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: N-POWER PLANT CANCELLATION SAID TO AFFECT U.S. INVESTMENT IN ROC
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A U.S. political heavyweight has said Taiwan's decision to halt construction of its fourth nuclear power plant will affect U.S. interest in bidding for the island's infrastructure projects, a visiting ROC lawmaker said here Monday.

Hung Tu, an opposition Kuomintang legislator, said although the U.S. government has repeatedly reaffirmed its non-interference stance on Taiwan's nuclear power plant issue, some U.S. political observers have expressed concern about the island's recent political situation.

Hung had visited Washington, D.C. and New York before arriving in San Francisco on his way back to Taipei. During his stay in the two U.S. major cities, Hung had met with Richard Bush, the top U.S. liaison officer with the Republic of China in the absence of official ties, and several noted American China hands.

Hung quoted an unidentified influential American as having said that Taiwan's decision to scrap the partially completed nuclear power plant project would reduce its own appeal to attract U.S. businesses to participate in the island's infrastructure construction projects in the future.
Hung said as his talks with the U.S. heavyweight were confidential, he couldn't divulge the identity of the American friend.

Hung instead said he had held talks with researchers with many noted U.S. think tanks, including the Peace Research Institute, the Heritage Foundation and the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, during his visits to Washington and New York.

"Many of the U.S. experts in affairs related cross-Taiwan Strait ties have not hidden their concern and worry about Taiwan's recent political and economic situation, particularly the Democratic Progressive Party-led government's handling of the nuclear power plant issue and its possible impact," Hung added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATION MARKS ANNIVERSARY OF GENERALISSIMO CHIANG'S BIRTH
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan County, Taiwan, Oct. 31 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, citing the need to attend to "matters of grave national concern," appointed his deputy secretary-general to pay tribute to the resting place of late President Chiang Kai-shek on his behalf Tuesday on the 114th anniversary of Chiang's birth.

Eugene Chien said that Chen had originally intended to follow the tradition of paying homage in person to the late leader at his mausoleum in Tzuhu in the northern Taiwan county of Taoyuan, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei.

However, Chien went on to say that the president was held up by matters requiring his immediate attention and therefore decided at the last moment during the previous evening to have Chien take his place.

Majority opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, and hundreds of veterans as well as people from all walks of life also paid their respects to the memory of Chiang, whose notable achievements included leading the eight-year War of Resistance against Japan from 1937 through 1945.

Chiang was also noted for his role in assisting neighboring Asian countries establish independent republics, fostering the establishment of the United Nations -- of which the Republic of China was a founding member -- and building Taiwan into an anti-communist stronghold.

Similar memorial services and commemorative activities were also held in other cities and counties around the island in memory of Generalissimo Chiang, who served as ROC president until his passing in 1975.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP PITCHES FOR SPONSORSHIP OF LATIN AMERICAN CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday she will launch a campaign to encourage local people to sponsor at least 10,000 impoverished children in Latin America.
Lu unveiled the plan while accompanying ambassadors or representatives of eight Central American countries on a visit to the Taichung branch of the Chinese Fund for Children and Families.
She said many local charity groups and individuals have sponsored and helped take care of child victims of a devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999.
"We hope this kind of benevolent activity will transcend national borders," Lu said, adding that many impoverished children in the Republic of China's Central American allies need care and help.
Lu said she is scheduled to launch her Central American impoverished children sponsorship campaign on World Children's Day, which falls on Nov. 20.

"Through the program, we can express our gratitude for all the support rendered by our Central American allies over the years," Lu said, adding that she believes the sponsorship program will also help Taiwan win more friendship and recognition in the international community.
Lu said sponsoring impoverished children can help change their future, which will in turn benefit all mankind.

The eight Central American allies whose impoverished children will benefit from the sponsorship program are Honduras, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Panama, Nicaragua, the Dominican Republic, Belize and Guatemala.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATOR SOLICITS MORE SUPPORT FOR RECALL OF PRESIDENT PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the opposition Kuomintang said Tuesday that he is continuing to solicit more support for his proposal to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

Ting said at noon that 123 legislators had already signed their names supporting the move to recall the president, adding that he is hoping to be able to gather the necessary two thirds of legislators to have the proposal stand.

Ting said that the dismissal of a president is a matter that requires extreme prudence and that he will take public opinion and other measures proposed by the opposition parties into consideration before submitting the proposal.

The recall proposal will stand if it is co-signed by one fourth of the legislators (55 seats) and agreed upon by two thirds of the legislators (147 seats), meaning that if all the legislators of the three major opposition parties, the KMT, PFP, and NP, support the motion, they will still have to solicit the support of six or seven more legislators to make the proposal stand.

In the 220-seat Legislative Yuan, the opposition Kuomintang dominates with 115 seats, compared with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's 67 seats. The opposition People First Party has 17 seats, the New Party nine seats, the National Non-Party League seven seats, and independents five seats.
Meanwhile, to try to preempt the possible recall proposal, legislators of the ruling DPP called for unity within the party.
Hsu Tain-tsair, DPP party whip, said that there is still some time before the opposition parties possibly submit recall proposals and that "the situation is still developing."
Hsu urged the opposition parties to "think twice" before making such a move, stressing that the party will do everything to meet its top priority of maintaining "political stability."

DPP legislator Chou Po-lun said that the fourth nuclear power plant is no longer the focus and that the urgent task now is to form a task force to deal with the crisis and to solicit the support of "anti-power forces" in the opposition camp.
Hsu said that while the opposition parties are in a state of euphoria over their unprecedented unity, the DPP will now unite behind the "ultimate goal" of political stability.

The latest political storm was unleashed when the Cabinet abruptly announced the halting of construction on the fourth nuclear power plant last Friday shortly after a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and KMT Chairman Lien during which the president promised to give more thought to the project.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-NUCLEAR ACTIVISTS TO SEEK RECALL OF PRO-NUCLEAR LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: Anti-nuclear activists and the Green Party announced Tuesday that they will take the initiative in moving to recall pro-nuclear legislators who in turn have begun to explore the possibility of recalling Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian.

In the latest twist to the controversy that began last Friday with the Cabinet's sudden announcement to scrap the fourth nuclear power plant project, the committee of anti-nuclear activists stated at a press conference that they will make the move to recall the opposition Kuomintang legislators "at the appropriate moment."
They added that they hope the legislators will meditate over their actions and rescind their proposal to recall the president.
Green Party central committee member Kao Cheng-yen criticized the legislators for being "bent on having their own way" without regard for public opinion.

Residents of Kungliao Township in Taipei County, where the nuclear plant stands 33 percent completed, said at the conference that they are "saddened" by the legislators who are clinging willfully to their course when the residents had finally received some good news after rallying against the plant's construction for the past 20 years.
They urged the pro-nuclear legislators to follow their conscience and stop letting the "bad dream" of nuclear power continue to endanger the future generations.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION HEAD BRUSHES ASIDE ROC PRESIDENT'S PATCH-UP GESTURE

TEXT.P: The head of Taiwan's majority opposition party on Tuesday brushed aside a patch-up gesture by Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian over a nuclear power plant controversy.
Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said, "There is no need for Chen to send a representative to see me or to visit in person to give his regards."
Leading a delegation to pay tribute to the resting place of late President Chiang Kai-shek on the 114th anniversary of Chiang's birth, Lien urged Chen not to "revolve around formalities."

Lien added that he would not be upset by Chen's gesture, whether it was an "arrangement with intentionally or unintentionally humiliating overtones," because he is only concerned about what the government is doing to ensure national stability and development.

Lien went on to criticize the government by saying that many people "screwed on new heads" after taking up new positions of power and now refuse to even admit that they are both Taiwanese and Chinese -- an apparent reference to Chen of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Later in the day, Lien also pointed to Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, a former KMT member who was expelled from the party for embracing the administration's anti-nuclear stance, as another example of the kind of people he said he scorns. He criticized Lin for appearing in a anti-nuclear television commercial while claiming to be a member of the KMT, which is traditionally pro-nuclear.

Opposition parties have been locked in battle with the ruling DPP government -- even going as far as rallying to recall the president -- since the Cabinet sprung a surprise on the nation last Friday by announcing that it was pulling the plug on the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project.
The announcement came hot on the heels of what was supposed to be a fence-mending meeting between Chen and Lien in which Chen had just promised to give careful thought to the nuclear plant issue.

Earlier in the day, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung explained at the Legislative Yuan that the Cabinet had "absolutely no intention" of being disrespectful to Lien and that if it came across that way, then he was willing to say sorry.

KMT Secretary General Lin Feng-cheng also accused the government of merely "putting on a show" when Presidential Secretary General Yu Shyi-kun earlier in the day proposed visiting Lin in order to convey the president's message and to work out the details for Chen to visit Lien in person.
KMT Spokesman Jason Hu also urged the president to keep his mind on policy-making instead of on showmanship.

Meanwhile, in order to keep up on events at this critical juncture following the controversy kindled by last week's Cabinet announcement, Lien has decided not to attend a meeting of the University of Chicago board of trustees, of which he is the only member without U.S. citizenship.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA YOUTH CORPS CHANGES OFFICIAL DESIGNATION

TEXT.P: The non-government, non-profit China Youth Corps (CYC) changed its Mandarin name Tuesday and dropped the words "anti-communism" from its official designation as a result of a change in world trends, according to CYC sources.
The CYC's goals of endeavors, however, remain unchanged, said President Jeanne Tchong-koei Li.

The name-change coincided with the organization's 48th founding anniversary. It was founded in 1952 by the late President Chiang Ching-kuo when Chiang was a young official in charge of youth affairs in the Republic of China.

Addressing a ceremony to mark the anniversary, Li said people had begun to question the appropriateness of CYC's "anti-communism" designation as early as 1987 when then-President Chiang allowed Taiwan residents to visit relatives in mainland China for the first time.

However, the issue was not addressed until early this year, when ex-CYC Vice President Hsieh You-hua motioned for the words "anti-communism" to be scrapped once and for all as cross-strait relations and the world situation had drastically changed, Li noted.
Li said that it took 334 rounds of meetings for CYC management to decide to formally change the official designation.

Meanwhile, parts of CYC's anthem were also changed for some less ideological lyrics, with terms such as "anti-aggression and anti-ferocity" changed to "having ideals and goals," and "obeying the leadership of the president" changed to "devoting our best," Li added.

In Tuesday's ceremony, 4,133 CYC volunteers from all over the world were cited for their unselfish devotion to voluntary work. A total of 86 representatives attended in person to receive the citations.

Aimed at guiding youth in their growth and development through various activities, CYC holds lectures and seminars to educate youth, in addition to providing a counseling hotline. Its most popular activities are outdoor recreational programs during summer and winter vacations, designed for teenagers and young adults.

The organization also sponsors youth goodwill missions to various destinations around the world, seeking to broaden young people's horizons. Since 1992, the CYC has organized youth cultural and educational exchanges with mainland China. Between 1998 and 1999, 615 ROC youths traveled to the mainland in 20 CYC groups, and 507 young mainlanders came to visit Taiwan.

Young Chinese who were born overseas and foreign youths are not excluded from CYC programs. During summer vacations, youths of Chinese descent can come to Taiwan to learn the Chinese language, culture, and customs. In addition, groups of young foreigners are invited to Taiwan each year for cultural and academic exchanges with their Taiwan counterparts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP, NEW PARTY MEETING REACHES 3-POINT CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: The leaders of two of Taiwan's opposition parties reached a three-point consensus Tuesday on promoting inter-party cooperation to help maintain domestic political stability.

People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong and Hao Lung-pin, convener of the New Party's National Campaign and Development Committee issued a joint statement on their consensus after a 40-minute closed-door meeting.
The statement said the two parties agree to establish a dialogue mechanism for the country's opposition parties to reflect mainstream public opinion.

The tiny New Party will organize a roundtable meeting of the leaders of the three opposition parties -- the New Party, the PFP and the Kuomintang -- next week to discuss strategies to cope with the domestic political situation in the wake of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government's decision to halt construction of the partially completed fourth nuclear power plant.

The statement further said the New Party and the PFP agree to forsake partisan biases and give top priority to national interests and stability. "And we'll use this principle as a basis to establish various levels of inter-party communication channels," the statement added.
Meanwhile, the two parties agreed to cooperate closely with the main opposition KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20 and still controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan or parliament.

Hao said the three parties will promote the passage of bills helpful to domestic political, economic and judicial reforms and fulfill their duty of providing a system of checks and balances against the ruling DPP.
The Soong-Hao consensus on opposition party cooperation was expected to receive KMT support, as KMT Chairman Lien Chan made similar appeals during separate meetings with Soong and Hau a day earlier.

The unprecedented reconciliation among the three opposition parties was prompted by their wrath at the DPP government's abrupt announcement of its decision to halt construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant last Friday. The plant, launched during KMT rule, is about one-third complete.

Lawmakers of the three opposition parties have joined forces to push for the dismissal of President Chen Shui-bian over the scrapping of the controversial project. Chen beat Soong and Lien in the March 18 presidential election.

The dismissal motion may stand a chance of passing the legislative floor, as the three opposition parties jointly control 141 seats in the 220-member legislature. The ruling DPP holds only 67 seats in the parliament.
